taxonomicNotes: Appeared on IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic name Hieremys.
Known from the type specimen only.
Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001).

Seven subspecies are generally accepted (TTWG 2017):

Malaclemys terrapin terrapin (Schoepff, 1793) - Northern Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin centrata (Latreille in Sonnini and Latreille, 1801) - Carolina Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin littoralis Hay, 1905 - Texas Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin macrospilota Hay, 1905 - Ornate Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin pileata (Wied, 1865) - Mississippi Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin rhizophorarum Fowler, 1906 - Mangrove Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin tequesta Schwartz, 1955 - Eastern Florida Diamondback Terrapin

These subspecific designations of terrapins were based on morphological characteristics (Carr 1952). However, molecular studies indicate that the morphological subspecific designations do not match well with the range-wide genetic differentiation, suggesting fewer independent lineages. Lamb and Avise (1992) first suggested two subpopulations that diverged near Jacksonville, Florida. More recent work using microsatellites suggested that five genetically distinct terrapin management units exist throughout the range (Hart et al. 2014). One unfortunate consequence of the previous heavy trade and farming of terrapins was the transport of individuals among populations, and the genetic signature of those translocations can still be detected today (Hauswaldt and Glen 2005; Converse et al. 2017; Converse and Kuchta 2018). A more thorough range-wide molecular study using more populations and loci is sorely needed to resolve the phylogenetic relationships and update the taxonomy of Malaclemys.

Lindholm (1929) recognized Testudo tornieri Siebenrock, 1903 as the type of a new genus, for which he established the name Malacochersus. The genus is monotypic, with only one species currently recognized. Genetic studies have demonstrated that Malacochersus is most closely related to Asian Indotestudo and Eurasian Testudo (Le et al. 2006; Parham et al. 2006; Fritz and Bininda-Emonds 2007). Phylogeographic studies of the species have not yet been realized, but are clearly needed in view of its disjunct distribution. Vernacular names used for the species in East African Kiswahili are Kobe ya Mawe and Kobe kama Chapati.

Six or seven subspecies are widely recognised: Melanochelys trijuga trijuga (Schweigger, 1812); M. t. coronata (Anderson, 1879); M. t. edeniana (Theobald, 1876); M. t. indopeninsularis (Annandale ,1913); M. t. parkeri (Deraniyagala, 1939); M. t. thermalis (Lesson, 1830). Subspecies wiroti (Reimann in Nutaphand, 1979) was synonymized with M. t. edeniana. The colour and size is considered as criteria for subspecies differentiation (Deraniyagala 1939, Das 1995, Das and Bhupathy 2009). The head of M. trijuga thermalis is highly ornamented with either red, orange, or yellow spots or blotches. During a study of 76 live M. t. thermalis from 19 different localities in Sri Lanka a high percentage (76.%) of specimens had orange, red, yellow and brown patches on the head. Head ornamentation was common and distinct in young (Abeysekera et al. 2015).

There are many Sinhala names for the species which vary according to the province. However, the widely used name is the Gal Ibbā, (= rock terrapin). The others are Goo Ibbā (= ordure terrapin), Diya kukula (= water fowl), Thumba Ibbā (= small terrapin), valan Ibbā (= pot terrapin) and mada kakkutta (= mud crab). In Tamil it is known as Karuppu Amai (= Black terrapin), Kal amai (= rock terrapin), Pee amai (= ordure terrapin), Tanni amai (= water terrapin).

The Natrix natrix complex has long been treated as a single widespread species throughout Europe and temperate Asia. Numerous subspecies have traditionally been recognized; recent molecular evidence indicates that most of these are not supported genetically (Speybroeck et al. 2016), including the formerly recognized species Natrrix megalocephala, but that the grass snake forms three geographically discrete clusters, each of which has recently been recognized as distinct species: Natrix astreptophora (Iberia) (Porkrant et al. 2016), N. helvetica (northern and central Europe) (Kindler et al. 2017) and N. natrix. The taxonomy of grass snakes east of the range of N. helvetica, still included within N. natrix, remains unresolved.
Generally considered to consist of at least two morphologically distinguishable lineages.

There are three subspecies: the nominate, Eryx jaculus jaculus (Linnaeus, 1758), E. j. turcicus (Olivier, 1801) and E. j. familiaris Eichwald, 1831; the latter inhabits territory of Dagestan and the Transcaucasian Region.

This species, formerly in the paraphyletic genus Laudakia, was assigned as the type (and presently sole) species of the new genus Stellagama by Baig et al. (2012). While this wide-ranging lizard, which presently has seven recognized subspecies (although this number varies according to different authors), is considered likely to be a species complex, "more extensive work is still required before splitting the S. stellio complex" (Baig et al. 2012), as most work to date has been morphological and genetic research is needed to clarify divisions in this taxon (Baig et al. 2012). S. stellio daani was previously synonymized with the nominate form, but its distinctiveness was recognized by Almog et al. (2005), and it is considered a distinct subspecies in the review of Laudakia conducted by Baig et al. (2012).
Speybroeck et al. (2020) acknowledge that this arrangement has been widely adopted, but prefer to retain the name Laudakia stellio pending "substantial evidence" to reject monophyly of Laudakia.

Preliminary data on the phylogeography of the species based on mtDNA sequences identified several independent evolutionary lineages (Joger et al. 2003, Carlsson et al. 2004, Ursenbacher et al. 2006). Based on molecular evidence, Vipera nikolskii represents a subspecific lineage of V. berus, with some evidence of hybridization between the two taxa in natural populations (Milto and Zinenko 2005, Zinenko et al. 2010).

Vipera sachalinensis, another taxon sometimes considered a full species, is included within the V. berus complex by Kalyabina-Hauf et al. (2004) and Joger et al. (2007). Similarly, V. barani should also be included in V. berus based on a recent integrative evaluation (Freitas et al. 2020). Finally, the populations of the western Alps in Italy are considered as another species V. walser based on genetic information (Ghielmi et al. 2016).

Based on a fragment of mitochondrial DNA and two nuclear protein-coding loci Gvoždic et al. (2010) suggested that Anguis fragilis is a species complex comprised of at least four species in Europe. Gvoždík et al. (2013) subsequently split A. fragilis into five species on genetic grounds. This arrangement has been accepted (Speybroeck et al. 2016), although morphological differences remain to be fully characterized (Uetz et al. 2019).

The nominate subspecies Phrynocephalus mystaceus mystaceus is found in Europe, ranging as far east as the Volga River sands inclusive. 
Wide mtDNA sampling of this species across its range suggests that two deeply divergent clades exist, one isolated in the Khorasan region of northeastern Iran and the other in the remainder of its Middle Asian range, a pattern previously found with more limited sampling using other genetic markers (Solovyeva et al. 2018). Solovyeva et al. (2018) "tentatively" elect to describe the Khorasan lineage as a subspecies, P. m. khorasanus, rather than a full species due to weak morphological differentiation from populations elsewhere and the existence of both morphologically and genetically intermediate populations in the Caspian and Middle Asian regions. At the same time, this work found that the two previously recognized subspecies - P. m. galli and P. m. aurantiacocaudatus - are not supported by either mtDNA or morphological data. Solovyeva et al. (2020) consequently synonymized them with the nominate form, while recommending further research to clarify the claimed morphological distinctiveness of the latter (based on characters they were unable to examine in preserved material).
Eastern populations of Malpolon formerly allocated to M. monspessulanus are now included within M. insignatus following Carranza et al. (2006).

Six genetically and geographically distinct lineages have been identified in Natrix tessellata, and some or all of these may warrant specific recognition following further research (Guiking et al. 2004).

There are six recognized subspecies: Eremias arguta arguta (Pallas, 1773) is distributed in Kazakhstan; E a. deserti (Gmelin, 1789) is found in the west of the species range from the Ural River in the west to the eastern parts of the North Caucasus in the southwest (this subspecies is present in Romania, Moldova and Ukraine); E. a. transcaucasica Darevsky, 1953 inhabits eastern parts of Transcaucasia; E. a. uzbekistanica Chernov, 1934 is present in Uzbekistan and the frontier regions of Turkmenistan, southern Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan; E. a. darevskii Tsaruk, 1986 is restricted to the Issyk Kul Depression in Kyrgyzstan; E. a. potanini Bedrjaga, 1912 is found in the area adjacent to Balkhash Lake and the Zaisan Depression in Kazakhstan. mtDNA results provide no justification for recognizing this latter form as distinct, and Poyarkov et al. (2014) indicate that this should be considered a junior synonym of the nominate subspecies. An unnamed form within from the Ili River Valley has been found to be distinct both genetically and morphologically (Orlova et al. 2012, Poyarkov et al. 2014), being sister to all other E. arguta, and may represent an undescribed species (Poyarkov et al. 2014).

This species was previously included in the genus Ophisaurus. Glass lizards from the Balkan Peninsula and southern coast of the Crimea are considered as a subspecies Pseudopus apodus thracius (Obst, 1978). The nominate subspecies, P. a. apodus is distributed Southeastern Europe, Ciscaucasia and Transcaucasia, southern Turkmenistan, eastern Uzbekistan, western Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and southeastern Kazakhstan.
This taxon was raised to species rank on the basis of a large genetic divergence from Elaphe quatuorlineata and clear morphological differences (Lenk et al. 2001).
This species is included in Dolichophis following Nagy et al. (2004), rather than Hierophis.

This species is within the subgenus Pelias according to Nilson et al. (1999) and was formerly treated as a synonym subspecies of Vipera ursinii. The results of Joger and Stumpel (2005) restricted Vipera ursinii on the group of the remnant, disjunct, populations of Europe west of Ukraine (Nilson and Andren 2001, Joger and Stumpel 2005, Ferchaud et al. 2012, Zinenko et al. 2015) and defined V. renardi as a valid species. V. renardi s.l. includes five subspecies: the nominate V. r. renardi (occupies the most part of the distribution range, except for some Central- and Middle Asian populations); V. r. tienshanica Nilson and Andrén, 2001 (Kyrgyzstan, eastern Uzbekistan, northern Tajikistan and south-eastern Kazakhstan), V. r. parursinii Nilson & Andrén, 2001 (found in northern Xinjiang-Uyghur Autonomous Region in China), V. r. puzanovi Kukushkin, 2009 (found in southern Ukraine in Crimea and western part of country) and V. r. bashkirovi Garanin, Pavlov & Bakiev, 2004 (Tatarstan in Russian Federation). Taxonomic issues are likely to remain, particularly in the correct delimitation of range limits between V. r. renardi and V. r. pustanovi. Additionally, within V. renardi distribution range there is a number of previously described species which are currently viewed as questionable or invalid (for more clarification of certain cases see in Ferchaud et al. (2012), Zinenko et al. (2015) and/or Freitas et al. 2020): Vipera altaica Tuniyev, Nilson & Andrén, 2010; Vipera eriwanensis (Reuss, 1933) from Lesser Caucasus and Eastern Turkey with synonym Vipera shemakhensis (Tuniyev et al. 2013) from Azerbaijan; Vipera ebneri Knőpfler & Sochurek, 1955 from Iran (Zinenko et al. 201,; Freitas et al. 2020); paraphyletic lineages of Vipera lotievi Nilson et al., 1995 from East Caucasus. Taxonomic relations within V. renardi or maybe V. renardi complex require more research (for example, North Caucasian populations traditionally referred to V. lotievi recently are recognized as basal lineages of V. renardi (Zinenko et al. 2015). Also, the taxonomic status of the populations from the Kazakh Altai remains unclear.

This species exhibits close similarities to Eryx tataricus, and the two are difficult to distinguish (Ezkandarzadeh et al. 2013). Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) attribute records of E. tataricus from Khorasan Province in northeastern Iran to E. miliaris (also see Mohammad et al. 2017). The distribution of the two taxa elsewhere is in need of clarification: Zhao and Adler (1993) provide a "composite range" for the complex in China as the separate ranges of the two taxa in this country cannot be identified. Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) outline the distribution of both species and report both from Mongolia, however Zhao and Adler (1993) and Terbish et al. (2006) consider that only E. tataricus occurs in this country. Cryptic species may exist within the E. miliaris-tataricus complex, based on the finding by Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) that two Iranian specimens (to which they applied the name Eryx cf. miliaris) could not confidently be referred to this taxon. In the northwestern (Russian) part of its range, the subspecies E. m. nogaiorum is recognized; however recent phylogenetic research implies that this population must be considered invalid (Eskandarzadeh et al. 2020).  The same study suggests that E. tataricus represents a junior synonym of E. miliaris (Eskandarzadeh et al. 2020), but this account retains it as valid pending further research to confirm this assignment given the complex taxonomic history of these names and the need for wider sampling outside Iran.

The name Coluber tyria Linnaeus, 1758 has been proposed as a putative senior synonym of Coluber nummifer and Schätti and Tillack (2010) applied to the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature to suppress this name to preserve the stability of the widely-used specific name nummifer.

Chamaeleo calcaricarens has variously been treated as a full species or as a subspecies of C. africanus. Largen and Spawls (2006) examined records attributed to both species, and found that the only available diagnostic character is unreliable, and restricted to males. These authors synonymized C. calcaricarens with C. africanus, and while acknowledging that C. africanus so defined may represent a species complex, argued that treating C. calcaricarens as a valid species on the basis of existing diagnostic characters would make it difficult or impossible to attribute many Ethiopian records to either form with certainty. C. calcaricarens was nonetheless accepted as a valid species without comment by Tilbury and Tolley (2009); Tilbury (2010) indicated that hemipenal morphology reliably diagnosed the two species, and formally resurrected that species. Tilbury (2010) did not consider C. africanus as ranging into the Horn of Africa, but the basis for this is unclear. This action is supported by evidence from a recent molecular phylogeny of the Chamaeleonidae that C. africanus from Niger and C. calcaricarens from Borama in Somalia are distinct at the species level (Tolley et al. 2013). Trape et al. (2012) apparently overlooked the resurrection of C. calcaricarens in describing C. africanus as ranging east as far as Somalia.
The validity of subspecies described from western Siberia and the Altai region, E. d. niger Golubeva, 1923 and E. d. tenebrosa Sobolevsky, 1929, is disputed.

The specific status of Phrynocephalus melanurus has until recently been uncertain. This taxon has often been treated as a distinct species (e.g. Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008), but it is considered a junior synonym of P. guttatus salenskyi by Mezhzherin and Golubev (1993) and as a subspecies of P. guttatus (Phrynocephalus guttatus ssp. melanurus Eichwald, 1831) by Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007), and this is how the taxon is treated currently by The Reptile Database (Uetz et al. 2021).

Dunayev (2009) upheld the distinctness of P. melanurus on biogeographical grounds, and recognized populations from the northern and southeastern parts of the Aral Sea region as P. g. moltschanovi, from the south Balkhash Lake region and Alakol Depression as P. kuschakewitschi, and from the Ili River Depression as P. g. alpherakii. Solovyeva et al. (2014) later investigated the genetics of this species complex, and supported the recognition of P. alpherakii and P. moltschanovoi  - as well as P. melanurus - as distinct species. P. melanurus is provisionally treated here as a distinct valid species.

Populations from Kazakhstan previously assigned to P. versicolor, as well as those from Siberia and northern Mongolia previously described as the subspecies P. v. kulagini, are referable to P. guttatus (Wang and Fu 2004, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).
This species is in need of major taxonomic revision.

The systematics of this species are extremely complicated due to the lack of comprehensive molecular treatments of the genus, as morphological differences between this species and Gloydius intermedius are minor (Sindaco et al. 2013). This was summarized by Wagner et al. (2016), who described Gloydius rickmersi from previously unnamed populations within this group, and remains unresolved.

The nominate G. h. halys inhabits the eastern part of the species range; G. h. caraganus is found in western areas including Kazakhstan and Middle Asia; G. h. caucasicus is distributed in Azerbaijan, northern Iran and northwestern Afghanistan. Isolated populations found in the eastern part of the species' range, including China, have been assigned to the subspecies G. h. cognatus and G. h. stejnegeri, however, the species was not recognized as occurring in China by specialists attending an assessment workshop in 2010, and Chinese populations - as well as those attributed to G. h. caucasicus - have previously been included within G. intermedius (Gloyd and Conant 1989). More recently, all subspecies have been elevated to species status (Shi et al. 2016, Shi et al. 2017, Asadi et al. 2019) and therefore the G. halys complex will need to be reassessed in the future.
Chalcides ocellatus is closely related to Chalcides colosii, which previously treated as a subspecies of the former (Schleich et al. 1996).

There are three subspecies: Coronella austriaca austriaca is present over most of the species range; C. a. fitzingeri (Bonaparte, 1840) inhabits the southern part of the Italian Peninsula and the island Sicily; C. a. acutirostris Malkus, 1995, has been erected for the populations of the north-western Iberian Peninsula. The results of an mtDNA phylogeographic study of this species suggests that, despite the lack of consistent morphological variation across the range, the current taxonomy "does not reflect the rich genetic diversity, deep divergences, and overall evolutionary history" of smooth snakes, and highlights the need for a full taxonomic revision of this species complex (Jablonski et al. 2019).

Simotes semicinctus was described in the 19th Century from a specimen with the locality data "probably Borneo", and was never subsequently rediscovered (Tillack et al. 2008). Wallach and Bauer (1996), accepting this uncertain locality data, referred this species to the Southeast Asian genus Oligodon. Tillack et al. (2008), however, examined this specimen in detail and concluded that it is not referable to Oligodon. Considering the locality data unreliable and comparing the specimen with snakes globally, these authors reached the unexpected conclusion that S. semicinctus is a junior synonym of Coronella austriaca. The Borneo locality must consequently be considered in error, as has been found with other specimens from the same collection (Tillack et al. 2008).
This species is included in Hemorrhois, rather than Coluber, following Nagy et al. (2004). It appears to be paraphyletic (Schätti and Utiger 2001).

Records of this species from Pakistan, reported at least as recently as Khan (1999), refer to Eremias persica, previously a subspecies of E. velox (Baig and Masroor 2006). Four subspecies are presently recognized, E. v. borkini, E. v. caucasica and E. v. roborowskii in addition to the nominate form.
This species is included in Dolichophis following Nagy et al. (2004), rather than Hierophis.

Six subspecies are generally recognized, Macrovipera lebetina lebetina from the island of Cyprus; M. l. obtusa (Dwigubsky, 1832) from Turkey, Iraq, western Iran, Syria, Lebanon, and isolated populations in eastern Transcaucasia (Dagestan); M. l. euphratica (Martin, 1838) from Iraq; M. l. transmediterranea (Nilson & Andrén, 1988) from North Africa; M. l. turanica (Chernov, 1940) from southern Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan; and M. l. cernovi (Chikin & Szczerbak, 1992) recorded in Afghanistan, Pakistan, eastern Iran, Turkmenistan and western Uzbekistan. The subspecies Macrovipera l. transmediterranea was described based on isolated records with nonspecific locality data in Algeria and Tunisia. These North Africa records appear to be based on old specimens without precise or collection localities, and their occurrence has never been confirmed (Sindaco et al. 2013). Sindaco et al. (2013) indicate that the diagnostic characters described for this subspecies fall within the range described for Daboia mauretanica, and recommend that its validity be considered doubtful unless new material is found. It can occur from sea level up to 2,500 m asl. Additionally, successful hybridization between endemic Macrovipera schweizerii from Milos and adjacent islands reported in Kamelin et al. (1997) and results of recent comprehensive molecular and morphological study of Freitas et al. (2020) open some doubts about the taxonomic position of the Milos Viper.

The populations found in southern Afghanistan, (Kashmir) and northern India are sometimes referred to as a separate subspecies: M. l. peilei. These normally have semidivided supraoculars (Mallow et al. 2003). Listed as Vipera lebetina obtusa in Leviton et al. (1992) Macrovipera lebetina deserti, V. l. mauritanica have been elevated to full species status. According to molecular studies (Herrmann et al. 1999), Macrovipera lebetina is paraphyletic with respect to Vipera and Pseudocerastes, and Eristicophis. Macrovipera lebetina peilei is not recognized as subspecies by Golay et al. (1993) and Mcdiarmid et al. (1999). Golay et al. (1993) lists peilei as a synonym of obtusa. Kaiser et al. (2013) considered the generic name Laidlawus Hoser, 2012 invalid and rejected its use instead of Macrovipera.

Two subspecies are recognised: Cuora mouhoutii mouhotii (Gray, 1863) and C. m. obsti (Fritz, Andreas & Lehr, 1997).

Traditionally placed in the monotypic genus Pyxidea until Honda et al. (2002) demonstrated that mouhotii is genetically nested inside Cuora. Hybrids of C. mouhotii with Cuora galbinifrons or C. bourreti gave rise to specimens that were erroneously described as a separate species, Cuora serrata.

Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Previously considered to contain just a single, variable species, Cyclemys remains subject to ongoing taxonomic investigations which rearrange the taxonomy and nomenclature on an ongoing basis. Key references: Fritz et al. 1996, 1997; Iverson and McCord 1997; Guicking et al. 2002.

Previously assigned to the genus Geochelone, following Loveridge and Williams (1957), the species has more recently been placed in Centrochelys Gray 1872, following Bour (1980), as subsequently recognized by Devaux (2000), TTWG (2017), and Petrozzi et al. (2020b), but not by Fritz and Havas (2007). There is very little morphological (Lambert 1993) or genetic (mtDNA) variation in this species; however, there is some divergence between eastern and western subpopulations of C. sulcata based on the presence of two haplotypes (Livoreil and Van Der Kuyl 2005), but subspecies are not recognized.
Includes a widespread dark morph and a 'rayed' morph in the western part of the range in Togo and Nigeria that has not yet been examined taxonomically (Bour and Maran 2003; Luiselli et al. 2018).

There is debate over the existence of two subspecies. Loveridge and Williams (1957) originally recognized two subspecies: Geochelone pardalis babcocki (Loveridge, 1935) alongside Geochelone pardalis pardalis (Bell, 1828). Genetic analysis by Le et al. (2006) supported this view, however, the geographical origin of the specimens were largely unknown. A recent Africa-wide phylogeographic study (Fritz et al. 2010) argued that there is no basis for the recognition of Stigmochelys p. babcocki.

The phylogenetic placement of the species remains dynamic: after being placed in Geochelone by Loveridge and Williams (1957), it has subsequently been placed in Stigmochelys by Gerlach (2001), Centrochelys by Vetter (2002), and Psammobates by Le et al. (2006); consensus appears to have settled on Stigmochelys.
Specimens of Pseudocerastes persicus recorded from Jordan might refer to P. fieldi (A. Disi pers. comm.).

This species is widely known under the generic name Malpolon (although it was included in the genus Scutophis by Geniez et al. 2004). Kelly et al. (2008) found that this species is genetically distinct from other members of Malpolon, but took no taxonomic action. Investigating the nomenclatural history of this snake, Böhme and de Pury (2011) resurrected the genus Rhagerhis for this taxon, a name previously (and erroneously) considered to be unavailable. Rhagerhis appears to be nested within Malpolon (Figueroa et al. 2016), but Uetz et al. (2019) notes that this apparent synonymy not been widely adopted.

Rhamphiophis maradiensis, described from Niger, is now understood to be a junior synonym of R. moilensis (Trape and Mané 2006, I. Ineich pers. comm. 2013), although this treatment has been disputed (L. Chirio pers. comm. in Uetz et al. 2019).

This account follows Anderson (1999) and Disi (2002) in including Trapelus blandfordi within T. persicus, itself now a junior synonym of T. ruderatus (Rastegar-Pouyani 2000). Trapelus ruderatus baluchianus (Olivier, 1804) is now included within Trapelus megalonyx Günther, 1864, following Rastegar-Pouyani (2000).

The relationship between Phrynocephalus interscapularis and P. sogdianus is unclear. The latter taxon has been listed both as a subspecies of P. interscapularis (Milto and Barabanov 2012) and as a full species (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008, Melville et al. 2009) in recent literature. Solovyeva et al. (2014) found "only insignificant" genetic differentiation between the two taxa and suggested that the status of P. sogdianus warrants further investigation.

Varanus irrawadicus Yang & Li, 1987 and V. vietnamensis Yang & Liu, 1994 were previously described as nominal species, but both were synonymized with V. bengalensis by Böhme and Ziegler (1997). The same authors raised V. bengalensis nebulosus (Gray, 1831) to full species status based on a V. b. bengalensis specimen obtained from a market in Phuket (exhibiting characters within the range of V. b. nebulosus), which was thought to prove sympatry between the two forms, together with differences in hemipenial structure. It is widely accepted that this specimen instead represents a geographic race of V. bengalensis, based on a very detailed study of geographic variation in V. bengalensis across its range (Auffenberg 1994). The Phuket locality is also considered doubtful, as this is an extensively-visited area where no nebulosus-morph monitors have otherwise been recorded, and the specimen recorded in the market may have been collected further north (D. Bennett pers. comm. 2017). Consequently V. nebulosus is treated here as a junior synonym of V. bengalensis.

Macey et al. (2005) conducted a phylogenetic analysis of the genus Teratoscincus and concluded on genetic grounds that T. keyserlingi (until then regarded as a subspecies of T. scincus) should be considered a valid species. This author did not, however, conduct any morphological work to determine whether the proposed arrangement represented a morphologically diagnosable species (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2013). Subsequently Wagner et al. (2016) noted that most Afghan records of this species appear to be referable to T. keyserlingi. These authors note that the assignment of Afghan records to the two taxa is "complicated", although they recognize both as distinct species occurring in Afghanistan. Nazarov et al. (2017) subsequently elevated the isolated Fergana Valley form T. s. rustamowi to specific status based on both molecular and morphological methods and clarified range limits within Teratoscincus as presently understood.

This taxon is sometimes considered to be a subspecies of Trapelus ruderatus (e.g.. Anderson 1999). After an examination of the type, Anderson (1999) determined T. microtympanum (known only from the imprecise type locality of 'Persia') to be a synonym of T. megalonyx.

Trape and Mané (2006) treat the West African form of this species as a full species Spalerosophis cliffordi, however, Schätti et al. (2009) note that no rationale was presented to justify this treatment. These authors adopt the traditional concept of this form as a subspecies of S. diadema, and this scheme is followed here. Baig and Masroor (2008) consider the former subspecies S. d. atriceps a full species, and this has subsequently been accepted (Schätti et al. 2009). The subspecies S. d. schirasianus has been recognized for Middle Asia, western Afghanistan and Pakistan, however the validity of this taxon is unclear and it has been recognized both as a subspecies and as a synonym of S. d. diadema in recent literature (Baig and Masroor 2008, Schätti et al. 2009); Wagner et al. (2016) tentatively retain it as a subspecies.

Hemidactylus persicus was described by Anderson in 1872 based on specimens collected from Shiraz, Iran; its type locality is restricted to Shiraz (Smith 1935). Morphologically typical animals occur in northeast Saudi Arabia (as far south as Al-Hofuf and perhaps ar-Riyadh), in Bahrain, Kuwait, and lowland Iraq, southern Iran, Pakistan and Gujarat (India) (Smith 1935, Anderson 1999, Minton Jr. 1966, Leviton et al. 1992, Vyas et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). They are characterized by relatively small size (up to 67 mm SVL), a low number of lamellae under the 1st toe of pes (mean 8.8, 8–9) and relatively numerous prenatal pores in males (mean 9.2, 8–11) arranged in a V-shaped line in front of the vent (Carranza and Arnold 2012).

Originally assessed for the UAE as the nominate subspecies, Cerastes gasperettii ssp. gasperettii Leviton & Anderson, 1967, but assessment moved to the species-level as only the nominate subspecies is present in the UAE. Indeed, the status of subspecies Cerastes gasperettii ssp. mendelssohni has been under dispute and the general consensus is that it might not be valid (J. Els pers. comm. 2018).

The taxon Trapelus sanguinolentus is variously considered a distinct species or a subspecies of T. agilis (the latter scheme following Rastegar-Pouyani 1998), and the taxon's appropriate status has yet to be resolved (Macey and Ananjeva 2004). This account treats T. sanguinolentus as a full species, the scheme provisionally adopted by Melville et al. (2009) and Wagner et al. (2011), and now accepted by many authors (Wagner et al. 2016), although Shahamat et al. (2020) found that this arrangement renders T. agilis paraphyletic based on mtDNA. We follow Anderson (1999) by including Laudakia kirmanensis within T. agilis (S. Anderson pers. comm. 2008).

The former of the new subspecies has conventionally been considered as belonging to T. a.  agilis, and the latter to T. a. isolepis. They are distinguishable from the other subspecies of T.  agilis complex by  having several distinctive morphological  characteristics. The distinctiveness of both subspecies is confirmed according to the author's previous extensive studies on this complex using uni- and multivariate analyses of morphological characters. Both subspecies mainly occur as geographical isolates in the periphery of the main range of the complex, and both have mainly been separated from the central continuum (= T. a. agilis) by eco-geographical barriers and are almost entirely restricted in distribution to the lowlands, desert and semi-desert regions with high annual temperature (Rastegar-Pouyani 1999.).

Zamenis var. tessellata was described from an unknown locality in "Asia Mineure", which is considered "almost certainly incorrect" by Schätti et al. (2014). Perry (2012) suggested that, if this locality is accurate, this may represent a distinct species, or that alternatively it could be a senior synonym of Platyceps saharicus. Schätti et al. (2014) indicate that the known specimen exhibits characters consistent with Platyceps saharicus from southern Israel, and reject the suggestion by Perry (2012) that it should be considered a valid species. The name tessellata has however generally been ignored by most authors, but has been used for Israeli snakes in some recent literature (Sinaiko et al. 2018). Sinaiko et al. (2018) found no evidence that two species of this group occur in Israel. These authors recommend further research to clarify the status of this name, and due to uncertainty surrounding both its provenance and identity it may be best considered a nomen dubium (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2019).

This taxon is a species complex (Baha El Din 2006), and it has been difficult to distinguish morphologically from the similar Acanthodactylus shtreibersi (Tamar et al. 2014). Tamar et al. (2014) reviewed the systematics of A. schreibersi using nuclear DNA and referred A. s. syriacus to the synonymy of the Mediterranean subspecies A. boskianus asper. Suibsequently, Psonis et al. (2016) confirmed that A. boskianus as presently recognized consists of at least four species-level taxa based on mitochondrial DNA, but refrained from taking taxonomic action on the basis that the relationships between clades were insufficiently resolved to reach a "safe conclusion" regarding species delimitation.

Baig et al. (2012) reassigned Laudakia caucasia to their new genus Paralaudakia. The proposed subspecies Paralaudakia caucasia triannulata has variously been attributed to this species and to P. microlepis. Preliminary molecular data indicates that P. c. triannulata forms a clade with adjacent populations of P. c. caucasia (Macey et al. 1998), however, Baig et al. (2012) suggested that the Transcaucasia population may have represented misidentified P. microlepis and recommended further studies that include molecular evidence to resolve the taxonomy of this and other atypical P. caucasia. These authors anticipate that this work will demonstrate a closer affinity to P. microlepis than P. caucasia, however, other authors hypothesize that the "triannulata" form may represent a hybrid between the two taxa (Ananjeva et al. 2014). Pending clarification of this issue this account follows a traditional concept that includes Stellio caucasia triannulata as a subspecies of P. caucasia.

Wagner et al. (2016) and Schatti et al. (2014) treat Platyceps mintonorum as a full species without discussion, but neither is concerned with a taxonomic reevaluation of Platyceps karelini. This account therefore follows Uetz and Hallerman (2015) in treating Platyceps mintonorum as a subspecies of P. karelini.

Khan (2006) regards mintonorum as a colour variation of P. karelini and not meriting subspecific status.
Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including T. fedtschenkoi.

Macey et al. (2005) conducted a phylogenetic analysis of the genus Teratoscincus and concluded on genetic grounds that T. keyserlingi (until then regarded as a subspecies of T. scincus) should be considered a valid species. This author did not, however, conduct any morphological work to determine whether the proposed arrangement represented a morphologically diagnosable species (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2013). Subsequently, Wagner et al. (2016) noted that most Afghan records of this species appear to be referable to T. keyserlingi. These authors note that the assignment of Afghan records to the two taxa is "complicated", although they recognize both as distinct species occurring in Afghanistan.

Nazarov et al. (2017) subsequently elevated the isolated Fergana Valley form T. s. rustamowi to specific status based on both molecular and morphological methods and clarified range limits within Teratoscincus as presently understood. Although the Arabian subpopulation of this species is isolated and restricted to the United Arab Emirates, Teratoscincus keyserlingii from Bandar-e-Abas in Iran and the United Arab Emirates are genetically similar.

Rastegar-Pouyani et al. (2010) conducted the first molecular phylogenetic treatment of this widespread lizard, and found that Eremias persica as presently understood contains at least eight genetically divergent lineages. These authors propose that at least four of these lineages warrant specific status. None have available names provided by Rastegar-Pouyani et al. (2010); while the name Eremias nigrolateralis was erected by Rastegar-Pouyani and Nilson (1997) this does not correspond to any clades identified in this research, and Rastegar-Pouyani et al. (2010) synonymize this form within E. persica. These authors indicate that further research is needed to describe the new taxa. Pending this research these taxa are retained within the definition of E. persica applied here with the exception of one of two clades known from the western portion of Namak Lake, which Rastegar-Pouyani suggest is sufficiently distinct on both morphological and molecular grounds that "recognition of this clade as E. persica should be discontinued".

The type locality for E. persica is reported to be near Isfehan. Although the exact locality is not clear, long-established descriptions of this taxon (Terentjev and Chernove 1965, Szczerbak 1974, Anderson 1999) correspond well with the populations of the south-east Isfehan and north Fars provinces (Pouyani et al. 2010).
This species has three subspecies: the nominate form, Eremias scripta ladsini, and E. s. pherganensis. The latter is confined to the Fergana Valley, an area under heavy human pressure.

Two subspecies are known in Turkey, R. m. staunini and R. m. melanocephalus, and these might represent distinct species (Baran and Atatür 1998). Only the subspecies R. m. satunini is present within the Caucasus.

We provisionally treat Pseudocerastes fieldi Schmidt, 1930 as a distinct species (Uetz and Hallermann 2010, Uetz et al. 2018, Šmíd and Tolley 2019), although in some accounts it is treated as a subspecies of P. persicus (Leviton et al. 1992).

Pseudocerastes bicornis Wall, 1913, described from a single locality on the Pakistan-Afghanistan border at the eastern range limit for the genus, has long been considered a junior synonym of P. persicus (Sindaco et al. 2013), and this scheme is followed here, but is listed as a valid species without comment by Khan (2006).

Recent studies have confirmed that Pseudocerastes persicus from Oman and the United Arab Emirates are genetically the same as those from Iran (de Pous et al. 2016).

Ptyas mucosa was described by Linnaeus in 1758 as Coluber mucosus based on specimens from India (Smith 1943). Two subspecies are recognized: P. m. mucosa and P. m. maximus, the latter being endemic to Sri Lanka. Some authorities recognize a third subspecies, P. m. nigricans Chernov, 1949, endemic to Turkmenistan.

Lycodon striatus was described by Shaw in 1802 based on drawings by Dr. Patrick Russell of specimens from Visakhapatnam and Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh (Smith 1943). The population present in Middle Asia, L. s. bicolor, might represent a distinct species (N. Ananjeva and N. Orlov pers. comm. September 2008).

Two subspecies have been described; the nominate subspecies, and S. mitranus muscatensis Murray, 1886. Scincus m. muscatensis was considered a synonym of S. mitranus mitranus by Gardner (2013) and Carranza et al. (2018).

This species has been considered to be a synonym of H. turcicus; while it is now recognized as valid (Baha El Din 2005, Carranza and Arnold 2012), its range limits remain unclear as a result of this former synonymy. The observation that many specimens exhibit apparently intermediate sets of characteristics (Loveridge 1947) is borne out by examination of Ethiopian H. sinaitus (Largen and Spawls 2006). B. Lanza (in Largen and Spawls 2006) attributes these shared characteristics to the existence of possible hybrids, but it may be that the relationship between H. robustus and H. sinaitus is in need of further investigation.

Comparison of nuclear and mitochondrial DNA sequences of geckos from Iran and Pakistan with H. robustus from Egypt and the UAE confirms that this species extends at least as far as Sind (Bauer et al. 2006). A recent study on the degree of molecular and morphological differentiation within the H. robustus species group allowed the redescription of H. robustus and the formal description of three new species of Hemidactylus – H. adensis and H. mandebensis from Yemen and H. awashensis from Ethiopia (Šmíd et al. 2015).

Hemidactylus porbandarensis Sharma, 1981 is a synonym of Hemidactylus robustus Heyden, 1827 (Bauer et al. 2012).
This species was described by Rüppell in 1835 based on specimens collected from Massaua Island, Eritrea (Smith  1935).

Gymnodactylus ingoldbyi Pricter, 1922 has long been synonymized with Cyrtopodion scaber and C. watsoni. However, study of the new material from Sulaiman tracts, along the western border of Punjab, Pakistan has proved the validity of Gymnodactylus ingoldbyi and established it as a northern race of Cyrtopodion kachhensis (Khan 1998). The subspecific name, ingoldbyi, is in honour of Christopher Martin Ingoldby (1887-1927), who was an officer in the British Army Medical Services and collected zoological specimens (Beolens et al. 2011).
West African subpopulations may represent a different species from that found in the Egyptian type locality (Trape et al. 2012).
Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including T. turcmenicus.
In Middle Asia the species is represented by the subspecies Boiga trigonata melanocephala (Annandale, 1904), which might represent a distinct species (N. Orlov pers. comm. September 2008).

This species has two recognized subspecies: the nominate form, and Laudakia melanura nasiri (known only from the type locality Tanishpa). A third form was originally described as the full species Stellio liratus before being synonymized with L. melanura and later revalidated as a subspecies (Baig et al. 2012 and refs therein). Based on a lack of consistency in characters used to define this subspecies, which they consider may represent differences in habitat or age, Baig et al. (2012) resynonymized L. m. lirata within L. m. melanura.

Mesalina watsonana forms a monophyletic group sister to all other Mesalina species (Šmíd and Frynta 2012). Based on molecular clock calibrations, the split between M. watsonana and the remaining taxa is estimated to have taken place in the mid-Miocene (15.9 Ma). Despite that the species is very agile and widespread on the Iranian Plateau, there is remarkably deep phylogeographic structuring at the population level with seven million years old basal radiation (Šmíd and Frynta 2012).

Harris and Arnold (2000) assert that the subspecies Acanthodactylus scutellatus hardyi is "better regarded as a full species" but provide no justification for this, simply pointing to differences highlighted by Arnold (1986). This recommendation has since been followed by several authors (Refai et al. 2003, Schlüter 2010, Uetz and Hallerman 2012), and molecular research suggests that this species does not belong to the same clade as members of the Acanthodactylus scutellatus group (Tamar et al. 2016). This account therefore treats A. hardyi as a separate species.
The molecular data demonstrate that Calotes versicolor represents multiple  species  and  at least  two  clades:  one  from  India-Myanmar  and  another  from Myanmar-Southeast Asia (Zug et al. 2006)
Populations to the east of the range of this species are now referable to Ophiomorus raithmai (Anderson and Leviton 1966).

This species was described in 1834 as Coluber ventromaculatus (Smith 1943). The type locality is unknown. This species is included in Platyceps following Nagy et al. (2004). Western populations of Platyceps ventromaculatus differ from populations in South Asia (India and Pakistan) for which the name Coluber chesneii Martin, 1838 is available. Schätti et al. (2012) determined that C. chesneii represents a subspecies of Platyceps karelini, removing these populations from P. ventromaculatus.

Khan and Khan (2000) didn’t specify any neotype for their new subspecies which are based on a figure in Gray (1830). The status of these subspecies, therefore, remains uncertain (no holotype specified, no valid description after ICZN) (Uetz et al. 2018). Barabanov (2003) indicated that the name C. v. bengalensis is not available and suggested the replacement name C. v. khanorum.

Coluber ventromaculatus Gray, 1834 is the type species of the genus Platyceps Blyth, 1860. Its occurrence in the Himalayan foothills (Himachal Pradesh, Uttaranchal) and the speciﬁc identity of the holotype of P. semifasciatus Blyth, 1860 needs further investigation. P. ventromaculatus crosses the Indus Valley and is found, for instance, along the Makran littoral to as far west as the border area with Iran. Coluber chesneii Martin, 1838 may be a valid northern Saharo-Arabian taxon of the genus Platyceps Blyth, 1860 (Schätti and Schmitz 2006).

Badiane et al. (2014) found the taxon “Pristurus rupestris” to contain two genetically well-differentiated species: an eastern clade (=Pristurus rupestris rupestris) that occurs in coastal Iran and the Hajar Mountain range in northern Oman and the eastern UAE, and a western clade distributed from coastal central Oman, through Yemen, Saudi Arabia and up to southern Jordan, with two possible names available: Pristurus guweirensis Haas, 1943 (=P. r. guweirensis elevated to species) or Pristurus migiurtinicus Scortecci, 1933 (synonymized with P. rupestris by Loveridge (1947). Further comparison of material from the type localities of Pristurus guweirensis and Pristurus migiurtinicus is required to confirm which is the applicable name for the western clade taxon, and Badiane et al. (2014) refer to the western clade as Pristurus sp. 1.

The resulting P. rupestris concept includes two nominal subspecies, P. r. rupestris (endemic to the Hajar Mountains) and P. r. iranicus (endemic to coastal Iran). P. r. iranicus is, however, morphologically identical to P. r. rupestris and recognizing it has been found to render P. r. rupestris paraphyletic, and it is possible that work in the near future may synonymize it within P. r. rupestris (S. Carranza pers. comm. 2018).

Within the Hajar Mountains, populations are a species complex that requires further study, and the taxonomic identity of subpopulations are likely to change (Garcia-Porta et al. 2017, Carranza et al. 2018).

This species has been the subject of competing taxonomic treatments, summarized in Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008), with Laudakia fusca treated variously as a synonym, a full species, or the subspecies Laudakia nupta fusca. Cheatsazan et al. (2008) inferred from morphological differences that the two forms may be reproductively isolated, however, this was rejected by Baig et al. (2012) who opined that "Morphological differences are clearly not distinct enough to recognize [the two subspecies] as full species". This account follows Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008) and Baig et al. (2012) in considering L. n. fusca a subspecies of L. nupta, however Baig et al. (2012) caution that this assignment should be considered preliminary, and that workers who have treated L. fusca as a junior synonym of L. nupta are "most probably" correct.

Echis carinatus was described by Schneider in 1801 as Pseudoboa carinata based on the drawings of the species by Dr. Patrick Russell published in 1796 (Smith 1943). Records of this species from Middle Asia and northern Afghanistan were until recently considered to represent the distinct species Echis multisquamatus. Molecular evidence suggests that E. multisquamatus warrants recognition as a subspecies of E. carinatus (Pook et al. 2009) and that scheme is followed here. E. sochureki is recognized as a distinct species from E. carinatus by some authorities.

The systematics of this species are extremely complicated due to the lack of comprehensive molecular treatments of the genus, as morphological differences between this species and Gloydius halys are minor (Sindaco et al. 2013). While these authors do not treat this species specifically, in distinguishing it from G. halys they describe its distribution, as recognized by Orlov and Barabanov 1999), as northeastern China, extreme southeastern Russia and the Korean Peninsula.

While long included in Eirenis, this species was transferred to Pseudocyclophis. Following Nagy et al. (2004), Pseudocyclophis is a subgenus of Eirenis and the correct nomen is therefore Eirenis (Pseudocyclophis) persicus; other authors have considered Pseudocyclophis a junior synonym of Eirenis. Rajabizadeh et al. (2015) conducted the first taxonomic review of this wide-ranging species, and determined on molecular, morphological and ecological grounds that the name E. persicus was properly attributable only to populations from the southern and western Zagros to the Persian Gulf. These authors elevated the recognized subspecies E. p. nigrofasciatus to specific status and erected the new species E. occidentalis for western populations. These authors also applied the available names E. walteri, E. mcmahoni and E. angusticeps to eastern populations. Unfortunately these latter taxa were only briefly diagnosed, without any discussion of comparative characters and with only summary descriptions of their distributions. Additionally, the novel species E. occidentalis differs morphologically from E. persicus only in patterning and in average scale counts determined based on limited numbers of specimens (9 and 7 respectively). Uetz and Hošek (2016) advised treating the results of this analysis as preliminary; although they recognize E. occidentalis, they do not accept the other actions proposed by Rajabizadeh et al. (2015). Two records reported from Afghanistan (Wagner et al. 2016) were not discussed by these authors, although they consider that E. angusticeps (in the east) may occur here and indicate that E. walteri "supposedly" does. Wagner et al. (2016) also consider it possible that these records refer to two different species within the persicus complex. It is however not clear whether the name E. walteri is validly applicable to either; while one of the Afghan specimens has historically been associated with that name, the historical concept of E. walteri refers to a colour morph within the E. persicus group and does not appear to fully correspond to the species concept recognized by Rajabizadeh et al. (2015). Pending further clarification of species boundaries within this group, this account follows the scheme proposed by Uetz and Hošek (2016) and retains E. walteri, E. nigrofasciatus, E. mcmahoni and E. angusticeps within the synonymy of E. persicus.
This represents a large species complex that requires substantial taxonomic revision (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019).

Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including T. longipes. These authors explicitly rejected the subspecific status for T. voraginosus suggested by Ščerbak and Golubev 1986 [1996] and followed by subsequent authors (e.g. Ananjeva et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). This account follows Bauer et al. (2013) in treating T. voraginosus as a full species. T. microlepis, typically treated as a subspecies, has a similar genetic distance to T. voraginosus and is treated as a full species by Nazarov and Poyarkov (2013). This scheme is followed here.

A previous assessment (Mousa Disi et al. 2010) of this taxon followed Arnold (1980), Ščerbak and Golubev (1996) and Disi (2002) in considering Bunopus blanfordii to be a synonym of B. tuberculatus. More recently Bauer et al. (2013) considered B. blanfordii a valid species. These authors do not discuss this assignment but state that they consider it valid "pending further investigation". As they provide no information on this taxon's distribution or differentiation from B. tuberculatus, B. blanfordii is tentatively retained within the species concept applied here. Phylogenetic analyses presented by Machado et al. (2018) show B. blanfordii nested within B. tuberculatus, indicating that recognizing it as distinct would render B. tuberculatus as presently understood, but these authors do not comment on this finding. This is a complicated species complex, and the genetics of B. blanfordii are currently under review to clarify its identity and true distribution (N. Ananjeva and T. Papenfuss pers. comm. 2016).

This species is sometimes included within the genus Eumeces. This is probably a polytypic species (Minton 1966). There are three recognized subspecies: Eurylpis taeniolatus taeniolatus Blyth, 1854; E.t. arabicus Szczerbak, 1990 and E. t. parthianicus Szczerbak, 1990. Khan (2006) notes that this division is based on colour pattern and not supported by morphological characters. The only other Indian representative of the genus, Eurylepis poonaensis, may be a junior synonym of E. taeniolatus (Sindaco and Jeremçenko 2008).

Eurylepis taeniolatus Blyth, 1854 is the type species of the genus Eurylepis.
This species is in need of taxonomic review as it is almost certainly a complex of species (S. Baha El Din pers. comm. 2009).  There are three subspecies.

Currently, two subspecies of Phrynocephalus maculatus Anderson, 1872 are recognised within its wide and discontinuous range. The nominotypic form is distributed in Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan, whilst P. m. longicaudatus Haas, 1957 - which Anderson 1999 suggested might be specifically distinct - is distributed mostly along the Arabian Gulf (Anderson 1999), reported from Oman, United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia (Arnold 1986).

Populations from Turkmenistan are now considered distinct as Phrynocephalus goluewii (N. Ananjeva and N. Orlov pers. comm. 2008). Phrynocephalus maculatus is the second Phrynocephalus species known to occur in Jordan (Baker et al. 2005).

Eryx johnii was first described by Russell in 1801 based on specimen from Tranquebar (=Tharangambadi), India (Smith 1943). The status of the subspecies Eryx johnii persicus is not clear; Sindaco et al. (2013) consider, based on an unpublished manuscript, that the name persicus is preoccupied by a different taxon (Wagner et al. 2016). The taxonomic status of E. j. persicus is in need of clarification (Vyas pers. comm.).

Eublepharis macularius fuscus has been elevated to specific status (Das 1997), but the validity of several proposed subspecies and their status is unclear (discussed in (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008, Khan 2006 and Wagner et al. 2016). This assessment follows Wagner et al. (2016) in treating the proposed species E. gracilis, described from a captive specimen of unknown origindescribed from a captive specimen of unknown origin, as a nomen dubium. These authors propose recognizing E. m. afghanicus as a full species but note that this status needs to be verified. On this basis, E. afghanicus is tentatively retained within the synonym of E. macularius in this assessment

Barabanov and Milto (2017) give the authority of this species as 'Lichtenstein, 1823', however, the name Scincus pannonicus was reported in this source (correctly, Fitzinger in Lichtenstein, 1823) without an associated description, and is consequently considered a nomen nudum by Uetz et al. (2018). The correct authority is consequently 'Fitzinger, 1824', in which publication the species was formally described (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2018).
This species is included in Platyceps following Nagy et al. (2004). Schätti (2004) and Schätti and Schmitz (2006) include Platyceps rogersi in synonymy with P. ventromaculatus.
This species was removed from synonymy with Walterinnesia aegyptia by Nilson and Rastegar-Pouyani (2007).

Anderson (1999) suggests that this taxon may not be specifically distinct from Eremias intermedia, however while recognizing this (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008) recent authors have nevertheless treated E. nigrocellata as a valid species (Ananjeva et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008, Darvish and Rastegar-Pouyani 2012, Uetz and Hallerman 2012).

The status of several described subspecies is unclear, with various authors referring to Lytorhynchus d. gaddi, L. d. arabicus and L. d. mesopotamicus as either subspecies or junior synonyms of L. d. diadema (competing views discussed in Bauer et al. 2017).

The status of L. kennedyi has been considered uncertain for several decades, with Leviton and Anderson (1970) suspecting that future research would demonstrate that these are conspecific. While some authors have followed these authors in provisionally accepting it as valid, others recognize it as simply a colour morph of L. diadema (discussed in Sindaco et al. 2013 and Bauer et al. 2017).  The situation is complicated further since competing evidence suggests both that the two species have been found in sympatry, supporting the notion that the two taxa are specifically distinct (Martens 1993); and that a specimen from Libya well outside the range of L. kennedyi exhibits the same patterning, supporting the idea that it is a colour morph (Moravec 1995). Bauer et al. (2017) refrain from making a judgment on the taxonomic status of L. kennedyi, but recognize the Libyan specimen as L. d. diadema.

This taxon is thought to be a complex of species that is in need of revision (Wallach et al. 2014; S. Baha El Din pers. comm.). West African members of this complex are no longer considered to belong to M. macrorhyncha (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2002), but the identity of populations from the Middle East, Pakistan and northwest India are still in need of clarification (Broadley and Wallach 2007). Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) assigned the species to their new genus, Myriopholis. These authors resurrected Leptotyphlops phillipsi from synonymy with M. macrorhyncha, however this action was apparently taken without examining specimens and as such this account treats this taxon as a junior synonym of M. macrorhyhncha pending resolution of this issue.

This species exhibits close similarities to Eryx miliaris, and the two are difficult to distinguish (Ezkandarzadeh et al. 2013). Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) attribute records of E. tataricus from Khorasan Province in northeastern Iran to E. miliaris. The distribution of the two taxa elsewhere is in need of clarification: Zhao and Adler (1993) provide a "composite range" for the complex in China as the separate ranges of the two taxa in this country cannot be identified. Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) outline the distribution of both species and report both from Mongolia, however, Zhao and Adler (1993) and Terbish et al. (2006) consider that only E. tataricus occurs in this country. Cryptic species may exist within the E. miliaris-tataricus complex, based on the finding by Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) that two Iranian specimens (to which they applied the name Eryx cf. miliaris) could not confidently be referred to this taxon. The subspecies Eryx tataricus vittatus is sometimes treated as a distinct species following Tokar (1989), a scheme followed widely in Russian literature, however the distinctness of this taxon was not supported by Kluge (1993 using a different set of osteological characters. Given the problematic taxonomy of the miliaris-tataricus complex as a whole and the low degree of both morphological and genetic differentiation between these taxa (Pyron et al. 2014, Ezkandarzadeh et al. 2013) it is retained here as a subspecies pending a revision of the group as a whole. This follows the recommendation by Reynolds et al. (2014), who identified E. t. vittatus as a diagnosable taxon but noted the lack of clarity regarding the distributions of all three taxa (E. tataricus, E. miliaris, and E. t. vitttaus). New phylogenetic research suggests that E. tataricus represents a junior synonym of E. miliaris (Eskandarzadeh et al. 2020), but this account retains it as valid pending further research to confirm this assignment given the complex taxonomic history of these names and the need for wider sampling outside Iran.

The taxon Trapelus sanguinolentus is variously considered a distinct species or a subspecies of T. agilis (the latter scheme following Rastegar-Pouyani 1998). Macey and Ananjeva (2004) found that the two taxa were genetically distinct. This account treats T. sanguinolentus as a full species following Melville et al. (2009) and Wagner et al. (2011), although Shahamat et al. (2020) found that this arrangement renders T. agilis paraphyletic based on mtDNA.

In Central Asia this form has sometimes been known as T. s. aralensis, although this subspecific division has been controversial (Macey and Ananjeva 2004). Macey and Ananjeva (2004) investigated allozyme variation within the two lineages of T. sanguinolentus, and found very little evidence of genetic variation. On this basis, T. s. aralensis should be considered a junior synonym of T. s. sanguinolentus (Macey and Ananjeva 2004).
The conservation assessment of this taxon is complicated by the conviction that the current taxonomic designation hides a complex of several different species.

Pelochelys bibroni was redescribed and separated from Pelochelys cantorii and restricted to the southern lowlands of New Guinea by Webb (1995), based partly on Rhodin et al. (1993). The genetic divergence of P. bibroni from Asian P. cantorii was confirmed by Engstrom et al. (2004), but it has yet to be compared genetically with P. signifera (Webb 2003), a morphologically distinct species from northern New Guinea. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named.

Peters (1982) raised a number of subspecies of Acanthodactylus cyanogaster to full species status. The relationship between this form and A. atricollis remains unclear, and will require molecular research to resolve (Largen and Spawls 2006). Prior to Spawls et al. (2002), A. atricollis was typically considered a junior synonym of A. cyanogaster following Parker (1942). Largen and Spawls (2006) opin that two distinct phenotypes exist that justify the recognition of both species, and this concept is followed here. As defined by these authors, A. cyanogaster is confined to Ethiopia and Eritrea, and confusion between this form and A. atricollis may have been exacerbated by erroneous assignment of material from more southern territories to A. cyanogaster (Largen and Spawls 2006).

Inger et al. (1984) questioned the specific distinction of this species and placed it within the synonymy of its closely related congener, Calotes rouxii Dumeril & Bibron 1837. But no subsequent authors have followed their arrangement, and instead recognized C. elliotti as a distinct species.
Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Its status compared to C. pulchristriata needs validation.

authority: Fritz, Guicking, Auer, Sommer, Wink & Hunsdörfer, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently; C. enigmatica is a recently-described species of the black-bellied Cyclemys group.

authority: Fritz, Guicking, Auer, Sommer, Wink & Hunsdörfer, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently.

authority: Fritz, Guicking, Auer, Sommer, Wink & Hunsdörfer, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently.
Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Its status compared to C. atripons needs validation.

In the past, specimens of softshell turtles collected from New Guinea were all originally assigned to what was considered to be a widespread Australasian species, Pelochelys bibroni (Owen 1853), until Rhodin et al. (1993) and Webb (1995) defined P. bibroni as being restricted to southern New Guinea, and separate from the previously described P. cantorii (Gray 1864) in the rest of Asia and northern New Guinea. Subsequently, Webb (2003) described the northern New Guinea softshell as the new species Pelochelys signifera. This taxonomy has been accepted since then (TTWG 2017). Pelochelys signifera was described largely based on characteristics of a juvenile specimen and coloration and texturing of the carapace to distinguish it from P. cantorii. No geographic variation has been reported within the species' range and no subspecies have been named. Phylogenetic relationships with P. cantorii and P. bibroni warrant further investigation.

This forest-associated species has a disjunct distribution within its known range, occurring in isolated forest patches. As with many other non-vagile habitat specialists that appear to have a large distribution, it may actually represent a species complex.
Accepted as Trioceros tempeli in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Accepted as Trioceros schoutedeni in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). This species overlaps in distribution with T. rudis and is morphologically similar, resulting in confusion between the two species. Where the two species co-occur, it is not possible to determine which records belong to T. schoutedeni and which to T. rudis. It differs from T. rudis mainly on the basis of a much reduced gular, and ventral crest.
Accepted as Rhampholeon boulengeri, but the wide but disjunct distribution could suggest this is a species complex (Tilbury 2010).
Accepted as Rhampholeon acuminatus in Mariaux and Tilbury (2006).
Accepted as Kinyongia vosseleri in Mariaux et al. (2008).

Accepted as Chamaeleo anchietae in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). This species has a wide and disjunct distribution. DNA barcoding shows that outlying populations of northern Tanzania and Rwanda attributed to this species are a separate, unidentified taxon. Two sub-species were described by Laurent in 1952 (C. anchietae marunguensis and C. a. mertensi) which derive from highlands on the western side of Lake Tanganyika, but this treatment needs to be confirmed by genetic analyses.
Accepted as Trioceros ntunte in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).
Accepted as Rhampholeon temporalis in Tilbury et al. (2006).
Accepted as Nadzikambia mlanjensis in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007). Populations of chameleons on nearby mountains in Mozambique do not represent this taxon (Branch and Tolley 2010).

Accepted as Rhampholeon platyceps (Tilbury 2010). Populations of Rhampholeon on Mt. Chiperone, Mabu and Namuli are separate taxa and should not be confused with R. platyceps (Branch et al. 2014). In addition, molecular phylogenetic analysis shows that the sub-species, R. platyceps carri is not valid (Branch et al. 2014).
This species was described from a single adult male specimen, as well as photographs of another adult male from Ngozi forest (Necas 2009).

This species was referred to the new genus Trioceros by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Its taxonomy is somewhat complex, as a number of subspecies have been described and their validity challenged (see Tilbury 2010 for a summary), and the status of records from Kenya, Tanzania, South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo (outside Kivu Province) is in need of verification. These records are provisionally assigned to "Trioceros rudis incertae sedis" by Tilbury (2010) and are consequently not included in this assessment pending taxonomic investigation. Records from Ethiopia may represent confusion with T. bitaeniatus (Tilbury et al. 2010) and are not considered here. Trioceros sternfeldi, previously considered a subspecies of T. rudis, is now considered a full species. The population from Aberdares National Park in Kenya, previously also considered to belong to T. rudis (Tilbury 2010), has been described as T. kinangopensis (Stipala et al. 2012). Finally, records of T. rudis from the Albertine Rift region make up the bulk of this species occurrence, but in general they are of uncertain status and may not be T. rudis sensu stricto - unless they come from the Rwenzori  Mountains, which is the type locality of T. rudis.
Accepted as Rieppeleon kerstenii Tilbury (2010).
Accepted as Chamaeleo gracilis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).
Accepted as Kinyongia uluguruensis in Mariaux et al. (2008).

authority: Menegon, Tolley, Jones, Rovero, Marshall & Tilbury, 2009
taxonomicNotes: Accepted as Kinyongia magomberae in Menegon et al. (2009).
Accepted as Trioceros schubotzi in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Accepted as Trioceros deremensis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). The species occurs as isolated populations in a number of different mountain ranges over a distance of several hundred kilometers. This could potentially mean there are multiple unrecognised cryptic species. Most chameleon species that are habitat specialists are not found in multiple isolated mountains that are at such great distances from each other.
Some records from the western portion of this lizard's range may be confused with Chamaeleo senegalensis (Tilbury 2010, Trape et al. 2012).

West African records of Chameleo dilepis (as C. quilensis), which has been considered as possibly occurring in Nigeria, are expected to represent confusion with this species; these records are instead attributable to C. necasi (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012).
Accepted as Kinyongia tavetana in Tilbury (2010).
Accepted as Kinyongia matschiei in Mariaux et al. (2008). Populations occur in the East Usambara Mountains, and these were formerly confused with K. fischeri.
Accepted as Kinyongia xenorhina in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).

Although this species is accepted as Trioceros werneri in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), recent work of populations isolated in forest patches on the Udzungwa, Uluguru, Nguru, and Ukaguru Mountains suggest that a number of cryptic species exist within T. werneri as currently conceived (Ceccarelli et al. In press). In addition, the population on Rubeho appears morphologically distinctive, although it has not been included in the phylogenetic framework. Further work to update and improve the taxonomy of this species complex is required, and re-assessments should be carried out once the taxonomic status of the species has been validated.
This species has a very large, but probably patchy distribution, and its small size would suggest it is not vagile. Therefore, it may actually represent a species complex.
Accepted as Rhampholeon beraduccii in Mariaux and Tilbury (2006).

Accepted as Rhampholeon moyeri (Menegon et al. 2002) although there has been some confusion around the taxonomy due to its close similarity to R. ulugurensis. A recent molecular phylogeny shows this species occurs in Udzungwa, Rubeho, Ukaguru, and Nguru (including Kanga), based on an analysis of recently-discovered populations of previously uncertain affinity (Fisseha et al. 2013). R. moyeri is therefore much more widespread than had been known, as many of these records had been erroneously attributed to R. ulugurunsis.
Accepted as Kinyongia tenuis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). The status of the Shimba Hills population as belonging to this taxon needs to be confirmed.

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank.The combined molecular and morphological analysis of Barej et al. (2010) necessitated major taxonomic changes to this taxon, and these authors elevated the subspecies T. w. perreti to species rank and removed T. serratus from synonymy. The correct assignment of one record close to the north Manengouba Mountains (Gounwouo et al. 2006) is uncertain, as this may represent either T. wiedersheimi or T. perreti (Barej et al. 2010). T. serratus is difficult to distinguish morphologically from T. wiedersheimi, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).
Accepted as Kinyongia carpenteri in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Described as Rhampholeon uluguruensis in Tilbury and Emmrich (1996), and was known only from the Uluguru Mountains and the nearby Mkungwe outcrop. Records from other localities within the Eastern Arc have been found to represent the very similar, recently-recognized species R. moyeri in a recent molecular study (Fisseha et al. 2013). Fisseha et al. (2013) conclude based on their results that R. uluguruensis is endemic to the Uluguru Mountains.

Accepted as Trioceros bitaeniatus in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Molecular phylogenetics suggests that Trioceros bitaeniatus is a complex of species (Kořený 2006) and the taxonomy clearly needs revision. Individuals from Kenya form a phylogenetic clade, but there is potentially species level structure within that clade. In addition, that phylogeny shows T. bitaeniatus to be polyphyletic with T. marsabitensis. The range may also include South Sudan, Ethiopia, southern Uganda, eastern DRC, and northern Tanzania but these localities have not been investigated in a phylogenetic context. Records from DRC and southern Uganda may actually be misidentified individuals of Trioceros ellioti, which was originally thought to be a subspecies of T. bitaeniatus based on their strong resemblance (Tilbury 2010).

There are two sub-species of this species, T. goetzei goetzei and T. goetzei nyikae (Tilbury 2010). The sub-species have not been investigated in a phylogenetic framework, but there is potentially divergence between them given their wide distribution but isolation on montane grassland plateau environments.
Accepted as Trioceros narraioca in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Trioceros sternfeldi  was described by Rand (1963) in his re-assessment if the Trioceros bitaeniatus complex (Rand 1963). He designated specimens from Mt. Meru and Mt. Kilimanjaro to the new subspecies Chamaeleo rudis sternfeldi. Some authors have accepted the subspecific designation (Mertens 1966), but others regarded the subspecies as invalid (Broadley and Howell 1991, Klaver and Böhme 1997, Spawls and Rotich 1997, Spawls et al. 2002). Tricoeros sternfeldi is now regarded as a full species by most authors (Necas 1999, Tilbury 2010, Stipala 2014, Spawls et al. 2014). However, the population of “T. sternfeldi” from Mount Hanang (sensu Tilbury 2010) was recently described as T. hanangensis (Krause and Böhme 2010) which restricts the distribution of T. sternfeldi to Kilimanjaro, Mt. Meru and the Ngorongoro highlands. In addition, Stipala (unpub. data 2013) suggests that the T. sternfeldi population from Ngorongoro is more closely related to T. hanangensis than to T. sternfeldi. Furthermore, the taxonomic status of recently discovered T. cf. sternfeldi populations in montane localities in Kenya (i.e. Samburu/Karsia Hills, Loita Hills) needs to be confirmed with additional research, but Stipala (2014) suggests they are genetically distinct from T. sternfeldi. 

Unassigned records tentatively referred to Trioceros rudis incertae sedis (Tilbury 2010) known from Tanzania and Kenya may belong to this taxon. Molecular work by Townsend and Larson (2002) confirmed the genetic distinctiveness of the Tanzanian ‘rudis’ from populations in the Albertine Rift and subsequent studies have re-enforced those conclusions with more detailed molecular analyses (Tolley and Tilbury 2009, Krause and Boehme 2010). In turn, many of the localities from the Albertine Rift may not represent T. rudis sensu stricto, so the Tanzanian/Albertine Rift comparison may not even refer to T. rudis but to several undescribed taxa. It is clear that the T. rudis/sternfeldi complex is in need of a taxonomic assessment that is based on comprehensive sampling from multiple localities, within a phylogenetic framework.

Accepted as Rhampholeon nchisiensis in Tilbury (2010). Preliminary molecular studies show that populations from Owemba Forest (Kipengere Mountain), originally thought to be this species, actually represent an undescribed species (K. Tolley, Unpub. data 2013).
Accepted as Kinyongia uthmoelleri in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).
Accepted as Kinyongia boehmei in Mariaux et al. (2008).

Accepted as Kinyongia fischeri in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007). Populations in the East and West Usambara Mountains previously thought to belong to K. fischeri are instead referable to K. vosseleri, K. multituberculata, and K. matschiei (Mariaux et al. 2008). K. fischeri occurs only in the Nguru and Nguu Mountains, Tanzania.

Accepted as Trioceros marsabitensis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). The systematics of this species has not been fully investigated, although the single specimen that was included in a molecular phylogeny shows T. marsabitensis and T. bitaeniatus to be paraphyletic (Kořený, 2006).
Accepted as Kinyongia excubitor in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).
Phylogenetic analysis of the genus Kinyongia, including individuals assigned to K. oxyrhina from several localities, suggests that this is a species complex (Tolley et al. 2011).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Two morphologically distinct subspecies, corresponding to a northern and southern distribution within the Cameroon mountain chain, are traditionally recognized, the southern T. q. quadricornis (Mertens 1968) and northern T. q. gracilior (Barej et al. 2010). Molecular data supports this division, although suggests a very recent split between these taxa (Barej et al. 2010). Klaver and Böhme (1992) suggest that the assignment of Mt Kupe specimens to T. q. quadricornis requires verification, and that these records may in fact represent a separate, isolated lineage. Barej et al. (2010) also supported the finding by Pook and Wild (1997) that the morphologically divergent and geographically disjunct Eisentraut's chameleon (T. eisentrauti) should be treated as a subspecies of T. quadricornis on molecular grounds, and formally made this change. Accepted as Trioceros quadricornis in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015). Glaw (2015) recognizes three subspecies: Trioceros quadricornis quadricornis, Trioceros quadricornis eisentrauti, and Trioceros quadricornis gracilior.
The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Accepted as Trioceros pfefferi in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), Tolley and Herrel (2014), and Glaw (2015).
Accepted as Trioceros johnstoni in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).
Accepted as Kinyongia multituberculata in Mariaux et al. (2008) and Tilbury (2010).
Accepted as Trioceros melleri in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Accepted as Kinyongia adolfifriderici in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), however there is considerable uncertainty with the taxonomic status of many populations (Greenbaum et al. 2012).
