The recent recognition that Kinyongia gyrolepis, a "superficially similar" species, is a sister taxon to Ugandan K. adolfifriderici, renders K. adolfifriderici as paraphyletic (Greenbaum et al. (2012).  

The type locality, "Irumu-Mavambi Urwald", provided by Sternfeld (1912) is considered vague, as Irumu and Mavambi (now Mawambi) are separate localities around 150 km apart along the Ituri River (Greenbaum et al. 2012), in the Orientale Province of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Both sites are however in areas of historical lowland rainforest, and this and other historical collections, from Medje and from "lowland and montane" areas of Rwanda and Uganda (Greenbaum et al. 2012 and references therein), show that the species occurs in lowland rainforest. The only recent records are from Afromontane forests in the Albertine Rift. Given that recent studies suggest the presence of multiple taxa within K. adolfifriderici, it is possible that lowland and montane populations belong to different species. Should this be the case, the name K. adolfifriderici would be applicable to the lowland populations conspecific with material from Ituri (Greenbaum et al. 2012). Furthermore, the isolated montane forest fragments along the Albertine Rift (e.g. Bwindi Forest, Nyungwe Forest) may house additional cryptic species.

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros), of which T. oweni is the type species, to generic rank. Accepted as Trioceros oweni in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015). The southern form was originally described as Chamaeleon unicornis and was differentiated by males having either no or reduced pre-orbital horns. This form was later considered a subspecies, but was synonomized and is regarded as a variant of T. oweni (Tilbury 2010).

Accepted as Trioceros ellioti in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). T. ellioti overlaps with T. bitaeniatus in distrubution, and therefore there are occasional mis-identifications. Most sources agree that it prefers more moist habitat and is at higher elevations than T. bitaeniatus.

Calotes rouxii was originally described by Duméril & Bibron, 1837, based on specimens from “India” (Smith 1935). Inger et al. (1984) synonymized C. elliotti Günther, 1864 with C. rouxii Duméril & Bibron, 1837, but the latter species is now being recognized as a distinct, valid species unequivocally (Das 2002).
Riopa pruthi was described by Sharma in 1977 based on material collected from Salem in Tamil Nadu, India. It was transferred to Lygosoma following Greer (1977).
Ateuchosaurus travancoricus was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from the Western Ghats, India. The same author reallocated this species to Ristella in 1871 (Smith 1935).
Cnemaspis kolhapurensis was described based on specimens collected from Kolhapur hills near Kolhapur town in Maharashtra, India by Giri et al. (2009).

Xylophis stenorhynchus was described by Günther in 1875 as Geophys stenorhynchus from the Western Ghats based on specimens from Travancore, India (Smith 1943) that possibly is a location in Anaimalai Hills, Coimbatore district in Tamil Nadu (Gower and Winkler 2007). Gower and Winkler (2007) are of the opinion that X. indicus (treated as a junior synonym of X. stenorhynchus) may be valid, however these authors note that this taxon is still known from only one specimen and that more material is required to evaluate its validity. These authors also described a new species, X. captaini, from material originally assigned to X. stenorhynchus.

Kaestlea palnica was described by Boettger in 1892 as Lygosoma (Leiolopisma) travancoricum var. palnica based on specimens collected from Kodaikanal, Palni Hills, Tamil Nadu. Smith (1935) accorded this form specific status. Species now assigned to Kaestlea have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected the new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.

The  taxonomy of Sibynophis sagittarius and S. subpunctatus is confused. Morgan (1973) in his revision of Sibynophiines, considered S. subpunctatus to be a synonym of S. sagittarius. At present they are considered to represent two separate species (Captain et al. 2004), but due to this historical confusion the distributions of the two species are in need of clarification.

Cnemaspis indraneildasii was described from Gund, North Kanara, Karnataka (Bauer 2002). The forms belonging to Cnemaspis kandiana (Kelaart 1852) (in part) from northern Western Ghats as reported by Smith (1935) are now included under Cnemaspis indraneildasii Bauer, 2002 following Das (2003).  Species boundaries in the C. kandiana complex generally need to be critically re-evaluated. It is likely that C. indraneildasii is a junior synonym of C. goaensis, based on molecular evidence that the two species exhibit "minimal genetic distances" (Sayeed et al. 2018).
Gerrhopilus tindalli was first described by Smith in 1943 from Nilambur, Kerala. Boulenger (1893) misidentified specimens from Nilambur as Typhlops thurstoni (Smith 1943).
Liopeltis calamaria was described by Günther in 1858 as Cyclophis calamaria based on specimens collected from Ceylon [Sri Lanka] (Smith 1943).

Cnemaspis littoralis was described by Jerdon in 1853 and the type locality was given as sea coast of Malabar (Smith 1935). Smith (1935) opined that the type was found in a warehouse and might have been imported to Malabar by human agency.

Grypothyphlops acutus was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril as Onychocephalus acutus in 1844 (Smith 1943). Since then it has been variously included under the genera Typhlops Oppel, 1811, Rhinotyphlops Fitzinger, 1843 and Grypotyphlops Peters, 1881 which came to be included under the genus Typhlops (Smith 1943). Though Das (2003) gave Rhinotyphlops acutus as the accepted nomen for this species basing on Wallach (1994), Wallach (2003) resurrected the genus Grypotyphlops and included this species under it (Wallach and Pauwels 2004).

Mabuya clivicola was described based on three specimens collected from Ponmudi, Thiruvananthapuram District, Kerala (Inger et al. 1984). Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002) this taxon is presently included within Eutropis Fitzinger 1843.

Hemidactylus anamallensis was described as Gecko anamallensis based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, southern India by Günther 1875, it was then placed under the genus Hoplodactylus by Boulenger (1885) (Smith 1935). Smith (1933) placed this species in a distinct genus Dravidogecko based on differences in the digital scansors, and in the preanal pore arrangement. However, based on studies by Russell (1972, 1976, 1979), and Russell and Bauer (1990), the taxon Dravidogecko has been synonymised with Hemidactylus (Bauer and Russell 1995). According to Bansal and Karanth (2010) H. anamallensis is basal to all remaining Hemidactylus, a finding which may warrant revalidation of Dravidogecko for this species (Mahony 2011).
Xylophis captaini was described as new species by Gower and Winkler (2007) from specimens previously assigned to Xylophis stenorhynchus.
Calotes grandisquamis was described by Günther in 1875 basing on a specimen collected from the foot of Canoot Ghat near Mananathavady, in Brahmagherry hills, Kerala, India (Smith 1935).

Cnemaspis sisparensis was described by Theobald in 1876. The taxon Cnemaspis anaikattiensis Mukherjee, Nixon and Bhupathy, 2005 from Anaikatti Hills, Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu is presently synonymized with Cnemaspis sisparensis (Manamendra-Arachi et al. 2007). However, the synonymization requires verification (Giri et al. 2009).  The populations south and north of Palghat Gap require taxonomic re-evaluation.

Psammophilus blanfordanus was first described by Stoliczka in 1871 as Charasia blanfordana basing on specimens from Central India (Smith 1935). This species is very similar, morphologically, to P. dorsalis and may have been misidentified for this in some studies.
Plectrurus guentheri was described as Plectrurus güntheri by Beddome in 1863 based on specimens from Walaghat, near Sisapara Ghat, Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu (Beddome 1863, 1870, Smith 1943).
Oligodon brevicauda was described by Günther in 1862 based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, Western Ghats in Coimbatore District, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943).

Dendrelaphis tristis was described by Daudin in 1803 as Coluber tristis based on the drawings of Dr. Patrick Russell in 1796 based on specimen from "Hyderabad", of present day Andhra Pradesh (Smith 1943). As the type is unavailable, the type locality (by designation of a neotype) has been assigned as Calcutta, India by Rooijen and Vogel (2008). Earlier also included Dendrelaphis schokari (Kuhl, 1820) and Dendrelaphis chairecacos (Boie, 1827) which are presently treated as distinct species (van Rooijen and Vogel 2008, 2009) restricted to Sri Lanka and southern India respectively. Two currently recognized synonyms of Dendrelaphis tristis, Leptophis mankas (Bell, 1826) and Dendrophis maniar (Boie, 1827) cannot be referred to either Dendrelaphis tristis or Dendrelaphis schokari (see Rooijen and Vogel 2009).

Records of this species from southwestern Kerala and Tamil Nadu needs to be verified (Rooijen and Vogel 2009) as these records could refer to D. chairecacos.

Chrysopelea ornata was described by Shaw in 1802 as Coluber ornatus based on specimens collected from Sri Lanka and Java (Smith 1943). Three subspecies, Chrysopelea ornata ornata, Chrysopelea ornata ornatissima and Chrysopelea ornata sinhaleya, are recognized. Further taxonomic work is required to establish whether this wide-ranging snake represents a species complex.

Mocoa bilneata was described by Gray in 1846 based on material from the summit of Nilgiri Hills. Species now assigned to Kaestlea have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected the new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.

The genus Brachyophidium Wall, 1921 is a monotypic genus comprising a single species Brachiophidium rhodogaster Wall, 1921. Smith (1943) included it under the genus Teretrurus Beddome, 1886, however, currently it is placed back under the genus Brachyophidium (Das 2003).
Melanophidium bilineatum was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Waynaad, Kerala (Smith 1943).
Rhinophis sanguineus was described by Beddome in 1863 based on specimens collected from Cherambady in Wayanad hills, Kerala, India  (Beddome 1863, Smith 1943).

Cnemaspis heteropholis was first described from Gund, Uttara Kanara, Karnataka (Bauer 2002, Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007). As no common name for this species is known we propose the name to be Gund Day Gecko.
Ophisops beddomei was first described as Pseudophiops beddomei by Jerdon in 1870 from Brahmagherry Hills in Wayanad, and it was later allocated to the genus Ophisops Ménétries, 1832 (Smith 1935).
Cnemaspis nairi was described based on specimens collected from Ponmudi near Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala (Inger et al. 1984).

The name Typhlops or Indotyphlops ductiliformes is used in a number of field guides and recent checklists (e.g. Khan 2006), although taxonomic sources presently regard this taxon as a junior synonym of Indotyphlops porrectus (Pyron and Wallach 2014, Hedges et al. 2014).

Uropeltis dindigalensis was described as Silybura dindigalensis by Beddome in 1877 based on specimens collected in the Sirumalai hills, near Dindigul, Tamil Nadu, India  (Beddome 1877, 1886, Smith 1943).

Uropeltis phipsonii was described as Silybura phipsonii by Mason in 1888 based on type series collected from the Bombay Ghats between Bombay (=Mumbai) and Pune, Maharashtra, India (Boulenger 1890, Smith 1943). The specific epithet is sometimes erroneously listed as 'phipsoni'. Uropeltis phipsonii has been treated as a synonym of Uropeltis rubrolineatus (Günther,1875) by Gans (1966) and revalidated by Rajendran (1985).

Peltopelor macrolepis was described by Beddome in 1862 as Trimeresurus macrolepis based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills in Western Ghats (Smith 1943). Malhotra and Thorpe (2004) resurrected the genus Peltopelor Günther, 1864 for the species macrolepis, as it is diagnosed by a combination of a long calyculate hemipenis and enlarged head scales.

Lygosoma guentheri was originally described as Eumeces punctatus by Günther in 1864. This name was subsequently found to be preoccupied, and Peters (1879) provided the replacement name Eumeces güntheri. It was later included within the genus Lygosoma (Boulenger 1890, Smith 1935).
Draco dussumieri was first described by Duméril and Bibron in 1837 based on specimens collected from Malabar (present day region of northern Kerala, India) (Smith 1935).

Eutropis gansi was described by Das (1991), based on specimens collected from Kalakkad-Munduthurai Tiger Reserve, Tirunelveli District, Tamil Nadu, India. This species was assigned to the genus Eutropis following the revision of Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002).

Dasia subcaerulea was described by Boulenger in 1891 as Lygosoma subcaeruleum based on a specimen collected from Bodanai-Kannur, Travancore (presently Bodinayakanur in Theni district of Tamil Nadu), India (Smith 1935). Joshua and Sekar (1984) assigned Indian specimens they collected to the Sri Lankan endemic D. haliana, and a number of additional records of this species have since been reported from India (see Wickramasinghe et al. 2011). Examined material of Indian "D. haliana" has recently been found to represent D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011, using the incorrect nomina Dasia halianus and D. subcaeruleum). The specimens collected by Joshua and Sekar (1984) were apparently not preserved and so cannot be examined, and in the absence of evidence to the contrary all records of D. haliana from India are considered to belong instead to D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011).

Cnemaspis jerdonii was described by Theobald in1868, however, no type locality was mentioned in the type description (Smith 1935, Das and Bauer 2000). The taxon scalpensis, which was described from Sri Lanka (Ferguson 1877) and long considered a subspecies of Cnemaspis jerdonii, has been elevated to species level (Wickramasinghe and Munindradasa 2007).  As with the other members of the genus Cnemaspis, populations north and south of the Palghat Gap need taxonomic revalidation.  Species boundaries in the C. kandiana complex generally need to be critically re-evaluated.

Bungarus sindanus was described by Boulenger in 1897 based on specimens collected from Umarkot and Sukkur, Sind, Pakistan (Smith 1943). Presently two distinct subspecies, Bungarus sindanus sindanus Boulenger, 1897 and Bungarus sindanus razai Khan, 1985, are recognized. A third, Bungarus sindanus walli Wall, 1907, has recently been treated as a full species (Wallach et al. 2014, Ahsan and Rahman 2017) and this scheme is tentatively followed here.

Bungarus sindanus is close to or conspecific with B. caeruleus and has widely been treated as a subspecies; while the two species have a reportedly overlapping distribution (Sindaco et al. 2013) this may be an artefact of the difficulty in distinguishing between the two taxa (Wagner et al. 2016) These latter authors assign the sole known Afghan specimen, reported as B. caeruleus, to B. sindanus.

Xylophis perroteti was first described as new species by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in 1854 as Platypteryx perroteti from the Western Ghats based on specimens from Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu. This species is superficially the most distinctive species in the genus, having 13 as opposed to 15 scale rows and being much larger (Whitaker and Captain 2004, Gower and Winkler 2007). It is suggested that a reassessment of the taxonomic status of X. perroteti is required (Gower and Winkler 2007).
Uropeltis liura was first described as Silybura liura by Günther in 1875 based on a specimen collected from Madura Hills (=Meghamalai/High Wavy Mountains), Tamil Nadu, India  (Smith 1943).
Lycodon flavomaculatus was described by Wall in 1907 based on specimens collected from Khirkee, Poona District, Maharashtra (Smith 1943).

Cnemaspis goaensis was described from Ponguinim, Canocona Taluka, South Goa, Goa (Sharma 1976). It is likely that C. indraneildasii is a junior synonym of C. goaensis, based on molecular evidence that the two species exhibit "minimal genetic distances" (Sayeed et al. 2018).

Uropeltis myhendrae was described as Silybura nilgherriensis var. myhendrae by Beddome in 1886 based on type series collected from the Myhendra mountain (=Mahendragiri), Tirunelvelli district, Tamil Nadu, India  (Beddome 1886, Smith 1943). Boulenger (1890) upgraded myhendrae to specific level.
Hemidactylus prashadi was described by Smith in 1935 based on specimens collected from Jog in North Kanara district (presently in Shimoga District) of Karnataka, India (Smith 1935).
Plectrurus aureus Beddome, 1880 is known only from the type locality in Kerala, India (Beddome 1880, Smith 1943).

Cnemaspis beddomei was described by Beddome in 1870 as Gymnodactylus marmoratus from Travancore as the type locality (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).  However, this name was preoccupied by Gymnodactylus marmoratus Dumeril and Bibron, 1836.  It was later renamed as Gymnodactylus beddomei by Theobald in 1876 (Smith 1935).  Species boundaries within the genus Cnemaspis need to be critically re-evaluated.

Lycodon travancoricus was described by Beddome in 1870 as Cercaspis travancoricus basing on specimens collected from Travancore Hills, (presently Ashambu Hills, Kerala) (Smith 1943). Constable (1949) treated this taxon as subspecies of Lycodon aulicus.

Two subspecies are recognized: Ophisops minor minor Deraniyagala, 1971 from Sri Lanka, and Ophisops minor nictans Arnold 1989 from India. Agarwal and Ramakrishnan (2017) found that Sri Lankan and Indian lineages are genetically divergent, and while morphological research has not yet been completed to confirm that two species are involved, Agarwal et al. (2018) provisionally apply the name O. nictans to Indian populations, restricting O. minor to Sri Lanka. Ongoing morphological and molecular research supports recognition of Sri Lankan populations as distinct, but suggests that at least two species may be involved in Sri Lanka alone (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

Fowlea flavipunctatus has been long treated as a subspecies of F. piscator. Literature records of this species and F. flavipunctatus, which occur in sympatry (Zug et al. 2006, Vogel and David 2006) are confused. Vogel and David (2006) provide comments on the taxonomy of the F. flavipunctatus-piscator complex, and divided it into eight taxa. The extreme south Indian and Sri Lankan populations are considered to represent an undescribed species (Vogel and David 2006). The genus as a whole is paraphyletic and in need of revision (Guo et al. 2012).
Cnemaspis wynadensis was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Wayanad.
Ristella beddomii was described by Boulenger in 1887 based on specimens collected from India (Smith 1935). However, the exact type locality within India is unknown (Smith 1935).

Oligodon arnensis was described as Coluber arnensis by Shaw in 1802 basing on specimens collected by Russell from Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh and Arni in North Arcot district of Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943).

Eryx whitakeri was first described by Das in 1991 based on a holotype from Mangalore in Karnataka and paratypes from a few localities in Kerala, Karnataka and Goa (Das 1991). It has often been mistakenly considered as a hybrid between Eryx johnii and Eryx conicus.

Euprepes innotata was originally described by Blanford in 1870 from Pemganga valley, Southeast Berar (presently Penganga valley in Yavatmal district of Maharashtra) (Smith 1935). The species was placed in the genus Mabuia by Boulenger  in 1887. Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002), this taxon was assigned to Eutropis Fitzinger 1843.

Ahaetulla perroteti was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in in 1854 as Psammophis perroteti based on specimens collected from India (Smith 1943). No specific type locality has been assigned so far.

Trimerusurus strigatus was described by Gray in 1842 (Smith 1943) based on specimens collected from Madras Presidency (see Boulenger 1896). The generic assignment of this unusual species is in need of clarification: Kraus et al. (1996), David and Ineich (1999) and Das (2003) treated it as species of Protobothrops, but Herrmann et al. (2004) and Malhotra and Thorpe (2004) suggested removing this species from Protobothrops and to treat it under Trimeresurus sensu stricto. This has generally been followed since (although the taxonomic arrangement proposed by David et al. 2011 reassigns all species in Trimeresurus sensu stricto as generally understood to Craspedocephalus, these authors' Craspedocephalus is identical to the accepted concept of Trimeresurus s.s., and explicitly includes T. strigatus). No genetic data is available, however, and both hypotheses regarding this species' generic assignment should be considered provisional.

Chamaeleo zeylanicus was first described by Laurenti in 1768, the description was based on drawing by Seba (1734, 1; plate 82, fig. 3) which represented a female specimen with no tarsal spur (Smith 1935, Klaver and Böhme 1997). Mertens (1969) restricted the type locality to Ceylon (=Sri Lanka). Differences in scalation suggest that Sri Lankan populations may not be conspecific with the mainland form, but the taxonomy of Asian chameleons has not been investigated to clarify their taxonomic status (Karunarathna et al. 2009).
Lygosoma lineata was described by Gray in 1839 as Chiamela lineata, and later allocated to the genus Lygosoma Gray 1828 by Boulenger in 1887 (Smith 1935).

Uropeltis macrolepis was described by Peters in 1862 as Silybura macrolepis based on a specimen collected from unknown locality in Bombay Hills, Maharashtra, India  (Smith 1943). The publication year is erroneously reported as 1861 (Boulenger 1893, Smith 1943, Das 2003). See Peters (1862). Two subspecies, U. m. macrolepis (Peters, 1862) and U. m. mahabaleshwarensis Chari, 1955 are recognized (Chari 1955).

This widespread species is apparently not monophyletic and so represents a species complex (Das et al. 2008, Barley et al. 2015). Records from Sri Lanka have been found to represent confusion with Eutropis madaraszi and two recently described species, E. austini and E. greeri (Batuwita et al. 2016).

Cnemaspis ornata was described by Beddome, 1870 based on specimens collected from Tirunelvelli, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1935). One or more superficially similar undescribed species of Cnemaspis may potentially have been misidentified as C. ornata (A. Bauer pers. comm. March 2011). Owing to this possibility the populations on both sides of Palghat Gap require taxonomic re-evaluation.
There are two subspecies presently recognized, and their taxonomic status is in need of clarification (R. Vyas pers. comm. 2019).
Typhlops exiguus was described by Jan in 1864 with the type locality mentioned as "East Indies" = "Indes Orientales" (Boulenger 1893). However, there is no mention of this taxon in Smith (1943).
Two subspecies, Coelognathus helenae helenae and C. h. monticollaris, are recognized, and taxonomic research is required to clarify whether C. h. monticollaris warrants recognition as a full species.

Hemidactylus maculatus was described by Duméril and Bibron in 1836 based on specimens collected from Bombay (presently Mumbai, Maharashtra), India (Smith 1935).  The subspecies H. maculatus hunae Deraniyagala, 1937 has recently been elevated to specific status (Bauer et al. 2010) and confined to Sri Lanka following the subsequent description of H. graniticolus (Agarwal et al. 2011). Variation within remaining Indian subpopulations requires further investigation.

Gehyra mutilata was described as Hemidactylus (Peropus) mutilatus by Wiegmann in 1834 based on specimens collected from Manila, Philippines (Smith 1935).  Glaw and Vences (2007) suggested that western Indian Ocean populations, including those from Madagascar, may not be conspecific with true G. mutilata, which has a type locality in the Philippines, however, Rocha et al. (2009) found that samples from Madagascar, the Seychelles and the Mascarenes were genetically indistinguishable from Philippine and mainland Asian populations.

Fisher (1997) and Rocha et al. (2009) demonstrated that there are two deeply divergent clades, and found that the name Gehyra insulensis is available for one of these. Although this name has not been formally resurrected (A.M. Bauer pers. comm. 2011) it is recognized by specialists working on Pacific reptiles, and the Pacific clade is treated separately, as G. insulensis, in these accounts. The taxonomic status of Indian populations has not been evaluated and it is unclear to which lineage they belong (A.M. Bauer pers. comm. 2011), and research is needed into Southeast Asian populations to examine levels of genetic variation (Rocha et al. 2009).

Grismer (2011a) noted that neither the original description of Gehyra butleri (Boulenger 1900) nor a later report of this species from the Cameron Highlands (Smith 1930) provided any diagnostic features that distinguish this species from G. mutilata. Based on this, and his own examination of Gehyra specimens from Peninsular Malaysia and Singapore, Grismer (2011a) synonymized G. butleri within G. mutilata.
This is a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic revision (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
This is a species complex in need of taxonomic revision (S.R. Ganesh and M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
Boiga dightoni was described by Boulenger in 1894 as Dipsas dightoni based on a specimen collected by Mr. S. Dighton from Peermade, Idukki District, Kerala (Boulenger 1894, Smith 1943).

Hemidactylus leschenaultii was described by Duméril and Bibron in 1836 based on specimens collected from Sri Lanka (Smith 1935). In a molecular analysis of South Asian Hemidactylus, Bauer et al. (2010) found that Sri Lankan and Indian samples were conspecific, however this research included only one sample from each country and more comprehensive sampling of Indian populations is required to confirm whether these represent a single species.

Gerrhopilus beddomii was described as Typhlops beddomei by Boulenger in 1890 from hills of south India (Smith 1943). According to Das (2003) beddomei is the correct spelling for the specific name of this taxon.

Cnemaspis indica was described as Goniodactylus indicus by Gray in 1846 based on specimens collected from Madras Presidency (Smith 1935), now mostly in Tamil Nadu, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).  The populations north and south of Palghat Gap should be re-evaluated.  However, for the purposes of this assessment the known distributions are considered to represent C. indica. The record from Nadukani (~300 m asl) in Thrissur Distrct, Kerala (Das and Whitaker 1990) needs validation as it was based on a juvenile specimen from outside the known elevational range of the species.

Rhinophis travancoricus was described by Boulenger in 1892 based on specimens from Vembayam in Thiruvananthapuram district, Kerala, India  (Boulenger 1892, Smith 1943). The common name Tamil Nadu Earth Snake is a misnomer, as this species has been reported from Kerala and the specific epithet 'travancoricus' refers to 'Travancore' as the region where the type locality is present. However, the erstwhile kingdom of Travancore included most of southern Kerala, the Kanyakumari district and some parts of the present day southwestern Tamil Nadu (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm.2011).
Boiga wallachi was described by Das in 1998 based on specimens collected from Nicobar Island, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India (Das 1998).

Eublepharis fuscus was described as a subspecies of Eublepharis macularius Blyth, 1854 by Börner (1981) from 60 km north of Bombay (presently Mumbai). However, this species is a distinct form and allopatric to Eublepharis macularius, hence has been elevated to species status (Das 1997). The taxa belonging to the genus Eublepharis are included under Family Eublepharidae since past 20 years (A.M. Bauer pers. comm. 09 May 2011).

There are two morphologically diagnosable populations of Ophisops leschanaultii in Sri Lanka alone, and these are not expected to be conspecific with Indian material based on preliminary morphological and molecular research (M. Wickramasinghe unpubl. data).

A morphological study of records attributed to this species from India suggests that the Indian records of Dasia hailiana instead represent the Indian endemic D. subcaerulea (Wickramasinghe et al. 2011, using the incorrect nomina Dasia halianus and D. subcaeruleum).

Lygosoma beddomei was described by Boulenger in 1887 based on material from Travancore Hills (Smith 1935). Species now assigned to Kaestlea have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected the new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.
Psammophis longifrons was first described by Boulenger in 1896 based on the head and neck collected from Cuddapah Hills, a location that many authorities feel might be wrong (Smith 1943).

Chalcides pentadactylus is known only from the type locality Kadal Undi, Beypur, in Kerala, India (Smith 1935, Das 2003). As it has not been collected since its original description and the type specimen is lost (Smith 1935) the continued presence of this species in India has been doubted (Venugopal 2010), and it may represent an introduction to this coastal area. S. Bhupathy (in 2004) and I. Das have surveyed in this area but have not recorded this species. Due to the loss of the only known specimen the true identity and origin of this skink, and its correct generic assignment, must await the examination of fresh material (Smith 1935).

Cnemaspis boiei  was described from an imprecise locality ("India") and no extant populations are known.  Limited understanding of variation in the species precludes meaningful comparison with some congeners, and it is possible the name is applicable to one or more species recently described under new names.
Uropeltis broughami was described as Silybura broughami by Beddome in 1878 based on specimens collected in the Sirumalai hills, near Dindigul, Tamil Nadu, India  (Beddome 1878, Smith 1943).

Coluber gracilis was described by Günther in 1862 as Zamenis gracilis (Smith 1943) based on specimens collected from the Western Ghats in Poona, Poona district, Maharashtra (Smith 1943). This species was described as distinct variety (Var. B) of Coluber ventrimaculatus by Günther in 1858 based on specimens collected from India (four individuals collected by W. Masters) and as Coluber gracilis in 1862 after discovery of an additional specimen in Chatham Museum, Fort Pitt purportedly collected from Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan (Günther 1862, Boulenger 1893, Smith 1943). Boulenger (1893) reports six specimens in the British Museum, including one collected by Col. Sykes from India, four specimens by W. Masters, and the type from the Chatham Museum, noted as being from an unknown locality. Despite the doubt that this raises over the assignment of Sindh as the type locality, Günther's account that the species occurs both in India and Pakistan has been accepted by subsequent authors.

Plectrurus perroteti was described by Duméril and Bibron in 1854 based on specimens collected from the Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943). The specific epithet is misspelt as perrotetii (see McDiarmid et al. 1999).

Uropeltis beddomii was first described by Günther in 1862 based on specimens collected in the Anaimalai hills, Tamil Nadu, India  (Günther 1862, Smith 1943). Sometimes the specific epithet is misspelt as "beddomei" (as in Smith 1943).

Dendrelaphis pictus was described as Coluber ahaetulla by Linnaeus in 1758. It was renamed Coluber pictus by Gmelin in 1789 (Smith 1943) and later reassigned to Dendrelaphis Boulenger 1890, a genus characterized by slender diurnal species that are predominantly arboreal (Rooijen and Vogel 2008a). There has been an ambiguity with regards to the systematics of this genus and the species involved therein, including a number of decisions to synonymize species within D. pictus made without adequate justification (see Rooijen and Vogel 2008a).

D. pictus is a recognized species complex, and many members of the genus have been considered junior synonyms or subspecies at one time or another (Vogel and van Rooijen 2008a). In recent years efforts have been made to clarify this situation, and a number of species have been removed from synonymy or described based on populations originally assigned to D. pictus. These include D. inornatus (including the former subspecies D. p. intermedius and D. p. timorensis) (How et al. 1996), D. nganonsonensis (Ziegler and Vogel, 1999), D. hollinrakei (Lazell 2002), D. haasi (Vogel and van Rooijen 2008a), D. marenae and D. grismeri (Vogel and van Rooijen 2008b).

This account follows Vogel and van Rooijen (2008b) in regarding D. pictus as a widespread form ranging from India to China and Lombok in central Indonesia, consisting of morphologically distinct mainland and Sundaland forms between which genetic exchange cannot be ruled out (Vogel and van Rooijen 2008b). Research on Chinese and remaining Indochinese populations is underway (Vogel and van Rooijen 2011), and further investigation is required to establish whether the mainland and island forms identified by Vogel and van Rooijen (2008b) should be recognized as distinct species. Additionally, the form that was earlier referred to this species from the Western Ghats in southern India is now recognized as Dendrelaphis ashoki (Vogel and van Rooijen 2011); these authors also resurrected D. andamensis, endemic to the Andaman Islands, from synonymy with D. pictus. A third form recognized by these authors, D. proarchos from northeastern India and Myanmar, is here retained within the synonymy of D. pictus until the nominate form is formally redescribed, as this proposed species exhibits a continuous distribution with D. pictus and morphological differences are difficult to reliably diagnose (P. Uetz pers. comm. May 2011). It is therefore difficult to establish the limits of either species' distribution within the range historically assigned to D. pictus. Additionally, gene flow between D. pictus and D. proarchos cannot be ruled out (Vogel and van Rooijen 2011), and so for consistency with Vogel and van Rooijen (2008b), which treated the two forms they identified within D. pictus as representing a single species on the same basis, D. proarchos should be considered a junior synonym of D. pictus pending further investigation to verify its specific validity.

It was regarded as a polytypic species as evidenced by the number of subspecies and varieties recognized (Vogel and Rooijen, 2008).
Calliophis melanurus was described by Shaw in 1802 based on the drawings of the snake from Nerva, Bengal (Smith 1943). The exact location of the type locality could not be traced.

Oligodon travancoricus Beddome, 1877, misspellt as Oligodon travancorica, was described as Oligodon travancoricum basing on specimens collected from south Travancore mountains (Smith 1943). It agrees very closely with sympatric congener, Oligodon venustus (Jerdon, 1853) with which it was synonymized by Wall (1914) although he changed his opinion in 1923 (Wall 1923). However, basing on differences in the hemipenis structure both the taxa are considered distinct (Smith 1943, Green 2010).

Hemidactylus giganteus was described by Stoliczka in 1871 based on specimens collected from Godavari River valley near Bhadrachalam, Andhra Pradesh (Smith 1935).  There is potential confusion between this species and H. aaronbaueri, and the identity of historical records of H. giganteus from within the range of this more recently-described species requires verification.

Bungarus caeruleus was described as Pseudoboa caerulea by Schneider in 1801 based on the collections and description by Dr. Patrick Russell from Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh (Smith 1943). Bungarus sindanus is close to or conspecific with B. caeruleus and has widely been treated as a subspecies; while the two species have a reportedly overlapping distribution (Sindaco et al. 2013) this may be an artefact of the difficulty in distinguishing between the two taxa (Wagner et al. in prep.). These latter authors assign the sole known Afghan specimen, reported as B. caeruleus, to B. sindanus.

Hemidactylus brookii was described by Gray, 1845 based on specimens collected from Borneo (Smith 1935). The traditional species concept for H. brookii is a very widespread, pantropical lizard, and its taxonomic history is confused (Bauer et al. 2010; see this paper and Mahony 2011 for a taxonomic discussion). New World members of this lineage were elevated to species status (as H. haitianus and H. leightoni) by Powell et al. (1996); H. haitanus has also been confirmed as the lineage represented on Bioko Island, Equatorial Guinea (Carranza and Arnold 2006), implying that this species likely represents a historical introduction to the West Indies. H. haitianus and H. leightoni have subsequently been synonymized within H. angulatus (Rösler and Glaw 2010). Carranza and Arnold (2006) elevated African H. angulatus, previously a subspecies of H. brookii, to specific status, confining H. brookii to Asia, and confirmed that H. angulatus, H. leightoni and H. haitianus are only distantly-related to H. brookii. Bauer et al. (2010) examined the taxonomic status of Asian forms and raised the taxon parvimaculatus Deraniyagala, 1953 to specific status, reporting it from south of Palghat Gap in India, and from Sri Lanka. This is probably also the form that occurs in the Comoros and Mascarene Islands based on genetic similarity to Sri Lankan populations (Rocha et al. 2005, Bauer et al. 2010) (although work in press suggests that some of these presumed H. parvimaculatus may be referrable to H. malcolmsmithi - A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019).

Rösler and Glaw (2010) subsequently removed the Indonesian H. tenkatei from synonymy with H. brookii on morphological grounds. Mahony (2011) synonymized the Burmese form H. subtriedroides, treated as a synonym of H. brookii by Bauer et al. (2010), with H. tenkatei. This action was subsequently disputed by Kathriner et al. (2014), but the status of H. subtriedroides remains unresolved (Lajmi et al. 2016). Following Zug et al. (2007) the Indian population previously treated as H. mahendrai is included in the synonymy of H. brookii by Bauer et al. (2010) and (provisionally, pending examination of type material) by Mahony (2011). The distributions of H. brookii and H. parvimaculatus in India remain unclear. A comprehensive review of all Indian taxa presently included within H. brookii is urgently required (Bauer et al. 2011).

Following this complex series of taxonomic changes, Mahony (2011) reexamined type specimens of H. brookii and redescribed this species based on two of the three syntypes (the third being found by these authors' examination to represent H. tenkatei). On nomenclatural grounds, Mahony (2011) retained Gecko tytleri within the synonymy of H. brookii. This author also tentatively retained H. murrayi from Gujurat as a junior synonym of H. brookii in the absence of comparative material to confirm its specific identity, but noted that based on the original description it is "very unlikely to be conspecific with H. brookii s.s.". He also provisionally included H. luzonensis (considered a probable junior synonym of H. tenkatei by Rösler and Glaw 2010) within the synonymy of H. brookii until Philippine specimens can be examined to verify their identity. Two remaining names previously treated as synonyms of H. brookii, H. gleadowi and H. kushmorensis, were resurrected for Pakistani members of the brookii complex found to represent distinct species (Mahony 2011).

Lajmi et al. (2016) conducted a combined morphological and molecular analysis of the H. brookii complex sensu lato, focusing particularly on delimiting species in India. These results suggest that 5-7 major clades exist within the complex, five of which appear to correspond to species described or resurrected in the above-described studies, and one of which contains five described species. The authors resurrect the name H. murrayi for the remaining clade based on comparison with material from the Gujurat type locality; they propose that this may be a senior synonym for the taxon described by Rösler and Glaw (2010) as H. tentakei. Their sequence data and comparison with Bornean material of H. brookii suggests that this name is likely to be applicable to the form widespread through mainland Southeast Asia, and that Bauer et al. (2010) were in error to consider this taxon conspecific with the Borneo type series. This account provisionally retains the name H. brookii for this taxon, as the Indian study did not conduct morphological analysis of Southeast Asian records to confirm their identity. Uetz (2017) noted that the status of H. murrayi is uncertain as the type series has been lost.

The species has also been recently placed in the typhlopid genera Typhlops and Typhlina (see Wallach 2009 for a complete synonymy). Following Wallach (2009), Typhlops khoratensis is considered a junior synonym of Indotyphlops braminus. Typhlops fletcheri has widely been treated as a junior synonym of Indotyphlops braminus, but examination of the holotype suggests that it is likely to represent a distinct species (A. Wynn pers. comm. to P. Uetz, in Uetz 2019). It is treated as valid (as I. fletcheri) without comment by Hedges et al. (2014), but as it has not been formally resurrected this account follows Pyron and Wallach (2014) in retaining it within I. braminus pending further taxonomic research.

This species has also been placed in the genus Ophites, although this has not gained wide acceptance. Lycodon capucinus is often synonymized with or treated as a subspecies of this species, but they are here considered as distinct species following Taylor (1965) and David and Vogel (1996). Lycodon aulicus may itself represent a complex of species (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. May 2011).

Eurylepis poonaensis was described by Sharma (1970) as Eumeces poonaensis based on a specimen collected from Katraj Ghat, Poona (now Pune District), Maharashtra, India. Griffith et al. (2000) and Schmitz et al. (2004) opin that Eurylepis poonaensis (Sharma 1970) belongs to Eurylepis taeniolatus group.  Further molecular work is needed to establish the relationship between this species and E. taeniolatus (Griffith et al. 2000, M.S. Khan pers. comm.)

The taxonomic history of Ahaetulla anomala was discussed by Mahopatra et al. (2017), who elevated it to specific status from within Ahaetulla nasuta and redescribed it, clarifying its distribution. Subspecific divisions within A. nasuta remain in need of clarification, as a number may represent distinct species and multiple varieties appear to exist within Sri Lanka - the type locality - alone (Deepak et al. 2019). This species complex is presently under revision (Achyuthan pers. comm. 2019).

Trimerusurus malabaricus was described by Jerdon in 1854 as Trigonocephalus malabaricus  based on specimens collected from different localities in Western Ghats (Smith 1943). Coluber gramineus has long been considered the type species of the taxonomically complex genus Trimeresurus (David et al. 2011), as the original type species T. viridis has long been considered a synonym. Investigation of this assignment by David et al. (2011) indicated that this was incorrect and that T. viridis (a combination that hasn't been used to describe a valid species since its original description in 1861), is instead a junior synonym of the Timorese species T. insularis. This recognition alters the generic identity of several taxa within the Trimeresurus genus complex, including T. malabaricus, and David et al. (2011) therefore assign T. malabaricus to Craspedocephalus (treated by these authors as a subgenus but more commonly as a full genus). This taxonomy does not, to date, appear to have gained broad acceptance, and this account retains T. malabaricus within Trimeresurus.

Teretrurus sanguineus was described as Plectrurus sanguineus by Beddome in 1867 based on specimens collected near Pollachi (as Ponachi) in Anaimalai hills, Tamil Nadu, India  (Beddome 1867, Smith 1943).

This species was described within the genus Vipera Laurenti, 1768 with the specific epithet russelii (Smith 1943), but was assigned to Daboia Gray, 1842 with the specific epithet russelli (Obst 1983, Hermann et al. 1992). This was corrected to russelii by Adler et al. (2000). The number of recognized subspecies of this wide-ranging snake, which was considered to have a heavily disjunct distribution in Southeast Asia, is variable, but six are traditionally accepted (Thorpe et al. 2007). Morphological analysis suggests that only two distinct forms exist, one (D. r. russelii) restricted to the Indian subcontinent and the other (for which the name with priority is D. r. siamensis) found in the remainder of the snake's range (Wūster et al. 1992). These authors refrained from elevating D. r. siamensis to a full species due to the lack of molecular research to support this conclusion. More recently, using both molecular and morphological data, Thorpe et al. (2007) found strong support for this conclusion and recognized two distinct species, D. russelii (incorporating the former subspecies D. r. pulchella and D. r. nordicus as well as D. r. russelii) and D. siamensis (incorporating D. r. limitis, D. r. sublimitis and D. r. formosensis). Due to low divergence between members of each lineage, Thorpe et al. (2007) do not recognize distinct subspecies of either form.

Examination of specimens from throughout this snake's range in Sri Lanka, and those from India, suggests that Hypnale hypnale consists of only a single morphologically diagnosable species despite its wide range (Maduwage et al. 2009). These authors designated a neotype and fix the type locality as Castle Rock in Karnataka, as the originally given type locality in "Levant, Egypt, Arabia" is "obviously incorrect"; referred Ancistrodon millardi, H. ceylonensis and Trimeresurus affinis to the synonymy of H. hypnale; and removed H. zara from synonymy. Maduwage et al. (2009) note that a previous suggestion that the type locality had been restricted to Sri Lanka is in error, but that it is not possible to tell whether the original specimen was taken in India or Sri Lanka.
Hemidactylus reticulatus was described by Beddome (1870) based on a specimen collected from Kollegal, Karnataka (Smith 1935).
Uropeltis ellioti was described as Siloboura ellioti by Gray in 1858 based on specimens collected near Madras (=Chennai), Tamil Nadu, India  (Gray 1858, Boulenger 1893, Smith 1943).
Typhlops thurstoni was first described by Boettger in 1890 based on specimens collected from Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943).

Some authors consider Hemiphyllodactylus insularis, whose description involved limited comparison with related species, to be a synonym of Hemiphyllodactylus typus Bleeker, 1860. Although Kluge (2001) recognized it as valid he did so without explanation, and its status remained unclear until it was formally revalidated and redescribed by Zug (2010). In this author's scheme, all bisexual "Hemiphyllodactylus typus" from the Philippines correspond to H. insularis.  In this author's scheme, all bisexual "Hemiphyllodactylus typus" from the Philippines correspond to H. insularis. Grismer et al. (2013) subsequently examined the systematics of this group through integrative (both morphological and molecular) analysis and rejected this concept, instead restricting the name H. insularis to a population from western Mindanao.

The taxonomy of this wide-ranging species is presently under revision (P. Wagner pers. comm. July 2012). Until this work is published, this account follows the concept defined in the recent revision of Mediannikov et al. (2012). This treats Agama agama as an essentially West African endemic, with A. bocourti as a partial synonym (remaining subpopulations of this former species being assigned to A. africana - J.-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012).

Cryptoblepharus boutonii as traditionally defined has numerous subspecies, most of which have been treated as full species by many workers, as has been supported for the Australasian region using both morphological and molecular techniques (Horner and Adams 2007, Horner 2007), and possibly also for C. b. aldabrae from Aldabra in the Seychelles (S. Rocha pers. comm. June 2011). The entire complex was revised and 54 species defined by Horner (2007).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

This species is known to be paraphyletic with respect to Madascincus arenicola and M. stumpffi, but is here treated as a single species following Miralles et al. (2011) on the basis that the northern (unnamed) and western (M. polleni) clades are morphologically indistinguishable and further work is required to clarify species delimitation in this group. The relationship between M. polleni and M. intermedius, morphologically indistinguishable forms both originally described from western Madagascar and with similar documented ranges, is in need of resolution (Miralles et al. 2011). M. intermedius is provisionally treated here as a junior synonym of M. polleni following Miralles et al. (2011); however, it has been suggested based on unpublished data that M. intermedius may itself be a complex of three or five distinct species (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). M. stumpffi, tentatively synonymized with M. polleni by Glaw and Vences (2007), is here treated as a distinct species on the basis of its monophyly and morphological distinctiveness (Andreone and Greer 2002, Miralles et al. 2011), despite relatively poor support for its recognition as a clade distinct from "M. polleni" (Miralles et al. 2011).
Research is needed to clarify whether records from the two known localities represent the same species (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011).

The recently-described Phelsuma ravenala is genetically nested within populations presently assigned to P. dubia, and further research is needed to clarify the status of both taxa (Rocha et al. 2009). Most subpopulations along the east coast of Madagascar are provisionally considered to belong to P. ravenala (Raxworthy et al. 2007) The subpopulation from Antsalova is genetically distinct (Rocha et al. 2009).

Vences et al. (2004) supported the recognition of Hemidactylus platychephalus as a valid species distinct from H. mabouia and confirmed its presence in Madagascar, where it corresponds to the H. mabouia of Glaw and Vences (1994). At least three distinct, geographically discrete lineages have been identified within East African populations of this species, suggesting that this may be a species complex (Rocha et al. 2010).
Otocryptis beddomii was first described by Boulenger in 1885 basing on specimens collected from Sivagiri Ghats in Cardamom Hills in Southern Kerala (Smith 1935).

The type of Barkudia insularis was long considered lost, and records from Waltair in Visakhapatnam were assigned to this species, then considered a monotypic genus, by multiple authors. The rediscovery of the holotype by Das and Dattagupta (1997) allowed comparison of the Visakhapatnam material with the the type. Based on this comparison, Das (1999) determined that the material from Waltair is not conspecific with B. insularis. This author confirmed the assignment of the neglected name Anguis melanosticta for this population and transferred the species to Barkudia.

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all the banded iguanas were lumped as a single species. The Fiji Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula) is now recognized as distinct from the Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus). Most previous references pertaining to iguanas in central Fiji are now attributed to B. bulabula.

Morphological data from recent surveys suggest there may be more than one taxa within the bulabula group. On two islands north of Vanua Levu (Mali and Cikobia), iguanas show marked variation in adult body size and some scale counts when compared to southern populations, for example, Makodroga and Kadavu. However, more samples and DNA analysis is needed to develop detailed comparisons (R. Fisher and P. Harlow pers. comm. 2011).

Conolophus marthae was recently described. No prior reference exists in the taxonomic literature as the species was not known before its description (Gentile and Snell 2009). The description was based on morphological, genetic, and behavioural diagnostic traits. The holotype is a free-living adult male tagged with a subcutaneous electronic marker, branded, and released. Further genetic evidence supporting separate taxonomic status of the Galápagos Pink Land Iguana prior to the species description is found in Gentile et al. 2009 and Tzika et al. 2008. Gentile et al. (2009) disclaims the name ‘‘rosada’’ for nomenclatural purposes (Articles 8.2 and 8.3, International Code of Zoological Nomenclature 1999).

The species is sometimes not easily separated morphologically from Ctenosaura pectinata. The typical black coloration can be confused with the southern C. pectinata clade, but males and females tend to be smaller. Based on genetic data, Zarza et al. (2008) suggested that the southern portion of the distribution of C. pectinata belongs to the C. acanthura clade. However, with a more complete and inclusive analysis, the limits of the distribution of both species is maintained as previously known, where C. acanthura is located north of the Tehuantepec Isthmus, México, and C. pectinata to the south (Zarza et al. 2019). Genetically, populations from Cuicatlán in the state of Hidalgo, México (Canseco-Márquez and Gutiérrez-Mayén 2010), correspond to C. pectinata (Zarza et al. 2008, 2019).

There has been considerable debate of the specific states of the San Esteban Spiny-tailed Iguana, and it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura hemilopha hemilopha (part, Lowe and Norris 1955) or Ctenosaura hemilopha conspicuosa (Lowe and Norris 1955).

The Ctenosaura hemilopha complex has been separated and lumped variously over time. The complex includes C. hemilopha, C. macrolopha, C. conspicuosa and C. nolascensis, and noted at the species or subspecies level (Grismer 1999a, 2002; Davy et al. 2011). Ctenosaura insulana, from Isla Cerralvo, is now recognized as part of the C. hemilopha species (Grismer 1999a, 2002).

Ctenosaura macrolopha has been considered as part of the Ctenosaura hemilopha complex. This complex has been separated and lumped variously over time and includes C. hemilopha, C. macrolopha, C. conspicuosa and C. nolascensis, and noted at the species or subspecies level (Grismer 1999, 2002). C. macrolopha has a 20-km linear north-south hybridization area with C. pectinata in the southern part of its distribution, where hybrids can be recognized by their mix of characters from both species (Zarza et al. 2008).

There has been considerable debate over the species status of the Nolasco Spiny-tailed Iguana, and it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura hemilopha hemilopha (Lowe and Norris 1955) or Ctenosaura hemilopha nolascensis (Smith 1972). The iguana was most recently recognized at the species level by Grismer (1999a). Genetic components of two lineages have been detected within the island (Cryder 1999, Davy et al. 2010, Reynoso et al. 2010).

Based on mitochondrial and nuclear DNA sequences, Zarza et al. (2008) suggested that the southern portion of the distribution of Ctenosaura pectinata belongs to the Ctenosaura acanthura clade. However, with a more complete and inclusive analysis, the limits of the distribution of both species is maintained as previously known, where C. acanthura is located north of the Tehuantepec Isthmus and C. pectinata to the south (Zarza et al. 2019). Additionally, the authors suggest this species should be split based on three different molecular and geographically concordant clades. The name Ctenosaura brachylopha can be resurrected to name northeastearn populations (originally described by Bailey 1928). Ctenosaura pectinata will remain for the central and eastern populations, and a new species will be described for the southern populations with further morphological data in progress. For the time being, the assessment of the species considers the standing taxonomy for C. pectinata, and evaluates its status throughout the entire distribution.

Morphological data places Sauromalus klauberi as sister to S. slevini, with that clade being sister to S. ater (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data places it with peninsular S. ater (Petren and Case 2002). Sauromalus klauberi was designated as a subspecies of S. ater by Soulé and Sloan (1966) without comment until Murphy (1983) elevated it back to species status. The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998).

Morphological data places Sauromalus slevini as sister to S. klauberi, with that clade being sister to S. ater (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data places it as sister to a clade containing both S. klauberi and populations of S. ater from the southern Baja California peninsula (Petren and Case 2002). Sauromalus slevini was designated as a subspecies of S. ater by Robinson (1974) without comment until Etheridge (1982) elevated it back to species status. The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998).

The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998). Morphological data places Sauromalus varius as sister to all other Sauromalus (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data groups S. varius in a clade with S. hispidus (Petren and Case 1997, 2002).

Hemidactylus frenatus was first described by Dumeril and Bibron in 1836 based on specimens from Java (Brygoo 1991). Fitzinger (1826) used the name Hemidactylus javanicus but as no description or diagnosis was provided, the name is considered a nomen nudum (Bauer 1994).

Mazuch et al. (2016) resurrected the name H. fragilis Calabrisi, 1915 for populations from northeast Africa which these authors recognized as a separate species, and this scheme is followed here.
Probably represents a complex of species (Bruna et al. 1996).

Following conventional usage the name Hemidactylus garnotii is used here for a widespread Asian, Indian Ocean and Oceanian species. Zug et al. (2007), in applying this concept, nevertheless caution that molecular analysis is necessary to confirm that Asian records are referrable to H. garnotti (whose type locality is Tahiti) following the recognition of the morphologically similar but karyotypically distinct H. vietnamensis and H. stejnegeri from this region.

This species has sometimes been treated as a synonym of Gehyra oceanica following Burt and Burt (1932); although most subsequent authors have continued to recognize G. vorax as valid, this was not systematically confirmed until combined morphological and molecular work by Flecks et al. (2012). This work also removed G. marginata and (by implication) G. membranacruralis from synonymy with G. vorax and assigned populations from Vanuatu and the Loyalty Islands to a new species, G. georgpotthasti, essentially confining G. vorax sensu stricto to Fiji.

Amarasinghe et al. (2015) revised Sitana ponticeriana, removing S. deccanensis from synonymy and describing two new species - S. bahiri and S. devakai - from Sri Lanka. Subsequently, Deepak et al. (2018) suggested that S. bahiri should be considered a junior synonym of S. ponticeriana, citing morphological and molecular evidence reported in previous papers that suggested "extensive overlap between S. ponticeriana and S. bahiri". Confusingly, Deepak et al. (2016b), the paper they cite in support of the morphological similarity, makes no reference to the two taxa being difficult to diagnose morphologically, describes distinct differences in dewlap size, and provides distribution records for S. bahiri that appear not to correspond to the known range of the species recognized under this name by Amarasinghe et al. (2015) (but may represent records of "Sitana cf. bahiri", a genetically similar form that Deepak et al. 2016a explicitly refrained from referring to S. bahiri). An earlier paper (Deepak et al. 2016a) states "Sitana bahiri from Sri Lanka has a bilobed hemipenis which has very different micro-ornamentation compared to its sister species Sitana ponticeriana" and also reports differences in dewlap size, which they consider an important diagnostic character for this genus. Due to this confusion, it is unclear whether the sequences referred to by Deepak and Karanth (2018) correspond to the original concept of S. bahiri. As Deepak et al. (2018) provided no novel data to resolve this confusion, S. bahiri is here treated as a valid species pending further taxonomic research.

Arnold (1986) considered Trapelus jayakari to be a junior synonym of T. flavimaculatus. This paper, a checklist, provides no justification for this action and does not take formal taxonomic action, so this concept is not followed here. Subsequent confusion over the validity of this taxon may be responsible for the lack of recent information on this species, as later authors may have considered it within T. flavimaculatus (S. Anderson pers. comm. June 2012).

This species has five subspecies:
M. moreletii moreletii Bocourt, 1871
M. moreletii fulvus Bocourt, 1871
M. moreletii rafaeli (Hartweg & Tihen, 1946)
M. moreletii salvadorensis (Hartweg & Tihen, 1946)
M. moreletii temporalis (Hartweg & Tihen, 1946)

Subspecies:
C. calyptratus calcarifer Peters, 1871.

A number of subspecies of Chamaeleo dilepis (C. d. dilepis, C. d. idjwiensis, C. d. isabellinus, C. d. martensi, C. d. petersii, C. d. ruspolii) are recognised, partly due to morphological variation across the species' very large geographic range (Klaver and& Böhme 1997, Neças 2004). The validity of these subspecies is unclear and a detailed taxonomic revision of the species complex would be useful. A preliminary phylogenetic analysis suggest there is species level diversity within C. dilepis (Main et al. 2018). Included in the C. dilepis species complex are C. roperi and C. quilensis, but their taxonomic status also requires further investigation. Tilbury (2018) considers all of the above-mentioned taxa, as well as C. angusticoronatus, as variants of a polymorphic C. dilepis.

The correct familial placement of this species and genus (a mono-specific genus) is under debate. Some authors treat it under Colubridae, others consider it a member of the Homalopsidae, and yet others prefer to place it under Natricidae (Zaher et al. 2009). The latter treatment is followed here, although the relationships within the Natricidae are not yet fully resolved.
This species is the only member of its genus.

Boiga forsteni was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in 1854 as Trigylphodon forsteni based on a specimen collected from unknown locality (Smith 1943). Four distinct colour morphs of this species have been recognized from Odisha, India, and variation within B. forsteni both in Odisha and elsewhere suggests that the taxonomy of this species warrants investigation (Mohapatra et al. 2010). More than seven colour morphs have since been identified in India, but its taxonomy remains unstudied (P. Mohapatra pers. comm.)

Independent molecular markers suggest A. javanicus includes two species: the first occurring in Thailand, West and East Malayia, North Sumatra and Riau, the second in Jambi and South Sumatra, Java and Kalimanatan (Sanders et al. in review).

This is a species with a taxonomically complex recent history. Recent research has shown the presence of several cryptic species (Trape et al. 2012, Bates and Broadley 2018). The Egyptian population has been split off as Dasypeltis bazi (Saleh and Sarhan 2016). Subsequently, Bates and Broadley (2018) described D. taylori from northern Somalia and D. arabica from Saudi Arabia and Yemen, both from material previously assigned to D. scabra. Dasypeltis scabra sensu stricto is widely distributed from the Cape through East African savannas to Sudan, South Sudan and Ethiopia in the north (Bates and Broadley 2018). For consistency with the lineage-based species concept applied by Bates and Broadley (2018) these authors recognized the diagnosably distinct form originally described as Dasypeltis scabra loveridgei (previously treated as a synonym of D. s. scabra) from Namibia as a full species.

This species was described as Dendrelaphis calligastra, and this is the form of the name that is most widely-used within Australian literature. The use of calligaster follows Boulenger (1894), who changed the gender of the species name in accordance with the masculine generic name Dendrophis (calligaster being masculine - P. Uetz and G. Vogel pers. comm. 2017) without comment.

The taxonomy of Dendrelaphis snakes has long been poorly-resolved, and has further been confused in the Australo-Papuan region by varied taxonomic treatments involving as many as 28 nominal taxa (species, subspecies and varieties) (van Rooijen et al. 2015). Dendrelaphis calligaster alone was recognized as containing six subspecies by Meise and Hennig (1932), all which were subsequently treated as full species (see discussion in van Rooijen et al. 2015). While recognizing that the status of many of these taxa was uncertain, Cogger et al. (1983) synonymized these taxa and D. lineolatus within D. calligaster; two of these (D. salomonis and D. papuensis) were revalidated the following year by McDowell (1984).

Van Rooijen et al. (2015) attempted the most comprehensive morphological revision of Australo-Papuan Dendrelaphis to date, based on a sample of 171 museum specimens from New Guinea, Australia and Palau and including type specimens for 20 of the nominal taxa (no types surviving for four others, and the remainder being examined based on photographs as the specimens were unavailable). This work revalidated Dendrelaphis lineolatus as a species distinct from D. calligaster, confirmed the validity of D. papuensis, and resynonymized D. salomonis within D. calligaster. In common with Cogger (1983) van Rooijen et al. (2015) caution that D. calligaster is likely to be a species complex, and that further studies are required to clarify divisions within this group and the status of D. salomonis. The status of D. c. distinguendus is unresolved as the holotype was destroyed in World War II; van Rooijen et al. (2015) provisionally elect to follow Cogger (1983) in considering this form a junior synonym of D. calligaster, but note morphological differences indicated in the description.
Dendrelaphis grandoculis was described by Boulenger in 1890 as Dendrophis grandoculis based on specimens collected from Thirunelvelli Hills and Coonoor Ghats, Tamil Nadu, India (Smith 1943).

Van Rooijen et al. (2015) revised the taxonomy of Australo-Papuan Dendrelaphis, removing D. striolatus (long considered a subspecies) from synonymy and assigning the majority of New Guinean records to a previously cryptic taxon, for which they determined the name with priority to be D. macrops. Additional records previously assigned to varieties of D. punctulatus (Meyer, 1874) were determined on the basis of the original descriptions (the types having been destroyed) to represent D. lineolatus (van Rooijen et al. 2015), which these authors recognize as a species distinct from D. calligaster. Based on the original description, the holotype having been lost, these authors also determine that the name Dendrelaphis olivacea Macleay, 1878 is "unambiguously" a junior synonym of D. punctulatus.

authority: Slowinski, Pawar, Win, Thin, Tun, Gyi, Oo & Tun, 2001

taxonomicNotes: The original holotype of this species has now been redescribed as M. chanardi ( David and Pauwels 2004).
This species and Ninia celata were described from specimens labelled as Ninia atrata.

This is a recognized species complex whose taxonomy has been considered problematic (David et al. 2011). These authors determined that this species was described from Bangladesh, rather than Thailand as previously proposed, and recognized Southeast Asian populations as the distinct species Oligodon fasciolatus (with which they synonymized the former subspecies O. cyclurus smithi and O. c. superfluens). These authors also removed Oligodon kheriensis from western Nepal and adjacent India as a distinct species.

A specimen reported by Liang (2003) as Oligodon cyclurus may in fact be conspecific with the enigmatic Simotes trinotatus, known from a single specimen and long synonymized ("clearly" erroneously based on an examination of the specimen - David and Vogel 2012) within O. purpurascens (David and Vogel 2012).
This species could be part of a species complex (G. Vogel pers. comm.).

Subspecies:
M. intestinalis intestinalis (Laurenti, 1768)
M. intestinalis lineata (Gray in Gray & Hardwicke, 1835 )
M. intestinalis bilineata (Peters, 1881)
M. intestinalis everetti (Boulenger 1896)
M. intestinalis philippina (Günther, 1864)
M. intestinalis suluensis (Steindachner, 1891)
M. intestinalis thepassi (Bleeker, 1859).

Harvey et al. (2000) notes that this species is part of a complex. These authors identified three, widely-accepted, species within the Indonesian range of the Morelia amethistina complex:, Morelia tracyae (northwestern Halmahera), Morelia nauta (Tanimbar Islands) and Morelia clastolepis (Ambon, Seram and most likely from the islands Haruku and Saparua). Taxonomic uncertainty in Morelia amethistina remains with regard to northern and southern populations in New Guinea and those from the Aru Islands (M. Auliya, pers. comm. 2010). Australian populations have been referred to the resurrected Morelia kinghorni (Harvey et al. 2000), however, Cogger (2014) notes that these authors did not provide a diagnosis. While accepting that Australian records are likely to be specifically distinct from M. amethistina, Cogger (2014) elects to retain kinghorni as a junior synonym until it has been fully diagnosed and the appropriate status of Liasis clarki resolved. This taxon was described from Murray Island and assigned "arbitrarily" (Cogger 2014) to M. amethistina by Harvey et al. 2000; should it instead be referable to M. kinghorni the name Morelia clarki (Barbour, 1914) would have priority.

Jiang and Zhao (1983) described a subspecies R. n. pentasupralabialis for the specimens from Sichuan and Yunnan, China. Subsequently, based on a morphological comparison, Zhao (1995) give a specific rank for this taxon, as R. pentasupralabialis. Therefore R. nuchalis is a monotypic species now.
This species is part of the Tantilla calamarina species group (Wilson 1999, Canseco-Márquez et al. 2007).

Because of the wide distribution of this species, many herpetologists believe that this is a species complex (Das 2002).

Gowri Shankar et al. (in press, 2021) confirmed this using molecular and morphological analyses, and proposed four distinct lineages;

  • Ophiophagus CS1 "Western Ghats"
  • Ophiophagus CS2 "Indo-China"
  • Ophiophagus CS3 "Indo-Malay"
  • Ophiophagus CS4 "Luzon"

This species has five subspecies:
M. dissoleucus dissoleucus (Cope, 1860)
M. dissoleucus dunni (Barbour, 1923)
M. dissoleucus melanogenys (Cope, 1860)
M. dissoleucus meridensis (Roze, 1989)
M. dissoleucus nigrirostris (Schmidt, 1955).
Taxonomic research is recommended on this species, which has not been subjected to modern taxonomic assessment and superficially resembles the black morph of Lycodon nympha.

This may be a species complex, within which distributional boundaries are not known. It is possible that records from Wallacean islands may not represent this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2017). Two species (D. leucurus and D. novaeguineae) are currently recognized for the Philippines, but the distributional boundary between the two is unclear. Records from Simeulue off the coast of Sumatra, which Greer (1985) remarked would represent a significant westward range extension if verified, were described as the new species D. tebai by Das and Lim (2009).

Genetic data analysed by Rocha et al. (2009) and Gehring et al. (2013) places Phelsuma comorensis in the P. lineata complex. P. comorensis likely represents a separate dispersal event from the radiation of the four other Comoran Phelsuma species (Harmon et al. 2008)

Anolis cristifer was originally considered to be a subspecies of A. pentaprion, based on a single male specimen the characteristics of which appeared to fall within the variations shown by southern populations of A. pentaprion (Smith 1968). It was elevated to species status based on distinct differences in scalation by Köhler and Acevedo (2004) and Köhler (2008). Since this species has not received much research attention, the taxonomy of it may still need to be resolved.

Recent DNA studies have elucidated the taxonomic status of this species. Previously, the name was applied to populations from four large islands (Isabela, Fernandina, Santa Cruz-Santa Fe and Santiago) and numerous associated satellite islets (Van Denburgh and Slevin 1913, Kizirian et al. 2004). Following DNA analysis, Benavides et al. (2007) restricted the range of the species to the Isabela-Fernandina islands, with the Santiago and Santa Cruz-Santa Fe populations now being recognized as Microlophus jacobi and M. indefatigabilis, respectively.

This taxon was elevated from a subspecies of Trimeresurus albolabris by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004). David et al. (2011) investigated the status of Trimeresurus viridis, the type species of the genus Trimeresurus and traditionally regarded as a junior synonym of the Indian species T. gramineus. They found this assignment to be incorrect, as investigation of the discovery of T. viridis suggested a Timorese origin and, therefore, that this name should instead have been applied to the sole species of green viper found on Timor, now known as Cryptelytrops (or Trimeresurus, according to some authors) insularis. Although T. viridis is the name with priority for this taxon, it has not been used to describe a valid taxon for over a century, while the names T. insularis and T. albolabris insularis are in widespread use. Following the provisions of the Zoological Code of Nomenclature, David et al. (2011) consider Trimeresurus viridis a nomen oblitum, and Trimeresurus insularis as the correct name for Cryptelytrops insularis. Following this arrangement, Cryptelytrops becomes a junior synonym of Trimeresurus; David et al. (2011) propose that species previously within the genus Trimeresurus sensu stricto be assigned to the genus (or, in their scheme, subgenus, however this is not followed by most authors) Craspedocephalus.

Horner (2007) synonymized Cryptoblepharus pallidus and C. boutonii aruensis within C. novaeguineae. This concept is not followed here pending further taxonomic investigation. Horner's sample sizes were small and workers in New Guinea consider that C. pallidus at least is likely to warrant recognition as a valid species (A. Allison pers. comm. 2014).
The specific status of Cryptoblepharus spp. is not completely accepted and most species are considered as subspecies by many authors (Rocha et al. 2006).

A taxonomic revision is required since this taxon was first described as the subspecies Lepidoblepharis festae colombianus by Mechler in 1968, and later elevated to species level by Vanzolini as L. columbianus in 1978. However, L. xanthostigma is reported to inhabit the same biogeographic zone in Colombia as L. columbianus, and these two may be conspecific. Further, the morphological difference between L. xanthostigma and L. columbianus are based on body size and other uninformative characters (J.C. Arredondo pers. comm. 2010).

Genetic studies by Vargas-Ramirez et al. (2006, 2007a, 2012) and Restrepo (2008) have shown that P. lewyana has low levels of genetic variability and no evidence of genetic population structure on a micro or macro-geographic scale, in addition to some level of inbreeding on a local scale.

Coluber gramineus has long been considered the type species of the taxonomically complex genus Trimeresurus (David et al. 2011), as the original type species T. viridis has long been considered a synonym. Investigation of this assignment by David et al. (2011) indicated that this was incorrect and that T. viridis (a combination that hasn't been used to describe a valid species since its original description in 1861), is instead a junior synonym of the Timorese species T. insularis. This recognition alters the generic identity of several taxa within the Trimeresurus genus complex, including T. gramineus, and David et al. (2011) therefore assign T. gramineus to Craspedocephalus (treated by these authors as a subgenus but more commonly as a full genus). This taxonomy does not, to date, appear to have gained broad acceptance, and this account retains T. gramineus within Trimeresurus.

The validity of this species is unclear. It is known only from a population in a port area of India, to which it may have been introduced, and it is consequently uncertain whether this lizard belongs to a known taxon from elsewhere in the world.

A previous assessment of this species included Anolis heteropholidotus within A. sminthus following a suggestion by Fitch and Siegel (1984), since although more recent work had treated the two species as distinct their precise relationship remained unclear. This assessment recognizes A. heteropholidotus as distinct following more recent usage, and its validity was confirmed by Hofmann and Townsend (2017).
Both molecular and morphological evidence suggest that Hemidactylus scabriceps may be a complex of at least two species (Srikanthan et al. 2018).

Uetz (2019) reports that "there appears to be no consensus" regarding whether this species is specifically distinct from Anolis oxylophus or whether the latter species should be treated as a junior synonym of A. lionotus. Savage et al. (2002) suggested the two taxa are likely to be synonymous, but subsequent data suggests that reliable diagnostic differences exist and this assessment follows recent authors (Nicholson et al. 2012, McCranie and Köhler 2015) in recognizing both species as valid.
