Rajendran (1985) is not convinced that this is a distinct species from Uropeltis smithi Gans, 1966. Pyron et al. (2016) examined the holotype of Uropeltis ruhunae and found that it is indistinguishable from populations currently included within U. woodmasoni.
The poorly-known Pristurus mazbah may be conspecific with this species.

This species is part of a group whose taxonomy is in need of resolution. A highly divergent haplotype was identified from Ethiopia in an analysis by Pook et al. (2009). These authors suggest the name Echis varius, presently a junior synonym of E. pyramidum, may be applicable to this form, but caution that morphological study is required to confirm this; this taxon was considered distinct by Cherlin (1990) in a review of Echis taxonomy. This work (in Russian in a journal with limited circulation among taxonomists) has, however, subsequently been "ignored" (Largen and Spawls 2010) and no attempt has yet been made to systematically evaluate Cherlin's proposals (Largen and Spawls 2010) although recent molecular work by Pook et al. (2009) validates his recognition of Arabian subpopulations as the separate species E. borkini and E. khosatzkii.

The validity of another of Cherlin's descriptions, E. megalocephalus, is uncertain, and McDiarmid et al. (1999) reported that the known specimens - from an "island in the southern Red Sea" understood likely to be in Eritrea's Dahlak Archipelago, where it has, however, not been recorded - may be referable to Echis pyramidum.  No genetic material is available for comparison, and so the molecular study by Pook et al. (2009) was unable to clarify the validity of this form. S. Spawls (pers. comm. 2020) recommends considering this species invalid pending the discovery of additional material, and this approach is followed here.
A recent phylogenetic study found no evidence of cryptic taxa within this wide-ranging snake species (Guo et al. 2019)

Since a number of forms within the Varanus indicus species group appear to represent independent evolutionary lineages and may therefore be island endemics, the likely future discovery of new species may affect the conservation status of this geographically widespread species. For monitors in the Caroline and Mariana Islands, future study of molecular and morphological similarities and differences to distant populations will help in elucidating whether the species occurs naturally on these islands or was introduced (Cota 2008). The latter seems unlikely, since monitor lizards have a long tradition in the history and mythology of the indigenous Chamorro people from Guam (Cunningham and Beaty 2001). Recently subpopulations from New Ireland, Lavongai and Djaul islands have been referred to the resurrected species V. douarrha (Weijola et al. 2016).

This species has four subspecies:
P. jerdonii jerdonii (Günther, 1875)
P. jerdonii bourreti (Klemmer, 1963) - Bourret's Pitviper
P. jerdonii meridionalis (Bourret, 1935)
P. jerdonii xanthomelas (Günther, 1889) - Red Spotted Pitviper.
Cryptelytrops insularis was split from C. albolabris (Malhotra & Thorpe 2004).
This widespread species seems to be a species complex and warrants further taxonomic research (P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019).
This species is assigned to the genus Himalayophis under the revisions by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004).

There is considerable debate about where this genus should be placed. Wallach and Günther (1998) established a new family, Xenophiidae, for the genus, but the Reptile Database places it under the Tropidophiidae. This assessment was first published under the family Tropidophiidae, but as there is no clear justification for this, it has been moved back under Xenophiidae until such time as the placement of this group is resolved.
This assessment follows Baha El Din (2001) in treating the subspecies Tropiocolotes tripolitanus algericus Loveridge, 1947, as a separate species.
This species has been considered as a synonym of Typhlops muelleri Schlegel, 1839.

This species is distinct from Ramphotyphlops braminus and treated as a valid species following (Wallach 2009). Typhlops psammophilus Annandale, 1906 and T. tenuis Gunther, 1864 are junior synonyms of T. pammeces (Wallach 2009).
This species is undoubtedly a complex of several species (C. Austin pers. comm.). It was also orignally part of the Nactus pelagicus complex, but was separated by Zug and Moon (1995).

Šmid et al. (2016) described two species from Saudi Arabia, Hemidactylus asirensis and H. alfarraji, from within H. yerburyii. These authors' molecular results also support the recognition of the subspecies H. y. montanus and H. y. pauciporosus as distinct species.
This species has two subspecies: Typhlops diardi platyventris Khan, 1998 and Typhlops diardi diardi Sschlegel, 1839.

For more than a century the name Cnemaspis kandiana was used as a "catchall" for a group of Cnemaspis taxa widely distributed in South and mainland Southeast Asia, and the islands of the Andaman and Nicobar groups (Maramendra-Arachchi et al. 2007, Das and Grismer 2003) Maramendra-Arachchi et al. (2007) redescribed this species and found, based on a morphological comparison with South Asian forms, that it should be considered endemic to Sri Lanka.

These authors did not use comparative material from Southeast Asian or island populations in their study and do not discuss the affinities of these forms. Consequently, although the species is no longer listed in most guides to Southeast Asian reptiles (e.g. Das 2010), it is not clear whether names are available for these populations. Chan-ard et al. (2015) use the name for a population found in Chumphon and Ranong Provinces in northern Peninsular Thailand. D. Mulcahy (unpubl. data) follows these authors in using C. kandiana as a working name for records recently taken in Lenya, in the neighbouring Tanintharyi region of southern Myanmar, although he reports a divergence of 8% in the ND2 gene from an available Sri Lankan sequence (Gamble et al. 2012).

Pending resolution of the systematics of Southeast Asian populations, these records are not considered to represent C. kandiana sensu stricto and this assessment follows the species concept applied by Maramendra-Arachchi et al. (2007).

This species has a complex taxonomic history, summarized in Wüster et al. (1997). Gasperetti (1988) synonymized this species with Atractaspis microlepidota, then understood to be a wide-ranging, predominantly African viper. This action was taken in spite of this author recognizing morphological differences between the two forms, and consequently this synonymy was rejected by Werner (1990) and some subsequent authors. Confusion about the appropriate taxonomic status of A. engaddensis nonetheless persists. David and Vogel (2010) indicate that A. engaddensis is distinct from both A. andersonii (the Arabian member of the former A. microlepidota species complex) and A. microlepidota (a species now understood to be confined to West Africa - Trape et al. 2006). A systematic revision of eastern Atractaspis following the redescription of A. microlepidota is however still lacking, and so the relationship between this species, A. andersonii and African forms is in need of clarification.

This species has been long known as Python reticulatus, and is still retained under this name in CITES legislation, but a combined morphological and molecular analysis by Rawlings et al. (2008) found that it belonged to a distinct lineage along with Python timorensis. Rawlings et al. (2008) accepted the name Broghammerus Hoser, 2004 for this clade, however, it was subsequently argued that this name may not have been validly published (Kaiser et al. 2013). Citing both this concern and the caution that broader genetic sampling is required to confirm the validity of the Python reticulatus-timorensis clade (Zug et al. 2011), O'Shea et al. (2013) reverted to the use of Python for this species. Reynolds et al. (2014) subsequently reported additional molecular support for a P. reticulatus-timorensis clade and coined the replacement name Malayopython.

This species exhibits considerable geographic variation across its range, and three subspecies - P. r. reticulatus, P. r. jampeanus and P. r. saputrai - are recognized (Auliya et al. 2002). The Philippine populations belong to the nominate form; however, the taxonomy of island forms of P. reticulatus, including those from the Philippines and eastern Indonesia, is unstudied and requires clarification (M. Auliya pers. comm. September 2011).
https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0182049 - add to Tax Note

Reports of Boiga cynodon from Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam, from where this species is absent, are often based on misidentified B. siamensis (Tillack et al. 2004). This species might be part of a larger species complex and is in need of more taxonomic research.

Nine subspecies of this wide-ranging snake are recognized. The nominate form Boiga dendrophila dendrophila is confined to Java. Two additional forms are restricted to Indonesia, B. d. gemmicincta (Sulawesi, including Togian) and B. d. occidentalis (the islands of Babi, the Batu Archipelago, Nias and Sumatra). Four subspecies are endemic to the Philippines, which are likely to be elevated to full species following further taxonomic studies. These are B. d. latifasciata (Mindanao, Dinagat, Samar, Leyte), B. d. multicincta (Palawan, Balabac), B. d. divergens (Luzon, Polillo, Catanduanes) and B. d. levitoni, found on Panay (Gaulke et al. 2004) and probably additional islands in the West Visayas region. The species is represented in Borneo by B. d. annectans, which is found in Brunei, Kalimantan and East Malaysia. The most wide-ranging subspecies, B. d. melanota, has been recorded from Sumatra, Singapore, West Malaysia, Thailand, Cambodia and Viet Nam.

The Philippine subspecies are sometimes treated locally as full species, but no formal taxonomic action has been taken (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2021).
No taxonomic issues.

Three subspecies are recognized: Chrysopelea. p. paradisi (the form represented throughout most of its range), C. p. celebensis (endemic to Sulawesi), and C. p. variabilis (endemic to the Philippines). This snake belongs to larger species complex which is need of taxonomic resolution.

The taxonomy of the Dendrelaphis caudolineatus complex was revised on the basis of morphology by van Rooijen and Vogel (2012). This revision elevated the subspecies Dendrelaphis flavescens and D. terrificus to specific status, removed D. philippinensis from synonymy, and described the new species D. levitoni. These actions removed D. caudolineatus from the Philippines and Sulawesi.

Coelognathus erythrurus was previously placed under the genus Elaphe. The last revision of this species recognized four subspecies  (Schulz 1996): C. erythrurus philippinus, C. e. erythrurus C. e. manillensis and C. e. psephenoura; C. philippinus has since been recognized as a full species (Helfenberger 2001). All but the nominate subspecies are endemic to the Philippines. In Sulawesi - where a separate subspecies C. e. celebensis is sometimes recognized (Leviton et al. 2018) - two forms are known C. e. celebensis. The northern form is usually dark brown to olive dorsally with a very distinct V shaped black markings. The southern form is usually blackish or dark brown with indistinct V shaped marking makes it very similar in colouration to C. flavolineatus.

Gonyosoma floweri is an established junior synonym of G. oxycephalum and has never been formally revalidated. It has recently been included as a valid species in two guides to Thai reptiles (Nutphand 2001, Chan-ard et al. 2015), but in both cases this appears to be a transcription error rather than a deliberate intent to revalidate this species and neither author justifies this arrangement (David et al. 2004, Pauwels and Grismer 2015).

This species is easily confused with Platyceps saharicus; an isolated record of Hemorrhois algirus from southern Algeria reported by Trape and Mané (2006) may represent P. saharicus (Geniez and Gauthier 2008). It is here treated as representing H. algirus pending confirmation of the identity of this record.

Studies into the taxonomy of this wide-ranging species, including resolution of the status of Boaedon fuliginosus arabicus, are needed. Boaedon angolensis, a "long forgotten" name described as a variety of B. lineatus and subsequently either neglected or treated as a junior synonym of either B. lineatus or B. fuliginosus, is treated as a full species by Marques et al. (2018) and Butler et al.(2019). The status of this taxon and other Angolan records of Boaedon is presently under review (Hallerman et al. unpublished, referenced in Butler et al. 2019). Trape and Mediannikov (2016) erected the new species B. subflavus and B. perisilvestris for clades they identified, based on a combination of morphological and molecular data, from Chad and the Republic of Congo.

The holotype of B. fuliginosus has been lost, and the type locality - "Java" - is clearly in error. Brongersma (reported in Roux-Estève and Guibé 1965) proposed fixing the the type locality as either coastal Ghana or an area of South Africa near Cape Town, and only B. lineatus is considered to occur in South Africa. On this basis, Trape and Mediannikov (2018) proposed restricting the name Boaedon fuliginosus to the only clade they identified from West Africa based on molecular analysis. This is necessarily provisional, as their samples did not include material from Ghana and the species' range has not been fully clarified either within or outside West Africa.

There may be some taxonomic confusion in Indochina between this species and L. stoliczkae. A specimen referred to Liopeltis cf. tricolor and L. tricolor by Orlov et al. (2003) and as L. tricolor by Nguyen et al. (2009), from Lam Dong Province, Viet Nam, may be conspecific with the record of L. stolickzae from adjacent eastern Cambodia reported by Stuart et al. (2006). Som et al. (2020) comment that the relationship between these taxa (and L. philippina) remains unresolved.
A record from Pulau Tioman originally assigned to L. tricolor proved on re-examination to represent a new species, which Som et al. (2020) described as L. tiomanica; verified records of L. tricolor from this island exist, and the two species may occur in syntopy (Som et al. 2020).

This species has been recently placed in the genus Ophites. Three subspecies are recognized: L. s. subcinctus, L. s. maculatus, and L. s. sealei. It is possible that the subspecies on Palawan Island (Lycodon subcinctus sealei Leviton, 1955) is an island endemic, however, this needs to be confirmed as Lanza (1999) reported a specimen from Western Sarawak, Malaysia and suggested that the species may have been accidentally introduced to the Philippines.

This species is currently treated as having three subspecies following the action of Broadley (1991) and subsequent revision of southern African Lycophidion by Broadley (1996) elevating the former subspecies pembanum and multimaculatum to specific status. The validity of subspecies L. c. loveridgei and L. c. jacksoni, both from northeastern and eastern Africa, should be investigated with a modern taxonomic analysis.

The Philippine taxon Oligodon notospilus has been considered a subspecies of O. vertebralis. This account follows Uetz and Hallerman (2012) and David and Vogel (2012) in considering O. notospilus a separate species, restricting the known distribution of O. vertebralis to Borneo.
This species is included in Platyceps following Nagy et al. (2004).

Zamenis var. tessellata was described from an unknown locality in "Asia Mineure", which is considered "almost certainly incorrect" by Schätti et al. (2014). Perry (2012) suggested that, if this locality is accurate, this may represent a distinct species, or that alternatively it could be a senior synonym of Platyceps saharicus. Schätti et al. (2014) indicate that the known specimen exhibits characters consistent with Platyceps saharicus from southern Israel, and reject the suggestion by Perry (2012) that it should be considered a valid species. The name tessellata has however generally been ignored by most authors, but has been used for Israeli snakes in some recent literature (Sinaiko et al. 2018). Sinaiko et al. (2018) found no evidence that two species of this group occur in Israel. These authors recommend further research to clarify the status of this name, and due to uncertainty surrounding both its provenance and identity it may be best considered a nomen dubium (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2019).
This species previously included in Coluber, it is now included in Platyceps following Nagy et al. (2004).

Psammodynates pulverulentus was first described as Psammophis pulverulentus by Boie in 1827 based on specimens collected from Java (Smith 1943). Its family assignment, based on genetic evidence, has been somewhat uncertain, although recent analyses place it in an indeterminate position within Lamprophiidae (Pyron et al. 2011, R.A. Pyron pers. comm. Apr 2011).

This form might be a colour morph or a subspecies of Psammophis schokari (U. Joger and W. Bohme pers. comm.), but Y. Werner and S. Baha El Din (pers. comm.) consider it to be a valid species as the two species are sympatric in large parts of their range.

Kelly et al. (2008) suggested that Psammophis punctulatus trivirgatus may warrant recognition as a full species, however these authors did not include samples from the nominate subspecies in their analysis and cautioned that they had too little data to fully clarify its relationships. The specific distinctiveness of the two forms is supported by the suggestion that their distribution overlaps in northern Somalia (Largen and Rasmussen 1993). Pending a formal taxonomic revision to clarify both the appropriate status of P. p. trivirgatus and the distribution of the two taxa in Ethiopia and Somalia, this form is here retained as a subspecies of P. punctulatus.

The taxonomy and distribution of this species has been considered the most contentious of any species in the taxonomically complex P. sibilans group (Spawls et al. 2001). Broadley (1977) considered this species to occur in Senegal on the basis of a single specimen; although this was considered a "hasty conclusion" by Hughes (1999), a number of subsequent authors have followed this authority and attributed records between Senegal and the Tanzanian type locality to P. rukwae (e.g. Largen and Rasmussen 1993, Chippaux 2006). This has resulted in extensive confusion in the literature between the distributions Psammophis rukwae, P. sudanensis and "P. leucogaster", a name of uncertain status.

Trape et al. (2019) fully revised the taxonomy of Central and northern African Psammophis, restricting P. rukwae to northern and eastern Africa with a western range limit in the Central African Republic and western Cameroon.

This species has presented one of the most taxonomically complex and intractable problems in African herpetology (Hughes 1999) for more than two hundred years (Broadley 1963). The exceptionally complex taxonomic history of this and related names is discussed by Trape et al. (2019), who fully evaluated the systematics of West and Central African Psammophis using both molecular and morphological data, including examination of hundreds of specimens.

The taxonomy of Psammophis sibilans as defined following this revision may still not be fully resolved, and a neotype designation is required to formally fix the commonly accepted type locality "Egypt" (Trape et al. 2019). Somalia was included in this species' range by Trape et al. (2019) based on sequences reported by Kelly et al. (2008), however, Trape et al. (2019) suggest that these sequences - as well as others from Ethiopia and one of their own specimens - indicate the likely occurrence of at least three cryptic species within P. sibilans.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. The validity and identity of records from Hainan was the subject of uncertainty until Zhao (1997) identified that this population represented a distinct species, which he described as Rhabdophis adleri.

Records of this species from West Africa previously attributed to Telescopus dhara or T. obtusus are now understood to represent T. tripolitanus (Crochet et al. 2008). Crochet et al. (2008) proposed treating Telescopus obtusus and T. somalicus as subspecies of T. dhara, pending research into the systematics of this poorly-sampled genus. Recently, Šmíd et al. (2019) conducted the first full-genus genetic analysis of Telescopus and found "a considerable degree" of variation that justified recognising T. obtusus as a distinct species, and this arrangement is followed here. High levels of genetic variation in the resulting concepts of both T. obtusus and T. dhara suggests that diversity within this group in both the Arabian Peninsula and the Horn of Africa is likely to be underestimated (Šmíd et al. 2019).

The status of T. somalicus remains unresolved as this taxon was not sampled; Šmíd et al. (2019) provisionally retain it as a subspecies of T. dhara, a species not otherwise known from Africa, however, it is unlikely to be referable to or closely-related to T. dhara (J. Šmíd pers. comm. 2019). Geniez (2015) treats it as a subspecies of T. obtusus, and this arrangement is followed here.

Records from west of Niger represent Naja senegalensis, formerly confused with this species (Trape et al. 2009). North African populations may also be taxonomically distinct, and further research is needed to clarify the systematics of this species (S. Baha El Din pers. comm.).
Populations of this recently-described species were formerly assigned to Naja pallida.
This species had previously been synonymized with Leptotyphlops macrorhynchus.
This species was assigned from Leptotyphlops to Myriopholis by Adalsteinsson et al. (2009).

This taxon was originally described as Trimeresurus xiangchengensis by Zhao et al. (1978), however, more recently it has been assigned to the genus of Protobothrops (Guo et al.2006). There has been much debate over the validity of this species. McDiarmid et al. (1999) suggested that it may be a synonym of Protobothrops mucrosquamatus, but Guo et al. (2009) concluded that it is a valid species and this arrangement is followed here.
Some authors believe that this species is not clearly distinguishable from Thecadactylus solimoensis (R. Caicedo pers. comm. 2013)

authority: Ziegler, David, Miralles, van Kien & Quang Truong, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species was formerly confused with Achalinus rufescens (Ziegler et al. 2008), and it is not clear whether additional records of this snake may have been confused with species of Achalinus.

This species has long been placed in the genus Elaphe. Although there is disagreement among authors, as many as eight subspecies are recognized: O. p. coxi, o. p. hainanus, O. p. kawakamii, O. p. laticinctus, O. p. nigrofasciatus, O. p. porphyraceus, O. p. pulcher, and O. p. vaillanti.

As currently understood, Oreocryptophis is monotypic, but it is reported to include at least one cryptic species on the basis of mtDNA data (Utiger et al. 2002).
This species was historically placed in the genus Calamaria.
Previously placed in the genus Trionyx, euphraticus was placed in the resurrected genus Rafetus by Meylan (1987), and this has been widely accepted as such (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2014).

Coelognathus radiatus was described by Boie in 1827 as Coluber radiatus based on specimens collected from Java, Indonesia. Dr. Patrick Russell's work "Indian Serpentes" published in 1801 also has drawings of this taxa (Smith 1943). This species has been long included under the genus Elaphe (Smith 1943), but following Helfenberger (2001) and Utiger et al. (2005), the Oriental Ratsnakes have been assigned to the genus Coelognathus.
This species may be a composite of two, seemingly distinct species, and this requires clarification.

Following revision of Trimeresurus by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004), the generic identity of this species remains to be clarified. David et al. (2011) exclude this species from their arrangement of Trimeresurus sensu lato, and suggest that it is likely to warrant a new genus (in their scheme, subgenus).
This species is closely related to Trimeresurus macrops. Older literature references to T. kanburiensis are likely to refer in fact to this taxon (Uetz et al. 2020).
The taxonomic status of this species should be verified with reference to the original description.

The species is known from the holotype, with a locality stated as "Pinang Malaya". The validity of this locality has been questioned (Wall 1923). According to McDiarmid et al. (1999), "The only exact locality known for this species is Bogor", in West Java, however the assignment of this specimen (USNM 043455) to Typhlops bothriorhynchus is believed to be in error (D.T. Iskander pers. comm. August 2011). Das (1996) removed this species from synonymy with T. diardi on the recommendation of V. Wallach, based on morphological differences (McDiarmid et al. 1999).
The species is currently known from the holotype alone.
This species has historically been treated as a synonym of Oligodon cinereus, where it was placed by Smith (1935).

The widely disjunct range of this species may be explained by a misidentification or taxonomic problem. A specimen referred to as Liopeltis cf. tricolor and L. tricolor by Orlov et al. (2003), and as L. tricolor by Nguyen et al. (2009), from Lam Dong Province, Vietnam, may be conspecific with the record of L. stolickzae from adjacent eastern Cambodia reported by Stuart et al. (2006).
This species has been alternatively placed in the genera Internatus, Pareas, Dipsas, and Amblycephalus.
The species was initially split from Trimeresurus popeiorum, however according current taxonomic concepts this is a separate species, endemic to Sumatra, Indonesia.
Three subspecies are recognized: Pseudoxenodon m. macrops, P. m. fukienensis, and P. m. sinensis.
No taxonomic issues.

Four subspecies are recognized: Sinomicrurus macclellandii macclellandi, S. m. iwasakii, S. m. swinhoei, and S. m. univirgatus. This is a species complex, and further study will be needed into the taxonomy and the conservation status of each of the component species.
Oligodon eberhardti has been confused with O. catenatus.

Three subspecies are recognized: Boiga ochracea ochracea, B. o. stolickzae (Wall, 1909) and B. o. walli (Smith, 1943). B. o. stolickzae is found in central Nepal, Sikkim in India, and in northern Myanmar (Uetz 2010).

Das (2010) treats B. walli as a full species under the proposed common name Wall's Cat Snake, with a distribution in Tenasserim (Tanintharyi Division, southern Myanmar) and the Andaman Islands, however, Uetz (2010) considers that this subspecies is confined to Bangladesh. B. walli is assessed separately.

Takeuchi et al. (2012) examined genetic relationships between Rhabdophis t. tigrinus from Japan, R. t. formosanus from Taiwan, and populations on the Asian mainland (sometimes recognized as the distinct subspecies R. t. lateralis, although the validity of this form has been disputed - see Takeuchi et al. 2012 for a discussion). On the basis of their results, these authors proposed specific status for R. t. formosanus and R. t. lateralis. Takeuchi et al. (2012) sequenced R. t. lateralis (which occurs throughout China and the Korean Peninsula, and in far eastern Russia) only from South Korea, and acknowledge the absence of known morphological characters that can distinguish this taxon from R. t. tigrinus. On this basis, and pending genetic comparison with specimens from China that can more fully characterize genetic variation within R. tigrinus, both R. t. lateralis and R. t. formosanus are provisionally retained here as subspecies of R. tigrinus.
This species has been split from Trimeresurus puniceus, but the two species are difficult to distinguish.

This species was described based on a record from Phong Nha-Ke Bang misidentified as Trimeresurus kanburensis (Orlov et al. 2004). Grismer et al. (2008) suggested that the species should be transferred to Viridovipera on the basis of morphological evidence. This change is supported by the molecular analysis of Dawson et al. (2008), who specifically investigated the phylogenetic position of this species and provided more detailed justification for transferring the species to Viridovipera.
No taxonomic issues.

Oligodon quadrilineatus was erroneously described as a species distinct from O. taeniatus following confusion over the number of dorsal scale rows possessed by the holotype (David et al. 2008), which was corrected when Campden-Main (1969) synonymized O. quadrilineatus within O. taeniatus. Despite accepting the correct number of scale rows for O. taeniatus, Das (2010) treated O. quadrilineatus as a separate species, but provided no characters by which the two forms could reliably be distinguished. The description given in Das (2010) matches the description of the neotype for O. quadrilineatus assigned by David et al. (2008), however, this neotype designation was made to affirm the synonymy of these two names following the loss of the O. quadrilineatus holotype, not to resurrect O. quadrilineatus as a valid species. David et al. (2011) corrected the neotype designation following the rediscovery of a museum specimen consistent with the original holotype. The newly-designated neotype is also referrable to O. taeniatus, and so O. quadrilineatus remains in synonymy with this species.

In their revision of the O. taeniatus complex, David et al. (2008) redescribed this species, erecting the new species O. deuvei, O. moricei and O. pseudotaeniatus to describe populations formerly included within O. taeniatus, and clarifying its distinction from O. barroni and O. mouhoti.
This species was formerly placed in the genus Maticora. Three subspecies are recognized: C. b. bivirgata, C. b. flaviceps, and C. b. tetrataenia.

Two subspecies have been recognized: Bungarus multicinctus multicinctus and Bungarus multicinctus wanghaotingi. The latter is treated here as a full species following Leviton et al. (2003). It is probable that both members of this species group contain additional cryptic forms (Leviton et al. 2003).
This species may be a synonym of T. diardii (Nguyen et al. 2009).
This species is similar to Oligodon theobaldi according to Smith (1943).
The species was recently described based on three specimens from museum collections. These were previously considered to belong to D. formosus.

authority: Vogel, David, Pauwels, Sumontha, Norval, Hendrix, Vu & Ziegler, 2009
taxonomicNotes: This species was described to science only in 2009 (Vogel et al. 2009).
No taxonomic issues.

Jiang (2004) indicated that, based on morphological similarities, P. chinensis should be treated as a synonym of P. formosensis. This assignment is not supported by recent genetic research, which found that P. formosensis is not closely-related to P. chinensis and is instead sister to P. hamptoni (Guo et al. 2011).

The former subspecies Gloydius strauchi monticola is now recognized as a distinct species. Longstanding taxonomic uncertainty exists regarding the validity of G. liupanensis and G. qinlingensis, both of which have previously been treated as synonyms of G. strauchi, and is discussed by Xu et al. (2012). These authors suggest that both are likely to be valid species, but that further work is needed to clarify this arrangement. Wang et al. (2019) further investigated the systematics of this complex and their results indicated that several species should likely be recognized. This account retains all forms within G. strauchi but reassessment of these elevated taxa should be considered in the future.
This species has also been placed in the genera Dendrophis and Ahaetulla.

This species was historically synonymized with Oligodon cinereus, where it was placed by Smith (1935). Reports of this species from Vietnam are based on confusion with O. taeniatus and/or O. deuvei (David et al. 2008).
No problems on taxonomy.
No taxonomy issues.

The species is listed as Ramphotyphlops ozakiae Wallach in a thesis by Niyomwan, Thirakhupt and Nabhitabhata 2001, the first publication to mention this species combination. Wallach had not, in fact, published the description of this species but had provided data on it to the lead author, who were apparently unaware that there was no published description (V. Wallach pers. comm. November 2010). Under the Rules of the Zoological Code of Nomenclature, the species has been "validly albeit unintentionally published" (V. Wallach pers. comm. November 2010), and the appropriate authority is considered to be Wallach in Niyomwam, Thirakhupt and Nabhitabhata 2001. Das (2010) assigns this species to Typhlops without discussion.

This snake is difficult to distinguish from other blind snakes in and around Sakaerat Biosphere Reserve, and so may be under-recorded (T. Chan-ard pers. comm. August 2011).

Smith (1943) treated this species as a junior synonym of Fowlea piscator, and more recently Vogel and David (2006) also questioned the distinctiveness of this species from F. piscator. Taxonomic study is needed to determine if this is a valid species, and, if so, its geographic distribution.

The species is poorly known and numerous subspecies have been described and now proven to belong to other species as synonyms. Oligodon annulifer bipartita Despax, 1912 is a subjective junior synonym of Oligodon pulcherrimus Werner, 1909. Oligodon durheimi Baumann, 1913 is a subjective junior synonym of Oligodon pulcherrimus Werner, 1909. Oligodon annulifer annulata (Van Lidth de Jeude, 1922) is a subjective junior synonym of Oligodon signatus (Günther, 1864). Oligodon annulifer confluens Werner, 1924 is a subjective junior synonym of Oligodon petronellae Roux in De Rooij, 1917 (Tillack & Gunther 2009) .

Stuebing and Inger (1999) suggested that this species, then known from only four juvenile specimens, was in fact a juvenile of another species of Oligodon. The recent collection of an adult specimen from a site in Brunei (J.M. Dehling pers. comm., Tillack and Günther 2009), however, confirms the validity of Oligodon annulifer as a distinct species.
Das et al. (2008) described the species based on one holotype and two paratypes. A record from Kutai (Brongersma & Helle 1958) might refer to this species but need confirmation.

The species was described from Java, but subsequently found in North Sulawesi and other islands from the east to New Guinea, which makes the record from Java unlikely biogeographically. The population from East Indonesia was described as a different subspecies, suturalis by Brongersma (1934), but this arrangement was not followed by In den Bosch and Ineich (1994) or McDowell (1974).
The species was previously included within the widespread species Xenochrophis piscator.
A specimen of Boiga cynanea from Bhutan was previously misidentified as B. ochracea ochracea (Tillack 2006).

The species was described based on a single specimen from Mt Kinabalu, about 120 years ago and only differs from the other species (H. periops) of the genus in having a fused prefrontal scute. The validity of this species is questionable (Stuebing and Inger 1999).

The species is relatively variable, and has been given numerous names which Inger and Marx (1965) list as synonyms. The form found on Java and Bali is sufficiently distinct to be recognized as a subspecies, Calamaria schlegeli cuvieri.
The species is described based on a single specimen, closely related to T. diardii (Wallach, 2001)
Prior to its recent description, this snake was included within Dendrelaphis pictus.

Smithsophis atemporalis was described from a sample of Northeast Indian Rhabdophis previously confused with Rhabdophis (now Smithsophis atemporalis) (Giri et al. 2019). Variability within this species across India and Indochina suggests that its taxonomy is in need of further resolution (Giri et al. 2019).

This snake, the type species of the genus Trimerodytes, has generally been included in the genus Opisthotropis following Pope (1935). This large genus has never been fully revised and the name Trimerodytes was largely neglected until Ren et al. (2019). Although these authors did not fully revise Opisthotropis, they identified that this genus is polytypic and that O. balteata belongs to the clade containing Sinonatrix. These authors consequently revalidated Trimerodytes, with Sinonatrix as a junior synonym, and suggested that further research is likely to reveal that Paratinophis praemaxiliaris should also be referred to Trimerodytes.

Nagy et al. (2004) identified that the genus Hierophis as then understood was paraphyletic, and that H. spinalis was closer to Eirenis than to other species of Hierophis. This author's recommendation that H. spinalis be transferred to Eirenis has not, however, been widely adopted, and Kharin (2011) erected the new monotypic genus Orientocoluber for this species.

The Vietnamese island specimens, which have been deposited in a Russian institution, have not recently been examined, and work is needed to confirm their identity (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2011).

Malhotra et al. (2011) present a redescription of this species, which as now defined is confined to Thailand, northern Cambodia and Laos. Populations from southern Cambodia and southeastern Thailand and from Vietnam are now assigned to Cryptelytrops cardamomensis and C. rubeus respectively.
The identity of records attributed to Sibynophis collaris from Cambodia and Viet Nam requires confirmation, as some may represent this species (B. Stuart pers. comm. August 2011).
Two subspecies are recognized: S. m. melanocephalus (Gray in Gray & Hardwicke, 1835) and S. m. insularis Mertens, 1927.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. It closely resembles Hebius [Amphiesma] modestum according to Smith (1943), and may therefore be hidden in natural history collections under this name.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

The species was previously considered as a subspecies of Python curtus. Other members of the "Python curtus group" are now considered as distinct species (Keogh et al. 2001, Rawlings et al. 2008, Zug et al. 2011); P. curtus in western Sumatra, P. brongersmai in the remainder of Sumatra and in mainland Southeast Asia, P. breitensteini from Borneo, and P. kyaiktiyo from Myanmar. The occurrence, origin and taxonomic status of members of the P. curtus group in Indochina, presently assigned to P. brongersmai, is uncertain (Zug et al. 2011). The separation of this species is supported by differences in scalation and colouration as well as by DNA analysis and geography (Keogh et al. 2001, Rawlings et al. 2008).

The species description indicates that this form might well be a Ramphotyphlops. However, the type specimen is lost and confirmation about its taxonomic status is still uncertain. Probably it is closely related to R. multilineatus.
No taxonomy issues.

The distribution of this species is likely confused with P. macularius in the literature and is probably unreliable. The two species were synonymized by Huang (2004), with P. macularius becoming a subspecies of P. margaritophorus. Vogel (2010) rejected this synonymy on the basis that Huang appears not to have examined and compared type material for the two forms. Recent molecular data reveals high genetic diversity within P. margaritophorus, and further research may justify the treatment of the two forms as separate species (Guo et al. 2011). An additional subspecies, P. m. tamdaoensis, is here retained within P. margaritophorus, although Das (2010) treats this as a separate species.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
O. hanitschi is the only species of its genus.

The validity of the subspecies Elaphe carinata deqenensis has been a source of some dispute (Guo et al. 2012 and refs therein). Based on morphological comparisons and low levels of genetic divergence within E. carinata, Guo et al. (2012) determined that the morphologcal characters used to diagnose the subspecies were unreliable, and provisionally synonymized it with E. c. carinata. These authors cautioned, however, that their genetic data was not sufficient to determine whether E. c. deqenensis is a valid evolutionary unit.

This species was treated as a subspecies of the ubiquitous Dendrelaphis pictus, until it was elevated to full species by Ziegler and Vogel (1999). It is very similar to D. cyanochloris (G. Vogel pers. comm. August 2011). Historical records of D. pictus, D. cyanochloris and D. ngansonensis may be confused, making the true distribution difficult to establish (Q.T. Nguyen and G. Vogel pers. comm. August 2011).
No taxonomy issues.
This species was resurrected from synonymy with Lycodon rushstrati by Vogel et al. (2009). The exact distribution of these two species needs further research.

This is a species complex, containing at least two recognized forms (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2011). It has also been confused with Oligodon cyclurus. Following Wagner (1975), Pauwels et al. (2002, 2011) consider that populations from southeast Myanmar, Laos, Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia should be referred to O. fasciolatus, and O. cyclurus should be confined to eastern India, Bangladesh, Myanmar and West Thailand. Research is ongoing to clarify the taxonomy of this group. This concept is applied here.
No taxonomic issues.
The species was described in 2004, although specimens are known since 1962 (Leong & Grismer 2004).
No taxonomic issues.

The distinction between Viridovipera gumprechti and the southern Chinese V. yunnanensis is taxonomically complex, and opinions differ on the distribution of the two forms (N. Ananjeva pers. comm. August 2011). Das (2010) opins that V. yunnanensis is the correct name for the species also found in Myanmar (Chin and Kachin States), Laos, and Vietnam outside the Annamite Mountains, but this account follows Nguyen et al. (2009) in assigning these records to V. gumprechti, confining V. yunnanensis to China.
This recently described species was historically confused with Oligodon taeniatus.
This species was previously recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. This species was redescribed by Malhotra et al. (2004), who clarified the distribution of this snake based on voucher specimens.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
Bungarus fasciatus was described by Schneider in 1801 based on drawings and a description by Dr. Patrick Russell of specimens collected from Bengal, India (Smith 1943).

This species has also been placed in the genus Ophites, but this is not widely accepted. This species is often synonymized with or treated as a subspecies of Lycodon aulicus, but they are here considered as distinct species following Taylor (1965) and David and Vogel (1996).

The historical concept of Agkistrodon blomhoffii included four subspecies: A. b. blomhoffii, A. b. brevicaudus, A. b. siniticus and A. b. dubitatus). Paik et al. (1993) elevated the Korean subspecies brevicaudus to specific status, a decision subsequently supported by genetic data (Xu et al. 2012). Based on mtDNA studies, Wang and Zhao (2007, 2008) found that Gloydius blomhoffii dubitatus and G. b. siniticus are both referrable to G. brevicaudus. Consequently the concept of G. blomhoffii accepted here is restricted to Japan and Kunashir Island.
Kaiser et al. (2018) note that Sarawak and Sabah specimens exhibit distinct morphology and that work to recognize the Sabah records as a distinct species is underway.

Das and Yaakob (2007) and Das (2010) placed this species in the genus Lycodon. The Reptile Database considers it to belong to the genus Lepturophis and does not recognize it as occurring on the Malay Peninsula, which is in error.

This snake has been treated as a subspecies of B. multicinctus (e.g. in the Reptile Database - Uetz et al. 2021). It is treated here as a full species following Leviton et al. (2003) and Chen et al. (2021). It is probable that both members of this species group contain additional cryptic forms (Leviton et al. 2003).
The species was previously considered as a variation of D. pictus.

Vogel et al. (2018) resurrected Elapoidis sumatrana from synonymy within E. fusca, but this action has been considered "dubious" due to overlapping morphological characters and the relatively small sample size (Uetz et al. 2019). Vogel et al. (2018) did not conduct any molecular analysis, and further research incorporating both molecular and morphological methods is required to clarify the validity of E. sumatrana.
Two subspecies are recognized: B. f. flaviceps and B. f. baluensis.

The genus Trirhinopholis is a junior synonym of Plagiopholis (see Smith 1943). This species has previously been treated as a synonym of P. nuchalis, but Tillack et al. (2006) provide evidence against this synonymy.

Psammophis indochinensis is variously treated as a full species (e.g. Hughes 1999, Pauwels et al. 2003, Nguyen et al. 2009) or as a subspecies of P. condanarus (e.g. McKay 2006, Cottone and Bauer 2009). Cottone and Bauer (2009) remark that "the validity of the subspecific division of [P. condanarus] has not been critically assessed". Based on the disjunct distributions of the two taxa and morphological differences highlighted by Pauwels et al. (2003) it is probable that the two forms represent different species (P. David and A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013) and this scheme is followed here. A full revision is however needed to clarify the relationships of these two taxa (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013).
Taxonomic study is required to assess whether populations across this large geographic area are truly conspecific. Two subspecies are recognized, Cylindrophis r. ruffus and C. r. burmanus.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
The species is difficult to distinguish from B. drapiezii (Ramadhan et al. 2010).
This species has been confused with the Malayan Krait (Bungarus candidus) by local people.

Possibly a synonym of Oligodon waandersi (Bleeker, 1860). This species has been listed as a species from Sulawesi, even the original label of the type mentioned as Java (fide Fritz 2019). However, this species has never been recorded from Sulawesi or Java. Furthermore the taxonomic status of this species is doubtful (fide Wagner in Fritz 2019). Therefore the taxonomic status of the species must be re-assessed.

Specimens from Riau and West Sumatra are very similar to each other. The  only specimen from North Sumatra might represent a different species  but paucity of specimens prevent further taxonomical treatment (Inger and Marx 1965).
This a recently split species from the Trimeresurus puniceus complex (David et al. 2006).

The species is only known from the holotype from Weh Island, Aceh, now lost (the museum where it was collected was destroyed during war so the specimen is not available). It is not known which is the most closely related species, but Tillack and Gunther (2009) suggest it is more similar to O. pulcherrimus.
The species is a well recognized species and recorded from many places in Borneo. Only two synonyms have been listed (Inger and Marx 1965).
This species is similar to Oligodon cruentatus according to Smith (1943).

This species is related to Viridovipera stejnegeri, with which it was formerly confused. The distinction between V. gumprechti and the southern Chinese V. yunnanensis is taxonomically complex, and opinions differ on the distribution of the two forms (N. Ananjeva pers. comm. August 2011). Das (2010) opins that V. yunnanensis is the correct name for the species found in Myanmar (Chin and Kachin States), Laos, and Vietnam outside the Annamite Mountains, but this account follows Nguyen et al. (2009) in assigning these records to V. gumprechti, confining V. yunnanensis to China.

Isolated records of this species from southern and central Viet Nam are referable to Hebius boulengeri.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

This species is tentatively referred to the Oligodon taeniatus-group solely on the basis of its striped pattern; the holotype was originally confused with O. taeniatus. A male specimen will be necessary to ascertain its position within the genus Oligodon.
The species is essentially well known and has five synonyms (Inger and Marx, 1965).

This species has long been treated as a subspecies of Fowlea piscator. Literature records of this species and F. piscator, which occur in sympatry (Zug et al. 2006, Vogel and David 2006) are confused. The subspecies F. f. schnurrenbergeri is now recognized as a full species (Vogel and David 2006). Additional study of this species complex is warranted, as additional species may exist under the name F. flavipunctatus.
The population from northern Vietnam previously assigned to this species was described as a separate species, Bungarus slowinskii, by Kuch et al. (2005).

This species was redescribed by David et al. (2006), who also clarified the original authorship and its identity as the type species of the genus Craspedocephalus, which David et al. (2011) propose as a replacement name for members of the Trimeresurus clade of Malhotra and Thorpe (2004), as they argue that Trimeresurus is instead the name applicable to the Cryptelytrops clade of these authors. In their redescription, David et al. (2006) consider records from Sumatera Berat, Natuna Island and the Mentawai Islands to represent a separate, undescribed form, Trimeresurus cf. puniceus, which is not included within this account

This species was long recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. This species has been treated as a subspecies of O. monticola by numerous authors. The taxonomy of O. monticola subspecies and closely related species is highly uncertain.
This species has also been placed in the genus Ophites, but this is not widely accepted.
This is a member of the Oligodon cinereus group (Smith 1943).
New genus Viridovipera erected by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004a).
Treated as a subspecies of P. inornatus in the Reptile Database.
No taxonomic issues.
Treated as a subspecies of C. lovii by the Reptile Database. We follow Das (2010) and consider this species as a separate species.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
This a species described from the highlands of Peninsular Malaysia (Vogel et al. 2004) from within the Trimeresurus popeorum complex.
The species boundaries within the genus are currently poorly understood and larger samples from Sumatra, Borneo and Peninsular Malaysia are required.
Two subspecies are recognized: S. p. percarinata and S. p. suriki.

Although this species is considered to be the most common member of the genus, reexamination of historical records is needed as a number of species of Pseudorabdion have been described since these were taken.

A phylogenetic analysis of the genus Amphiesma has found it to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species have consequently been assigned to Herpetoreas or Hebius (Guo et al. 2014). The Russian subspecies H. vibakari ruthveni may be elevated to specific status in future.

Based on mtDNA research, Wang and Zhao (2008) considered that Gloydius blomhoffi dubitatus is a subpopulation of G. brevicaudus.  Another mtDNA study indicated that G. brevicaudus siniticus is not a subspecies of Gloydius blomhoffii (Wang and Zhao 2007).
Specimens reported by Campden-Main (1970) as Oligodon cyclurus with "rarely 17 rows" may refer to this species (David et al. 2008).

This species was long recognized as a subspecies of P. curtus (as P. c. brongersmai), but was elevated to a full species by Keogh et al. (2001) on the basis of its morphological and genetic distinctiveness. Most reports of this species from Viet Nam are unverified, and it is unclear both whether these represent native occurrences, human introductions or erroneous records, and whether these records are conspecific with Malay Peninsula P. brongersmai (Zug et al. 2011). A record from Cambodia (Barker and Barker 1994) is "most likely incorrect" due to the doubtful authenticity of these authors' source, who falsely reported the origin of animals in the pet trade (D. Barker in litt. June 2010, reported by Zug et al. 2011). A recent confirmed record from Viet Nam (T.M. Phung unpubl. data) does, however, come from a site adjacent to the Cambodian border.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
This species was long recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. In a revision by Vogel et al. (2007) the T. wagleri complex was differentiated into several species.

This snake was originally described as a subspecies of Dinodon rufozonatum, and later transferred to D. flavozonatum by Smith (1943). This assignment has subsequently been shown to be incorrect, and Orlov and Ryabov (2004) elevated this taxon, then treated as a subspecies of D. rufozonatum, to full species level.

Orlov et al. (2002) suggested that this snake should be treated as a synonym of Ovophis monticola convictus (now O. convictus - Malhotra et al. 2011). The specific status of this form has recently been supported on the basis of both morphological and genetic evidence (Malhotra et al. 2011). This revision also extended the distribution of this species in Vietnam as far south as the Da Lat Plateau, and reassigned records from Laos to other species.
This species was long recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. It has sometimes been confused with T. venustus and T. purpureomaculatus (see David et al. 2004; Malhotra and Thorpe 2004).

A subspecies of this snake has been recognized from Kangean Island, but its validity has never been evaluated. This snake exhibits striking dimorphism in colouration and pattern, with both morphs occurring in sympatry (van Rooijen et al. 2011). A recent analysis found that these forms were otherwise indistinguishable morphologically as well as genetically, and concluded that the two morphs do not represent different species (van Rooijen et al. 2011).

A female specimen with the type locality "Chine" was described in 1854 under the name Simotes trinotatus; this taxon has long been considered a junior synonym of O. purpurascens although this latter species is not otherwise known from China (David and Vogel 2012). Examining the holotype, David and Vogel (2012) concluded, based on differences in patterning, that it is "clearly distinct" from O. purpurascens, but that its taxonomic status cannot be determined without the discovery of further material.

This species was long recognized in the genus Trimeresurus. The subspecies C. p. andersoni from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands has been elevated to a full species (Malhotra and Thorpe 2004, Leviton et al. 2008).
No taxonomic issues.
Zhao (1995) treated this former subspecies of Ovophis monticola as a valid species, and this assignment has since been supported by Malhotra et al. (2011).
Treated as a subspecies of C. subradiatus in the Reptile Database.
No taxonomic issues.
The species is known from the type series of six specimens and one doubtful record from Singapore (Grandison 1978). This uncertain record has not been included in the current assessment.
This species was long recognized in the genus Elaphe.

The species name is often spelled Calamaria lowi. According to Uetz and Hallerman (2010), this combination was first used by Mocquard only three years after the original description. Four subspecies are recognized: C. l. lovii in Borneo, C. l. wermuthi in Java, C. l. gimletti in Peninsular (West) Malaysia and nearby Riouw Archipelago and Aor Island, and C. l. ingermarxorum in Viet Nam. C. gimletti is here treated as a full species, following Das (2010), and so is not considered in this account. Calamaria l. ingermarxorum is known only from the holotype specimen.
This species was placed in the genus Ophites by Zhao and Adler (1993), but Lycodon is the name in most frequent use for this species and the change has not been widely accepted.

This species has long been placed in the genus Elaphe. It was transferred to Orthriophis by Utiger et al. (2002) and then back again to Elaphe by Chen et al. (2017). Although there is disagreement among authors, as many as seven subspecies are recognized: O. t. friesei, O. t. grabowskyi, O. t. mocquardi, O. t. ridleyi, O. t. schmackeri, O. t. taeniurus, and O. t. yunnanensis.

The subspecies previously known as Elaphe taeniura vaillanti (Mocquard, 1905) is renamed Elaphe taeniura mocquardi Schulz, 1996 (nomen novum pro Coluber vaillanti Mocquard, 1905 [non Simotes vaillanti Sauvage, 1877, a subjective synonym of Elaphe porphyracea nigrofasciata]). Note that mocquardi and yunnanensis appear to intergrade in Viet Nam (Orlov et al. 2000).

Treated as a subspecies of Boiga ochracea in the Reptile Database. However, compared with the typical form B. walli exhibits different scale counts and a non-overlapping distribution, justifying its treatment as a distinct species (I. Das pers. comm. Aug 2011, Das in litt.). Phylogenetic research is needed to confirm the distinctiveness of this taxon and its relationships to other species of Boiga, but it may not be closely-related to B. ochracea (I. Das pers. comm. Aug 2011).
The taxonomic status of this species should be verified with reference the original description.

Figueroa et al. (2016) proposed synonymizing Cyclophiops within Ptyas. While provisionally adopting this scheme, Meetei et al. (2018) caution that as this analysis did not examine C. doriae, the type species of Cyclophiops, further research is needed to confirm this assignment.

Ablabes hamptoni was described by Boulenger at a time when morphological variation in C. doriae was poorly-understood, and was characterized as differing from the latter species in the shape of the rostral shield and, by Smith (1943), in the number of ventral scale rows. In a recent analysis of morphological variation within C. doriae, Meetei et al. (2018) found that the holotype - and still only known specimen - of C. hamptoni falls within the range of variation now known for C. doriae. These authors consequently synonymized A. hamptoni within C. doriae.

This species was referred from Zaocys to Ptyas by David and Das (2004) (as P. nigromarginata). Although Zaocys is now considered a junior synonym of Ptyas (Utiger et al. 2005), the older name is still followed by some authors (e.g. Wang and Xie 2009).

The correct form of this species' name is Oligodon catenatus (P. David pers. comm. September 2011), and this combination was used by Smith (1940) who first transferred the species to Oligodon (although Smith (1943) later used the form O. catenata). However, the species is widely written as O. catenata in the literature.

The record of this species from Thailand was formerly confused with Oligodon dorsalis (T. Chan-ard pers. comm. August 2011), and confusion also exists between historical records of this species and O. eberhardti (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. September 2011).

Oligodon eberhardti has been renamed from the synonymy of O. catenatus. Oligodon herberti is supposed to have solid vertebral stripe. Oligodon eberhardti is supposed to have broken vertebral stripes. Holotype lost, according to Smith (1943), from 'Asam' (then comprising the modern day Assam State, in addition to much of the rest of northeastern India) (Das et al. 1998).
The taxonomic status of the second species of the genus (Hydrablabes prefrontalis) is uncertain and probably it is only an individual variant of H. periops (Stuebing & Inger 1999).

authority: Kuch, Kizirian, Truong, Lawson, Donnelly & Mebs, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This small reddish brown snake is the sole member of its genus.
The species is a part of what was previously known as Trimeresurus borneensis complex or T. puniceus (sensu lato).
This species may be closely related to  Macrocalamus chanardi.
Five subspecies are recognized: Calliophis m. maculiceps, C. m. atrofrontalis, C. m. hughi, C. m. michaelis, and C. m. smithi.
The species was recently described to science (Slowinski and Wüster 2000).

This species was historically placed in the genus Amblycephalus. Recent molecular work supports morphological evidence indicating that this species and Pareas nuchalis form a clade distinct from other Pareas (Guo et al. 2011), and its generic status may therefore warrant revision. Two subspecies are recognized: P. c. carinatus and P. c. unicolor.
No taxonomic issues.
Bungarus javanicus is considered to be a melanistic form of B. candidus (see Kuch and Mebs 2007).
The species was described based on a single specimen. Inger and Marx (1965) placed Calamaria raveni as a synonym of this species.

In a revision by Vogel et al. (2007) the Tropidolaemus wagleri species complex was differentiated into several taxa, including the resurrection of T. subannulatus. The Western Philippine populations belong to T. subannulatus, but those from Mindanao include snakes assigned to both this species and T. philippensis. Tropidolaemus subannulatus has a wide distribution in Central Indonesia, Malaysia and Philippines, T. wagleri is restricted to mainland Southeast Asia, down to Sumatra and Bangka, West Indonesia. T. subannulatus will be split further in the future (G. Vogel pers. comm. September 2011).
This species was previously recognized in the genus Trimeresurus, and Popeia is considered a subgenus of Trimeresurus by some authors (David et al. 2011).

Other members of the "Python curtus group" formerly included within this species are now considered to be distinct species (Keogh et al. 2001, Rawlings et al. 2008, Zug et al. 2011); P. brongersmai in the remainder of Sumatra and in mainland Southeast Asia, P. breitensteini from Borneo, and P. kyaiktiyo from Myanmar. The occurrence, origin and taxonomic status of members of the P. curtus group in Indochina, currently assigned to P. brongersmai, is uncertain (Zug et al. 2011).

This snake is a member of the Oligodon taeniatus group, and prior to its description had been confused with the nominate species (David et al. 2008). Confusion may also be possible with the similar O. barroni and with O. mouhoti, since at least one known specimen exhibits patterning closely resembling the latter species (David et al. 2008).
The species was previously assigned to Popeia sabahi or Popeia popeiorum (David et al. 2009).

Malhotra et al. (2011) described this species based on specimens formerly assigned to Cryptelytrops macrops. The identity of a Vietnamese record from Phu Quoc of a viper in the C. macrops complex requires clarification, as this subpopulation may belong to either C. cardamomensis or C. rubeus. Although this record is not included in either this account or that for C. rubeus pending clarification, biogeographic affinities suggest this record is most likely to represent C. cardamomensis (B. Stuart and L. Grismer pers. comm. September 2011).

This species was recently described based on southern Vietnamese records formerly attributed to Cryptelytrops macrops (Malhotra et al. 2011). The identity of a Vietnamese record from Phu Quoc of a viper in the C. macrops complex requires clarification, as this subpopulation may belong to either C. cardamomensis or C. rubeus. Although this record is not included in either this account or that for C. cardamomensis pending clarification, biogeographic affinities suggest this record is most likely to represent C. cardamomensis (B. Stuart and L. Grismer pers. comm. September 2011).
Calotes nemoricola was first described by Jerdon in 1853 based on specimens collected from Coonoor Ghat, Nilgiri Hills, Western Ghats, India (Smith 1935).
Salea anamallayana was first described by Beddome in 1878 as Lophosalea anamallayana based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, Coimbatore district, Tamil Nadu (Smith 1935).

Both the identity of this species and its appropriate generic assignment are unclear, as it is known only from the original description, no surviving specimens are known to exist, and multiple authors have suggested that characters described for this species are more consistent with Calotes than with Salea (Das et al. 2019). These authors note that there are consequently only two "true" members of this genus, S. anamallayana and S. horsfieldii.

Coluber bholanathi was described by Sharma in 1976 based on three specimens (one male and two females) collected from Nagarjuna Hill, Andhra Pradesh (Sharma 1976, Srinivasulu and Das 2008). Additional work is needed on this species to validate its taxonomic placement with respect to Coluber gracilis.

Cnemaspis australis was described by Manamendra-Arachchi, Batuvita and Pethiyagoda in 2007 based on type specimen from Tirunelveli, Tamil Nadu, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007). The holotype is a syntype of C. tropidogaster, a taxon now understood to be endemic to Sri Lanka. Following recent clarification of the species concept for C. tropidogaster, research is needed to establish its relationship to Indian taxa and to verify the validity of C. australis.

Cnemaspis gracilis was first described based on specimens collected from Palghat Hills in Madras Presidency (presently Palakkad Hills, Kerala, India) (Beddome 1870). C. gracilis has been synonymized with C. kandiana previously (see Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007). Though Deraniyagala in 1932 considered the taxon gracilis as a subspecies of the taxon kandiana, Smith (1935) opined that it differed from kandiana in its scalation pattern, in having the subdigital lamellae being smaller and the postmentals being usually in contact (Smith 1935).  Despite the fact that diagnostic differences between C. gracilis and its congeners have been identified (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007), there remain taxonomic problems in the C. kandiana complex as a whole.

Cnemaspis monticola was first described by Manamendra-Arachchi, Batuvita and Pethiyagoda in 2007 based on type specimen from Wynaad, Kerala, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007). The holotype and paratypes are syntypes of C. tropidogaster, a taxon now understood to be endemic to Sri Lanka.  Following recent clarification of the species concept for C. tropidogaster, research is needed to establish its relationship to Indian taxa and to verify the validity of C. monticola.  The three known specimens are all females and thus the diagnostically important condition of precloacal/femoral pores cannot be evaluated.

Cnemaspis mysoriensis was described by Jerdon in 1853 based on specimens collected from Bangalore, Karnataka, India (Smith 1935, Giri et al. 2009).  The holotype is missing and a neotype was designated by Giri et al. (2009).
Cnemaspis otai was described based on specimens collected from Vellore, Tamil Nadu (Das and Bauer 2000).

Hemidactylus aaronbaueri was described by Giri in 2008 basing on specimens collected from Ghatghar, Junnar Taluk, Pune District, Maharashtra, India (Giri 2008).  Specimens from within the range of H. aaronbaueri have previously been referred to as H. giganteus (A. Bauer pers. comm. March 2011).

Hemidactylus albofasciatus was described by Grandison and Soman in 1963 based on specimens collected from Dorle, Rajapur taluk, Ratnagiri district, Maharashtra, India (Grandison and Soman 1963). This species was included in the genus Teratolepis (Kluge 2001, Das 2003), presumably based on the presence of enlarged scales on the tail and narrow digital lamellae. However, a recent molecular phylogenetic analysis by Bauer et al. (2008, 2010) and Bansal and Karanth (2010) reveals that Teratolepis is embedded within the tropical Asian clade of Hemidactylus.

Hemidactylus bowringii was first described as Doryura bowringii by Gray in 1845 based on specimens reportedly collected from Hong Kong or its neighbourhood (Smith 1935). A taxonomic evaluation of the bowringii group in Myanmar and adjacent Yunnan (McMahan and Zug 2007) precipitated a re-evaluation of Indian "H. bowringii", and subsequently these populations were reallocated to Hemidactylus aquilonius by Purkayastha et al. (2010), restricting H. bowringi to China and adjacent areas. McMahan and Zug (2007) proposed a provisional arrangement in which the name Hemidactylus bowringii applies to a taxon found "from eastern Indochina through southern China to Taiwan and the Ryukyus". These authors caution however that several nomenclatural issues remain to be resolved in order to ascertain whether this is the taxon to which the name H. bowringii properly refers. MacMahan and Zug (2007) suggest that the name Hemidactylus berdmorei, presently a junior synonym of H. bowringi, may be available for a taxon from Tanintharyi should this prove to be specifically distinct from H. bowringii group populations in central and northern Myanmar. Subsequent work involving "many weeks of survey" in north-central and southern Tanintharyi has not recorded bowringii group geckos, leading G. Zug (pers. comm. 2018) to conclude that H. berdmorei should be treated as a nomen dubium.
Hemidactylus gracilis was described by Blanford in 1871 based on specimens collected from southeast Berar and Raipur in Central Province (now in Chhattisgarh) (Smith 1935).

Hemidactylus treutleri was described by Mahony (2009) based on specimens collected from Golconda Fort, Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh. This species was recognized as a distinct taxon from other members of the Hemidactylus brookii complex (Mahony 2009).

Indian populations of H. triedrus are known to exhibit high genetic diversity (Bansal and Karanth 2010), and a taxonomic review of this species was conducted by Mirza et al. (2018). These authors described H. sahgali and H. whitakeri, and redescribed H. triedrus.

Mahony (2011) argued that H. subtriedrus is a nomen dubium and a junior subjective synonym of H. triedrus, and this scheme is followed here.

Hemidactylus lankae has previously been treated as a subspecies of Hemidactylus triedrus, but based on levels of genetic divergence, Bauer et al. (2010) proposed elevating it to species level. Mirza et al. (2018), noting that the types of H. lankae have been lost and the description is inadequate, proposed regarding this name as a nomen dubium pending a full examination of Sri Lankan material. These authors included a sequence of "H. lankae" in their phylogeny and found that it formed a clade with H. triedrus sensu stricto, but it is not clear that either their sequence or that of Bauer et al. (2010) represents "true" H. lankae and the identity of this taxon remains unknown. Morphological variation within Sri Lankan subpopulations suggests that more than one taxon may be included in the present concept of H. lankae, possibly including an undescribed species from northern islands, and that true H. triedrus may range into the northern province of Sri Lanka (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009).

For the purposes of this assessment, Sri Lankan populations are retained within H. triedrus and H. lankae is considered a junior synonym pending resolution of taxonomic issues within this group.

Mabuya allapallensis was described based on specimens collected from Allapally, near Chanda, Chandrapur district, Maharashtra (Schmidt 1926). Smith (1935) considered M. allapallensis to be a variant of M. macularia, which it closely resembles, but was subsequently revalidated by Sharma (1969).  Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002), this taxon is presently included within the genus Eutropis Fitzinger, 1843.

Tiliqua trivittata was originally described by Hardwicke & Gray in 1827 based on drawings by Hardwicke of specimens collected from Dum Dum, West Bengal, India (Smith 1935). Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002) this taxon is presently included within Eutropis Fitzinger 1843.

Riopa albopunctata was described by Gray in 1846 based on specimen from "Madras", India (Smith 1935). Greer (1977) subsequently synonymized Riopa within Lygosoma. Ganesh (2017) noted that Lygosoma is neuter rather than feminine, and that the correct specific epithet for this species is albopunctatum rather than the widely-used albopunctata.

Lygosoma goaensis was described by Sharma (1976) based on specimens collected from Goa. A recent record from a site in Maharashtra is considered to represent this species, however, taxonomic work is required to clarify this, as this record might instead represent an undescribed species.

This species, as Hagria vosmaeri, was described by Gray in 1839 based on speciemens from "Java", later corrected to Bengal, India (Smith 1935, Seetharamaraju et al. 2009). It has been noted that this species differs from Lygosoma lineata by only a single, variable character (Boulenger 1887), and as such research is needed to verify whether L. vosmaeri is a valid species.

Ristella guentheri was described by Boulenger in 1887 based on specimens collected from Sirimalai Hills, Madura district, India (Smith 1935). Records of this species from sites east of Palani (Sirimalai) may represent a different species from those from the western slopes of the Western Ghats.

Deraniyagala (1937) erected the subspecies Hemidactylus maculatus hunae based on a holotype from Sri Lanka, and assigned material from South India to this new form. Agarwal et al. (2011) described H. graniticolus based on six of these South Indian specimens, restricting H. hunae (elevated to a full species by Bauer et al. 2010) to Sri Lanka, the remaining Indian material being found to represent H. maculatus.
Hemidactylus parvimaculatus was treated as a subspecies of H. brookii Gray, 1845 when it was first described by Derayanigala (1953). Bauer et al. (2010) raised it to species level.
Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the systematics of this species throughout its range and its relationship with members of the Lycodon aulicus complex (C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2019).

Uropeltis bicatenata was described as Silybura bicatenata by Günther in 1864 based on specimen collected in Deccan,  India  (Smith 1943). Uropeltis bicatenata has been considered a junior synonym of Uropeltis ceylanica Cuvier, 1829 (nomen nudum), implicitly or explicitly, since Beddome (1886) until resurrected from synonymy by Gower et al. (2008).
Calodactylus aureus was described by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Tirupattur hills (=Tirupati hills), Eastern Ghats (Smith 1935).

Hemidactylus aquilonius was described by McMahan and Zug (2007) based on specimens collected from He Pu, Kachin, Myanmar. A taxonomic revision of the bowringii group (McMahan and Zug 2007) precipitated a re-evaluation of Indian "Hemidactylus bowringii", and these populations were subsequently reallocated to Hemidactylus aquilonius by Purkayastha et al. (2010).

Members of this genus have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected a new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.

This species is a species complex containing multiple morphs and crossing several biogeographic zones (P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019). There is a degree of confusion over the identity of the type locality, which has variously been given as Bengal or Dehradun (the latter of which appears to be an incorrect assignment based on the type locality of one of the synonyms Euprepes warthii, a name coined in 1885, as the original locality was given as Bengal) which will affect the appropriate identification of this species following taxonomic revision. Only the holotype of E. warthii is available, which may have contributed to this confusion.

The taxonomy of Sibynophis sagittarius and S. subpunctatus is confused. Morgan (1973), in his revision of Sibynophiines, considered S. subpunctatus to be a synonym of S. sagittarius. At present, they are considered to represent two separate species (Captain et al. 2004), but due to this historical confusion the distributions of the two species are in need of clarification.

Dendrelaphis chairecacos was described as Dendrophis chairecacos by Boie in 1827 basing on drawing by Dr. Patrick Russell (Smith 1943). This species has been recently resurrected from the synonymy of D. tristis and a neotype has been designated from Kottayam, Kerala (van Rooijen and Vogel 2009).
Oligodon venustus was described by Jerdon in 1853 as Xenodon venustum based on specimen collected from north Kanara, Karnataka (Smith 1943). Smith (1943) opines that the type is lost.

Current nomenclature within the genus Dipsosaurus is not supported with recent genetic data. Hypervariable markers (microsatellites), which are appropriate for identifying current population structure have revealed three distinct groups on the Baja Peninsula: one in North Baja and two in South Baja (Valdivia-Carrillo et al. 2017). Whereas, DNA sequence data (from mitochondrial and nuclear markers), which are appropriate for identifying long-term divergence, support the mid-peninsular divergence found with the microsatellite markers, with a single evolutionary significant unit in South Baja (Packer et al. 2015, M. Packer et al. unpublished data). This mid-peninsular divergence has also been shown in multiple other taxa that are distributed across Baja (Leaché et al. 2007, Dolby et al. 2015). Lastly, the DNA sequence data also reveals connectivity between the northern Baja populations and the mainland populations (Packer et al. 2015). Thus, there are likely two evolutionary significant units within the genus, neither of which correspond to current species or subspecies boundaries. The species currently known as Dipsosaurus catalinensis is included in this assessment.

Amarasinghe et al. (2018) designated a neotype for E. multifasciata and examined the taxonomy of names associated with the Eutropis multifasciata group using both molecular and morphological data, and found that the subspecies E. m. balinensis and E. m. tjendikianensis represent junior synonyms of E. multifasciata. This species has long been considered a species complex, and deep divergence between several 16S clades identified by Mulcahy et al. (2018) supports this suggestion.

Two species of Hydrosaurus are currently reported from the Philippines; H. amboinensis in the south and H. pustulatus in the north. However, there is some confusion in the identification of species and consequently the distribution of these species. Further taxonomic studies are needed to clarify the distribution of Hydrosaurus in the Philippines (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).
