Although the holotype was labeled as coming from Hong Kong this species' presence in China is questionable (Zhao et al. 1999).
Barley et al. (2020) found genetic divergence between higher-elevation and lowland populations in the Cordillera, and recommend research into mid-elevation contact zones to understand gene flow.
This species was called Cosymbotus platyurus until the revision of geckos in the genus Hemidactylus by Carranza and Arnold in 2006 (Kaiser et al. 2011).

The taxonomy of this species is very poorly understood. It is not clear whether the nominotypic population in Northern Sulawesi is conspecific with other Sulawesi populations or the Philippine population.

Sphenomorphus variegatus is a species complex. The type locality has been restricted to Mindanao and true S. variegatus is likely limited to the Philippines, where it is widespread. "S. variegatus" on Sulawesi is a separate species complex that is also widespread and abundant. S. variegatus is also known from a few specimens from Borneo, Flores, and Morotai, all of which are likely misidentifications (J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017). Sulawesi population are conspecific with those in the Philippine and within Sulawesi, it is likely to be a species complex (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

R. Brown and A. Diesmos (pers. comm. 2007) suggested that the Palawan population may represent a distinct species. Subsequently, a wide-ranging investigation of both morphological and molecular diversity within Philippine species of Eutropis identified as many as six genetic clades that may warrant recognition as distinct species, including the Palawan lineage (Barley et al. 2013) despite highly conserved morphology. Work to describe several of the cryptic species identified by Barley et al. (2013) is presently underway (R. Brown pers. comm. 2017).
Species boundaries within Dasia are not well-defined and the taxonomic status of this species has not been investigated (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

This widespread gecko may be a species complex (Rösler et al. 2011). Genetic data suggests that this species' occurrence at least in the Lesser Sunda Islands, where it is widespread, is a consequence of human-mediated dispersal, as subpopulations on these islands exhibit no genetic diversity compared with subpopulations from Java (J. McGuire unpubl. data). Rösler et al. (2011) revalidated the name Gekko reevesii for populations from northern Viet Nam and southern China long recognized as being morphologically distinct from, and broadly sympatric with, G. gecko. These authors identified two "relatively deeply divergent evolutionary lineages" within this species, and indicated that deeper sampling of G. gekko from across its range is necessary to resolve the systematics of this group.

This taxon is known to consist of multiple independent lineages (Bucol et al. 2011 suggest four or six, R. Brown pers. comm. 2017 opines that the true figure could be 5-7, or greater). At least one genetic lineage - identified by McGuire and Heang (2001) from Siquijor - appears to correspond to differences in patterning between this form and animals from Negros (Bucol et al. 2011). The taxonomy of this possible species complex is likely to require revision (Bucol et al. 2011), but presently remains unresolved (R. Brown pers. comm. 2017).

Genetic and morphological research identified three geographically distinct evolutionary lineages within the widespread Lygosoma quadrupes, corresponding to the recently-recognized Philippine form L. tabonorum (Heitz et al. 2016), a taxon restricted to Java to which the name L. quadrupes is applicable, and a lineage found throughout the Southeast Asian mainland (Siler et al. 2018). This latter taxon, representing the major part of the former range of L. quadrupes, was described as the new species L. siamensis by Siler et al. (2018).

This species is often confused with Gekko mindorensis. Subpopulations within the Philippines are assigned arbitrarily to one species or the other based on the island on which they are found. G. monarchus-mindorensis is likely either a single species or a larger species complex than suggested by the existing division (R. Brown and E. Rico pers. comm. 2007). This latter view is supported by more recent research (Brown et al. 2008, 2009; Rösler et al. 2011), including the description of G. rossi from the island of Calayan (Brown et al. 2009).

Records of this species from Borneo were assigned to the newly-recognized Lipinia inexpectata by Das and Austin (2007), although the name L. quadrivittata is used - presumably in error - for records from Malaysia in Danum Valley Research Center and Nang Tekalit, Sarawak, and Dewhurst, Sabah in the Field Museum database (The Field Museum 2017).

The Philippine populations are referred to the subspecies Lamprolepis smaragdina philippina (Mertens, 1928), which is endemic to the Philippines. A taxonomic revision may lead to a further division of the Philippine populations as some inter-island variation is evident (M. Gaulke pers. comm. 2008). Linkem et al. (2013) sampled specimens from Papua New Guinea, from the Philippines and the Moluccas. These authors identified two clades within “Lamprolepis smaragdina” in the eastern Moluccas; the clade from Halmahera (for which the name Lamprolepis smaragdina will be applicable following any taxonomic revision, as it is shared with the species’ type locality on the Caroline Islands) reappears in PNG, but a separate clade is found on Seram. In the absence of material from Indonesian New Guinea, it is unknown which clade(s) historical records of this species from the region represent. Genetic evidence does not support the existence of numerous previously recognized subspecies from the New Guinean region.

Lygosoma buergeri is tentatively treated as a junior synonym following Brown (1991), based on this author's observation that the only difference between this species and New Guinean Emoia atrocostata is in the number of scale rows (28 rather than 38). Brown (1991) considers that this difference may simply be a typographic error. Subsequent examination of the holotype by A. Allison supports this conclusion (A. Allison pers. comm. 2013).

This may be a species complex, within which distributional boundaries are not known. Two species (D. leucurus and D. novaeguineae) are currently recognized for the Philippines, but the distributional boundary between the two is unclear. Sanguila et al. (2016) refer to the Mindanao population as Dibamus cf. leucurus, and suspect that Philippine members of this group represent an undescribed species.

Recent work has revalidated the neglected name Bronchocela burmana for populations from Myanmar, and the relative distributions of the two species in Thailand are in need of clarification (Zug et al. 2017). Two additional recently-described taxa from Thailand and Malaysia, Bronchocela shenlong and B. rayaensis, have also historically been confused with B. cristatella (Grismer et al. 2015) Hallerman (2009) described the new species B. rubrigularis from the Nicobar Islands; no subsequent work appears to have investigated any other records assigned to B. cristatella from the Nicobars, and these islands are still included within the distribution of B. cristatella by Grismer (2011a,b) and Chan-ard et al. (2015). Grismer et al. (2015) report that outstanding taxonomic issues within B. cristatella, including the fact that this species lacks a type specimen or type locality, are due to be addressed "at length in an integrative taxonomic revision of the entire genus".

The name Darevskia lindholmi has, MacCulloch et al. (2000) note, an "unusual history" (Ineich and Doronin 2017). No species of this or a related name has ever been formally described; Latz and Cyrén (1936) provisionally proposed the subspecific epithet lindholmi for Crimean specimens, should these prove distinct from the topotypes of Lacerta saxicola (which they did not examine), and these authors have subsequently been treated as the authors of this name. Doronin (2012a) subsequently corrected this, clarifying that according to the Zoological Code of Nomenclature the author of Lacerta saxicola lindholmi must be Ščerbak, 1962.

The only differential diagnosis appears to be a table presented by MacCulloch et al. (2000), but these authors did not formally describe the taxon (which they determined warranted specific status, as earlier suggested by Ryabinin et al. 1996). The name has subsequently been accepted, as Darevskia lindholmi (Ananjeva et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).

The species was previously included within Boiga cynodon, but differs in body colouration and having a higher number of body scales. The Lesser Sunda island population was described as the new species Boiga hoeseli by Ramadhan et al. (2010).

Earlier included under Dendrelaphis pictus (Linnaeus, 1758). The populations referred to as D. pictus from Western Ghats are now recognized as Dendrelaphis ashoki Vogel and Rooijen, 2011 following a revision of this species complex in India.

This was formerly regarded as a subspecies of Ovophis monticola. Malhotra et al. (2011) recommended elevating it to a full species based on genetic research and morphological variation. This account follows that recommendation; however as no formal taxonomic action has been taken to elevate this taxon, its appropriate taxonomic status remains uncertain.
The distribution of Ovophis monticola (sensu stricto) follows Malhotra et al. (2011).

This species is included in older literature within Gonocephalus godeffroyi (e.g. McCoy 1978, McCoy 1980). The Melanesian-Australian agamid genus Hypsilurus was completely reviewed by Manthey and Denzer (2006), and the name Hypsilurus macrolepis resurrected for this endemic eastern Solomon Island species. The characters these authors used to differentiate this species from H. longi are, however, not adequately defined, and further comparative material is required to verify species boundaries in these taxa (M. McCoy pers. comm. 2012).

The Melanesian-Australian agamid genus Hypsilurus was completely reviewed by Manthey and Denzer (2006), and the name Hypsilurus macrolepis resurrected for this endemic eastern Solomon Island species. The characters these authors used to differentiate the resurrected Hypsilurus macrolepis (formerly a synonym of H. godeffroyi) from H. longi are not adequately defined, and further comparative material is required to verify species boundaries in these taxa (M. McCoy pers. comm. 2012).
This is a widespread species that may well represent a species complex (P. Oliver and A. Allison pers. comms. 2014).

The Palauan type locality of Hypsilurus godeffroyi, previously considered to include related forms from the Solomon Islands and New Guinea now understood to be separate species, is of uncertain reliability (Bauer and Watkins-Cowell 2001). The collector Alfred Tetens did indeed visit Palau, and accurately reported the provenance of a number of species, however H. goddefroyi is one of several species he reported from the island group that have never subsequently been rediscovered there, records considered in error by Schmeltz (1869). More recently, subfossil remains of a large agamid lizard have been identified from Palau, and the types of H. godeffroyi themselves are similar to but distinct from any species known from nearby regions (Bauer and Watkins-Cowell 2001, Crombie and Pregill 1999). This supports the contention by Crombie and Pregill (1999) that the Palauan locality is an accurate record. Bauer and Watkins-Cowell (2001) however caution that the collector's inconsistent record of providing accurate locality data combined with poor knowledge of the agamid fauna from Pacific islands west of Manus (in New Guinea's Admiralty Islands) make it difficult to establish with certainty that the types of H. godeffroyi belong to the same species as the animal known from remains in Palau.

This account provisionally retains the name H. godeffroyi for the Palauan lizard, which is not referrable to any other known species of Hypsilurus and which, from the failure of extensive surveys to locate surviving populations, is considered to be an endemic, probably extinct taxon. Further taxonomic work is required to establish whether this is the correct name for the Palauan species.
Two subspecies are recognized: Candoia aspera aspera, confined to the Bismarck Archipelago, and C. a. schmidti throughout the remainder of the range.

For all Candoia spp., current taxonomy follows Reynolds and Henderson (2018) and relevant references cited therein, who distinguish five species and 12 populations. At present Candoia paulsoni includes six populations, i.e. C, p. paulsoni, C. p. mcdowelli, C. p. rosadoi, C. p. sadlieri, C. p. tasmai, and C. p. vindumi.

The type locality of Candoia carinata is Ambon Island (Böhme et al. 1998). Currently two populations are recognized, C. c. carinata and C. c. tepedeleni (Smith et al. 2001).  The taxonomic status of specimens in Raja Ampat is uncertain (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019). The genus still remains taxonomically unresolved, and Indonesia's historical collection needs to be re-examined (A Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).

Kaiser et al. (2018) revised the complicated taxonomy of this species, restricting it to the northern islands in Maluku and removed Lycodon aruensis and L. lividum from synonymy. A consequence of this action, which Kaiser et al. (2018) acknowledge as "unfortunate", is that records from New Guinea - where S. modestus was formerly considered to be widespread and likely to represent records of multiple species - cannot presently be assigned with confidence to any named species.
This species is a complex of 3-4 species (R. Fisher pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of Gekko vittatus is currently uncertain and should be reconsidered when published data becomes available (M. McCoy pers. comm. November 2011).

This species was confused with Lepidodactylus lugubris for about 100 years, as were several other species.  Ota et al. (1995) resurrected this species from synonomy, and it is now widely recognized as the maternal ancestor for the parthenogenetic L. lugubris (Radtkey et al. 1995).
This species exhibits low levels of genetic differentiation from Lepidodactylus gardneri (P. Oliver et al. 2020).

A unique and specialised species, in a monotypic genus, described by Gray (1855). Köhler (1997) referred the Bougainville and Buka populations to the subspecies Corucia zebrata alfredschmidti based on the colour and pattern of live animals. McCoy (2006), on the basis of this description, suggests that this would also include the Shortland Islands populations. All individuals to the east of the Shortland Islands are thus referred to as Corucia zebrata zebrata.

This species appears to be a complex of several species, the taxonomy is  currently being assessed by several researchers (Hamilton, Fisher,  Richmond, and Zug). Recent surveys in southern Lau have found that populations there might represent separate species (R. Fisher pers. comm.).
This probably represents a species complex.
This is a species complex.

This species was formerly known under the name Emoia murphyi. Based on morphological and genetic differences some populations currently assigned to E. tongana are being described as a different species (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2012).

M. McCoy (pers. comm. November 2011) states that "Based on extensive observations of living lizards in the wild, and examination of preserved specimens, I believe that the Malaita population of this skink may represent an undescribed species."

This species was originally described as a Raratonga population of Emoia trossula. Its appropriate taxonomic rank is unclear. Although it was originally described based on its molecular differentiation from other island populations of E. trossula (Zug et al. 2011), unpublished genetic results confirm its close relationship to E. trossula and it has been suggested that it may warrant subspecific rank within E. trossula (R. Fisher pers. comm. 2012). This account considers E. tuitarere a valid full species pending any formal taxonomic action to change its taxonomic status and to clarify the taxonomy of E. trossula, which Zug et al. (2011) imply may be a species complex.
This is considered to be a species complex, and it is likely that the population from Rotuma is a separate species.
This is a species complex, the nominate population is from the southern Maluku Islands from Seram and Ambon, these are likely different from other populations (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
Specimens from the Talaud Islands represent a distinct, undescribed, species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
This species is currently incorrectly included in Sphenomorphus, it needs to be reassigned to another genus (G. Shea pers. comm. to M. McCoy November 2011).

This species exhibits "extraordinary" morphological variability across its range, both geographically and altitudinally, and at a number of localities in Western Province two morphotypes coexist without evidence of intergradation (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). Further taxonomic research is required to clarify the systematics of this likely species complex, as no genetic work has yet been conducted and no tissue is available from the type locality (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015).
This is most likely a species complex.
The populations on Buka and Bougainville show some genetic differences, which may necessitate undertaking conservation measures for both island populations.
First described by Parker (1939).

This species was described with a New Caledonian type locality, however, all subsequent records of this species are from the Solomon Islands and the New Caledonian locality is presumed to be in error (G. Shea pers. comm. 2013).
Although the Rennell Island monitor has been raised to full species level (Böhme et al. 2002), McCoy (2006) regards Varanus juxtindicus as a synonym of V. indicus.
Long regarded as a subspecies of the widespread varanid lizard Varanus indicus (Mertens 1941), it was elevated to full species status by Sprackland (1994).

Vences et al. (2004) confirmed the validity of Hemidactylus mercatorius as a species distinct from H. mabouia, with which it had previously been confused, considering that it represented mainland African and Madagascan members of this species complex. Uncertainty over the exact definitions of these two species, and potential confusion with additional species of Hemidactylus, remain, making it difficult to establish the global distribution of either H. mercatorius or H. mabouia. Vences et al. (2004) found that Madagascan H. mercatorius were genetically distinct from a sample from Mozambique. Within Madagascan H. mercatorius, at least three distinct lineages appear to exist (Vences et al. 2004, Boumans et al. 2007). Rocha et al. (2005) found that Gulf of Guinea "H. mabouia" identified by Jesus et al. (2005) belonged to the northern Madagascar lineage of H. mercatorius identified by Vences et al. (2004). This concept of H. mercatorius as a widespread island species appears to correspond to Clade A of the H. mabouia-mercatorius complex identified by Rocha et al. (2010), which is also found in Tanzania, South Africa (where three separate lineages have been identified), Uganda, the Seychelles, including a lineage endemic to the Aldabra archipelago, and Réunion (Sanchez et al. 2012). However, given the apparent basal relationships of mainland African members of this clade and continuing uncertainty over their taxonomic assignment, this assessment follows Rocha et al. (2010) in restricting the name H. mercatorius to island populations within this clade, with continental populations remaining under the name H. mabouia until the taxonomy of this species complex is resolved. This treatment is acknowledged as being "completely inadequate" (Rocha et al. 2010) as East African coastal populations alone exhibit substantial variation both between and within several recognized major lineages, and the taxonomy of this species complex, and clarification of the mainland African range of H. mercatorius, is in need of further resolution. Based on current understanding, Clade A of H. mercatorius also appears to represent introduced populations in South America and Cape Verde traditionally referred to H. mabouia (Carranza and Arnold 2006, S. Rocha pers, comm. April 2012). Research into the genetics of South American H. mabouia is however preliminary. Only one lineage has so far been identified from Brazil, however there is insufficient data to clarify whether this is the only introduced lineage in the Americas (D. Borges pers. comm. April 2012). Pending resolution of this issue, all Neotropical introductions of this species are referable to H. mabouia (D. Borges pers. comm. April 2012), and this treatment is followed here. Within mainland West Africa, populations of H. mabouia ranging from Senegal to Guinea, Ghana, Togo and Cameroon are genetically similar (J-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012), but these have not been compared with East African samples and so the relationship between this widespread form and the present concept of H. mercatorius is unclear.

Butler et al. (2019) report that work is ongoing to revise the systematics of the H. mabouia complex, and that this will recognize Hemidactylus benguellensis, presently a junior synonym of H. mabouia (but tentatively recognized as distinct by Marques et al. 2018), as a genetically and morphologically distinct species. This account refrains from accepting this taxonomic change pending the completion of this wider-ranging revision.

Following Peters and Orejas-Miranda (1970) Amastridium sapperi has been treated as a subspecies of A. veliferum, and this arrangement is still followed by some authorities (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2010). Recent work, however, generally treats it as a full species (e.g. Wilson and Townsend 2006, Wilson et al. 2010).

Wermuth (1967) considered Agama cornii, known from a single specimen with the type locality Om Ager (in Eritrea) a doubtful species. Moody (1980) formally synonymized A. cornii within A. hartmanni, however, this work was an unpublished doctoral thesis and no justification was presented for this decision (Wagner and Bauer 2011). This revision was followed by Largen and Spawls (2010) who indicated that A. cornii was an invalid name. Wagner and Bauer (2011) investigated the taxonomy of poorly-known species of Agama from the Horn of Africa, and found that the sole specimen of A. cornii is identical to the types of A. hartmanni, confirming that A. cornii is a junior synonym of A. hartmanni.
Central Saharan populations were recently recognized as a distinct species, Agama tassiliensis (Geniez et al. 2011).

This could be the sister species to Acanthodactylus aureus and more research is needed into the taxonomy of this species. This species has a continental distribution while A. aureus has a coastal distribution.

This is a complex of three known forms. Trape et al. (2012) apply the name Acanthodactylus inornatus to populations at the northern edge of the Sahara, but do not take formal taxonomic action and include this form within their description of "Complexe Acanthodactylus dumerilii". The appropriate taxonomic status of a form from central Western Sahara is uncertain, but it may warrant recognition as either a subspecies or full species (Trape et al. 2012).

This could be the sister species to Acanthodactylus taghitensis and more research is needed into the taxonomy of this species. This species has a coastal distribution while A. taghitensis has a continental distribution.

Baha El Din (2007) examined records of this species from Egypt and found that populations east of 28º E represented a discrete species which he described as Acanthodactylus aegyptius. The two species are, however, sympatric in part of the Egyptian Western Desert, and around the Qattara Depression (Baha El Din 2007). Records from eastern Egypt, including all areas east of the Nile, and from Israel, are attributable to A. aegyptius.
The northern subspecies, Anolis lemurinus bourgeaei, has sometimes been treated as a full species. Anolis rhombifer was synonymized within A. lemurinus by Fitch and Seigel (1984).

This is considered to be a complex consisting of at least three species, with the available names Anolis nannodes Cope, 1864 (Chiapas to northern Nicaragua) and A. intermedius Peters, 1863 (Costa Rica) available for populations outside the Atlantic versant of Veracruz (G. Köhler pers. comm. 2012). The complicated status of these names and of others currently included within the synonymy of A. laeviventris remains to be fully resolved, and this assessment follows Uetz et al. (2019) in retaining a traditional concept of A. laeviventris pending a taxonomic revision.

The only record from Mexico was of one specimen reportedly collected from Cozumel over 100 years ago and described as ANOLIS cozumelae. Closer inspection of the specimen found this to be a specimen of A. cristatellus, but it has not been reported again on the island and there is now significant doubt regards the validity of this record.

Anolis damulus, described based on vague characters, is of uncertain provenance and identity (S. Poe pers. comm. 2011). The description does not indicate a type locality, but later workers have assumed a locality in Mexico. If this provenance is correct, it may be conspecific with the apparently similar Anolis rodriguezii or another common Mexican anole, but examination of the holotype is needed to clarify this (S. Poe pers. comm. 2011). A museum specimens referred to this species exists from Oaxaca, but it is presently unclear how this specimen relates to the holotype, and so whether the two represent the same species (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2019).

Anolis sericeus sensu lato has recently been split by Köhler and Vesely (2010) into three species based on hemipenial and dewlap characters. Poe et al. (2017) treated the enigmatic taxon Anolis williamsi, described from Brazil probably in error (Uetz et al. 2019), as a tentative junior synonym of A. sericeus. Conversely, M. Rodrigues (unpubl.) suspects A. williamsi is likely to be a junior synonym of A. fuscoauratus (L. Mahler pers. comm. 2019) Köhler (2012) synonymized A. cumingi within A. sericeus.

A historical record from Half Moon Cay in Belize attributed to the closely-related Anolis carolinensis probably represents this species (L. Mahler pers. comm. October 2011), and further surveys on this island have never recorded A. carolinensis here (Lee 2000). Further studies are needed into the populations on the islands of Belize which may warrant species status. This may also be true for the Mexican populations.

Armstead et al. (2017) removed Anolis parvauritus from southern Colombia and northern Ecuador from synonymy with A. biporcatus. These authors expressed "little doubt" that the resulting concept of A. biporcatus is a species complex which will need more extensive geographic sampling to resolve.

Barlow et al. (2013) studied the molecular phylogeography of Bitis arietans throughout Africa (but excluding Somalia where B. a. somalica occurs) and determined that there were several parapatric mitochondrial clades, including a widespread southern African clade subdivided into four separate subclades. While the taxonomic status of the various African clades requires further investigation, evidence of secondary admixture genes among previously isolated refugial subpopulations suggests that southern African subclades do not represent cryptic species. A complex history of refugial isolation and secondary expansion associated with climatic cycles was indicated for southern Africa (Barlow et al. 2013). Two subspecies are currently recognized, namely B. a. arietans (widespread in sub-Saharan Africa) and B. a somalica (restricted to Somalia) (Branch 1999).

Until recently, the widespread Boa constrictor was the only recognized species within the genus Boa, with multiple morphological variants across its range described as subspecies. Two Caribbean populations, described as Boa constrictor orophias and B. c. nebulosa, have been informally recognized as full species for almost a decade (Henderson and Powell 2009). Multiple recent studies (summarized in Card et al. 2016) have investigated the systematics of Boa constrictor across its wider range on both morphological and molecular grounds. The name Boa constrictor was subsequently confined to the South American clade defined by Reynolds et al. (2014), with North and Central American taxa referred to Boa imperator.

The systematics of Boa constrictor may require further research to resolve: Card et al. (2016) applied a model that made the a priori assumption that South American samples comprised a single species and so were unable to discriminate between South American clades. These authors did, however, report a sister relationship between a Colombian clade and the remainder of Boa constrictor + imperator based on mitochondrial data and also found support for three distinct mitochondrial clades within the remainder of B. constrictor. In their text these authors assigned records from the Choco of Colombia and Ecuador to B. imperator, apparently following the division between northern and southern clades first identified by Hynková et al. (2009), and suggested that the latter may range into Peru, but did not discuss the basis for this assignment their map of the three clades indicates a southern range limit for B. imperator in northernwestern Colombia.

A systematic revision of this species has been warranted for some time, based on evidence that the traditional concept was not monophyletic (Jadin et al. 2012). On the basis of molecular evidence reported by these authors, Jadin et al. (2012) redescribed Cerrophidion godmani and described two new species - C. sasai (Costa Rica and Panama) and C. wilsoni (Guatemala and El Salvador) - to encompass populations south of Guatemala formerly assigned to this taxon.
Greenbaum et al. (2006) revised and re-described this species, confirming its distinctiveness compared with Chalcides ocellatus.
There is a single record of this species in Mexico that is based on a misidentified Clelia scytalina. It is not thought to occur in Mexico.
Previously considered a subspecies of Crotalus durissus, it has recently been elevated to species status by Wüster et al. (2005).

Crotalus totonacus was previously considered within the Crotalus  durissus species complex, and it is considered by recent studies to be in the Crotalus molossus species complex (Campbell and Lamar 2004, Wüster et al. 2005, Anderson and Greenbaum 2012, Alencar et al. 2016)

This species is paraphyletic, and resolution is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of Crotalus simus in much of its range. The species concept applied here follows Savage et al. (2005), who designated a neotype for this species and applied the name to Central American snakes formerly considered to belong to C. d. durissus.

Very low levels of genetic divergence between this species and the similar Echis pyramidum (with which it is sometimes confused) have led to suggestions that E. leucogaster should be considered a subspecies of the former taxon (Arnold et al. 2009, Pook et al. 2009).
The status of Gonatodes fuscus is presently unresolved (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2017), and it is retained here as a subspecies of G. albogularis following recent literature.

In Venezuela, the name "speciosus" is used for convenience, but the taxon known as Gymnophthalmus speciosus in South America is not the same taxon present in Central America, to which the name G. speciosus is properly applicable (Ugueto and Rivas-Fuenmayor 2010, Vanzolini and Carvalho 1991, Carvalho 1997). This assessment encompasses the species complex as presently understood, including populations from Colombia and Venezuela. Records from southern Apure state in Venezuela represent an undescribed taxon in the process of being described (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2016), and are excluded from this account.

This species is difficult to distinguish from Hemidactylus robustus (Largen and Spawls 2006), which has itself historically often been treated as a synonym of H. turcicus (e.g. by Loveridge 1947). While H. robustus is now accepted as a valid taxon, the observation that many specimens exhibit apparently intermediate sets of characteristics (Loveridge 1947) is borne out by examination of Ethiopian H. sinaitus (Largen and Spawls 2006). B. Lanza (in Largen and Spawls 2006) attributes these shared characteristics to the existence of possible hybrids, but it may be that the relationship between H. robustus and H. sinaitus is in need of further investigation.

This species exhibits considerable geographic variation in morphology, and it is suspected that this variation reflects the existence of multiple species (e.g. Savage 2002). Accordingly, Ruane et al. (2014) split Lampropeltis triangulum into seven species.

Collins (1991) proposed that subspecies taylori be recognized as a distinct species but presented no supporting data (see also Dowling 1993); taylori intergrades morphologically with two adjacent subspecies and does not appear to be a distinct entity (Williams 1988, Roth and Smith 1990).

Armstrong et al. (2001) examined populations of subspecies syspila and elapsoides in western Kentucky and adjacent Tennessee and concluded that the two taxa exist in sympatry with minimal, if any, gene flow between the populations.

The correct year of publication of the original description is 1789 (not 1788 as commonly cited).
Spawls et al. (2002) note that the current concept of this species, which ranges from Senegal to East Africa, is probably incorrect, and suggest that the genus Latastia is in need of revision.
This is part of a species complex. Taxonomic work is underway to resolve this complex.

Campbell (1998) considered Leptodeira septentrionalis polysticta (southern Mexico to Costa Rica) to be a distinct species, however considered that it may be conspecific with L. s. ornata of lower Central America and South America. Lee (2000) retained polysticta as a subspecies of  L. septentrionalis, and this scheme is followed here.
Leptophis santamartensis is considered a junior synonym of L. ahaetulla occidentalis (Albuquerque et al. 2012).

The taxonomy of Epictia (formerly Leptotyphlops) in Central America is in need of resolution. Sunyer and Köhler (2010) provisionally recognize only the single species E. goudoti pending clarification of this situation. These authors tentatively synonymize E. nasalis and E. ater within this species, the latter without discussion. These authors consider E. nasalis a possible synonym on the basis that the single known individual differs from typical E. goudoti by a single scale character and no further specimens have been found in 70 years, indicating that it may be merely an aberrant individual rather than a genuine species.

Subsequently, McCranie and Hedges (2016) discussed the complex taxonomic history of E. goudoti and related species and elevated E. ater (including E. nasalis as a junior synonym), E. albifrons, E. bakewelli and E, phenops from subspecies of E. goudoti, on the basis of both morphological and molecular evidence. As molecular data was not available for Colombia, where the type locality of E. goudoti occurs, further taxonomic issues may exist within E. goudoti, which as now defined ranges from Panama to Trinidad. These authors return E. fallax - removed from synonymy by Natera-Mumaw et al. (2015) - to the synonymy of E. goudoti, but do not comment on this assignment.
This species has often been placed in the genus Dryadophis, but Dixon and Tipton (2004) placed it in Mastigodryas on the basis of seniority.
This species has often been placed in the genus Dryadophis, but Dixon and Tipton (2004) placed it in Mastigodryas on the basis of seniority.

P. Geniez (pers. comm.) suggests that the record from Egypt does not correspond to Mesalina pasteuri. However, comparisons of specimens from Egypt and those from the type locality by S. Baha El Din (pers. comm.) indicate that the species is truly present in Egypt.

Baha El Din (2006) suggested that this species represents a species complex; subsequent genetic research has confirmed this view (Kapli et al. 2008). These latter authors identified several major clades as candidate species, as well as confirming the validity of the recently-described Mesalina bahaeldini, previously included within M. guttulata (Segoli et al. 2002). A revision of the M. guttulata species complex in the Middle East and Arabia was conducted by Sindaco et al. (2018), erecting the new species M. austroarabica and M. arnoldi for Arabian populations, identifying a further, undescribed candidate species from this region, and restricting M. guttulata to Africa. High levels of genetic variability within African populations suggest that unresolved taxonomic issues exist within the resulting concept of M. guttulata (Sindaco et al. 2018).

A recent molecular phylogenetic analysis covering northern populations of Oxybelis aeneus (from North America to Panama) found three distinct clades in this area, all of which differed from a fourth clade from Trinidad and Tobago (Jadin et al. 2019). These authors refrain from taking taxonomic action pending the results of ongoing research incorporating both molecular and morphological data across the full distribution of this species complex (Jadin et al. in preparation), and suspect that additional cryptic species will be recognized as a result of this work.

This species and Oxyrhopus petola, both originally described by Linnaeus (1758), have long been recognized to be synonymous. Savage (2011) investigated the complex nomenclatural history of this taxon, and determined O. petolarius to be the correct name for this species.

Philochortus rudolfensis is now considered to be a separate species by some authors (see Spawls et al. 2002). Uetz and Hallerman (2012) caution that only five specimens of this latter taxon are known, and suggest retaining it within P. intermedius pending further research, however Spawls et al. (2002) suggest that the two taxa are unlikely to be closely-related due to apparent differences in their habitat requirements. This account therefore provisionally follows Spawls et al. (2002) in treating P. rudolfensis as a separate species.

Parker (1942) reported an atypical specimen from the Haud in Somalia, which he tentatively assigned to "Philochortus intermedius subspec. ?" Largen and Spawls (2006) indicate that this specimen is "Clearly" not P. intermedius, but also that no further material of this form is known and that its taxonomic status cannot be clarified without additional specimens.
Animals recorded from Jordan represent Pristurus rupestris (R. Sindaco pers. comm.).

Records of Ptyodactylus hasselquistii, a northern African and southwest Asian species, from Mangu (=Mango in Togo - J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2012) and Shoa Hoggar Gebirge in Ghana (Uetz and Hallerman 2010) represent confusion with this species (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. June 2012). Records of P. hasselquistii from Cameroon also presumably represent confusion with P. ragazzii, which is known to occur in this country.

Difficulty in distinguishing Ptyodactylus populations on morphological grounds have been hampered by the morphological similarity of these geckos, and consequently many historically-described species have widely been treated as subspecies of a widely-distributed Ptyodactylus hasselquistii (see discussion in Metallinou et al. 2015).

Metallinou et al. (2015) performed the first genus-wide systematic revision of Ptyodactylus applying molecular techniques. They found high levels of genetic divergence within the P. hasselquistii complex (within which they retained the recently-described taxa P. orlovi, P. dhofarensis and P. ananjevae [Nazarov et al. 2013] pending the completion of ongoing work), and recovered two major clades that required further material from Arabia to fully resolve.

Simó-Riudalbas et al. (2017) conducted an analysis of Ptyodactylus hasselquisti across the Hajar Mountains. These authors identified two endemic lineages from these mountains, one corresponding to P. orlovi and one described as the new species P. ruusalijibalicus. These authors' analysis provided further support for the recognition of P. dhofarensis and P. ananjevae (Nazarov et al. 2013) and these are consequently recognized as valid species in this account, however the distributions of these taxa relative to P. hasselquisti remain unclear. A wider-ranging taxonomic revision of the P. hasselquistii complex is underway (S. Carranza pers. comm. 2018).

The status of this species in El Salvador is unclear. Smith et al. (2001) stated that Sceloporus acanthinus ranges into El Salvador, while Köhler et al. (2006) and Köhler (2008), following advice from E. N. Smith, included El Salvador populations in S. malachiticus. These accounts follow the latter authors in attributing Salvadorian records to S. malachitus.

Based on patterns of multilocus isozyme variation, Mendoza-Quijano et al. (1998) recognized Sceloporus variabilis marmoratus as a distinct species (Sceloporus marmoratus), and they proposed that the remaining S. variabilis populations be split into multiple species. In commenting on the proposed split, Crother et al. (2000) pointed out that the sample of marmoratus was from a single locality more than 500 km from the closest sample of S. v. variabilis and concluded that more extensive sampling from intermediate localities is needed to determine if marmoratus and variabilis are separate lineages.

Sceloporus variabilis marmoratus is retained here following Crother et al. (2000) and Bell et al. (2003) pending further investigation of its taxonomic status.
This taxon was elevated to species status by Arnold and Leviton (1977).

Hedges and McCranie (2012) examined the systematics of this species complex, assigning northern populations to the resurrected Sphenomorphus continentalis. These authors described two new species, S. leonardovaldezi and S. guanajae, based on records from the Bay Islands off the coast of Honduras. More recently, remaining "S. millepunctatus" populations from the Bay Islands have been examined and determined to represent two additional, distinct species, S. alphus (Islha de Guanaja) and S. poindexteri (Islha de Utila) (McCranie and Hedges 2013).

The large, globally-distributed genus Sphenomorphus has long been suspected to be paraphyletic; molecular analysis by Linkem et al. (2011) confirmed this and found the genus to be paraphyletic with regard to a large number of existing skink genera. These authors assigned S. incertus (which was not included in their analysis) to Scincella.
The status of this taxon is unclear.

On examination of the lectotype of Ascalabotes sthenodactylus, Metallinou and Crochet (2013) determined that this specimen belongs to S. mauritanicus, now generally regarded as a valid species. S. sthenodactylus is a widely-used name for a well-known taxon distributed south and east of the range of S. mauritanicus, and in order to preserve the prevailing usage of both names Metallinou and Crochet (2013) indicate an intent to apply to the International Commission for Zoological Nomenclature to permit a neotype designation. Pending a decision on any application, this account retains the prevailing usage for this species.

While it has been proposed that S. sthenodactylus as presently defined represents a species complex (S. Baha El Din pers. comm., Metallinou et al. 2012), in a review of the status of names proposed for North African Stenodactylus Metallinou and Crochet (2013) explicitly refrain from recognizing species within this complex pending further research. These authors do note that the name S. zavattari is available for a lineage identified by Metallinou et al. (2012) as ranging from Kenya to Egypt, should future work determine that this lineage warrants specific or subspecific recognition.
The subspecies Tarentola annularis relicta is restricted to southern Sudan.

This is a complex that contains up to three separate species. Two subspecies, Tarentola ephippiata hoggarensis and T. e. senegambiae have been elevated to full species status (citing molecular grounds, but without supporting data) by Trape et al. (2012) and that treatment is followed here.

This is thought to be a species complex (Mausfeld 2000, Böhme 1985). Populations attributed to this species in which adult males have unmarked throats have been attributed to Trachylepis langheldi (Trape et al. 2012).

Trapelus mutabilis is a taxonomically complex form with numerous recognized synonyms (Wermuth 1967; see Wagner et al. 2011 for currently-recognized synonymy). Wagner and Böhme (2007) confirmed that, as suspected from its variability and complex taxonomic history, the traditional concept of T. mutabilis is a species complex. These authors referred a specimen of "T. mutabilis" from Chad to a new species, T. schmitzi. Further research aimed at resolving taxonomic problems with this complex was hindered by the fact that no holotype for T. mutabilis has been located, and may not have been assigned (Wagner et al. 2011). Consequently, Wagner et al. (2011) assigned a neotype and redescribed this species in their revision of North African Trapelus. On the basis of combined morphological and molecular evidence, these authors restricted T. mutabilis to north and northeastern Africa, erecting the new species T. boehmei for western populations.

Wagner et al. (2011) confirmed subspecific status for T. m. pallidus, variously considered either a synonym for T. mutabilis (Schleich et al. 1996) or a full species T. pallidus (e.g. Moody 1980, Baha El Din 2006), and erected the new subspecies T. m. poppeki. Bauer et al. (2017) expressed doubts about the validity of this subspecies, and suggested that the genetic variation these authors reported may be an artefact of the absence of samples from the intervening portion of the range.

The Middle Eastern form Trapelus agnetae, previously a subspecies of T. pallidus but considered a possibly distinct species (Y. Werner pers. comm.), was confirmed as a genetically distinct lineage and formally resurrected as a full species by Wagner et al. (2011).

Using morphological data, LaDuc and Johnson (2003) re-evaluated the status of Trimorphodon biscutatus and concluded that T. biscutatus vilkinsonii should be regarded as a distinct species. This action was upheld by Devitt et al. (2008), who revised the T. biscutatus complex and elevated the remaining four subspecies - T. b. lambda, T. b. lyrophanes, T. b. paucimaculatus and T. b. quadruplex - to specific status on the basis of both molecular and morphological data.
This species has previously been placed in the genus Sibon, but was transferred back to Tropidodipsas by Wallach (1995).
This taxon was formerly treated as a subspecies of Tropiocolotes tripolitanus, but it was elevated to full species status by Baha El Din (2001).
Populations from Niger and southern Algeria exhibit several differences from those in Egypt, and may represent a cryptic species (Trape et al. 2012).
Wilms et al. (2009) recognized Uromastyx nigriventris from Morocco and western Algeria, previously treated as a subspecies of U. acanthinura, as a distinct species on the basis of genetic evidence.

This species is sometimes considered a subspecies of Uromastyx acanthinura. In a revision of the genus Uromastyx, Wilms et al. (2009) found that U. geyri was genetically basal to all other members of the U. acanthinura group (including the full species U. acanthinura, U. dispar and U. nigriventris), and it was also distinguishable from these forms based on a PCA of morphological data. Consequently it is considered a full species here.

The subspecies Uromastyx dispar flavifasciata is considered by some authors (e.g. Geniez et al. 2004) to be a full species. This account follows the revision by Wilms et al. (2009) in treating U. dispar as having three subspecies: U. d. dispar, U. d. flavifasciata and U. d. maliensis, as these forms were found to form a distinct clade within the U. acanthinura group by these authors, and can only be distinguished morphologically by details of colouration in the adult males (Wilms et al. 2009). Trape and Trape (2012, in Trape et al. 2012) erected a fourth subspecies, U. d. hodhensis, for populations in southeast Mauritania. Populations of U. d. dispar outside Nubia, the Sudanese type locality, are genetically and ecologically closer to West African forms than to the Nubian population (Trape et al. 2012), suggesting that subspecific divisions within U. dispar are in need of revision.

U. ornata and the previously recognized U. philbyi exhibit a high degree of morphological and genetic similarity (Wilms et al. 2007). These authors therefore treat U. philbyi as a subspecies of U. ornata, where it had previously provisionally been placed (e.g. Wilms and Böhme 2007), and this scheme is followed here. U. ornata itself has variously been treated as either a full species or a subspecies of U. ocellata (see Wilms and Böhme 2007 for a discussion of this lizard's taxonomic history).

Although Böhme and Ziegler (1997) elevated Varanus niloticus ornatus, the large forest water monitor of the Congo Basin region, to full species status, a recent molecular analysis by Dowell et al. (2015) indicated that this taxon should be considered a junior synonym of V. niloticus. Varanus niloticus is likely to be a species complex whose taxonomy remains unresolved, but recovered three genetic distinct lineages, in the west, north and southern part of Africa  (Dowell et al. 2015).

Xenodon rabdocephalus is believed to be a species complex. Populations from Central America and Colombia that "almost certainly" fall outside the true range of Xenodon rabdocephalus sensu stricto were tentatively assigned to the resurrected Xenodon angustirostris by Myers and McDowell (2014). These authors were however not able to examine the holotype of X. angustirostris, and as such the status of this taxon requires confirmation. Morphological differences between Central American populations identified by Myers and McDowell (2014) further suggest that multiple species may fall within their concept of X. angustirostris. These authors note however that the distribution they propose for this taxon is "zoogeographically plausible" and that any effort to delimit species within this group based on the identified differences would amount to guesswork. Myers and McDowell (2014) are more confident in resurrecting Xenodon suspectus from synonymy with X. rabdocerphalus, but this account follows the Reptile Database (Uetz et al. 2018) in retaining both taxa within the X. rabdocephalus complex until its taxonomy is more fully-resolved.
Two subspecies are recognized: Meizodon semiornatus semiornatus and M. s. tchadensis, the latter from Sudan and Chad (Branch 1998).

A recent phylogenetic study found that Philothamnus semivariegatus is paraphyletic, containing four distinct clades which are thought to represent up to four cryptic species (Engelbrecht 2017). The four clades are delineated along broad geographic lines: Central Africa, southeastern Africa, northeastern South Africa, and central-northern South Africa. The study did not include material from West Africa, so more comprehensive sampling could reveal additional candidate taxa. Engelbrecht et al. (2019) provided additional support for the four-clade arrangement, but without access to material from the type locality were unable to determine to which clade the name P. semivariegatus refers. On this basis they refrained from taking action pending a full revision of this species complex.

The three recognized subspecies are treated as distinct species by Wallach et al. (2014), but there has been no formal taxonomic revision and Portillo et al. (2018) note that samples of this genus are needed to clarify its relationships.

This species was formerly considered to be wide-ranging through West, Central and East Africa. Trape et al. (2006) redescribed this species, finding it to be morphologically distinct from A. micropholis and A. watsoni, the latter considered since Laurent (1950) to be a synonym of A. micropholis (which the same author considered a subspecies of A. microlepidota). Trape and Mané (2000) subsequently identified A. microlepidota and A. micropholis as distinct forms, noting that the two occur in sympatry in West Africa, but did not formally redescribe either species. A. microlepidota has an indeterminate type locality "Probably in West Africa"; the holotype closely resembles recent material from Senegal (Trape et al. 2006). The revision by Trape et al. (2006) confined this species to "Senegambie" and Mauritania, although no specimens are yet known from the Gambia. The other two taxa are more wide-ranging, with A. watsoni reaching Central Africa (Trape et al. 2006).

Unfortunately, in their revision Trape et al. (2006) did not consider records east of Sudan, although the traditional concept of A. microlepidota ranges into East Africa as far as Eritrea and southeastern Kenya, and into the Arabian Peninsula. David and Vogel (2010) note that, by implication, the Arabian subspecies A. m. andersonii was elevated to full species status by this treatment. These authors support this assignment by comparing this form with the taxa described by Trape et al. (2006); although they do not detail the results of this comparison, they indicate that A. andersonii is distinct from all three West African species. East African records of "A. microlepidota" remain of uncertain taxonomic status, although Trape et al. (2006) report that they are not conspecific with the holotype of A. microlepidota. These records are provisionally considered to represent A. watsoni (P. David pers. comm. June 2012) until the taxonomy of East African populations is resolved.
Populations from the Eastern Hajar Mountains in Oman are now referred to A. arnoldi (Simó-Riudalbas et al. 2018).

According to Arnold (1980), the “differences between some of the known populations […] as belonging to H. homoeolepis are greater than those between some recognised species of Hemidactylus”; therefore the taxonomic status of populations assigned to H. homoeolepis needs to be revised also on the basis of molecular studies.
It has been proposed that this poorly-known species is conspecific with Pristurus saada.
This species has commonly been considered a subspecies of Uromastyx ocellatus, however Wilms et al. (2007) found that it represents a valid species within the U. yemenensis clade.

Some or all Tanzanian subpopulations presently referred to the similar Trachylepis brevicollis may instead represent T. dichroma (Günther et al. 2005), and this is also suggested by the proximity of two localities to Klein's Camp, where T. dichroma is known to occur (Branch et al. 2007). Research is needed to confirm this. Trachylepis brevicollis has numerous synonyms, and while it appears to be monotypic in much of its range, a formal revision is required to clarify the status of East African taxa currently included within T. brevicollis (Branch et al. 2007).

A recent study (Sindaco et al. 2018) has shown that some populations from southern Arabia previously classified as Mesalina adramitana represent a distinct species (M. austroarabica) belonging to the M. guttulata species complex. Another still unpublished study (S. Carranza pers. comm. 2018) indicates that genetic variability within M. adramitana is very high and includes two clades (northern and southern) that split approximately 5.5 million years ago around the general area of Bar Al Hikman, Oman. The UAE populations belong to the northern clade.
Mendes et al. (2018) undertook a genetic study across the Hajar Mountains and found this species to comprise of two very distinct genetic lineages that may correspond to two independent species.

The appropriate generic assignment of Leiopython albertisii is in need of clarification (Schleip and O'Shea 2010). Due to close genetic affinities between sampled specimens of Bothrochilus boa and L. albertisii (which was then understood to be monotypic), Rawlings et al. (2008) proposed including this species within Bothrochilus. Subsequently, Schleip (2008) revised Leiopython and formally removed several cryptic forms from synonymy with L. albertsii. According to Schleip and O'Shea (2010), the sample used to justify the assignment of L. albertisii to Bothrochilus belongs instead to L. hoserae (now L. meridionalis, see Schleip 2014) on the basis of its locality data. The relationship between true L. albertisii and Bothrochilus therefore remains unclear, and this account follows Schleip and O'Shea (2010) in retaining Leiopython for this species pending resolution of this issue.
This is the type species of the genus Opisthotropis.

Prior to 2012 Pseudotrapelus sinaitus was considered a widespread species or species complex found throughout much of northeastern Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Multiple subsequent papers (summarized in Tamar et al. 2016) described five additional species, most from within populations previously assigned to P. sinaitus and based on individual or a small number of specimens. Tamar et al. (2016) performed the first phylogenetic analysis of the genus, and while they found that genetic variability within the genus was "not high" they supported the recognition of six Pseudotrapelus species on both morphological and molecular and better-characterized their distributions.

The resulting concept of P. sinaitus remains taxonomically "interesting" and Tamar et al. (2016) recommend that further studies investigating morphological and genetic variation should be undertaken to clarify the systematics of this taxon.
We follow Carranza et al. (2002) in treating this species as a member of the genus Tarentola, instead of Geckonia where it has traditionally been placed, on the basis of molecular evidence.

The known specimen of this snake was referred to Dendrelaphis pictus by Karsen et al. (1998), although Lazell and Lu (1990) had previously recognized its distinctiveness. It was formally described as a new species by Lazell (2002). It is similar to D. subocularis, and Lazell (2002) hypothesizes that this may be a relict species that diverged from the common ancestor of this species and D. pictus. Wall (1903) reported D. pictus from Hong Kong; as this specimen has now been lost (Lazell and Lu 1990) it is unclear whether this record is referrable to D. hollinrakei.
This species was described by Vogel and van Rooijen (2008) to encompass Philippine snakes formerly included within the widespread Dendrelaphis pictus.

Broadley (2000) elevated Trachylepis striata punctatissima, T. s. wahlbergii and T. s. sparsa to species status. Some confusion still exists regarding the status of these three taxa, as intergrades have been reported from some parts of their overlapping ranges. Molecular data suggest that the two most widespread members of the T. striata species complex - T. striata and T. wahlbergii - may not be reciprocally monophyletic (Castiglia et al. 2006). The entire complex requires re-examination at the phylogeographic scale (Marques et al. 2018). Older specimen records of the T. striata complex need to be confirmed using the key provided in Broadley (2000).

Liu et al. (2012) conducted a molecular phylogenetic analysis of this recently-described species and concluded that genetic evidence supports its recognition as a full species by Yang et al. (2011). Further work is required to resolve its relationships with the morphologically similar P. trungkhanensis, which was not included in the genetic analysis (Liu et al. 2012).
This species was previously included within Dendrelaphis gorei (Vogel and van Rooijen 2011).

authority: Crottini, Gehring, Glaw, Harris, Lima & Vences, 2011
taxonomicNotes: This species belongs to the Phelsuma mutabilis group of dull-coloured day geckos, and closely-resembles P. borai and P. mutabilis (Crottini et al. 2011). Records of P. mutabilis from central Madagascar may instead represent P. gouldi, and further research is needed to clarify this (Crottini et al. 2011).

The two specimens recorded from Ambohijanahary differ in patterning from typical Amphiglossus meva described from the rest of the species' range, and were excluded from the type series (Miralles et al. 2011). Data was not available to include these specimens in molecular analysis, and Ambohijanahary is far to the south and west of either of the other known sites. The specific status of the population from Ambohijanahary is therefore in need of confirmation.

Molecular and morphological evidence indicates that this newly-discovered phenotype belongs to the "Madascincus polleni species complex", rendering M. polleni as defined by Miralles et al. (2011) paraphyletic with regard to this species and Madascincus stumpffi. It is treated here as a distinct species following Miralles et al. (2011), as it is morphologically distinct and strongly genetically divergent from the other three clades identified for this complex.

Glaw and Vences (2007) tentatively synonymized this species with Madascincus polleni, and Miralles et al. (2011) found that M. polleni is paraphyletic with respect to this species and M. arenicola. Based on morphological distinctiveness, however, and the discovery that M. stumpffi forms a (weakly-supported) monophyletic clade distinct from other members of the "Madascincus polleni species complex", Miralles et al. (2011) support recognition of M. stumpffi distinct from M. polleni, as proposed by Andreone and Greer (2002).

M. stumpffi exhibits two colour morphs, and further research is needed to clarify whether these represent distinct lineages (Miralles et al. 2011).

The first specimen of this snake to be collected was misidentified as Cryptelytrops albolabris (Zhao 2006, Guo and Wang 2011). The two species are not closely-related. and instead Sinovipera sichuanensis has been recovered as the sister taxon to Cryptelytrops + Viridovipera, prompting Guo and Wang (2011) to erect the new genus Sinovipera.

Utiger et al. (2002) found little genetic differentiation between this species and Elaphe schrencki, of which it had previously been considered a subspecies (Zhao and Adler 1993), despite clear morphological differences. Utiger et al. (2002) suggested that the specific status of E. anomala requires verification. An et al. (2010) corroborated these results for Korea, finding that Korean populations - presently assigned to E. schrenckii - did not warrant recognition as separate species.
Zhao (1997) described this species based on specimens from Hainan originally attributed to Rhabdophis chrysargos.
The two known specimens of Typhlops lazelli were originally attributed to the widespread Ramphotyphlops albiceps (Wallach and Pauwels 2004).

Wilms and Schmitz (2007) recognized this taxon as a form distinct from Uromastyx ocellata, within which it had previously been included, and described it as the subspecies Uromastyx yemenensis shobraki. Further study (Wilms et al. 2007) revealed that genetic differences between U. yemenensis and U. shobraki are sufficient to justify recognition of the latter as a full species.

Reports of this species from Saudi Arabia represent confusion with Ablepharus pannonicus (Arnold 1986). This is an exclusively African species, and is absent from the Arabian Peninsula (R. Sindaco pers. comm. 2012). Schmitz et al. (2005) recommended reassigning this species to the resurrected genus Afroablepharus, however, Branch et al. (2005) argue that further genetic work is required to clarify the assignment of southern and eastern African taxa to this genus.

Although Smith (1849) initially used 'walbergii' as the specific epithet, he later corrected this to 'wahlbergii' in an often overlooked errata slip (Ulber 1999). Such an inserted slip, under Article 32.5.1.1 of the ICZN (1999), is clear evidence of an inadvertent error that has been corrected. The absence of the errata slip from some copies of Smith's work has contributed to confusion on this point (e.g. Greenbaum et al. 2007).

Jacobsen (1989) drew attention to the presence of a cryptic species in northern savanna areas of South Africa, which was later described by Jacobsen and Broadley (2000) as Panaspis maculicollis. Older specimen records of P. wahlbergii should therefore be checked using the key in Jacobsen and Broadley (2000), particularly in areas of known sympatry.

According to Medina et al. (2016), 'P. wahlbergii' is a complex of at least nine cryptic species which are awaiting formal descriptions, and Tanzanian populations presently attributed to this species and identified by these authors as "Panaspis sp. Tanzania 1" are likely to represent P. megalurus.

The taxonomic status of P. longipes is uncertain (Rösler et al. 2008). Boulenger (1885) synonymized this species within P. crucifer. Bauer et al. (1991) designated a lectotype from Kursi bei Aden (Yemen), but do not redescribe this species.
The taxonomic status of this species remains unclear.

This very recently-described snake is a member of the Python curtus species complex (with P. curtus, P. brongersmai, and P. breitensteini), and was briefly considered to represent a disjunct record of P. brongersmai (Zug et al. 2011).

This species was originally described as a subspecies of Pristurus gasperetti, the nominate form of which (including populations from Saudi Arabia) is now recognized to be a synonym of P. flavimaculatus (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).

Jiang and Zhao (1983) described a subspecies R. nuchalis pentasupralabialis for the specimens from Sichuan and Yunnan, China. Subsequently, based on a morphological comparison, Zhao (1995) give a specific rank for this taxon, as R. pentasupralabialis.

Jiang (2004) indicated that, based on morphological similarities, Pareas chinensis should be treated as a synonym of P. formosensis. This assignment is not supported by recent genetic research, which found that P. formosensis is not closely-related to P. chinensis and is instead sister to P. hamptoni (Guo et al. 2011).

Until recently, this species was included within Daboia russelii, a species understood to have a widespread but heavily disjunct distribution within South and Southeast Asia. The number of recognized subspecies of this wide-ranging snake is variable, but six are traditionally accepted (Thorpe et al. 2007). Morphological analysis suggests, however, that only two distinct forms exist, one (D. r. russelii) restricted to the Indian subcontinent and the other (for which the name with priority is D. r. siamensis)  found in the remainder of the snake's range (Wūster et al. 1992). These authors refrained from elevating D. r. siamensis to a full species due to the lack of molecular research to support this conclusion. More recently, using both molecular and morphological data, Thorpe et al. (2007) found strong support for this division and recognized two distinct species, D. russelii (incorporating the former subspecies D. r. pulchella and D. r. nordicus as well as D. r. russelii) and D. siamensis (incorporating D. r. limitis, D. r. sublimitis and D. r. formosensis). Due to low divergence between members of each lineage, Thorpe et al. (2007) do not recognize distinct subspecies of either form.

Rocha et al. (2009) showed that the Pacific island populations and Indian Ocean populations of Gehyra mutilata represent separate evolutionary lineages. These authors caution that further taxonomic research is needed, including research into the affinities of unstudied Indonesian populations of G. mutilata and related taxa, before formal taxonomic action is taken, however they indicate that if the Pacific form is found to be valid, the name G. insulensis will be applicable. Subsequent research has confirmed the validity of these two lineages, and used the binomial G. insulensis for the Pacific form (Heinicke et al. 2011). The specific status of Indonesian populations east of Wallace's Line has yet to be evaluated, however, molecular evidence suggests a close relationship between a sample from Krakatau, in western Indonesia, and Oceanian G. insulensis (Heinicke et al. 2011), leading these authors to suggest that Krakatau and Oceanian populations are "probably conspecific". On this basis, and based on biogeographic patterns seen in other Pacific reptiles, intervening Indonesian populations are provisionally assigned to G. insulensis. Hemidactylus platurus, described from Krakatau in 1859, is tentatively considered a junior synonym of G. insulensis, however, the possibility exists that this unstudied species (known also from mainland Java) is not conspecific with the modern population on Krakatau, which presumably represents a colonization subsequent to the 1883 eruption (Heinicke et al. 2011).
Previously a synonym of R. depressus.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown it to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
Populations in the central Nicobar Islands needs additional taxonomic research.

Tropidolaemus huttoni is known only from two juvenile type specimens that closely resemble juveniles of T. wagleri. Boundy (2008) reported a purported third specimen based on historical museum collection associated with a jar label Lonavala near Pune in Maharastra. Ganesh et al. (2014) considers it to be of doubtful distinction with respect to T. wagleri Group.

The taxonomic status of Draco norvilii was considered doubtful by Musters (1983), who elected to treat it as a subspecies of Draco blanfordii. McGuire et al. (2007), in an evaluation of Draco systematics based on mitochondrial DNA, explicitly refrained from making a judgment on this issue.

This taxon has more recently been accepted as a full species (e.g. Manthey 2010, Islam and Saikia 2013), but it is not clear that any formal action has been taken to justify this treatment. J. McGuire (pers. comm. 2019) notes that this species cannot reliably be distinguished from D. blanfordii and suspects that it is unlikely to be valid either as a species or subspecies, however cautions that further material is needed to resolve this issue.
This species is presently under revision (C. Murthy pers. comm. 2019).

Molecular data suggest that C. mansarulum may be conspecific with C. rohtasfortai, considered the commonest sandstone gecko in Pakistan by Khan (2008), in which case the name C. mansarulum (Duda and Sahi 1978) has priority (Agarwal et al. 2014).
The validity of this species, whose sole known specimen exhibits some overlap in characters with Takydromus sexlineatus, is unclear (Uetz et al. 2021).
Additional research is needed into the taxonomic validity of this species.

According to Gans (2005), Amphisbaena fuliginosa ranges from Trinidad to French Guiana (Starace 1998), including Venezuela, Guyana, and Suriname (Hoogmoed 1973). Subpopulations in Colombia, formerly included in A. fuliginosa, were recognized by Gans (2005) as A. amazonica and A. varia. This split was not supported by any data or analyses, and it is not accepted in this assessment. Thus, A. amazonica, A. varia, along with A. bassleri, are here included in A. fuliginosa.

McCranie and Wilson (1996) regarded C. atitlanensis as a synonym of C. bivittatus. Characteristics of recently acquired specimens from extreme southwestern Honduras (J. R. McCranie) also suggest that the two taxa may be conspecific (L. Porras, pers. comm. 2013).

Wilson et al. (1986) examined all the available material then available for the nominal taxa Celestus atitlanensis and C. bivittatus and concluded that "no significant differences exist among the material examined and that separation of the taxa atitlanensis and bivittatus cannot be maintained", and consequently proposed that C. atitlanensis be considered a junior synonym of C. bivittatus. Subsequently Campbell and Camarillo (1994) examined the same material, along with additional material they assigned to C. bivittatus, and came to the opposite conclusion. These authors highlighted differences in ecology and geographic distribution as well as morphological characters to support their hypothesis that the two taxa are distinct.

The status of C. atitlanensis has subsequently been uncertain. L. Porras (pers. comm. 2013) reported that new material obtained by J.R. McCranie from extreme southwestern Honduras suggests that the two taxa may be conspecific. No detailed analysis of these taxa has however been undertaken for more than 20 years, and in particular molecular data are lacking to resolve the status of this taxon (L. Wilson pers. comm. 2018). This account follows Campbell and Camarillo (1994) in recognizing both taxa as distinct pending further work, following the recommendation of L. Wilson and L. Porras (pers. comm. 2018).
Recent molecular work sequencing Jamaican species of Celestus has confirmed the validity of this species (S.B. Hedges unpubl. data).

This species was briefly considered a synonym of Bachia pallidiceps following Dixon (1973), but was removed from synonymy by McDiarmid and DeWeese (1977). While generally treated as a valid species, some authorities continue to recognize B. blairi as a junior synonym of B. pallidiceps, apparently on the basis that the "only clear difference seems to be a bright dorsolateral stripe in pallidiceps that is missing from blairi" (Uetz and Hallerman 2010).

The concept assessed here includes the taxonomically contentious Cercosaura ampuedai from northeastern Colombia and Venezuela. Recent redescriptions of both C. ampuedai (Hernández-Ruz 2005) and C. vertebralis (Hernández-Ruz and Bernal González 2011) highlight morphological differences between these two taxa and support their recognition as distinct species, and this assignment has been accepted in a checklist to the reptiles of Venezuela (Rivas et al. 2012). More recent treatments, which have not included Colombian or Venezuelan material, nevertheless treat C. ampuedai as a junior synonym of C. vertebralis (Doan and Lamar 2012). Doan and Cusi (2014) discuss the taxonomy of C. ampuedai in detail, and, based on literature sources and material of C. vertebralis (including Colombian samples), conclude that all characters considered diagnostic for C. ampuedai are variable within C. vertebralis, and formally synonymized the two taxa. These authors did not examine any specimens associated with the name Cercosaura ampuedai from Colombia or Venezuela, and examination of this material is required to clarify the taxonomy of "C. vertebralis" in northeastern Colombia and Venezuela (Gutiérrez-Cárdenas et al. in review). As presently understood C. vertebralis appears to be a species complex containing several cryptic taxa (J. M. Daza and D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2013).

Uzzell (1965) considered Echinosaura palmeri a subspecies of E. horrida based on the observation that four specimens from Ecuador and Colombia he examined appeared to be intermediate between the two forms. Reexamining this material, Fritts et al. (2002) found that the Ecuadorian specimens instead represented Teuchocercus keyi rather than E. horrida, and that the Colombian specimens were typical E. horrida, with no evidence of intergradation. Based on these results, and noting "the lack of evidence for intergradation between E. horrida and E. palmeri", Fritts et al. (2002) elevated E. palmeri to species level.

Uzzell (1965) considered Echinosaura panamaensis a subspecies of E. horrida on the basis that differences between the two forms were "slight". Detailing specific morphological differences that reliably distinguish these taxa, Fritts et al. (2002) rejected this assignment and elevated E. panamaensis to species level.

Peloso and Avila-Pires (2010) examined the taxonomic history of this species in detail, and re-evaluated characters previously considered to distinguish it reliably from Ptychoglossus nicefori. These authors concluded that a number of these characters were unreliable, and that as many specimens originally used to diagnose P. nicefori were damaged or juveniles, there is currently insufficient evidence to justify considering P. nicefori a valid species, and referred it to the synonymy of P. brevifrontalis.

Sceloporus prezygus was treated as a subspecies of S. serrifer following Axtell (1960), a placement supported by the finding by Stuart (1970) that this form exhibits apparently random variation across its range and cannot reliably be distinguished from other populations thought to intergrade with S. serrifer. This arrangement is still followed by some authorities (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2010, Wiens et al. 2010), however other recent work has considered S. prezygus a full species, albeit of questionable or uncertain status (Sites et al. 1992, Wiens and Reeder 1997), and this is the approach followed in the most recent regional and taxonomic species lists (Bell et al. 2003, Wilson et al. 2010). Wiens et al. (2010) found that S. s. prezygus is the closest relative of S. serrifer, however this analysis of higher-level relationships in the genus did not discuss this finding and so the appropriate status of this taxon requires further clarification.

Records formerly assigned to this species from Guanaja are now understood to represent a distinct species, Phyllodactylus paralepis, based on molecular and morphological evidence (McCranie and Hedges 2013).
Meyer and Wilson (1971) synonymized Anolis heteropholidotus within A. sminthus, but Köhler (1996) later resurrected it from synonymy.

Anolis quaggulus was removed from synonymy with A. humilis by Köhler (2003), but the diagnostic characters this author uses to distinguish the two taxa are considered insufficient by Poe et al. (2016). Anolis humilis marsupialis was elevated to specific status by Savage and Bolaños (2009), an action upheld by Köhler et al. (2015).
Both Hulebak and Poe (2006) and Ponce and Köhler (2008) synonymized Anolis pandoensis within Anolis kemptoni.

G. Köhler (pers. comm. 2012) suggests that records from the Pacific versant presently included within this species may represent a separate species, for which the name Anolis pulchripes is available, but taxonomic research is needed to confirm this. Poe (2016) notes that the characters used to distinguish this species from Anolis zeus, presently recognized as a distinct species, are not reliable.
Köhler and Kreutz (1999) resurrected this species from synonymy with Anolis cupreus, within which it had been placed by Stuart (1955).
Several Panamanian populations previously referred to as Anolis microtus are now referred to as Anolis ginaelisae Lotzkat, Hertz, Bienentreu & Köhler, 2013.
Prior to its description by Köhler (2009), this species was referred to as a population of Anolis altae.

There remains some confusion as to whether Anolis lionotus is a separate species from the very similar A. oxylophus, a situation complicated by the apparent loss of the Panamanian A. lionotus holotype (Wilson et al. 2010). Citing unpublished work, Köhler (2001) justified earlier works (Köhler 1999, 2000) that treated A. oxylophus as a synonym without comment. As no published work has yet formally synonymized these taxa, however, this account follows Savage (2002) and Wilson et al. (2010) in considering A. lionotus a separate species from A. oxylophus, with A. oxylophus ranging from Honduras to western Panama.
