The validity of this species was confirmed by Köhler (2007), who recognized it as the senior synonym for the species previously recognized as Anolis vociferans. The Guatemalan type locality for A. salvini, which is known from Costa Rica and Panama, is considered to be in error (Köhler 2008).
Was formerly treated as part of Anolis sericeus.
This is of unclear taxonomic status (Etheridge and Williams 1985, Abdala et al. 2012).

Hecht (1951) treated Aristelliger nelsoni as a subspecies of A. praesignis in a distribution map of the species' range but provided no supporting justification. This scheme has nonetheless been widely followed since, although distinct morphological differences between A. nelsoniand the nominate form were highlighted by Bauer and Russell (1993). McCranie (2018) corroborated this finding, and noted that the deep sea separating the Swan Islands from the Cayman Islands and Jamaica further supports the recognition of the two taxa as distinct species. This author recommended treating A. nelsoni as a full species pending molecular research to clarify its status, a recommendation that had previously been followed by Powell and Henderson (2012). On this basis, and noting that the proposed subspecific status has never been adequately justified, this account follows McCranie (2015, 2018) in treating A. nelsoni as a full species. Ongoing research suggests that the resulting concept of A. praesignis is itself a complex containing multiple species-level lineages (S.B. Hedges in prep.).

Ameiva ameiva is a known species complex, but its taxonomy has never been investigated in detail and species boundaries are not clear. Ugueto and Harvey (2011) conducted a preliminary study of variation in this group, which strongly suggested that Lesser Antilles populations attributed to this species are specifically distinct from forms found in the mainland, Swan Island, and Trinidad & Tobago. These authors recognized two species, A. atrigularis and A. praesignis, from within Venezuelan populations attributed to this species, but indicated that additional species exist within the complex. Henderson and Powell informally recognize the Lesser Antilles populations under the name Ameiva aquilina, and this name has recently been used in grey literature (Sadjak et al. 2016); this form is retained here within Ameiva ameiva pending clarification of species boundaries within this complex.

McCranie and Hedges (2013) examined the systematics the Cnedmidophorus lemniscatus complex across Central America and Colombia. These authors elevated the northern Central American subspecies C. l. ruatanus to specific status and assigned Panamanian populations to the new species C. duellmani. These authors also recommended elevating the South American forms C. l. gaigei, C. l. espeuti, C. l. splendidus, and C. l. arenivagus to specific status, with the caveat that these were not the focus of their research and further work including molecular research is required to confirm this arrangement. This validity of C. arenivagus and C. splendidus was subsequently supported by molecular research (Goicoechea et al. 2016) and these authors also accepted C. gaigei as a valid species. These authors do not discuss the Colombian C. espeuti, referring to it in passing as C. l. speuti but not including it within the content of their Cnemidophorus lemniscatus species group. C. espeuti is considered valid here following Uetz et al. (2018) but the taxonomic status of this form is consequently unclear

Kofron (1988) suggested that Anomalepis flavapices may be conspecific with A. aspinosus because their dorsal scale counts are similar. However, scale counts between populations of Anomalepis in Ecuador and Peru do not overlap (although both species remain known from few specimens) and their distributions are highly distinct in biogeographical terms, with A. flavapices restricted to the coasts of northwestern Ecuador, and A. aspinosus to the dry valleys of northeastern Peru (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia, pers. comm. 2014).

Dixon and Kofron (1984) refer two literature records of "Liotyphlops anops" from Dunn (1944), from Santander and Cundinamarca, to L. argaleus, while cautioning that they were not able to examine these specimens and that they may instead represent a new species.

This action was accepted by Vanzolini (in Peters and Donoso-Barros 1986) but has since been the source of some confusion as McDiarmid et al. (1999) suggested this assignment may be uncertain, although Dixon and Kofron (1984) removed these records from the distribution of L. anops. Santos (2018) consequently includes Santander and Cundinamarca within the distribution of L. anops (adding further to the confusion, this author apparently maps the wrong type locality for L. anops, placing it in Meta Department).

No reports of Trachyboa gularis have appeared in the scientific literature since the species was first described, and it has rarely been mentioned. The name has, however, been used in pet trade articles ( Arnett 1992, Burger 2017) to refer to a species from coastal Ecuador that "does well" in certain captive conditions, suggesting a known extant population. The basis for this is not clear and no diagnosis is provided to clarify whether this represents "true" T. gularis. It is probable that any animals in trade marketed as T. gularis in fact belong to T. boulengeri.

Sudré et al. (2017) examined 155 Atlantic Forest Chironius specimens, representing the recognized species C. exoletus and C. quadricarinatus as well as specimens identified as C. pyyrhopogon (the types of the latter having been lost). These authors found no morphological or meristic differences between Atlantic Forest C. exoletus and C. "pyrrhopogon" and provided the first photographic evidence of similar labial markings in other species of Atlantic Forest Chironius, suggesting that this is not a reliable diagnostic character. These authors consequently followed Dixon et al. (1993) in treating C. pyrrhopogon as a junior synonym of C. exoletus. These authors note that, as suggested by Dixon et al. (1993), the widespread C. exoletus is likely to be a species complex, and that the name C. pyrrhopogon will be available if Atlantic Forest populations prove to represent a distinct species.

Hollis (2006) elevated this taxon, previously the subspecies Chironius carinatus flavopictus, to full species status based on the identification of nine unambiguous autapomorphies that distinguish the two taxa.
The specific name should probably be spelt as bivittatum (Cadle and Savage 2012).

The holotype of this species was for some time transferred to an American institution in Washington DC before being returned to Bogota by J. Lynch, and it is possible that reports of a second record refer to the holotype in two separate collections (C. Arredondo, J. Daza and R.Caicedo pers. comms. 2013)

McCranie (2011) resurrected the name Dendrophidion clarkii for northern populations within the D. nuchale species complex. Cadle and Savage (2012), in a subsequent revision of this complex, confirmed the validity of D. clarkii but restricted this name to populations ranging from Costa Rica and Panama to Colombia and Ecuador; these authors assigned remaining Central American populations to a new species, D. rufiterminorum.
A specimen assigned to this species from Trinidad, well outside its known range, was described as Leptophis stimsoni by Harding (1995).
McCranie (2011) resurrected this species from synonymy with Mastigodryas melanolomus to encompass populations from Honduras to Panama, with M. melanolomus occurring from Honduras northward.
This taxon may represent more than one species.

The western population of this species in Ecuador is apparently a new species (J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014). The form on Tobago may represent a distinct species, for which the name M. dunni is available (Montingelli 2009).

The taxonomic relationship between this species and other species of Tantilla needs to be resolved. Variation within the T. melanocephala species complex, as then understood, was characterized across the species' range by Wilson and Mena (1980) and several subsequent studies (discussed in Mata-Silva and Wilson 2016) have revised the systematics of T. melanocephala, primarily in Central America, Colombia and Ecuador, recognizing a number of previously cryptic species and referring T. equatoriana, described by Wilson and Mena (1980), to the synonymy of T. melanocephala (Greenbaum et al. 2004). A subpopulation recently recognized from Brazil as a separate species, T. marcovani, was subsequently found to represent a junior synonym of T. melanocephala (Mata-Silva and Wilson 2016). The resulting species concept is of a trans-Andean snake confined to South America and Panama, however, subpopulations east of the Andes - which are thought to include the topotypical subpopulation (which has the type locality "America", but is thought likely to refer to a locality on the Guiana Plateau - P. Passos pers. comm. 2016) have received less attention and their systematics remain unclear. Recent unpublished work has investigated the systematics of Brazilian subpopulations (A. Silveira unpubl. thesis), but this did not include comparisons from subpopulations elsewhere in the species' range. Based on scale counts Trinidad and Tobago each appear to possess an endemic species within this complex, separate from mainland populations (J. Murphy pers. comm. 2015).

This species closely resembles Tantilla melanocephala, being distinguished only by a mid-ventral stripe. As it is known from only three specimens, it is possible that this is an occasional morph of this commonly-collected species rather than a separate taxon, but research is needed to determine whether this is the case (M. Yanez-Munoz pers. comm. 2016).
This species was previously considered to belong to Tantilla taeniata (McCranie 2011).

Based on mtDNA data (Devitt 2006) and patterns of morphological variation, Devitt et al. (2008) recognized six species in the Trimorphodon biscutatus species complex: T. lyrophanes, T. lambda, and T. vilkinsonii in the United States and Mexico, and T. biscutatus, T. paucimaculatus, and T. quadruplex occurring to the south in Mexico/Central America. 

Trimorphodon lambda hybridizes with T. vilkinsonii in extreme southeastern Arizona (Cochise County) and southwestern New Mexico (Grant and Hidalgo counties) (Devitt et al. 2008). This species may also come into contact with T. lyrophanes in southeastern California and/or extreme southern Nevada, and with T. paucimaculatus near the Sonora-Sinaloa border (Devitt et al. 2008). Specimens from contact zones may be difficult to identify (Devitt et al. 2008).

Based on mtDNA data (Devitt 2006) and patterns of morphological variation, Devitt et al. (2008) recognized six species in the Trimorphodon biscutatus species complex: T. lyrophanes, T. lambda, and T. vilkinsonii in the United States and Mexico, and T. biscutatus, T. paucimaculatus, and T. quadruplex occurring to the south in Mexico/Central America.

Following Peters and Orejas-Miranda (1970) Amastridium sapperi has been treated as a subspecies of A. veliferum, and this arrangement is still followed by some authorities (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2010). Recent work, however, generally treats it as a full species (e.g. Wilson and Townsend 2006, Wilson et al. 2010).

The distribution of this species in Costa Rica with respect to that of Clelia scytalina is extremely confused, due to inconsistencies between species lists for this country and in descriptions of these species' colouration, morphological characters and ecology in the relevant literature, discussed in detail in Wilson et al. (2010). The expectation that C. equatoriana occurs in Costa Rica is based on the identification of a specimen from the northern highlands of the country's Cordillera Central (Zaher 1996), an unusual record for this predominantly lowland species which is not otherwise known north of Panama (Wilson et al. 2010). Due to difficulties presented by variation in and inconsistent descriptions of morphological characters for C. equatoriana, molecular work will be needed to establish whether this species in fact occurs in Costa Rica or whether highland populations are conspecific with C. scytalina (Wilson et al. 2010). Pending resolution of this issue, and following Wilson et al. (2010), Costa Rican records of C. equatoriana are considered to represent C. scytalina in these accounts.

Coniophanes piceivittis taylori and Coniophanes piceivittis taeniata were elevated to species status by Flores-Villela and Smith (2009), who also described C. michoacanensis from populations previously assigned to piceivittis.

The year of description of this species is frequently given as '1869', but is given as '1870' here following Wallach et al. (2014), Uetz et al. 2021), based on the actual year of publication of the describing publication.
This species may represent a species complex containing at least 16 species (Curcio 2008).
This species is thought to be a species complex, as different morphs are known (Mohapatra).
McCranie (2011) resurrected the name Leptodeira rhombifera for northern populations previously assigned to L. annulata, based on the recognition that L. annulata is a species complex.

authority: Crother, White, Savage, Eckstut, Graham & Gardner, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Based on a phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data, Crother et al. (2011) determined that populations of Pantherophis vulpinus west of the Mississippi River should be recognized as a distinct species (Pantherophis ramscotti), whereas populations of P. vulpinus east of the Mississippi River represent a single species (P. vulpinus). The authors concluded that nominal P. gloydi of the eastern Great Lakes basin should be regarded as conspecific with P. vulpinus.

The identity of the three records attributed to this species from Colombia is uncertain, as two of these exhibit scale counts within the range of geographical variation known for Urotheca lateristiga (J.D. Lynch pers. comm.), and the third was a road-killed juvenile in a poor state of preservation.

Castro-Herrera & Vargas Salinas (2008) reported a specimen from Colombia, however this is thought likely to represent confusion with Micrurus mipartitus (Colombia checklist in prep.) Other references to this species, both prior and subsequent to this paper, restrict its range to lower Central America, and the species' occurrence in Colombia is "very doubtful" (Colombia checklist in prep).

The taxonomy of Epictia (formerly Leptotyphlops) in Central America is in need of resolution. Sunyer and Köhler (2010) provisionally recognize only the single species E. goudoti pending clarification of this situation. These authors tentatively synonymize E. nasalis and E. ater within this species, the latter without discussion. These authors consider E. nasalis a possible synonym on the basis that the single known individual differs from typical E. goudoti by a single scale character and no further specimens have been found in 70 years, indicating that it may be merely an aberrant individual rather than a genuine species. This arrangement has subsequently been accepted by Wallach (2016), who redescribed Epictia ater. This scheme is followed here for E. nasalis, however E. ater is tentatively treated as a valid species pending clarification of the basis for synonymizing it within E. goudoti.

This species had been placed in the genus Guinea, which Hedges (2011) found to be a junior synonym of Tricheilostoma on the basis that the type species, G. bicolor, was also the type species for the previously-erected genus Tricheilostoma.

This species had been placed in the genus Guinea, which Hedges (2011) found to be a junior synonym of Tricheilostoma on the basis that the type species, G. bicolor, was also the type species for the previously-erected genus Tricheilostoma.
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).
This species was formerly classified as Atropoides occiduus following recommendations by Castoe et al. (2005) but was designated as a separate species following Smith and Ferrari-Castro (2008).
Lotzkat et al. (2011) revised the taxonomy of Anolis pachypus, confining it to Panama and extreme southern Costa Rica. Records further north represent Anolis tropidolepis and A. magnaphallus.

Cherlin (1990) described the subspecies Echis pyramidum borkini from western Yemen and southwest Saudi Arabia. Molecular evidence suggesting that Yemeni populations exhibit high sequence divergence from remaining members of this species complex was used to support recognition of E. borkini as a full species by Pook et al. (2009) and Stümpel and Joger (2009).

In their revision of West African Agama, Mediannikov et al. (2012) concluded on both molecular and morphological grounds that this form, previously considered a subspecies of A. agama, is a valid full species in its own right. Molecular evidence reported in this study also indicates that A. sylvanus specimens from the type locality of that species belong to A. africana, and A. sylvanus (=A. sylvana) is therefore considered a junior synonym of A. africana (Medianikov et al. 2012). Some populations previously treated as belonging to Agama bocourti are now considered to belong to A. agama, with the remainder assigned to A. africana (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012); A. bocourti is consequently no longer treated as a valid species (Mediannikov et al. 2012). Due to this series of taxonomic changes, the true distribution of this species is in need of clarification (Trape et al. 2012). The taxonomy of this form remains unsettled and is currently under review, although it is considered a valid species (P. Wagner pers. comm. July 2012).

This species was synonymized with Agama sankaranica and A. wieldholzi by Grandison (1968) based on an examination of the syntypes. Mediannikov et al. (2012) conducted morphological and molecular comparisons between specimens of A. sankaranica from throughout its range and specimens from the A. boensis type locality agreeing with the original description of that species. The results of this work suggest that A. boensis should be recognized as a valid species (Mediannikov et al. 2012).

Northern and southern lineages of A. boulengeri, which are separated from one another by a 3 km stretch of unsuitable sandy habitat in the upper Gorgol el Aliod river valley, exhibit a higher degree of genetic differentiation than some recognized species of Agama do from one another (Goncalves et al. 2012). This has been taken as evidence that A. boulengeri contains an undescribed candidate species, and further sampling is required to clarify this (Goncalves et al. 2012).

The status of this species, which was until recently known only from a single, damaged specimen, has long been uncertain (Trape 2011). The action by Wagner et al. (2009) in synonymizing the similarly poorly-known A. insularis within this form added further confusion. These authors did not however compare the diagnostic midbody scale rows of the A. cristata holotype with those of A. insularis (only with A. boulengeri), and so although all specimens examined in this paper were validly attributed to A. insularis, the synonymy of the two taxa was in made in error (Trape 2011). Recent molecular work confirms that these two species belong to distinct clades (Mediannikov et al. 2012). Confusion over the identity of these species was exacerbated by uncertainty over the type locality of A. cristata, which the original description gives only as Sankaran in "Soudan Français" (modern Mali) (Trape 2011). The Sankaran region extends over a large area encompassing parts of Guinea and Côte d'Ivoire as well as southern Mali. Wagner (2009) give the type locality as "Bomanesco, Sankaran, Guinea", associating the unknown locality "Bomanesco" (taken from museum record books but not given in the original description - J-F. Trape pers. comm. May 2012) with Massouia in Guinea, assuming the A. cristata type locality to be the same as that for A. sankaranica (of which some authors had treated A. cristata as a junior synonym - Wagner et al. 2009). The identity and location of "Bomanesco" remain unknown, although the "Soudan Français" reference suggests a locality in Mali. Mediannikov et al. (2012) list it as a Malian locality with the proviso "not located".

Two subspecies are presently recognized, and preliminary molecular data indicates that these belong to two distinct lineages that warrant recognition as species: Agama doriae in the Horn of Africa and the Sudans, and A. benueensis for populations from West and Central Africa (Wagner et al. in litt.), as suggested by Moody and Böhme (1984). This account retains the current species concept, in which A. d. benueensis is treated as the western subspecies of A. doriae, pending publication of this revision.

The validity of this species has historically been questioned, and it has variously been treated as a valid species or as a synonym of A. boulengeri (see Wagner et al. 2009 for a discussion). Wagner et al. (2009) re-examined the original material together with recently-collected specimens and concluded that A. insularis (to which they erroneously applied the name A. cristata, having incorrectly synonymized A. insularis within this species - Trape 2011) is a valid species, a conclusion supported by Trape (2011) and by recent molecular evidence (Mediannikov et al. 2012).

Some records previously assigned to this species in Senegal, Guinea-Bissau and western Guinea are attributable instead to Agama boensis (Mediannikov et al. 2012). The western limit of this lizard's range in Mali is in need of clarification (Mediannikov et al. 2012).

This species was previously included within Agama impalearis until recognized as distinct by Geniez et al. (2011), although the correct assignment of central Saharan populations had previously been queried (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). Specimens sampled from Tassil N'Ajjer exhibit a high level of genetic divergence from populations in the Aïr and Hoggar Mountains, suggesting that the taxonomy of this species is in need of further study (Goncalves et al. 2012).

Trapelus agnetae was treated as a synonym of T. pallidus until Disi et al. (2001) found it to be identical to the subspecies T. p. haasi, and thus T. p. haasi should be considered a junior synonym of T. p. agnetae. Subsequent molecular research found T. p. pallidus to be synonymous with T. mutabilis, but that T. p. agnetae belonged to a separate clade (Wagner et al. 2011). These authors therefore resurrected T. agnetae as a full species.

Gans (1987) indicates that the name Amphisbaenia lamottei "is available for the high-[scale] count population of Cynisca liberiensis", and Gans (2005) recognizes Cynisca lamottei as a valid species known only from the types. Neither work, however, took any formal taxonomic action and C. lamottei is not generally recognized as a valid species (Uetz and Hallerman 2010). In their report on a specimen of "Cynisca cf. liberiensis" from the Mt Nimba area, Böhme et al. (2011) refer to the specimens Gans (1987, 2005) assign to C. lamottei as C. liberiensis.

A recent molecular phylogeny suggests that Trioceros affinis is likely to be a species complex potentially containing two separate species (Ceccarelli et al. 2014), but more comprehensive sampling is needed to confirm this.
There are no taxonomic issues at present, although this species can be confused with female Trioceros montium (Tilbury 2010).

This species was formerly thought to be a population of Trioceros sternfeldi (Tilbury 2010), but was recently described as Trioceros hanangensis by Krause and Böhme (2010). Molecular phylogenetic analyses of mitochondrial markers (Jan Stipala unpub. data 2013) suggests that the "T. sternfeldi" population in the Ngorongoro crater highlands is more closely related to T. hanangensis than to T. sternfeldi. However, the phylogenetic trees were not fully resolved and no nuclear markers were included, so further research is needed.

authority: Stipala, Lutzmánn, Malonza, Borghesio, Wilkinson, Godley & Evans, 2011

taxonomicNotes: The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Barej et al. (2010) elevated the former subspecies to species rank based on molecular and morphological differences from the nominate taxon. Accepted as Trioceros perreti in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Mertens (1940) synonymized Chamaeleon (=Chamaeleo) serratus within Chamaeleo wiedersheimi on the basis that specimens examined, including those from the Bamenda Highlands, were indistinguishable from a C. wiedersheimi paratype from the same locality. This view was subsequently supported with reference to additional material and the original description (Mertens 1968, Klaver and Böhme 1992). The holotype of C. serratus, with the unspecific locality "Südkamerun", is lost, and was probably destroyed during World War II (Klaver and Böhme 1992), so has never been available for comparison. Combined morphological and molecular research by Barej et al. (2010) found that Bamenda specimens belong to a clade separate from Trioceros wiedersheimi. Designating a neotype for T. serratus, these authors therefore resurrected this name for the newly-recognized species, fixing the type locality as Belo, Mt Oku, and removed it from synonymy with T. wiedersheimi. The two species are, however, difficult to distinguish morphologically, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).

This widespread African gecko was formerly considered a subspecies of Hemidactylus brookii, and was elevated to species level by Carranza and Arnold (2006). Hemidactylus albituberculatus, known from scattered sites from Togo to Cameroon, was recently recognized as distinct from H. angulatus, however, true H. angulatus is still considered to occur in areas occupied by the new species (Trape et al. 2012).

Subpopulations from the New World were assigned to the subspecies Hemidactylus brookii haitianus which is now synonymized with H. angulatus (Rosler and Glaw (2010).

Arnold et al. (2008) revised the taxonomy of this species, formerly considered the only endemic species of Hemidactylus on Cape Verde and including the subspecies H. b. boavistensis (Boavista and Sal) and H. b. razoensis (Santo Luzia and Raso) in addition to populations from Fogo and São Nicolau unassigned to any subspecies. These authors re-elevated H. b. boavistensis to full species status and described the Fogo population as a new species, H. lopezjuradoi. The São Nicolau population was retained within H. bouvieri on the basis that available material is too poorly-preserved to permit morphological description, but was found to be genetically distinct from typical H. bouvieri. Arnold et al. (2008) consider that once better material becomes available this form will warrant description as a distinct taxon.
This is a widespread rainforest species complex but ranges of the new  species need clarification. It seems to occur only in undisturbed forest  (P. Wagner and J. Penner pers. comm. 2012).
Ongoing taxonomic revision of this taxon suggests that populations currently assigned to this species from Angola and the Democratic Republic of the Congo may represent a distinct species.

The records provided for Lygodactylus gutturalis by Lanza (1990) correspond to two of the localities provided for L. picturatus keniensis (now L. keniensis) by Loveridge (1947), and presumably represent this latter species as L. gutturalis is not considered to occur in Somalia.
L. Ceriaco (pers. comm. 2020) considers the three recognized subspecies, Lygodactylus t. thomensis, L. t. delicatus and L. t. wermuthi, to be distinct species.

Hynková et al. (2009) suggested that Boa imperator is likely to warrant recognition as a full species. This arrangement was further supported by Reynolds et al. (2014) and is followed here. Two subspecies are recognized: B. i. imperator and B. i. sabogae (Reynolds and Henderson, in press).

Genetically this species is nested within Anolis roquet from Martinique based on mtDNA results reported by Thorpe et al. (2005). If this result is supported by other genetic markers this would render A. roquet paraphyletic. Further research is needed to support this conclusion, as it is possible that the mtDNA results represent hybridization events. This research may reveal that A. extremus should be considered a junior synonym of A. roquet, or that some of the Martinique populations should be assigned to A. extremus.

The Barbuda subspecies Anolis wattsi forresti is considered a full species by some authors following Roughgarden (1995), but no work appears to exist following up on this proposed arrangement and it requires verification. Lazell (1972) observed that the two species intergrade in extreme northern Antigua and nearby islands, and although it is considered plausible that the Barbuda taxon is distinct (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2019) the islands of the Antigua Bank were connected as recently as 10,000 years ago. This assessment follows Lazell (1972) and Hedges et al. (2019) in treating A. w. forresti as a subspecies pending further research.

Anderson (1875) described it as Trionyx nigricans from the pond at the Hazrat Sultan Bayazid Bostami Shrine in Nasirabad near Chittagong, Bangladesh. Subsequent authors believed that the species either became extinct in the wild (Pritchard 1979, Groombridge 1982) or that it ‘descended from introduced individuals of the more widespread Trionyx gangeticus’ (Groombridge 1982, Khan 1987) or of N. hurum (Rashid 1990). Using mainly skull osteology as well as coloration and pattern characters, Praschag and Gemel (2002) recognized it from northeast India as Aspideretes nigricans. Based on molecular data, Engstrom et al. (2004) and Praschag et al. (2007) transferred the genus Aspideretes Hay, 1903 into synonymy of Nilssonia (Gray, 1872). See Praschag and Gemel (2002) for discussion of taxonomic distinction from other large Asian softshell species.

The evolutionary relationship of Tomistoma with other crocodilians was debated for many years, and the species was usually aligned with the true crocodiles (Crocodylidae) based on morphological evidence (Norell 1989, Tarsitano et al. 1989, Brochu 1997). Molecular studies since the 1980s suggest a closer relationship to Gavialis (Densmore 1983, Densmore and Dessauer 1984, Gatesy and Amato 1992, Harshman et al. 2003, McAliley et al. 2006). A recent molecular study found that Tomistoma shares gene sequences with Gavialis which are absent from Crocodylus, Mecistops (see Shirley 2010) and Osteolaemus, suggesting Tomistoma should be placed within the family Gavialidae (Willis et al. 2007).

Praschag et al. (2007, 2008) demonstrated that the widespread species Batagur baska comprised at least two genetically distinct species, and separated out B. affinis for the southern species occupying southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, and Sumatra in Indonesia, retaining the name B. baska for the more northern species from India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar.
Was under Iguanidae.
This species is the sole member of its genus.

The Mona Rhinoceros Iguana is currently recognized as a distinct species, Cyclura stejnegeri (ITWG 2016). Prior to 2000, it was considered a subspecies in the group including Cyclura cornuta cornuta from Hispaniola (Dominican Republic and Haiti), Cyclura cornuta stejnegeri from Mona Island, Puerto Rico, and Cyclura cornuta onchiopsis, which presumably went extinct on Navassa Island in the mid-19th century (Powell 1999).

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all the banded iguanas were lumped as this single species. The Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus) is now recognized as distinct from the Fiji Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula). Most previous references pertaining to iguanas in central Fiji are now attributed to B. bulabula. This taxonomic change includes references to the introduced population on Vanuatu, now described as B. bulabula (Bauer 1988, Keogh et al. 2008). The introduced population on Tonga remains as B. fasciatus.

 

Recent unpublished data finds some morphological and colour variability between islands in the Lau Group, but genetically these populations have less inter-island variability than within the other two species of Brachylophus. The systematics of the iguanas on the islands in the northern Lau Group (north of Tuvuca) is unknown, but for now they will be retained within this taxon.

Recent genetic data (Keogh et al. 2008) have shown that each subpopulation (island) of this species is genetically unique.  This data, along with many morphological characters, clearly define this species, although the observed genetic inter-island variability might be consistent with subspecific differences after further assessment.

Carettochelys insculpta is the only surviving extant member of the genus Carettochelys and the family Carettochelyidae, a formerly widespread turtle family dating back to the Eocene and previously occurring across Asia and much of the rest of the globe. As such, it is considered a deep phylogenetic lineage with high-priority conservation needs, a so-called EDGE species (Evolutionarily Distinct, Globally Endangered). The common name in Indonesian Papua is Kura-kura Moncong Babi and the common name in Papua New Guinea is Piku.

Until recently, the various forms of this species complex were thought to represent just a single species, Cyclemys dentata, but are now recognized as representing a complex of six full species: C. atripons Iverson & McCord, 1997 (KH, TH); C. dentata (BN, ID, TH, MY, SG), C. enigmatica Fritz et al., 2008 (BN?, ID, MY, SG); C. fusca Fritz et al., 2008 (MM); C. gemeli Fritz et al., 2008 (BD, IN); C. oldhamii Gray, 1863 (ID, LA, MM, MY, TH, VN); and C. pulchristriata Fritz, Gaulke & Lehr, 1997 (VN). Their conservation status was not assessed previously because the taxonomy and distribution remain in flux; it was considered likely that some taxa would be threatened.

Two subspecies are recognised, Pangshura smithii smithii (Gray, 1863) and P. s. pallidipes (Moll, 1987). Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001).
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Heosemys and Geoemyda.

Le et al. (2014) concluded that the Yangtze and Red River subpopulations of Rafetus swinhoei do not show significant genetic divergence and do not warrant recognition as separate evolutionary significant units for conservation management. However, it appears that Le et al. (2014) did not actually have any samples from the Yangtze subpopulation, only samples from the Vietnamese and Chinese parts of the Red River catchment. Chen (2015) found two distinct mtDNA lineages of R. swinhoei which are roughly 2.8% divergent from each other (Cytochrome B and NADH dehydrogenase 4), one represented by Red River specimens and the second one by a Shanghai museum specimen of unknown origin. In the meantime, tissue samples from the male of Suzhou Zoo and the female of Changsha Zoo proved to be concordant with the Shanghai museum specimen (H. Chen pers. comm.). This points to a possibility that the Yangtze and the Red River subpopulations may represent separate taxa at least at the level of subspecies. In that case the Yangtze subpopulation would represent the nominate form Rafetus swinhoei swinhoei and the Vietnamese and Chinese Red River subpopulation the subspecies Rafetus swinhoei leloii.

Was treated under the generic name Geoemyda in the 1996 IUCN Red List. The genus was changed to Heosemys in the 2000 IUCN Red List. Now reassigned to a new monotypic genus, Leucocephalon (A. Rhodin pers. comm.).

The relationship between this species and Parahelicops annamensis has long been uncertain (David et al. 2015), due to poor knowledge of variation in both taxa. With access to a series of 13 specimens of P. annamensis David et al. 2015 were able to redescribe both species and, based on the results of their analysis, erected the new genus Isanophis containing the single species I. boonsongi.

These iguanas are sometimes referred to in the literature as Enyaliosaurus quinquecarinatus Gray, 1845. A specimen that was originally described by Gray (1842) as Ctenosaura quinquecarinata was later re-examined as a novel species from México and named Ctenosaura oaxacana (Kohler and Hasbún 2001).

Originally described as a subspecies of the Cuban Rock Iguana (Cyclura macleayi lewisi Grant, 1940; Cyclura nubila lewisi sensu Schwartz and Thomas, 1975), this iguana was elevated to species-level by Burton (2004), supported by Malone et al. (2000) and S. Funk (unpublished data 2008).

Chelodina pritchardi is a distinct and recognized species, with an adequate description and diagnosis (Rhodin 1994, Georges et al. 2002, Georges and Thomson 2010, TTWG 2017). No subspecies or geographic variations are recognized, but it has not yet been genetically analyzed. It can be confused with the morphologically similar Chelodina novaeguineae, but the species do not occur sympatrically.

Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001). Previously included tentoria and circumdata as subspecies.

Three subspecies are generally recognized: Pangshura tentoria tentoria (Gray, 1834), P. t. circumdata (Mertens, 1969), and P. t. flaviventer Günther, 1864. Schleich and Kästle (2002) elevated flaviventer to full species due to co-occurrence with circumdata in Nepal, and documented intermediates which they interpreted as hybridization.

Traditionally placed in the genus Kachuga, it was assigned to the subgenus Pangshura by Moll (1987); Pangshura was elevated to genus level by Das (2001).

Appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 2000 to 2006 under the name Kachuga tentoria.

Three subspecies are currently recognized, Lissemys punctata punctata (Bonnaterre, 1789), L. p. andersoni Webb, 1980, and L. p. vittata (Peters, 1854), following the most recent taxonomic review by Praschag et al. (2011), which also split off the Sri Lankan populations as a separate species, L. ceylonensis (Gray, 1856).

Caiman crocodilus has four subspecies currently recognized:  C. c. crocodilus, C. c. fuscus, C. c. chiapasius, and C. c. apaporiensis. Caiman yacare previously was considered to be a fifth subspecies (i.e., C. c. yacare). However, it is now generally accepted as a full species (King and Burke 1989), and is no longer treated as a subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2011).

Busack and Pandya (2001), using morphological analysis, stated that there were no differences between subspecies. However, Venegas-Anaya et al. (2008), using mitochondrial DNA analysis, recognized three out of these four subspecies (no samples from C. c. apaporiensis used in this study) and delimited geographically distributions within the C. crocodilus complex. DNA analyses also suggest a geographic divergence in two groups: the Mesoamerican group including C. c. fuscus and C. c. chiapasius and the South American group, which includes C. c. crocodilus and C. yacare (Amato and Gatesby 1994; Venegas-Anaya et al. 2008).

Recent morphological analysis of the Apaporis River caiman (C. c. apaporiensis), based on holotype and paratypes skulls from the Chicago Field Museum (USA), corroborates a significant morphological differentiation with the rest of the C. crocodilus subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2015a) as reported by Frederico Medem in 1952. However, DNA analysis conducted with additional paratypes from Colombian collections showed that several of those skulls identified as C. c. apaporiensis in the Instituto de Ciencias Naturales, National University of Colombia collection fall into the C. c. crocodilus clade (Bloor 2013). Nevertheless, a more in-depth study is being initiated in late 2018, to collect less fragmented DNA (from live individuals rather than ancient bones) and larger sample sizes (for both morphological and genetic analyses), which will hopefully provide new evidence on the validity of this subspecies.

The species is closely related to, and approximately 6 mya, and derived from Caiman crocodilus, the Common or Spectacled Caiman (Godshalk 2006). The two species are sympatric in the Madeira River from its confluence with the Amazon, south to approximately the Bolivian border. Studies of morphology (Brazaitis et al. 1998,  Busack and Pandya 2001) and genetics (Hrbek et al. 2008) suggest a cline of introgression between the two species along this transect although each species retain distinctive and non-overlapping genetic features at the limits of their distributions. Biogeographic investigation suggests that the species arose in its southern range as a vicariance event related to movement of the Brazilian shield and has subsequently re-invaded the Amazon system via the Madeira and its tributaries (Godshalk 2008 a,b). Caiman crocodilus and C. yacare have been considered as the same or as subspecies. However, careful review of large samples, in regard to both morphology and genetics, indicates that C. yacare is a Significant Evolutionary Unit with distinct species level distinction (Vasconcelos and Campos 2007,  Hrbek et al. 2008).

The specific name of this species is variably given as Crocodylus johnsoni or C.  johnstoni.  The species was named by Krefft after a Mr Johnstone, but as C. johnsoni (see discussion in King and Burke 1989, Tucker 2010). Crocodylus johnstoni (with a 't') has received widespread use, particularly by Australian workers and Cogger et al. (1983) proposed formalising this use, notwithstanding that the correct name based on Johnstone would be 'johnstoneii'. Tucker (2010) argues, using the new edition of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, that the use of C. johnstoni be the prevailing spelling based on the intention of Krefft to quickly correct the spelling (Gray 1874). As such, for Red List purposes, C. johnstoni will be used predominantly but it should be clear that C. johnsoni and C. johnstoni are the same species and the terms can be used interchangeably.

The African Nile Crocodile is now recognized as two distinct species: one occupying eastern Africa, the Nile valley and southern Africa and retaining the name Crocodylus niloticus Laurenti, 1768; and the other occupying west and central Africa, including the Congo, Niger and Ogoue drainages and assigned to the existing name Crocodylus suchus Geoffroy, 1807 (Schmitz et al. 2003, Hekkala et al. 2011).  Red List assessments now treat these two taxa independently.

Published work on the morphology and nesting biology of the New Guinea crocodile suggests significant difference between populations in drainages north of the dividing ranges and those to the south that may indicate a species level split in this species (Hall 1989, Hall and Portier 1994).
Barrington Land Iguanas appear to be sister to a clade composed of the western (Isabela and Fernandina) populations of Conolophus subcristatus (Gentile et al. 2009).

The western (Isabela and Fernandina) populations of Conolophus subcristatus appears to be sister to the Barrington Land Iguana (Conolophus pallidus; Gentile et al. 2009). Further analysis (Rassmann et al. 2004, Gentile et al. 2009) shows that these western populations and the central island populations of C. subcristatus form two separate clades, consistent with the pattern of morphological differentiation described in Snell et al. (1984). Tzika et al. (2008) suggest that some populations of C. subcristatus may deserve recognition as species, on Plaza Sur in particular, based on their genetic differentiation within the genus.

Recent DNA and morphological studies suggest that this species belongs in its own monotypic genus, Mecistops (McAliley et al. 2006).  This finding has been supported by all subsequent phylogenetic studies (e.g., Hekkala et al. 2011, Meredith 2011, Oaks 2011,Shirley et al. 2013) and Mecistop has gained wide use and acceptance in the literature and is hence used here.

A recent study (Shirley 2013, Shirley et al. 2013) has found significant molecular and morphological support for two divergent taxa in this genus - one distributed entirely in West Africa and the other in Central Africa. Formal taxonomic revisions and recognition of these two unique taxa are expected soon.

Hybridization between C. moreletii and C. acutus in the wild has been reported from the coastal regions of Belize (Hekkala 2004; Ray et al. 2004; Hekkala et al. 2015) and Mexico (Cedeño-Vázquez 2008; Cedeño-Vázquez et al. 2008a,b; Rodriguez et al. 2008a,b; Gonzalez-Trujillo et al. 2012; Pacheco-Sierra et al.  2016).

The only known extant population of C. siamensis outside mainland Southeast Asia, located in East Kalimantan Province (Indonesian Borneo), is genetically distinct and considered an ‘Evolutionarily Significant Unit’ (Gratten 2003).

The species was named by Schmidt in 1935 from specimens from Najuan Lake, Mindoro. The species has been considered a subspecies of C. novaeguineae but currently it is accorded full species status on the basis of unique morphology, distribution and genetic separation (see Uetz et al. 2016).
This species is under taxonomic review and it is likely to be split into five species (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2018).

The previous assessment of the Turks and Caicos Rock Iguana (Gerber 2004) recommended additional genetic studies to fully evaluate the subspecific designation of Cyclura carinata bartschi (Cochran 1931) on Booby Cay, located 0.5 km off the east end of Mayaguana Island, The Bahamas. Two independent population genetic studies have now demonstrated that iguanas on Booby Cay are not genetically different from C. carinata in the Turks and Caicos Islands, and therefore should not be considered as a separate subspecies (Bryan et al. 2007, Welch et al. 2017). Further, the Booby Cay population is genetically most similar to populations from the eastern side of the Caicos Bank, rather than the most geographically proximate populations on the western and northern sides of the Caicos Banks (Welch et al. 2017). Since it is likely that humans introduced iguanas to Booby Cay, this population is not included in the species’ extent of occurrence.

Welch et al. (2017) describe the existence of two distinct Evolutionary Significant Units (ESUs, sensu Moritz 1994) for C. carinata: one inhabiting islands on the western end of the Caicos Bank, and one inhabiting the remaining islands of the Caicos Bank and islands of the Turks Bank. Multiple management units (MUs) are also identified within each ESU (Welch et al. 2017). Considering the severe geographic and genetic fragmentation of iguanas across the archipelago these authors recommended the two ESUs be elevated as different subspecies.

Fossils from Puerto Rico were originally described by Barbour (1919) and named Cyclura portoricensis. These and additional fossils from Puerto Rico were re-examined by Pregill (1981) and attributed to Anegada Rock Iguanas, Cyclura pinguis.

Prior to 2000 three subspecies were commonly recognized: Cyclura cornuta cornuta from Dominican Republic and Haiti, Cyclura cornuta stejnegeri from Mona Island, Puerto Rico, and the extinct Cyclura cornuta onchiopsis from Navassa Island (Schwartz and Carey 1977). That taxonomy has subsequently been followed by some authors (for example, Malone et al. 2000, Pérez-Buitrago et al. 2007, and references therein). However, all three taxa are now recognized as species (ITWG 2016).

Wüster et al. (2001) described a new species of Drymarchon from northwestern Venezuela, bringing the species total for the genus to four (five if couperi is recognized as a species). This taxonomic rearrangement treats D. corais and D. melanurus as distinct species. The species in the United States, Mexico, Central America, and South America west of the Andes and in Venezuela is D. melanurus. D. corais occurs in South America east of the Andes (Wüster et al. 2001).  Wüster et al. (2001) also recognized D. couperi and D. margaritae, previously considered subspecies, as full species but without examining specimens, based on previously published (but unspecified) morphological differences and application of the evolutionary species concept. Subsequent checklists (e.g. Crother et al. 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) have adopted this taxonomy.

McCranie (2011) agreed with these taxonomic changes, but noted that these actions were taken on the basis of limited sampling and emphasized the need for further study to clarify the taxonomy of this group. The resulting concept of D. melanurus is likely to be a species complex; McCranie (2011) suggested that two species-level taxa may be included under the name D. melanurus in Honduras alone.
Naja naja was described by Linnaeus in 1758 as Coluber naja basing on drawings by Seba (1734) from India (Smith 1943).

The morphological diversity of this species complex is not adequately reflected in current subspecific divisions (Auliya and Koch 2020). This species is divided into three subspecies which occupy distinct geographical regions and can be identified by size, tail shape, and the number of bands on the body and tail. Varanus griseus griseus has a rounded tail and highest number of bands, Varanus griseus caspius reaches the largest size and has a laterally compressed tail, while Varanus griseus koniecznyi is the smallest subspecies and has the fewest bands (Stanner 2004).
Köhler (2008) included this species in Adelphicos quadrivirgatus.

Western populations have been proposed to constitute a distinct species, Coluber mormon (Fitch et al. 1981), but this distinction has been demonstrated to be invalid (Corn and Bury 1986; see also Greene 1984).

Wüster et al. (2001) described a new species of Drymarchon from northwestern Venezuela, bringing the species total for the genus to four (five if couperi is recognized as a species). This taxonomic rearrangement treats D. corais and D. melanurus as distinct species. The species in the United States, Mexico, Central America, and South America west of the Andes and in Venezuela is D. melanurus. D. corais occurs in South America east of the Andes (Wüster et al. 2001).  Wüster et al. (2001) also recognized D. couperi and D. margaritae, previously considered subspecies, as full species but without examining specimens, based on previously published (but unspecified) morphological differences and application of the evolutionary species concept. Subsequent checklists (e.g. Crother et al. 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) have adopted this taxonomy.
McCranie (2011) agreed with these taxonomic changes, but noted that these actions were taken on the basis of limited sampling and emphasized the need for further study to clarify the taxonomy of this group. The resulting concept of D. melanurus is likely to be a species complex; McCranie (2011) suggested that two species-level taxa may be included under the name D. melanurus in Honduras alone.
This species was previously incorrectly referred to as Imantodes tennuissimus Cope, 1866.
This species has often been placed in the genus Dryadophis, but Dixon and Tipton (2004) placed it in Mastigodryas on the basis of seniority.
Some authors consider the northern populations of the Yucatan peninsula as a separate species, Pliocercus andrewsi, but here it is considered a subspecies.

Jadin et al. (2013) investigated the systematics of Pseustes (for which they resurrected the senior synonym Phrynonax), within which they recognized the species P. poecilonotus, P. shropshirei, and P. polylepis (the latter resurrected from synonymy within P. poecilonotus). Natera-Munaw et al. (2015) resurrected the name Phrynonax lyoni encompassing both Venezuelan records of P. shropshirei and an eastern coastal subpopulation of P. polylepis, the latter without examining the specimens. The characters these authors use to distinguish P. lyoni are, however, confusing and examination of the eastern coastal specimens confirms their assignment to P. polylepis (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2016). On this basis, this account follows a traditional concept of P. shropshirei encompassing the Venezuelan populations, and P. lyoni is retained as a junior synonym of P. poecilonotus.
Campbell (1998) suggests that the southern population, found in Belize and Guatemala, may represent a different species from the Mexican population.
The subspecies victa of peninsular Florida is treated as a species by some authors.
We follow Campbell (1998) in considering Tantilla cuesta to be a synonym of this species.
The Mexican populations are one subspecies and the Guatemalan/Belize species are another that could potentially be elevated to species status (J. Lee pers. comm.).

Some uncertainty remains concerning the taxonomic status of Sceloporus cupreus (see: Smith and Taylor 1950, Wiens and Reeder 1997, Bell et al. 2003). We retain cupreus within siniferus pending conclusive studies into this relationship.
Some experts consider this species conspecific with Sceloporus variabilis (Mendoza-Quijano et al. 1998).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

Parkinson et al. (2000) concluded that Agkistrodon bilineatus howardgloydii and A. b. russeolus should not be elevated to species status based on shallow mitochondrial divergence and similar morphologies. Although noting that sample sizes in this study were low and covered only a small number of localities, Porras et al. (2013) reinterpreted this evidence and along with comparisons of colour patterns, proposed that A. b. howardgloydi and A. b. russeolus should be elevated to species status. These taxa were, however, retained within A. bilineatus by Wallach (2014).
Elachistodon westermanni was described by Reinhardt in 1863 based on specimens collected from Rangapur, Bangladesh (Smith 1943).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. duncanensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments    

This species from Pinzón (Duncan Island) was included on IUCN Red Lists before 2007 under the name Geochelone nigra ssp. ephippium. However, this name was interpreted by Pritchard (1996) to actually refer to Chelonoidis abingdonii, the Pinta Giant Tortoise, and therefore was replaced by the name duncanensis Pritchard, 1996, a recommendation accepted by Fritz and Havas (2007) as well as TTWG (2007, 2014). While the name duncanensis is used here, as it has been on the Red List since 2007, a genetic analysis of the ephippium type specimen is planned, which will determine whether the name change is indeed warranted. Many researchers (e.g., Jensen et al. 2015), including most of the Assessors on this account, continue to use the name C. ephippium for the Pinzón Tortoise, and we await genetic analysis for a final determination as to the correct name to use.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. niger as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments. This species from Floreana has also been referred to in some recent literature as C. elephantopus, but that name is a nomen dubium (TTWG 2009) and should not be used for the this species. The spelling of the specific name was recently changed from nigra to niger as a result of the determination that the gender of the generic name Chelonoidis is actually masculine rather than feminine (Olson and David 2014).
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the generic names Geoemyda and Heosemys. No subspecies or synonymised data.

The Desert Tortoise was previously considered to be a single wide-ranging species, Gopherus agassizii (sensu lato), inhabiting the Mojave and Sonoran Desert regions of the southwestern USA and northwestern Mexico (Iverson 1992). The species was eventually found to be polytypic, and Murphy et al. (2011) split out the morphologically and genetically distinct Sonoran Desert subpopulations as Gopherus morafkai, the Sonoran Desert Tortoise. Further analysis demonstrated that G. morafkai was also polytypic and therefore split further to separate and describe the Sinaloan Thornscrub Tortoise further to the south as G. evgoodei (Edwards et al. 2016). This taxonomy of three species of desert tortoises has been accepted by TTWG (2017) and Berry and Murphy (2019).

The taxon Hardella indi (Gray, 1870) was traditionally considered a subspecies, Hardella thurjii indi, but was most recently synonymized as insufficiently distinct from the typical form to warrant recognition (Praschag et al. 2007).

Two species of Hydrosaurus are currently reported from the Philippines; H. amboinensis in the south and H. pustulatus in the north. However, there is some confusion in the identification of species and consequently the distribution of these species. Further taxonomic studies are needed to clarify the distribution of Hydrosaurus in the Philippines (A. Diesmos pers. comm., 2007).

A phylogeographic analysis of this species (Paulo 2001) indicated two divergent lineages distributed respectively in the Central Mountain System (Sierras de Bejar, Gredos and Guadarrama) and in the rest of its distribution. However, studies in the zone of contact between these two lineages suggest that speciation has not yet taken place (Crochet and Dubois 2004).

Densmore et al. (1992) elevated Nerodia harteri paucimaculata to species status after Rose and Selcer had suggested that already in 1989. Other authors have pointed out that there is no single character that will allow separation of individuals from the two populations 100% of the time. Treated here as a good species.

This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Darevskia, following Arribas (1998, 1999), Fu et al. (1997), Fu (1998) and Harris et al. (1998). It is not certain that the eastern and western populations belong to the same species; further taxonomic studies are needed to resolve this issue. Subspecies D. p. praticola inhabits the northeastern part along the Caspian Sea. D. p. pontica (Lantz and Cyren, 1919) inhabits the coast of the Black Sea and north-western Caucasus.

This species is included in Zamenis following Utiger et al. (2002).

Hofmann et al. (2018) described a third subspecies, H. h. lyciensis, and clarified the ranges of the three subspecies;
Z. h. hohenackeri: south-eastern Anatolia, Turkey.
Z. h. lyciensis: southern Anatolia, western Syria, to northern Israel, and Cyprus.
Z. h. taurica: Black Sea coast of Anatolia south and east to the Caucuses and north-western Iran and north-eastern Iraq.
This species was formerly included within Podarcis erhardii.
This taxon was previously considered part of algirus, but was described as a separate species by Busack et al. (2006).

Šmíd et al. (2019) found that T. fallax as presently understood is paraphyletic with respect to T. nigriceps and T. hoogstraali, but refrained from taking taxonomic action. These authors used the name T. f. syriacus for samples from Jordan and Israel which fall within their T. nigriceps clade, supporting the suggestions by Disi et al. (2001) and Göçmen et al. (2007) that records from Jordan should be regarded as T. nigriceps.
Specimens from India, Pakistan, Arabian Peninsula, Iran, Sudan, Somalia and Kenya are now referable to H. robustus (S. Baha El Din 2006; Bauer et al. 2006).
Eastern populations of Malpolon formerly allocated to M. monspessulanus are now included within M. insignatus following Carranza et al. (2006).

Elaphe sauromates was separated from E. quatuorlineata, of which it was previously a subspecies, on the basis of a large genetic divergence (Lenk et al. 2001). While this has since largely been accepted (Jablonski et al. 2019), the name E. quatuorlineata has however been used in recent literature referring to populations outside the range of this species as now understood (e.g. Moldova - Tsurcan 2016, Romania - Popescu et al. 2013), and these are treated here as referring to E. sauromates.
Formerly included within Iberolacerta monticola, but recognized to be distinct by Arribas, Carranza and Odierna (2006).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Sindaco et al. (2014),
Formerly included as a subspecies of Lacerta laevis.

Animals from Israel and Jordan are referable to Platyceps collaris, not P. najadum. As many as seven subspecies are recognized
"At least seven" distinct subspecies are generally recognized, some of which (e.g. P. n. dahlii, which encompasses most European populations) may warrant recognition as full species  following a revision of this species complex (Geniez 2018).
This taxon was previously considered part of algirus, but was described as a separate species by Busack et al. (2006).
This may be a species complex. Further studies into the taxonomic status of a number of populations of this species are needed.

authority: Lymberakis, Poulakakis, Kaliontzopoulou, Valakos and Mylonas, 2008

taxonomicNotes: Although the generic epithet Podarcis is masculine (Böhme 1997, Böhme 1998), tiliguerta is a noun (meaning "lizard" in the local Sardinian language) and therefore it is not conjugated. This taxon possibly consists of at least two separate species, one on Sardinia and one on Corsica (C. Corti pers. comm.).

authority: Baran, Kumlutaş, Lanza, Sindaco, Ilgaz, Avci & Crucitti, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This species includes five subspecies. Following Arnold et al. 2007, Lacerta cappadocica became Apathya cappadocica.
Previously considered to be a subspecies of Zamenis longissima. Elevated to species level by Nilson and Andrén (1984). Included in Zamenis following Utiger et al. (2002, 2005).

This species was formerly recognized as Agamura gastropholis.

Has been synonymyzed with Gymnodactylus (=Cyrtopodion) agamuroides by Wettstein, 1951 (in Wermuth 1965).
There is a need to revise the taxonomic status of this species, especially with regards to its relationship with Telescopus fallax. Additionally, this this taxon may consist of more than one species.
This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but it is now placed in the genus Timon (Mayer and Bischoff 1996; Fu 1998, 2000; Harris et al. 1998; Harris and Carretero 2003).
This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Darevskia, following Arribas (1998, 1999), Fu et al. (1997), Fu (1998) and Harris et al. (1998).
E. hakkariensis is now included within E. thospitis (Nagy et al. 2003).
The nominate subspecies E. c. collaris is found over most of the species range, the exception being near Tuzluca (eastern Turkey), where E. c. macrospilotus (Werner, 1904) is found.

There are two subspecies. The nominate subspecies is distributed in eastern Transcaucasia, as well as in the eastern Turkey and the Azerbaijani province of northwestern Iran. The subspecies, E. s. kopetdaghica Szczerbak, 1972 is distributed in Kopet Dagh (Iran and Turkmenistan) northern Khorasan and eastern Mazanderan (Iran).
This taxon has previously been recognised as a subspecies of Phrynocephalus helioscopus.
The concept of the species assessed here excludes Mediodactylus dehakroensis (Masroor, 2009), but some authors consider them to be conspecific.

This species is not closely related to Lacerta sensu stricto Harris et al. (1998), and has been placed in a different genus (Muller 2002). This was referred to subgenus Parvilacerta Harris, Arnold & Thomas, 1998. This subgenus includes two species: Parvilacerta fraasii (Lehrs, 1910) and Parvilacerta parva (Boulenger, 1887).
The generic assignment of this taxon is still unclear.
The type specimen for this species was misidentified as T. ruderatus (Rastegar-Pouyani, 2000).

This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Darevskia, following Arribas (1998, 1999), Fu et al. (1997), Fu (1998) and Harris et al. (1998). Three subspecies are described. The nominative subspecies D. v. valentini is distributed in the whole Transcaucasia. D. v. lantzicyreni (Darevsky and Eiselt, 1967) occurs through most of Turkey. D. v. spitzenbergerae (Eiselt, Darevsky and Schmidtler, 1992) is known only from the type locality in vilayet Khakyari in extreme southwestern Turkey.
This species has sometimes been included in Montivipera raddei.
We provisionally follow Melnikov et al. (2008) in considering Phrynocephalus horvathi to be distinct at the species level pending additional taxonomic studies.
HOLOTYPE. (MMTT/AHI 1008) CAS 238636.
This species was elevated to species status from Vipera ursinii anatolica by Nilson and Andrén (2001).

The specimen collected from Samha Island was indicated by Joger (2000) to represent a new undescribed species (Haemodracon sp.). Recently collected specimens from Samha Island are apparently identical to the Socotran ones (Razzetti et al. 2011), and are treated here as belonging to H. riebeckii.

This species was removed from Phyllodactylus and included in the new Socotran endemic genus Haemodracon by Bauer et al. (1997). According to Gamble et al. (2007) the genus Haemodracon belongs to the family Phyllodactylidae .

Leviton et al. (2018) cite unpublished phylogenetic studies supporting the distinctiveness of this species from Boiga angulata, with which Leviton (1970) suggested it might be conspecific. Despite this, these authors state that confusion remains regarding "the identity and distribution" of this species although they do not elaborate on the basis for this.
This species is sometimes placed within the genus Mabuya.

This species is often confused with certain populations of S. abdictus and S. jagori. Subpopulations are frequently assigned arbitrarily to one species or the other based on islands. This is likely either one species or a species complex (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007). Linkem et al. (2011) found that Spenomorphus coxi divergens appeared to be closer to neighbouring populations S. abdictus aquilonius than S. c. coxi, but did not recommend taxonomic changes other than the erection of the new genus Pinoyscincus.

The taxonomy of this widespread island species - which has four nominal subspecies, one of which is dubious and the others of which have distributions correspond to recognized faunal regions - "is in serious need of review" (Leviton et al. 2018).
Further studies are needed into the taxonomic relationship between this species and its Mindanao Island congeners (A. Diesmos and A. Demegillo pers. comm. 2007).

Leviton (1959) suggested that this species may be conspecific with Dryocalamus (now Lycodon) tristrigatus, to which it was described as being very similar in the original description. As of Leviton et al. (2018) this issue remains unresolved.
Further taxonomic studies are needed to confirm that the Visayan subpopulations are the same species as the Luzon subpopulation (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).
This is a species complex in need of additional taxonomic work (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).

Two subspecies have already been described for the Philippines, Cyclocorus lineatus lineatus (Luzon and Mindoro) and Cyclocorus lineatus alcalai (Negros, Cebu, Panay) (M. Gaulke pers. comm. 2008). These may represent distinct species (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007), but no taxonomic action has yet been taken (Leviton et al. 2018).

Further taxonomic studies are needed to more clearly determine the range of the three Gonocephalus species present in the Philippines (Gonocephalus interruptus; G. semperi; and G. sophiae). Animals with white spots on the flanks are often readily identified as G. semperi, however this is not a good diagnostic character and other Gonocephalus species (such as G. interruptus) can also exhibit white spots. The type description of Gonocephalus interruptus is based on a semiadult and a juvenile only (re-examined by M. Gaulke). these lizards show their characteristic scalation after reaching maturity. Therefore it is highly likely that Boulenger mistook young G. semperi for a new species (M. Gaulke pers. comm. 2008), a synonymy first suggested by Taylor (1922).
Welton et al. (2017) conducted the first molecular phylogeny of Philippine Gonocephalus, based on sampling across the whole archipelago. Their results suggested that "as many as 12 Philippine lineages" may warrant treatment as candidate species. The complexity of the taxonomy involved, and the fact that none of the three nominal species in the Philippines has a type locality more specific than "Philippines", made it impossible for these authors to assign these names to specific lineages within the Philippine radiation. This account follows the distribution listed for samples of G. semperi by Welton et al. (2017) with the caveat that the application of these names requires further research to clarify.
Additional studies into the taxonomic status of this species are needed (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).
The Visayan subspecies, Oxyrhabdium leporinum visayanum (present on the islands of Cebu, Negros and Panay), may warrant elevation to species level (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).
Additional studies into the taxonomic status of this species are needed.

This species is often confused with C. gervaisi. Gaulke and Vogel (2005) suggest that the record from Panay cannot safely be attributed to C. bitorques, it might actually represent an undescribed species; this record is however attributed to this species without comment by Leviton et al. (2018) and so is accepted here. Photographic records of Calamaria taken in Bohol (2000) and Ifugao (2007) (M. Sarmiento pers. comm. 2021) may represent a different species. 
Ongoing taxonomic research indicates that this species is nested within Calamaria gervaisi, and that the clade encompassing the type locality is likely to be widespread, with a range encompassing at least Luzon, Panay and Mindoro (R. Brown pers. comm. 2021).

This species exhibits "considerable intraspecific divergence", with populations from the Bicol Peninsula in southeast Luzon and Catanduanes divergent from those in the island's centre (Siler et al. 2013). No taxonomic changes were proposed by these authors and the relationships of populations assigned to this species from other islands is unresolved. Dela Cruz and Maranan (2018) state that the species is endemic to Luzon Island, however C.J. dela Cruz (pers. comm. 2021) mentions that this was a mistake.

Leviton et al. (2018) formally synonymized L. tessellatus, a dubious species known only from the Manila holotype, within L. capucinus, following more than a century and a half of uncertainty about the validity of this name. These authors took this action "with a degree of hesitancy" and agreed with Ota (2000) that further material will be required to clarify whether it is a valid species.

According to some experts this may not be a valid species, because only one fairly minor morphological characteristic distinguishes it from the widespread species Boiga drapiezii (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007). More recently, Leviton et al. (2018) agree that it is likely future taxonomic research will reveal it to be a colour morph of B. drapiezii.

There is some uncertainty regarding the validity of this species (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007), although Leviton et al. (2018) accept it as valid without comment despite describing it as "long enigmatic".

This species is sometimes confused with populations of S. coxi and S. abdictus. Subpopulations are often assigned arbitrarily to one species or the other based on islands. This may be a species complex (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007), as suggested by molecular research (Linkem et al. 2010, 2011).

The validity of this species has been "seriously questioned" by recent systematic research (Leviton et al. 2018). This is based on the finding by Siler et al. (2013) that there is very little to no genetic divergence between this species and Lycodon alcalai, and Leviton et al. (2018) suggest that the two taxa may be conspecific.

As presently understood this species is widespread in the Philippines, however it is subject to confusion with another widespread species Gekko monarchus, and subpopulations within the Philippines are assigned arbitrarily to one species or the other based on the island on which they are found (R. Brown and E. Rico pers. comm, 2007).

Brown et al. (2008) state that "the majority of the Philippines' ... cryptic species diversity [in Gekko] undoubtedly masquerades under the widespread species Gekko mindorensis and Gekko monarchus", a suggestion supported by molecular research (Siler et al. 2012).

Siler et al. (2014) investigated the relationship between this species complex Gekko mindorensis and the Taiwanese Gekko kikuchii, with which it was previously proposed G. mindoerensis may be synonymous. While cautioning that the complexity of the genetic patterns obtained in their coalescent analysis precluded Siler et al. (2014) from making extensive taxonomic changes to the G. mindorensis complex without further data, they were sufficiently confident in the relationship between Luzon and Lanyu clades, and of their distinctiveness from G. mindorensis from southern Luzon, to extend the range of G. kikuchii to northern and central Luzon. While they acknowledged that this action renders G. mindorensis paraphyletic pending further research, this latter is a known species complex and they argue that their arrangement better-reflects current knowledge, especially in the context of evaluating each taxon's conservation status.

Some authorities consider that populations in the Philippines are poorly differentiated from Boiga cynodon (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007), but other authorities do not recognize significant differentiation problems between B. cynodon and B. angulata (M. Gaulke pers. comm. 2008). Confusion may have arisen because a number of literature references to B. angulata are associated with images of B. cynodon (Leviton et al. 2018).
There are problems differentiating some Philippine B. angulata populations from Boiga drapiezii (Gaulke 2001), and Leviton et al. (2018) consider it likely that B. angulata will prove to be a colour morph of B. drapiezii.
Leviton et al. (2018) cite unpublished phylogenetic studies supporting the distinctiveness of Boiga philippina from B. angulata, with which Leviton (1970) suggested it might be conspecific. Despite this, these authors state that confusion remains regarding "the identity and distribution" of the B. philippina species although they do not elaborate on the basis for this.

Records from Mt. Hamiguitan were referred to as Sphenomorphus cf. diwata by Brown and Alcala (1980), and more recent specimens from this locality closely resemble but are not identical to known specimens of S. diwata (Delima et al. 2007). These latter authors recommended further research to determine whether this represents greater variation than previously recognized in S. diwata, or whether the Haniguitan population is a distinct species.
Subsequently Supsup et al. (2017) accepted the Delima et al. (2007) records as S. diwata without comment, and suggested that a record of Parvoscincus beyeri - a species endemic to Luzon - reported by Relox et al. (2011) is likely to represent S. diwata (Supsup et al. 2017).
Check Linkem et al paper 2011

Further taxonomic studies are needed to more clearly determine the range of the three Gonocephalus species present in the Philippines (Gonocephalus interruptus; G. semperi; and G. sophiae). Animals with white spots on the flanks are often readily identified as G. semperi, however this is not a good diagnostic character and other Gonocephalus species (such as G. interruptus) can also exhibit white spots. The type description of Gonocephalus interruptus is based on a semiadult and a juvenile only (re-examined by M. Gaulke). these lizards show their characteristic scalation after reaching maturity. Therefore it is highly likely that Boulenger mistook young G. semperi for a new species (M. Gaulke pers. comm. 2008), a synonymy first suggested by Taylor (1922).
Welton et al. (2017) conducted the first molecular phylogeny of Philippine Gonocephalus, based on sampling across the whole archipelago. Their results suggested that "as many as 12 Philippine lineages" may warrant treatment as candidate species. The complexity of the taxonomy involved, and the fact that none of the three nominal species in the Philippines has a type locality more specific than "Philippines", made it impossible for these authors to assign these names to specific lineages within the Philippine radiation. Pending further resolution of this issue this assessment follows the traditional three-species arrangement, and applies the name G. interruptus to a taxon from Mindanao, as stated without providing a source for this information by Taylor (1922).
Possible species complex - confirm with Rafe. Linkem et al paper 2010, 2011 - Otosaurus cumingi

Additional studies into the taxonomic status of this species are needed (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007). The appropriate generic (and familial) assignment has been disputed, with Pyron and Wallach (2014) assigning it to Gerrhopilus and Hedges et al. (2014) placing it in Malayotyphlops. Although Wynn et al. (2016) opine that this Typhlops manilae should not be included in the genus Malayotyphlops until its affinities can be "better evaluated", this nomenclature is retained here to preserve the definition of Typhlops sensu stricto as a New World genus (Hedges et al. 2014), and it cannot confidently be assigned to Gerrhopilidae.
