Although this species exhibits low levels of genetic divergence from the Cerberus rynchops complex (Alfaro et al. 2004), now recognzed as C. schneiderii in the Philippines (Murphy et al. 2012), Murphy et al. (2012) note that its morphological, ecological and geographic isolation warrant continued recognition of this species as distinct, and based on this together with the estimated age of divergence from C. schneideri (Alfaro et al. 2008) Leviton et al. (2018) recommend retaining this species as valid, while noting that this status has been "seriously questioned".
Bernstein et al. 2021 - finds that this is minimally distinct genetically from schneiderii. mtDNA result, and possible that there could be nuclear variation so far undetected. No formal taxonomic action yet, but likely to be synonymised in future.
This enigmatic species is not very clearly assignable to available genera, but is probably best placed in Ramphotyphlops for now (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).
This is probably a species complex of three to four species (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).

This species is often confused with populations of S. coxi and S. jagori. Subpopulations are often assigned arbitrarily to one species or the other based on islands. Linkem et al. (2011) found that the two subspecies of Sphenomorphus abdictus form a clade with S. coxi and S. jagori and erected the new genus Pinoyscincus. Despite identifying that one clade within S. a. aquilonius was not monophyletic with respect to S. jagori, Linkem et al. (2011) proposed no changes to the species concept. A comprehensive taxonomic revision of this complex is still required (McLeod et al. 2011). Some populations from the Babuyan Islands may represent a distinct species (Linkem et al. 2010).

There are various taxonomic problems related to C. annulatus and C. philippinicus. They may be one species, or the populations on different islands may have been inappropriately divided between the two taxa (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).
This species is sometimes placed within the genus Parias.

As part of a morphological revision of Philippine water monitors, Koch et al. (2010) identified three distinct lineages within Varanus marmoratus as then understood. These authors described two of these as the new species V. rasmusseni and V. palawanensis. Mindoro populations previously assigned to this species are of uncertain identity, and are excluded from all three of the species recognized by these authors (Koch et al. 2010).

This species is known from only four specimens and its validity is questionable. Additional taxonomic work needed to clarify the species' status (R. Brown and A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007, Supsup et al. 2016). This species' highly disjunct known distribution, with records from islands in three geologically distinct islands, suggests that the four known specimens may correspond to as many as three different, undescribed species (Brown et al. 2013, Supsup et al. 2016).
Zug et al. (1985) suggested that the holotype of the enigmatic species Leiolopisma fasciolare might in fact be the lost holotype of Lipinia vulcania. Recent examination of this specimen (G. Shea in prep.) has confirmed that it represents the New World species Scincella lateralis.

There are currently three subspecies recognized: L. a. auriculata; L. a. kempi; and L. a. herrei. It seems possible that these taxa will all be elevated to species level following additional taxonomic work (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).

There are three subspecies (Hemibungarus calligaster calligaster; H. c. gemianulis; H. c. macclungi) which may merit elevation to species level (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007). Although no formal taxonomic action has been taken, and the status of these remains to be formally resolved, the three taxa are treated as distinct in recent keys and checklists of Philippine snakes (Leviton et al. 2014, 2018). 
Two specimens from the Bicol region of Luzon reported by Ross and Gonzales (1992) have not been assigned to subspecies, and research is need to clarify to which of the three currently recognized species these refer (Leviton et al. 2018).
This species exhibits no genetic divergence from, and may be conspecific with, Lycodon chrysopateros, and very low divergence from L. bibonius (Siler et al. 2013).

R. Brown (pers. comm. 2007) highlighted taxonomic problems involving Cyrtodactylus annulatus and C. philippinicus, both of which have previously been understood to be widespread in the Philippines but with poorly-characterized ranges (Welton et al. 2009). Welton et al. (2009), who redescribed C. annulatus, did not investigate C. philippinicus in detail. Welton et al. (2010) confirmed that multiple divergent genetic lineages exist within C. philippinicus as presently understood, and stressed the need for a comprehensive revision of this species.

Some authors consider Hemiphyllodactylus insularis, whose description involved limited comparison with related species, to be a synonym of Hemiphyllodactylus typus Bleeker, 1860. Although Kluge (2001) recognized it as valid he did so without explanation, and its status remained unclear until it was formally revalidated and redescribed by Zug (2010). In this author's scheme, all bisexual "Hemiphyllodactylus typus" from the Philippines correspond to H. insularis. Grismer et al. (2013) subsequently examined the systematics of this group through integrative (both morphological and molecular) analysis and rejected this concept, instead restricting the name H. insularis to a population from western Mindanao.
Records from the Babuyanes Group of islands may refer to an undescribed species (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2021).

There are currently three subspecies recognised: L. p. pulchella; L. p. taylori; and L. p. levitoni. It seems possible that these taxa will all be elevated to species level following additional taxonomic work (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).

Kaiser et al. (2018) discuss the problematic type locality, "Java", for this Philippine endemic. This erroneous locality, and the preservation of specimens labelled as both this species and the similarly-named Lycodon muelleri in the same collection jar, have resulted in confusion regarding the relationship between these two unrelated Philippine snakes and the distributions of each.
Further research is required to determine whether there is any differentiation between Samar-Leyte populations and those from Mindanao (Leviton et al. 2018).
This species is sometimes placed within the genus Parias. It was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Trimeresurus flavomaculatus.

It has been suggested that Bronchocela cristatella and B. marmorata occur in sympatry on Luzon on the basis of "slight" morphological differences between specimens, but there is no genetic evidence that two species co-occur on this island (Siler et al. 2011). These authors consequently recognize only B. marmorata from Luzon. Brown et al. (2013) concur that it is likely that only one species occurs on Luzon, for which the name B. marmorata is appropriate, but note that further research is required to confirm this. This is supported by evidence that the two morphotypes occur within a single population at least at one locality (McLeod et al. 2011).
Denzer et al. (2020) clarified the identity of Lophyrus spinosus, considered a junior synonym of Brochocela mamorata since it was first described. Although this synonymy was doubted by Hallerman (2005) he did not justify this conclusion (Denzer et al. 2020). Denzer et al. (2020) identified the sole known specimen of L. spinosus as a New Guinean member of the genus Hypsilurus, and consequently formally removed it from synonymy with B. marmorata.

Although this species has not been included in any recent taxonomic treatment due to the absence of genetic material, it is "likely" to be a valid species distinct from any other known Eutropis on Mindanao (Barley et al. 2020). With the recognition that multiple species of Eutropis occur in southwestern Mindanao, Barley et al. (2020) suggest that three atypical specimens collected from near Digos City, which are biogeographically disjunct from other known records, may represent an undescribed species.

This species is sometimes placed within the genus Parias. Currently there are two subspecies, T. f. flavomaculatus and T. f. halieus (Leviton et al. 2011). These authors agreed with this arrangement, and with the recognition of Trimeresurus mcgregori from the Batanes islands as a separate species. These authors suggested that records from Mindanao may represent recognition as a distinct species, for which the name Trimeresurus schadenbergi is available. 
More recently Leviton et al. (2018) referred records from Dinagat and part of northern Mindanao as T. cf. flavomaculatus, suggesting that two distinct species may be present on Mindanao. Pending a taxonomic treatment of this complex these are included within T. flavomaculatus for the purposes of this assessment.
Taxonomic revision underway - Elsa, led by Ynigo Del Prado, Russell Venturina, and Nino, Erl Maglangit, Arvin Diesmos, Mae Diesmos
 - Erl

Davis et al. (2014) redescribed this species and clarified its range limits relative to Brachymeles bonitae and the new species B. mapalanggon and B. isangdaliri. This did not affect the species concept previously recognized on the Red List, but confirmed that the record of "B. tridactylus" from Romblon reported by Siler et al. (2012) represents B. bonitae.

Linkem and Brown (2013) suggest that Sphenomorphus curtirostris from Mindanao, presently a junior synonym of Parvoscincus decipiens despite occurring outside the known range of this species, may either be a distinct species or conspecific with P. kitangladensis. Should the latter be the case, curtirostris would be the name with priority, but Brown and Linkem (2013) elect not to take taxonomic action pending collection of more material of these taxa.

Further taxonomic studies are needed to more clearly determine the range of the three Gonocephalus species recognized in the Philippines (Gonocephalus interruptus, G. semperi, and G. sophiae). Animals with white spots on the flanks are often readily identified as G. semperi, however this is not a good diagnostic character and other Gonocephalus species (such as G. interruptus) can also exhibit white spots.

Welton et al. (2017) conducted the first molecular phylogeny of Philippine Gonocephalus, based on sampling across the whole archipelago. Their results suggested that "as many as 12 Philippine lineages" may warrant treatment as candidate species. The complexity of the taxonomy involved, and the fact that none of the three nominal species in the Philippines has a type locality more specific than "Philippines", made it impossible for these authors to assign the three presently used names to specific lineages within the Philippine radiation. This account follows the distribution listed for samples of G. sophiae by Welton et al. (2017) with the caveat that the application of these names requires further research to clarify.
Hallerman (2005), rejecting the long-accepted assumption that Lophyrus spinosus is a junior synonym of Bronchocela marmorata, suggested that L. spinosus is a junior synonym of G. sophiae. This was rejected by Denzer et al. (2020), who determined that L. spinosus is an apparently valid but unknown species of Hypsilurus collected from western New Guinea.

Koch el al. (2010) recognized populations outside Mindanao as a distinct subspecies, Varanus cumingi samarensis; this taxon has since been elevated to species status (Welton et al. 2014). Koch et al. (2010) noted that the taxonomic status of records from Basilan requires further clarification as this population resembles V. samarensis, and that the taxonomic status of water monitor populations from Dinagat and Siargao requires investigation..
The affinities of this distinctive skink are unclear, and Linkem et al. (2011) elected to retain it within Sphenomorphus pending further research to clarify its relationships.

A 2007 Red List assessment of this species suggested that this species may occur on Babuyan Claro. A similar gecko described from this island has been described as the new species Gekko crombota (Brown et al. 2008), and consequently this assessment assumes that G. porosus is not likely to occur on Babuyan Claro.

There is a need for further examination of many specimens currently allocated to this species (e.g., those taken on Mindanao) to better determine their correct identification (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007). Records from Basilan, Samar, Luzon and Mindanao are not assigned to this species by Leviton et al. (2018).

The juveniles of other Oligodon are often mistaken for this species, resulting in erroneous records (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007). Tillack et al. (2009) found that the type of Oligodon rhombifer is indistinguishable from that of O. ancorus and synonymized it within O. ancorus. As O. ancorus is endemic to the Philippines this implies that the Sumatran type locality for O. rhombifer - a species known only from the holotype - is in error.
Additional studies into the taxonomic status of this species are needed. Records from the island of Mindoro may represent an undescribed species (A. Diesmos and R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).

Specimens from Ranomafana in the eastern rainforest belt agree with this species genetically, but further work is required to clarify the status of rainforest forms (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011). Research is needed to clarify the extent of differentiation between Madagascarophis meridionalis and M. colubrinus and to establish whether a hybrid zone exists (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Records from the north of this chameleon's range require taxonomic confirmation. Records from Parc National Tsingy de Bemaraha may represent this taxon,. F. petteri, or an undescribed form; due to uncertainty about the correct assignment of these records the Bemaraha records are not included in the assessments for either F. petteri or F. wilsii.

A number of specimens from Tsaratanana formerly considered unusual Calumma malthe (Brygoo 1971, 1978) probably represent this species (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). Raxworthy and Nussbaum (2006) explicitly note that atypical specimens from Marojejy described as C. sp. aff. malthe (Brygoo 1978) do not represent C. peltierorum, and these have since been found to represent true C. malthe (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. June 2011).
Molecular investigation is required to establish whether some records currently assigned to Madascincus melanopleura instead represent this species.
Domergue (1984) erected the subspecies Pararhadinea melanogaster marojejyensis for the apparently isolated Marojejy subpopulation, known from a single specimen.
This species is in need of taxonomic revision to clarify differences between subpopulations from western dry deciduous forest and those from eastern humid forest.
The Furcifer verrucosus, F. nicosiai, F. oustaleti group is in need of major revision and probably contains as yet undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007).

Crottini et al. (2009) considered Cryptoscincus, of which C. minimus was the only member, a junior synonym of Paracontias based on molecular evidence. Specimens from Baie de Sakalava, noted by Glaw and Vences (2007) as needing further study to verify their assignment to this species, have now been confirmed as P. minimus (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).
Mitochondrial (but not morphological) evidence suggests that this species may be conspecific with B. ambreensis (Townsend et al. 2010).

Following the recent description of Blaesodactylus ambonihazo, which is expected to be more widespread than is currently known, further morphological and genetic study is needed to clarify the northern limit of B. sakalava's distribution and to verify the specific identity of records north of Bemaraha (Bauer et al. 2011). The same research found that specimen of B. sakalava from Bemaraha exhibited high genetic divergence from a population from Ifaty in southern Madagascar (Bauer et al. 2011); however morphological and genetic analysis of additional specimens from areas throughout this gecko's range is required to establish whether cryptic species exist within B. sakalava as currently recognized (Bauer et al. 2011).

There is uncertainty about the number of species represented under the names Uroplatus fimbriatus and U. giganteus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). Raxworthy et al. (2008) consider U. giganteus to be a synonym for U. fimbriatus; however it has also been argued that additional undescribed species may be revealed within U. giganteus and/or U. fimbriatus by future molecular study (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011), and the population of U. cf. giganteus at Marojejy may warrant separate specific status (Greenbaum et al. 2007). The scheme followed here is that of Glaw et al. (2006), which considers this group to consist of two species, U. fimbriatus and U. giganteus, which correspond to the southern and northern clades of U. fimbriatus respectively (Raxworthy et al. 2008; F. Glaw, pers. comm. January 2011). Due to the geographical proximity of the U. fimbriatus type locality, Nosy Mangabe, to genetic U. giganteus, further research is needed to establish whether the assignment U. fimbriatus to the southern clade treated here under that name is valid, or whether this name should instead be applied either to a single species including both presently recognized clades, or to a northern form presently included under the name U. giganteus (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011).

The taxonomic status of southernmost subpopulations requires investigation (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). A taxonomic revision of all Malagasy Typhlops needs to be carried out (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
F. monoceras is considered a junior synonymn of F. rhinoceratus (Glaw and Vences 2007).
The taxonomic status of records from Tsaratanana, referred to Calumma cf. guillaumeti by Raxworthy et al. (2008), is in need of clarification (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. June 2011).

The population on Grand Comore is genetically similar to mainland Madagascar and does not warrant species status (Münchenberg et al. 2008). Recent overseas dispersal is the most likely mode of colonization and the population on Grand Comore is of conservation and evolutionary importance.

There is some uncertainty about the validity of this species, which is very similar to Lygodactylus arnoulti (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011, May 2011), although "it should probably be considered a distinct species" (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).
This species might be a junior synonym of X. grandidieri (M.Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

A subspecies Palleon (formerly Brookesia) nasus pauliani is recognized from high-altitude sites at Andringtra, but it was not found during the most recent surveys and its taxonomic status remains unresolved (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996).
Calumma gastrotaenia is a species complex, and is in the process of being revised (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011).

This species was synonymized with B. dentata by Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995). This synonymy was questioned by Glaw et al. (1999), and the validity of this species was supported by Townsend et al. (2009)

A full taxonomic revision of the Calumma nasutum species group is needed. At present, possible records of C. guibei from Manarikoba cannot be distinguished with certainty from C. boettgeri or putative undescribed forms (Andreone et al. 2009).

The population of Zonsaurus tsingy on the offshore island of Nosy Hara may represent a new species; as this form is so far known from only a single individual, further studies in this locality are needed to clarify this issue (Raselimanana et al. 2009).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Because of notable difference in reproductive biology, oviparous highland subpopulations may represent a distinct, undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007); if this proves to be the case this species will then require reassessment. This is a variable species throughout the south and southwest, exhibiting marked variation in colouration between geographic areas, although this is not currently thought to reflect taxonomic differences (A. Raselimanana pers. comm. May 2011). A red-tailed skink without the striped patterning of M. igneocaudatus, which is sympatric with the nominate form between Kirindy and Morondava, appears to represent a still-undescribed species (A. Raselimanana pers. comm. May 2011).

This species was until recently thought to be known only from the holotype (Glaw and Vences 2007); however animals found in the Fort Dauphin area are considered to represent this species (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011). This requires clarification, and the taxonomic status and relationships of this skink are in need of further study (Glaw and Vences 2007).

Yoder et al. (2005) suggested that Zonosaurus rufipes at Daraina may contain cryptic species; however genetic analysis of this species, including five specimens from Daraina, strongly supported its recognition as a monophyletic group (Raselimanana et al. 2009), and hence justify treating it as a single species.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. (2002), who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. (2006) recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
Stenophis guentheri was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.

Genetic data reveal that U. ebenaui is a complex of several species and a full taxonomic revision is required (Glaw and Vences 2007, Greenbaum et al. 2007, Raxworthy et al. 2008). Subpopulations from Marojejy, Tsaratanana and Montagne d'Ambre may warrant specific status (Greenbaum et al. 2007).
A Blaesodactylus population from Ankarafantsika previously assigned to this species was recently described as a new species, B. ambonihazo (Bauer et al. 2011).
Records of this species were formerly considered as C. brevicorne.

Nagy et al. 2010 removed Stenophis tulearensis from synonymy with this species (where it had been placed by Vences et al. 2004).The same authors elevated the subgenus Phisalixella to a full genus. The taxonomic identity of both P. tulearensis and P. variabilis requires further clarification (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
This species is closely related to at least three other putatively new species that require further taxonomic study (Glaw and Vences 2007).
The taxonomy of this species is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).
Molecular data indicate that this species is a complex of more than one taxon (Glaw and Vences 2007).
Zonosaurus maramaintso may be a colour variant of Z. boettgeri (Glaw and Vences 2007). Genetic data is needed to confirm the relationships of these taxa.

The taxonomy of Langaha alluaudi and L. pseudoalluaudi is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007). Records from southeast Madagascar, including a record from Amboasary Sud previously attributed to L. pseudoalluaudi (Glaw and Vences 2007), are now considered to represent L. alluaudi (A. Raselimanana and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011)

Distinct molecular differences between populations at low and mid altitude warrant research into the systematics of this species (Glaw and Vences 2007). Research is needed to clarify whether some records may be attributable to the similar M. minutus (Glaw and Vences 2007).

This species is genetically and morphologically similar to Zonosaurus quadrilineatus and these taxa may represent subspecies or just colour variants (Yoder et al. 2005). Additional study is needed to resolve this issue, hence they are treated as separate species here.

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.

authority: Franzen, Jones, Raselimanana, Nagy, D’Cruze, Glaw & Vences, 2009

taxonomicNotes: The U. henkeli and U. sikorae complex is in need of full taxonomic revision. A recent study treated U. sameiti as a full species that occurs in the same sites as U. sikorae but at lower elevations (Raxworthy et al. 2008).

A record of Typhlops microcephalus from Tsaratanana, to the south of other known localities, has recently been found to represent a different species (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011). High levels of genetic differentiation have been found between a specimen from the humid forest type locality, Montagne d'Ambre, and specimens from the dry forest sites Montagne des Français and Ampombofiofo. Further research is needed to clarify whether these related forms represent a single species or whether each of the three sites harbours a distinct species currently included within T. microcephalus (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).

A taxonomic revision of all Malagasy Typhlops needs to be carried out (M. Vences pers. comm January 2011).

Glaw and Vences (2007) considered Amphiglossus waterloti a synonym of Amphiglossus reticulatus, but noted the need for additional work to clarify this issue given morphological variation within these skinks.

Three subspecies are recognized: Phelsuma l. lineata, P. m. bombetokensis and P. m. punctulata. A fourth subspecies, P. l. dorsivittata, was recently elevated to species-level (Rocha et al. 2010) and is treated here as a separate species. The taxonomy of the remaining forms is in urgent need of clarification, and the genetically variable P. l. lineata may include unrecognized taxa (Glaw and Vences 2007). The assignment of a genetically distinct subpopulation from Marojejy is uncertain and thought to represent a distinct, undescribed species (Rocha et al. 2009, 2010). It is not treated in either this assessment or that of P. dorsivittata.

Records of this species from northern Madagascar, noted by Glaw and Vences (2007) as requiring further taxonomic study, may represent C. parsonii, C. oshaugnessyi or, in Montagne d'Ambre, C. ambreensis (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. June 2011), although there are no confirmed records of true C. oshaugnessyi from northern Madagascar (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011). A record from Tsaratanana requires further investigation to clarify its specific identity (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. (2002), who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. (2006) recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Molecular evidence suggests that each of the four islands of the Comoros archipelago is home to a distinct lineage of Trachylepis comorensis, which may justify recognition as distinct species (Rocha et al. 2010). The same study found that T. maculilabris casuarinae from Ilha Casuarina (treated as a full species by Broadley 2000) belongs to the Moheli clade of T. comorensis. Genetic similarity between T. m. casuarinae and T. comorensis (based on specimens from Madagascar, also part of the Moheli clade) had previously been used to argue for synonymizing T. comorensis within T. maculabris (Carretero et al. 2005). However, although T. comorensis is nested within T. maculabris as presently-defined, Rocha et al. (2010) found that it represents a discrete monophyletic group that includes T. m. casuarinae. Given the long recognition of T. comorensis as a valid species, and because T. maculabris as presently-defined is a known species complex whose taxonomy is in need of revision (Rocha et al. 2010, Jesus et al. 2005), T. comorensis is treated here as a full species, encompassing the Ilha Casuarina form in addition to subpopulations from the Comoros and Madagascar.
This species is poorly-defined by morphological characters, and so its range is very poorly known.

There are three recognized subspecies, P. m. modesta, P. m. leiogaster and P. m. isakae. There is weak genetic evidence for these subspecies and P. m. isakae in particular is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).

A 1996 record from Anjaharibe-Sud attributed considered to represent Amphiglossus cf. tsaratananensis (Raxworthy et al. 1998) has not been verified, and this species is here considered endemic to Tsaratanana (C. Raxworthy and F. Andreone pers. comm. July 2011).
Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995) classed Brookesia legendrei as a junior synonym of B. ebenaui.
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). Stenophis iarakaensis was assigned to Phisalixella by Nagy et al. (2010).

There is strong genetic differentiation between the southeast and western populations of this species, and molecular data indicate that an undescribed species probably exists (Münchenberg et al. 2008).

This chameleon was formerly considered a subspecies of C. gastrotaenia, but was elevated to species status by Böhme (1997). Individuals from Andohahela in the southeast require additional study to verify their taxonomic status (Andreone et al. 2001, Glaw and Vences 2007).
Stenophis pseudogranuliceps was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.

The taxonomy of Langaha alluaudi and L. pseudoalluaudi is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007). Records of L. pseudoalluaudi from southern Madagascar are now considered to represent L. alluaudi (A. Raselimanana and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
Ithycyphus blanci, known from Marojejy slightly to the north of the known range of I. goudoti, may represent an unusual form of this species.
This is a geographically variable species, and the taxonomic relevance of this variation is warranted (Glaw and Vences 2007).

The identity of Calumma linotum, a nasutum-group member described from the imprecise locality "Madagascar", is particularly unclear. Raxworthy et al. (2008) applied the name "Calumma cf. linota" to a population from Tsaratanana, but without comment and the justification for this assignment is therefore unclear. Gehring et al. (2012) likewise associated this name with a form from northern Madagascar, within the morphologically distinct boettgeri group. This entire group is in need of fundamental taxonomic revision (Andreone et al. 2009), and Gehring et al. (2012) identified two clades within their C. linotum alone. Pending resolution of the complex systematics of this group, and given uncertainty about the correct attribution of the name C. linotum to northern Madagascan populations, this taxon is provisionally considered a synonym of an undetermined species within the nastum group, likely C. boettgeri (F. Glaw pers. comm. to P. Uetz 2014, Uetz and Hallerman 2014).
The Furcifer verrucosus, F. nicosiai, F. oustaleti group is in need of major revision and probably contains as yet undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007).

Molecular data have shown that Trachylepsis gravenhorstii is a complex of undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007). Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
A taxonomic revision of all Malagasy Typhlops needs to be carried out (M. Vences pers. comm January 2011).

The Furcifer verrucosus, F. nicosiai, F. oustaleti group is in need of major revision and probably contains as yet undescribed species (Glaw and Vences 2007). Previous records of this species from the Menabe Region appear to be a previously undescribed taxon (Raselimanana 2008).

The taxonomic status of most populations attributed to this species is unclear and requires further study (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011); it may only be known with certainty from the type locality Lokobe, on the island of Nosy Be. A taxonomic revision of all Malagasy Typhlops needs to be carried out (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
Stenophis inornatus was assigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of these genera.
Notable morphological differences between sites suggest that this is a complex of two or three species (Glaw and Vences 2007).
Specimens resembling this species have been recorded from near Makira at approximately 50 m asl., but these require  confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011).
Five subspecies are recognized.

This species was previously included within Calumma brevicorne (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). Boumans et al. (2007) confirmed the genetic distinctness of these two species, but noted "remarkably low" genetic differentiation between C. brevicorne from Andasibe and C. crypticum from Mandraka. Additional taxa may remain to be described within this species (Boumans et al. 2007).
Taxonomic research is needed to identify whether the populations from Andohahela and Ivohibe represent the same or distinct species (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).
There are some inter-site differences in morphology, with specimens from the northeast being the most distinct (Puente et al. 2009).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

Three subspecies are recognized, P. q. quadriocellata, P. q. lepida and P. q. bimaculata. A fourth subspecies, P. q. parva, has recently been elevated to species-level (Rocha et al. 2010) and is treated as a separate species here. Genetic data indicate that Phelsuma quadriocellata is a complex of several additional species, probably including the subpopulation known from Nosy Boraha, and is in need of full revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).

A subspecies, Calumma parsonii cristifer is recognized from around Analamazaotra and Mantadia. At least three distinct colour morphs from different localities are also known (Brady and Griffiths 1999).

There is no observed genetic distinction between Z. laticaudatus and Z. anelanelany in the south-east and further studies are needed using a larger sample size (only two individuals of Z. anelanelany have been included in comparisons), and from a wider area, than has been previously undertaken to clarify whether this is a real effect (Raselimanana et al. 2009). The two species are morphologically distinct, and therefore introgression or hybridization may account for the lack of genetic differences (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). This research would also help to determine whether Z. laticaudatus populations south of the Onilahy River are a distinct species, and one which encompasses Z. anelanelany (Raselimanana et al. 2009)
A taxonomic revision of all Malagasy Typhlops needs to be carried out (M. Vences pers. comm January 2011).
This species is in need of research to establish whether differences between subpopulations warrant changes to this species' taxonomic status (Glaw and Vences 2007).

This species exhibits inter-population variation that warrants taxonomic investigation (Vences et al. 2002). Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).

This species is in need of taxonomic revision as its validity is uncertain (Glaw and Vences 2007). It may represent a morph of the very similar Madascincus melapleura (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011).

This poorly-known species is in need of taxonomic investigation to clarify whether known subpopulations all represent the same species (F. Glaw pers. comm. July 2011), and its relationships to other Amphiglossus species are unclear (Schmitz et al. 2005).
This species shows a strong similarity to B. thieli (Andreone et al. 2009). The B. thieli/B. lineata complex is in need of revision and may contain several new species (Andreone et al. 2009).

Specimens from the south and southwest are genetically and morphologically different and further studies using larger sample sizes are now required to resolved the taxonomic status of these (Glaw and Vences 2007, Münchenberg et al. 2008).
The taxonomy of Brookesia betschi is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).

A population from Montagne d'Ambre formerly considered a subspecies of Calumma oshaugnessyi has been given specific status in recent literature, as C. ambreense (Glaw and Vences, 2007; Andreone et al. 2009).

Although considered a subspecies of C. oshaughnessyi in the past, Glaw and Vences (2007) gave it specific status because of its distinctness, and this was accepted by Andreone et al. (2009). A specimen from Tsaratanana is tentatively assigned to this species, however its taxonomy is in need of clarification (M. Vences pers. comm. June 2011) and Tsaratanana is not considered part of this chameleon's range in this assessment.

The authority has variously been given as Merrem, 1820 or as Milbert, 1812; the latter is followed here and is generally accepted (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011). Three lineages are known from Mauritius (Austin et al. 2004), and if these are described as separate species the conservation status of P. cepediana will need to be reassessed.

Calumma hilleniusi has variously been considered either a full species or a subspecies of C. brevicorne (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). The identity of southern subpopulations currently assigned to this species requires verification (Vences et al. 2002).
It is presently unclear whether Ithycyphus blanci is a valid species, or simply an aberrant specimen of I. goudoti with an unusual number of scale rows (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011).
Mitochondrial (but not morphological) evidence suggests that this species may be conspecific with B. antakarana (Townsend et al. 2010).
The Z. aeneus subpopulation in the forest of Daraina in northern Madagascar shows notable genetic and morphological differences compared with other subpopulations (Raselimanana et al. 2009).
This species is closely-related to Zonosaurus brygooi (Raselimanana et al. 2009), and genetic study is required to clarify the relationship between these two forms (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011).
Miralles et al. (2011) suggest that Androngo is "most probably a synonym of Pygomeles".

There is uncertainty about the number of species represented under the names Uroplatus fimbriatus and U. giganteus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). Raxworthy et al. (2008) consider U. giganteus to be a synonym for U. fimbriatus; however it has also been argued that additional undescribed species may be revealed within U. giganteus and/or U. fimbriatus by future molecular study (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011). The scheme followed here is that of Glaw et al. (2006), which considers this group to consist of two species, U. fimbriatus and U. giganteus, which correspond to the southern and northern clades of U. fimbriatus respectively (Raxworthy et al. 2008; F. Glaw, pers. comm. January 2011). Due to the geographical proximity of the U. fimbriatus type locality, Nosy Mangabe, to genetic U. giganteus, further research is needed to establish whether the assignment U. fimbriatus to the southern clade treated here under that name is valid, or whether this name should instead be applied either to a single species including both presently recognized clades, or to a northern form presently included under the name U. giganteus (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011).
The records from Antsolipa are known only from photographs, and the identity of skinks at this site requires confirmation (Labanowski and Lowin 2011).

The taxonomy of this species and its relationships to similar, unassigned specimens from other high- and mid-elevation sites in Madagascar are in need of intensive taxonomic research (Glaw and Vences 2007).

There is little morphological difference in specimens from scattered localities in Madagascar, although specimens from the two northwestern populations Berara and Ankarafantsika show a considerable molecular divergence (Puente et al. 2005, 2009).
Specimens from Isalo currently attributed to this species (Glaw and Vences 2007), and included in this assessment, likely represent an undescribed taxon (F. Andreone pers. comm. January 2011).

This species resembles, but has long been recognized as distinct from, Calumma brevicorne,  being noted as C. sp. aff. brevicorne when first collected (Brygoo 1978). It was formally described only when Raxworthy and Nussbaum (2006) clarified the taxonomy of this species group.

Glaw and Vences (2007) note that a population resembling P. petiti occurs at Tsingy de Bemaraha, but this form is not known from any specimens and is not considered to belong to this species. The Tsingy de Bemaraha form is not considered in this assessment.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. January 2011).

Recently-discovered specimens from Baie de Sakalava are provisionally assigned to X. grandidieri, a species previously known only from a single specimen with the type locality "Madagascar" (Glaw and Vences 2007; F. Glaw pers. comm.April 2011), on the basis that two other restricted-range species described by Mocquard have been found at the same locality, providing evidence that collections took place within or near this site (F. Glaw pers. comm. April 2011). These records were treated as belonging to X. mocquardi in Glaw and Vences (2007). Xenotyphlops mocquardi is itself likely to be a junior synonym of this species, as it falls within the range of variation observed within more recently-collected Baie de Sakalava specimens assigned to X. grandidieri (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011; F. Glaw pers. comm. April 2011). If this is the case, this will represent a slight range extension to the south (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

This species is clearly distinct from any other Malagasy Lygodactylus. It is presumed that the village of Mandritsara where the species has been recorded represents the type locality. However, as the type locality is given as "Mt. Mandritsara, northwest Madagascar" in the original description (Pasteur, 1965), and no mountain exists near the village (which is in northeast Madagascar), this cannot be verified with certainty.
This validity of this species, which very closely resembles Amphiglossus ornaticeps, requires confirmation (Glaw and Vences 2007).

Zonosaurus maromaintso may be a colour variant of Z. boettgeri (Glaw and Vences 2007). Genetic data is needed to confirm the relationships of these taxa. Specimens of Z. boettgeri from the island of Nosy Be (the type locality) are also distinct from those of the nearby mainland and require additional study to clarify their specific status (Raselimanana et al. 2009); should this subpopulation prove to be distinct, the mainland form would therefore require a different name.

Following the recent description of Blaesodactylus ambonihazo, which is expected to be more widespread than is currently known, further morphological and genetic study is needed to clarify the southern limit of B. boivini's distribution and to verify the specific identity of records south of Ankarana (Bauer et al. 2011).

Higher-elevation populations belong to the subspecies Phelsuma madagascariensis boehmei. Two former subspecies, P. m. kochi and P. m. grandis, were elevated to full species by Raxworthy et al. (2009), a change later supported by genetic analysis (Rocha et al. 2010).
Large variation in body size warrants a taxonomic and genetic revision of this species (Puente et al. 2009).

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.
The taxonomy of this species is in need of revision (Glaw and Vences 2007).

This widespread chameleon was redescribed by Raxworthy and Nussbaum (2006), who distinguished six additional species formerly included within C. brevicorne and clarified that the proposed subspecies Calumma brevicorne tsarafidyi was invalid. Genetic studies to clarify the taxonomy and distribution of this species and its relation to other species of large occipital-lobed Calumma are ongoing (Boumans et al. 2007).
In the past, this gecko has been treated as a subspecies of Paroedura bastardi, but genetic studies support its recognition as a distinct species (Jackman et al. 2008).

Lygodactylus h. trilinegularis is treated by Puente et al. (2009) as a subspecies of L. heterurus rather than as a distinct species. This requires further taxonomic investigation (Glaw and Vences 2007). Specimens from Montagne des Français are referred to as L. cf. heterurus in D'Cruze and Kumar (2011).
Two subspecies are recognized, P. p. pusilla and P. p. hallmanni.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
The taxonomy of Pseudoxyrhopus imerinae and P. quinpuelineatus is in need of revision

Cope (1885) used both Cyclura onchiopsis and Cyclura nigerrima; but only the former was diagnosed. Consequently, the latter must was a nomen nudum. Nearly a year later, Cope (1885 [1886]) provided a diagnosis for C. nigerrima. Barbour (1937) relegated C. nigerrima to a subspecies of C. cornuta. Schwartz and Carey (1977) formally placed C. nigerrima in the synonymy of C. onchiopsis.

Originally described as a full species, the Navassa Rhinoceros Iguana was relegated to subspecific status within the Rhinoceros Iguanas (Cyclura cornuta) first by Cope (1885 [1886]), without presenting any evidence other than superficial physical similarity. That status was contradicted by Barbour and Noble (1916), although Barbour (1937) later reverted to the subspecific designation. Carey (1977) recognized Cyclura onchiopsis as a full species, but most subsequent authorities followed Schwartz and Thomas (1975) in recognizing it as a subspecies. Powell (1999) re-elevated the taxon to full species status.

Kaestlea travancorica was described by Beddome in 1870 as Mocoa travancorica based on specimens collected from Travancore hills in Kerala (Smith 1935). Members of the this genus have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella until Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected a new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.
Ctenosaura praeocularis was recently described and may be previously referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura flavidorsalis and less often as Ctenosaura quinquecarinata.
This species was previously included in the genus Ophisaurus.
This species is very similar to Calumma nasutum Dumeril & Bibron, 1836 (Glaw and Vences 2007). The species taxonomy is currently uncertain and needs to be resolved.

According to the phylogenetic tree by Macey et al. (2008) Chamaeleo monachus is the basal taxon of all other species of the Chamaeleo chamaeleon species group, and originated by an early vicariant isolation when Socotra detached from the other Gondwanan plates.

This species represents a distinct phylogenetic lineage within Chamaeleo (Townsend and Larson 2002, Tolley et al. 2013). It diverged from other Chamaeleo approximately 38 mya (Tolley et al. 2013). Despite this, it is strongly supported as being in the Chamaeleo clade, and most other chameleon genera contain species or lineages of similar age. Therefore, although some suggestions have been made that this taxon could be representative of a separate genus (Townsend and Larson 2002, Tilbury 2010), the most parsimonious solution is to retain it within Chamaeleo in order to remain consistent within the context of the entire family.
Trioceros feae and T. camerunensis have previously been considered to be subspecies of T. montium.

This species occurs in several disjunct subpopulations, and this unusual distribution may reflect a complex of several cryptic species (K. Tolley pers. comm. 2012). J. Mariaux (pers. comm.) suggests that Congolese specimens at least may represent a separate species.
This is sometimes considered to be a subspecies of Homalopsis buccata.
Very closely related to E. innominata and E. jagorii with very similar morphology and DNA, they may even be conspecific.

Although Sri Lankan and Southeast Asian populations of this species exhibit little variation, mitochondrial data suggest divergence of approximately 3% between sequences from Sri Lanka and Singapore (Ukuwela et al. 2017).
This species is the sole member of its genus.

This taxon is probably a species complex of three distinct species with morphological evidence indicating that one specimen from the Aru Islands is distinct from the typical M. richardsonii; and likewise another two specimens (one from Broome) are also distinct from the typical M. richardsonii and the one from Aru (Murphy in prep.).

Based on morphology and DNA evidence, there are possible grounds for dividing this species into three: a South Asian species extending from India to Phuket, a Southeast Asian species from Phuket to Philippines and Indonesia, and a Palau species occurring in Palau exclusively.
This may be a species complex comprising more than one species. However, it is difficult to differentiate based on the small number of specimens available.

Based on morphological information this is probably a complex of 3-6 different species (J. Murphy pers. comm. 2009). Two subspecies have been described: Homalopsis buccata buccata (Linnaeus, 1758) and H. buccata nigroventralis (Deuve, 1970).

Very closely related to E. innominata and E. longicauda with very similar morphology and DNA, they may even be conspecific.

Note this assessment excludes E. subtaeniata which is treated separately as a valid species.
There is a manuscript in preparation that suggests that this species should not be in the genus Cantoria (J. Murphy in prep.).
This is treated by some authors as a synonym of E. jagorii (see The Reptile Database).
DNA evidence suggests that this taxon includes more than one species. However separation is cryptic.
Very closely related to E. jagorii and E. longicauda with very similar morphology and DNA, they may even be conspecific.
It is not certain that this species belongs in the family Homalposidae (J. Murphy pers. comm. 2009). In addition, this species requires taxonomic clarification as it may be conspecific with B. albus.
The neotype for this species was described in 2007, and was accompanied by several paratypes (Rasmussen et al. 2007).
This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

Molecular and morphological evidence suggests that this species might be a synonym of the very widespread Asian species Hydrophis cyanocinctus (Sanders et al. 2013), and this issue should be a priority for future taxonomic studies. However, because some morphological data indicate that we have more than one species involved in the Australian complex (Mirtschin et al. 2017),  we suggest following Cogger (1975) and using the name H. pacificus until this complex has been investigated more thoroughly.This species-complex has also been treated under the genus Leioselasma (Kharin 2005), however, based on molecular data is the species included in the genus Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species is sometimes treated under the genus Microcephalophis.

The genus Polyodontognathus has been described for this species (Kharin 2004). Kharin (2004) also suggests there may be two subspecies: H. c .caerulescens in the west (India, Sri Lanka, Burma, Malacca Straits) and H. c. hybridus (Sclegel 1844) in the east (Thailand, Indonesia, Australia). Data from Sanders et al. (2013) confirmed that the taxon belongs to Hydrophis.
This species has also been treated under the genus Leioselasma but is maintained in Hydrophis by Uetz et al. (2018).

The taxonomic status of species in the genus Emydocephalus is uncertain. It has been suggested that populations of E. annulatus in the Philippines are a distinct species (Alcala et al. 2000). Systematic studies are needed to determine the taxonomic status and geographic distributions of species in the genus Emydocephalus (Rasmussen and Ineich 2010). A new species is descripted from Vietnam (Dotsenko 2011), excluding E. annulatus from that area. However, the new species is only based on one specimen giving some doubt of its validity.
This species has also been treated under the genus Pseudolaticauda (the subgeneric name).
This species has also been treated under the genus Disteira.

This is a species complex (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2009). Three subspecies have been described.

Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
Previously subsumed under the specific name L. colubrina (Cogger and Heatwole 2006).
In the Australian region, most people call this species H. pacificus and they may be the same species (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2008). Sometimes treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Smith (1926) regarded H. ocellatus to be a subspecies of H. ornatus and referred Australian specimens previously included in H. ornatus to it. Later, H. o. ocellatus was raised to species level because of its distinctive DNA, colour pattern and a higher number of midbody scale rows compared with H. o. ornatus in Asia (Rasmussen et al. 2011, Rasmussen et al. 2014, K. L. Sanders et al. 2013, Smith 1974). This species has by some authors been treated as a subspecies under Chitulia ornata (Kharin 2005) but molecular studies in 2013 included it in the genus Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species was known only from the holotype until 1987 (Rasmussen 1992).  Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species has also been treated under the genus Disteira (Kharin and Czeblukov 2009) but molecular studies have included it in the genus Hydrophis (Sander et al. 2013).

H. geometricus Smith, 1986, is a synonym for this species (Rasmussen and Smith 1997). It has also been treated under the genus Leioselasma by Kharin (2005b). However, molecular data indicate it belongs to the genus Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species has been described as synonymous with, or a subspecies of H. ornatus. Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

This species has a highly variable colour pattern throughout its range and, as currently recognized, may comprise a complex of two or more species (Cogger 1975, A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2009). The taxon is sometimes treated under the genus Leioselasma, however, molecular analyses place it in Hydrophis (Sanders et al. 2013). A molecular study of 39 Sea Snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera. Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013).

The identification and distribution of Hydrophis atriceps and H. fasciatus are based on Smith´s monograph (1926), where he separated them at a subspecies level and mentioned the typical form (Hydrophis fasciatus) occurs to west of the Malay Peninsula and the other form (Hydrophis atriceps) is found east of the Malay Peninsula throughout the Malay Archipelago and south to Australia. Smith mentioned the dividing line to be in the region of Singapore, despite including a specimen from China in the western subspecies and two specimens from India and Rangoon in the eastern form. The specimen from China, included by Smith in the western form (H. f. fasciatus), is the type of Hydrophis lindsayi (Gray 1831) which antedates the name H. f. atriceps by 22 years. This indicates that if the taxa are separated into two geographically distinct forms, and this specimen was incorrectly assigned by Smith (1926) to H. f. fasciatus, the right name for the eastern population would be H. fasciatus lindsayi and not H. fasciatus atriceps. Later, Cogger et al. (1983) raised the two taxa to species level, referring the Australian specimens to H. atriceps. Ward (1996) assigned five specimens to H. atriceps from the northern Australian continental shelf. All the specimens were collected by prawn trawlers (Ward 1996).Whether the name for an Australian population of the H. fasciatus complex proves to be atriceps, fasciatus or lindsayi, we regard the species to be in Australian waters based on at least one specimen from the region of Darwin (AMR14022) and the specimens mentioned by Ward (1996). We suggest using the name H. atriceps for the Australian population of this species until further taxonomic clarification (Rasmussen et al. 2014).
Previously subsumed under the specific name L. colubrina, but it has been shown that these are sibling species which are reproductively isolated from each other (Shine et al. 2002).

This species has three subspecies: Hydrophis ornatus ornatus (Gray, 1942), Hydrophis ornatus godeffroyi Peters, 1873, and Hydrophis ornatus ocellatus Gray, 1849. The status of these subspecies is very uncertain, and the subspecies ocellatus is treated in this assessment as a separate distinct species (H. Cogger pers. comm. 2009).

H. lamberti has been incorrectly considered a synonym of H. ornatus (Smith 1926). This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

There is some debate as to whether L. schistorynchus is a separate species, or a subspecies of L. semifasciata, due to similarities in venom chemistry (Guinea et al. 1983, Tamiya et al. 1983) and morphology (McCarthy 1986). This is disputed by Cogger and Heatwole (2005).

The Reptile Database treats this species under the genus Pseudolaticauda.

Some of Smith’s (1926) Hydrophis belcheri specimens have since been re-assigned to H. coggeri and all specimens called H. melanocephalus in Australian waters are regarded as H. coggeri (Rasmussen et al. 2014). Data from Sanders et al. (2013) confirmed that the taxon belongs to Hydrophis.
After the separation of H. fasciatus and H. atriceps (Cogger et al. 1983), H. atriceps is only found east of Singapore and H. fasciatus west of Singapore (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2008).
Molecular phylogenies place Hydrophis macdowelli within Hydrophis as sister species to H. czeblukovi (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species has been treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Aipysurus dubuisii has ventral scales each with a shallow posterior notch and weak median keel, and body scales smooth. In addition, all its head shields are fragmented except for rostral and nasal scales. This Sea Snake's colour is variable, typically purplish-brown with pale edges to scales forming reticulum, and often with cream bands tending to form triangular lateral blotches (Wilson and Swan 2013).

Before 2006, L. saintigironsi (endemic to New Caledonia), L. guineai (endemic to southern Papua New Guinea), and L. frontalis (a dwarf species endemic to Vanuatu) were considered to be the same species as L. colubrina (Heatwole et al. 2005, Cogger and Heatwole 2006).

Many earlier references to this species, including most records from Australian waters, are based on the misidentification of a species previously known as H. melanocephalus. It has also been treated under the genus Chitulia (Kharin 2005a). Hydrophis belcheri was described by Gray (1849) who gave the type locality “New Guinea” with no further information. Smith (1926) re-described H. belcheri based on 21 specimens mainly from the Philippines, New Guinea and Fiji Islands. Most of Smith’s H. belcheri specimens have since been re-assigned to the following taxa: Hydrophis coggeri, H. czeblukovi, H. pachycercos and H. pacificus (Cogger 1975; Kharin 1983, 1984; Rasmussen et al.2007; Rasmussen et al. 2014; Rasmussen and Smith 1997).
This species has been (incorrectly) described as a synonym of H. ornatus (Rasmussen 1989).  It has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
Shea (1996) notes that the name of this species should be spelled greyae, not greyi, because it was named in honour of a Mrs. Beatrice Grey and hence should bear the feminine ending.

A recent phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and is followed by most authors (D'Anastasi et al. 2016, Leviton et al. 2014, Lillywhite et al. 2014, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Rasmussen et al. 2014, Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2016, Udyawer et al. 2015, Ukuwela et al. 2014).
This species is sometimes treated under the genus Chitulia.

Aipysurus tenuis is a relatively slender snake that can be distinguished from closely-related A. laevis by the number of ventral scales (at least 180) and scale rows at mid-body (19) (Rasmussen et al. 2014). A. tenuis can reach a total length of 1.05 m with tail up to 14 cm. The head is brown and darker in colour than the rest of the body. Dorsally, most scales have a light brown edge in the middle and rear of the scale, and dark brown in the middle and the tip of the scale, forming longitudinal lines along the medial line and more or less distinct cross-bands on the sides(Cogger 2014, Mirtschin et al. 2017) . The body scales are smooth and imbricate (overlapping), and males may have small tubercles along hind edge of the scale. The anal scales are divided and overlapping. Subcaudals 33-36 and single. The head shields are enlarged, symmetrical and occasionally fragmented.
This species has also been treated under the genus Disteira (Kharin and Czeblukov 2009) but was included in the genus Hydrophis in 2013 (Sanders et al. 2013).
This species has been treated under the genus Leioselasma.

Aipysurus fuscus is a small to moderately sized venomous snake, typically reaching a length of 60 cm and maximum total length of 98 cm (Cogger 2014, Francis 2006, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Storr et al. 2002). Adults are brown, blackish-brown or purplish-brown, but often have obscure, paler cross bands on the lower flanks. Sometimes the lateral scales will have a darker patch at the centre, resulting in faint, longitudinal striations; younger snakes are typically lighter and dark banded.

Aipysurus fuscus can be differentiated from closely related A. laevis by its smaller size, darker colouration and by the number of scales on belly and mid-body (155 – 172 ventral scales and less than 21 scale rows around the midbody). Other scale features used in taxonomy of A. fuscus include: head shields are regular with some fragmentation of scales occasionally (prefrontals, frontal and supraoculars) especially the parietals; upper labials six to nine, with the first three or four sometimes divided horizontally; anal scales are divided, while ventral scales are broad with a medium keel and no posterior notch. Body scales are smooth with some lowest rows weakly keeled in males. Body scales are imbricate (overlapping) and there are typically 19 scale rows around the neck and 19 around the mid-body. Females have between 24 to 33 subcaudal scales, while males have 30 to 37 subcaudal scales (Francis 2006, Rasmussen et al. 2014).

Microsatellite markers for A. fuscus and A. laevis sampled across four Timor Sea reefs were analysed to assess evidence for recent inter-specific gene flow and historical introgression (Sanders et al. 2014). The data fit an Isolation–Migration model, which showed significant and asymmetrical levels of gene flow following species divergence, and highest rates of introgression from the large A. laevis population into the much smaller A. fuscus population(Sanders et al. 2014). Population assignment analyses recovered two ancestral clusters that broadly corresponded to morphological species designations, but revealed high frequencies of hybrids on all four reefs and individuals of pure A. fuscus ancestry only at Scott and (historically) Ashmore. Most unexpectedly, 95% of snakes sampled at Hibernia were hybrids that resembled A. laevis in phenotype, revealing a collapse of reproductive barriers (‘reverse speciation’) at this reef. These results have dire implications for the conservation status of A. fuscus, and highlight the fragility of reproductive barriers in a recent marine radiation (Sanders et al. 2014).

This species has also been treated under the genus Microcephalophis, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.
Smith (1926) described two subspecies: K. jerdoni jerdoni and K. jerdoni siamensis. Further studies are needed to finalize the validity of the two subspecies (Rasmussen and Anderson 1990).

There has been some discussion regarding two possible subspecies L. l. laticaudata (see Rasmussen 1989) and L. l. affinus (Anderson, 1871) (see Heatwole et al. 2005) though most authorities treat L. laticaudata as a single lineage. The Reptile Database lists a third subspecies L. l. wolfii Volsoe, 1956.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under review. The Reptile Database treats this species under the genus Disteira.

Based on colour variations, Glaw and Vences (2007) hypothesized that more than one species may be hidden under the name Liophidium vaillanti. The population from Isalo also probably represents a distinct species (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011).

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.
Calliophis bibroni was described as Elaps bibroni by Jan in 1858 based on specimens collected from unknown locality in India (Smith 1943).
Köhler et al. (2009) synonymized Geckolepis anomala and G. modesta with G. typica.

There are five distinct subspecies P.f. filfolensis (Filfola Island, Malta); P.f. generalensis (the General's Rock, Malta); P.f. kieselbachi (Selmunett Islands, Malta); P.f. laurentiimuelleri (Linosa and Lampione Islands, Italy); P.f. maltensis (Malta).

Podarcis gaigeae was separated from this species by Gruber (1986). Although this status was not recognized by Gasc et al. (1997), it is supported by additional genetic results (Harris and Arnold 1999).
This is a distinct species within the Varanus indicus species group (Ziegler et al. 2007).

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
This species might be a synonym of T. porrectus Stolicza, 1871, but clarification is required from further examination of types.

Afro-Malagasy species within the genus Mabuya were recovered as a distinct clade by Mausfeld et al. 2002, who applied the generic name Euprepis to this group. Bauer (2003) found that this assignment was in error, as the name Euprepis was not available for Afro-Malagasy skinks, and resurrected Trachylepis for the clade. A more recent study with more extensive genetic sampling failed to recover this group (Carranza and Arnold 2003), although this research included few African and no Madagascan Trachylepis. Although Whiting et al. 2006 recovered a monophyletic Afro-Malagasy clade, these authors cautioned that their sampling was not sufficient to test genus boundaries, and pending resolution of relationships within Mabuya a number of authors prefer to retain the older nomenclature (Whiting et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2010). Trachylepis is used here as the accepted genus name for these skinks among most African workers (A. Bauer pers. comm. May 2011).
The taxonomy of Geckolepis has not yet been fully determined and it is probable that current species definitions do not reflect biological reality (M. Vences pers. comm.).

The taxonomy of Amphiglossus melanurus has not yet been fully determined and it is probable that current species definitions do not reflect biological reality (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011). Glaw and Vences (2007) include A. poecilopus as a synonym.

The taxonomy of Geckolepis has not yet been fully determined. It is probable that current species definitions do not reflect biological reality (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011), and G. maculata is considered to be a species complex (F. Glaw and O. Hawlitschek pers. comm. May 2011). A recent record from northern Madagascar has been attributed to G. cf. maculata (Durkin et al. 2011).
This species was transferred from Amphiglossus johannae to Flexiseps (Eren et al. 2017).
The taxonomy of this species requires further study to clarify its distinction from the similar Amphiglossus tanysoma (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011).

Siler et al. (2014) investigated the relationship between this species and the Philippine species complex Gekko mindorensis, with which it was previously proposed it may be synonymous. Based on the results of their morphological and molecular study, these authors concluded that the species is distinct from the majority of G. mindorensis populations as presently recognized although it represents a recent - and possibly human-mediated - colonization from Luzon.

While cautioning that the complexity of the genetic patterns obtained in their coalescent analysis precluded Siler et al. (2014) from making extensive taxonomic changes to the G. mindorensis complex without further data, they were sufficiently confident in the relationship between Luzon and Lanyu clades, and of their distinctiveness from G. mindorensis from southern Luzon, to extend the range of G. kikuchii to northern and central Luzon. While they acknowledged that this action renders G. mindorensis paraphyletic pending further research, this latter is a known species complex and they argue that their arrangement better-reflects current knowledge, especially in the context of evaluating each taxon's conservation status. The name G. mindorensis is used for the southern members of the complex following the usage of Siler et al. (2014), however further research may reveal that this name is a junior synonym of G. kikuchii (R. Brown pers. comm. 2021).
The Gekko mindorensis-kikuchii complex is likely to include as many as 8 species, some of which may fall within G. kikuchii as presently understood (R. Brown pers. comm. 2021). Further collections and needed and there is too little known morphological variation to distinguish between lineages (R. Brown pers. comm. 2021).

Three subspecies are recognized:
Anolis whitemani whitemani Williams, 1963
Anolis whitemani lapidosus Schwartz, 1980
Anolis whitemani breslini Schwartz, 1980.

Glor et al. (2003) presented evidence that the two subspecies A. whitemani whitemani and A. whitemani breslini are different species.
Genetic and morphological data suggest that this is a complex of various species (M. Vences pers. comm.).

Some western records of Phelsuma mutabilis, especially in the northwest, may refer to this species, but this is difficult to establish with certainty as genetic evidence shows that true P. mutabilis is also found in this region (Glaw et al. 2009).

authority: Gehring, Pabijan, Ratsoavina, Köhler, Vences & Glaw, 2010
Vieites, Ratsoavina, Randrianiaina, Nagy, Glaw & Vences, 2010

taxonomicNotes: A photograph of the only known specimen of this species was included by Glaw and Vences (2007) as Paracontias hildebrandti, with the note that this identification was tentative.
