These clades corresponded to an eastern/northern clade encompassing the continental United States and Sonora, Mexico, and northern and southern Baja California peninsula clades. The most recent phylogenetic study on S. ater using double-digest Restriction-Associated DNA sequencing (ddRADseq; Sumarli, 2020) confirmed the presence of at least two major lineages within S. ater, peninsular and continental groups, that diverged in northern Baja California. Based on strong support from multispecies coalescent-based and modern phylogenetic analyses, Sumarli (2020) suggested these two major lineages should be recognized as distinct species. Within the continental lineage especially, Sumarli (2020) identified substantial phylogeographic substructure corresponding to the different desert regions in southwestern North America requiring further investigation with more extensive geographic sampling.

Dixon and Vaughan (2003) examined morphological variation in 867 individuals of Mexican and US Leptotyphlops allied with L. dulcis and concluded that L. dissectus, L. dulcis, and L. myopicus (a Mexican species) should be regarded as distinct species. Formerly dissectus and myopicus were treated as subspecies of L. dulcis. Crother et al. (2003) adopted this taxonomic revision.

Dixon and Vaughan (2003) examined morphological variation in 867 individuals of Mexican and US Leptotyphlops allied with L. dulcis and concluded that L. dissectus, L. dulcis, and L. myopicus (a Mexican species) should be regarded as distinct species. Formerly dissectus and myopicus were treated as subspecies of L. dulcis. Crother et al. (2003) adopted this taxonomic revision.

Dixon and Vaughan (2003) examined morphological variation in 867 individuals of Mexican and US Leptotyphlops allied with L. dulcis and concluded that L. dissectus, L. dulcis, and L. myopicus (a Mexican species) should be regarded as distinct species. Formerly dissectus and myopicus were treated as subspecies of L. dulcis. Crother et al. (2003) adopted this taxonomic revision.
This species formerly was included in the genus Streptosaurus. See Aguilars-S. et al. (1988) for information on genetic variability in the genus Petrosaurus.

Some literature of the mid-1900s regarded the coronatum-blainvillii complex as comprising two species. Stebbins (1985, 2003) did not recognize any subspecies of P. coronatum. Grismer and Mellink (1994) concluded that P. cerroense lacks discrete diagnostic characteristics and should not be recognized as a species. Brattstrom (1997) examined morphological variation and also determined that P. cerroense should be included in P. coronatum; furthermore, he concluded that there are no valid subspecies of P. coronatum. Grismer (2002) treated the named subspecies of P. coronatum as pattern classes rather than as valid taxa. In a morphological study, Montanucci (2004) concluded that P. coronatum should be split into four species (P. blainvillii, P. cerroense, P. coronatum, and P. wigginsi), with P. blainvillii in the United States and the northern half of Baja California, and the three other species in Baja California. Given the disparity among the conclusions from morphological studies, genetic data are needed in order to determine whether or not P. coronatum (sensu Stebbins 2003) represents multiple species.

Reeder and Montanucci (2001) examined phylogenetic relationships of horned lizards (Phrynosoma) based on mtDNA and morphology. They did not consider phylogenetic patterns within P. coronatum.

Leaché and McGuire (2006) report that "a thorough analysis of the P. coronatum group based on mtDNA and nuclear data is currently underway".

Zamudio et al. (1997) examined mtDNA variation in short-horned lizards throughout western North America and concluded that the Pacific Northwest segment of the population should be recognized as a species (P. douglasii) distinct from the species (P. hernandesi) represented in the remainder of the range. In addition, there was no support for the recognition of any of the nominal subspecies; thus each species is best regarded as monotypic. See Hammerson and Smith (1991) for information on the correct spelling of the specific name (formerly douglassi). The specific name is here spelled with a double-i ending, since that is how it was rendered in the original description.

Zamudio et al. (1997) examined mtDNA variation in short-horned lizards throughout western North America and concluded that the Pacific Northwest segment of the population should be recognized as a species (P. douglasii) distinct from the species (P. hernandesi) represented in the remainder of the range. In addition, there was no support for the recognition of any of the nominal subspecies; thus each species is best regarded as monotypic.

In the past, some authors have questioned whether S. woodi is sufficiently differentiated from S. undulatus to be considered a distinct species. More recently, S. woodi has been rather consistently recognized as a distinct species.

This species was separated from Scelophorus magister by Grismer and McGuire (1996). S. zosteromus now comprises what was formerly considered S. rufidorsum, S. monserratensis, and S. zosteromus (Grismer and McGuire 1996).

Based on electrophoretic analyses, Adest (1977) concluded that Uma scoparia, Uma notata and Uma inornata comprise a single species (Uma notata). Stebbins (1985, 2003) maintained the three taxa as distinct species. Phylogenetic relationships inferred from mtDNA sequences indicate that Uma notata rufopunctata is more closely related to Uma inornata than to Uma notata notata (Wilgenbusch and de Queiroz 2000, Trepanier and Murphy 2001). Trepanier and Murphy (2001) concluded that for the northern species of Uma existing data support either a two-species arrangement (Uma scoparia, Uma notata) or five-species classification (Uma scoparia, Uma notata, Uma inornata, and Uma rufopunctata, plus an undescribed species from Mohawk Dunes, Arizona). Trepanier and Murphy prefered the latter arrangement and stated that a description of the Mohawk Dunes species is in progress. Crother et al. (2003) adopted the taxonomy preferred by Trepanier and Murphy, and this is followed here.

Heifetz (1941) described Uma notata cowlesi from Tecopa Bay, Sonora, but this subspecies was not regarded as worthy of recognition by Norris (1958) and Pough (1977).
This species comprises two subspecies which will be elevated to full species in the near future (L. Canseco-Márquez pers. comm.).

Uma rufopunctata formerly was regarded as a subspecies of Uma notata. Based on electrophoretic analyses, Adest (1977) concluded that Uma scoparia, Uma notata, and Uma inornata comprise a single species (Uma notata) (Adest 1977). Stebbins (1985, 2003) maintained the three taxa as distinct species. Phylogenetic relationships inferred from mtDNA sequences indicate that Uma notata rufopunctata is more closely related to Uma inornata than to Uma notata notata (Wilgenbusch and de Queiroz 2000, Trepanier and Murphy 2001). Trepanier and Murphy (2001) concluded that for the northern species of Uma existing data support either a two-species arrangement (Uma scoparia, Uma notata) or five-species classification (Uma scoparia, Uma notata, Uma inornata, and Uma rufopunctata, plus an undescribed species from Mohawk Dunes, Arizona). Trepanier and Murphy prefered the latter arrangement and stated that a description of the Mohawk Dunes species is in progress. Crother et al. (2003) adopted the taxonomy preferred by Trepanier and Murphy. Uma rufopunctata encompasses the nominal subspecies cowlesi, which has been regarded as invalid by most authorities subsequent to its description in 1941.

Sceloporus arenicolus formerly was included in this species (see discussion in Degenhardt et al. 1996).

Collins (1991, 1997) and Collins and Taggart (2002) listed subspecies vandenburgianus of southern California and Baja California as a distinct species, but they did not provide any data to support this treatment. Wiens and Reeder (1997) also listed this lizard as a species but again did not specifically address taxonomic status. Crother et al. (2000) briefly commented on the proposal to treat vandenburgianus as a species but retained it as a subspecies of S. graciosus. We follow Grismer (2002) in treating S. vandenburgianus as a species distinct from S. graciosus.

See Sites et al. (1992) for a review of phylogenetic hypotheses for lizards of the genus Sceloporus.

Taxonomy of the Sceloporus grammicus complex has not been fully resolved. The specific and subspecific names currently applied to the taxa in the United States may prove to be incorrect (Crother et al. 2000).

See Upton and Murphy (1997) for a phylogeny of Uta based on mtDNA sequences. These data suggest that U. stansburiana from the islands of Angel de la Guarda, Mejia, and Raza should be recognized as a distinct species. However, Grismer (2002) retained these populations in U. stansburiana.

Subspecies stejnegeri (southeastern Arizona to western Texas and southward into north-central Mexico) was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but Collins did not present supporting data. Stebbins (2003) did not recognize any subspecies.

We follow Grismer (2002) in considering animals on Isla Cedros, formerly considered to be an endemic species U. concinna, as belonging to U. stansburiana.

We follow Grismer (2002) by assigning populations of Uta from Carmen, Danzante, and Coronado Islands in the Gulf of California to the name Uta stansburiana, rather than to the name Uta mannophora Dickerson, 1919, which is presumably a synonym of Uta stansburiana.
The taxonomic status of Anolis adleri is unclear, and it may represent a synonym of Anolis liogaster (Lieb 1981).
The taxonomic status of Anolis baccatus appears to be unclear and requires further investigation (see: Fitch and Henderson 1973,Lieb, 1981, Nieto-Montes de Oca 1996).
Until the recent publication by Lara-Góngora (2004), populations of Sceloporus lemosespinali were included within S. grammicus.
This species is known only from the holotype. It is suspected to be a senior synonym of A. quercorum; further taxonomic work is needed to resolve this issue (G. Santos-Barrera pers. comm.).

Grismer and McGuire (1996) evaluated data on karyotypes, allozymes, and color pattern of populations from Mexico, Arizona, California, and New Mexico. They concluded that the Sceloporus magister complex is composed of three species: S. zosteromus (endemic to Baja California and comprising what was formerly considered S. rufidorsum, S. monserratensis, and S. zosteromus), S. lineatulus (Isla Santa Catalina, Mexico), and S. magister, which was regarded as monotypic. Grismer and McGuire recommended that the several nominal S. magister subspecies be recognized only as informal pattern or convenience classes, not as formal subspecies.
We follow Wiens et al. (1999) in recognizing S. oberon at the species level.

Martinez-Mendez and Mendez-de la Cruz (2007) recommended elevating the subspecies Sceloporus ornatus caeruleus to specific status. These authors noted however that "The phylogenetic relationships of S. o. caeruleus are still not satisfactorily resolved".

Sceloporus undulatus is morphologically highly variable (Stebbins 1985, Conant and Collins 1991, Hammerson 1999). Leaché and Reeder (2002) examined range-wide mtDNA variation and identified at least four apparently monophyletic (but morphologically highly variable) groups, which they proposed as species under the evolutionary species concept (Eastern group: east of Mobile Bay; Central group: east of the Rockies and west of Mobile Bay; Western group: southern Wyoming to central Arizona and northern New Mexico; Southwestern group: eastern Arizona and central New Mexico to northern Mexico and western Texas). All of the groups are discordant with recognized subspecies circumscriptions. For example, the Central group encompasses six nominal subspecies ranging from the foothills of the Rocky Mountains in Colorado to the Gulf Coast of southern Mississippi. Populations of the morphologically distinctive subspecies erythrocheilus in central Colorado grouped with subspecies garmani (Central group) rather than with populations of erythrocheilus in south-central Colorado (Western group). Leaché and Reeder (2002) tentatively proposed the following names: eastern group, S. undulatus; central group, S. consobrinus; western group, S. tristichus; southwestern group, S. cowlesi. However, Leaché and Reeder identified no diagnostic characters for any of the proposed species, and the distributions of proposed species were only coarsely mapped and do not correspond closely with the distributions of previously recognized subspecies, leaving in doubt the specific identities of many Sceloporus populations.

Miles et al. (2002) examined allozyme variation (24 loci from 12 populations, 6 of the 11 recognized subspecies, plus 3 additional species and an outgroup species). Phylogenetic trees were inconsistent with current subspecific designations. Additionally, S. occidentalis, S. virgatus, and S. woodi arose within S. undulatus. The subspecies S. u. hyacithinus and S. u. undulatus are polyphyletic, and S. u. garmani and S. u. tristichus are paraphyletic. Two major lineages were identified: (1) a midwestern grasslands group (includes a population from St. Louis County, Missouri) and (2) various populations from eastern woodlands and western canyonlands.

Further integrated study of morphological and genetic variation, and more detailed genetic examination of various geographic areas, are needed before a well-founded, geographically comprehensive taxonomic revision of the S. undulatus group can be made (e.g., see Niewiarowski et al. 2004).
We follow Grismer (2002) in treating Sceloporus vandenburgianus as a species distinct from S. graciosus.

Based on electrophoretic analyses, Adest (1977) concluded that Uma scoparia, Uma notata, and Uma inornata comprise a single species (Uma notata) (Adest 1977). Stebbins (1985, 2003) maintained the three taxa as distinct species. Phylogenetic relationships inferred from mtDNA sequences indicate that Uma notata rufopunctata is more closely related to Uma inornata than to Uma notata notata (Wilgenbusch and de Queiroz 2000, Trepanier and Murphy 2001). Trepanier and Murphy (2001) concluded that for the northern species of Uma existing data support either a two-species arrangement (Uma scoparia, Uma notata) or five-species classification (Uma scoparia, Uma notata, Uma inornata, and Uma rufopunctata, plus an undescribed species from Mohawk Dunes, Arizona). Trepanier and Murphy prefered the latter arrangement and stated that a description of the Mohawk Dunes species is in progress. Crother et al. (2003) adopted the taxonomy preferred by Trepanier and Murphy.

Based on patterns of morphological variation, Aguirre-L. et al. (1999) and Grismer (1999) concluded that Urosaurus microscutatus is a junior synonym of U. nigricaudus. Crother et al. (2003) adopted this taxonomy and applied the name Baja California Brush Lizard to the single species. Grismer (2002) and Stebbins (2003) called it the Black-tailed Brush Lizard.
We follow Grismer (2002) in treating this as a species distinct from Aspidoscelis hyperythra.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species is a parthenogenetic allotriploid of hybrid origin. Allozyme and mDNA data indicate that C. exsanguis probably arose by the hybridization of C. septemvittatus or C. scalaris with an allodiploid intermediate form (or forms) created by one or more earlier hybridization events involving a male C. inornatus and a female C. costatus or C. burti stictogrammus (see Stuart 1991). Putative similarity to C. flagellicaudus and C. sonorae is overrated according to Frost and Wright (1988). This species formerly was included in other species of the sexlineatus species group. See Stuart (1991) for a review of the nomenclatural history of this species.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species was previously confused with C. exsanguis and C. sonorae (Behler and King 1979). It appears to comprise a complex of groups having different origins through hybridization (Frost and Wright 1988).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species is a parthenogen, derived through hybridization between A. (tigris) marmorata and A. inornata (Frost and Wright 1988, Cole et al. 1988). It exhibits low clonal diversity (Parker and Selander 1984). See Cole et al. (1988) for a discussion of the origin of two atypical electrophoretically distinct clones.

Cnemidophorus perplexus is a senior synonym of A. neomexicana (the lectotype of perplexus evidently is not a hybrid (Taylor and Walker, 1996). To promote nomenclatural stability, Smith et al. (1997), including Walker, proposed to the ICZN that C. neomexicanus be conserved and that Cnemidophorus perplexus be suppressed. This proposal was approved.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Walker et al. (1997) recognized this triploid parthenogen as a distinct species; formerly it was included in C. tesselatus (A. tesselata).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Taxonomy is unstable with respect to whether septemvittata is a species (Forstner et al. 1998) or a subspecies of A. gularis (Walker 1981, Walker et al. 2001) or A. scalaris (Smith et al. 1996, if septemvittata is not included in A. gularis). See Walker et al. (2001) for a detailed discussion of taxonomic uncertainties. Crother et al. (2000, 2003) listed A. septemvittatus as a distinct species that includes scalaris. See Crother et al. (2000) for discussion of their selection of C. septemvittatus (= A. septemvittata) as the proper name when septemvittata, scalaris, and semifasciata are all considered synonyms.

Aspidoscelis septemvittata hybridizes with A. gularis in several areas (Walker 1986, Forstner et al. 1998).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

See Walker et al. (1990) for information on continuing hybridization between A. sexlineata and A. tesselata in Colorado.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus. This species hybridizes (rarely) with A. tigris in southern Arizona (Stebbins 1985). It appears to comprise a complex of groups with different origins through hybridization (Frost and Wright 1988).

MtDNA data suggest an ancient divergence between populations in the north-central Florida peninsula and populations in the south-central peninsula; high genetic distances exist within south-central populations, whereas genetic structure within northern populations is less discrete and characterized by much shallower divergences (Mulvaney et al. 2005). These findings suggest that south-central populations may be candidates for taxonomic recognition (or recognition as distinct management units) if confirmed by additional genetic and morphological data (Mulvaney et al. 2005).

This species formerly was included in the family Amphisbaenidae. Most recent studies recognize four families within Amphisbaenia, with Rhineura floridana as the sole living member of the family Rhineuridae (Kearney 2003). A molecular phylogenetic analysis supports this arrangement (Macey et al. 2004).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).
The subspecies marmoratus is regarded as a distinct species by some authorities, but is retained here as a subspecies following Reeder et al. (2002).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). Mexican species have thus been treated the same way.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

E. brevilineatus and E. callicephalus were treated as subspecies of E. tetragrammus by Lieb (1985, 1990). Tanner (1987) maintained that callicephalus should be retained as a distinct species. Lieb (1990) noted that additional sampling and study of material from Chihuahua is needed to clarify the status of callicephalus. Meanwhile, Crother et al. (2003) listed E. callicephalus as a species, based on allopatry and morphological diagnosability relative to E. brevilineatus and E. callicephalus.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The change has thus been extended to the Mexican species.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species may comprise two or three historical groups of independent origin (Frost and Wright 1988, Cuellar 1977). Further research is needed to determine if A. velox comprises multiple species of different ploidy levels.

Aspidoscelis velox arose through hybridization; parental species were A. inornata and either A. costata or A. burti stictogramma (Moritz et al. 1989).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name has thus also been used for the Mexican species.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name has thus also been used for the Mexican species.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name has thus also been used for the Mexican species.

Subspecies insularis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but no supporting data were presented, and other authors have not adopted this proposal.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Recent phylogenetic analyses using DNA data indicate that the Plestiodon (Eumeces) gilberti morphotype (generally large-bodied and uniformly colored, versus the small-bodied and striped P. skiltonianus morphotype) has arisen independently at least three times (three clades) and that two of the three clades are nested within the geographically more widespread P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). Plestiodon lagunensis of southern Baja California is also nested phylogenetically within P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). A taxonomic revision is therefore warranted, but further study is needed before the species limits within this group can be definitively determined (Richmond and Reeder 2002).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Plestiodon lagunensis is nested phylogenetically within P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). A taxonomic revision therefore is warranted, but further study is needed before the species limits within this group can be definitively determined (Richmond and Reeder 2002).

Stebbins (2003) treated P. lagunensis of southern Baja California as a subspecies of P. skiltonianus whereas Grismer (2002) recognized P. lagunensis as a distinct species (following Grismer 1994).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The Mexican species are thus also treated under this genus.

Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name has thus also been applied to Mexican species.

Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name has thus also been applied to Mexican species.

There has been disagreement over whether the southern subspecies should be called P. m. epipleurotus or P. m. gaigeae (see Hammerson 1999). The name eplipleurotus went long unused but has priority, and a recent informal ICZN evaluation concluded that epipleurotus is the name that should be used (Axtell and Smith 2004). Hammerson (1999) suggested that the variable skink (subspecies epipleurotus) might be a distinct species; genetic study is needed to resolve the question.

This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name is thus also used for Mexican species.

Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name is thus also used for Mexican species.

MtDNA data suggest that colonization of P. septentrionalis into previously glaciated areas was from a single source with restricted gene flow (Fuerst and Austin 2004). Parsimony and maximum likelihood phylogenetic analyses showed reciprocal monophyly between the allopatric northern (P. s. septentrionalis) and southern (P. s. obtusirostris) subspecies (Fuerst and Austin 2004). These results, combined with the morphological differences found in previous studies (Taylor 1935), suggest that these allopatric populations are on separate evolutionary trajectories (Fuerst and Austin 2004). Further sampling of southern populations is needed to elucidate the taxonomic status of the various populations.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Recent phylogenetic analyses using DNA data indicate that the Plestiodon gilberti morphotype (generally large-bodied and uniformly colored, versus the small-bodied and striped P. skiltonianus morphotype) has arisen independently at least three times (three clades) and that two of the three clades are nested within the geographically more widespread P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). Plestiodon lagunensis of southern Baja California is also nested phylogenetically within P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). A taxonomic revision is therefore warranted, but further study is needed before the species limits within this group can be definitively determined (Richmond and Reeder 2002).

Stebbins (2003) treated P. lagunensis of southern Baja California as a subspecies of P. skiltonianus whereas Grismer (2002) recognized P. lagunensis as a distinct species (following Grismer 1994).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Plestiodon brevilineatus and P. callicephalus were treated as subspecies of P. tetragrammus by Lieb (1985, 1990). Lieb (1990) indicated intergradation between tetragrammus and brevilineatus in southern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Dixon (1987) and Conant and Collins (1991) accepted the conspecific relationship between tetragrammus and brevilineatus. Tanner (1987) maintained that callicephalus should be retained as a full species. Lieb (1990) noted that additional sampling and study of material from Chihuahua is needed to clarify the status of callicephalus. Crother et al. (2000) listed P. callicephalus and P. tetragrammus as distinct species, with brevilineatus as a subspecies of P. tetragrammus.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name is thus also used for Mexican species.
This is a species complex that is currently under revision (L. Canseco pers. comm.).

The enigmatic taxon Hombronia fasciolaris was described from material nominally collected from New Zealand by the US Exploring Expedition, which has resulted in continuing confusion regarding its true provenance, the appropriate generic name (the species has most often been included in Leiolopisma), and the identity of the type specimen (Zug 1985). Shea (in prep.) has recently re-examined the known specimen and traced its likely history, finding that it is likely to have been correctly identified as the H. fasciolaris holotype but that it does not correspond to any genus found in regions visited by the US Exploring Expedition but instead falls within the known range of variation of the widespread New World species Scincella lateralis. This author formally synonymized H. fasciolaris within S. lateralis.
The two subspecies of this taxon will be elevated to separate species in the near future (L. Canseco-Márquez pers. comm.).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

The subspecies xanthonota - generally treated as a subspecies of A. burti (e.g., Wright and Lowe 1993) - was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991). No supporting data were presented; the proposed split was based on presumed allopatry and diagnosability. Crother et al. (2000) followed Collins and listed xanthonota as a species distinct from A. burti. Under the genus Cnemidophorus, Stebbins (2003) retained xanthonota as a subspecies of A. burti. We also retain xanthonota within burti, pending clarification of its status. It is unclear whether or not the populations of this species around Guaymas (A. burti burti) are conspecific with A. burti stictogrammus (D. Frost pers. comm.). The populations in the south of the range are A. burti griseocaphalus.
We follow Wright (1993) and Flores-Villela and Canseco-Márquez (2004) in treating Aspidoscelis alpinus as a synonym of this species. However, Aspidoscelis costatus could be a synomym of A. sackii.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Not all authors agree on which populations should be assigned to this species. Aspidoscelis septemvittata is regarded as a species by some (Wright et al. 1983), as a subspecies of A. gularis by others; septemvittata and gularis hybridize in southwestern Texas (Forstner et al. 1998). Crother et al. (2003) listed A. gularis and A. septemvittata as separate species. See Walker (1981, 1986) for discussion of systematic issues. See Walker et al. (1991) for information on hybridization between A. gularis and A. laredoensis.
This is part of a species complex that is currently under revision.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species is a diploid, parthenogenetic species derived from hybridization between A. sexlineata viridis and A. gularis gularis (Wright et al. 1983, Frost and Wright 1988, Abuhteba et al. 2000). It includes two morphotypes (Walker 1986, Frost and Wright 1988, Paulissen et al. 1988); electrophoretic data indicate that the LAR-A morphotype comprises two electromorphs (cryptic clones); the other morphotype (LAR-B) apparently is genetically uniform over its entire range; LAR-A and LAR-B apparently arose from separate hybidization events (Abuhteba et al. 2001), whereas the cryptic clones of LAR-A arose via mutational or recombinational divergence (see Paulissen et al. 1988). See Walker et al. (1989, 1991) for information on hybridization between laredoensis and A. gularis.

Papenfuss et al. (2001) examined genetic and morphological variation of Xantusia and reviewed allozyme data from Bezy and Sites (1987). They concluded that three species are represented in Arizona: Xantusia vigilis, a yucca-dwelling species; X. arizonae, a granite-adapted species; and X. bezyi (newly described), another granite-associated species. Crother et al. (2003) listed X. bezyi and X. vigilis as distinct species but included arizonae as a subspecies of X. vigilis. Stebbins (2003) mentioned the taxonomic changes proposed by Papenfuss et al. but did not adopt them. Sinclair et al. (2004) examined phylogeographic patterns in Xantusia and concluded that X. bezyi is a valid species (but more widely distributed than previously known) and that X. arizonae has a smaller range than previously understood.

authority: Perez-Ramos, Saldana de la Riva & Campbell, 2000

taxonomicNotes: The taxonomic concept of Crotalus mitchellii assessed here, excludes the subspecies angelensis Klauber, 1963 and subspecies muertensis Klauber, 1949; these are both assessed separately as good species.

Analysis of historical biogeography based on mtDNA data (Pook et al. 2000) revealed two main clades, one including populations from east and south of the Rocky Mountains and the other consisting of populations west of the Rocky Mountains. The conventionally recognized subspecies do not fully correspond to the phylogenetic pattern, and a review of the systematic status of several populations is needed (Pook et al. 2000).

Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) examined mtDNA variation among 26 populations of C. viridis and also identified two main clades: eastern, including subspecies viridis and nuntius (low levels of genetic divergence), and western, including all other subspecies. However, Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) differed from Pook et al. (2000) with respect to the relationships among members of the western clade, although Ashton and de Queiroz studied only a few individuals from each member of the western clade and stated that the relationships within the western clade are largely unresolved and that none (except possibly cerberus) appeared to deserve recognition as separate evolutionary species. Ashton and de Queiroz suggested that the two main clades be regarded as distinct species, C. viridis (eastern clade) and C. oreganus (western clade). The historical biogeographic scenario described by Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) suggests secondary contact between C. viridis and C. oreganus in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah.

Douglas et al. (2002) examined mtDNA variation in C. viridis, with emphasis on the populations on the Colorado Plateau. As did Pook et al. (2000) and Ashton and de Queiroz (2001), they identified eastern and western clades, with the former including the nominal subspecies viridis and nuntius and the latter encompassing all of the other subspecies. Douglas et al. (2002) argued that all of the western subspecies should be recognized as species, but they did not effectively indicate details of distributional relationships in the contact zones among the proposed species. Douglas et al. (2002) concluded that the taxon nuntius should be regarded as a synonym of viridis.

Crother et al. (2003) considered all of the foregoing evidence and adopted the two-species taxonomy (Crotalus oreganus, Crotalus viridis) that is supported by the congruence among all three studies cited above. Campbell and Lamar (2004) also recognized only the two species. However, further clarification of the distributions of C. viridis and C. oreganus is needed, particularly in the contact zones in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah. For example, populations in northwestern Colorado (Moffat County) identified by Douglas et al. (2002) as C. viridis were mapped as C. oreganus concolor by Campbell and Lamar (2004).

We follow Crother et al. (2003) and Campbell and Lamar (2004) in recognizing C. oreganus and C. viridis as separate species. In addition subspecies caliginis Klauber, 1949 is also treated separately as a good species.
The taxonomic status of the two subspecies (widely separated populations in the Sierra Madre Occidental and Sierra Madre Oriental) needs to be evaluated (Crother et al. 2000).

Murphy et al. (1995) examined variation in mtDNA, allozymes, and morphology of red diamond rattlesnakes and concluded that Crotalus ruber and C. exsul should be considered a single species (C. exsul) with three subspecies (C. e. exsul, C. e. ruber, and C. e. lorenzoensis. Smith et al. (1998) applied to the ICZN to conserve the name Crotalus ruber for the red diamond rattlesnake by giving the name Crotalus ruber precedence over the name C. exsul. ICZN (2000) gave Crotalus ruber precedence over C. exsul whenever the two names are considered to be synonyms.
This species was first collected in 1941 (Schmidt and Shannon, 1947) but was misidentified as C. triseriatus (Alvarado-Diaz and Campbell, 2004).
This species is treated by some authors (including the Reptile Database) as being synonymous with Crotalus atrox Baird & Girard, 1853.

Analysis of historical biogeography based on mtDNA data (Pook et al. 2000) revealed two main clades, one including populations from east and south of the Rocky Mountains and the other consisting of populations west of the Rocky Mountains. The conventionally recognized subspecies do not fully correspond to the phylogenetic pattern, and a review of the systematic status of several populations is needed (Pook et al. 2000).

Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) examined mtDNA variation among 26 populations of C. viridis and also identified two main clades: eastern, including subspecies viridis and nuntius (low levels of genetic divergence), and western, including all other subspecies. However, Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) differed from Pook et al. (2000) with respect to the relationships among members of the western clade, although Ashton and de Queiroz studied only a few individuals from each member of the western clade and stated that the relationships within the western clade are largely unresolved and that none (except possibly cerberus) appeared to deserve recognition as separate evolutionary species. Ashton and de Queiroz suggested that the two main clades be regarded as distinct species, C. viridis (eastern clade) and C. oreganus (western clade). The historical biogeographic scenario described by Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) suggests secondary contact between C. viridis and C. oreganus in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah.

Douglas et al. (2002) examined mtDNA variation in C. viridis, with emphasis on the populations on the Colorado Plateau. As did Pook et al. (2000) and Ashton and de Queiroz (2001), they identified eastern and western clades, with the former including the nominal subspecies viridis and nuntius and the latter encompassing all of the other subspecies. Douglas et al. (2002) argued that all of the western subspecies should be recognized as species, but they did not effectively indicate details of distributional relationships in the contact zones among the proposed species. Douglas et al. (2002) concluded that the taxon nuntius should be regarded as a synonym of viridis.

Crother et al. (2003) considered all of the foregoing evidence and adopted the two-species taxonomy (Crotalus oreganus, Crotalus viridis) that is supported by the congruence among all three studies cited above. Campbell and Lamar (2004) also recognized only the two species. However, further clarification of the distributions of C. viridis and C. oreganus is needed, particularly in the contact zones in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah. For example, populations in northwestern Colorado (Moffat County) identified by Douglas et al. (2002) as C. viridis were mapped as C. oreganus concolor by Campbell and Lamar (2004). We follow Crother et al. (2003) and Campbell and Lamar (2004) in recognizing C. oreganus and C. viridis as separate species.
This may be a species complex (L. Canseco-Márquez pers. comm.)
Recent analysis suggest that the Central American populations may be different from the South American ones (Castoe et al. 2005).
Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the relationship between this species and Lepidophyma smithi.

Papenfuss et al. (2001) examined genetic and morphological variation of Xantusia and reviewed allozyme data from Bezy and Sites (1987). They concluded that three species are represented in Arizona: Xantusia vigilis, a yucca-dwelling species; X. arizonae, a granite-adapted species; and X. bezyi (newly described), another granite-associated species. Crother et al. (2003) listed X. bezyi and X. vigilis as distinct species but included arizonae as a subspecies of X. vigilis. Stebbins (2003) mentioned the taxonomic changes proposed by Papenfuss et al. but did not adopt them. Sinclair et al. (2004) examined phylogeographic patterns in Xantusia and concluded that X. bezyi is a valid species (but more widely distributed than previously known) and that X. arizonae has a smaller range than previously understood.
Formerly considered a subspecies of X. henshawi (see Lee 1976).

Grismer and Galvan (1986) described Xantusia henshawi gracilis on the basis of morphological, electrophoretic, and ecological differences from other subspecies. Lovich (2001) used mtDNA data to examine the phylogeography of X. henshawi populations in southern California and concluded that the allopatric subspecies Xantusia henshawi gracilis should be recognized as a distinct species, Xantusia gracilis. This conclusion is supported by previously published allozyme data (showing fixed allelic differences) and a compatible historical biogeographical scenario.

Papenfuss et al. (2001) examined genetic and morphological variation of Xantusia and reviewed allozyme data from Bezy and Sites (1987). They concluded that three species are represented in Arizona: Xantusia vigilis, a yucca-dwelling species; X. arizonae, a granite-adapted species; and X. bezyi (newly described), another granite-associated species. Crother et al. (2003) listed X. bezyi and X. vigilis as distinct species but included arizonae as a subspecies of X. vigilis. Stebbins (2003) mentioned the taxonomic changes proposed by Papenfuss et al. but did not adopt them.

Subspecies utahensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but no supporting data were presented. Collins and Taggart (2002) listed utahensis as a subspecies of X. vigilis.
This is a species complex that is currently under revision.

Genetic analyses in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific indicate that nesting populations comprise separate and identifiable stocks that should be treated as separate management units (Bass et al. 1996, Bowen et al. 1996, Bowen and Karl 2007). Hawksbill aggregations on foraging grounds comprise animals from multiple nesting populations and often include animals from distant rookeries (Broderick et al. 1994, Bowen et al. 2007).
Previously, Gallotia simonyi included the subspecies auaritae by Mateo et al. (2001), but Afonso and Mateo (2003) treats this as a full species.
Specimens in the south and southeast require further taxonomic study (Glaw and Vences 2007). The northernmost records might be a hybrid zone with A. madagascariensis.
This species has been confused with the similar Acanthodactylus dumerilii (Trape et al. 2012).

Holaspis laevis has variously been treated as a subspecies of H. guentheri (e.g. Branch 1998, Spawls et al. 2018) or as a full species (e.g. Broadley 2000, Greenbaum et al. 2011, Trape et al. 2012). The latter scheme is now accepted (Arnold 2002) and is followed here.

Holaspis laevis has variously been treated as a subspecies of H. guentheri (e.g. Branch 1998, Spawls et al. 2018) or as a full species (e.g. Broadley 2000, Greenbaum et al. 2011, Trape et al. 2012). The latter scheme is now accepted (Arnold 2002) and is followed here.

The provenance and validity of this species, which is known only from the holotype, is unclear. It is described as originating in Porto Novo in Benin, however it has not been relocated in surveys of this site (J.-F. Trape unpubl. data). Although no formal taxonomic action appears to have been taken, it has been proposed that it may be synonymous with an East African species, putting the reliability of the West African locality in doubt (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2012). It was not included in a recent checklist of reptiles of Benin (Ullenbruch et al. 2010); this was an error of omission (W. Böhme to J.-F. Trape pers. comm.), and not a formal opinion on the validity or provenance of this taxon.
This taxon was previously treated as a subspecies of Tarentola rudis, but was elevated to full species status by Vasconcelos et al. (2012) on the basis of morphological and molecular evidence.

This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Tarentola rudis endemic to Fogo and Brava. Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated to full species status and included the subspecies T. r. hartogi within the new species concept (as the distinct subspecies T. protogigas hartogi), extending the species' range to Rombos Islet.

Until recently, Tarentola rudis was considered a moderately widespread gecko in Cape Verde, where it was represented by five subspecies, including the nominate form (Vasconcelos et al. 2012). Molecular research indicates that this is a polyphyletic grouping, and consequently Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated T. r. boavistensis, T. r. protogigas and T. r. maioensis to species status, leaving a monotypic T. rudis.

Molecular evidence indicates that this recently-described species, which includes records previously assigned to Tarentola darwini, is highly distinct from other Cape Verdean Tarentola (Vasconcelos et al. 2010, 2012).

The traditional concept of Tarentola caboverdiana considered this species endemic to the northern island group in the Cape Verde archipelago, with subspecies recognized for each island within its range (Vasconcelos et al. 2010, 2012). In a full taxonomic revision of Cape Verdean Tarentola, Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated the subspecies raziana, substituta and nicolauensis (the latter previously recognized as belonging to a separate clade by Vasconcelos et al. 2010) to species status, confining T. caboverdiana to Santo Antão.

Molecular research into Cape Verde Tarentola revealed that T. darwini from Santiago differed strongly from the populations from São Nicolau and Fogo, and that the Santiago population itself consisted of two evolutionary significant units (ESUs), one in the north and one in the south of the island (Vasconcelos et al. 2010). Subsequently, following a combined molecular and morphological approach Vasconcelos et al. (2012) formally revised T. darwini, restricting it to Santiago (and encompassing both ESUs), erecting T. bocagei for the São Nicolau form, and T. fogoensis for specimens from Fogo.

Vasconcelos et al. (2010) found on the basis of molecular evidence that Tarentola caboverdiana nicolauensis was not closely-related to other members of the T. caboverdiana group. Subsequently, in a full revision of Cape Verdean Tarentola using both morphological and molecular evidence, Vasconcelos et al. (2012) formally elevated T. nicolauensis to full species status.
Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated this species, previously a subspecies of Tarentola caboverdiana, to full species status on the basis of molecular evidence.
Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated this species, previously a subspecies of Tarentola caboverdiana, to species level based on molecular evidence.

A molecular phylogeny confirmed that Gerrhosaurus flavigularis represents the sister group of the G. nigrolineatus species complex (see G. intermedius account) and sub-structuring of its populations indicated that further investigations are required (Bates et al. 2013).

This species was formerly placed within Gerrhosaurus, but a molecular phylogeny showed that it represents a divergent lineage (Bates et al. 2013). The new, monotypic genus Broadleysaurus was erected to accommodate Gerrhosaurus major. Contrary to the suspicion of Largen and Spawls (2006), who suggested that genetic research may reveal the two recognized subspecies warrant recognition as separate full species, the phylogeny of Bates et al. (2013) did not provide support for Gerrhosaurus m. bottegoi as a distinct subspecies, and these authors synonymized it within B. major.

The taxonomic history of this neglected taxon is discussed by Greenbaum et al. (2006). These authors revalidated it as a species distinct from Chalcides ocellatus, of which it had previously been considered a subspecies.
This species was at one point considered a subspecies of Chalcides thierryi (Trape et al. 2012).
This species is very similar to Chalcides pulchellus, which was formerly considered the western subspecies of this taxon (Trape et al. 2012).

Chioninia nicolauensis was until recently treated as a subspecies of C. fogoensis. Molecular research conducted by Miralles et al. (2010) revealed that the two taxa are not closely-related, and these authors therefore elevated C. nicolauensis to species level.

Miralles et al. (2010) clarified the formerly disputed taxonomy of this species, confirming its validity as a species separate from C. stangeri, and the position of Mabuya (now Chioninia) salensis as a subspecies of C. spinalis. Although these authors refer to their resulting species concept as Chioninia spinalis sensu lato, and determine that the five subspecies they recognize (C. s. spinalis, C. s. salensis, C. s. maioensis, and their newly-described C. s. santiagoensis and C. s. boavistensis) are partially genetically isolated from one another, they indicate that none of these clades warrant specific status.

Molecular evidence indicates the existence of two clades within the traditional species concept of Chioninia fogoensis, one corresponding to the subspecies C. f. antaoensis and C. f. fogoensis, and the other to C. f. nicolauensis (Miralles et al. 2010). These authors elevated the latter taxon to specific level, and investigated the distribution and nomenclatural history of C. f. fogoensis. Miralles et al. (2010) concluded that both the original type locality (Fogo) and records of C. f. fogoensis from São Vicente were in error, and that the best-preserved members of the type series were attributable to the Santo Antão population. C. f. antaoensis is therefore considered a junior synonym of C. f. fogoensis, this latter now considered to have a Santo Antão type locality (Miralles et al. 2010).
Although genetically distinct, this species is morphologically very similar to Cophoscincopus simulans, and the two species co-occur in waterbodies in southeast Guinea (Trape et al. 2012)
This species is genetically distinct from, but morphologically very similar to, Cophoscincus greeri, with which it co-occurs in waterbodies in southeastern Guinea (Trape et al. 2012).

The type locality of this species is unknown; the original description refers to "Liberia, West Coast of Africa" (Hallowell 1852), however, a subsequent reference to this species by the same author (Hallowell, 1857) makes no mention of this country. This latter reference refers to "Habitat: Gaboon", taken by later authors (e.g. Schmidt 1919) to refer to Gabon. This interpretation is thought to be in error, and the species is not listed for Gabon by Pauwels and vande Weghe (2008). The species is however not considered to occur in West Africa (Trape et al. 2012), and Liberia is not included in the only recent characterization of the species' full distribution (Chirio and LeBreton 2007).
This may represent a complex of more than one species (L. Chirio pers. comm. 2019).

East African and eastern-central African populations previously attributed to this species were described as a new species, Lepidothyris hinkeli, by Wagner et al. (2009), who resurrected the genus Lepidothyris.

This species was only recently recognized as distinct from the former Mochlus (= Lygosoma) fernandi species complex (Wagner et al. 2009). These authors described the species to encompass East and Central African populations east of Gabon, and assigned the three members of the former M. fernandi complex to the resurrected genus Lepidothyris.

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopa (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus - type species: Mochlus afer - as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. Mochlus afer is therefore the appropriate name for the species referred to in older literature as Lygosoma afrum.

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner et al. (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however, these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009; P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).
This taxon is currently comprised of at least two distinct species.

Fuhn (1964) synonymized Ablepharus anselli within Panaspis tancredi; accepting this, Jacobsen and Broadley (2000) also formally synonymized A. moeruensis and A. seydeli within this species based on the types' possession of identical scale characters. Largen and Spawls (2006) dispute this on geographical grounds given the wide distances between the known localities and the lack of evidence for populations between these areas. This issue does not seem to have been investigated subsequently, however Largen and Spawls (2010) report that P. tancredi is known only from the holotype. Medina et al. (2016) were unable to clarify the relationship between P. tancredi and P. seydeli in the absence of confirmed material of the former, but on the basis of their results consider A. anselli and A. moruensis to be junior synonyms of a distinct P. seydeli as previously proposed by Broadley and Cotterill (2004). These authors caution that better sampling may reveal that these taxa warrant recognition as distinct species.

This widespread taxon could be a species complex (Trape et al. 2012). These authors indicate that Trachylepis paucisquamis, for which they provide a separate species account, is probably a junior synonym of T. affinis, and this scheme is followed here pending resolution of relationships within this taxon. Central African populations are likely to represent an undescribed species.

West African records of this Central African skink represent confusion with Trachylepis aureogularis (Trape et al. 2012), a name these authors resurrected to apply to populations from Guinea to Ghana.

This taxon was described as a variant of Trachylepis perrotetti and subsequently recognized as a subspecies of this form. Re-examining the two 1921 syntypes, Böhme et al. (2011) concluded that they represented a distinct species belonging to the T. buettneri/sudanensis species group, and resurrected the name T. keranoanensis.

The Reptile Database presently treats Trachylepis infralineata from Europa Island as a distinct species, apparently based on a personal communication, but genetic data (Rocha et al. 2010) suggests that it should be regarded as a junior synonym of T. maculilabris. It has subsequently been included as a subspecies of T. maculilabris (Sanchez et al. 2019).

Trape et al. (2012) indicate that this taxon is a complex of at least four forms likely to warrant recognition as either full species or subspecies; presently only two subspecies, Trachylepis perrotetii perotetti and T. p. upembae, are recognized, with the latter considered a distinct species by Broadley and Cotteril (2004). An additional form, T. keroanensis, is treated here as a distinct species following its elevation by Böhme et al. (2011).

Broadley and Cotteril (2004) note that the Tanzanian subspecies Amblyodipsas katangensis ionidesi "should probably be regarded as a sister species", but no formal taxonomic action has been taken to elevate this taxon to specific status.
The taxonomic validity of the subspecies Amblyodipsas polylepis hildebrantii which occurs in East Africa has yet to be assessed using molecular techniques.

Lanza (1990) opines that the then-recognized subspecies Aparallactus jacksonii oweni "very probably" warrants recognition as a full species. No subsequent work appears to have investigated this issue, and although Wallach et al. (2014) report Lanza's suggestion these authors do not comment on it. A. j. oweni is presently considered a junior synonym of A. j. jacksonii (Wallach et al. 2014).

Segniagbeto et al. (2011) examined a specimen from Sansane Mangu in Togo originally identified as Aparallactus bocagii (now a subspecies of the southeastern African A. capensis), and found that it represented A. lunulatus, validating a synonymy first proposed by Loveridge (1944) within the species then known as A. liddiardae. Segniagbeto et al. (2011) found no support for the suggestion by de Witte and Laurent (1947) that taxa these authors synonymized within A. lunulatus (including A. liddiardae) might warrant subspecific status. The validity of a recognized subspecies from Somalia, A. l. scortecci, is "uncertain" (Lanza 1990). A full taxonomic revision of this species is warranted to clarify the status of the three presently-recognized subspecies, A. l. lunulatus, A. l. scortecci and A. l. nigrocollaris.
No notable taxonomic issues, although it relation to the rest of Aparallactus complex needs to be investigated.

Following Laurent (1950), this species has been considered a junior synonym of Atractaspis micropholis, itself treated by this author as a subspecies of the wide-ranging A. microlepidota, which was understood to occur through West, Central and East Africa. Trape et al. (2006) redescribed A. watsoni, finding it to be morphologically distinct from A. microlepidota and A. micropholis, the latter elevated to full species status in this treatment. In the revision, the majority of A. microlepidota records were assigned to A. watsoni, which was described as ranging eastwards to Sudan. These authors also examined the holotype of A. nigra, a synonym of A. microlepidota, and confirmed its synonymy with A. watsoni.

Unfortunately, in their revision Trape et al. (2006) did not consider records east of Sudan, although the traditional concept of A. microlepidota ranges into East Africa as far as Eritrea and southeastern Kenya, and into the Arabian Peninsula. David and Vogel (2010) note that, by implication, the Arabian subspecies A. m. andersonii was elevated to full species status by this treatment. These authors support this assignment by comparing this form with the taxa described by Trape et al. (2006); although they do not detail the results of this comparison, they indicate that A. andersonii is distinct from all three West African species. East African records of "A. microlepidota" remain of uncertain taxonomic status, although Trape et al. (2006) report that they are not conspecific with the holotype of A. microlepidota. East African, Somali and southern Ethiopian records are here treated as belonging to Atractaspis fallax, previously a subspecies of A. microlepidota and treated as a full species by Largen and Spawls (2010), and this scheme has also been adopted by Spawls et al. (2018). Remaining records from eastern Africa are provisionally considered to represent A. watsoni (P. David pers. comm. June 2012) until the taxonomy of eastern African populations is resolved.
A proposed assignment of this species to Charina (Kluge 1993) has not subsequently been widely accepted, but is used in a number of subsequent sources (e.g. McDiarmid et al. 1999, Chippaux 2006).

The validity of the generic name Gongylophis has been subject to some dispute (briefly summarized by Lanza and Nistri 2005). This genus is now generally considered a junior synonym of Eryx (as tentatively followed by Lanza and Nistri 2005) (Noonan and Chippindale 2006). This is supported by the phylogeny of Noonan and Chippindale (2006), which recovered species of Gongylophis (conicus and colubrinus) nested within Eryx.

The validity of the generic name Gongylophis has been subject to some dispute (briefly summarized by Lanza and Nistri 2005). This genus is now generally considered a junior synonym of Eryx (as tentatively followed by Lanza and Nistri 2005) (Noonan and Chippindale 2006). This is supported by the phylogeny of Noonan and Chippindale (2006), which recovered species of Gongylophis (conicus and colubrinus) nested within Eryx.
Schätti and Trape (2008) erected the new genus Bamanophis for this species, which had previously been placed in Haemorrhois.
Following its original description, this species was long forgotten until redescribed, as Crotaphopeltis acarina (now a junior synonym), by Roman in 1974.
Although this species has a wide distribution in sub-Saharan Africa, a phylogeographic analysis suggests this is a single taxon (Engelbrecht 2017).

Gravlund (2002) found a high level of genetic diversity within Crotaphopeltis tornieri, with a sample of C. hotamboeia from the Mount Rungwe nested between C. tornieri from the same locality and specimens from other mountains. Support for this arrangement was weak, and consequently this author refrained from suggesting taxonomic changes, but the relationship between these two species (and within C. tornieri itself) remains in need of clarification.

This species was formerly part of the Dasypeltis scabra species complex, having long been considered a junior synonym of D. scabra, but was resurrected by Trape and Mané (2006) based on differences between the holotype and other Ethiopian specimens. Unfortunately, these authors did not characterize the species' distribution, which was subsequently clarified by Bates and Broadley (2018).

Bates and Broadley (2018) discuss the history of the name Dasypeltis lineolata Peters, 1878, and conclude that, as there appears to have been only a single literature reference to this name since 1899 (Saleh and Sarhan 2016), it does not meet the conditions for being considered a senior synonym for D. atra Sternfield, 1912. These authors elect to continue using the more widely-recognized name D. atra to preserve taxonomic stability and report that a petition has been filed with the ICZN to suppress the older name.

This species was recently recognized as a species distinct from Dasypeltis scabra (Trape and Mané 2006b), a conclusion supported by combined morphological and molecular analysis (Trape et al. 2012). Is distribution is likely to be incompletely known as a result of confusion with this species (Segniagbeto et al. 2011).

This species was recently recognized as a species distinct from Dasypeltis scabra (Trape and Mané 2006b), a conclusion supported by combined morphological and molecular analysis (Trape et al. 2012). Its distribution is likely to be incompletely known as a result of confusion with this species (Segniagbeto et al. 2011). Trape and Mané (2006b) recognized two subspecies, D. g. gansi and D. g. latericia; the latter was elevated to a full species by Trape et al. (2012).

Dasypeltis medici lamuensis is a junior synonym of D. medici (Bates and Broadley 2018). The taxonomic status, particularly in terms of the recently synonymised subspecies Dasypeltis medici lamuensis, requires further investigation.
This species was recently recognized as a species distinct from Dasypeltis scabra (Trape and Mané 2006b), a conclusion supported by combined morphological and molecular analysis (Trape et al. 2012).

Dipsadoboa weileri, which as currently defined has a heavily-disjunct distribution in West, Central and western East Africa, is very similar to D. unicolor, differing in the colouration of the tail (Spawls et al. 2018). Records from Mt. Nimba in Guinea and from Togo now assigned to this species were formerly attributed to D. unicolor, although the occurrence of true D. unicolor in Guinea (including the Mt. Nimba area) has been confirmed and a historical record from Togo is accepted (Segniagbeto et al. 2011, Böhme et al. 2011). Records of the two species across their ranges are likely to have been confused, but it is unknown which existing records of D. unicolor represent this species and which D. weileri (J. Penner pers. comm. 2013).
The type locality New Caledonia is in error (Chippaux 2006).

This species as currently defined has a heavily-disjunct distribution in West, Central and western East Africa. This taxon is very similar to Dipsadoboa unicolor, differing in the colouration of the tail (Spawls et al. 2002), and records from Guinea and Togo now assigned to this species were formerly attributed to D. unicolor (Segniagbeto et al. 2011, Bohme et al. 2011). Records of the two species are likely to have been confused across their ranges, but it is unknown which existing records of D. unicolor represent this species and which D. weileri (J. Penner pers. comm. 2013).
Recent records of this species from the Nguru Mountains and Udzungwa Scarp Forest are thought likely to represent an undescribed species (M. Menegon pers. comm. 2014).

Loveridge (1955) indicates that records of Meizodon coronatus from South Sudan are referable to M. regularis, a view supported by Schätti (1985). A subsequent record of M. coronatus from the Imatong Mountains (Friis and Rasmussen 1981) may also represent M. regularis, however, this specimen is not available for examination and its identity is consequently uncertain (K. Ullenbruch pers. comm. 2013).

Molecular sampling of Philothamnus using three mitochondrial and two nuclear markers recovered two distinct clades within Philothamnus carinatus (Engelbrecht et al. 2019), which these authors identified as candidate species. Engelbrecht et al. (2019) caution that no samples were available from Cameroon, between the ranges of the two clades, and that further research is needed incorporating samples from this area to clarify whether they are specifically distinct.

In a molecular analysis of Philothamnus (Engelbrecht et al. 2019), two of three species delimitation methods suggested that the recognized subspecies P. nitidus loveridgei is a junior synonym of P. n. loveridgei. These authors nevertheless refrained from taking taxonomic action pending further research, as only two specimens of P. n. loveridgei were included in analysis.
This species has three subspecies, and it is possible that these may represent full species (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2014). Subspecies Rhamnophis aethiopissa aethiopissa is found in Gabon.
There are currently two recognized subspecies, namely Telescopus semiannulatus semiannulatus and T. s. polystictus.

Crochet et al. (2008) addressed confusion surrounding the identity of this and the related species Telescopus obtusus and T. dhata, confirming that all three represent distinct species and that T. dhara is absent from West Africa. These authors confirmed that T. tripolitanus represents a valid name, rendering the replacement name T. guidimakaensis a junior synonym, and synonymized the poorly-known Tunisian form Pseudotarbohis gabesi (incorrectly, P. gabesiensis) with T. tripolitanus.
This taxon was elevated to species level (from a subspecies of Thelotornis capensis) by Broadley (2001).
Thrasops schmidti was elevated to specific status by Broadley and Wallach (2002) on morphological and biogeographical grounds, having previously been considered a subspecies of T. jacksonii.

Toxicodryas is the name applied to African species formerly included within the predominantly Asian genus Boiga. This scheme, introduced by Welch (1982), has since been followed by various authors (e.g. Trape and Mané 2006, Uetz and Hallerman 2010), but rejected by others on the basis that a formal revision of Boiga is necessary to validate this arrangement (Segniagbeto et al. 2011). Recent molecular research indicates Boiga is paraphyletic with respect to Toxicodryas and related African genera (Pyron et al. 2013), and for consistency with common usage of these other generic names, Toxicodryas is used here as a valid genus pending a revision of Boiga.

Toxicodryas is the name applied to African species formerly included within the predominantly Asian genus Boiga. This scheme, introduced by Welch (1982), has since been followed by various authors (e.g. Trape and Mané 2006, Uetz and Hallerman 2010), but rejected by others on the basis that a formal revision of Boiga is necessary to validate this arrangement (Segniagbeto et al. 2011).
