Recent molecular research indicates Boiga is paraphyletic with respect to Toxicodryas and related African genera (Pyron et al. 2013), and for consistency with common usage of these other generic names, Toxicodryas is used here as a valid genus pending a revision of Boiga.

Populations from the southern part of the range (South Africa and southern Mozambique) differ genetically from Tanzanian specimens (Pook et al. 2005). Because Dendroaspis angusticeps was described from specimens collected from KwaZulu-Natal and Maputo (Mozambique), northern populations may require a new specific ranks if genetic differences are found to be at the species level. Some authors informally treated northern populations as Dendroaspis intermedius (see Broadley and Blaylock 2013, Wallach et al. 2014). However, further work is needed within a phylogenetic framework, as is additional sampling that covers the range of both northern and southern populations.
Previously treated as a subspecies of Elapsoidea semiannulata (Broadley 1971, 1990), but later revived as a full species (Broadley 1998).

.An analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear gene sequences plus morphological data (Wüster et al. 2018) has solved the long-standing uncertainty surrounding the Naja melanoleuca ‘species complex’. This is now shown  to contain five distinct species: a more restricted N. melanoleuca; N. guineensis (western Africa); N. savannula (savanna parts of western and central Africa); N. peroescobari (endemic to the island of São Tomé); and N. subfulva (central to northeast and Africa and southwards to Angola in the west and South Africa in the east).

This species was transferred from Lamprophis to Boaedon by Kelly et al. (2011). Based on morphological differences across this snake's range it is thought to represent a species complex, with several cryptic species occurring under this name in Central Africa (Segniagbeto et al. 2011). Boaedon angolensis, a "long forgotten" name described as a variety of B. lineatus and subsequently either neglected or treated as a junior synonym of either B. lineatus or B. fuliginosus, is treated as a full species by Marques et al. (2018) and Butler et al. (2019). The status of this taxon and other Angolan records of Boaedon is presently under review (Hallerman et al. unpublished, referenced in Butler et al. 2019).

This species has historically been confused with the Lamprophis (=Boaedon) fuliginosus species complex (Hughes 1997), although it is"without any doubt" a validly distinct species (Lanza 1978). Hughes (1997) does not treat the "maculatus" form in detail, but shows a wide range in Somalia and Ethiopia with isolated records in Kenya and Tanzania. Spawls et al. (2018) elect to retain all members of the Boaedon fuliginosus complex in East Africa within B. fuliginosus pending a full taxonomic revision. Pending further data to resolve the taxonomy and distribution of this and related species, and because Hughes (1997) did not explicitly justify the assignment of the name B. maculatus to East African or Ethiopian material, this assessment follows Spawls et al. (2018) in referring East African material to Boaedon fuliginosus pending further research, and Largen and Spawls (2010) in considering the species' occurrence in Ethiopia as unconfirmed.
This species was transferred from Lamprophis to Boaedon by Kelly et al. (2011).

Chippaux (2006) considers that the elevation of Bothrophthalmus brunneus to full species by Roux-Estève (1965) is not justified, on the basis that the two taxa differ only in colouration and exhibit identical scalation, and consequently treats it as the subspecies B. lineatus brunneus. This account follows the majority of more recent authors in treating B. brunneus as a separate species (e.g. Vidal et al. 2008, Kelly et al. 2011).

The need to clarify the validity of Chamaelycus werneri - which is distinguished from Chamaelycus fasciatus based on a single scale character which is "probably not a stable condition" and is variable within the genus (O. Pauwels pers. comm. 2019) - was recognized as early as Angel (1934). Both Bogert (1940) and Knoeppfler (1966) (who collected the only material assigned to C. werneri since it was described) considered that this character was likely to represent variation within C. fasciatus. Multiple authors have since considered the two taxa conspecific either explicitly or by implication, and most recently Chippaux and Jackson (2019) proposed treating C. werneri as a junior synonym of C. fasciatus.
This species was transferred to Gonionotophis from Mehelya by Kelly et al. (2011) and then to Limaformosa by Broadley et al. (2018).

Broadley et al. (2018) provisionally referred this species to the resurrected Mehelya based on morphological similarities, but it was not included in these authors' genetic analysis and these authors recommended phylogenetic analysis to resolve its status.
Kelly et al. (2011) reassigned this species from Mehelya to Goniotophis and then Broadley et al. (2018) reassigned it back to Mehelya.

Broadley (1991) elevated Lycophidion multimaculatum to full species status, from a subspecies of L. capense. This action was unfortunately neglected by Spawls et al. (2002), who retained this form within their concept of L. multimaculatum.

In his revision of southern African Lycophidion, Broadley (1996) stated that records of L. semiannule from Zambia and Zimbabwe had been erroneously assigned to this species, and referred most remaining records of this species to the resurrected L. acutirostre. This act confined L. semiannule to Benguerua Island in southern Mozambique (Broadley 1996).
This species was assigned from Leptotyphlops to Myriopholis by Adalsteinsson et al. (2009).
This species was assigned from Leptotyphlops to Myriopholis by Adalsteinsson et al. (2009).

This species was assigned from Leptotyphlops to Myriopholis by Adalsteinsson et al. (2009). This species has been treated as a subspecies of Myriopholis narirostris, but full species status was proposed by Trape and Mané (2000) based on morphological differences and has since been followed by other authors (e.g. Padial 2006). Leptotyphlops debilis was synonymized with this form by Hahn and Wallach (1998).

Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) reassigned this species from Leptotyphlops to Rhinoleptus, a genus otherwise known only from the West African R. koniagui. Boundy (2013) disputes this assignment and refers the species instead to Myriopholis.
Previously treated as a subspecies of Natriciteres variegata, but treated as a full species by Spawls et al. (2002) and Broadley et al. (2003).

Segniagbeto et al. (2011) report that Trape and Mané (2006) revalidated this species (which Segniagbeto et al. 2011 list under the spelling Prosymna gregerti), which had previously been considered a variant of P. meleagris. The description of this form given by Trape and Mané (2006), however, is incomplete, as it indicates that unnamed subspecies occur outside the region treated in their guide but presents no descriptions of these. Chirio et al. (2011) subsequently reviewed P. meleagris and P. greigerti, presenting full descriptions and clarifying the distributions of these taxa. These authors recognized two subspecies of P. greigerti: P. g. greigerti, known from West Africa and from scattered records in Central and northeast Africa (with an eastern range limit in Ethiopia), and P. g. collaris from Sudano-Sahelian West Africa east to western Chad (with a single highly disjunct record from eastern Sudan).

Trape and Mané (2006) revalidated P. greigerti, previously considered a variant of P. meleagris, an action which removed P. meleagris from most of northern West Africa and from areas east of Nigeria. Subsequently, Chirio et al. (2011) formally redescribed both P. meleagris and P. greigerti.
Hemirhagerrhis viperina from north-central Namibia was previously considered a subspecies of H. nototaenia (Branch 1998).
This species has long been included in the genus Dromophis, which was synonymized with Psammophis based on the molecular findings of Kelly et al. (2008).

This taxon is likely to represent a species complex, the taxonomy of which is unresolved (Akani et al. 2003), and it has long been unclear whether Central African populations are attributable to this species (Trape and Mané 2006). In a revision of the Psammophis sibilans group Trape et al. (2019) clarified that the subspecies P. occidentalis should be recognized as a junior synonym of a distinct P. mossambicus (which Kelly et al. 2008 had previously suggested may be a junior synonym of a P. phillipsi). Trape et al. (2019) further found that Psammophis irregularis is genetically almost indistinguishable from typical P. phillipsi and that this name should be considered a junior synonym of P. phillipsi.

This species is commonly referred to as Dromophis praeornatus (e.g. Trape and Mané 2006, list of usages in Uetz and Hallerman 2010); this account follows Uetz and Hallerman (2010) and Segniagbeto et al. (2011) in assigning this species to Psammophis.

Based on an examination of the holotype, Broadley (1977) synonymized this taxon, previously treated as a subspecies of Psammophis subtaeniatus, with P. sibilans sibilans. The validity of P. sudanensis has subsequently been uncertain. Spawls et al. (2002) tentatively elect to recognize it as a valid species, and this is supported by a subsequent re-examination of the holotype by D.G. Broadley, which suggests that it is "probably" valid (Kelly et al. 2008). The distribution of the resurrected species is however somewhat unclear given its long history as either a subspecies or synonym of other taxa.

In their revision of the Psammophis sibilans group, Trape et al. (2019) confirmed on the basis of morphological and molecular evidence that P. sudanensis warrants specific status. This analysis supported the opinion of Hughes (1999) that Psammophis leucogaster, variously considered a junior synonym or subspecies of P. sudanensis or as a subspecies of P. rukwae, is a junior synonym of P. sudanensis.

This revision may not have fully resolved the taxonomy of P. sudanensis, as genetic data suggests that East African populations may be distinct from those in West Africa despite similar morphology (Trape et al. 2019).

Kelly et al. (2008) transferred this species from Rhamphiophis to Psammophylax. The status of P. togoensis, which has been considered either a subspecies of Psammophylax acutus (Chippaux 2006, Kelly et al. 2008) or a full species (Chirio and LeBreton 2007, Segniagbeto et al. 2011), is uncertain. Segniagbeto et al. (2011) investigate this issue and determine that available material is insufficient to clarify its appropriate taxonomic status with certainty, but conclude based on their examination of the available material that consistent morphological differences exist which justify treating P. togoensis as a separate species. Records of P. acutus from West Africa are here considered to represent P. togoensis.

This species has been considered as either a subspecies of Psammophylax acutus (Chippaux 2006, Kelly et al. 2008) or a full species (Chirio and LeBreton 2007, Segniagbeto et al. 2011). These latter authors indicate that available material is insufficient to clarify its appropriate taxonomic status, but based on their examination of the available material consistent morphological differences exist which justify treating P. togoensis as a separate species. Records of P. acutus from West Africa are here considered to represent P. togoensis. The species is now placed in the genus Kladirostratus (Keates et al. 2019).

Several authors (Spawls et al. 2002, Kelly et al. 2008) consider the northern form of this species, Psammophylax variabilis multisquamis, a full species. No justification has been provided for this assignment. Largen and Spawls (2010) note that no convincing argument has yet been made to justify treating P. v. multisquamis as a full species, but caution that P. variabilis as presently understood may nonetheless be a complex of three or four species.

Specific status for Rhamphiophis oxyrhynchus rostratus was suggested by Parker (1949), and supported by Loveridge (1955, who nonetheless retained the trinomial pending further research). Despite this, literature treatments have been inconsistent, with Largen and Rasmussen (1993) and Ineich (2001) continuing to treat it as a subspecies. Rhamphiophis rostratus has been treated as a full species in most recent literature (e.g. Kelly et al. 2008, Largen and Spawls 201, Spawls et al. 2018) and this arrangement is supported by molecular data (Vidal et al. 2008).

The southern African taxon Python sebae natalensis was elevated to full species status by Broadley (1999). A phylogenetic analysis (K. A. Tolley, Unpublished data 2019) supports the treatment of P. natalansis and P. sebae as full species.

The southern African taxon Python sebae natalensis was elevated to full species status by Broadley (1999). A phylogenetic analysis (K. A. Tolley, Unpublished data 2019) supports the treatment of P. natalensis and P. sebae as full species.

Reynolds et al. (2014) proposed placing Apodora papuana within the large Australasian python genus Liasis. This placement, it has since been argued (Barker et al. 2015), is difficult to reconcile with significant differences in head morphology between Apodora and Liasis, and the appropriate taxonomic assignment consequently remains unclear.

Broadley and Wallach (2009) assigned this species, formerly in Typhlops, to the newly-erected genus Afrotyphlops. These authors also revalidated four of the five species synonymized within T. lineolatus by Roux-Estève (1974), and elevated the subspecies T. l. tanganicanus to full species status. Taxonomic issues may remain, as Broadley and Wallach (2009) did not consider West African (nominate) populations, and L. Chirio (pers. comm. 2012) suggests that those east of central Nigeria may not be conspecific with West African A. lineolatus.

Broadley and Wallach (2009) assigned this species, formerly in Typhlops, to the newly-erected genus Afrotyphlops. There are morphological differences between specimens from the majority of this snake's range and those from the more humid Basse Casamance (Senegal) and southern Mali, and the status of this form is uncertain (Trape and Mané 2006). Broadley and Wallach (2009) presented a short description of this species, which excluded localities attributed to A. liberiensis , formerly a subspecies of A. punctatus. These authors did not discuss A. liberiensis beyond assigning it to this new genus, so the basis for the implied elevation to species level is unclear. Böhme et al. (2011) describe the taxonomic assignment of "Typhlops liberiensis" as "not yet stable".
This species was reassigned from Rhinotyphlops to the resurrected genus Letheobia by Broadley and Wallach (2007).
It seems plausible that this is a complex of several species that requires additional taxonomic study.

Molecular studies have indicated that the disjunct South African subpopulation is not substantially divergent from subpopulations to the north (W. Wüster and A. Barlow unpubl. data, 2007). The South African subpopulation is also morphologically similar to the closest subpopulation in Zimbabwe/Mozambique (e.g. Broadley 1990). The lack of genetic differentiation suggests that Bitis gabonica once had a large and continuous distribution that was fragmented only relatively recently, resulting in various isolated subpopulations such as the one in southern Africa. This subpopulation should be considered regionally important in terms of the overall conservation of the species and the maintenance of genetic variability. Bitis rhinoceros of West Africa is now treated as a full species and not a subspecies of B. gabonica, rendering the latter monotypic (Lenk et al. 2001).
It seems possible that this is a complex of at least four species, with further taxonomic studies recommended.

Trape and Mané (2006) considered the validity of this species unclear, and proposed synonymizing it within Echis ocellatus. This proposal was rejected by Pook et al. (2009), who found molecular evidence for a distinct lineage corresponding to E. jogeri, and this account therefore treats E. jogeri as a valid species.
Populations from Central Africa have been assigned to Echis romani by Trape (2018).
Gongylomorphus fontenayi was previously treated as a subspecies of G. bojeri.

Zug (1998) revalidated the name Gymnodactylus cheverti Boulenger, 1885 for bisexual records of the Nactus pelagicus complex found in the southern Cape York Peninsula. N. cheverti is itself a species complex whose taxonomy is presently under investigation (C. Hoskin and P. Couper, in prep.)

authority: Ratsoavina, Louis Jr., Crottini, Randrianiana, Glaw & Vences, 2011
taxonomicNotes: A small Uroplatus from Montagne d'Ambre has long been recognized as likely to be distinct from U. ebenaui based on morphological differences (Glaw and Vences 1994), and molecular evidence has supported this view (Greenbaum et al. 2007, Raxworthy et al. 2008). Ratsoavina et al. (2011) investigated the status of "U. ebenaui" in the national park, finding additional molecular evidence for the specific status of the atypical form, and formally described it as a new species.

Wagner et al. (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however, these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). Freitas et al. (2019) subsequently formally proposed this arrangement.

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner et al. (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however, these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner et al. (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however, these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).
Because this species was described relatively recently, it is often referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura palearis or Enyaliosaurus palearis, the sister species that it was split from.

Chilabothrus schwartzi is a recently elevated boa species (Reynolds et al. 2018). The species was originally described as Epicrates chryogaster schwartzi by Donald W. Buden in 1975 based on four type specimens collected by locals on Crooked and Acklins islands. Individuals were not recorded again in the literature (and no additional specimens were secured) until Reynolds et al. (2018) recorded four individuals on Crooked Island in 2017. Subsequent analyses of DNA, morphology, and comparison with the types by Reynolds et al. (2018) provided support for the elevation of the lineage to the specific level within the West Indian endemic genus Chilabothrus on the basis of diagnostic and divergent morphological and genetic characters.
Until recently this species was considered a subspecies of Epicrates cenchria, but was elevated to species status by Passos and Fernandes (2008).
Three subspecies are recognized: Chilabothrus f. fordii (Günther, 1861), C. f. agametus (Sheplan & Schwartz, 1974) and C. f. manototus (Schwartz, 1979) (see Reynolds et al. 2018).

This species was described as Rhynchonyx ambiniger; upon transfer to the feminine genus Apostolepis the specific epithet was emended to ambinigra by Boulenger (1896). This was considered an unjustified emendation by Peters and Donoso-Barros (1970), and subsequently both forms of the name have been used by recent authors (e.g. ambiniger - Cacciali et al. 2016, Uetz et al. 2018; ambinigra - Wallach et al. 2014, Nogueira 2018).

This species was described from São Paolo State in Brazil, far from any subsequent records, and the attribution of material away from the type locality to this species has long been uncertain. The same specimens from Asunción in Paraguay were attributed by Boulenger to both A. dorbignyi (Boulenger 1894) and A. ambiniger (Boulenger 1896). The latter scheme has since been accepted, and records of A. dorbignyi from Paraguay appear to be errors based on the earlier paper (Cacciali et al. 2016), but no work appears to have formally attempted to resolve the taxonomy of this species.

Until recently the Brazilian holotype, which is thought to have been lost, was the only known specimen of this species, although it was included in historical checklists for Paraguay following Bertoni (1914). The assignment of recent material from a second Brazilian locality (Albuquerque and de Lema 2012) and Paraguay (Cacciali et al. 2016) to this species is therefore provisional pending further taxonomic research into this poorly-known taxon (Cacciali et al. 2016).

De Lema and Albuquerque (2010) placed Apostolepis quinquelineata Boulenger, 1896  in synonymy of A. nigrolineatus (Peters, 1896); although this scheme has not been universally adopted (e.g. Curcio et al. 2011, Starace 2013) it is now generally accepted (Borges-Nojosa et al. 2016) and is followed here. Curcio et al. (2011) also assigned A. pymi and A. rondoni to the synonymy of A. nigrolineatus.
De Lema and Renner (2016) redescribed this species, formally removing Apostolepis borellii from its synonymy.

This species was synonymized within Apostolepis assimilis within a year of its description (Ferrarezi et al. 2005) on the basis that the described characters fell within the latter species' range of variation. These authors did not, however, examine the holotype of A. tertullianobeui, and following a subsequent comparison of the holotypes of the two species, Lema and Renner (2007) revalidated it. This was not followed in the checklist by Wallach et al. (2014) but was accepted by Costa and Bérnils (2015), who determined that A. parassimilis represents a junior synonym of A. tertullianobeui. The validity of this species remains in question (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020); and is considered doubtful, but it is accepted as valid in a recent atlas to Brazilian snakes (Nogueira et al. 2019).

The identity of two records from Santa Cruz in Bolivia, assigned to this species by Harvey (1999), based on two specimens that these authors acknowledged differ from the holotype, remains uncertain. Entiauspe and Lema (2015) concluded that these represented Apostolepis christineae based on photographs of the museum specimens, but did not examine the specimens to confirm this identification and A. christineae is so far known with certainty only from the Brazilian type locality. Pending direct examination of the specimens it is considered speculative to assign these records to either species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), and they are consequently excluded from this assessment.

The most recent treatment of this species is that of Hoogmoed (1980), who considered that the previously-described range of this species, which extended through much of South America east of the Andes and south as far as Argentina, was likely to represent a species complex. Although this author indicated that a full evaluation of records assigned to this species throughout South America was necessary to resolve the taxonomy of this form, no such revision appears to have been attempted. Pending clarification on the taxonomy of this species, this account considers only records confirmed by Hoogmoed (1980) as representing A. badius.
This species is presumably a species complex.

Passos et al. (2010) discussed the taxonomic history of Atractus paraguayensis and uncertainty about its range limits in Argentina, as following Williams and Gudynas (1991) and subsequent authors, Argentine and southern Brazilian records had been attributed to A. taeniatus. Passos et al. (2010) compared data from the holotypes of A. paraguayensis and A. taeniatus and concluded that Argentine and Brazilian records previously attributed to A. taeniatus in fact represent A. paraguayensis. Giraudo et al. (2012) subsequently argued that in Argentina, the name A. paraguayensis should be restricted to populations from northwest of Corrientes, which Giraudo and Scrocchi (2000) had found to be distinct from A. taeniatus, and that records from Misiones, Corrientes and Entre Rios included within A. paraguayensis by Passos et al. (2010) instead represent an indeterminate species, for which these authors use the name "Atractus sp."

Passos et al. (2010) synonymized Atractus kangueryensis within A. thalesdelemai, based on their finding that a re-examination of the holotype of the latter showed no reliable morphological differences between the two taxa.

authority: Franco, de Carvalho Cintra & de Lema, 2006

taxonomicNotes: The authorship of the specific name for this species has been contentious. Some researchers have have suggested that Jan (1863) was the author of the species since he first described C. flavolineatus, but other researchers contend that Jan's description was so incomplete that it was not possible to ascertain what snake he had in mind and therefore suggested Boettger (1885) as the author, since he was the first to provide a detailed description of the species. The discovery by Hamdan et al. (2014) of a surviving syntype permitted a full diagnosis and clarification of the taxonomic identity of C. flavolineatus, and these authors confirmed Jan (1863) as the correct author.

The complex taxonomic history of Dipsas incerta is summarized by Passos et al. (2004). These authors removed the Brazilian taxon Dipsas alternans - including the junior synonyms Sibynomorphus barbouri and S. garbei - from synonymy with D. incerta. The status of a third synonym proposed by Amaral (1929) - Leptognathus praeornata - is not clear. This was not included in the synonymy of either D. alternans or D. incerta by Passos et al. (2004) and was recognized as a full species by Harvey (2008). This author did not justify this treatment, and noted that the available images of D. praeornata were not sufficient to distinguish it from either D. incerta or D. alternans. Harvey and Embert (2008) subsequently applied this name to a Venezuelan population (contra Rivas et al. 2012 they did not formally resurrect it) but L. Esqueda (pers. comm. in Uetz et al. 2018) notes that the original description is sufficient only to assign it to the genus Dipsas and suggests that the name may be a nomen dubium.

Comparing the illustration of D. incerta with material from D. variegata and D. copei, Passos et al. (2004) concluded that D. incerta is a senior synonym of D. copei and designated a neotype for D. incerta. These authors nonetheless report some differences between the D. copei specimens and the D. incerta illustration. Harvey (2008) disputes the neotype designation, arguing that Passos et al. (2004) did not sufficiently justify the need for a neotype. This author also rejects the proposed synonymy, reporting greater differences in colouration between the two taxa than suggested by Passos et al. (2004). Harvey (2008) suggests that, if the French Guiana type locality is in error, D. incerta may prove to be synonymous with a known taxon, but that it is "certainly not" the same species as D. copei.

Pending further research this assessment treats D. incerta as a valid species distinct from D. copei, D. alternans and D. praeornata.

Neither Hydrodynastes bicinctus nor its proposed subspecies H. b. schultzi was well-characterized in the original descriptions (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015). These authors examined variation throughout the species' Brazilian range and found no evidence to support the distinctiveness of H. b. schultzi, and synonymized it within the nominate form.

Liophis longiventris and Liophis canaima were relegated to the synonymy of Liophis (now Erythrolamprus) breviceps based on morphological characters by Fernandes et al. (2002). The names Liophis longiventris and Erythrolamprus longiventris have since been used to refer to a valid species by multiple authors (Franca et al. 2006, Grazziotin et al. 2012) but none of these was a taxonomic treatment, and the action by Fernandes et al. (2002) appears to have been overlooked rather than rejected (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019), and the species is listed as a junior synonym by Wallach et al. (2014). Accordingly these taxa are treated as junior synonyms of E. breviceps in this assessment.

Historically, the name Oxyrhopus formosus has been applied to a widespread snake in much of northern South America and its range limits relative to O. occidentalis (which was included within O. formosus prior to Hoge et al. 1973) have been poorly-characterized. Partial revisions in Colombia (Lynch 2009) and the Guiana Shield (MacCulloch et al. 2009) removed O. formosus from these territories and Ecuador (Lynch 2009), but no study to date has evaluated the taxonomic status of this species using material from throughout its range (H. Zaher pers. comm. 2019). H. Zaher (pers. comm. 2012) suggests that O. formosus sensu stricto may be confined to Bahia in northern Brazil. Pending the completion of a formal revision presently in preparation (H. Zaher pers. comm. 2019), this assessment follows the published concept applied by MacCulloch et al. (2009).
It comprises four subspecies (Leynaud and Bucher 1999), three of which are found in Argentina: Oxyrhopus rhombifer rhombifer, O. r. bachmanni, and O. r. inaequifasciatus (Giraudo et al. 2012).

The recent description of Oxyrhopus vanidicus, which very closely resembles O. melanogenys, makes the specific identity of previously reported records of O. melanogenys in Peru, Brazil, Ecuador, and Colombia uncertain (Lynch 2009). Examining specimens from Venezuela, Rivas et al. (2012) could find no consistent differences between O. vanidicus and O. melanogenys, raising doubts about the specific validity of O. vanidicus. Records for Brazil in Lynch (2009) were not based on examined specimens, but from images from Martins and Oliveira (1998).

Elapomorphus bilineatus was described based on a specimen considered to be a hybrid between E. suspectus and E. spegazzinii (de Lema 1984), the former form itself recognized as a subspecies of E. spegazzinii (Lema 1984). It therefore appears that the names E. (now Phalotris) bilineatus and E. spegazzinii refer to the same species, and recent authors have considered E. spegazzinii a junior synonym of P. bilineatus (e.g. Giraudo and Scrocchi 2002). The systematics of this taxon are further complicated by suggestions that P. bilineatus is itself a junior synonym of P. lemniscatus (Lema 1979, Carreira et al. 2005). This account treats P. bilineatus as valid pending resolution of this issue.

This is a species complex whose systematics are under review (Arredondo 2011). As presently understood three subspecies are recognized: Philodryas olfersii olfersi, P. o. herbeus and P. o. latirostris.

Sibynomorphus inaequifasciatus is known from a single specimen from "Sudamerica", probably collected in Brazil but never subsequently recorded there. A specimen from Paraguay originally assigned to this species (Cope 1862) was later included in the type series of the new species Sibynomorphus turgidus by the same author (Cope 1868). Recent examination of this individual confirmed its identity as S. turgidus (P. Cacciali, unpubl. data), and the holotype is therefore the only example of S. inaequifasciatus known to exist.

Based on the original description Peters (1960) noted that all but one of the holotype's characters have been reported from aberrant individuals of S. vagans and that it also shares characters in common with S. neuwiedi. It is therefore possible that S. inaequifasciatus is conspecific with one of these two species, in which case the name S. inaequifasciatus would have priority (Peters 1960). In the absence of additional specimens and reliable information on its provenance its appropriate taxonomic status cannot be verified and the holotype ("Probably in the Paris Museum" - Peters 1960) has not been located. Peters (1960) recommends "discarding" the name on this basis, but despite this recommendation the name S. inaequifasciatus has subsequently been used to refer to a valid species in checklists for Brazil and (erroneously) Paraguay.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.
Specimens from northeastern Peru present morphological variations and may represent a distinct species (G. Gagliardi pers. comm. 2014)

The name Thamnodynastes nattereri has been used informally in several papers (e.g. Bailey et al. 2005) to refer to an "easily-diagnosable" Atlantic Forest population of this species thought likely to be specifically distinct (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2017), but the type of this taxon is lost and research is ongoing to determine the status of this population and whether T. nattereri is the appropriate name.

It is necessary to perform a morphological and genetic study of this species throughout its range, as it is thought possible that more than one species may be included under this name (R. Maneyro pers. comm. 2016).
Zaher et al. (2009) synonymized the genus Lystrophis under Xenodon.

Jadin et al. (2013) investigated the systematics of Pseustes (for which they resurrected the senior synonym Phrynonax), within which they recognized the species P. poecilonotus, P. shropshirei, and P. polylepis (the latter resurrected from synonymy within P. poecilonotus). These authors did not however include material from P. shropshirei in their analysis, and the taxonomic status of this taxon relative to P. polylepis is unclear (Gutiérrez-Cárdenas et al. in review, G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015). It is treated here as a valid species following Jadin et al. (2013), however, further research is required to confirm this arrangement. Natera-Munaw et al. (2015) resurrected the name Phrynonax lyoni encompassing both Venezuelan records of P. shropshirei and an eastern coastal population of P. polylepis, the latter without examining the specimens. The characters these authors use to distinguish P. lyoni are however confusing and examination of the eastern coastal specimens confirms their assignment to P. polylepis (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2016). On this basis, this account follows a traditional concept of P. shropshirei encompassing the Venezuelan populations, and P. lyoni is retained as a junior synonym of P. poecilonotus.
Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the relation between Epictia munoai and other species of the genus.

In a recent review of the Bothrops neuwiedi complex based on morphology and mitochondrial genes, Carrasco et al. (2019) suggested that B. matogrossensis is a complex of species. Additional taxonomic review is needed to clarify this problem.

Silva (2004) and Silva and Rodriguez (2008) consider that Bothrops diporus is found in Missiones in Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and west of Parana and Sao Paulo in Brazil. These populations are, however, morphologically distinct from animals found at this species' type locality (Rio Bermejo, in the Chaco ecoregion) (Giraudo 2004, Cacciali et al. 2016). It is possible that these populations are specifically distinct from 'true' B. diporus found in central and northern Argentina, and west of the Rio Paraguay in Paraguay (A. Giraudo, unpubl. data). These may prove to be referable to B. pubescens, B. neuwiedi, B. mattogrossensis or populations intermediate between these taxa (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), but molecular studies to resolve the systematics of this taxon and of the B. neuwiedii group as a whole are presently lacking. As such, the taxonomy and distribution of every member of this group remains unclear.

Silva (2004) and Silva and Rodrigues (2008) consider that Bothrops diporus is found in Missiones in Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and west of Parana and Sao Paulo in Brazil. These populations are, however, morphologically distinct from animals found at this species' type locality (Rio Bermejo, in the Chaco ecoregion) (Giraudo 2004, Cacciali et al. 2016). It is possible that these populations are specifically distinct from 'true' B. diporus found in central and northern Argentina, and west of the Rio Paraguay in Paraguay (A. Giraudo, unpubl. data). These may prove to be referable to Bothrops pubescens, B. neuwiedi, B. mattogrossensis or populations intermediate between these taxa (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), but molecular studies to resolve the systematics of this taxon and of the Bothrops neuwiedii group as a whole are presently lacking. As such, the taxonomy and distribution of every member of this group remains unclear.

Bothrops pauloensis is a species complex (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014). Cacciali et al. (2016) described problems assigning material from Paraguay to members of the former Bothrops neuwiedi. These authors tentatively assigned this material to two former members of this group: B. diporus and B. pauloensis, while emphasising that further work was needed to confirm this assignment.

Silva (2004) and Silva and Rodriguez (2008) consider that Bothrops diporus is found in Missiones in Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and west of Parana and Sao Paulo in Brazil. These populations are, however, morphologically distinct from animals found at this species' type locality (Rio Bermejo, in the Chaco ecoregion) (Giraudo 2004, Cacciali et al. 2016). It is possible that these populations are specifically distinct from 'true' B. diporus found in central and northern Argentina, and west of the Rio Paraguay in Paraguay (A. Giraudo, unpubl. data). These may prove to be referrable to Bothrops pubescens, B. neuwiedi, B. mattogrossensis or populations intermediate between these taxa (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), but molecular studies to resolve the systematics of this taxon and of the Bothrops neuwiedii group as a whole are presently lacking. As such, the taxonomy and distribution of every member of this group remains unclear.
The species has also been referred to as Bothrops bilineata in the literature.

The correct generic allocation of the species needs to be reviewed. The status of populations currently referred to Bothrops pulchra remains unresolved; there appear to be two distinct taxa, and one of them appears to be quite close to, if not conspecific with, B. chloromelas (Campbell and Lamar 2004).

Bothrops rhombeatus was resurrected by Folleco-Fernández (2010) from synonymy with B. colombianus. Unfortunately, when comparing this species with the widespread B. asper, this author neglected to examine material from outside the Cauca Department of Colombia, although B. asper is a very widespread, variable species. Ramírez-Chaves and Solari (2014) investigated the validity of B. rhombeatus and concluded that it was likely to be a junior synonym of either B. atrox or B. asper but that, based on the absence of type material, its identity could not be determined with certainty and so it should be considered a nomen dubium.
Hedges (2011) assigned this species from Guinea to Tricheilostoma.

Dispholidus is presently considered to be a monotypic genus, however the complex pattern of regional morphological variation in this very widespread snake has led to suggestions that the species is a complex (summarized by Eimermacher 2012). On the basis of molecular evidence, this author identified four clades within D. typus that are likely to warrant recognition at specific status. Formal descriptions based on these results and on morphological data are in preparation, and additional cryptic species may be found within the D. typus complex (Eimermacher 2012). Broadley and Blaylock (2013) considered populations in (mainly) the Western and Eastern Cape provinces as being referable to D. t. typus, while populations elsewhere in the range (where males are usually mainly green dorsally) were treated as D. t. viridis.
The range of this species overlaps with Lycophidion albomaculatum Steindachner, 1870, a species that until recently was classified as L. semicinctum albomaculatum.

The correct status of Agama castroviejoi, which is genetically close to A. boueti, is presently unclear. Geniez et al. (2011) synonymized this taxon within A. boueti, but this was rejected by Mediannikov et al. (2012) as this taxon is reliably diagnosable and ecologically distinct from A. boueti, more closely resembling A. impalearis in colour pattern and ecology. Trape et al. (2012) provide a key summarizing diagnostic differences in morphology between this form and A. boueti. P. Wagner (pers. comm. 2012) contends, however, that differentiation in colour pattern and ecology within this taxonomically complex genus is not sufficiently well-understood to justify delimiting species on this basis and points out that, on the basis of molecular evidence (Geniez et al. 2011), recognizing A. castroviejoi would render A. boueti as presently understood paraphyletic, and that mtDNA divergence between the two taxa is low. More recently, wider geographic sampling from within A. boueti's range has also found little or no genetic divergence between this species and A. castroviejoi (Goncalves et al. 2012). The appropriate status of this latter taxon remains under review (Wagner et al. in prep), and it may warrant subspecific status. A. boueti itself may be a species complex containing at least one undescribed taxon in the eastern portion of its range (I. Ineich pers. comm., J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2012), and further research is needed to clarify the true identity of A. boueti before the appropriate status of A. castroviejoi can be determined. This account therefore follows Geniez et al. (2011) and Goncalves et al. (2012) in treating A. castroviejoi as a synonym of A. boueti pending further research.

New Guinean Nactus previously included within N. pelagicus were explicitly excluded from a revision by Zug and Moon (1995), which revised this species complex and assigned the names N. pelagicus and N. multicarinatus to forms from neighbouring regions (Zug and Moon 1995, Zug and Fisher 2012). Subsequent research uncovered greater diversity in New Guinea's Admiralty Islands than had previously been recognized, including both a form sharing characteristics with Oceanian N. pelagicus (and attributed to this taxon by Zug and Fisher 2012) and a rarer, undescribed species (Zug and Fisher 2012). These authors named the latter Nactus kunan.
Chamaeleo laevigatus (Gray, 1863), from Central and East Africa, was previously considered to be a subspecies of C. senegalensis.

McCranie (2011) proposed elevating Cubophis canthigerus brooksi to specific status following the recognition by Hedges et al. (2009) that Cayman Island populations also previously included within C. canthigerus are genetically distinct from this species. Although Hedges et al. (2009) did not consider the status of the Honduran population, McCranie (2011) notes that it is geographically closer to the Cayman Islands than to Cuban C. canthigerus, and so it is implausible that C. canthigerus and C. brooksi are conspecific.

Recent molecular phylogenetic analyses (Schmitz et al. 2005) clarify the evolutionary relationships of the skinks of the genus Panaspis and show that Panaspis togoensis is highly distinct from P. breviceps (of which it considered a subspecies in some accounts e.g. Loveridge 1952, Grandison 1965) .

Taylor (1956) reviewed Middle American Mabuya found in Costa Rica and concluded that three species could be diagnosed: M. brachypoda, M. alliacea and M. unimarginata. Subsequent authors adopted this scheme inconsistently (Hedges and Conn 2012), and most recent publications have rejected this division and placed all Mabuya in Middle America in Mabuya unimarginata following Savage (2002), who contended that intergradation between these forms indicated the presence of only a single species in Costa Rica. Hedges and Conn (2012) reexamined representatives of these proposed species, and confirmed the original diagnosis of Taylor (1956). These authors noted that the position taken by Savage (2002) was not supported by evidence and was inconsistent with the observation presented by Taylor (1956) that M. unimarginata and M. brachypoda occur within 10 km of one another with no indication of hybridization, Hedges and Conn (2012) therefore revalidated M. brachypoda and M. alliacea, and assigned all former Mabuya in Central America to the new genus Marisora.

Taylor (1956) reviewed Middle American Mabuya found in Costa Rica and concluded that three species could be diagnosed: M. brachypoda, M. alliacea and M. unimarginata. Subsequent authors adopted this scheme inconsistently (Hedges and Conn 2012), and most recent publications have rejected this division and placed all Mabuya in Middle America in Mabuya unimarginata following Savage (2002), who contended that intergradation between these forms indicated the presence of only a single species in Costa Rica. Hedges and Conn (2012) reexamined representatives of these proposed species, and confirmed the original diagnosis of Taylor (1956). These authors noted that the position taken by Savage (2002) was not supported by evidence and was inconsistent with the observation presented by Taylor (1956) that M. unimarginata and M. brachypoda occur within 10 km of one another with no indication of hybridisation, Hedges and Conn (2012) therefore revalidated M. brachypoda and M. alliacea, and assigned all former Mabuya in Central America to the new genus Marisora. Marisora brachypoda is the most widespread of the three mainland species, and there are indications from both morphology and molecular analysis that further taxonomic work is required to clarify the identity of additional forms within this possible species complex (Hedges and Conn 2012).

This species was previously included within Agama agama, alongside which it occurs over part of its range (Mediannikov et al. 2012). It was recognized as a distinct species on both genetic and morphological grounds (Mediannikov et al. 2012).
This recently-described gecko was previously confused with Hemidactylus angulatus (Trape et al. 2012).
Trape et al. (2012) consider this taxon, formerly a subspecies of Tarentola ephippiata, a full species on molecular grounds, although they provide no data in support of this conclusion.

This species replaces Leptosiaphos aloysiisabaudiae, which it closely resembles, in West Africa (Trape et al. 2012). A population of four-toed Leptosiaphos from the Adamaoua Plateau in Cameroon may be attributable to this species. Trape et al. (2012) provisionally consider this population conspecific with L. dungeri in their species account. Genetic research is required to clarify whether the Cameroonian population represents L. dungeri (Trape et al. 2012), which L. Chirio (pers. comm. 2012) opins is "most probably" endemic to the Jos Plateau.
Broadley et al. (2006) indicate that this species was included within the concept of Melanoseps loveridgei applied by Spawls et al. (2002) (but not earlier authors).

Branch et al. (2005) report two specimens of a Melanoseps from Mozambique which they tentatively refer to M. loveridgei, and Broadley et al. (2006) include these records within their diagnosis of M. loveridgei. These latter authors find, however, that the current definition of M. loveridgei appears to be polyphyletic, and suggest that the taxon is likely to represent a species complex. Broadley et al. (2006) indicate that the specimens they describe as the new species Melanoseps emmrichi were included within M. loveridgei by Spawls et al. (2002). The phylogeny in Broadley et al. (2006) shows that populations currently assigned to M. loveridgei are not monophyletic, and research is needed to diagnose cryptic taxa within this species complex.
Broadley et al.(2006) assign one of two historical records of Melanoseps longicauda, from a site along the Pangani River, to the newly-recognized M. pygmaeus.

Bauer et al. (2003) attributed the holotype and only known specimen of Lygosoma thomasi to this species based on the original description by Tornier (1903). This account therefore treats Lygosoma thomasi as a junior synonym of Leptosiaphos kilimensis, with the proviso that the type of L. thomasi has not been located and so this assignment cannot presently be confirmed with reference to the original material.

The taxonomy of this species, and other Philochortus species, needs to be reviewed (S. Baha El Din pers. comm). Schleich et al. (1996) indicated that the relationship between this species and West African P. lhotei was in need of clarification. More recently, Trape et al. (2012) considered West African P. lhotei a junior synonym of this species as its morphological characters fall within the range of variability of Egyptian P. zolii reported by Baha El Din (2006) (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012).

The status of Varanus ocellatus is uncertain; it has been variously treated as a synonym of either V. albigularis or V. exanthematicus (Bennett 2004). This account follows Bennett (2004) in considering this form a synonym of V. exanthematicus with a distribution in Sudan (presumably South Sudan given the distribution for V. exanthematicus provided by this author). Specimens from Djibouti, Somalia and Ethiopia previously attributed to V. ocellatus are now understood to represent V. albigularis (Ineich 2001, Largen and Spawls 2006).

The following subspecies are recognised:
Atractaspis irregularis angeli Laurent, 1950
A. i. bipostocularis Boulenger, 1905
A. i. conradsi Sternfield, 1908
A. i. parkeri Laurent, 1945
A. . uelensis Laurent 1945.

Hughes (2003) clarified the distributions of this species and P. bocourti, finding that only P. barthii occurs in West Africa and that this species does not occur east of Ghana. Apparently unaware of this work, Chippaux (2006) gives the incorrect distribution "Côte d'Ivoire au Gabon et au Cameroun", justifying its removal from territories further west by indicating that the type locality "Guinea" in fact refers to Ghana. Although Guinea was the name historically applied to much of western West Africa (Hughes 2003), Chippaux (2006) provides no justification for assuming a Ghanaian type locality, and a record of this species exists from Mt. Nimba in southern Guinea (Hughes 2003). Böhme et al. (2011) continue to refer to this record as P. bocourti following Angel (1954), however Hughes (2003) discuss this record and consider the attribution to P. bocourti to be in error.

This species was previously considered to occur throughout western and central Africa, from Gambia to western Uganda (Spawls et al. 2002). Trape and Mané (2006) re-examined specimens of this species and Dasypeltis scabra from West Africa, erecting three new species distributed in the Sahel, Sudanese savannah and the Guinean tropics respectively. Trape et al. (2012) re-examined the systematics of West African Dasypeltis, and confirmed that D. macrops is a junior synonym of D. fasciata.

Trape et al. (2006) redescribed this species, Atractaspis microlepidota and A. watsoni. The identity of these three species has been confused since Laurent (1950), who considered A. watsoni to be a synonym of A. micropholis, and this in turn a subspecies of A. microlepidota. Trape and Mané (2000) subsequently identified A. microlepidota and A. micropholis as distinct forms, noting that the two occur in sympatry in West Africa, but did not formally redescribe either species. A. micropholis has an indeterminate type locality originally identified only as somewhere in Africa. The description of the type locality as "Northern Nigeria" in a British Museum catalogue may be a later amendment to the specimen record (Trape et al. 2006), however, it is consistent with the distribution of the species provided by these authors.

The redescription by Trape et al. (2006) of Atractaspis microlepidota, previously considered to range from West Africa east to Arabia and the Near East, confined this formerly widespread species to West Africa. These authors did not consider the status of populations outside West Africa, but by implication elevated the Arabian subspecies A. m. andersonii to specific status. This scheme is followed by David and Vogel (2010) pending a revision of eastern members of this species complex, on the basis that A. andersonii is morphologically distinct from any of the three species recognized for West Africa by Trape et al. (2006). David and Vogel (2010) also consider the status of A. engaddensis, suggested by Gasperetti (1988) to be a synonym of A. microlepidota. The view put forward by Gasperetti (1988) has been contested on the basis of morphological differences between the two forms, differences already recognized by Gasperetti (1988) (Werner 1990). David and Vogel (2010) support the view that the two species are distinct, noting that A. engaddensis differs from both A. microlepidota and A. andersonii, and that A. engaddensis and A. andersonii appear to occur in sympatry in Arabia. A systematic revision of eastern Atractaspis following the redescription of A. microlepidota is however still lacking, and so the relationship between A. andersonii, A. engaddensis and African forms is in need of clarification.

It seems likely that several cryptic taxa are currently subsumed under the name Atractaspis bibronii (Nagy et al. 2005). Morphological and genetic techniques should be employed to conduct a major revision of this species across its entire range.

Arnold (2000) elevated the former subspecies Nactus serpeninsula durrelli (emended to durrellorum by Michels and Bauer 2004) to specific status, restricting N. s. serpeninsula to Serpent Island. Although Arnold (2000) elevated this taxon to a full species without comment, his taxonomy is accepted by researchers and conservationists working with this taxon and is consequently applied here.

This species was described as a subspecies of the Serpent Island Night Gecko Nactus serpensinsula under the name N. s. durrelli (Arnold and Jones 1994), and elevated to specific status by Arnold (2000). The species was named in honour of both Gerald and Lee Durrell and hence the specific name should be plural; consequently Michels and Bauer (2004) emended it to Nactus serpensinsula durrellorum. This work unfortunately neglected the action of Arnold (2000) elevating this taxon to specific status, and consequently the correct combination Nactus durrellorum has so far been used only in grey literature such as technical reports. Although Arnold (2000) elevated this taxon to a full species without comment, his taxonomy is accepted by researchers and conservationists working with this taxon and is consequently applied here.

Three subspecies are currently recognized: Phelsuma borbonica borbonica Mertens,1966, P. b. mater Meier, 1995 and P. b. agalegae Cheke, 1975. P. b. agalegae, only present on Agalega islands, is a very poorly known subspecies.

Due to the limits of the taxonomic descriptions of subspecies and more recent developments of systematic methods, a systematic revision of Phelsuma borbonica is necessary (Sanchez and Caceres 2019). A genetic study has shown that two distinctly differentiated evolutionary lineages with a high level of genetic differentiation between populations exist on Réunion Island (Thébaud 2013).

Bour et al. (1995) elevated the the subspecies Phelsuma ornata inexpectata to species rank, based on coloration and biological criteria. Phylogenetic studies confirm that this taxon is well-differentiated from Mauritian P. ornata (Austin et al. 2004), and it is currently accepted as a full species by most herpetologists.

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Phelsuma abbotti (e.g. Spawls et al. 2002), but has widely been treated as a full species in recent literature (see Uetz and Hallerman 2012 for examples of usage) and this assignment is supported by combined morphological and molecular analysis (Rocha et al. 2010).

Previous species delimitation of Agama was rooted in morphological and geographic variation (McLachlan 1981), but recent multilocus phylogenetic work has established the phylogenetic relationships of African Agama, including those among the southern African taxa (Leaché et al. 2009, 2014). However, the taxonomic status of the Agama aculeata species complex (A. aculeata aculeata, A. a. distanti, A. armata) requires further investigation because no samples of A. a. distanti were included in the recent studies. Although McLachlan (1981) referred ground agamas from KwaZulu-Natal to A. a. armata, Bourquin (2004) followed Jacobsen (1989) and treated these populations as A. a. distanti.

Historical records of Agama aculeata (previously a subspecies of A. armata) and A. hispida (of which A. armata was previously considered a subspecies) from East Africa refer to A. armata (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2013). Additional molecular analyses may help to better illuminate the population genetic diversity across this taxon’s large geographic range and resolve taxonomic issues with this and related taxa.

This species is known from a small number of specimens and has rarely been considered in the literature (Wagner and Bauer 2011). Wagner and Bauer (2011) examined the holotype and determined that it was distinct from other taxa examined in their review of Ethiopian "Agama agama", however, these authors noted similarities with A. spinosa (not treated in this research) and concluded that "the status of A. bottegi is still doubtful", listing this form in their review as Agama bottegi incertae sedis.

Spawls et al. (2002) erroneously give this species' name as Agama caudospina. A. kaimosae, at the time known only from Kaimosi, was considered a junior synonym of A. caudospinosa until revalidated by Wagner et al. (2008). The subspecies A. c. spawlsi has recently been described from a small area close to Mt. Kenya (Wagner 2010).

Wagner et al. (2011) investigated the distribution of this recently-described lizard, confirming records provisionally assigned to this species in the original description and erecting a new subspecies, Agama finchi leucerythrolaema, for a population from Uganda; these authors also assigned records from Gambela in Ethiopia to this subspecies. Records of Agama agama sensu lato from western Ethiopia and Eritrea depicted by Largen and Spawls (2010) in fact represent A. finchi (Wagner et al. 2011, citing S. Spawls pers. comm.)

This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Agama caudospinosa. Following the collection of new material from a site close to the type locality, Wagner et al. (2008) revalidated A. kaimosae on the basis of both morphological and genetic evidence. Except for male breeding colours it is morphologically indistinguishable from its apparent sister species, A. mwanzae, but genetic evidence and the occurrence of A. kaimosae and A. mwanzae in sympatry in Kenya's Loita Hills suggests both forms are valid species.

This is a member of the former Agama agama species complex, and is still treated within accounts for Agama agama in some recent field guides (e.g, Largen and Spawls 2010 - part). Böhme et al. (2005) distinguished the A. lionotus group, encompassing East African members of the former A. agama complex, from the A. agama group. The taxonomy of Agama lionotus thus defined is still not fully resolved. Recent work has determined that A. turuensis (a former synonym of A. l. elongis) is a valid species (Wagner et al. 2008) and that A. l. usambarae is a junior synonym of A. l. lionotus (Wagner 2007). Agama l. dodomae has been elevated to full species status, including the subspecies A. d. ufipae (P. Wagner unpubl. thesis, Wagner et al. in prep.). As currently defined following this complex sequence of taxonomic changes, A. lionotus contains the two recognized subspecies A. l. lionotus and A. l. elongis, and the latter is likely to be elevated to specific status in the near future (P. Wagner, in prep.).

Unpublished genetic work suggests that the record of this species from Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008) probably belongs to an undescribed species (M. Menegon pers. comm. 2015). An Agama population from the Udzungwa mountains appears to be morphologically referable to A. montana, but this too is thought to represent an undescribed species (M. Menegon pers. comm. 2015). Neither of these populations is included in this assessment pending further research to clarify the taxonomic status of the new records.

Recent authors have recognized Agama planiceps schacki as a full species based on unpublished evidence that the two taxa are close relatives but specifically distinct (Marques et al. 2018, Butler et al. 2019). This account refrains from formally recognizing this change pending the completion of a detailed revision of this group mentioned by Marques et al. (2018).

Due to distinct differences between this species and other Ethiopian Agama, Largen and Spawls (2006) speculate that its assignment to this genus may be incorrect. Leaché et al. (2014) report results indicating that the species forms a clade sister to remaining Agama and state that work is underway to allocate it to a different genus.

The three recognized subspecies are not well-defined (Wagner and Bauer 2011). Reflecting this lack of clarity, Lanza (1990) attributes central and southern Somali records to an unidentified "Agama rueppelli ssp.". Wagner and Bauer (2011) indicate that a review of this species' taxonomy is required.

This taxon has been considered a junior synonym of Agama agama elongis since shortly after its description. Böhme et al. (2005), in distinguishing the East African A. lionotus complex from A. agama, gave turuensis as the name of a presumably valid subspecies of A. lionotus, separate from A. lionotus elongis. This arrangement was not discussed, and A. turuensis therefore remained a junior synonym of A. l. elongis until the examination of new material by Wagner et al. (2008) determined that A. turuensis represents a valid species separate from A. lionotus.

Prior to Harvey et al. (2017) Dendragama was considered to be monotypic and so records from throughout Sumatra were referred to the sole species, D. boulengeri. D. schneideri, presently a junior synonym of D. boulengeri, is considered valid by Harvey et al. (2017) and - although these authors do not take formal taxonomic action - their concept of D. boulengeri excludes this taxon. Another junior synonym, Salea rosaceum, was found by these authors to have been misattributed, and Harvey et al. (2017) referred this name to the synonymy of Pseudocalotes tympanistriga.
In their recent revision of Xenagama, Wagner et al. (2012) described western populations formerly included within X. batillifera as a new species, X. wilmsi, restricting X. batillifera to Somalia.
Trape et al. (2012) consider this taxon, formerly a subspecies of Tarentola ephippiata, a full species on molecular grounds, although they provide no data in support of this conclusion.

Trape et al. (2012) resurrected this species from synonymy, assigning the name Trachylepis aureogularis to West African populations previously assigned to T. albilabris. It has often been confused with both this species and T. affinis, this latter a more widespread species found throughout the range of T. aureogularis (Trape et al. 2012).
Schätti and Charvet (2003) examined the systematics of this and related species from Somalia, and found that the more widespread Coluber smithii should be considered a subspecies of Platyceps brevis.

The taxonomic history of Coluber florulentus and its subspecific forms is discussed by Schätti (1988), who redescribed this species and the subspecies C. f.  keniensis, and described the West African subspecies C. f. perreti. Schätti (1988) confirmed the validity of C. smithii (later determined to be a subspecies of Platyceps brevis by Schätti and Charvet 2003) and C. taylori as species distinct from C. florulentus. Nagy et al. (2004) assigned C. florulentus to Platyceps. Schätti et al. (2014) erected the new combination Platyceps perreti for the subspecies P. f. perreti, and this is implicitly accepted by Spawls et al. (2018) who do not refer to Cameroon or Nigeria within the distribution of P. florulentus. These authors do not however justify this action and refer to only a single minor morphological difference without specifying sample sizes, and consequently Uetz et al. (2019) do not recognize P. perreti pending further research. Chippaux and Jackson (2019) also list the Central African taxon under the name "Platyceps florulentus perreti", but do not comment on this assignment.

Broadley and Wallach (2009) listed Typhlops angeli, from Mt. Nimba in Guinea, as a valid species without comment, assigning it to Letheobia. The validity of this species apparently remains unclear: it has been referred to as a valid species in several subsequent checklists and mentioned - but not included in analysis - by Pyron and Wallach (2014); by contrast Böhme et al. (2011) continued to recognize it as a junior synonym of L. manni.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. Populations with three-keeled scales, a characteristic of Trachylepis affinis, are common (especially in Liberia), and T. paucisquamis may be a junior synonym of T. affinis (Trape et al. 2012).
No synonyms or subspecies of Kinixys homeana have been described, and no geographic variation is known.

This species was described by Arnold et al. (2008) based on recent Hemidactylus records from Fogo originally attributed to H. bouvieri. The identity of historical records from this island is unclear; some are thought to represent the new species (Arnold et al. 2008).
Hemidactylus boavistensis has long been treated as a subspecies of H. bouvieri, but was re-elevated to species status by Arnold et al. (2008) based on morphological and molecular evidence.

Lanza (1990) states, without justification, "synonym of Hemidactylus. jubensis Boulenger, 1895?", and this issue does not appear to have been investigated since, possibly due to poor knowledge of the latter species (only known from a single locality in southern Ethiopia - Largen and Spawls 2006). Largen and Spawls (2006) note that if this synonymization is correct, H. jubensis would prove to be much more widely-distributed. Ongoing genetic work (Mazuch, Agarwal and Bauer, in prep.) indicates that H. barodanus as presently understood is a species complex, and preliminary results indicate that H. jubensis is likely to be a distinct, valid species (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019).
Mazuch (2013), citing Smid et al. (in prep), indicates that this is a species complex.

Mahony (2011) revalidated Hemidactylus gleadowi, previously a junior synonym of H. brookii, and restricted its known distribution to the type locality as material historically assigned to this species from elsewhere has never been compared with the lost types to confirm their identity.

This species has previously been treated as a subspecies of Hemidactylus maculatus, but based on levels of genetic divergence Bauer et al. (2010) proposed elevating it to species level. Somaweera and Somaweera (2009) noted that most authors consider this species as being endemic to Sri Lanka, and Bauer et al. (2010) confirmed that ongoing research suggests that Indian records represent a distinct species.
Kenyan records of this species may not be conspecific with those in Somalia and Ethiopia (Spawls et al. 2018).

Lanza (1990) states, without justification, "synonym of Hemidactylus jubensis Boulenger, 1895?", and this issue does not appear to have been investigated since, possibly due to poor knowledge of the latter species (only known from a single locality in southern Ethiopia - Largen and Spawls 2006). Largen and Spawls (2006) note that if this synonymization is correct, H. jubensis would prove to be much more widely-distributed. Ongoing genetic work (Mazuch, Agarwal and Bauer, in prep.) indicates that Hemidactylus barodanus as presently understood is a species complex, and preliminary results indicate that H. jubensis is likely to be a distinct, valid species (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019).
This species is known only from the holotype, but recent research has confirmed that it "is without any doubt valid" (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019, Šmíd et al. in press).

Mahony (2011) revalidated Hemidactylus kushmorensis, previously a junior synonym of H. brookii, and recognized it as distinct from the revalidated H. gleadowi with which it had historically been synonymized.

Parker (1942) opined that this species was described based on juvenile Hemidactylus turcicus, and Loveridge (1947) indicated that Parker "may well be right in this allocation". Fifty years later, Spawls and Rotich (1997) likewise remarked that this species may be a synonym of H. turcicus (African populations of which were subsequently referred to H. turcicus - Baha El Din 2005).

Although H. puccionii is presently accepted as valid, its taxonomy does not appear to have been investigated in order to clarify this situation. Records from northern Somalia attributed by Parker (1942) to H. turcicus, whose similarity to the types of H. puccionii was discussed, appear to be attributed to H. robustus by Lanza (1990) (who does not record H. puccionii for northern Somalia). Spawls and Rotich (1997) report a single record from Mandera in Kenya; this record is attributed to H. robustus by Spawls et al. (2002).

Hemidactylus squamulatus is a species complex whose taxonomy is currently in the process of revision (T. Mazuch and S. Spawls pers. comm. 2014). Preliminary research indicates that populations from northern Kenya and Ethiopia are genetically distinct from those from south-central Kenya and Tanzania (to which the name H. squamulatus is applicable), representing at least one cryptic species (T. Mazuch, in prep.). The description of an additional member of the complex from Ethiopia, which is both morphologically and genetically distinct from both Kenyan/Tanzanian H. squamulatus and from the north Kenya/Ethiopia clade, is currently underway (T. Mazuch, in prep.)

Spawls et al. (2002) express doubt whether two specimens collected from Mkomazi Game Reserve are conspecific with the type collection. Pending resolution of this issue this assessment follows these authors in provisionally including Mkomazi within this species' distribution.
This species is valid, however, it is part of a species complex which needs further research to resolve all the separate species. The complex as a whole is assessed here.

Rösler and Glaw (2010) removed the Indonesian H. tenkatei from synonymy with H. brookii on morphological grounds. Mahony (2011) synonymized the Burmese form H. subtriedroides, treated as a synonym of H. brookii by Bauer et al. (2010), with H. tenkatei. This action was subsequently disputed by Kathriner et al. (2014), but the status of H. subtriedroides remains unresolved (Lajmi et al. 2016).

Mahony (2011) also provisionally included H. luzonensis (considered a probable junior synonym of H. tenkatei by Rösler and Glaw 2010) within the synonymy of H. brookii until Philippine specimens can be examined to verify their identity.

Lajmi et al. (2016) conducted a combined morphological and molecular analysis of the H. brookii complex sensu lato, focusing particularly on delimiting species in India. These authors resurrect the name H. murrayi for a clade which they propose may be a senior synonym of the taxon described by Rösler and Glaw (2010) as H. tentakei.

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyami, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyami and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyami, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyami and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyami, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyami and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

Parker (1942) indicates that the status of this species is doubtful due to overlap between many characters in this species and the variable Holodactylus africanus, but cautions that certain characters are not known to have analogues in H. africanus and so refrained from taking taxonomic action.

It is unclear whether Anolis lemniscatus is a valid species. It was omitted by Miyata (1982) in a checklist of the herpetofauna of Ecuador, and listed as a synonym of Anolis tropidogaster Hallowell, 1857 by Peters (1967) following examination of the syntypes. It was subsequently included as a valid species in a catalogue of Neotropical squamates by Peters and Donoso-Barros (1970) but without justification. It has recently been suggested that Anolis lemniscatus may be conspecific with Anolis binotatus and A. bitectus, in which case Anolis binotatus will be the oldest available name, and research is ongoing to clarify the status of these taxa (F. Ayala et al. in prep.).

Lazell (1972) and Schwartz and Henderson (1991) recognize four subspecies. Subsequent research investigated morphological and molecular variation in this species and found that there was no evidence of subspecific structure (Malhotra and Thorpe 2000).
