This species, formerly a subspecies of Anolis wattsi, was recognized as a full species based on mtDNA and allozyme data presented by Schneider et al. (2001), as well as biogeographical and morphological differences from Anolis wattsi.

Two subspecies are recognized:
A. grahami grahami Gray, 1845
A. grahami aquarum Underwood & Williams, 1959.

Anolis leachi Dumeril & Bibron (1837) of Antigua and Barbuda is sometimes considered a subspecies of A. bimaculatus (G. Mayer pers. comm. 2010), but is now generally regarded as a full species and is treated as such here.
Two subspecies are recognized: Anolis monticola monticola Shreve, 1936 and A. m. quadrisartus Thomas & Schwartz, 1967.
Two subspecies are recognized: Anolis strahmi strahmi Schwartz, 1979 and A. s. abditus Schwartz, 1979.
Two subspecies are recognized: Anolis centralis centralis Peters, 1970 and A. c. litoralis Garrido, 1975.

Köhler et al. (2019) found that the holotype of Anolis cybotes saxatilis was conspecific with Anolis whitemani, and consequently established the combination Audantia saxatilis for the species previously known as A. whitemani. As the genus-level revision by Nicholson et al. (2012) remains controversial (Köhler et al. 2019), this assessment retains A. saxatilis within Anolis.

A number of subspecies have been described:
Anolis olssoni olssoni Schmidt, 1919
Anolis olssoni alienus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni dominigensis Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni extentus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni ferrugicauda Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni insulanus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni montivagus Schwartz, 1981
Anolis olssoni palloris Schwartz, 1981.

Nussbaum and Hoyer (1974) showed that subspecies utahensis is indistiguishable from subspecies bottae, and they regarded the concept "umbratica" as meaningless; Collins (1990) apparently agreed with this view and did not recognize any subspecies. In contrast, Erwin (1974) proposed that subspecies umbratica warrants species status; this suggestion did not gain the support of other herpetologists. Stewart (1977) recognized two subspecies (bottae andumbratica) and, pending further study, regarded populations from Mt. Pinos and the Tehachapi Mountains, California, as intergrades between these two subspecies. Stebbins (1985) continued to recognize three subspecies (bottae, utahensis, and umbratica). Rodriguez-Robles et al. (2001) used mtDNA data to examine phylogeography of Charina bottae and concluded that "C. b. umbratica is a genetically cohesive, allopatric taxon that is morphologically diagnosable" [using a suite of traits] and that "it is an independent evolutionary unit that should be recognized as a distinct species, Charina umbratica". The authors acknowledged that a mixture of bottae and umbratica traits exists in populations in the Tehachapi Mountains and Mount Pinos, but they interpreted this as persistent ancestral polymorphisms. They also found no support for recognizing utahensis as a valid taxon. Crother et al. (2003) and Crother (2012) listed C. umbratica as a species. The consensus supports treating bottae and umbratica as two separate species and that treatment is followed here.

Records of this species from the Bahamas (Henderson and Powell 2009) represent the former subspecies Chilabothrus striatus strigilatus, elevated to specific status by Reynolds et al. (2013) and which will be assessed separately.

Chilabothrus monensis monensis and C. m. granti have been widely treated as distinct species following Henderson and Powell (2009), who noted that "the two taxa likely are distinct at the species level". This hypothesis was tested on a genetic dataset by Rodríguez-Robles et al. (2015) using coalescent species delimitation analysis. These authors concluded that "with a very high probability" C. monensis and C. granti represent two distinct species.

Chilabothrus monensis monensis and C. m. granti have been widely treated as distinct species following Henderson and Powell (2009), who noted that "the two taxa likely are distinct at the species level". This hypothesis was tested on a genetic dataset by Rodríguez-Robles et al. (2015) using coalescent species delimitation analysis. These authors concluded that "with a very high probability" C. monensis and C. granti represented two distinct species.

Two subspecies are recognized:
S. savagei savagei Shreve, 1968
S. savagei juanilloensis Shreve, 1968.

Klausewitz (1957) recognized six subspecies, although without clear diagnoses and consequently these subspecies were often ignored (i.e. Broadley and Howell 1991). Wagner et al. (2018) examined the systematics of this species using an integrative analysis incorporating both morphological and genetic data, elevating five subspecies to specific status and restricting Acanthocercus atricollis to southeastern Africa.

Peters (1982) distinguished two species within "Agama phillipsii", describing A. trachypleura on the basis of two museum specimens. Largen and Spawls (2006) compared these specimens and determined that, while A. trachypleura could not be distinguished from the type series of A. phillipsii, Peters (1982) had correctly recognized two taxa within the complex, and had applied the established name A. phillipsii to the undescribed form in error. Largen and Spawls (2006) therefore synonymized A. trachypleura within Acanthocercus phillipsii, and erected the new name A. guentherpetersi for Peters' concept of "Agama phillipsii".

Peters (1982) distinguished two species within "Agama phillipsii", describing A. trachypleura on the basis of two museum specimens. Largen and Spawls (2006) compared these specimens and determined that, while A. trachypleura could not be distinguished from the type series of A. phillipsii, Peters (1982) had correctly recognized two taxa within the complex, and had unfortunately applied the established name A. phillipsii to the undescribed form in error. Largen and Spawls (2006) therefore synonymized A. trachypleura within Acanthocercus phillipsii, and erected the new name A. guentherpetersi for Peters' concept of "Agama phillipsii".

Wagner et al. (2013) presented the first revision of the genus Xenagama, previously characterized by the unusual tail morphology of its two then-recognized species. These authors more fully-defined the genus and assigned Acanthocercus zonurus, previously recognized as having affinities to Xenagama batillifera (Boulenger 1895), to Xenagama.

Gans (2005) lists Agamodon immaculatus, described and since treated as a subspecies of A. anguliceps, as a full species. This author provides no basis for this action (and Gans and Pandit 1965, in the only review of this genus, had indicated that it was probably conspecific with A. anguliceps), and this account therefore treats this taxon as a subspecies of A. anguliceps.

Gans (2005) treats the two recognized subspecies, Ancylocranium b. barkeri and A. b. newalae, as full species, but provides no justification for this action. As A. b. newalae was described as a subspecies and both taxa are still known only from the type specimens, it is not clear that there is any basis for changing this taxonomic arrangement and this account therefore retains A. b. newalae as a subspecies of A. barkeri (as do, e.g., Uetz and Hallerman 2012).

Gans (2005) treats both Ancylocranium i. ionidesi and A. i. haasi (the latter originally described as a subspecies of A. ionidesi) as full species, but provides no justification for this action and it has not been followed subsequently (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2012).

This species has been considered a subspecies of Atractaspis microlepidota (Spawls et al. 2002). The systematics of members of this former species complex are complicated, and A. microlepidota itself was confined to West Africa in a revision of this species by Trape et al. (2006). These authors did not address the systematics of eastern members of this group, however by implication the recognized subspecies A. fallax (eastern Africa) and A. andersonii (Arabia) were elevated to full species status by this action, and this has been followed subsequently (e.g. for A. andersonii - Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). Largen and Spawls (2010), who conservatively retain the name A. microlepidota (=A. watsoni, see Taxonomic Note under that species) for populations ranging as far as northwestern Ethiopia and South Sudan, nevertheless consider A. fallax a distinct, separate species, and these authors' species concept for A. fallax is followed here.

The taxonomic status of Chilorhinophis carpenteri is unclear. This has historically been considered a full species (e.g. Loveridge 1955, 1958), but is treated here as a subspecies of C. butleri following more recent usage (Spawls et al. 2002, 2018).
Rasmussen (2002) reviewed Micrelaps and found that M. boettgeri represented a junior synonym of M. vaillanti. This scheme has since been followed by Largen and Spawls (2010) and is accepted here.

This taxonomic status of this species was contentious prior to the revision by Baig et al. (2008), and it was commonly regarded as a subspecies or colour morph of Spalerosophis diadema. As a result of this confusion, and the failure by a number of authors to identify records to subspecies, the precise distribution of this snake has been uncertain.

This taxon was long regarded as a morph within Naja nigricollis, until genetic evidence demonstrated that the two forms are not sister taxa (Wüster and Broadley 2007). These authors therefore described this form as a new species.

Records of this species from southern Afghanistan refer to Acanthodactylus blanfordii, previously understood to be a subspecies (UNEP 2008, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).

Several subspecies of A. cantoris have been elevated to full species status, namely A. blanfordi, A. arabicus, A. schmidti. There are strong similarities between A. cantoris and A. blanfordi, and their most significant differences are pertaining to osteology characters. In addition, they can be distinguished by hemipenial features, and the separation of postfrontal and postorbital bones in A. blanfordi and fusion of these bones in A. cantoris (The Reptile Database 2017).

Mertens (1938) determined that the name Lacerta carinata is preoccupied and was not available for Peters' taxon. This author selected the available replacement name Latastia petersiana for this species. The name L. carinata was however subsequently used for this taxon by multiple authors.

Parker (1942) suggests that Latastia ventralis, known from a single specimen from "Somaliland", may be a junior synonym of L. carinata (=L. petersiana). The current status of L. ventralis Werner, 1917 is unclear. Following Parker (1942) Uetz and Hallerman (2012) treat L. ventralis as a possible synonym of L. petersiana, but Parker's work appears to be the only mention of this taxon in the literature since its original description. In the absence of any recent treatment of L. ventralis, and as this name has not been applied to a valid species for more than 75 years, this assessment follows Parker's proposal and Uetz and Hallerman (2012) in treating L. ventralis as a junior synonym of L. petersiana, although formal taxonomic work is needed to verify this assignment and the Somaliland type locality appears to lie outside the known range of L. petersiana.

Largen and Spawls (2006) follow Arillo et al. (1967) in considering the separation of L. petersiana from Latastia caerulopunctata "dubious", but take no taxonomic action. They do, however, assign records of "L. carinata" from the Danakil depression and from near Jaldessa (both in Ethiopia) to L. caerulopunctata, confining L. petersiana to Somalia. The Jaldessa record is however considered dubious by T. Mazuch (pers. comm. 2019), as based on his visits to the locality the habitat here is not suitable for L. caeruleopunctata, and L. petersiana is presumed to have similar ecological requirements.

Ineich (2001) indicates that Latastia scorteccii, traditionally regarded as a subspecies of L. doriai, is currently recognized as a full species. He provides no source or basis for this, however, and more recent work by Largen and Spawls (2006) recognizes only L. doriai. This account therefore includes L. d. scorteccii as a subspecies of L. doriai.

The appropriate generic placement of this species, which is known from a single damaged specimen, is unclear. The original assignment of this species to Eremias was found to be in error following clarification of identity of this genus (Arnold et al. 1998). These authors assigned the species to Mesalina, rejecting an alternative arrangement assigning the species to a monotypic genus, but raised some doubts about this assignment on the basis of certain characters and biogeography.

Lanza (1990) lists this species as a subspecies of Eremias (now Pseuderemias) mucronata without discussion. Apparently following this, Largen and Spawls (2006) list Eremias septemstriata as a junior synonym of P. mucronata, again without discussion. Pending clarification of the grounds for this treatment, this account follows Parker (1942) and Arnold (1986) in considering P. septemstriata a valid species.
This is likely to be a species complex, and it is not clear whether Kenyan populations represent the same species found at the Ituri type locality (P.K. Malonza, pers. comm. 2019).

The records provided for Lygodactylus gutturalis by Lanza (1990) correspond to two of the localities provided for L. picturatus keniensis (now L. keniensis) by Loveridge (1947), and presumably represent this latter species as L. gutturalis is not considered to occur in Somalia.

The exact taxonomic status of this form is somewhat confused. It was originally described as a full species (Parker 1935), but the describing author later assigned it subspecific status within the variable Latastia longicaudata (Parker 1942). Lanza (1983) appears to have coined the combination L. carinata caerulopunctata without discussion. Despite recognized similarity between these forms (Arillo et al. 1967) it is not clear that L. caerulopunctata has ever otherwise been relegated to subspecific status within L. carinata (now L. petersiana), and subsequent authors appear not to have recognized this action (e.g. Lanza 1990, Largen and Spawls 2006). Lanza (1990) consider L. carinata and L. caerulopunctata separate full species (again without discussion), and Largen and Spawls (2006) follow this author in considering that "There seem to be good reasons to follow Lanza (1990) and treat L. caeruleopunctata as a species distinct from L. longicaudata". These same authors follow Arillo et al. (1967) in considering the separation of this species from L. petersiana "dubious", but take no taxonomic action. They do, however, assign records of L. petersiana from the Danakil depression and from near Jaldessa (both in Ethiopia) to L. caerulopunctata, confining L. petersiana to Somalia.

Philochortus rudolfensis, previously considered a junior synonym of P. intermedius, is now considered to be a separate species by some authors (see Spawls et al. 2002). Uetz and Hallerman (2012) caution that only five specimens of this taxon are known, and suggest retaining it within P. intermedius pending further research, however, Spawls et al. (2002) suggest that the two taxa are unlikely to be closely-related due to apparent differences in their habitat requirements. This account therefore provisionally follows Spawls et al. (2002) in treating P. rudolfensis as a separate species.
Broadley and Wallach (2007) transferred this species from Rhinotyphlops to the resurrected genus Letheobia.

An early record of Agama doriae, a species not otherwise known east of the Rift Valley, from Ogaden in Ethiopia is likely to be attributable to this species, but this requires confirmation (Largen and Spawls 2006). Records from Somalia have been assigned to the new species A. somalica by Wagner et al. (2013).

Chirio and Ineich (2006) consider Mehelya savorgnani, traditionally treated as a subspecies of M. capensis, a full species based on differences in habitat, ventral count and colour pattern, but provide no detailed justification for this treatment and indicate that taxonomic work on this genus is required. This scheme has nevertheless been followed subsequently (Chirio and LeBreton 2007, Largen and Spawls 2010, Kelly et al. 2011). This taxon was not included in the genetic work carried out by Kelly et al. (2011), who assigned both species to the resurrected genus Gonionotophis, and so its relationship with G. capensis remains in need of clarification. Pending further work, this account tentatively follows Chirio and Ineich (2006) in treating G. savorgnani as a full species, a scheme accepted by Lanza and Broadley (2014). A record from Woroqi Galbeed in northern Somalia attributed to this taxon by Lanza (1990) is considered to represent G. unicolor by Largen and Spawls (2010). The species has since been transferred to the genus Limaformosa by Broadley et al. (2018).

Largen and Spawls (2010) and Kelly et al. (2011) treated Mehelya unicolor as a species distinct from M. capensis, and the latter in assigning both to the genus Gonionotophis. Kelly et al. (2011) did not address the specific status of this taxon and their molecular results indicate a close affinity with G. capensis. In a subsequent revision of the G. capensis group, Lanza and Broadley (2014) formally synonymized this species within G. (subsequently transferred to Limaformosa by Broadley et al. 2018) chanleri.
Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) erected the new genus Epacrophis for the former Leptotyphlops reticulatus species group, with Glauconia reticulata as the type species.

Broadley and Wallach (2007) redescribed this species, assigning the Ethiopian and Marsabit records to a new species, Leptotyphlops aethiopicus, as well as describing new species encompassing records of L. emini from Mt. Kilamanjaro (L. keniensis) and southwest Tanzania (L. mbanjensis). A further species removed from within L. emini, L. monticolus, was "insufficiently diagnosed" and has subsequently been considered a junior synonym of L. emini (Spawls et al. 2018).

This species was formerly placed in the synonymy of Leptotyphlops macrorhynchus, until it was resurrected by Wallach and Lanza (2004) based on an examination of the holotype.  Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) referred L. braccianii to their new genus Myriopholis.
Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) assigned this species to their new genus Myriopholis, but noted that this assignment was tentative in the absence of specimens to examine.

Wallach and Lanza (2004) revived this species from the synonymy of Leptotyphlops macrorhynchus. Previous records of this species and of L. cairi from Ethiopia and Eritrea refer instead to L. erythreaus. Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) assigned this species to their new genus Myriopholis.

Broadley and Wallach (2007) revised the species of Leptotyphlops occurring in northeastern Africa, erecting the new name L. tanae for populations of "L. longicaudus" in Kenya, Somalia and southern Ethiopia, and L. ionidesi for those from Tanzania to Malawi. These authors did not discuss or redescribe L. longicauda itself, however, by implication this taxon is now confined to southeastern Africa. Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) erected the new genus Myriopholis for the Leptotyphlops longicauda group of Broadley and Wallach (2007).

This species was described to encompass populations previously assigned to Leptotyphlops longicaudus (Broadley and Wallach 2007). Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) assigned this species to their new genus Myriopholis.
Prosymna stuhlmanni, formerly a subspecies of P. ambigua, is now generally considered a full species (e.g. Branch 1998, Broadley 1992,Uetz and Hallerman 2012,  Spawls et al. 2018).

Chelodina parkeri is a morphologically distinct and uncontroversially recognized species, with an adequate description and diagnosis (Rhodin and Mittermeier 1976, Georges et al. 2002, Georges and Thomson 2010, TTWG 2017). No subspecies or geographic variations are recognized, but it has not yet been genetically analyzed. It could conceivably be confused with Chelodina oblonga (formerly Chelodina siebenrocki or Chelodina rugosa), but these species do not occur sympatrically and C. parkeri is distinguished by the distinct white head patch immediately above and behind the tympanum, with or without dark blotches, and a ventral surface of the cervical scute longer than wide.
This is the sole member of its genus.
Records of this species from Australia represent confusion with Carlia storri, which was not recognized as a distinct taxon until Ingram and Covacevich (1989).

The former subspecies Glaphyromorphus crassicaudus arnhemicus (Storr, 1967) is now regarded as a full species by some authors (Greer 1989, Reeder 2003), but retained as a subspecies by Wilson and Swan (2013), although Greer (1989) found that arnhemicus was not the sister taxon to crassicaudus. It is not recognized by Cogger et al. (2014), who does not comment on this omission. G. Shea (pers. comm. 2017) considers it a valid species based on discrete morphology and distribution. Additionally, taxonomic issues may exist with Queensland populations as multiple species may be present under the name G. crassicaudus (P. Couper pers. comm. 2017). This account treats G. arnhemicus as a distinct taxon following Greer (1989), as future taxonomic changes within G. crassicaudatus will not impact the strongly allopatric G. arnhemicus (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
This species was described in 2003; it is a distinct species within the Varanus prasinus species group (Ziegler et al. 2007).
This species is part of the Varanus indicus species group, which was found to have relatively low genetic distances between species which suggests recent speciation (Ziegler et al. 2007).

There is significant taxonomic uncertainty surrounding this species, which is part of the Varanus prasinus complex (Ziegler et al. 2007). Extensive fieldwork on Rossel Island has been carried out without encountering the animal, and native people dispute that it exists; it may therefore be that the single specimen has incorrect locality data (S. Sweet pers. comm. 2007). Additionally Koch et al. (2014) expressed doubt about the validity of the taxon telenesetes on morphological grounds. The original green colouration of the type specimen has largely faded over the years and it now appears brownish gray. Therefore, the taxon telenesetes could represent a synonym of V. prasinus, which differs from V. telenestes mainly in colouration, but further evidence is needed. An approach to obtain sequence data from the holotype was not successful due to genetic degradation resulting from long-term preservation (A. Koch, pers. obs.).

McDowell (1984) notes that the subpopulation on the Huon Peninsula, north of New Guinea's central mountains, is completely isolated and appears to be morphologically distinct from records south of this range. This author suspected that the northern record may represent a separate species, however, with only a single specimen from this region he refrained from proposing any taxonomic changes.
There is a need to review the specimens currently allocated to this species, it may represent a complex of species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019).

This species has three subspecies:
T. mairii mairii (Gray, 1841)
T. mairii brongersmai Malnate & Underwood, 198)
T. mairii plumbea (Macleay, 1877).

T. m. brongersmai and T. m. plumbea are likely to be synonymous because of similar distribution.

Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis , with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus, although the name A. praelongus is still applied to this group by some authors (Wilson and Swan 2013). This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Subsequent work found that a Kimberley form, which had long been assumed to belong to the A. rugosus complex but not previously included in comparative analysis, warranted recognition as a distinct species related to A. pyrrhus (Maddock et al. 2015), to which Maddock et al. (2015) gave the name A. cryptadrymos. Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

Liasis fuscus has previously been treated as a junior synonym of L. mackloti following Stuhl (1932), which was formerly treated as being widespread in eastern Indonesia. Based on limited mtDNA sampling, Rawlings et al. (2004) found that Australian water pythons are divided into two clades, representing L. fuscus in Queensland and New Guinea and L. mackloti in the Northern Territory and the Indonesian islands Babar, Timor and Semau. Nevertheless, Australian workers have continued to recognize only a single water python species in this country pending resolution of taxonomic problems (Cogger 2014, Wilson and Swan 2017). The range limits of the resulting concept of L. fuscus have been unclear: Barker and Barker (1994) recognized New Guinean and Australian populations as being conspecific, consistent with colour variation reported by McDowell (1975). In contrast Cogger (2014) proposed considering it endemic to Australia. As the holotype belongs to the Queensland-New Guinea clade, D. Equerre (pers. comm. 2018) suggests that New Guinea populations should provisionally be assigned to this species, consistent with the scheme recently adopted in Barker et al. (2018).

Six different subspecies have been recognized in Australia (Barker and Barker 1994), largely based on colour pattern, although the boundaries between many of these are fluid and poorly defined (Cogger 2014). Of there only Morelia spilota imbricata is supported by genetic data and geographic isolation.

This status of populations assigned to this species in New Guinea is unclear (O'Shea 2007). Seven subspecies are typically recognized; the elevation of several to species level by Hoser (2000) was made without comment and has been rejected by subsequent workers (Schleip and O'Shea 2010). Hoser's proposed subspecies Morelia spilota harrisoni is poorly-defined, being based on a small sample with variable characters that overlap with previously recognized M. spilota subspecies, and is considered invalid by Schleip and O'Shea (2010). Additionally, it has been argued that the name Morelia harrisoni was not validly published (Kaiser et al. 2013). Pending resolution of taxonomic issues within New Guinea carpet pythons, it has recently been proposed that all New Guinea representatives of this species should be regarded as M. s. variegata sensu lato (forthcoming New Guinea python book).

Molecular analysis conducted by Rawlings and Donnellan (2003) found that Morelia viridis consists of two monophyletic lineages, corresponding to a north-south division in the region of New Guinea's central cordillera. These authors discussed the possibility that these two clades warranted recognition as two distinct species based on the degree of sequence divergence. They were unable to reliably determine range limits due to limited sampling along the apparent contact zone and declined to take taxonomic action pending further analysis, including the more thorough use of nuclear genes with wider geographic sampling. Rawlings and Donnellan (2003) noted that McDowell (1975) did not identify any morphological characters in New Guinean green pythons that appear to correspond to these clades and reported that there was no clear geographic barrier between the two taxa.

The northern clade, which was not named by Rawlings and Donnellan (2003), was associated with the available name Chondropython azureus Meyer, 1874 by Schleip and O'Shea (2010). Barker et al. (2015) coined the combination Morelia azurea for this taxon and designated a neotype, recognizing this taxon as the sister species to M. viridis. As the further research recommended by Rawlings and Donnellan (2003) has not been conducted to confirm the status and distribution limits of M. azurea, it is here retained within M. viridis.

The precise identity of this species appears to be uncertain. Largen (1997) and Lanza (1990) refer this name to a species found in Eritrea, Djibouti and Somalia. By contrast Joger (1987) refer records from Eritrea and Djibouti to Uromastyx princeps, an assignment considered in error by Ineich (2001), who considered a specimen from Djibouti referrable to this taxon (as U. ocellata macfadyeni). This situation was discussed by Wilms and Böhme (2007), who found that the Djibouti specimen was referrable to U. ocellata, and that the only specimens available that could be referred to U. macfadyeni are from Somalia. This account therefore follows this source and Wilms et al. (2009) in treating U. macfaydeni as a species endemic to Somalia.

The Uromastyx ocellata species group consists of six species, including the recent descriptions U. shobraki and U. yemenensis (Wilms and Schmitz 2007), which can be difficult to distinguish. A further species, U. macfadyeni, is not closely-related (Wilms et al. 2009) but has also sometimes been treated as a synonym of U. ocellata (Wilms and Böhme 2007). The species concept presented here is that of Wilms et al. (2009).
Molecular research by Kelly et al. (2008) confirmed the validity of Psammophis tanganicus, previously tentatively treated as distinct from P. biseriatus following Bezy and Drewes (1985).
Molecular research by Kelly et al. (2008) confirmed the validity of Psammophis tanganicus, tentatively treated as distinct from P. biseriatus since Bezy and Drewes (1985).

The taxonomy of the genus Cryptoblepharus is controversial and cannot be considered stable despite recent reviews by Rocha et al. (2006) and Horner (2007). Based on the results of their mitochondrial sequence analysis, Rocha et al. (2006) concluded that the subspecific assignments of the Western Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus are the most appropriate. By contrast, Horner (2007) used morphological characteristics from a small sample to elevate C. boutonii africanus to species status, and recognized it as distinct from its former synonym C. ahli. The taxonomy of Horner (2007) is followed in this assessment, in keeping with the adoption of a general evolutionary species paradigm in South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. However, it is acknowledged that taxon allocation in allopatric, highly mobile populations, such as those of the C. boutonii species complex, is controversial.

Weinell and Bauer (2018) examined morphological and genetic variation within the Trachylepis varia complex and identified eight major clades across the species' range. These authors' focus was on resolving the taxonomy of southern African members of this group, from which they revalidated Trachylepis laevigata and T. damarana. A clade recognized from most of Angola, Zambia and the southern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is likely to correspond to one of two recognized species, either T. albopunctatus or T. angolensis (Weinell and Bauer 2018). On this analysis Trachylepis varia sensu stricto corresponds to a clade ranging from the Tanzania-Mozambique border south through southeastern Africa. The status of the remaining candidate species, encompassing populations in East Africa, the Horn of Africa and the DRC, remains unresolved, and pending a full revision of this species complex these are retained within the concept of T. varia applied here.

Loveridge (1957) synonymized Mabuya isselii, known from Ethiopia and Eritrea, within M. varia. This author did not provide a detailed justification for this action, and recently several authors have used the name Mabuya isselii (Largen 1997; Largen and Spawls 2006, 2010) or Trachylepis isselii (Sindaco et al. 2012) to refer to a valid species. None of these authors, however, has commented on this assignment, and no clear diagnosis appears to exist that reliably distinguishes this taxon from T. varia (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2012). Pending the re-examination of material assigned to M. isselii recommended by Loveridge (1957), this account follows this author and Uetz and Hallerman (2012) in treating M. isselii as a junior synonym of T. varia.
Broadley and Wallach (2007) described this species based on two historical specimens from South Sudan originally attributed to Typhlops pallidus and first reported by Loveridge (1955).
Was placed in the new genus Megatyphlops by Broadley and Wallach (2009) and later transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014)

This species was for a long time treated as either a synonym or a subspecies of Rhinotyphlops (now Megatyphlops) schlegelli, although it was considered a full species without discussion by Spawls et al. (2002). Broadley and Wallach (2009) reviewed the R. schlegelli species complex in their revision of African blindsnakes, and formally resurrected M. brevis as a full species within their new genus Megatyphlops. The species was subsequently transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014)

Previously known by the name Rhinotyphlops schlegelli mucruso, but elevated to full species status and placed in the new genus Megatyphlops by Broadley and Wallach (2009) and later transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014)

Until recently, four subspecies were recognized under the name Rhinotyphlops schlegelii (schlegelii, petersii, mucruso, brevis; see Hahn 1980), but the latter two have now been elevated to species status within the genus Megatyphlops (Broadley and Wallach 2009) and later transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014). Rhinotyphlops s. petersii is considered a junior synonym of M. schlegelii (Broadley and Wallach 2009).

This taxon was described as a subspecies of Typhlops cuneirostris by Gans and Laurent (1965), and later synonymized with it (Roux-Esteve 1974). The review of African blind snakes by Broadley and Wallach (2009) supported its distinctiveness, and these authors removed T. calabresii from synonymy and elevated it to full species status. It was subsequently transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014)
Broadley and Wallach (2009) removed Typhlops calabresii from synonymy with this species.  Hedges et al. (2014) transferred this species to Afrotyphlops.

The status of Varanus ocellatus is uncertain; it has been variously treated as a synonym of either V. albigularis or V. exanthematicus (Bennett 2004). This account follows Bennett (2004) in considering this form a synonym of V. exanthematicus with a distribution in Sudan (presumably South Sudan given the distribution for V. exanthematicus provided by this author). Specimens from Djibouti, Somalia and Ethiopia previously attributed to V. ocellatus are now understood to represent V. albigularis (Ineich 2001, Largen and Spawls 2006). A phylogeographic study comparing populations throughout the range of V. albigularis would be informative, including clarification of the status of forms previously recognized as subspecies but rejected by Broadley and Howell (1991), and the currently recognized subspecies V. a. angolensis. Currently three subspecies are recognized: Varanus a. albigularis (southern Africa, north to Angola, Zambia, Mozambique), V. albigularis angolensis (Angola, Namibia, Zambia, DR Congo), V. albigularis microstictus (northeastern Africa, Ethiopia to northern and central Mozambique) (Auliya and Koch 2020).

The validity of this species is uncertain, as the three known specimens may be referable to the widespread and variable Echis pyramidum species complex (McDiarmid et al. 1999), the systematics of which have never been reviewed across the species' entire range (Pook et al. 2009, J. Penner pers. comm. 2012). The species' description, in Russian in a journal to which few taxonomists have access (Cherlin 1990) further complicates comparative work (J. Penner pers. comm. 2012). No genetic material is available for comparison, and so the molecular study by Pook et al. (2009) was unable to clarify the validity of this form. These authors included this species within their E. pyramidum complex on the basis of morphology, but noted that based on their results unrecognized cryptic diversity probably exists within E. pyramidum in the Horn of Africa.

The status of this taxon, which is sometimes listed as a subspecies of Afrotyphlops punctatus or occasionally of A. congestus, is "not yet stable" (Böhme et al. 2011). Branch and Rödel (2003) elected to recognize it as a distinct species pending genetic research, and this arrangement was followed without comment by Broadley and Wallach (2009), who listed listed Typhlops liberiensis as a valid species assigned to their new genus Afrotyphlops. Trape and Baldé (2014) supported this arrangement on the basis of examination of Guinean specimens and "preliminary" molecular data.

Originally treated under the genus Typhlops, was transferred to the new genus Megatyphlops by Broadley and Wallach (2009) and later transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014) and then to Letheobia (Wallach and Gemel 2018).
The conspecific nature of the populations from each island needs review, as these may represent distinct species.
Originally treated under the genus Typhlops, was transferred to the new genus Megatyphlops by Broadley and Wallach (2009) and later transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).
This former species complex was revised by Broadley and Wallach (2007), restricting Letheobia pallida sensu stricto to Zanzibar.

Cherchi (1954) described a new subspecies Uromastyx princeps scortecci from Eil (Nugaal, Puntland). All populations of U. princeps from a few kilometres north of Eyl to a few kilometers south of Obbia (Cherchi 1958), as far south as Meregh or Mogadishu have been assigned to this form. Subsequently, Moody (1987) synonymized U. p. scortecci within U. p. princeps until more material is available to clarify its status. This account follows this and subsequent authorities (Wilms 2005, Wilms et al. 2009) in considering U. princeps to be monotypic until molecular data and an integrative systematic revision is able to clarify relationships within this group.

The taxonomic history of this species is complicated by historical confusion with Chamaeleo africanus. Ineich (2001) placed C. calcaricarens in the synonymy of C. africanus without discussion. Largen and Spawls (2006) discussed its similarity to Chamaeleo africanus, and concluded that the only morphologically diagnosable character, a hemipenal character, was unreliable. They therefore formally referred C. calcaricarens to the synonymy of C. africanus. In contrast, Tilbury (2010) indicated that hemipenal characters reliably distinguish this species from C. africanus and formally resurrected C. calcaricarens (previously considered valid without comment by Tilbury and Tolley 2009). This action is supported by evidence from a recent molecular phylogeny of the Chamaeleonidae that C. africanus from Niger and C. calcaricarens from Borama in Somalia are distinct at the species level (Tolley et al. 2013). Trape et al. (2012) apparently overlooked the resurrection of C. calcaricarens in describing C. africanus as ranging east as far as Somalia.
This species is currently subject to taxonomic revision.
This is a species complex, whose taxonomy is unresolved (Cogger 2000).
This species is currently under taxonomic review (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017). Records of this species outside of the Kimberleys are misidentifications.

Recently, Smith et al. (2011) used genetic data to identify several lineages within the nominal taxa Diporiphora bilineata, indicating the possible presence of multiple cryptic taxa with highly conserved morphology and making species identifications difficult.
This species is currently under taxonomic revision (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017).

Manthey and Denzer (2016) examined genetic material and voucher specimens for Melanesian Hypsilurus (sensu lato) and Australian outgroups including the two representatives of this genus. The results supported an earlier suggestion (Manthey and Denzer 2006) that the Australian taxa and Melanesian H. dilophus, the type species of the genus Lophosaurus, formed a separate species group from the remaining Oceanian taxa. While Manthey and Denzer (2016) deferred nomenclatural changes to Melanesian Hypsilurus sensu lato pending further work, these authors resurrected Lophosaurus for the clade containing H. dilophis, H. spinipes and H. boydii.

Manthey and Denzer (2016) examined genetic material and voucher specimens for Melanesian Hypsilurus (sensu lato) and Australian outgroups including the two representatives of this genus. The results supported an earlier suggestion (Manthey and Denzer 2006) that the Australian taxa and Melanesian H. dilophus, the type species of the genus Lophosaurus, formed a separate species group from the remaining Oceanian taxa. While Manthey and Denzer (2016) deferred nomenclatural changes to Melanesian Hypsilurus sensu lato pending further work, these authors resurrected Lophosaurus for the clade containing H. dilophis, H. spinipes and H. boydii.

This species was long included within Physignathus alongside the Chinese water dragon Physignathus cocincinus, however recent genetic research indicates that P. cocincinus is no more closely-related to P. leuseurii than it is to other Australian agamids (Townsend et al. 2011). These authors resurrected the generic name Istiurus to accommodate the Australian species, however Amey et al. (2012) pointed out that this name is a junior synonym of Hydrosaurus, and so is not available for the eastern water dragon. These authors resurrected the name Intellagama for this taxon.

Lophognathus maculilabris is included by Melville et al. (2011) within L. temporalis, which has a type locality on nearby Timor Laut and is widespread in northern Australia and New Guinea, on the basis that there is little genetic divergence between the samples from Tanimbar and northern Australia.
This species is similar in some respects to Hemidactylus platycephalus Peters, 1854, but the latter has a more southerly distribution and the ranges of the two are not known to overlap.

Literature references differ on the correct gender of the species name; both striata and striatus are used, the former more commonly, however, the species appears to have been described as striatus (see list of basionyms in Uetz and Hallerman 2012). Parker (1942) raises doubts about the validity of this species, noting its similarity to Pseuderemias brenneri. He declines to take formal taxonomic action on the basis that "certain differences ... have not yet been shown to be invalid, and a conservative attitude has been adopted until more definitive evidence is forthcoming". The taxonomy of this species does not appear to have been subject to any subsequent investigation and so its validity must still be considered uncertain pending further research.

The complicated nomenclatural history of the name Lygodactylus picturatus is discussed by Röll (2000). This author rejects the poorly-substantiated proposal by Pasteur (1965) that the holotype represents the species now known as L. mombasicus, and considers this author's name L. luteopicturatus to be a junior synonym of L. picturatus: Spawls et al. (2018) concur that L. luteopicturatus is "almost certainly" a junior synonym of L. picturatus, and this scheme is followed here. The combination Lygodactylus sudanensis is used in the key by Largen (1997) and by Largen and Spawls (2010), in both cases without justification; this was subsequently followed by Spawls et al. (2018). This account follows the generally accepted concept of Lygodactylus picturatus, including the two subspecies L. p. picturatus and L. p. sudanensis. The status of L. p. zanzibaritis requires clarification: this former subspecies of L. luteopicturatus is accepted as a subspecies of L. picturatus by Spawls et al. (2018), but was not explicitly discussed by Röll (2004). Two previously accepted subspecies, L. p. gutturalis and L. p. mombasicus, are now regarded as a full species.
It is thought that populations of Leptosiaphos aloysiisabaudiae from Nigeria and Cameroon may represent a separate, undescribed species (Chirio and LeBreton 2007).

Cyrtodactylus loriae is considered to be a species complex; in this account, "true" C. loriae is considered to range from the Owen Stanley Range to Milne Bay, with records elsewhere attributed to undescribed members of the complex. It is likely that even this restricted concept of C. loriae includes populations attributable to two different taxa (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2015).

Records from New Guinea are in error, reflecting confusion with C. mimikanus (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2015). C. marmoratus as previously understood is a species complex composed of many species, only some of which have been described (e.g. C. sadleiri from Christmas Island, C. deveti from Halmahera Island and Morotai Island, C. halmahericus from Halmahera and Saram islands). Additional species are likely to be described from other parts of the range (J. McGuire and D. Iskandar per. comm. 2017).

Specimens referred to Cyrtodactylus mimikanus collected at Yongsu, Cyclops Mountains, Foja Mountains, Wapoga River Basin, and the Mamberamo Basin (all in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea) represent an undescribed species (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2014). This other taxon also occurs in the far northwest of Papua New Guinea (Kraus and Allison 2006, Rösler et al. 2007, Oliver et al. 2011, P. Oliver. pers. coms. 2014).

Populations from Raja Ampas, Geelvink Bay area and elsewhere on the Vogelkop Peninsula appear to represent a different species (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2014), but taxonomic action is not likely to be undertaken in the near future (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2016). These populations are consequently retained within Cyrtodactylus papuensis until further research clarifies species limits within this group.

Records attributed to Gehyra baliola from the Australian mainland are doubtful, as there has been no recent revision to clarify their identity. Available keys are not helpful in verifying the identity of these specimens (C. Hoskin and P. Couper pers. comm. 2017) and an undescribed species sometimes referred to G. baliola is known to occur at the northern tip of Cape York (C. Hoskin pers. comm. 2017).
The taxonomy of the medium sized Gehyra group in New Guinea is very poorly known and the validity and distribution of all taxa is unclear (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2014).

This species is thought to be a junior synonym of Gehyra insulensis (R. Fisher pers. comm. 2013). The holotype has yet to be examined following the recent revalidation of G. insulensis, and G. lampei is here treated as a valid species pending a formal taxonomic revision.

This species is thought to be a junior synonym of Gehyra insulensis (R. Fisher pers. comm. 2013). The holotype has yet to be examined following the recent revalidation of G. insulensis, and G. leopoldi is here treated as a valid species pending a formal taxonomic revision.

The taxonomy of this species complex, encompassing the names Gehyra papuana, G. interstitialis and G. lampei has long been intractable. In common with Brongersma (1934) recent workers provisionally assign all medium-sized Gehyra from mainland New Guinea to a single taxon under the name G. papuana (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2014). Genetic work is presently underway to clarify the status of populations from the north and east of New Guinea included here within G. papuana (P. Oliver unpubl. data), and four different clades have so far been identified within this complex (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2016). The status of southern populations is in need of clarification once genetic material becomes available (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2014).
Oliver et al. (2018) found a deep genetic divergence within this species, suggesting that further taxonomic research is needed and that this may be a complex of two species.
A divergent population of this species is known from the English Company Islands (Craig Moritz pers. comm. 2017).
This species' distribution, encompassing several archipelagos off the coast of New Guinea, suggests that it may be a complex of several island-endemic cryptic species (A. Allison pers. comm. 2014).

Zug et al. (2004) assigned New Guinean records of this species to the new taxa Carlia aenigma and C. aramia, restricting C. longipes to northern and northeastern Australia. On the basis of mitochondrial, allozyme and morphological data, Donnellan et al. (2009) subsequently authors assigned records from the Northern Territory, the northern Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait islands to a distinct species, for which the name Carlia sexdentata was available, and several records from Darnley Island to a third species, Carlia quinquecarinata.
Work is underway to attempt to resolve the systematics of this taxon, which is thought to represent a species complex (C. Hoskin pers. comm. 2017).

This species is known with certainty only from the southern end of Cenderawasih Bay and the area around Timika, both in Indonesian New Guinea. Museum specimens referred to this species come from all parts of mainland New Guinea, the Aru and Kei Islands, and Halmahera, Seram, and satellite islands, but these certainly represent a complex of species, the taxonomy of which that will require access to more continuously sampled series of living material to resolve (Kraus 2007).
There are three subspecies.

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017), one of which was genetically close to C. spaldingi. Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to the clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved polyphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingi and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size). Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017), one of which was genetically close to C. spaldingi. Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to the clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved polyphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingi and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size). Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. spaldingi following Cogger (2014).

Differences between populations from New Guinea and Cape York and those from the remainder of the species' Australian range suggest that this taxon may be a species complex (G. Shea and A. Allison pers. comm. 2014).
This species is known to be a complex of closely related species, currently undergoing revision (Goldberg and Kraus 2008).

Distribution suggests that this may be a species complex or populations may be introduced (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). How et al. (1998) reports that the specimen from Selaru differs morphologically from the range of characters in this species' description, but that describing it as a distinct taxon would be premature as only a single specimen is known.

Leiolopisma sembalunicum, described from Lombok, is presently a junior synonym of this taxon. Material has not recently been collected from Lombok and the status of this taxon is in need of clarification.

This species might well be a junior synonym of Tribolonotus novaeguineae. Zweifel (1966) found no clearly-defined differences between the two taxa, which were distinguished based mainly on subjective characters and a difference in colouration that cannot be determined from preserved species. This author cautioned against synonymizing the two taxa as he had not examined the type specimens of either species. No more recent treatment has investigated this issue, and as such the distributions of the two taxa relative to one another are uncertain. Records of the two forms in sympatry are likely to represent  differences in identification by different collectors rather than the genuine co-occurrence of two taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2014)

Tribolonotus gracilis might well be a junior synonym of Tribolonotus novaeguineae. Zweifel (1966) found no clearly-defined differences between the two taxa, which were distinguished based mainly on subjective characters and a difference in colouration that cannot be determined from preserved species. This author cautioned against synonymizing the two taxa as he had not examined the type specimens of either species. No more recent treatment has investigated this issue, and as such the distributions of the two taxa relative to one another are uncertain. Records of the two forms in sympatry are likely to represent  differences in identification by different collectors rather than the genuine co-occurrence of two taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2014)

The disjunct distribution of this species, with no records from well-surveyed intervening areas, suggests that it may be a species complex (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). It is not presently possible to clarify the taxonomy of Sphenomorphus anotus, as specimens from all localities are morphologically similar and genetic material is available from only one population (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015).

This species, which is apparently present over most of New Guinea (also in the central mountain ranges), in the Bismarck Archipelago and in the Admiralty Islands, is possibly a group of closely related species; names available for different populations include cranei, derooyae, maindroni, and wolfi. The Bismarck and Admiralty Island populations, which differ from those on the mainland, have often been named Sphenomorphus maindroni. However, the type locality of S. maindroni is Haar (or Haas) on the New Guinea mainland in Indonesian New Guinea (Boulenger 1887). Dr. A. Greer considers that the holotype of S. maindroni is the only positively known specimen of this taxon, and the name is therefore not available for island populations. Pending a more detailed study of populations presently contained within S. derooyae, all specimens assigned to this taxon are here considered to belong to S.  derooyae.

Recent collections containing significant numbers of small Sphenomorphus have allowed a preliminary investigation of this species' taxonomy (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). The results suggest that this species exhibits high levels of genetic diversity, even between nearby populations at different elevations (including low- and higher-elevation samples from the type locality) (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). Additionally, every known local population can be distinguished by at least one consistent morphological character (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). It is therefore likely that S. forbesi represents a species complex, and further work is required to clarify species limits within this group.

Sphenomorphus muelleri is a species complex whose taxonomy has not been the subject of significant published research for over a century, although multiple morphotypes have long been recognized (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). Differences between these morphotypes allow names to be assigned to each once their taxonomy is clarified, and to determine that "true" S. muelleri is the name applicable to subpopulations ranging to the west the type locality (Lobo in Triton Bay), mainly along the Vogelkop Peninsula.

To date, the only one of these taxa to have been formally removed from synonymy is S. latifasciatus. The name S. englishi is available for the morphotype found across most of the New Guinea mainland, but requires formal elevation from synonymy (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). Records from Maluku and the Aru Islands represent an additional undescribed species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015).

Further research is needed to clarify whether the wide but apparently discontinuous distribution of this species reflects cryptic diversity. It is possible that Sphenomorphus oligolepis sensu stricto may have a restricted range in the area of the Mimika River type locality (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
This is a species complex, and taxonomic research is presently underway (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

This species has three recognized subspecies: Varanus panoptes panoptes Storr, 1980, V. p. rubidus Storr, 1980 and V. p. horni Böhme, 1988. Molecular evidence suggests that at least the two Australian subspecies may be specifically distinct (S. Keogh and S. Donnellan, unpubl. data)
The taxonomic validity of this species remains uncertain because diagnostic morphological characters largely overlap with Varanus prasinus from New Guinea (Koch et al. 2010).
Although this species was found to exhibit neither morphological nor geographic variation by van Rooijen et al. (2015), M. O'Shea (unpubl. data) comments that it may represent a species complex.

Dendrelaphis girii was described based on the holotype from Castle Rock, Karnataka and five paratypes from Goa, Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra, India (Vogel and Van Rooijen in 2011). This species had previously been confused with D. bifrenalis, a species now understood to be endemic to Sri Lanka (Vogel and Van Rooijen 2011).

This species closely-resembles Dendrelaphis cyanochloris, with which it is sympatric in at least part of its Thai range (Vogel et al. 2012). A record from western Thailand reported by Pauwels et al. (2003) that these authors attributed to D. cyanochloris was found to represent D. nigroserratus by Vogel et al. (2012).

The taxonomy of Dendrelaphis snakes has long been poorly-resolved, and has further been confused in the Australo-Papuan region by varied taxonomic treatments involving as many as 28 nominal taxa (species, subspecies and varieties) (van Rooijen et al. 2015). Dendrelaphis calligaster alone was recognized as containing six subspecies by Meise and Hennig (1932), all which were subsequently treated as full species (see discussion in van Rooijen et al. 2015). While recognizing that the status of many of these taxa was uncertain, Cogger et al. (1983) synonymized these taxa and D. lineolatus within D. calligaster; two of these (D. salomonis and D. papuensis) were revalidated the following year by McDowell (1984).

Van Rooijen et al. (2015) attempted the most comprehensive morphological revision of Australo-Papuan Dendrelaphis to date, based on a sample of 171 museum specimens from New Guinea, Australia and Palau and including type specimens for 20 of the nominal taxa (no types surviving for four others, and the remainder being examined based on photographs as the specimens were unavailable). This work confirmed the validity of Dendrelaphis papuensis, but suggested that the species may have a more restricted distribution than previously assumed.

van Rooijen and Vogel (2008) resurrected Dendrelaphis schokari from synonymy with D. tristis on morphological grounds, applying this name to a number of records from Sri Lanka and five from the Western Ghats in southwest India. Shortly thereafter, van Rooijen and Vogel (2009) determined that Indian records represented a distinct species, and that the name Dendrelaphis chairecacos was available for these populations.

Kaiser et al. (2018) note that one of the diagnostic characters used to identify juvenile Stegonotus diehli is not reliable, and "do not believe that this name has been applied consistently or with the data from the holotype in mind". Although Kaiser et al. (2018) treat this species as valid they do not characterize its distribution (which they indicate is the subject of ongoing research) and the only specimen they attribute to this species is the holotype, and note that work is in preparation to clarify the identity of S. diehli sensu stricto.

Records of Stegonotus guentheri away from Milne Bay have been reported from several offshore islands, but are thought likely to be misidentifications (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015). Research is underway to clarify the complicated taxonomy of Stegonotus and will reexamine these island specimens (C. Kaiser in prep.). Until this work is complete this account follows O'Shea (1996) in considering S. guentheri endemic to Milne Bay.

McDowell (1972) examined three specimens from New Britain and Duke of York Island that he tentatively reported as "Stegonotus spec. cf. parvus", based on a hemipenal character and unusually high ventral counts in the two male specimens. While he considered this form likely to represent a distinct species, he declined to take taxonomic action on the basis that further material from New Britain may reveal that this simply reflects geographical variation within typical S. parvus. Recently Kaiser et al. (2018) revised the taxonomy of Stegonotus, and assigned a neotype for this species. These authors did not characterize the distribution of this species, and indicate that this is the subject of ongoing research (Kaiser et al. 2018). Pending the completion of this work, this account applies the previously-understood concept of this species' distribution.

This species lacks a traceable type specimen and the proposed holotype has been assigned to this taxon incorrectly, complicating resolution of taxonomic issues within this likely species complex (Kieckbusch et al. 2018).

Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis , with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus. This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis , with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus. This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

The diagnostic features of this species were poorly-described (P. Couper pers. comm. 2017), and it may form a cline of variation between A. rugosus to the north and A. antarcticus to the south (Wüster et al. 2005). Longstanding taxonomic issues (summarized by Wüster et al. 2005) exist within Acanthophis, with the names A. praelongus and A. antarcticus having been widely used to encompass both Australian and New Guinean taxa, including a number of Australian populations flagged as being distinct (Wüster et al. 2005). These authors provide the first modern phylogenetic framework for analyzing variation in the genus, and attribute Northern Territory and northern Queensland representatives of their 'clade A1' to the Acanthophis rugosus complex, a form shared with New Guinea and previously treated as a subspecies of A. antarcticus. This clade is itself divided into two broadly sympatric forms and Wüster et al. (2005) note that the oldest name available for the second clade is Acanthophis hawkei. Although these authors refrain from considering this taxon a separate species and no subsequent taxonomic work appears to have validated it, Threatened Species Scientific Committee (2012) state that "[Acanthophis hawkei] is conventionally accepted as a distinct species". Detailed systematic research is required to resolve outstanding issues within this complex, as molecular approaches alone may be insufficient and a number of candidate species within the group exhibit sympatric or parapatric distributions (Wüster et al. 2005).

Demansia reticulata reticulata and D. reticulata cupreiceps have long been considered subspecies of Demansia psammophis, in part following Storr et al. (1986). This treatment was followed by Wilson and Swan (2013) while Cogger (2014) recognized only D. r. reticulata as being distinct from D. psammophis. These arrangements neglect evidence presented by Hutchinson and Tyler (1996) that D. psammophis and D. reticulata (=D. r. cupreiceps of Storr 1978) co-occur in the Flinders Ranges with no evidence of intergradation. This suggests a species boundary exists between between D. psammophis and D. r. cupreiceps, and the most recent treatments follow Storr (1978) in treating D. reticulata, including D. r. cupreiceps, as a species distinct from D. psammophis (e.g. Wallach et al. 2014).
There is a degree of taxonomic uncertainty about this species (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017).
The boundary between this species and Furina ornata is poorly defined and requires resolution both geographically and taxonomically (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Numerous intermediate forms exist.
The boundary between this species and Furina diadema is poorly defined and requires resolution both geographically and taxonomically (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Numerous intermediate forms exist.
Sometimes confused with Psedonaja mengdeni, an therefore probably under-recorded.

This species was described (as Pseudechis pailsei, later emended to pailsi - Wüster et al. 2001) from Queensland and the assignment of Northern Territory records, which were found to be significantly genetically different by Wüster et al. (2005), to this species has been considered tentative. This issue is further complicated by the taxonomy of this and several related 'pygmy mulga snakes' (Pseudechis australis group), three of which (P. rossignoli, P. pailsi and P. weigeli) were described outside the peer-reviewed literature and between which species limits have subsequently been unclear (Wüster et al. 2005, Kuch et al. 2005, Maddock et al. 2017). The original description of P. pailsei was made without reference to the earlier description of Cannia weigeli, and supposedly diagnostic features of these forms appear to be identical (Wüster et al. 2001). Maddock et al. (2017) conducted a wide-ranging genetic study of this group in an effort to clarify species delimitation. These authors caution that their sampling is limited, but their results provisionally support recognition of P. pailsi, P. weigeli and P. rossignoli as distinct species, and of a tenth species they refer to as 'NT dwarf form' which appears to correspond to Northern Territory records previously assigned to P. pailsi. These authors' sampling only included three samples of P. pailsi and they acknowledge that additional data is required to confirm specific status for both the Northern Territory form (which was recovered as the sister taxon to P. pailsi) and P. weigeli. No attempt has been made to characterize morphological differences between these three putative taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The systematics of Pseudechis are quite unsettled and it is possible that Pseudechis rossignolii may turn out to be conspecific with an Australian taxon (Allison 2006). Molecular research suggests that P. rossignoli is likely to be valid (Wüster et al. 2005) and it was found to be strongly supported (albeit on the basis of limiting sampling) by Maddock et al. (2017). Wüster et al. (2005) note, however, that the species was described on the basis of "inadequate character evidence" and so a formal re-description may be required.

The taxonomy of this and several related 'pygmy mulga snakes' (Pseudechis australis group) has been complicated to resolve, in part because three of these species (P. rossignoli, P. pailsi and P. weigeli) were described outside the peer-reviewed literature species limits have subsequently been unclear (Wüster et al. 2005, Kuch et al. 2005, Maddock et al. 2017).  The original description of P. pailsei (=P. pailsi - Wüster et al. 2001) was made without reference to the earlier description of Cannia weigeli, and supposedly diagnostic features of these forms appear to be identical (Wüster et al. 2001). Maddock et al. (2017) conducted the first wide-ranging genetic study of this group in an effort to clarify species delimitation within the P. australis group. These authors caution that their sampling is limited, but their results provisionally support recognition of P. pailsi, P. weigeli and P. rossignoli as distinct species, and of a tenth species they refer to as 'NT dwarf form' which appears to correspond to Northern Territory records previously assigned to P. pailsi. These authors' sampling only included three samples of P. pailsi and they acknowledge that additional data is required to confirm specific status for both the Northern Territory form (which was recovered as the sister taxon to P. pailsi) and P. weigeli. No attempt has been made to characterize morphological differences between these three putative taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The original description of this taxon erroneously applied the name Leiopython albertisii bennetti, in contravention of nomenclatural rules regarding the use of eponyms referring to more than one person, and was emended to bennettorum by Wüster et al. (2001). Schleip (2008) elevated the taxon to specific status. The validity of the original description has, however, been questioned (Kaiser et al. 2013) on the basis that it appears not to have been validly published. Subsequently, Schleip (2014) proposed the new name Leiopython montanus for this taxon, which was accepted by Barker et al. (2015), and this account follows this arrangement.

No genetic revision of Leiopython has been undertaken, with several species (L. biakensis, L. fredparkeri, L. huonensis and L. montanus) having recently been described only from museum material, none with collection dates more recent than 1967. Live specimens are known only for L. albertsii and L. meridionalis, in part due to the difficulty of tracing specimens from remote areas of New Guinea (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). The validity of these taxa must consequently be considered uncertain.

No genetic revision of Leiopython has been undertaken, with several recent species (L. biakensis, L. fredparkeri, L. huonensis and L. montanus) having been described only from museum material, none with collection dates more recent than 1967. Live specimens are known only for L. albertsii and L. meridionalis, in part due to the difficulty of tracing specimens from remote areas of New Guinea (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). The validity of these taxa must consequently be considered uncertain.

No genetic revision of Leiopython has been undertaken, with several species (L. biakensis, L. fredparkeri, L. huonensis and L. montanus) having recently been described only from museum material, none with collection dates more recent than 1967. Live specimens are known only for L. albertsii and L. meridionalis, in part due to the difficulty of tracing specimens from remote areas of New Guinea (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). The validity of these taxa must consequently be considered uncertain.

The validity of the name Leiopython hoserae, used both in the original description (Hoser 2000) and the subsequent formal recognition of this taxon as a full species (Schleip 2008), has been questioned on the basis that the original description - which was not widely accepted (Schleip 2008) - appears not to have been validly published (Kaiser et al. 2013). Subsequently, Schleip (2014) proposed the new name Leiopython meridionalis for this taxon, subsequently accepted by Barker et al. (2015), and this account follows this arrangement.

No genetic revision of Leiopython has been undertaken, with several species (L. biakensis, L. fredparkeri, L. huonensis and L. montanus) having recently been described only from museum material, none with collection dates more recent than 1967. Live specimens are known only for L. albertsii and L. meridionalis, in part due to the difficulty of tracing specimens from remote areas of New Guinea (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). The validity of these taxa must consequently be considered uncertain.

This species is closely allied to, and sometimes treated as a subspecies of, Morelia spilota (Cogger 2014). Pending resolution of the systematics of the Morelia spilota group, and due to the geographic separation of the two taxa, this account follows Cogger (2014) in treating M. bredli as a full species. Barker and Barker (1994) refer a specimen from the Tanami Desert to M. bredli that exhibits intermediate characters between M. bredli and M. spilota variegata. Genetic material is not available to confirm this assignment and pending resolution of the taxonomy of this species group the Tanami record, which is some way to the north of the known range of M. bredli, is not considered in this assessment.

Hedges et al. (2014) found that Ramphotyphlops polygrammicus was polyphyletic, with the nominate form (which has a type locality on Timor) being appropriately assigned to their new genus Sundatyphlops, while Australian samples nested within the Australian radiation Anilios. These authors identify two potentially diagnostic morphological characters for the Australian taxon, for which the only available name is Typhlops torresianus (described from Murray Island). Hedges et al. (2014) caution that future taxonomic work is likely to reveal that the remaining populations retained within S. polygrammicus may represent distinct species, based on their occurrence on separate islands and some morphological differences. Previous reviews of this taxon have used characters from multiple populations which are no longer included within this species, and a careful review of museum material assigned to S. polygrammicus is required (Hedges et al. 2014). As defined by Hedges et al. (2014), S. polygrammicus presently consists of five subspecies each from a different island following De Lang (2011), and these authors consider Typhlops soensis (from Timor) a junior synonym of S. p. polygrammicus.
This is a species complex (M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).
The validity of subspecific divisions in this taxon are unclear, as they have not been supported by preliminary genetic data (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).

Taxonomic issues within Pseudonaja nuchalis, long considered to be a widespread Australian species, were first suggested by Mengden (1985). Mengden (1985) concluded that at least three, and potentially as many as nine, taxa exist within P. nuchalis, although he provided limited karyotypic and morphological data to enable the true number of species-level taxa included within this species complex to be critically evaluated (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Investigation of colour pattern variation (Bush 1989a,b, Orange 1992) demonstrated that at least some of this variation could not be used to delimit species within this group. Skinner et al. (2005) conducted the first molecular analysis of the putative species identified by Mengden (1985) and distinguished three distinct genetic lineages. Subsequently, Skinner (2009) used combined morphological and molecular data to recognize three distinct species: P. mengdeni, P. aspidorhyncha and P. nuchalis sensu stricto (the latter representing the northern "Darwin morph" of Mengden 1985). Sampling of all three taxa was limited for such a wide-ranging species complex and not fully consistent between the 2005 and 2009 studies, and neither study included specimens from Queensland or northern regions of Western Australia, while being limited for the Northern Territory (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
