It is consequently unclear to which taxon the majority of records from northern Australia belong, and although Skinner (2009) referred a single historical specimen from the Stannery Hills in Queensland to the synonymy of P. nuchalis on the basis of morphology, this assignment was made without genetic data. Further complicating this situation is the lack of unequivocal diagnostic characters distinguishing P. nuchalis s.s. from P. mengdeni (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Seven subspecies have so far been described, however, a taxonomic review is required as some may represent full species (Spawls et al. 2018). Broadley et al. (2003) recognize D. l. shirana as the full species D. shirana, noting that "many of the isolated populations of the north seem to represent good evolutionary species". Largen and Spawls (2010) indicate that the name Duberria abyssinica would be applicable to another northern population, endemic to the Ethiopian highlands, if found to be distinct, but while noting that northern populations are "almost certainly" distinct species these authors prefer to apply the name D. lutrix to Ethiopian populations. Pending a formal revision that clarifies the distribution of true D. lutrix and other taxa within this species complex, we follow Largen and Spawls (2010) in retaining northern forms, including D. shirana and D. abyssinica, within D. lutrix.

Two allopatric subspecies of Duberria lutrix are recognized in southern Africa, namely D. l. lutrix (South Africa, Lesotho, and Eswatini (Swaziland)) and D. l. rhodesiana (Zimbabwe and Mozambique), but they are genetically deeply divergent and probably represent separate species (Bates et al. 2014). Broadley and Blaylock (2013) noted that molecular data suggests that most recognized subspecies of D. lutrix, extending from the Cape to Ethiopia—including D. l. rhodesiana—probably represent distinct species.

Historically, Limaformosa [=Gonionotophis] capensis formed a species complex that including several subspecies (L. c. capensis, L. c. savorgnani, L. c. unicolor, L. c. chanleri, and L. c. fiechteri). Recent revisions (Lanza and Broadley 2014, Broadley et al. 2018) have elevated or reassigned all subspecies leaving Limaformosa capensis monotypic.
This species was originally regarded as a subspecies of Meizodon semiornatus, but was elevated to full species status in 1982 (Spawls et al. 2002).
The monotypic genus Aeluroglena is very similar to Meizodon, and further research may eventually show it to be indistinguishable (M. Largen pers. comm. 2008).
Formerly placed under Gonionotophis, this species has been transferred to the newly erected genus, Gracililima (Broadley et al. 2018).

This species was treated as a synonym of Hemirhagerrhis nototaenia until the revision of this genus by Broadley and Hughes (2000) resurrected it. This action was unfortunately not recognized by Spawls et al. (2002), who included records of H. hildebrandti from East Africa within their account for H. nototaenia, but has been followed by subsequent authors (e.g. Largen and Spawls 2010).

This species has two subspecies: Prosymna a. ambigua Bocage, 1873 and P. ambigua bocagii (Boulenger, 1897)  P. stuhlmanni, formerly a subspecies of P. ambigua, is now generally considered a full species (e.g. Branch 1998, Broadley 1992, Uetz and Hallerman 2012, Spawls et al. 2018).

authority: Crottini, Miralles, Glaw, Harris, Lima & Vences, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Formally elevated to species level having previously been included within F. lateralis (Florio et al. 2012).

authority: Florio, Ingram, Rakotondravony, Louis Jr. & Raxworthy, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Formally elevated to species level having previously been included within F. lateralis (Florio et al. 2012).

The larger form from the arid south (formerly treated as F. lateralis ssp. major) is now recognized to be a separate species, Furcifer major Florio et al. 2012). In addition, populations of F. lateralis from the north-west of its distribution are also recognised as a new species, Furcifer viridis (Florio et al. 2012).

Kinyongia gyrolepis is the sister species to Kinyongia adolfifriderici and superficially looks very similar (Greenbaum et al. 2012). Its name, however, is a reference to the enlarged circular scales that are found on its flanks, a trait not seen in Kinyongia adolfifriderici.

authority: Stipala, Lutzmánn, Malonza, Wilkinson, Godley, Nyamache & Evans, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Although this species was revalidated by Hughes (1985), removing Philothamnus irregularis from southern Africa, Branch (2018) note that this action has sometimes been neglected, including literature as recent as Ceriaco et al. (2014, 2016) and so P. irregularis is sometimes erroneously included in the Angolan species list.

Alexander (1987) suggested that the subspecies Philothamnus natalensis occidentalis and P. n. natalensis should both be considered full species status on the basis of certain morphological and behavioral differences. This has now been confirmed by a phylogenetic analysis (Engelbrecht 2017, Engelbrecht et al. 2018).
This species unusual distribution, occurring as several discrete populations, suggests that this species may be a species complex (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2014).

Psammophis indochinensis is variously treated as a full species (e.g. Hughes 1999, Pauwels et al. 2003, Nguyen et al. 2009) or as a subspecies of P. condanarus (e.g. McKay 2006, Cottone and Bauer 2009). Cottone and Bauer (2009) remark that "the validity of the subspecific division of [P. condanarus] has not been critically assessed". Based on the disjunct distributions of the two taxa and morphological differences highlighted by Pauwels et al. (2003) it is probable that the two forms represent different species (P. David and A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013) and this scheme is followed here. A full revision is, however, needed to clarify the relationships of these two taxa (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2013).

Flecks et al. (2012) examined the systematics of the Gehyra vorax species complex using both molecular and morphological data, and described this species based on populations from Vanuatu and the Loyalty Islands previously included within G. vorax.

Leviton (1968) recognized both Boiga drapiezii and B. schultzei but could not determinate their true relationships. Both taxa were treated as full species pending a better definition of B. drapiezii. Alcala (1986) and Greene (1989) regard B. schultzei as a valid species rather than as a synonym of B. drapiezii, and this arrangement is followed here, although recently Leviton et al. (2018). suggested that both B. schultzei and B. angulata will prove to be colour morphs of B. drapiezii following further research.

All characters of scalation and colouration of specimens from Gia Lai province in Viet Nam are in accordance with those of specimens from Thailand-Malaysia and from Indonesian populations. The absence of records from southern Laos and Cambodia can probably be explained by poor investigation of this territory (Orlov et al. 2003).
Dendrelaphis kopsteini, D. formosus and D. cyanochloris have frequently been confused in the literature, although D. kopsteini is the only one with bright red or orange neck colouration.

Leviton (1959) suggested that this species may be conspecific with Dryocalamus (now Lycodon) philippinus, to which it was described as being very similar in the original description. As of Leviton et al. (2018) this issue remains unresolved, but this assessment follows these authors in assigning Philippine records to L. philippinus.
Oligodon subcarinatus is treated as a synonym of O. signatus following Tillack and Günther (2010), who examined type specimens of both species.
No taxonomic issues.

Specimens listed as Pareas carinatus from Borneo might refer to this species. Recent genetic evidence (Guo et al. 2011) indicates that these two species form a clade that is sister to remaining Pareas species, suggesting that a revision of the generic name for P. carinatus and P. nuchalis may be warranted.
The species is separated from Parias sumatranus (Stuebing & Inger, 1998). It was previously confused with T. hageni and T. kanburiensis.
This green pitviper is part of the Trimereusurus popeorum complex.
This genus has two species, the other (S. khasiensis) is restricted to the Khasi Hills in India.

Nicholson et al. (2012) considered the names Anolis binotatus and Norops binotatus as nomina dubia, but provided no justification for this contention. This species may be conspecific with Anolis lemniscatus and A. bitectus, in which case Anolis binotatus will be the oldest available name, and research is ongoing to clarify the status of these taxa (F. Ayala et al. in prep.). A. lemniscatus and A. bitectus were not included in the phylogeny of Poe et al. (2017), who reported that their unpublished results suggest these taxa are not valid, and the taxonomy of these taxa is presently subject to investigation (F. Ayala pers. comm. 2019).

Due to morphological similarity and unclear geographic boundaries between these species, it has been unclear whether Anolis antonii, A. mariarum, and A. tolimensis (which replace each other geographically along the Cauca and Magdalena river valleys) are separate species. Recent studies have found that these taxa can be distinguished on molecular (Poe et al. 2017) and morphometric (Grisales-Martínez et al. 2017) grounds.
The validity of this species is uncertain, as it is only known from one specimen and the description is inadequate (J. Velasco pers. comm. 2013).

Due to morphological similarity and unclear geographic boundaries between these species, it has been unclear whether Anolis antonii, A. mariarum, and A. tolimensis (which replace each other geographically along the Cauca and Magdalena River valleys) are separate species. Recent studies have found that these taxa can be distinguished on molecular (Poe et al. 2017) and morphometric (Grisales-Martínez et al. 2017) grounds.
Specimens reported to belong to this species by Molina et al. (2003) instead represent Anolis fuscoauratus (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015).
This species may be a synonym of Anolis calimae (M.R. Castañeda and J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014), which was described from a closely adjacent locality.

Batista et al. (2015) found that the holotype of Anolis purpurescens is conspecific with Anolis chocorum, based on a comparison with individuals collected near the type locality of the latter species. These authors formally synonymized A. chocorum within A. purpurescens. Batista et al. (2015) described a new species, Dactyloa (=Anolis) maia, from records north of the southern Darién previously assigned to A. chocorum.

Due to morphological similarity and unclear geographic boundaries between these species, it has been unclear whether Anolis antonii, A. mariarum, and A. tolimensis (which replace each other geographically along the Cauca and Magdalena river valleys) are separate species. Recent studies have found that these taxa can be distinguished on molecular (Poe et al. 2017) and morphometric (Grisales-Martínez et al. 2017) grounds.
This taxon appears to be a species complex, with four morphologically distinct populations that are thought to represent distinct species (J.E. García-Pérez pers. comm. 2016).
This taxon may be a synonym of A. steyeri (Rivas et al. 2012).

The two known specimens of Anadia escalerae differ in several characters discussed by Kok et al. (2013). Additionally both specimens are reported to be damaged, further complicating identification (Kok et al. 2013). As interspecific variation in A. escalerae is entirely unknown, and the two specimens were taken in the same biogeographic region, Kok et al. (2013) conservatively assign the second specimen to A. escalerae, but caution that this identification is provisional.

Following molecular evidence that Bachia heteropa is a species complex (Kohlsdorf and Wagner 2006, Kohlsdorf et al. 2010) Murphy et al. (2019) conducted a revision of Bachia heteropa in the Caribbean and adjacent Venezuela incorporating both morphological and molecular data. These authors confirmed specific status for B. alleni (proposed by Kohlsdorf and Wagner 2006 based on small sample sizes), elevated three other recognized subspecies and junior synonyms to specific level, and described an additional species, B. beebei, from populations previously included within B. heteropa.

Sturaro et al. (2018) revised the Cercosaura ocellata species complex, redescribing C. ocellata itself, elevating the former subspecies C. o. bassleri to specific level, removing C. olivacea from synonymy and describing the new species C. anordosquama.

It has been suggested that differences in colouration between northern coastal and southern populations in French Guiana indicate long isolation and possibly represent different species (IUCN France 2016). These populations were not included in the analysis by Sturaro et al. (2018).

Taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the relation with Cercosayua goeleti, considered as a full species by several authors and as a junior synonym of C. phelpsorom by others (Rivas et al. 2012). This account follows Rivas et al. (2012) in considering C. goeleti a junior synonym of C. phelpsorum.
This may not be a distinct species but may be synonymous with Leposoma southi (see comment in Uetz and Hošek 2016).

This species was reassigned from Neusticurus to the new genus Potamites by Doan and Castoe (2005), in work following a wider molecular analysis of relationships within Gymnophthalmidae. While this arrangement has subsequently been widely followed, and has been adopted here, Rodrigues et al. (2007) argue that the taxonomic changes proposed by Castoe et al. (2004) - and by implication those of Doan and Castoe (2005) - are premature based on limited taxon sampling and morphological similarities between taxa recovered as distinct by Castoe et al. (2004).

This species, which has the largest distribution of any Potamites species, has a somewhat complex taxonomic history, summarized by Chávez and Vásquez (2012), as a result of uncertainty regarding the validity and distribution of Potamites ocellatus. This latter taxon is presently considered valid and known with certainty only from Bolivia following Vanzolini (1995), who assigned Peruvian records of P. ocellatus to the P. ecpleopus species complex sensu lato, but the relationship between these two taxa and their relative distributions remain unclear. Further research on the systematics of P. ecpleopus may also reveal cryptic species within this complex.
Colombian specimens previously identified as G. concinnatus are were described as G. riveroi by Sturaro and Avila-Pires (2011).

Pinto et al. (2019) evaluated the taxonomic status of the Gonatodes humeralis using molecular data. While these authors found that, contrary to these authors' expectations and evidence from similar studies on other Amazonian lizards, this widespread species is monotypic in mainland South America, they found that the populations from Trinidad and Tobago are specifically distinct. Pinto et al. (2019) resurrect the name G. ferrugineus for the Trinidadian species, although these authors note that the two taxa cannot presently be distinguished morphologically. 
Following the recognition by Rösler et al. (2019) that the holotype of Cnemaspis timoriensis represents the first known specimen of Gonatodes humeralis, these authors report that an application to the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature is in preparation to preserve the name humeralis for this taxon in order to preserve nomenclatural stability.

Colombian records of this species refer to Lepidoblepharis colombianus, which prior to Vanzolini (1978) was considered a subspecies of L. festae and possibly conspecific with L. xanthostigma (J. Arredondo pers. comm. 2010).
This species was described from within the Ameiva ameiva species complex (Ugueto and Harvey 2011).

Kentropyx borckiana represents a unisexual clone that originated from one or more parthenogenetic hybrids between Kentropyx calcarata x K. striata, the other two species of this genus known from the Guiana region (Cole et al. 1995).

This species is difficult to distinguish from Kentropyx altamazonica, and taxonomists have long struggled to separate the two reliably (Harvey et al. 2012). These authors reported that K. calcarata may be more variable in characters assumed to be diagnostic than previously supposed, but as this work was not a species-level taxonomic treatment further research is needed to clarify species boundaries within the altamazonica-calcarata complex.
This is a species complex (J.C. Murphy pers. comm. 1997).

The systematics of Tupinambis teguixin remain poorly studied, with Fitzgerald et al. (1999) describing the taxonomy as “tortuous.”  Investigating the genetics of this taxon, these authors found that “…the split among T. teguixin from Cuyabeno, Ecuador and Roraima, Brazil was comparable to differences between T. teguixin and T. longilineus and even to that between T. rufescens and T. merianae.” This issue remains in need of resolution; Harvey et al. (2012) have supported the view that T. teguixin is indeed a complex of multiple taxa.

There are two common names applied to Tupinambis teguixin in the pet trade and popular literature, the golden tegu and the black and white tegu (Balsai 1998); suggesting differences in coloration. The name "black and white" tegu is also commonly applied to Salvator merianae. These two species have been long confused in the scientific and popular literature. Beebe (1945) was well aware of the variation in coloration and pattern in neonates and adults. He wrote, “The tegu is a large, heavily-built lizard, with considerable pattern and color variation. In general it is black above, spotted and blotched on the head and body and broadly banded on the tail with bright yellow. The young are banded from nape to tail tip.” In the same paper he later wrote, “Another pattern of unusual prominence was four longitudinal series of white dashes down the back from the nape to three-fourth’s the length of the tail.”

Plica plica is a widespread, common species known to be morphologically variable across its range (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2015, Murphy and Jowers 2013). De Oliveira et al. (2016), sampling the species across its range, identified five genetic lineages with a major division between the Guiana Shield and Amazonia, although their sample sizes were small and they proposed no taxonomic action.

Murphy and Jowers (2013) reviewed the taxonomy of northern subpopulations using both morphological and molecular evidence and coined new names for four populations: P. caribbeana, P. kathleenae, P. medemi and P. rayi.

The primary goal of these latter authors' work was "not to revise the entire species group" but to identify avenues for further research. These new taxa were consequently supported by data from a small number of specimens, and two of the proposed species are based only on their holotypes, Given the likely complexity of taxonomic issues within the variable P. plica, M. Hoogmoed (pers. comm. 2015) argues that Murphy and Jowers (2013) were premature in assigning novel names to these taxa, which were erected without reference to existing meristic data (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2019), and research is underway in Brazil to investigate the systematics of this genus. In an earlier examination of the specimen Murphy and Jowers (2013) designated the holotype of P. kathleenae, Hoogmoed (1973) could find no morphological differences between this specimen and material of typical P. plica from Guyana and Suriname, and ongoing taxonomic work suggests that this is not a good species (S. Gomides pers. comm. 2018).

In order to preserve nomenclatural stability, this account treats P. caribbeana, P. kathleenae, P. rayi and P. medemi as junior synonyms of P. plica pending a more comprehensive review of the putative P. plica complex.

Plica umbra is a species complex whose taxonomy is presently unresolved (T. Hrbeck pers. comm. 2016). A revision of the genus is presently underway that is likely to change our understanding of species boundaries in both P. plica and P. umbra (S. Gomides pers. comm. 2018).

In a wide-ranging revision of Chironius Hollis (2006) elevated Chironius cochranae, then a subspecies of C. multiventris, to specific status. Klazcko et al. (2010) subsequently synonymized C. cochranae within C. multiventris, as they were unable to find any characters that could differentiate the two taxa.
The taxonomic status of Atractus andinus and A. attenuates is under investigation and is likely to be revised in the near future (P. Passos pers. comm. 2019).
The taxonomic status of Atractus andinus and A. attenuatus is under investigation and is likely to be revised in the near future (P. Passos pers. comm. 2019).

Ongoing work investigating the systematics of Ecuadorian Atractus suggests that morphological characters may not reliably differentiate species (Cisneros-Heredia in prep.) Molecular results for Atractus medusa, which is included in this study, are not yet available but it is possible that Ecuadorian records referred to this species are not conspecific with Atractus medusa (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016).

Three species of Atractus described by da Silva (2004), A. davidhardi, A. janethae and A. lucilae, are treated as junior synonyms of A. torquatus following Passos and Prudente (2012), who found that the characters used to diagnose them were variable throughout Amazonian populations and could not be used to recognize discrete species. These authors consider it unlikely that more than one lineage of "A. torquatus" exists within the Amazon Basin, however, further research is required to clarify whether this Amazonian population is genuinely conspecific with Guiana Shield A. torquatus (Passos and Prudente 2012).
The taxonomic relationship between A. fuliginosus and A. univittatus needs resolution (Rivas et al. 2012).
Rueda-Almonacid (2009) regarded this species as synonymous with Atractus crassicaudatus, but Passos and Lynch (2010) showed them to be diagnosable based on hemipenial morphology.
Records of this species from Brazilian Amazonia (Cunha and Nascimento 1984) were described as a distinct species, Atractus hoogmoedi, by Prudente and Passos (2010).
This species was previously a member of the Dipsas oreas complex, from which it was elevated by Cadle (2005).
It is a species complex (See Dixon 1983).

Records from Trinidad and Venezuela are now recognized as a distinct species, Erythrolamprus zweifeli (Rivas et al. 2012). Records from Tobago were described as the new species E. pseudoreginae by Murphy et al. (2019). Coluber violaceus, a taxon known only from a lost holotype, has long been treated as a junior synonym of E. reginae.
Recently included in the genus Erythrolamprus.
This taxon is a species complex (Dixon 1987).

The taxonomy of Synophis bicolor has historically been complicated, as the type locality is uncertain and significant morphological differences have long been recognized between Colombian and Ecuadorian populations, but the species is rare in collections (Torres-Carvajal et al. 2015). Competing results were presented by Pyron et al. (2015) and Torres-Carvajal et al. (2015) further confusing the true identity of this species. Consequently, Pyron et al. (2016) - involving members of both research groups -  formally redescribed this species, re-evaluating the identity of specimens used in the prior reasons.
A record from Colomia's Guajira Peninsula that Campbell and Lamar (2004) suggested may be referrable to T. gambotensis was found to represent T. paraguanae by Bailey and Thomas (2007).

Valencia et al.  (2016) synonymized Micrurus catamayensis within M. bocourti. This proposed synonymy is complicated by uncertainty surrounding the precise type locality of M. bocourti, and consequent uncertainty over whether the specimens examined by this author are topotypical (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2018).
Passos and Fernandes (2005) elevated this taxon to species level, from a subspecies of Micrurus surinamensis.

Micrurus obscurus is now considered a full species by many authors (most recently Savage and McDiarmid 2017), and this scheme is followed here, however, it is considered a subspecies of M. spixii by Campbell and Lamar (2004).

Micrurus psyches is a complex, and the original description was poorly done and vague.  There are several as-yet unidentified black-and-white coral snakes in Colombia (specifically the Cordillera Oriental and La Macarena), and records of M. psyches from this country are likely to represent confusion with one or more of these.

Micrurus obscurus is now considered a full species by many authors (most recently Savage and McDiarmid 2017), and this scheme is followed here, however, it is considered a subspecies of M. spixii by Campbell and Lamar (2004).
Micrurus nattereri, previously a subspecies of M. surinamensis, was elevated to specific status by Passos and Fernandes (2005).
Epictia amazonica was removed from synonymy with E. signata by Natera-Mumaw et al. (2015) based on a reexamination of the holotype, and this scheme has been accepted by subsequent authors.

This species has a complex taxonomic history, and was formerly considered to include the now generally-recognized species Bothrops leucurus, B. moojeni, B. marajoensis, and B. isabelae. The taxonomic status of a further form described from Venezuela, Bothrocophias colombiensis (the Colombian type locality being in error), was discussed by Johnson and Dixon (1984) and these authors concluded that it could not be reliably diagnosed as a taxon distinct from Bothrops atrox. The species has subsequently been treated as a junior synonym of B. atrox. Recent molecular analyses have, however, recovered a cryptic clade unrelated to B. atrox within this species complex, to which the authors have applied the name B. colombiensis (Pyron et al. 2011). There is, however, no clarity on either the diagnosis or geographical distribution of "true" B. colombiensis, and as such it is not clear whether the name B. colombiensis has been correctly applied to these sequences (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). Pending further research to clarify this situation, which "will not be solved now" (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014), and because no formal taxonomic action has been taken to resurrect B. colombiensis, this account follows Johnson and Dixon (1984) and most subsequent authorities in treating B. colombiensis as a junior synonym of B. atrox.

Ramirez-Chaves and Solari (2014) published a note declaring Bothrops ayerbei as an unavailable name under the rules of the International Code of Zoological Nature as the species description was published in an electronic publication before 2011.

Parker (1942) recognized geographical variation within Xenagama batillifera, identifying a variant in the extreme west of the species' range characterized by differences in tail morphology. In revising Xenagama, Wagner et al. (2013) described this western form as the new species X. wilmsi based on both morphological and molecular data.

Recent large collections from eastern New Guinea and its outlying islands have allowed the taxonomy of Sphenomorphus aignanus to be investigated. Formerly this species was understood to occur along the north coast of Papua New Guinea (with inland records from the Owalama and Sibium Mountain Range in Oro Province), and on a number of islands in the D’Entrecasteaux and Louisiade Archipelagos (Zweifel 1976, Kraus and Allison 2004, Allison and Iova 2009, Goldberg et al. 2009, G. Shea. pers. coms. 2014).

This research has revealed that specimens from the type locality, Misima Island, are morphologically and genetically distinct from populations elsewhere, which themselves represent a series of undescribed single-island endemics separate from both S. aignanus and the mainland taxon (G. Shea pers. comm. 2015). This account considers the name S. aignanus to refer to the Misima population alone.

This species has two subspecies:
M. bicoloratus bicoloratus Sternfield, 1908
M. bicoloratus moyeri Rasmussen, 2002.
As the species is known from only one specimen, S. Spawls (pers. comm. 2014) raises the possibility that it may be an aberrant specimen of a better-known species.
The relationship between Aparallactus capensis and A. nigriceps (of southern Mozambique) should be investigated if possible.
A. mwanzae was previously regarded as a subspecies of A. planiceps Peters, 1862 (Spawls et al. 2002).

Amphisbaena nanguruwensis was relegated to a subspecies of Chirindia ewerbecki by Gans and Rhodes (1967), and this scheme was subsequently followed by Broadley and Howell (1991), Spawls et al. (2018) and Uetz and Hallerman (2012). Gans (2005) treated the two taxa as full species, but as he provided no justification for this action his scheme is not followed here.

This account provisionally follows recent authors (Broadley and Howell 1991, Branch et al. 2005, Spawls et al. 2018) in treating the Tanzanian Amphisbaenula orientalis as a junior synonym of Chirindia swynnertoni (contra Gans 2005, who assigns A. orientalis to Chirindia without discussion, but recognizes it as a valid species). While Broadley and Howell (1991) simply note "NEW SYNONYMY" without providing justification for this action, Branch et al. (2005) note that neither of these species has been well-diagnosed and that the characters used to distinguish them are of dubious validity. These latter authors therefore prefer to retain the synonymy pending the collection of further material and genetic analysis. Gans (2005) also treats C. bushbyi (known only from "Amatongas" in Mozambique) as a full species; as this assignment was not discussed, this taxon is considered a junior synonym of C. swynnertoni here following Broadley and Gans (1978).
Schargel et al. (2013) referred Atractus arangoi to the synonymy of A. major.

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Chamaesaura macrolepis (e.g. Spawls et al. 2002), but has more recently been treated as a full species (e.g. Stanley et al. 2011, Spawls et al. 2018, Uetz et al. 2021).

This species was until recently considered a subspecies of Chamaesaura anguina. Genetic evidence recovers the two forms as sister taxa, however, the genetic (as well as geographic) distance between them is "significant" (Stanley et al. 2011). Based on this and the existence of reliable diagnostic features, these authors elevated C. anguina to species level.

This species is listed as Cordylus sp. by Spawls et al. (2018), shortly prior to the publication of the species' formal description (Broadley and Branch 2002). The two specimens attributed to C. beraduccii included in genetic analysis by Greenbaum et al. (2012) exhibited divergent branch lengths in these authors' phylogeny, possibly indicative of the presence of cryptic species (Greenbaum et al. 2012).

This is a widespread species with numerous junior synonyms, and molecular research is required to understand the systematics of this possible species complex (Stanley et al. 2011). A morphologically similar East African form, Cordylus beraduccii, was described based on material formerly included within C. tropidosternum (Broadley and Branch 2002), and has since been found to be genetically distinct (Stanley et al. 2011). These latter authors also elevated the southern subspecies, C. t. jonesii, to full species status. It may yet prove to be the case, as first suggested by Loveridge (1944), that Tanzanian C. tropidosternum represent a different species from the nominate form, but research is needed to determine this (Stanley et al. 2011). C. angolensis, a poorly-described species whose sole known specimen was destroyed and which was for a long time considered a junior synonym of C. tropidosternum, is here treated as a valid species following Branch et al. (2005) and subsequent workers, however Branch et al. (2005) note that its status remains problematic.

This is a member of the former Agama agama species complex, and is still treated within accounts for A. agama in some recent field guides (Spawls et al. 2002, Largen and Spawls 2010 - part). Böhme et al. (2005) distinguished the A. lionotus group, encompassing East African members of the former A. agama complex, from the A. agama group. A. l. dodomae has subsequently been elevated to full species status, including the subspecies A. d. ufipae (P. Wagner unpubl. thesis, Wagner et al. in review).

The Tanzanian Lygodactylus angularis grzimeki was described as a subspecies, but was treated as a full species in some recent literature on East African Lygodactylus (Spawls et al. 2002, Röll et al. 2010) and this treatment was followed in an earlier Red List assessment. As the justification for considering it a full species is unclear, and it is not included in the most recent guide to East African reptiles (Spawls et al. 2018), this account follows that source and older literature in regarding it as a subspecies of L. angularis.

Lygodactylus laterimaculatus has historically been treated as a subspecies of Lygodactylus schlefferi, and this arrangement is still followed by Uetz and Hallerman (2012). Recent literature on East African reptiles (Spawls et al. 2002) and Lygodactylus (Röll et al. 2010), however, treats it as a full species, although the basis for this is unclear. Röll et al. (2010) included L. laterimaculatus in genetic analysis and found it to be monophyletic within the L. schlefferi species group, but as these authors did not include L. schlefferi itself in their analysis the appropriate taxonomic status of L. laterimaculatus remains uncertain. L. uluguruensis, previously considered a junior synonym of L. schlefferi, is also now considered a valid species (Spawls et al. 2002).

This species has historically been treated as a subspecies of Lygodactylus schlefferi, and this arrangement is still followed by Uetz and Hallerman (2012). Recent literature on East African reptiles (Spawls et al. 2002) and Lygodactylus (Röll et al. 2010), however, treats it as a full species, although the basis for this is unclear. Röll et al. (2010) included this species in genetic analysis and found it to be monophyletic within the L. schlefferi species group, but as these authors did not include L. schlefferi itself in their analysis the appropriate taxonomic status of L. laterimaculatus remains uncertain.
This is considered to be a complex of several species that needs additional taxonomic review.

Van den Berg (2017) noted that the taxonomic status of this species was in doubt, however, after examination of the collections it has been confirmed to be a good species (L. Ceríaco pers. comm. 2019).
Thrasops schmidti was elevated to specific status by Broadley and Wallach (2002) on morphological and biogeographical grounds, having previously been considered a subspecies of T. jacksonii.

This species was included within Boulengerina until this genus was synonymized within Naja by Wüster et al. (2007), whose findings confirmed an arrangement first suggested by Nagy et al. (2005). Subsequently, Wallach et al. (2009) revived Bouleringina as a subgenus and expanded its content. Subspecies: Naja annulata annulata (Buchholz & Peters, 1876) is found in Gabon.
Three specimens attributed to this species (without examination) by Loveridge (1944) have instead been found to represent Cordylus tropidosternum (Broadley and Branch 2002).

This species currently comprise two valid subspecies Platysaurus m. maculatus and Platysaurus m. lineicauda, although current studies shows at least two cryptic lineages present in northern Mozambique (Whiting pers. comm. June 2019). Stanley et al. (2011) retain the subspecific division, but do not include either subspecies in their analysis and so their relationship to one another remains unresolved. An isolated subpopulation in the Zambezi Valley, probably represents a separate species (D. Broadley pers. comm. in Branch et al. 2005), but is retained in this account pending formal taxonomic action. There is a single subpopulation from Tanzania in Masasi  (Spawls et al. 2018) that has not been phylogenetically investigated.
This species is a member of a confusing assemblage of bicoloured coral snakes which requires further research to confirm the validity of currently recognized forms (Campbell and Lamar 2004).

Dixon and Kofron (1984) refer two literature records of "Liotyphlops anops" from Dunn (1944), from Santander and Cundinamarca, to L. argaleus, while cautioning that they were not able to examine these specimens and that they may instead represent a new species.

This action was accepted by Vanzolini (in Peters and Donoso-Barros 1986) but has since been the source of some confusion as McDiarmid et al. (1999) suggested this assignment may be uncertain, although Dixon and Kofron (1984) removed these records from the distribution of L. anops. Santos (2018) consequently includes Santander and Cundinamarca within the distribution of L. anops  (adding further to the confusion, this author apparently maps the wrong type locality for L. anops, placing it in Meta Department).
Specimens originally classed as Atractus crassicaudatus collected from Panama have been redescribed as A. imperfectus Myers, 2003.

The species was first described as Tropidodipsas perijanesis (Alemán 1953), Peters (1970) later transferred it to the genus Dipsas and finally, a new genus Plesiodipsas was created for the species (G.Rivas pers. comm. 2010).

Harvey and Embert (2009) recently revised this species, expanded its known range, and added several names to its synonymy. A subsequent publication by the senior author (Harvey et al. 2009) provided additional information about the species’s morphology and a revised key to South American Dipsas.

Historical records from Colombia (Perez-Santos and Moreno 1988) and Ecuador (Valencia 2007) of this Atlantic Forest endemic represent confusion with other species. The only voucher specimen in a Colombian collection belongs to the similar Taeniophallus brevirostris, while the description of Ecuadorian specimens does not match that of Echinanthera undulata (Passos et al. unpublished).

The recent description of Oxyrhopus vanidicus, which very closely resembles O. melanogenys, makes the specific identity of previously reported records of O. melanogenys in Peru, Brazil, Ecuador, and Colombia uncertain (Lynch 2009). Examining specimens from Venezuela, Rivas et al. (2012) could find no consistent differences between O. vanidicus and O. melanogenys, raising doubts about the specific validity of O. vanidicus.
This species used to be recognized with two subspecies but now Micrurus langsdorffi ornatissimus (Jan, 1858) is considered a separate species.
Zaher et al. (2009), in a molecular review of caenophidian snakes, found that Xenoxybelis was nested within Philodryas. These authors therefore synonymized Xenoxybelis with Philodryas.

Synophis lasallei is "exceptionally likely" to represent a species complex based on differences in characters reported for specimens examined by Pyron et al. (2015); these authors found that a sampled specimen was nested within S. bicolor.

A taxonomic revision is required since this taxon was first described as subspecies Lepidoblepharis festae colombianus by Mechler in 1968, and later elevated to species level by Vanzolini as L. columbianus in 1978. However, L. xanthostigma is reported to inhabit the same biogeographic zone in Colombia as L. columbianus, and these two may be conspecific. Further, the morphological difference between L. xanthostigma and L. columbianus are based on body size and other uninformative characters (J. Arredondo pers. comm. 2010).

The population situated on the eastern slopes of the Andes above Villavicencio may represent a hybrid or intergrade population between P. bicolor and P. nicefori (Loveridge, 1929). Further study is required. Harris (1994) suggests that this eastern record may represent an undescribed species, and it is not considered part of this species here.

The distributional pattern (occurring in Amazonia and the Colombian Andes) suggests this taxon may be a species complex (R. Caicedo pers. comm. 2013). It is widely confused with Cercosaura oshaughnessyi, with which it apparently co-occurs across much of its range. Some authors have elected to follow Uzzell (1973) in treating C. oshaughnessyi as a junior synonym of C. argulus pending resolution of the taxonomic relationship between these taxa, and Torres-Carvajal et al. (2015) found that the two taxa were only weakly differentiated both morphologically and genetically. While these authors did find that the two taxa exhibited reciprocal monophyly and recognized C. oshaughnessyi as distinct as a result, their sample included only two specimens of C. argulus and this account retains C. oshaughnessyi in synonymy with C. argulus pending confirmation of its status as a distinct species and clarification of its distributional limits.

The taxonomic rearrangement of Campbell and Lamar (2004) (based on morphology) was corroborated by the molecular data of Wuster et al. (2005), confining Crotalus durissus (previously understood to range throughout the Neotropics) to South America (M. Martins, pers. comm. 2010). Rivas et al. (2012) propose recognizing the current subspecies Crotalus d. vegrandis from the lowlands of Maturín and Anzoátegui (northeastern Venezuela) as a full species based only on size and colour pattern. This scheme is adopted by the Reptile Database as of November 2018 (Uetz 2018), however, other works do not (Campbell and Lamar 2004, Wuster et al. 2005) and the recognition of this species would warrant more evidence than a smaller size and a peculiar colour pattern.

This taxon actually may be a species complex; a range-wide taxonomic reevaluation is needed (Caicedo-Portilla 2011). It was formerly within the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

Tropidurus catalanensis was recently revalidated as a full species (Kunz and Borges-Martins 2013), having been relegated to subspecific status by Cei (1993). This action has since been accepted by Carreira and Maneyro (2015). Kunz and Borges-Martins (2013) identified additional groups within the T. torquatus species complex, including a restricted-range taxon from Brazil that they described as T. imbituba. Remaining northern populations of T. torquatus appear to belong to at least three taxa, however, Kunz and Borges-Martins (2013) considered the available sampling insufficient to describe these as separate taxa.

Murphy et al. (2019) described specimens from Tobago previously included within B. flavescens as a new species, B. whitei. 

Bachia flavescens has long been recognized to be a species complex (Kizirian and McDiarmid 1998) encompassing "a substantial number of taxa" (Murphy et al.  2019) but has received little taxonomic attention. The holotype has been lost, there is no associated type locality, and the available illustration of the holotype is considered "all but useless for identification" (Murphy et al. 2019). These authors recommend that the name Bachia flavescens be considered a nomen nudum, arguing that the continued use of this name of unclear provenance to apply to a composite species is unhelpful in understanding the systematics of the remaining, undescribed members of this group. 

As the systematics of this group are poorly-understood and consequently no replacement names have been proposed for any of the populations  Murphy et al. (2019) refer to as Bachia cf. flavescens this account continues to use the name B. flavescens for this species complex.

Three subspecies are recognized: Bachia trisanale trisanale (Cope, 1868), B. t. abendrothi (Peters, 1871) , and B. t. vermiformis (Cope, 1874).

Avila-Pires (1995) suggests that B. trisanale and B. peruana may not be distinct species, however, the author states that not enough specimens were available for examination to clarify this.
Some authors believe that this species is not clearly distinguishable from Thecadactylus rapicauda (R. Caicedo pers. comm. 2013)

Lamb et al. (2010) elevated A. p. occidentalis to specific status based on morphological evidence and a highly allopatric distribution, an arrangement that had previously been suggested by Spawls et al. (2002). Lamb et al. (2010) also found A. p. tasmani to be nested within A. orientalis (itself a subspecies of A. meleagris prior to this revision) and formally synonymized it within this taxon. Following these changes, A. percivali is monotypic, representing only the former subspecies A. p. percivali. Unfortunately technical difficulties prevented the inclusion of A. p. percivali in the molecular analysis by Lamb et al. (2010) to elucidate its relationship with A. occidentalis and A. orientalis.

Typhlosaurus aurantiacus were transferred to Acontias by Lamb et al. (2010). Broadley (1968, 1990) recognized five subspecies: A. a. aurantiacus, A. a. bazautotoensis, A. a. carolinensis, A. a. fitzsimonsi, and A a. parietalis. The later two speceis has been raised to species-level (Pietersen et al. 2018). The revised narrower concept of Acontias aurantiacus is now confined to Mozambique. Although KwaZulu-Natal subpopulations of this species have been referred to A. a. aurantiacus (e.g. Branch 1998), Broadley (1990) clarified that these, along with specimens from Inhaca Island, Mozambique, are referable to A. parietalis.

There is significant taxonomic uncertainty surrounding this species. Both Varanus scalaris and V. similis were previously thought to be part of the Varanus timorensis species group, but V. similis is now often considered to form a separate complex with V. scalaris (Bennett 1995, Böhme 2003), or to be a subspecies of V. scalaris (Smith et al. 2004). V. similis is likely to be elevated to full species status in the future (Smith et al. 2004), and the group is currently being researched (Smith et al. 2004, S. Sweet pers. comm.). While it is likely that V. scalaris may be split into as many as ten species in the future, V. s. similis alone may be three distinct species (Smith et al. 2004). While noting that it is presently regarded as a subspecies following Smith et al. (2004), Koch et al. (2013) treat V. similis as a full species although they take no taxonomic action. Given the taxonomic complexity within the V. scalaris complex, this account retains V. similis as a subspecies of V. scalaris pending a formal revision.

This species was previously considered a variety of Melanoseps ater, but was elevated to full species status by Broadley and Howell (1991) and this arrangement has subsequently been accepted (Spawls et al. 2002, Broadley et al. 2006). The lectotype has been lost, but the original description suggests a generic assignment to Typhlacontias rather than Melanoseps (Broadley et al. 2006). This author uses both the name Melanoseps longicauda and the abbreviation T. longicauda to refer to this species, and considers the taxon incertae sedis pending recovery of the lectotype. Broadley et al. (2006) assign one of two historical records of M. longicauda, from a site along the Pangani River, to the newly-recognized M. pygmaeus.

This taxon was previously considered a subspecies of Melanoseps ater, but was elevated to specific status by Broadley (2000) following the collection of new material and comparison with the original specimens. This arrangement has subsequently been accepted (Spawls et al. 2002, Broadley et al. 2006).
Phylogenetic study indicates that the subspecies on Mount Mulanje in Malawi represents a distinct species, and once elevated, the conservation of both taxa will need to be reassessed.
This species belongs to the didactyle Scelotes bidigittatus group (Broadley 1994). The phylogenetic relationships of taxa within the genus Scelotes requires investigation.

This species was originally described as a subspecies, Scelotes arenicola insularis (Broadley 1990), but Broadley (1994) treats S. insularis as a full species. The type specimen is from Benguera Island (Broadley 1990, Broadley 1994).
The phylogenetic relationships of taxa within Scolecoseps requires investigation.

The subpopulation on the Nyika Plateau, which in the past has been treated as a subspecies (Mabuya brauni hildae) and a separate species (Mabuya hildae), may represent a distinct species (W. Conradie and D. Pietersen pers. comm. 2019).

Some or all Tanzanian populations presently referred to the similar Trachylepis brevicollis may instead represent this species (Günther et al. 2005), and this is also suggested by the proximity of two localities to Klein's Camp, where T. dichroma is known to occur (Branch et al. 2007). Research is needed to confirm this.

Broadley (1996) revised southern African Lycophidion and elevated L. pembanum, previously considered a subspecies of L. capense, to specific status. This revision was based on museum material, as no recent records of this taxon exist. The collection of new specimens and their inclusion of genetic analysis may therefore be required to verify this assignment (P. Malonza pers. comm. 2014).

Visser (2010) noted that males of the brown phase of this species from northern Namibia have much shorter and morphologically different hemipenes compared to specimens of the larger black phase in the Western and Northern Cape provinces of South Africa, and  that the northern subspecies Pseudaspis cana anchietae may be valid.

The clade to which this species belongs (which includes Leptotyphlops scutifrons, L. conjunctus and L. incognitus) has a convoluted taxonomic history which is only now being unravelled with the use of phylogenetic analyses (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009, Busschau et al. 2020). Although initially treated as a full species by Broadley and Watson (1976), most subsequent authors have treated it as a subspecies of L. scutifrons (Branch 1998, Broadley and Broadley 1999, Broadley and Wallach 2009), although Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) again treated it as a full species in a subsequent phylogenetic study of the group. Records from the Congo region originally assigned to this species were later re-assigned to either L. scutifrons or Namibiana latirostris (Broadley and Broadley 1999). Recent phylogenetic analyses indicate that this species is paraphyletic, with at least three clades that are not sister groups, with divergences dating between 17–23 million years ago. Of these, the clade that occurs in the interior Eastern Cape Province of South Africa can be considered L. conjunctus (sensu stricto), given that the original type locality of ‘Cape of Good Hope’ has been restricted to the Eastern Cape Province (Broadley and Watson 1976). Such a treatment would render two clades unassigned to any species. Until such time that the relevant taxonomic changes can be made, these latter clades are included within L. conjunctus (sensu lato).

This species was described as a subspecies of Leptotyphlops scutifrons (Broadley and Wallach 2007), however, based on high levels of genetic divergence Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) elevated it to specific rank.
This species is only known from the type and its phylogenetic distinctiveness needs to be clarified. Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) documented deep genetic diversity within the group.

The species complex to which these snakes belong has a convoluted taxonomic history. Taxonomy of the group is only now being unravelled with the use of molecular analyses (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009). Previously, Leptotyphlops conjunctus and L. incognitus were treated as full species, or as subspecies of L. scutifrons (Broadley and Watson 1976, Broadley and Broadley 1999, Broadley and Wallach 2007). Additional subspecies of L. scutifrons recognized from East Africa by Broadley and Wallach (2007) have now been raised to species level (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009), removing L. scutifrons from this region but leaving its distribution records somewhat unclear. A preliminary molecular phylogeny (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009) has also identified numerous undescribed cryptic species within the L. scutifrons/conjunctus/incognitus complex that require fuller analysis.

The taxonomic status of this species has been unclear due to the lack of recent material prior to Branch et al. (2019) due to its similarity to related taxa. These authors clarified that it warrants recognition as a good species related to Psammophis jallae, of which it has sometimes been considered a junior synonym.

Although a phylogenetic analysis suggested that Psammophis mossambicus may be a junior synonym of P. phillipsii (Kelly et al. 2008), recent work now assigns all records of P. phillipsi in Central Africa that are north, south and east of the Congo forest block to P. mossambicus and that P. phillipsii is restricted to West Africa (Trape et al. 2019). These authors synonymized P. occidentalis - variously treated as a full species or a subspecies of P. phillipsii - within P. mossambicus.
A recent phylogenetic analysis of the genus Atheris indicates that A. rungweensis may contain additional cryptic species diversity (Menegon et al. 2014).

While many authors refer to Atheris subocularis as A. squamigera, Lawson et al. (2001) provided evidence to support their consideration as a separate species. Phylogenetic analysis of cytochrome b sequences provide strong support (90%) for A. subocularis as a discrete clade that is possibly nested within its sister species A. squamigera. The exact evolutionary relationship between these species is unclear based solely on molecular data. The comparison of morphological measurements between four A. subocularis and 11 A. squamigera further distinguish these sister species from one another. The most notable differences are three measurements related to aspects of scalation and two to colouration.

There has been extensive taxonomic confusion within Chondrodactylus, which is the subject of ongoing research (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2020). Four taxa presently accepted as species - C. turneri, C. laevigatus, C. pulitzerae and C. fitzsimonsi (Uetz et al. 2021) - have all previously been treated as subspecies of a single widespread species under the name C. turneri or C. laevigatus. Genetic evidence suggests that taxonomic issues remain within C. laevigatus (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2020). Due to a lack of clarity about range limits of these various taxa, which have been recognized as distinct based on phylogenetic work (Bauer and Lamb 2002, 2005; Heinz et al. 2011), these assessments follow preliminary work presented by A. Bauer, T. Jackman and I. Brennan at conferences (pers. comm. 2020), and for species other than C. turneri summarized by Marques et al. (2018).
Phylogeographic studies are recommended to clarify whether the isolated western record from the Ruwenzori Mountains is conspecific with Cnemaspis elgonensis (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2014).
This species was formerly included within Pachydactylus, but was assigned to the resurrected genus Elasmodactylus by Branch et al. (2005).
This is the type species of the genus Elasmodactylus, resurrected from synonymy with Pachydactylus by Bauer and Lamb (2005).

This species previously was recorded from several countries in central Africa, but a recent taxonomic review restricts the range to southern Democratic Republic of the Congo and Angola. Central African records may be referred to Hemidactylus steindachneri, H. hecui, or another species.

The population in the Gulf of Guinea oceanic islands usually referred to H. molleri represents an introduced population of H. longicephalus.

A widespread species that previously had a number of poorly defined subspecies, however, most have been raised to full species (Röll et al. 2010) leaving one subspecies L. c. pakenhami. Rebelo et al. (2019) suggest that this subspecies is instead part of L. groetei, leaving L. capensis monotypic.
Records of this species have previously been confused with the larger Lygodactylus gravis, which is known from nearby localities and may occur sympatrically with this species (Spawls et al. 2002).

Pasteur (1995) found that Lygodactylus viscatus, described in the 19th Century, is conspecific with L. howelli, and that the former is therefore the name with priority. This name has been accepted subsequently (Spawls et al. 2002, Röll et al. 2010). L. viscatus is a fossil species described from a copal deposit (Spawls et al. 2002), and the name L. howelli remains in use by some authorities (Uetz and Hallerman 2012).
Röll et al. (2010) found that this species is very closely related to Lygodactylus mombasicus and recommended that its taxonomic status should be investigated to confirm its validity.

The taxonomic status of Lygodactylus picturatus ukerewensis is unclear. Uetz and Hallerman (2012) follow Broadley and Howell (1991) in treating this taxon as a junior synonym of L. manni, however, neither source justifies this assignment (which is apparently not followed by Spawls and Rotich 1997). Spawls et al. (2002) note that "it is not clear" whether this taxon is a synonym or whether it warrants recognition as a full species, while provisionally retaining it within their treatment of L. manni. Neither L. manni nor L. p. ukerewensis is included in the recent analysis of Lygodactylus species by Röll et al. (2010), and so this situation remains in need of resolution.

This taxon is not included by name in Spawls et al. (2002); on the basis of the range description and identifying characters provided by these authors, they follow the proposal by Pasteur (1965) that the name L. picturatus applies to a black-and-white-headed form here treated under the name L. mombasicus following Röll (2000), who found no support for this assignment and considered that it disrupted the nomenclatural stability of the group, and based on molecular evidence, which suggests the taxon is more closely-related to L. kimhowelli and L. keniensis than to L. picturatus (Röll et al. 2010). Historical usage is inconsistent regarding the treatment of L. mombasicus as a species, a subspecies, or a synonym, as well as in the assignment of the names L. picturatus and L. luteopicturatus (see discussion in Röll 2000). No "definite solution" to the taxonomic concept or distribution of L. mombasicus yet exists, and work is underway to resolve this situation (B. Röll, pers. comm. 2013).

Spawls et al. (2002) assert that this species has been elevated from the synonymy of Lygodactylus schlefferi, however the basis for this is not clear. This scheme has, however, been followed subsequently (Röll et al. 2010) and is accepted here pending reevaluation of the taxonomic status of this species.

Wagner et al. (2014) investigated the taxonomy of Adolfus alleni, then understood to consist of four isolated, high montane subpopulations in western Kenya. Using a combination of morphological, genetic and meristic data, these authors found support for the presence of two species within A. alleni. Wagner et al. (2014) described the more widespread taxon as A. masavaensis, confining A. alleni to Mt. Kenya.

On the basis of molecular evidence, Greenbaum et al. (2011) erected the new genus Congolacerta for Adolfus vauereselli and the newly-described Congolacerta asukului, and assigned Lacerta vauereselli as the type species.

Recent phylogenetic analyses using mitochondrial and nuclear sequence data showed that this species, long known by the name Ichnotropis squamulosa, is actually in the genus Meroles (Edwards et al. 2012, 2013; Engleder et al. 2013).

The taxonomy of the genus is unstable. However, a molecular phylogeny of the genus Nucras confirmed the species status of N. ornata, which is the sister species of N. intertexta, but is also closely related to N. holubi (Edwards et al. 2013). Records in northern Mozambique should be assigned N. boulengeri.

The traditional concept of this species included four subspecies other than the nominate form. Melanoseps ater longicauda and M. a. udzungwensis have been elevated to specific status (Broadley and Howell 1991, Broadley 2000), and this change has subsequently been accepted (Spawls et al. 2002, Broadley et al. 2006). Broadley et al. (2006) fully revised this and related East African species, and found the remaining two subspecies M. a. matengoensis and M. a. misukuensis (the former already regarded to be "doubtfully distinct" by Spawls et al. 2002) to be junior synonyms of M. ater.

Greer (1977) synonymized Riopia (at that point containing the African genus Mochlus as a synonym following Broadley 1966) within the large, predominantly Asian genus Lygosoma. This scheme was followed until Wagner et al. (2009) investigated the systematics of the African Lygosoma fernandi group using both morphological and molecular data. This study revalidated another African genus, Lepidothyris, and identified a monophyletic clade containing Mochlus afer and M. sundevalli. No other Mochlus taxa were included in this study, and the content of this revalidated genus was not discussed, however, these authors noted that all African taxa are distinct from Asian forms and confined Lygosoma and Riopa to Asia (Wagner et al. 2009, P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012). By implication, all African taxa other than Lepidothyris fernandii, L. hinkeli and L. striatus are presently considered to belong to Mochlus (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2012).

This species was described on the basis of a single specimen, which was subsequently destroyed in World War II (Spawls et al. 2002). The description itself is considered inadequate (Broadley 1995), lacking many characters used in modern diagnoses (Spawls et al. 2002). As such, the status of this species is uncertain (Broadley 1995) and the assignment of a second specimen to S. acontias (Loveridge 1955) must be considered tentative. Broadley (1995) mentions that, if the characters of S. acontias were accurately described, no subsequent material (presumably including the Kilwa specimen) can be attributed to this taxon. This specimen is provisionally included in the species concept applied here, following Spawls et al. (2002).

Currently Trachylepis bayonii is composed of the nominate form, and T. b. huilensis and T. b. keniensis but ongoing formal taxonomic revisions will elevate T. b.huilensis to species level. Although it has yet to be critically addressed, T. b. keniensis will likely also be elevated to species level in the near future.

This species, formerly considered a subspecies of Trachylepis quinquetaeniata, was formally revalidated by Broadley and Bauer (1998), although the same species concept was used slightly earlier under the name Mabuya margaritifer by Branch (1998). Broadley (2000) assigned Euprepis gularis, previously treated as a junior synonym of Mabuya quinquetaeniata margaritifer, to Mabuya (now Trachylepis) quinquetaeniata sensu stricto.

The specific ending was incorrectly amended (as T. margaritifera) but subsequently corrected by Broadley (2001). Trachylepis margaritifer differs consistently from T. quinquetaeniata with regard to colouration of juveniles and females, and it has higher midbody scale counts; the two taxa have also been found in sympatry in southeastern Kenya (Broadley and Bauer 1998).
The validity of Psammophylax tritaeniatus fitgeraldi Broadley, 1960 has been questioned (see Uetz et al. 2018).

authority: Pan, Chettri, Yang, Jiang, Wang, Zhang & Vogel, 2013
Huang, Ding, Burbrink, Yang, Huang, Ling, Chen & Zhang, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Hedges and Conn (2012) discussed the taxonomic history of this widespread species complex, and, on the basis of their results and those of Miralles and Carranza (2010), erected three new species to encompass Caribbean populations. One of these, Copeoglossum aurae, was also found to occur on Peninsula de Paria in Venezuela; unpublished data suggests this species ranges more widely in northeastern Venezuela (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2018). These authors note that taxonomic issues remain within the mainland South American skinks presently included within C. nigropunctatum, but recommended continued use of this name pending a full revision.

Based on morphological analysis Hedges and Conn (2012) removed Mabuya dominicana from synonymy with M. mabouia (which they restricted to Martinique) and recognized six additional new species from within this complex, four of which (M. desiradae, M. guadeloupae, M. grandisterrae and M. cochonae) they assigned to the "M. guadeloupae species group" based on morphological differences between taxa from the Guadeloupe archipelago and those elsewhere. Subsequently, Hedges et al. (2016) included material of M. desiradae in both morphological and molecular analyses, the results of which led to Hedges et al. (2016) recognizing a population from Iles de la Petite Terre as a separate species, M. parviterrae, specifically distinct from M. desiradae from La Désirade.

Unfortunately most of these taxa are now either extinct or extremely rare, and as such the sample sizes used to distinguish these species were very small (five or fewer specimens for every member of the M. guadeloupae group), which A. Miralles (pers. comm. 2018) suggests is not sufficient to obtain statistically meaningful results.. This data limitation, along with the discovery of an additional related population from Iles des Saintes (Angin and Gomès 2015, Gomès and Ibéné 2015) has led to subsequent disagreements about the systematics of this group:  Miralles et al. (2017) proposed recognizing a single species for the archipelago (for which they selected the name M. desiradae), including M. parviterrae and the three taxa for which molecular data were not available: M. cochonae, M. grandisterrae and M. guadeloupae, a scheme subsequently rejected by Hedges et al. (2019).

These accounts follow the multispecies taxonomy presented by Hedges and Conn (2012), Hedges et al. (2016) and Hedges et al. (2019) but recognize that an accurate resolution of the taxonomy of this group may never be possible.

These accounts follow the multispecies taxonomy presented by Hedges and Conn (2012), Hedges et al. (2016) and Hedges et al. (2019) but recognize that an accurate resolution of the taxonomy of this group may never be possible.

Subsequently, Hedges et al. (2016) included material of M. desiradae in both morphological and molecular analyses, the results of which led to Hedges et al. (2016) recognizing a population from Iles de la Petite Terre as a separate species, M. parviterrae, specifically distinct from M. desiradae from La Désirade.

Unfortunately most of these taxa are now either extinct or extremely rare, and as such the sample sizes used to distinguish these species were very small (five or fewer specimens for every member of the M. guadeloupae group), which A. Miralles (pers. comm. 2018) suggests is not sufficient to obtain statistically meaningful results.. This data limitation, along with the discovery of an additional related population from Iles des Saintes (Angin and Gomès 2015, Gomès and Ibéné 2015) has led to subsequent disagreements about the systematics of this group:  Miralles et al. (2017) proposed recognizing a single species for the archipelago (for which they selected the name M. desiradae), including M. parviterrae and the three taxa for which molecular data were not available: M. cochonae, M. grandisterrae and M. guadeloupae, a scheme subsequently rejected by Hedges et al. (2019).

These accounts follow the multispecies taxonomy presented by Hedges and Conn (2012), Hedges et al. (2016) and Hedges et al. (2019) but recognize that an accurate resolution of the taxonomy of this group may never be possible.

authority: (Miralles, Rivas, Bonillo, Schargel, Barros, García-Perez & Barrio-Amorós, 2009)
(Miralles, Rivas, Bonillo, Schargel, Barros, García-Perez & Barrio-Amorós, 2009)

taxonomicNotes: This species was described based on a large series of historical specimens previously assigned to Spondylurus semitaeniatus, itself treated as a junior synonym of S. sloanii until revalidated by Hedges and Conn (2012).

Skinks from the Virgin Islands have had a confused taxonomic history since the 18th century, and have mostly been treated as Mabuya sloanii (=Spondylurus sloanii), or sometimes M. mabouia or M. semitaeniatus (=S. semitaeniatus) (Hedges and Conn 2012). In their revision of Caribbean skinks, Hedges and Conn (2012) determined that historical material from St. Croix variously treated as belonging to M. sloanii or M. mabouya represented a previously unknown large skink, which they named Spondylurus magnacruzae.

This species was described based on a large series of historical specimens which, since the first collection in 1894, have been assigned to four different species, most recently Mabuya (now Spondylurus) sloanii (Hedges and Conn 2012).

Mabuya nitidus was removed from long synonymy with Mabuya sloanii by Hedges and Conn (2012), who redescribed this species and assigned it to Spondylurus. S. nitidus, which was at the time known only from historical material, was not included in these authors' genetic analysis, however molecular work has since confirmed its specific validity (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data). The identity of a presumably extinct skink from Vieques is unknown, as several species are now known to occur in Puerto Rico (Hedges and Conn 2012). It may have been a population of S. nitidus or S. culebrae (or even the Virgin Islands endemic S. sloanii) (Hedges and Conn 2012), however the possibility also exists that the report referred to a species endemic to Vieques (Hedges and Conn 2012). A reference to mabuyine skinks being "relatively common" on Vieques (Rivero 1998), is thought likely to be in error, as no specimens exist or have been reported in extensive recent surveys, and mabuyine skinks were unknown to the island's inhabitants in 1931 (Hedges and Conn 2012). Genetic research is needed to clarify the appropriate taxonomic status of populations from islands off Puerto Rico (Hedges and Conn 2012).

This species was previously included within the synonymy of Spondylurus sloanii (Hedges and Conn 2012). The exact definition of S. semitaeniatus has been a source of some historical confusion, due in part to an unspecific type locality "America" and in part to taxonomic actions to synonymize or recognize it taken without reference to the original material (Hedges and Conn 2012).  Grant (1932) associated this taxon with Mona and Culebra (both in Puerto Rico), however the revision by Hedges and Conn (2012) identified these islands as being represented by two Spondylurus species, neither conspecific with the type of S. semitaeniatus. These authors found instead that the holotype corresponds with a species which is widespread in the Virgin Islands. Hedges and Conn (2012) fixed St. Thomas as the type locality.

The somewhat complicated taxonomic history of this species is discussed in detail by Hedges and Conn (2012). In recent usage this species has been considered to be a widespread skink occurring on most of the Virgin Islands, along with Culebra and Mona in Puerto Rico (the latter, along with some Virgin Island records, under the presumed synonym Mabuya semitaeniatus) (Hedges and Conn 2012). These authors reviewed the taxonomy of Caribbean skinks and determined that M. (=Spondylurus) semitaeniatus is a valid species surviving mainly on smaller islands in the British Virgin Islands, and that the Puerto Rican populations are specifically distinct from both this taxon and S. sloanii. Molecular results suggest that S. sloanii and S. semitaeniatus are not especially closely-related (Hedges and Conn 2012). Hedges and Conn (2012) note that further material is required to better-characterize S. sloanii and to determine whether the widespread island populations all represent the same species.

Euprepes spilonotus was described based on two specimens, one from the "West Indes" and one without locality data (Hedges and Conn 2012). For most of the following two centuries this name was thought to apply to a taxon from Jamaica, and subsequently treated as a junior synonym of Mabuya (now Spondylurus) sloanii (Hedges and Conn 2012). In their revision of Caribbean skinks, Hedges and Conn (2012) determined that the holotype was distinct from the Jamaican species (now S. fulgidus) and was instead conspecific with S. sloanii material from St. Thomas and St. John in the US Virgin Islands. This material was itself found to represent a species distinct from S. sloanii, and Hedges and Conn (2012) therefore erected the combination Spondylurus spilonotus and restricted the type locality to "St. Thomas or St. John".

Grossmann and Tillack (2003) synonymized Asthenodipsas tropidonotus, described from Sumatra, within A. vertebralis on morphological grounds. Molecular data subsequently confirmed that the Sumatran population is genetically distinct from mainland A. vertebralis, and Loredo et al. (2013) consequently removed A. tropidonotus from synonymy with A. vertebralis and identified morphological diagnostic features. This action restricted A. vertebralis to the Malay Peninsula, and the identity of records of this species from Kalimantan is consequently in need of clarification.

A number of new Brookesia were described from the north-west of Madagascar which were formerly attributed to B. minima (Glaw et al. 2012). The known range of B. minima is therefore smaller than previously reported.
This species was previously referred to as Brookesia sp. Montagne des Francais and Brookesia sp. nov.

This species was originally named as a distinct species before being reduced to the subspecies, Trioceros bitaeniatus Fischer, 1884 by Werner (1911). Rand (1963) revised the complicated systematics of the bitaeniatus group and elevated T. hoehnelii to a full species once again, while several other taxa from the bitaeniatus group became junior synonyms under T. hoehnelii (Chamaeleon leikipiensis Steindachner 1891, Chamaeleon bitaeniatus bergeri Sternfeld 1912, Chamaeleon bitaeniatus alteelgonis Loveridge 1935).  At present T. hoehnelii (Steindachner, 1891) is considered monotypic (Klaver and Bohme 1986, Spawls et al. 2004, Tilbury 2010) although some authors have recognised T. hoehnelii altaeelgonis as a valid taxon (Mertens 1966, Necas 1999). In addition, there are several areas of potential disjunction in the distribution of this species, which could lead to isolation of populations. The Mt. Elgon population is apparently genetically distinct, but the level of this divergence has not been established (Stipala 2014). Therefore, the species should be investigated in a phylogenetic context.

There is some uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of the presumed Southern Highlands population of this species. It was originally considered a sub-species (Trioceros laterispinis brookesiaformis) but was later synonymised (Böhme 1987). There is only one specimen from the Southern Highlands, and its actual collection locality (Kibau Iyayi) is not certain. The existence of this population significantly affects this species' extent of occurrence and both its occurrence in this area and taxonomic status needs to be verified.

Accepted as Trioceros ituriensis (Tilbury 2010). A new record from Kibale forest in Uganda shows that a population may exist on the eastern side of the high Rwenzori Mountains. This population should be investigated in a phylogenetic context.
Once formerly considered as a subspecies R. marshalli marshalli Broadley, 1971, but phylogenetic studies confirm that this taxon is a separate species (Matthee et al. 2004).

Leptotyphlops merkeri was previously considered a subspecies of L. scutifrons (Broadley and Wallach 2007), but is now treated as a full species following the finding that the two taxa are not close relatives (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009). A record from Malawi (Broadley and Wallach 2007) is presumed to represent a different species (W. Branch pers. comm. 2014). Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) found high levels of sequence divergence within members of Leptotyphlops as these authors defined the genus; although Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) did not include this species in their analysis, these authors caution that cryptic taxa may be found within members of the genus other than those they analyzed

The appropriate taxonomic status of three taxa traditionally regarded as distinct species - Laudakia badakhshana, L. bocharensis and L. himalayana - is uncertain, in part due to the existence of  populations with apparently intermediate characteristics between the known ranges of these taxa. In their revision of Laudakia, Baig et al. (2012) identified these three forms as a subgroup within their new genus Paralaudakia. The confusion regarding their appropriate status is summarized in these authors use of the combinations Paralaudakia (himalayana) badakhshana and P. (himalayana) bocharensis to describe this situation. As presently understood, however, the three taxa are diagnosably distinct and with essentially allopatric distributions (Baig et al. 2012), and are here treated as good species.

The appropriate taxonomic status of three taxa traditionally regarded as distinct species - Laudakia badakhshana, L. bocharensis and L. himalayana - is uncertain, in part due to the existence of  populations with apparently intermediate characteristics between the known ranges of these taxa. In their revision of Laudakia, Baig et al. (2012) identified these three forms as a subgroup within their new genus Paralaudakia. The confusion regarding their appropriate status is summarized in these authors use of the combinations Paralaudakia (himalayana) badakhshana and P. (himalayana) bocharensis to describe this situation. As presently understood, however, the three taxa are diagnosably distinct and with essentially allopatric distributions (Baig et al. 2012), and are here treated as good species.

Baig (1992) refers Agama chernovi and A. isozona to the synonymy of P. bochariensis.

It is considered as a supra-species complex and constitutes a sub-group within Paralaudakia along with Paralaudakia bochariensis and Paralaudakia badakshana and this group may be considered as small Paralaudakia lizards (Baig et al. 2012).
This species was reassigned from Laudakia to the new genus Paralaudakia by Baig et al. (2012).

The status of two synonyms of the widespread Laudakia tuberculata, L. dayana and L. sykesii, was examined briefly by Baig et al. (2012). These authors revalidated L. dayana as a distinct species, and indicated that L. sykesii is comprised of representatives of both valid species. These authors also elevated the former subspecies L. t. sacra to specific status.
Khan (2008) placed the species in the genus Altigekko.

Mediodactylus has often been treated as a subgenus or synonym of Cyrtopodion. Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and that Mediodactylus warrants recognition as a valid genus. This species belongs to a species complex including M. russowii and M. zaryudni, the systematics of which have yet to be fully resolved, and research is underway to clarify this situation.

Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including T. voraginosus. These authors explicitly rejected the subspecific status for this taxon suggested by Ščerbak and Golubev (1996) and followed by subsequent authors (e.g. Ananjeva et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). This account follows Bauer et al. (2013) in treating T. voraginosus as a full species.
This species was tentatively assigned to Cyrtodactylus from Cyrtopodion by Bauer et al. (2013).
