Molecular data suggest that C. mansarulum may be conspecific with C. rohtasfortai, considered the commonest sandstone gecko in Pakistan by Khan (2008), in which case the name C. mansarulum (Duda and Sahi 1978) has priority (Agarwal et al. 2014).
Tenuidactylus baturensis was transferred to Altigekko by Khan (2003). Based on genetic analysis, the species was assigned to Altiphylax by Bauer et al. (2013).
In the original description, the authors used three different spellings; A. tokobajevi was used first and therefore has priority.

Alsophylax szczerbaki from Turkmenistan is now generally regarded as a full species (see Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008) rather than a subspecies of A. loricatus, and this treatment is followed here; however, the older scheme is used in Ananjeva et al. (2006).

Alsophylax szczerbaki from Turkmenistan is now generally regarded as a full species (see Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008) rather than a subspecies of A. loricatus, and this treatment is followed here; however, the older scheme is used in Ananjeva et al. (2006).
Jin and Brown (2013) consider Phrynocephalus guinanensis a junior synonym of P. putjatai based on genetic results obtained in an unpublished PhD thesis (Jin 2008), and this scheme is followed here.

Elaphe japonica is treated as a valid species by Ananjeva et al. (2006), who however note that it is often treated as a colour morph of Elaphe (now Euprepiophis) conspicillata. There appears to be no formal taxonomic work addressing the status of E. japonica, however there are many Russian literature references to a species of this name (L. Borkin pers. comm, 2016, P. Uetz pers. comm. 2013). Utiger et al. (2002) do not refer to this taxon but implicitly include it within E. conspicillata in describing this species as being shared between Japan and the Kuril Islands (as only "E. japonica" occurs on Kunashir). Similarly, only E. conspicillata is recognized in the checklist produced by the Herpetological Society of Japan. This account treats E. japonica as a junior synonym of E. conspicillata (and adopts the nomen conspicillata in preference to conspicillatus) following Uetz and Hallerman (2012).
It has been suggested that isolated populations in western Mongolia might represent cryptic species (Terbish et al. 2006).
As presently understood, Eremias buechneri is endemic to China; records from Kyrgyzstan are now referred to Eremias kokshaaliensis (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).

This species has been treated as a subspecies of Eremias multiocellata (e.g. Zhao and Adler 1993, Ščerbak 2003), but is here treated as a full species following recent usage (e.g. Ananjeva et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). This status has been confirmed by recent molecular work (Orlova et al. 2017).

Based on morphological grounds, Ablepharus grayanus is clearly distinguished from A. pannonicus occurring in the eastern and western regions of the Iranian Plateau (Karamiani et al. 2015). Records from Afghanistan may represent a different species.

Schleich and Kästle (2002) indicate that a population found in Dhorpatan (Nepal) and Kashmir attributed to Asymblepharus himalayanus may represent a cryptic species. The Dhorpatan locality is considered here to represent a different species, as these two localities are separated by entirety of the western Himalaya (L. Borkin pers. comm. 2016).

In order to clarify the status of a recently-identified Peruvian population of Euspondylus (which they described as E. excelsum), Chávez et al. (2017) examined material previously assigned to E. maculatus. These authors found that three records of E. maculatus from Chanchamayo and Santo Domingo Provinces in Peru represent two separate, undescribed species.

A review of the known populations referred to Petracola ventrimaculatus, incorporating both morphological and ecological data, indicated that this taxon is a species complex (Echeverría-Espinosa 2014). This work suggested that the distribution of P. ventrimaculatus may be restricted to Celendin (Cajamarca) when the taxonomy is clarified.

authority: Kirizian, Bayefsky-Anand, Eriksson, Minh Le & Donnelly, 2008

taxonomicNotes: Oreosaurus lacertus Stejneger, 1913 is presently considered a valid species under the name Proctoporus lacertus (Goicoechea et al. 2013).
In this assessment, specimens attributed to Riama inanis are referred to this species (Rivas et al. 2012).

Southern records of this species are based on juveniles with characteristics similar to both D. prolixum or D. graciliverpa (Cadle 2012), and their specific status is therefore in need of clarification.
Previously confused with Dendrophidion brunneum (see Cadle 2012).

Species delimitation within this group is complicated by the use of limited morphological characters for comparison in earlier descriptions (Aguilar et al. 2017). Liolaemus disjunctus was described from a "doubtful" type locality (Aguilar et al. 2017) at the northern limit of this genus' distribution, and there is no evidence from recent fieldwork that this or any other species of Liolaemus occurs here (C. Aguilar pers. comm. 2015). It is likely that L. disjunctus represents a known species of Liolaemus, but was described as a different taxon on the basis of this erroneous type locality (Aguilar et al. 2017).

According to C. Aguilar, preliminary molecular data suggests that the lowland populations between the type locality and southern Peru may be different, undescribed species (C. Aguilar pers. comm. 2016).
Molecular data indicate that this species actually comprises two species.
This species needs further taxonomic research.
This species represents the oldest lineage of Microlophus on the Galápagos Islands, and so is more evolutionarily distinct than other members of the group (Benavides et al. 2007).
The two colour morphs likely comprises different species (E. Lehr and P. Venegas, pers. comm. 2014).
Some populations in the highlands of Cajamarca and La Libertad regions presently assigned to Stenocercus stigmosus may represent undescribed species (C. Aguilar pers. comm. 2014).

Harvey (2008) found only weak morphological differentiation between this species and Dipsas peruana. While this author tentatively retained D. schunki as a valid species, he cautioned that further taxonomic work is needed to confirm this assignment.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

authority: Arteaga, Salazar-Valenzuela, Mebert, Peñafiel, Aguiar, Sánchez-Nivicela, Pyron, Colston, Cisneros-Heredia, Yánez-Muñoz, Venegas, Guayasamin & Torres-Carvajal, 2018
taxonomicNotes:
Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas. As the name Dipsas petersi was already preoccupied (by Dipsas indica petersi Hoge and Romano, 1975, sometimes treated as a full species), these authors coined the new name Dipsas jamespetersi for Sibynomorphus petersi (Orces & Almenariz, 1989).

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that D. jamespetersi was paraphyletic with respect to a sample of Dipsas vaga. As neither species was included in their revision further research is required to determine whether these taxa are genuinely conspecific or whether the GenBank sample of D. vaga used represents a misidentification (A. Arteaga pers. comm. 2018).

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.
This species may represent a misidentification of Tachymenis peruviana, which also occurs in this region (C. Aguilar pers comm. 2014).

Records of this species from Ecuador have been reassigned to Micrurus ornatissimus (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2015). It is possible that both species are in fact synonyms, however, this the taxonomic issues involved have not been fully resolved and work is underway to clarify this situation (J. Valencia pers. comm. 2016).
This species was assigned to the new genus Paralaudakia (from Laudakia) by Baig et al. (2012).
This species was reassigned from Laudakia to the new genus Paralaudakia by Baig et al. (2012).

This species was reassigned from Laudakia to the new genus Paralaudakia by Baig et al. (2012). Baig (1992) and Baig et al. (2012) suggest that records from Turkmenistan historically attributed to Paralaudakia caucasia are probably attributable to P. microlepis, and that molecular analysis indicating that that these represent true P. caucasia (Macey et al. 1998) may have used sequences properly attributable to P. microlepis. It has been suggested that these may represent a hybrid population due to apparently intermediate characteristics between the two forms (Baig et al. 2012 and refs therein, Ananjeva et al. 2014), but further genetic research is needed to clarify this (Ananjeva et al. 2014). Pending resolution of this issue this account attributes Turkmen records to P. caucasia following Macey et al. (1998) and Ananjeva et al. (2014).
Records from Chile previously attributed to this species have been described as a separate taxon, Liolaemus puna.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

Cadle (2001) stated that specimens of Stenocercus aculeatus may represent two or more species, based on the species' apparent disjunct distribution.  Until recently the name Stenocercus aculeatus was applied to two different species described as Leiocephalus aculeatus O´Shaughnessy, 1879 and L. angulifer Werner, 1901 from eastern Ecuador and northeastern Peru, respectively. These two names were synonymized by Burt and Burt (1931) as L. iridescens aculeatus, which was subsequently recognized as Ophryoessoides aculeatus (Etheridge 1966) and later as S. aculeatus (Frost 1992). Upon resurrection of S. angulifer, which occurs in eastern Ecuador, S. aculeatus was restricted to the departments of La Libertad, Loreto, and San Martín at elevations of 723-1311 m in northeastern Peru (Torres-Carvajal 2007).

Further taxonomic studies are needed into the relationship between Phrynocephalus helioscopus and P. persicus; as some authors treat them as being conspecific. P. horvathi is variously treated as a subspecies of P. helioscopus or P. persicus; the latter is accepted by Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007). Specific status for P. saidalievi, previously included within P. helioscopus, has been confirmed by Solovyeva et al. (2014).

Golubev (1998) recognizing Iranian populations as distinct, describing the new subspecies Phrynocephalus vindumi. Solovyeva et al. (2014) included only P o. vindumi in genetic analysis, with no samples from P. o. ornatus, leaving the appropriate status of this taxon unresolved, The genetic distance between the two taxa has subsequently been confirmed to be at a level typical of that between species in Phrynocephalus lizards (Macey et al. 2018). Consequently this account treats Phrynocephalus vindumi as a full species.
This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Phrynocephalus reticulatus Eichwald, 1831  (=Phrynocepallus ocellatus, see taxonomic note for P. reticulatus) (Szczerbak 2003).

Wang and Fu (2004) investigated the systematics of the Phyrnocephalus versicolor species complex, which they defined to include P. przewalskii and P. frontalis as well as what were then understood to be eastern populations of P. versicolor (western ones apparently being attributable to P. guttatus). On the basis of molecular evidence, these authors synonymized all three taxa under the name P. przewalskii. The same results, however, revealed two hithero unsuspected, reciprocally monophyletic clades within the complex. Although P. versicolor sensu stricto appears to be a junior synonym of P. przewalskii based on the type locality (the type specimens themselves have not been examined to confirm this), Wang and Fu (2004) argue that the name should be applied instead to the separate northern clade (Clade E of Wang and Fu 2004) following ICZN rules on the conservation of prevailing usage. This arrangement has subsequently been accepted as valid (Babarov and Ananjeva 2007). The southern clade of the former P. versicolor complex is (as of April 2016) undescribed (Wang and Fu 2004).  Terbish et al. (2006), while noting that populations further north are likely attributable to P. guttatus, nevertheless included these records within P. versicolor, thereby extending its range into northern Mongolia, Russia and Siberian Kazakhstan. This account, however, follows Wang and Fu (2004) and Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008) (who assign all Kazakh records to P. guttatus) in restricting this species to China and southwest Mongolia. The population from Tuva in Siberia and the Altai Mountains described as the subspecies P. v. kulagini is likewise attributable to P. guttatus (Wang and Fu 2004). Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007) consider P. hispidus  a subspecies of Phrynocephalus versicolor, a scheme still adopted by the Reptile Database. On genetic grounds Solovyeva et al. (2014) identified a distinct clade within the P. versicolor complex from the Dzungarian Gobi to which they apply the name P. hispidus. This taxon was not formally redescribed and its distribution has yet to be accurately characterized, but is treated here as a separate taxon.

Doubts have been expressed regarding the validity of Atractus meridensis, which differs from it morphologically only in the number of scale rows (15 vs. 17) (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2018). Although both forms have been recorded in sympatry in the Chama River Valley, it is possible that this represents variation within a single population. As presently understood A. meridensis is known from both sides of the Mérida Mountain range. It is possible that the specimens from the Mérida city area both represent A. erythromelas and are specifically distinct from the record from the Santo Domingo type locality, in which case A. meridensis would represent a valid species restricted to the northern versant of the range (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2018). As only one specimen is known from the type locality, the true status of A. meridensis is difficult to determine (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2018).

Sindaco and Jeremçenko (2008) treat Ablepharus lindbergi, previously considered a subspecies of A. bivittatus, as a full species without discussion. This is now the scheme followed in some checklists (Uetz and Hallerman 2015), and A. lindbergi is considered a separate taxon here based on its distribution and differences in scalation (see Wagner et al. 2016).

Determining the taxonomic identity of Telescopus rhinopoma has been complicated by inconsistencies in the characters measured for the same type specimens, and for different species, by multiple authors (Böhme 1977). This author declined to present a taxonomic treatment of this complex group of snakes but suggested based on their measurements that T. rhinopoma appeared to represent part of a cline of variation between T. tessellatus, T. martini (presently recognized as a subspecies or junior synonym of T. tessellatus) and T. fallax. No subsequent treatment appears to have investigated the validity of T. rhinopoma, although Nilson and Rastegar-Pouyani  (2013) note that it differs in scale counts from all western Iranian Telescopus (including both tessellatus and fallax).

This species is included in Zamenis following Utiger et al. (2002). Zamenis lineatus was separated from this species by Lenk and Wuster (1999). Two subspecies are recognized: Z. l. longissimus (Laurenti, 1768) is widely distributed in western, central and southern Europe, except in southern Italy and Sicily which are inhabited by Z. lineatus. Z. l. rechingeri Werner, 1932 is found in the larger Cyclades islands, in particular on Amorgos. Elaphe longissima romana (Suckow, 1798) is probably a synonym of both Z. longissmus.

As presently understood this species is monotypic (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). Szczerbak and Golubev (1996) highlight morphological differences which may justify treating the junior synonym Agamura cruralis as warranting at least subspecific status, but note that comparative material is insufficient to confirm this assignment.

Mediodactylus has often been treated as a subgenus or synonym of Cyrtopodion. Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and that Mediodactylus warrants recognition as a valid genus. The nominate subspecies M. russowi russowi is distributed in Central Asia and Kazakhstan. The subspecies M. r. zarudnyi (Nikolsky, 1900) occurs in northeastern and eastern Iran (Khorasan and Sistan Provinces).

It is possible that the subspecific form M. r. kopalensis (Shnitnikov, 1928) from Kazakhstan will be revalidated as a species following additional molecular research; this form was not included in analysis or discussed by Bauer et al. (2013), who investigated the systematics of Palearctic naked-toed geckos.

Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including the type species of this genus, T. caspius. The nominate subspecies T. c. caspium (Eichwald, 1831) is distributed throughout the species' range with the exception of Wulf Island (Azerbaijan) in the Caspian Sea, 12 km from the Apsheron Peninsula, where the endemic subspecies T. c. insularis (Akhmedow & Szczerbak, 1978) is found.

A phylogeographic study of this species based on mtDNA (Kalyabina et al. 2001) identified three groups of populations. Further studies of contact areas are needed to evaluate the taxonomic status of these three lineages (Crochet and Dubois 2004). This species has "many" subspecies (Speybroeck et al. 2016): nine are generally recognized (Andres et al. 2014) but others have been described and there is a degree of inconsistency between authors in both the number of subspecies and their range boundaries. Andres et al. (2014) found that Lacerta agilis boehmica is more distinct genetically from other members of the species complex than Lacerta viridis and L. bilineata are from one another, but took no taxonomic action. These authors also identified issues in need of taxonomic attention within the L. agilis complex.

This species contains a number of different lineages, some of which might constitute separate species (see Bea et al. (1990), Surget-Groba et al. (2001, 2002), Mayer and Böhme (2000), and Mayer et al. (2000) for further details).
This species is one of a number of taxa previously included within the ill-defined "Thamnodynastes strigilis" species complex (Bailey and Thomas 2007)
Populations north and south of the Amazon River probably represent different species (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2014).
Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the separation of this species from T. torquatus (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).

Carvalho (2016) revised Tropidurus guarani, identifying four morphotypes within populations assigned to this taxon and describing three of these as the new species T. lagunablanca, T. tarara and T. teyumirim.
A record of this species from Trinidad (Murphy 1997) is believed to represent an undescribed species (CaribHerp), and is not considered in this assessment.

Records now attributed to this species include historical specimens previously identified as Thamnodynastes nattereri (Maracaibo) and the ill-defined "T. strigilis" complex (Rio Hacha in the Guajira Peninsula) (Bailey and Thomas 2007). A Colombian record that Campbell and Lamar (2004) suggested may be referrable to T. gambotensis was found to represent T. paraguanae by Bailey and Thomas (2007).

Morphological differences and geographic distance from its only congener Callopistes maculatus has led some authors to place this species in the monotypic genus Tejovaranus. This scheme has not been adopted in recent revisions of teiid or squamate taxonomy (Harvey et al. 2012, Pyron et al. 2013), and so the species is retained in Callopistes here.

Cabrera (2012) described "the southernmost population" of the Cnemidophorus ocellifer complex (now Ameivula ocellifera following Harvey et al. 2012) as the Chaco endemic Cnemidophorus abalosi. The distribution provided by these authors covers most of Paraguay and northern Argentina, and by implication may therefore restrict A. ocellifera to Brazil and Bolivia. Cabrera (2012) did not discuss the distribution of the revised A. ocellifera, however, and so sympatry between the two taxa in at least part of this range cannot be ruled out. Avila et al. (2013) do not list this species for Argentina. It is likely that further species will be described from within the A. ocellifera species group (Cabrera 2012).

Cnemidophorus pseudolemniscatus is a triploid parthenogenetic species that originated from hybridization between C. cryptus and C. lemniscatus. In terms of the diploid bisexual ancestors, C. pseudolemniscatus has two genomes from C. lemniscatus and one from C. gramivagus (Cole and Dessauer 1993).

Cabrera et al. (2019) investigated the systematics of Contomastix lacertoides using both morphological and molecular evidence, and concluded that Argentinian populations represent a distinct species, which they named C. celata.

Contomastix charrua was described from a population then referred to Cnemidophorus (now Contomastix) lacertoides on the basis of differences in coloration, structure of the hyoid apparatus and geological history of the cape (Cabrera and Carreira 2009). Borteiro et al. (2013) found no morphological differences between the two taxa and referred C. charrua to the synonymy of C. lacertoides. S. Carreira (pers. comm. 2016) indicates that ongoing research has identified additional differences that may warrant recognizing C. charrua as a separate species, and recommends retaining C. charrua as a valid species pending comparison with material from the C. lacertoides type locality, which was not done by Borteiro et al. (2013). C. charrua was recognized as a distinct species by Cabrera et al. (2019), but these authors do not discuss this assignment.
The relationship between this species and Contomastix vittata is in need of resolution (R. Langstroth in litt.).

Anolis bitectus may be conspecific with populations presently known as Anolis lemniscatus and A. binotatus (in which case Anolis binotatus will be the oldest available name), and research is ongoing to clarify the status of these taxa (F. Ayala et al.in prep.).

Poe et al. (2009) suggested that this lizard may be a junior synonym of Anolis festae, but took no formal taxonomic action. Miyata (2013), by implication, appeared to share this interpretation, but no supporting evidence was presented and no taxonomic action was proposed.

A specimen from northern Peru resembling this species (P. Venegas, unpubl. data) is some way inside the country, and so appears to be isolated from the Ecuadorian localities, but due to differences between this specimen and the Ecuadorian form it is not clear that this is referrable to the same species.
This species was previously a member of the Dipsas oreas complex, from which it was elevated by Cadle (2005).

Dipsas bucephala and D. cisticeps form a probable species complex whose taxonomy is unresolved. Cacciali et al. (2016) agree with Harvey and Embert (2008) that these taxa are specifically distinct from Dipsas indica, but note that these authors only examined specimens of the Bolivian subspecies which these authors recognize as Dipsas cisticeps "until further evidence proves us wrong". In light of the lack of a formal recent treatment to clarify the status of D. cisticeps, and the likelihood that further cryptic species exist within D. bucephala as presently understood (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), this assessment follows the treatment adopted by Harvey and Embert (2008) and followed most recently by Nogueira et al. (2019), who treat D. cisticeps as a subspecies of D. bucephala.
Passos et al. (2004) synonymized D. copei with Leptognathus incertus, but this was rejected by Harvey (2008). Rivas et al. (2012) also recognized D. copei.

Cadle and Myers (2003) revised the systematics of this species and referred records from Panama, Ecuador, Colombia and Peru to other species (Harvey and Embert 2008 subsequently confirmed its occurrence in the latter country and Bolivia). In a revision of Bolivian Dipsas, Harvey and Embert (2008) includes D. neivai as a junior synonym of D. variegata on the basis that specimens of D. neivai cannot "confidently" be distinguished from D. variegata and this arrangement is followed here. Wallach et al. (2014) recognize Dipsas neivai as a distinct species, but provide no justification. Research is recommended to clarify the taxonomic status of D. neivai, as Harvey and Embert (2008) did not examine the types of either taxon.
Micrurus mertensi and M. catamayensis may be synonyms (J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014). Micrurus peruvianus may also be part of this clade.

This species has three subspecies:
E. melanotus melanotus (Shaw, 1802)
E. melanotus lamari (Dixon & Michaud, 1992)
E. melanotus nesos (Dixon & Michaud, 1992).

authority: Grazziotin, Zaher, Murphy, Scrocchi, Benavides, Zhang & Bonatto, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Erythrolamprus almadensis is a species complex (Dixon 1991).
Ascenso et al. (2019) supported the recognition of Erythrolamprus dorsocorallinus as distinct from E. reginae, although Wallach et al. (2014) suggested that these taxa may be conspecific.
This is a species complex (Dixon and Markezich 1992).
The species may be a synonym of Anolis fuscoauratus, and further taxonomic work is needed (Poe and Yañez-Miranda 2008).

authority: Grazziotin, Zaher, Murphy, Scrocchi, Benavides, Zhang & Bonatto, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
Wallach (2016) summarized the controversial history of the names Epictia albifrons and E. tenella, which he divided into three schools of thought. In two of these the two taxa are synonymous, but there is disagreement over whether the correct name is albifrons or whether this name should be considered a nomen dubium and the correct name is therefore tenella. The third scheme proposes that the two taxa are validly distinct. Wallach (2016) rejected the neotype designation - based on a damaged specimen - by Natera-Munaw et al. (2015) and proposed a different neotype, further confusing the situation.

Pinto et al. (2018) investigated this issue in detail. This work found both that the name E. albifrons was applied incorrectly by Wallach (2016) due to confusion surrounding this species' diagnostic characters, and that this author's action in rejecting the earlier neotype designation violated International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature rules. Pinto et al. (2018) concluded that the names E. albifrons and E. tenella refer to the same taxon and that the name albifrons should have priority. The species recognized as E. albifrons by Wallach (2016) has not been identified, and is thought to be an undescribed species of unclear provenance by Pinto et al. (2018).

A series of five specimens assigned to this species from Pusuq'huni, Arque Province (Tarifa et al. 2007) are instead referable to Liolaemus variegatus (two specimens) and an indeterminate species tentatively assigned to the Liolaemus montanus group (Jiménez-Robles et al. 2016)

Southern populations presently assigned to this species appear to resemble Liolaemus bitaeniatus and may be referrable to the latter species (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016). If so, L. variegatus would be restricted to higher elevations in the vicinity of the type locality, with L. bitaeniatus replacing it in warmer inter-Andean valleys.
Historical records of this species include those under the name Bothrops lanceolatus or varied names from mainland Bothrops species, of which caribbaeus was previously treated as a subspecies.
This species may be synonymous with Contomastix leachei (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).

authority: Goicoechea, Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher & de la Riva, 2013
Goicoechea, Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher & de la Riva, 2013

taxonomicNotes: The Vipera ursinii species complex (or the synonymous subgenus Acridophaga REUSS, 1927) has a large distribution area from Eastern France to Western China, which was shaped by the last three glacial periods (Ferchaud et al. 2012). This species group comprises small vipers, which live in grasslands, either in lowlands or on mountain tops (Nilson and Andrén 2001). In the last two decades some V. ursinii subspecies have been elevated to distinct species level based on molecular and morphological analyses (V. renardi, V. anatolica, and V. eriwanensis). The Greek Meadow Viper (Vipera ursinii graeca) was described as a subspecies of Vipera ursinii by Nilson and Andrén (1988) based on morphological analyses. Ferchaud et al. (2012) proposed that V. u. graeca should be elevated to species, according to the results of mitochondrial DNA phylogenetic analyses. Based on a mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analyses Mizsei et al. (2017) proposed a full species rank for the Greek Meadow Viper (=Vipera graeca) to resolve the polyphyly in the Vipera ursinii–renardi complex.

A molecular phylogeny indicated that Gerrhosaurus nigrolineatus was restricted to Gabon and the lower Congo region in west-Central Africa, while most other populations currently identified under this name were referable to G. intermedius. Gerrhosaurus intermedius and G. flavigularis occur in close proximity and have been confused in the past because the two species are often similar in colour pattern. However, they differ with regard to size (G. intermedius grows to 183 mm SVL versus 142 mm SVL in G. flavigularis) and scalation (e.g. in G. intermedius scales under the feet are keeled and spinose and there are usually four supraciliaries; in G. flavigularis scales under feet are smooth and tubercular and there are usually five supraciliaries) (FitzSimons 1935, Jacobsen 1989, Branch 1998). Gerrhosaurus intermedius is also a more robust species with a relatively larger head. Nevertheless, Jacobsen (1989) noted that morphologically flavigularis-like specimens with intermedius-like colour patterns and blue throats occur in the northeast of Limpopo and southwest of North-West Province, and require further investigation. A morphological and genetic revision of the G. nigrolineatus species complex (G. nigrolineatus, G. intermedius, G. auritus, G. bulsi and G. multilineatus) is needed.

This species was transferred to the genus Calumma by Klaver and Böhme (1986) and then back to Archaius by Townsend et al. (2010). The species is found on three oceanic islands that are separated by 20-50 km of open water. It is expected that migration between islands is extremely infrequent, and that populations are divergent, possibly at the species level. These populations therefore, should be investigated in a phylogenetic framework.

Recently-discovered museum specimens from Peru exhibit minor differences in scalation from typical Ecuadorian Bothrops lojanus. These do not correspond to diagnostic characters identified in the original description of B. lojanus, and "in the absence of additional information" Carrasco et al. (2016) opin that these do not warrant the recognition of Peruvian specimens as a different species. These authors did not however conduct any integrative analysis to demonstrate that the Peruvian and Ecuadorian populations are conspecific, and multiple biogeographic barriers within the intervening area - and the trans-Andean distribution the Peruvian records imply - suggests that while they are closely-related they may not belong to the same species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2019).

Based on patterns of endemism found among other reptiles it is hypothesized that populations from Santiago may not be conspecific with those from Santa Cruz (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2017). Analysis to clarify this issue is planned as part of wide-ranging research on Galápagos snakes to be conducted in 2017 (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2017).

Maximum likelihood analysis of a combined morphological and allozyme dataset confirmed that, as suggested by Thomas (1997), Pseudalsophis slevini sensu stricto is endemic to Pinzon island and is more closely-related to P. steindachneri than to populations from the  western islands Fernandina, Isabella and Tortuga (Zaher et al. 2018). Zaher et al. (2018) described the western form as the new species P. darwini.

authority: Schargel, Lamar, Passos, Valcenia, Cisneros-Heredia & Campbell, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Jeremčenko and Panilov (1999) elevated Phrynocephalus helioscopus saidalievi to specific rank, and this has subsequently been followed by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008) and Solovyeya et al. (2014). While Solovyeva et al. (2011) considered this action premature, the lead author's later molecular work concluded that "Genetic isolation of Ph. h. saidalievi from other subspecies is considerable (p = 9.53%– 10.29%) and comparable with the species level of differentiation" (Solovyeva et al. 2014). The subspecies P. s. takirnoy has been described from northern Tajikistan; its validity is unclear and has apparently rarely been referenced in literature.
Wagner et al. (2016) assign specimens previously attributed to Alsophylax pipiens from Afghanistan to A. levitoni; consequently A. pipiens is no longer considered to occur in Afghanistan.
This species was named after Markus Comba whose financial and organizing support was very important for the expedition that helped discover this species.

This species is possibly conspecific with Mediodactylus sagittifer and if so the concept of that taxon will change and it will require reassessment. Bauer et al. (2013) keep it separate as a valid species.

authority: Grismer, Wood Jr, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012
Grismer, Wood Jr, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Acredita tratar-se de um complexo de espécies (Pellegrino et al. 2005).

authority: Grismer, Wood Jr, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Records of the species from the Lenggong Valley have been recognized as the distinct species Cyrtodactylus lenggongensis (Grismer et al 2016).

authority: Grismer, Wood Jr, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species was described from a single juvenile specimen, and consequently further taxonomic review of this species is needed (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Phung, Nguyen, Hoang & Ziegler, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species, which formerly included two subspecies (Micrurus pyrrocryptus pyrrhocryptus and M. p. tricolor) was split in two valid species, with the elevation of M. p. tricolor to full species status (da Silva Jr and Sites 1999).

Rivas et al. (2018) report that Philodryas boliviana is "common, well-known and easily identified" in dry inter-Andean forests. As only three confirmed specimens of this species exist, none from the province or habitat type where this work was conducted, it is not clear that this name has been applied appropriately by these authors.

There is a narrow zone of intergradation between Amphisbaena angustifrons and A. plumbea, in which there are individuals with intermediate characters, and there is a possibility that it is one species (Gans 1965, Gans and Diefenbach 1972).

Due to the presence of specimens with intermediate characters, in large parts of intergradation areas, it is possible that  A. darwini, A. trachura and A. heterozonata all represent a single species (Gans 1966), for which Amphisbaena darwinii is the oldest available name.
This is a polymorphic species, possibly representing a species complex (Gans 1971).
There is a narrow zone of intergradation between A. angustifrons and A. plumbea, in which there are individuals with intermediate characters, and it is possible that these are conspecific.

Due to the presence of specimens with intermediate characters, in large parts of intergradation, it is possible that specimens attributed to Amphisbaena darwini, A. trachura and A. heterozonata may belong to a single species for which A. darwini is the oldest available name (Gans 1966). If so, this would extend A. darwini's range to northern Argentina, southern Bolivia, and central Paraguay (Montero 1996, Montero and Terol 1999)

Systematic relationships among Ophiodes species are unclear. The distribution of this taxon is consequently uncertain and there is a need for further taxonomic research to clearly separate it from Ophiodes cf. striatus (Montechiario et al. 2011).

Cacciali and Scott (2012) reported that the Ophiodes striatus complex was represented in Paraguay by two species, one of which was in the process of being described. This work was published by Cacciali and Scott (2015), who named the novel taxon Ophiodes luciae.
Micrurus mertensi and M. catamayensis may be synonyms (J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014). Micrurus peruvianus may also be part of this clade.
Taxonomic research is recommended because it may represent a species complex (Giraudo et al. 2012).
This species may have been confused with Micrurus steindachneri, and research is underway to resolve this situation (E. Smith in prep.)

This species should be considered endemic to Catamarca, Argentina (Troncoso-Palacios 2014). However, this species is taxonomically problematic because the type specimens are apparently lost and its type locality is unclear (Lobo et al. 2010, Troncoso-Palacios 2014). If it is not possible to collect topotypic specimens matching the description of the type to designate a neotype, Liolaemus andinus should be considered a nomen dubium, since it is a name of unknown application. Records from Jujuy (Argentina) and Atacama (Chile) probably correspond to other species (Troncoso-Palacios 2014).

authority: Breitman, Fulvio-Pérez, Parra, Morando, Sites & Avila, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species is poorly-studied as it was recently-described from a largely inaccessible region based on a limited number of characters (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). It appears to belong to the taxonomically complex Liolaemus elongatus-kriegi group, within which species delimitation is in need of further study (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). Medina et al. (2017) provided support for the continued recognition of L. carlosgarini. In common with earlier work by Medina (2015) these authors found, however, that haplotypes within this species were shared between L. carlosgarini and other species, and that the species showed no clear molecular differentiation from L. smaug or from an undescribed candidate species.
The taxonomy of this species is currently being reviewed. It is possible that it is a junior synonym of L. kriegi (Medina 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species should be revised.

authority: Martinez, Avila, Fulvio Perez, Perez, Sites & Morando, 2011
Abdala, Semhan, Moreno Azocar, Bonino, Paz & Cruz, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
R. Langstroth (pers comm. in Troncoso-Palacios 2014) suggested that it is possible that Liolaemus molinai from Chile (a taxon which has alternately been treated either as a valid species [e.g. by Demangel et al. 2015] or as a synonym of L. andinus following Lobo et al. 2010), may be a junior synonym of L. erguetae. Preliminary results from ongoing work (Trocosco-Palacios in litt.) support this proposal. Further complicating this issue is uncertainty concerning the identity and relationships of species described as L. erroneous and L. porosus (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).

Further taxonomic study is recommended to fully diagnose all four of these nominal species and clarify their relationships, including the use of molecular approaches due to the absence of clear morphological and geographic limits between these taxa (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).
Some authors synonymize this species with  Liolaemus andinus (Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013b).

Populations formerly recognized as Liolaemus alticolor have been described in recent years, including Liolaemus chungara from Chile (Quinteros et al. 2014),  Liolaemus incaicus from southern Peru (Lobo et al., 2007), and Liolaemus puna from southern Bolivia, northern Chile and northern Argentina (Lobo and Espinoza 2004). These descriptions have been based on morphological differences and apparent biogeographical barriers, without fully examining clinal variation in this formerly widespread species, particularly from the area between the core ranges of L. alticolor and L. puna (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016). Taxonomic research is needed to clarify relationships within this group (R, Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).
Was under Iguanidae.

This species is known from three specimens, all dating to the 1860 description and apparently not well-preserved (M. de Gamboa pers. comm. 2017). As this species has never subsequently been rediscovered, the type locality is imprecise and considered uncertain (M. de Gamboa pers. comm. 2017) and it belongs to a taxonomically complex group of lizards, it is impossible to determine both whether Liolaemus melanopleurus is a good species and whether any new material can be referred to this taxon.

Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) consider this species as a junior synonym of Liolaemus schmidti, which is a junior synonym of L. andinus; Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy. Alternatively, it has been proposed that it may be a junior synonym of L. erguetae (R. Langstroth in Troncoso-Palacios, 2014). Further taxonomic study is recommended to fully diagnose this species and clarify its relationships.
R. Langstroth (pers. comm., 2019) will submit a paper in 2019 which places Liolaemus islugensis in the synonymy of Liolaemus schmidti (Marx, 1960).

Langstroth (2011) found that specimens attributed to Liolaemus reichei from near Tacna in Peru were instead attributable to L. poconchilensis, extending the range of this species into southern Peru and confining L. reichei (which this author synonymized with L. stolzmanni) to northern Chile.
Currently research is underway to determine if this taxon represents more than one species.

The taxonomic status of this species remains unclear (Avila et al. 2013). It was synonymized with Liolaemus dorbignyi by Nuñez and Jaksic (1992), and revalidated again by Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005).

authority: Abdala, Semhan, Moreno Azócar, Bonino, Paz & Cruz, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) synonymized Liolaemus schmidti with L. andinus, however, Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy on the basis that L. andinus is taxonomically problematic because the type specimens are apparently lost and its type locality is unclear. R. Langstroth (pers. comm. 2016) has examined the L. schmidti type series and material from Catamarca and adjacent Chile and recommends considering the taxon valid on the basis of significant morphological differences, although it is part of a large group of taxonomically complex species related to Liolaemus multicolor which have never been subject to a taxonomic revision. As such, the true identity of many records is unknown. The concept applied in this account includes L. ormofi, a recent description considered a junior synonym of L. schmidti by Troncoso-Palacios (in litt.) and R. Langstroth (pers. comm. 2016).

Breitman et al. (2014) shows that there appears to be no genetic differentiation (based on mitochondrial markers) between this species and Liolaemus zullyae, recommending further studies to test whether there is hybridization between these species, or both represent a single species having two distinct male morphotypes.

authority: Abdala, Semhan, Moreno Azocar, Bonino, Paz & Cruz, 2012

taxonomicNotes: There appears to be no genetic differentiation between this species and L. scolaroi. Detailed studies are needed to test whether there is hybridization between these species or if both represent a single species with two distinct male morphotypes (Breitman et al. 2014).

authority: Núñez, Veloso, Espejo, Veloso, Cortes & Araya, 2010

taxonomicNotes: It is recommended that the taxonomic status of the subspecies be reviewed (Abdala et al. 2012, Avila et al. 2013).

This species was described based on one specimen from a region with a relatively high number of described Phymaturus species. Current data are insufficient to verify species boundaries within this group to clarify whether all of these taxa are genuine, or whether they instead represent a single one geographically structured species with extensive polymorphisms.

authority: Núñez, Veloso, Espejo, Veloso, Cortes & Araya, 201

taxonomicNotes: Pincheira-Donoso et al. (2008) consider Phymaturus dorsimaculatus to be a junior synonym of P. vociferator, in which case this species would also occur in the Province of Neuquén, Argentina (Avila et al. 2013); however, Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy and their scheme is followed here. M. Vidal (pers. comm. 2016) notes that no studies have been conducted that demonstrate this proposed synonymy. While Pincheira-Donoso et al. (2008) referred to previous work suggesting that the two taxa may be conspecific based on overlap between morphological traits (Pincheira-Donoso 2004), these authors provided no new data to support this conclusion and so the systematics of these taxa remains unresolved.

Zaher (1999) recognized Philodryas dorsalis and P. occidentalis as species distinct from P. biserialis; this action - which was not in a paper primarily concerned with taxonomy - appears to have subsequently been neglected, however, the taxonomic action appears not to have been disputed and Zaher et al. (2009) listed all three taxa within the newly-erected genusPseudalsophis without comment. This arrangement is consequently followed here.

Zaher (1999) recognized Pseudalsophis dorsalis and P. occidentalis as species distinct from P. biserialis; this action, which was not in a paper primarily concerned with taxonomy, appears to have subsequently been neglected. However, the taxonomic action appears not to have been disputed and Zaher et al. (2009) listed all three taxa within the newly-erected genus Pseudalsophis without comment. This arrangement is consequently followed here.

Zaher (1999) recognized Pseudalsophis dorsalis and P. occidentalis as species distinct from P. biserialis; this action, which was not in a paper primarily concerned with taxonomy, appears to have subsequently been neglected. However, the taxonomic action appears not to have been disputed and Zaher et al. (2009) listed all three taxa within the newly-erected genusPseudalsophis without comment. This arrangement is consequently followed here.

This species as it is currently known is probably a species complex (R. Espinoza pers. comm.). The occurrence of this species in Chile has been questioned, with suggestions that records are referable to a related species. Recent collections have, however, been taken from this country (M. Ruiz de Gamboa, unpubl. data) and the most recent published treatment of this species' distribution concluded that the species ranges to Arica and Parinacota Region in northern Chile (Troncoso-Palacios 2014).

authority: Aguilar, Wood, Cusi, Guzman, Huari, Lundberg, Mortensen, Ramí, Robles, Suárez, Ticona, Vargas, Venegas & Sites, 2013
Aguilar, Wood, Cusi, Guzman, Huari, Lundberg, Mortensen, Ramí, Robles, Suárez, Ticona, Vargas, Venegas & Sites, 2013
Aguilar, Wood, Cusi, Guzman, Huari, Lundberg, Mortensen, Ramí, Robles, Suárez, Ticona, Vargas, Venegas & Sites, 2013
Grismer, Wood, Jr., Mohamed, Chan, Heinz, Sumarli, Chan & Loredo, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This is a known species complex of at least ten species, some with restricted ranges in northeast Australia (C. Moritz pers. comm. 2017).

The populations in the arid part of the southern and eastern Kimberleys are highly isolated and genetically divergent and subject to local extinction. There are two species to be described in the southeast part of its range, one is endemic to limestones in Judburra National Park, and the second is more widespread around Halls Creek including Purnululu National Park (C. Moritz pers. comm. 2017).

The status of Shinisauridae, erected by Ahl (1930), as a distinct, monotypic family was supported by Macey et al. (1999). Ziegler et al. (2008) determined that morphological and mitochondrial genetic differentiation among extant subpopulations was insufficient to justify the recognition of Chinese and Vietnamese subpopulations as separate taxa or subspecies, despite an apparent geographical separation of at least 500 km.

authority: Recorder, Werneck, Teixera, Colli, Sites & Rodrigues, 2014
Nuñez, Veloso, Espejo, Veloso, Cortes & Araya, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Wagner et al. (2014) investigated the taxonomy of Adolfus alleni, then understood to consist of four isolated, high montane subpopulations in western Kenya. Using a combination of morphological, genetic and meristic data, these authors found support for the presence of two species within A. alleni. Wagner et al. (2014) described the more widespread taxon as A. masavaensis, confining A. alleni to Mt. Kenya.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Liotyphlops ternetzii (Boulenger, 1896) by Dixon and Kofron (1984).

Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) consider that Liolaemus constanzae consist of two subspecies: L. c. constanzae and L. c. donosoi both occurring in Antofagasta province, Chile, and the former subspecies also found in Salta province, Argentina. However, Avila et al. (2013) were unable to find any reliable bibliographic citation or reference material collected in Argentinean territory.

Lobo et al. (2010) argue that both forms should be considered separate species, whereas Troncoso-Palacios (2013) considers L. donosoi as a junior synonym of L. constanzae. Given this information, it is recommended further taxonomic studies be conducted to establish a correct diagnosis of the species. The concept applied here includes L. c. donosoi as a subspecies pending resolution of this issue.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

There is uncertainty regarding the identity of records of this species from Argentina, considered to represent this species by Avila et al. (2013). Other authors suggest that these records may be referrable to L. abdalai (Quinteros 2012, Abdala et al. 2012).
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

Records presently assigned to this species from Argentina are very unlikely to represent this species, as the Argentinian and Chilean populations are separated by mountains up to 5,000 m high, and the Argentinian records are themselves from valleys more than 400 km from one another (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). Resolution of this issue is complicated as the few known Argentinian specimens are poorly-preserved (L. Avila pers. obs.). For the purposes of this assessment L. gravenhorstii is considered to be endemic to Chile.

There are two subspecies:
T. chilensis chilensis (Schlegel, 1837)
T. chilensis coronellina (Werner, 1898).

Fernandes et al. (1998) synonymized Heterorhachis poecilolepis with Sibynomorphus ventrimaculatus.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Homonota horrida has variously been treated as a full species or as a junior synonym of H. fasciata, with synonymization proposed by both Abdala and Lavilla (1993) and Cacciali et al. (2007). At present the two taxa are considered to be synonymous (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), and this scheme is followed here.

The former subspecies Phymaturus palluma patagonicus Koslowsky, 1898, has been elevated to species status. An additional species, P. roigorum, has recently been described based on material previously believed to represent P. palluma (Lobo and Abdala 2007).

The ICZN has ruled that the current usage of the generic name Phymaturus (Gravenhorst, 1837) and the specific name P. palluma (Molina, 1782) for a genus and a species of lizard from South America is conserved by designation of the holotype of Centrura flagellifer (Bell, 1843) as the neotype of Lacerta palluma (Molina, 1782). Lobo and Etheridge (2013) subsequently examined the history of this specimen and concluded that it represents the species recently described as P. gynechlomus. Consequently, P. gynechlomus is a junior synonym of P. palluma (Lobo and Etheridge 2013).
This is a species complex (Langstroth 2005, Nogueira 2006) which contains two recognized subspecies: Cercosaurus schreibersii schreibersii Wiegmann, 1834 and C. s. albostrigatus (Griffin, 1917).

After a comparison of the type material of Phalotris tricolor and Elapomorphus (=Phalotris). punctatus, Lema et al. (2005) concluded that both names referred to a single species, for which the name P. tricolor has priority. The same paper described a new species, P. mattogrossensis, from Brazil, assigning all Brazilian records of P. tricolor to this taxon (with a single exception based on a specimen they did not examine, and which is considered doubtful - N. Scott pers. comm. 2016). Records from eastern Paraguay, accepted as P. tricolor by Lema et al. (2005), are now understood also to represent P. mattogrossensis (Cacciali and Motte 2007).

This species was synonymized with Brookesia minima by Raxworthy and Nussbaum (1995) but later resurrected (Schimmenti and Jesu 1996, Glaw et al. 1999). The taxonomy of the B. minima group is in need of revision and the distribution of all species needs to be re-evaluated following thorough morphometric and molecular studies.

This species appears to be referrable to Gehyra based on available keys to the genus, however, New Guinean Gehyra have been neglected by taxonomists and some types have been lost (Skipwith and Oliver 2014). This, together with this species' unique fringe of flattened scales along the tail, suggests that its phylogenetic assignment may need to be reassessed when more more data becomes available (Skipwith and Oliver 2014).

Due to the presence of specimens with intermediate characters, in large parts of intergradation, it is possible that specimens attributed to Amphisbaena darwini, A. trachura and A. heterozonata may belong to a single species for which A. darwini is the oldest available name (Gans 1966). If so, this would extend A. darwini's range to northern Argentina, southern Bolivia, and central Paraguay ( Montero 1996, Montero and Terol 1999)

Contomastix charrua was described from a population referred to Cnemidophorus (now Contomastix) lacertoides on the basis of differences in coloration, structure of the hyoid apparatus and geological history of the cape (Cabrera and Carreira 2009). Borteiro et al.(2013) found no morphological differences between the two taxa and referred C. charrua to the synonymy of C. lacertoides. S. Carreira (pers. comm. 2016) indicates that ongoing research has identified additional differences that may warrant recognizing C. charrua as a separate species, and recommends retaining C. charrua as a valid species pending comparison with material from the C. lacertoides type locality, which was not done by Borteiro et al. (2013).

Chironius maculoventris was recognized as a full species by Hollis (2006), but is still considered a subspecies of C. quadricarinatus by some authors (Motte et al. 2009, Uetz and Hallerman 2014), a species that is distributed in central, northwestern, and southwestern Brazil (Pinto et al. 2008, Pinto et al. 2010).
Cacciali et al. (2009) synonymized Simophis rohdei within S. rhinostoma.

It was thought that the species was probably also found in parts of Bolivia, but taxonomic studies suggest that Bolivian populations may well represent undescribed species, as allopatric speciation may be prevalent in this group of rare and habitat-restricted lizards (Rodrigues et al. 2007, 2008) .

Amaral (1933) suggested that differences between the male holotype and C. kraepelini and the female holotype of C. modesta were likely to be the result of sexual dimorphism, and concluded that C. kraepelini is therefore a junior synonym of C. modesta, and this conclusion is supported by Rodrigues et al. (2007). Doubt has been cast on this assignment by Vanzolini et al. (1977), who observe that the type material of C. kraepelini consisted of one male and one female and that the description makes explicit reference to an 'Alopoglossus-like' character not shared with Colobosaura. None of these authors are thought to have examined the type material, which has been lost, and Vanzolini et al. (1977) note that "The animal has to be seen again before anything sensible can be said about it".

Most recently, Cacciali et al. (2017) reported the collection of new Colobosaura material from the Paraguay River drainage and confirmed that this specimen was not conspecific with C. modesta on the basis of both morphological and genetic data. These authors tentatively applied the the only available name - C. kraeplini - to this material on the basis that there are no known morphological characters that distinguish it from the species described by Werner.

Genetic analyses suggest that the subspecies Tarentola mauritanica fascicularis is probably a valid species (Harris et al. 2004), but no formal taxonomic proposal has yet been made (Crochet and Dubois 2004). Tarentola mauritanica appears to be a species complex, with animals in northwestern Libya and southern Tunisia possibly representing a separate species (S. Baha El Din pers. comm.).

Jadin et al. (2013) investigated the systematics of Pseustes (for which they resurrected the senior synonym Phrynonax), within which they recognized the species P. poecilonotus, P. shropshirei, and P. polylepis (the latter resurrected from synonymy within P. poecilonotus). Taxonomic issues remain within this complex, and in particular the status of Pseustes lyoni - described from northern Venezuela and later synonymized with P. poecilonotus. Following the resurrection of P. polylepis by Jadin et al. (2013), P. lyoni should presently be considered a junior synonym of this taxon (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015, Uetz et al. 2021). It has, however, been suggested either that it may be conspecific with P. shropshirei (Guttierez et al. in review) or that it may be a valid species (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015), and research is required to resolve this issue.
There is taxonomic confusion in the literature between Argyophis [Typhlops] diardii and A. muelleri, the latter having previously been treated as a subspecies of the former.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra, as did several authors (Pritchard 1996; Caccone et al. 1999; Beheregaray et al. 2003; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980; Fritts 1983; Ernst and Barbour 1989) and more recently several researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) have treated most of them as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. abingdonii as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The name Testudo ephippium, athough widely applied to the Pinzón [Duncan Island] Tortoise in the past, was interpreted by Pritchard (1996) to possibly be based on a type specimen from Pinta, and therefore potentially a senior synonym of Testudo abingdonii, but this has not yet been determined genetically.

Köhler and Hedges (2016) revised the taxonomy of green anoles within the "Anolis chlorocyanus group" and clarified species limits. These authors restricted the name A. chlorocyanus to populations east and north of the central mountains in the Dominican Republic. Based on this work Köhler and Hedges (2020) petitioned the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN) to set aside the type status of the syntypes for A. chlorocyanus in order to stablize the current and long established usage of the names A. chlorocyanus and A. coelestinus. The petition was unsuccessful and hence A. callainus was published as a replacement name for the Hispaniolan anole formerly referred to as A. chlorocyanus and as a result A. coelestinus is renamed as A. chlorocyanus (Köhler and Hedges 2020).

Anolis eewi has been synonymised with A. planiceps and subsequently re-elevated  to full species by several authors (Rivas et al. 2012). Most recently, Poe et al. (2017) synonymised this species within A. planiceps and this arrangement is followed here.
Phylogenetic analyses indicate that the Venezuelan G. superciliaris may be a junior synonym, but more work is needed to be certain (Schargel et al. 2010).

authority: Schargel, Rivas, Makowsky, Señaris, Natera, Barros, Molina & Barrio-Amorós, 2010

taxonomicNotes: In a catalogue of the herpetofauna of Venezuela's Calderas region (Barrio-Amorós 2010) Gonatodes ligiae appears under the name G. concinnatus and G. purpurogularis under the name G.  ligiae (C. Barrio-Amorós pers. comm. 2017). A subsequent examination of the type series of G. ligiae, which is presently held in the Universidad de Concepción in Chile, clarified that this interpretation was not correct and confirmed the identity of true G. ligiae (Barrio-Amorós and Ortiz 2016).

authority: Rivas, Ugueto, Schargel, Barros, Velozo & Sánchez, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species has been reported from sites outside Brazil, in French Guiana (Starace 1998) and the Koetari River in Suriname (Ouboter et al., in O'Shea et al. 2011, National Zoological Collection of Suriname). Later reexamination of French Guiana specimens by Starace in 2013 determined that these represent Amphisbaena vanzolini (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2016). The Koetari record, attributed to A. slevini before Starace corrected the identification of the French Guiana specimens, has subsequently been reexamined and found also to represent A. vanzolini (P. Ouboter unpubl. data). As such, A. slevini is still known with certainty only from areas close to Manaus in Brazilian Amazonia.

Depending on author, Phymaturus dorsimaculatus is considered either a synonym of Phymaturus vociferator (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008) or as a valid species. Troncoso-Palacios and Lobo (2012) argue that P. dorsimaculatus is a valid species, given that the second chinshields are separated, a characteristic that together with the vocalization (according to Pincheira-Donoso 2004) and the scapular black bars fused in the male, allow reliable differentiation from P. vociferator.
Was under Iguanidae.
The one specimen of this species may be referrable to Anolis punctatus (G. Rivas and W. Schargel, unpublished data).

Further material is required to confirm the validity of and better-define diagnostic characters in Atractus eriki, which is known from four specimens and belongs to a taxonomically difficult genus (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2018).

Independent examinations of material assigned to Atractus erythromelas and A. meridemsis by both W. Schargel and A. Markezich suggests that A. meridensis may be a junior synonym of A. erythromelas (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2019). Alternatively that the species' occurrence on both versants of the Mérida mountain range may represent misidentification of material away from the type locality (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2019). At present this issue is difficult to resolve as only a single specimen is known from the type locality and exhibits only minor morphological differences from A. erythromelas, and no published work has examined the relationship between these two species (W. Schargel pers. comm. 2019).
The relationship between this species and Atractus pamplonensis needs clarification.
The population in Trinidad currently referred to this species may represent a distinct form.

A combination of genetic analysis, divergence time estimates and ecological niche modelling identified five discrete clades within Lampropeltis getula, which did not correspond to recognized subspecific divisions (Pyron and Burbrink 2009a). Accordingly Pyron and Burbrink (2009b) subsequently revised the systematics of L. getula, elevating L. splendida and L. californiae to specific status, redefining and elevating the former subspecies L. nigra and L. holbrooki, and synonymizing remaining subspecies (L. g. floridiana and L. g. meansi) within a monotypic L. getula. Pyron and Burbrink (2009b) also confirmed the previously recognized synonymy of L. g. goini and L. g. sticticeps within L. getula.

A combination of genetic analysis, divergence time estimates and ecological niche modelling identified five discrete clades within Lampropeltis getula, which did not correspond to recognized subspecific divisions (Pyron and Burbrink 2009a). Accordingly Pyron and Burbink (2009b) subsequently revised the systematics of L. getula, elevating L. splendida and L. californiae to specific status, redefining and elevating the former subspecies L. nigra and L. holbrooki, and synonymizing remaining subspecies (L. g. floridiana and L. g. meansi) within a monotypic L. getula. Pyron and Burbrink (2009b) also confirmed the previously recognized synonymy of L. g. goini and L. g. sticticeps within L. getula.

A combination of genetic analysis, divergence time estimates and ecological niche modelling identified five discrete clades within Lampropeltis getula, which did not correspond to recognized subspecific divisions (Pyron and Burbrink 2009a). Accordingly Pyron and Burbink (2009b) subsequently revised the systematics of L. getula, elevating L. splendida and L. californiae to specific status, redefining and elevating the former subspecies L. nigra and L. holbrooki, and synonymizing remaining subspecies (L. g. floridiana and L. g. meansi) within a monotypic L. getula. Pyron and Burbrink (2009b) also confirmed the previously recognized synonymy of L. g. goini and L. g. sticticeps within L. getula.

Based on an examination of the types, Pincheira-Donoso and Nuñez (2005) synonymized Liolaemus hernani within L. curicensis, a decision upheld in a review of recent taxonomic changes within Liolaemidae by Lobo et al. (2010).
Was under Iguanidae.

A combination of genetic analysis, divergence time estimates and ecological niche modelling identified five discrete clades within Lampropeltis getula, which did not correspond to recognized subspecific divisions (Pyron and Burbrink 2009a). Accordingly Pyron and Burbink (2009b) subsequently revised the systematics of L. getula, elevating L. splendida and L. californiae to specific status, redefining and elevating the former subspecies L. nigra and L. holbrooki, and synonymizing remaining subspecies (L. g. floridiana and L. g. meansi) within a monotypic L. getula. Pyron and Burbrink (2009b) also confirmed the previously recognized synonymy of L. g. goini and L. g. sticticeps within L. getula.

authority: Aguirre-Peñafiel, Torres-Carvajal, Sales Nunes, Peck & Maddock, 2014
Abdala, Procopio, Stellatelli, Travaini, Rodríguez & Monachesi, 2014

taxonomicNotes: US populations long were known as Sceloporus cyanogenys, until Olson (1987) concluded that cyanogenys and serrifer are conspecific. Olson recognized four subspecies of S. serrifer: serrifer, plioporus, prezygus, and cyanogenys (carniceps was rejected as invalid). Sceloporus serrifer cyanogenys and S. serrifer plioporus appear to intergrade in a band across southern Tamaulipas through southmost Nuevo Leon and central San Luis Potosi (Olson 1987). In contrast, DNA data presented by Weins and Reeder (1997) suggest that serrifer and cyanogenys may not be closely related; however, the authors acknowledged that this might be "an artefact of weak support." Further study is needed to clarify the relationships among serrifer, cyanogenys, and other apparently related species. The inclusion of S. prezygus as a subspecies was supported by the finding by Stuart (1970) that this form exhibits apparently random variation across its range and cannot reliably be distinguished from other populations thought to intergrade with S. serrifer. This arrangement is still followed by some authorities (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2010, Wiens et al. 2010), however other recent work has considered S. prezygus a full species, albeit of questionable or uncertain status (Sites et al. 1992, Wiens and Reeder 1997), and this is the approach followed in the most recent regional and taxonomic species lists (Bell et al. 2003, Wilson et al. 2010). Wiens et al. (2010) found that S. s. prezygus is the closest relative of S. s. serrifer, however this analysis of higher-level relationships in the genus did not discuss this finding and so the appropriate status of this taxon requires further clarification. S. prezygus is here provisionally treated as full species.

There are two subspecies:
Tropidurus peruvianus salinicola (Mertens, 1956)
Tropidurus peruvianus peruvianus (Lesson, 1830).

Peters and Donoso-Barros (1970) listed nine subspecies, many of which have been elevated to full species status since then.
Three subspecies are recognized:Callopistes maculatus maculatus, C. m. atacamensis Donoso-Barros, 1960, and C. m. manni Donoso-Barros, 1960.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) considered Liolaemus kuhlmanni to be a synonym of L. zapallarensis. Lobo et al. (2010) disagree with this synonymy on the basis that it was proposed without justification. Troncoso-Palacios and Garin (2013) indicated that ongoing molecular phylogenetic work showed L. kuhlmanni to be belong to a clade L. zapallarensis and other species and also included it in their diagnosis. However, some other Chilean specialists nevertheless consider it likely that the proposed synonymy is correct (M. de Gamboa pers. comm. 2017).
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.
Was under Iguanidae.

Castro and Tobar-González (2014) suggested there may be differences between high-elevation and low-elevation populations of this species on Cantillana, but had access only to lower-elevation specimens that agree with their recently-collected specimen.
Was under Iguanidae.

This species has two subspecies:

Pseudalsophis e. elegans (Tschudi, 1845)
P. e. rufidorsatus Günther, 1858.
Tachymenis elongata is a junior synonym of this species (Tipton 2005).

Liolaemus stolzmanni is a member of a poorly-characterized radiation of species whose systematics have long been complicated by restricted access to the remote areas where these lizards occur (Langstroth 2011). Confusion has surrounded the correct attribution of records from northern Chile and adjacent regions of Argentina, Bolivia and Peru) to either Liolaemus stolzmanni or Liolaemus reichei, the oldest available names for taxa from this region, due to inadequacies in or misunderstandings of the original descriptions by subsequent authors (Langstroth 2011). This situation was further complicated by the descriptions of multiple additional taxa from Chile, Peru and Bolivia, with several specimens previously reported as L. reichei being properly attributable to L. poconchilensis and Bolivian material described as L. stolzmanni having been referred to L. pachecoi (Langstroth 2011). Examining photographs of the type series of L. stolzmanni, Langstroth (2011) synonymized L. reichei (as now understood, a species restricted to northern Chile) with this older name and proposed emending the type locality from "Hoch-Peru" to "Deserts of Iquique, Tarapaca Region, Chile", on the basis that this species is not known to occur anywhere within the territory of modern Peru and indeed appears to be endemic to this area of northern Chile.

Liolaemus pleopholis is either a cryptic species or maybe a synonym of L. signifer (Troncoso-Palacios 2014), thus a further taxonomic study is recommended to establish a correct diagnosis of the species.

This account follows the species concept proposed Troncoso-Palacios and Garin (2013), who treat Liolaemus copiapensis as a junior synonym, and the former subspecies L. oxycephalus and L. inconspicuus as distinct taxa.

authority: Quinteros, Valladares, Semham, Acosta, Barrionuevo & Abdala, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Demangel Miranda (2016) included Phymaturus aguedae in the synonymy of P. darwini, a decision subsequently rejected by Troncoso-Palacios et al. (2019).

The subspecies Alsophis antiguae sajdaki is thought by some to represent a full species (Hedges et al. 2009), which would render A. antiguae extinct. There is however evidence against this proposition from a study of more than 400 live specimens from Great Bird Island which concluded that, apart from some geographical variation in ventral counts, the proposed diagnostic characters represented sexual dimorphism. On this basis this account considers that A. antiguae is still extant, represented by the surviving form A. a. sadjaki (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2010, 2015).

Burbrink (2001) used cytochrome b sequences to examine phylogenetic relationships among Elaphe guttata populations (one specimen from each of 53 locations throughout most of the range). He found no support for recognition of the nominal subspecies intermontanus and meahllmorum as distinct taxa; these appear to be junior synonyms of E. guttata emoryi. Burbrink identified three partitions within E. guttata: an eastern partition (east of the Mississippi River) corresponding to E. guttata guttata, a western partition corresponding to E. guttata emoryi (including E. g. intermontanus and E. g. meahllmorum), and a central partition in western Louisiana and eastern Texas. The central partition, in pine and pine-hardwood habitat west of the Mississippi River, clustered closer to the eastern partition than to the western partition. Burbrink recognized the three partitions as species using evolutionary species criteria: (1) Elaphe guttata (Red Corn Snake) (eastern partition , (2) Elaphe emoryi (Great Plains Rat Snake) (western partition), and (3) Elaphe slowinskii (Slowinski's Corn Snake) (central partition). One specimen (Hidalgo County, Texas) of the central partition (based on cytochrome b characteristics) was located outside the presumed geographic area and habitat identified for other members of that partition. Crother et al. (2003) adopted these changes. Ernst and Ernst (2003) recognized E. emoryi and E. guttata as distinct species, but their manuscript evidently was completed before Burbrink's paper was published; they did not comment on E. slowinskii.

Utiger et al. (2002) examined mtDNA variation in New World and Old World "Elaphe" and determined that North American rat snakes included in the genus Elaphe form a monophyletic lineage that is distinct from Old World snakes that also have been regarded as Elaphe. They resurrected the genus Pantherophis for the rat snakes north of Mexico, including the following species: Pantherophis obsoletus (and P. alleghaniensis and P. spiloides, if one recognizes those taxa as species), P. guttatus, P. emoryi, P. vulpinus, P. gloydi, and P. bairdi. Crother et al. (2003) noted this proposal but did not adopt it, pending further review. Burbrink and Lawson (2007) agreed with Utiger et al. (2002) that these species do not belong in Elaphe, but suggested that the genus Pantherophis might belong in Pituophis. We retain this species in Pantherophis, following Utiger et al. (2002) pending further information on the relationships of these taxa.

There are currently two recognized subspecies:
A. hyporissor hyporissor
A. hyporissor leberi.

This species has two subspecies:C. crusculus crusculus (Garman, 1888), C. crusculus cundalli (Grant, 1940).

Based on molecular evidence (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data), two taxa previously considered subspecies of C. crusculus have been elevated to full-species status (Henderson and Powell 2009). Celestus maculatus (Garman, 1888) occurs on Cayman Brac and Little Cayman and C. molesworthi (Grant, 1940) occurs along the northern coast of Jamaica, where it is allopatric with C. crusculus.

The following subspecies are recognized:
C. curtissi curtissi Grant, 1951
C. curtissi aporus Schwartz, 1964
C. curtissi diastatus Schwartz, 1964
C. curtissi hylonomus Schwartz, 1964.

This species has two subspecies: A. sanctonum sanctonum Barbour, 1915 and A. s. danforthi Cochran, 1938. Zaher et al. (2009) recognized A. danforthi as a distinct, separate species, but this was a broad molecular treatment of advanced snakes with an emphasis on South America and did not provide detailed justification for this assignment. The subspecific arrangement has been retained by subsequent authors (Wallach et al. 2014) and is preferred pending a phenotypic and genetic review of snakes from Iles des Saintes (R. Gomes pers. comm. 2019).

This species has only recently been placed in the genus Caraiba (Zaher et al. 2009).

The species has a number of subspecies:
C. andreae andreae (Reinhardt & Lütken, 1862)
C. andreae melopyrrha (Thomas & Garrido, 1967)
C. andreae morenoi (Garrido, 1973)
C. andreae nebulatus (Barbour, 1916)
C. andreae orientalis (Barbour & Ramsden, 1919)
C. andreae peninsulae (Schwartz & Thomas, 1960).

This species has the following subspecies:
S. difficilis anthracomus Schwartz, 1983
S. difficilis difficilis Barbour, 1914
S. difficilis diolenius Schwartz, 1983
S. difficilis euopter Schwartz, 1983
S. difficilis lycauges Schwartz, 1983
S. difficilis peratus Schwartz, 1983
S. difficilis typhlopous Schwartz, 1983.

A taxonomic review is required, as many currently recognized subspecies were described using now-outdated species concepts. This is likely to have an impact on future re-assessments of what might be a complex of species.

Two subspecies are recognized:
S. torrei spielmani Grant, 1958
S. torrei torrei Barbour, 1914.

Two subspecies are recognized:

Sphaerodactylus streptophorus sphenophanes Thomas & Schwartz 1983
Sphaerodactylus streptophorus streptophorus Thomas & Schwartz 1977

There is some uncertainty concerning the correct spelling of the specific epithet for this species; the Reptile Database uses 'pleei', however, based on the ICZN rules it is argued that the original spelling of 'pleii' is what should be used (R. Powell and M. Breuil pers. comms.).

This species has three subspecies:
G. pleii pleii Bocourt, 1881
G. pleii luetkeni Bocourt, 1881
G. pleii nesydrion Thomas, 1965.
