Populations in northern Hispaniola long attributed to Aristelliger lar have recently been found to represent either Aristelliger hechti or an undescribed taxon close to A. hechti (S.B. Hedges in prep.).

Surget-Groba and Thorpe (2013) investigated the phylogenetics and biogeography of what they recognized as the Sphaerodactylus vincenti species complex, and applied the name S. festus to northern populations (northern Martinique and Dominica). These authors caution that the diagnostic features they identified exhibit some overlap between S. festus and S. vincenti and that more work is needed to clarify their status as separate species. Nevertheless, recognition of these two species is based on the "best available information" (Surget-Groba and Thorpe 2013) and has subsequently been followed by researchers working in the region, and this scheme is consequently adopted here. These authors' genetic analysis also found that S. kirbyi from Mustique in the Grenadines was nested between Martinique and St. Vincent populations and considered it a junior synonym of S. vincenti. This arrangement is considered unlikely to be correct by other workers on biogeographical grounds (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015), and S. kirbyi is treated as a separate species here.

This species has the following subspecies:
S. corticola aporrox Schwartz, 1968
S. corticola campter Schwartz, 1968
S. corticola soter Schwartz, 1968
S. corticola corticola Garman, 1888.

A taxonomic review of this species is required to assess the validity of the currrent subspecies, as they have not been reassessed for over 40 years and two additional undescribed subspecific taxa are known (Henderson and Powell 2009).

The species has two subspecies:
Leiocephalus schreibersii schreibersii (Gravenhorst, 1837)
Leiocephalus schreibersii nesomorus Schwartz, 1968.

A subspecies has been described, Ctenosaura similis multipunctata (Barbour and Shreve 1934, Occasional Papers of the Boston Society of Natural History 8: 197) from Isla de Providencia, Colombia (Henderson and Powell 2009), however, given that the nominotypical subspecies occurs on nearby San Andrés Island (90 km distant), the validity of this subspecies should be re-evaluated.
Trabalho recente alocou espécies de Anolis em diferentes gêneros (Nicholson et al. 2012), mas não foi amplamente aceito.

Trabalho recente alocou espécies de Anolis em diferentes gêneros (Nicholson et al. 2012), mas não foi amplamente aceito. Existem problemas de identificação entre A. philopunctatus e A. punctatus, principalmente de fêmeas, o que leva a algumas incertezas quanto aos limites de distribuição das espécies.
Trabalho recente alocou espécies de Anolis em diferentes gêneros (Nicholson et al. 2012), mas não foi amplamente aceito.

authority: Ribeiro, Nogueira, Cintra, da Silva & Zaher, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species has rarely been mentioned in the literature, and Uetz et al. (2019) consider its status uncertain. Boulenger (1887) assigned it to Diploglossus, a genus restricted to the Americas, but nothing is known of its distribution.

Wermuth (1969) considered this taxon a species inquirenda (i.e. of both uncertain provenance and doubtful validity).Cope (1868) observed that it closely resembles Celestus occiduus from Jamaica, but no surviving specimen is known to clarify its true identity.
Raised to full species by Thomas and Hedges (1998).

Wallach et al. (2014) follow Henderson and Powell (2009) in recognizing Boa orophias and B. nebulosa as full species, however, some other authors (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2015) still treat both as subspecies of Boa constrictor.

Wallach et al. (2014) follow Henderson and Powell (2009) in recognizing Boa orophias and B. nebulosa as full species, however, some other authors (e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2015) still treat both as subspecies of Boa constrictor.

This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Leptophis ahaetulla, until elevated and redescribed by Murphy et al. (2013). These authors also recognized a separate lineage within L. coeruleodorsus, known from a single specimen collected in Tobago, as the distinct species L. haileyi.

Köhler and Hedges (2016) identified six genetic clusters within Anolis aliniger, and concluded that this evidence of genetic isolation together with "subtle" morphological differences supported the recognition of six separate species. These authors applied the name Anolis aliniger to the clade found in the northern Central Cordillera, the general area of the type locality.

Anolis angusticeps oligsaspis from the Bahamas is sometimes treated as a full species in recent checklists, including the subspecies A. a. chickcharneyi (Nicholson et al. 2012, 2018, Uetz 2019), but this species complex has not been subject to recent taxonomic research to confirm this assignment (R. Powell pers. comm. 2020).

The Anolis chlorocyanus [was coelestinus] species group consists of four genetic clusters identified by Köhler and Hedges (2016), and these authors identified "subtle" morphological differences between most of these that justified recognition as distinct species. Köhler and Hedges (2016) described these as distinct species and applied the name Anolis coelestinus - from a nonspecific locality in western Haiti - to the species found along the western portion and northern coast of the Tiburón Peninsula and the northern coast. Based on this work Köhler and Hedges (2020) petitioned the International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN) to set aside the type status of the syntypes for A. chlorocyanus in order to stablize the current and long established usage of the names A. chlorocyanus and A. coelestinus. The petition was unsuccessful and hence A. callainus was published as a replacement name for the Hispaniolan anole formerly referred to as A. chlorocyanus and as a result A. coelestinus is renamed as A. chlorocyanus (Köhler and Hedges 2020).

Köhler et al. (2019) conducted a morphological and genetic analysis of the Anolis cybotes group (under the generic name Audantia following Nicholson et al. 2012, while acknowledging that this revision is not universally accepted) and their resulting phylogeny identified 14 distinct clusters, corresponding to the six recognized species within this group and seven cryptic taxa within the previously-recognized concept of Anolis cybotes. These authors consequently revised A. cybotes, removing three species from synonymy and describing four new species. These authors also confirmed that Anolis riisei, a Hispaniolan name with an indeterminate type locality, should be treated as a junior synonym of A. cybotes sensu stricto. Finally, these authors synonymized Anolis haetianus with A. cybotes based on the location of the type locality and the state of preservation of the type material.

This taxon has long been included within Anolis marmoratus, either as a subspecies or within A. m. marmoratus (Stenson et al. 2004). Its status has subsequently been uncertain, with different authors treating it differently, although recent authorities (Breuil 2002, Hedges and Conn 2012, Henderson and Powell 2009) treat it as a full species. Morphologically intermediate populations between this species and A. marmoratus are known from the tip of Grande-Terre on mainland Guadeloupe (Lazell 1964); these are not considered to belong to A. desiradei for the purposes of this account.

Reynolds (2016) summarizes evidence from mitochondrial DNA and biogeography that Anolis ernestwilliamsi represents a very recent adaptation from the widespread Anolis cristatellus found on neighbouring islands. He suggests, based on evidence that the species exhibits a low or nonexistent level of ecological separation from a nearby population of A. cristatellus and that observed morphological differences are likely to reflect a combination of genetic drift and very recent adaptations to a non-natural substrate, that the Carrot Rock population is unlikely to be sufficiently divergent to justify continued recognition as a distinct species (Reynolds 2016 and refs therein).
Genetic sampling suggests that Sombrero island specimens may be specifically distinct from Anolis gingivinus (Thorpe et al. unpubl. data).

This species was elevated by Roughgarden (1995) from a subspecies of Anolis marmoratus, and this scheme is followed by Breuil (2002). No genetic material appears to exist for this population, which was elevated on morphological grounds, and its taxonomic status is in need of review.

Several former subspecies of Anolis marmoratus were elevated to specific status on morphological grounds by Roughgarden (1995). The validity of several of these assignments, which appear to be inconsistent with recent genetic work (Stenson et al. 2004), is unclear, and treatment of these taxa as either full species or subspecies is inconsistent in the recent literature.

Genetically Anolis extremus is nested within Anolis roquet from Martinique based on mtDNA results reported by Thorpe and Stenson (2003). If this result supported by other genetic markers this would render A. roquet paraphyletic. Further research is needed to support this conclusion, as it is possible that the mtDNA result may represent hybridisation events. This research may reveal that A. extremus should be considered a junior synonym of A. roquet, or that some of the Martinique populations should be assigned to A. extremus.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain at present, and a revision of the material in collections is likely to show that this species is a synonym of a known taxon (A. Fong pers. comm. 2016).
Roughgarden and Pacala (1989) recognized Anolis terrealtae as a full species distinct from A. marmoratus and this scheme has been followed by subsequent authors.

This species was until recently considered a subspecies of Bachia heteropa, and was elevated to specific status in a full revision of this group (Murphy et al. 2019). These authors discuss the nomenclatural history of Brachypus cuvieri Fitzinger 1826, an enigmatic name that may represent a senior synonym of B. trinitatis, and propose that B. cuvieri should be considered a nomen dubium due to uncertainty over the true identity of this specimen.

Previously, there were three subspecies recognized:
Typhlops biminiensis biminiensis Richmond, 1955
Typhlops biminiensis paradoxus Thomas, 1968
Typhlops biminiensis epactia Thomas, 1968

Typhlops biminiensis epactia and Typhlops biminiensis paradoxus have both been elevated to species status (Typhlops epactius and Typhlops paradoxus by Thomas and Hedges (2007).

This species has been treated as a subspecies of Leiocephalus carinatus, but is treated as a full species in recent literature (McCranie 2011, 2015, 2018; Hedges et al. 2019). McCranie (2018) notes that the species exhibits diagnostic features which do not overlap with other members of the L. carinatus group, supporting its recognition as a full species.

Hecht (1951) treated Aristelliger nelsoni as a subspecies of A. praesignis in a distribution map of the species' range but provided no supporting justification. This scheme has nonetheless been widely followed since, although distinct morphological differences between A. nelsoni and the nominate form were highlighted by Bauer and Russell (1993). McCranie (2018) corroborated this finding, and noted that the deep sea separating the Swan Islands from the Cayman Islands and Jamaica further supports the recognition of the two taxa as distinct species. This author recommended treating A. nelsoni as a full species pending molecular research to clarify its status, a recommendation that had previously been followed by Powell and Henderson (2012). On this basis, and noting that the proposed subspecific status has never been adequately justified, this account follows McCranie (2015, 2018) in treating A. nelsoni as a full species.

Two subspecies have been described, one from the Maria Islands and one from the Saint Lucia mainland. There is a recent record confirming the occurrence of the Maria Island form at Grand Anse on the Saint Lucia mainland (M. Morton pers. comm. to J. Daltry 2015).

Ameiva desechensis is treated here as a full species following Rivero (1998), the scheme followed by Caribherp (2017). The taxonomic status of this form has nevertheless been unclear due to competing treatments, with some authors considering it a subspecies of Ameiva exsul (e.g. Schwartz and Henderson 1991). A recent molecular treatment of teoid lizards (Goicoechea et al. 2016) adopted this arrangement by implication, as these authors listed the species they provisionally assigned to the resurrected genus Pholidoscelis, but made no mention of this taxon (N. Angeli pers. comm. 2017). Taxonomic relationships between Ameiva e. exsul and other proposed subspecies are the subject of work presently under review (N. Angeli in litt.), which may clarify the status of A. desechensis.

Records from Hellshire have been sequenced and identified as a separate, undescribed species (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data), confirming that Tropidophis stullae is known only from Portland Ridge and likely to be endemic to this area.

The taxonomic history of Typhlops lumbricalis is complicated, and is summarized by Domínguez and Díaz (2011). These authors revised this species and restricted its distribution to the Bahamas, but did not fully characterize records of the Typhlops lumbricalis group from Cuba, all previously considered to belong to this species. This and subsequent work described the new species Typhlops oxyrhinus, T. pachyrhinus (Domínguez and Díaz 2011) and T. leptolepis (Domínguez et al. 2013), and redescribed T. silus Legler, 1959 (Domínguez and Díaz 2015), considered a junior synonym of T. lumbricalis since Richmond (1961). These descriptions were all based on morphological data and limited sampling of specimens held in museums outside Cuba. This sampling may be inadequate to fully characterize diversity and delimit species in a particularly complex group of blindsnakes, and further taxonomic work including both molecular approaches and wider sampling of international collections is needed to confirm species boundaries within this group (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2017

The taxonomic history of Typhlops lumbricalis is complicated, and is summarized by Domínguez and Díaz (2011). These authors revised this species and restricted its distribution to the Bahamas, but did not fully characterize records of the Typhlops lumbricalis group from Cuba, all previously considered to belong to this species. This and subsequent work described the new species Typhlops oxyrhinus, T. pachyrhinus (Domínguez and Díaz 2011) and T. leptolepis (Domínguez et al. 2013), and redescribed T. silus Legler, 1959 (Domínguez and Díaz 2015), considered a junior synonym of T. lumbricalis since Richmond (1961). These descriptions were all based on morphological data and limited sampling of specimens held in museums outside Cuba. This sampling may be inadequate to fully characterize diversity and delimit species in a particularly complex group of blindsnakes, and further taxonomic work including both molecular approaches and wider sampling of international collections is needed to confirm species boundaries within this group (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2017).

The taxonomic history of Typhlops lumbricalis is complicated, and is summarized by Domínguez and Díaz (2011). These authors revised this species and restricted its distribution to the Bahamas, but did not fully characterize records of the Typhlops lumbricalis group from Cuba, all previously considered to belong to this species. This and subsequent work described the new species Typhlops oxyrhinus, T. pachyrhinus (Domínguez and Díaz 2011) and T. leptolepis (Domínguez et al. 2013), and redescribed T. silus Legler, 1959 (Domínguez and Díaz 2015), considered a junior synonym of T. lumbricalis since Richmond (1961). These descriptions were all based on morphological data and limited sampling of specimens held in museums outside Cuba. This sampling may be inadequate to fully characterize diversity and delimit species in a particularly complex group of blindsnakes, and further taxonomic work including both molecular approaches and wider sampling of international collections is needed to confirm species boundaries within this group (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2017

Hedges pers. comm. 2017

The taxonomic history of Typhlops lumbricalis is complicated, and is summarized by Domínguez and Díaz (2011). These authors revised this species and restricted its distribution to the Bahamas, but did not fully characterize records of the Typhlops lumbricalis group from Cuba, all previously considered to belong to this species. This and subsequent work described the new species Typhlops oxyrhinus, T. pachyrhinus (Domínguez and Díaz 2011) and T. leptolepis (Domínguez et al. 2013), and redescribed T. silus Legler, 1959 (Domínguez and Díaz 2015), considered a junior synonym of T. lumbricalis since Richmond (1961). These descriptions were all based on morphological data and limited sampling of specimens held in museums outside Cuba. This sampling may be inadequate to fully characterize diversity and delimit species in a particularly complex group of blindsnakes, and further taxonomic work including both molecular approaches and wider sampling of international collections is needed to confirm species boundaries within this group (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2017).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

This species was treated as a colour variant of Chrysopeles ornata prior to its description in 1943. While Somaweera et al. (2015) found no new Indian records among 13 examples of historical Chrysopelea ornata specimens from this country, the species has recently been confirmed from India. It is possible that additional historical specimens of "C. ornata" exist in collections to which these authors did not have access, and that these may include specimens referable to C. taprobanica (Somaweera et al. 2015).
Two subspecies are currently recognized: Tarentola americana americana (Cuba) and T. a. warreni (Bahamas)
This is a species complex (B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015)

Surget-Groba and Thorpe (2013) investigated the phylogenetics and biogeography of what they recognized as the Sphaerodactylus vincenti species complex, and applied the name S. festus to northern populations (northern Martinique and Dominica). These authors caution that the diagnostic features they identified exhibit some overlap between S. festus and S. vincenti and that more work is needed to clarify their status as separate species. Nevertheless, recognition of these two species is based on the "best available information" (Surget-Groba and Thorpe 2013) and has subsequently been followed by researchers working in the region, and this scheme is consequently adopted here. These authors' genetic analysis also found that S. kirbyi from Mustique in the Grenadines was nested between Martinique and St. Vincent populations and considered it a junior synonym of S. vincenti. This arrangement is considered unlikely to be correct by other workers on biogeographic grounds (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015), and S. kirbyi is treated as a separate species here.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. becki as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.    

Chelonoidis becki has generally always been considered a distinct taxon based on its isolated occurrence on Wolf Volcano on northern Isabela, consistent also with prior recognition of the other tortoise populations on central and southern Isabela volcanoes as distinct taxa: microphyes, vandenburghi, guntheri, and vicina. However, as population morphologies were considered, the dome-shaped central and southern Isabela populations were merged by Pritchard (1996) into a broader vicina taxon, into which microphyes, vandenburghi, and guentheri [= guntheri] were synonymized. Later genetic analysis demonstrated that all southern Isabela populations are very closely related to each other, with C. becki more closely related to C. darwini from Santiago (Poulakakis et al. 2012, 2015).

Chelonoidis becki includes two distinct genetic lineages, each of which occurs in nearly separate ranges: one on the eastern and northern slopes of Wolf Volcano associated with Piedras Blancas and the other on the southwestern slopes associated with Puerto Bravo (Garrick et al. 2014).Both of these lineages derived from tortoises from Santiago (C. darwini, Caccone et al. 1999, 2002; Garrick et al. 2014).

Genetic data indicate the presence on Wolf Volcano of hybrid individuals from species from distant islands (C. niger [Extinct], C. abingdonii [Extinct], and C. hoodensis), as well as the presence of hybrid individuals with species from the same island. The first ones, and possibly all, are likely to have arrived on Wolf Volcano because of human activities, while those from other volcanoes of Isabela are the possible results of sporadic tortoise dispersal events from one volcano to the next by land (from Darwin Volcano) or by sea from the central (Alcedo Volcano) or southern (Sierra Negra and Cerro Azul) Isabela volcanoes (Beheragaray et al. 2007).

The carapace morphology of Wolf Volcano tortoises is quite variable, with carapace shapes ranging from domed to intermediate to saddlebacked Given that the ancestor of this species is C. darwini from Santiago (Caccone et al. 1999; Caccone et al. 2002; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2013; Garrick et al. 2012, 2014), a species with an intermediate carapace shape, we assume that this is the ancestral carapace shape for C. becki, whereas the presence of domed and saddlebacked individuals is likely the result of past mating events with individuals from other islands (see above).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. chathamensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

Pritchard (1996) restricted the name chathamensis to the now-extirpated tortoise populations of southwestern and central San Cristóbal, but excluded the eastern San Cristóbal population, considering this population to represent a possibly distinct subspecies for which no name was available. For purposes of this Red List Assessment, the eastern San Cristóbal population is considered part of chathamensis until taxonomic clarity emerges.

Testudo wallacei Rothschild, 1902, was described with type locality “Chatham Island?”, but its type locality was designated Jervis Island [Rábida] by Van Denburgh (1914); Rábida tortoises were hypothesized to be an introduced population (Pritchard 1996), later confirmed by genetic analysis (Poulakakis et al. 2012) to represent tortoises from southern Isabela, and the name wallacei is considered a nomen dubium and synonym of C. vicina (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2014).

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra, as did several authors (Pritchard 1996; Caccone et al. 1999; Beheregaray et al. 2003; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980; Fritts 1983; Ernst and Barbour 1989) and more recently several researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) have treated most of them as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. darwini as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. hoodensis as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. This Red List assessment therefore now treats C. porteri as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier Red List assessments.

The name C. porteri now refers only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). A second tortoise species on eastern Santa Cruz Island from the Cerro Fatal region has recently been described as C. donfaustoi (Poulakakis et al. 2015), thus separating what was formerly considered one species into two. A third very small group of tortoises occurs in the northwestern region of Santa Cruz near Cerro Montura. The tortoises found at Cerro Montura have been identified as genetically indistinguishable from the Pinzón tortoise, C. duncanensis (Russello et al. 2005), and it is considered that they were probably introduced from Pinzón to Santa Cruz by humans.

Some recent literature suggests that the valid name for the Western Santa Cruz tortoise may be C. nigrita (e.g., EMBL database). However, the Tortoise and Freshwater Turtle Specialist Group follows the nomenclature of Pritchard (1996), Fritz and Havas (2007), TTWG (2014), and TEWG (2015), who concluded that nigrita is a nomen dubium and placed it in questionable synonymy under C. porteri.

There is unpublished morphological and genetic data supporting the suggestion by Cogger (2014) that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Christinus guentheri.
Was originally published on the IUCN Red List under the genus Underwoodisaurus, but following Oliver and Bauer (2011) it is now placed under Uvidicolus.
This species is treated by some authors under the genus Amphibolurus, but we follow the Reptile Database here in keeping it under Lophognathus. This species is currently under revision.

Despite some mitochondrial diversity in this species, which is somewhat divergent, population genetics indicates that this is a single very widespread species that readily mixes in central areas of its range (B. Carter unpubl. data).
This is currently under taxonomic review (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017). As presently understood there are two subspecies: Diporiphora albilabris albilabris and D. a. sobria) (Macdonald 2016).
A redefinition of this species is underway, in order to resolve longstanding difficulties in correctly assigning records to this taxon (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017)

There is apparently an isolated Western Australian record in the vicinity of Queen Victoria Spring (Ninox Wildlife Consulting 2009, citing Burbidge et al. 1976 and McKenzie and Burbidge 1979, however this record is not referred to in the latter - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017), the type locality of the more recently-described Diporiphora reginae, which seems to be genetically distinct from the remainder of the range.
Gehyra australis is a complex of two to four species (Paul Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
Taxonomic revision of Nephrurus wheeleri is underway, and the subspecies N. w. cinctus is likely to be elevated to specific status in the near future (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
Published genetic analyses indicate that the two disjunct populations are most likely conspecific (Oliver and Bauer 2011).
This is probably a species complex, comprising of at least one desert form and one tropical form (M. Hutchinson pers. comm.).

There are three subspecies:
N. levis occidentalis Storr, 1963,
N. levis pilbarensis Storr, 1963, and
N. levis levis De Vis, 1886.

An isolated subpopulation in the Northwest Cape is morphologically identical to subpopulations elsewhere (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017), but genetic research is needed to confirm that it is conspecific.

Populations from the Barossa Valley southward are characterized by different throat color in males and appear to be genetically distinct from and have limited contact with the northern part of its range.
Edwards et al. (2015) identified multiple lineages within this species, but no taxonomic revision has yet been undertaken.
A taxonomic revision of this species complex has recently been undertaken and is likely to be published in the near future (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017).
Genetic work has revealed that this is a species complex, however, additional work is required to revise the taxonomy.
Preliminary, unpublished genetic work indicates that this and related species may be in need of revision (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017)

Recent genetic analysis indicates that disjunct records from the Monaro Tablelands in New South Wales represent a distinct population (Scott and Keogh 2000, Melville et al. 2007), but no formal taxonomic action has yet been taken. Records from the Darling Downs in Queensland have been described as the distinct species Tympanocryptus condaminensis (Melville et al. 2014).

Tympanocryptis uniformis is definitively known only from the holotype, putatively collected from "near Darwin" in 1911. Storr (1964) identified a specimen from the Western Kimberley as T. uniformis in a revision of Tympanocryptis in Western Australia, but in a subsequent genus-wide revision he reassigned this specimen to T. lineata centralis (Storr 1982). Wilson and Knowles (1988) reported T. uniformis from the Top End on the basis of a photograph, but without directly comparing this image with the holotype.

A subsequent visit to this locality found that the colour morph reported by Wilson and Knowles (1988) was genetically indistinguishable from T. macra (J. Melville, unpubl. data). J. Melville (unpubl. data) consequently considered T. l. macra, described by Storr (1982), as a junior synonym of T. uniformis, and this opinion has subsequently been adopted inconsistently in recent field guides at least one of which (Cogger 2014) retains the concept adopted by Storr (1964) of a species ranging from near Darwin to the Kimberley.

This attribution was apparently made without examination of the T. uniformis holotype (which also appears not to have been examined by Storr 1982 in his description of T. l. macra), and the original description of T. l. macra is consistent with the population both Wilson and Knowles (1988) and J. Melville (unpubl. data) referred to as T. uniformis (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). It is consequently unclear whether the population examined by Melville represents T. uniformis (in which case this name is a senior synonym of the species presently known as T. l. macra) or whether T. uniformis is a valid species that has not been recorded for more than a century. This issue is complicated by the smaller size of the T. uniformis holotype than T. l. macra, which implies that if it is conspecific with T. l. macra it represents a subadult specimen (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
This group is undergoing taxonomic revision (J. Melville pers. comm. 2017).
This species has recently been split into five separate species: Tympanocryptis cephalus, T. gigas, T. diabolicus; T. fortescuensis; and T. pseudopsephos (Doughty et al. 2015).

The name Tympanocryptis condaminensis was erected by Melville et al. (2014) for the subpopulation of T. pinguicolla found in the Darling Downs, on the basis of genetic evidence that the two taxa are specifically distinct.

Melville et al. (2014) identified at least four genetic lineages which what was then considered the single species Tympanocryptis tetraporophora, three of which were described in this paper as the new species T. wilsoni, T. condaminensis and T. pentalineata. These authors refrained from describing the fourth lineage, calling for further work to resolve the taxonomy of this clade, and it is possible that further taxonomic issues remain.
Kharin (1981) recognized two subgenera in the genus Aipysurus: Aipysurus and Smithohydrophis. He included Aipysurus foliosquama in Smithohydrophis (Kharin 1981).

Molecular data indicate strong population subdivision around Australia between the Great Barrier Reef, Gulf of Carpentaria and Timor Sea Reefs (Lukoschek et al. 2007, 2008). In addition, there is a deep genetic divergence along the west Australian coastline between populations that occur in the offshore Timor Sea reefs and coastal populations that occur in Broome (Lukoschek unpublished data) and potentially further south. Some specimens from Western Australia are included in the species Aipysurus pooleorum. However, the taxonomic status between A. pooleorum and A. laevis need to be investigated. Microsatellite markers for A. fuscus and A. laevis sampled across four Timor Sea reefs were analysed to assess evidence for recent inter-specific gene flow and historical introgression (Sanders et al. 2014). The data fit an Isolation–Migration model, which showed significant and asymmetrical levels of gene flow following species divergence, and that the highest rates of introgression from the large A. laevis population into the much smaller A. fuscus population (Sanders et al. 2014). Population assignment analyses recovered two ancestral clusters that broadly corresponded to morphological species designations, but revealed high frequencies of hybrids on all four reefs and individuals of pure A. fuscus ancestry only at Scott and (historically) Ashmore. Most unexpectedly, 95% of snakes sampled at Hibernia were hybrids that resembled A. laevis in phenotype (morphology), revealing a collapse of reproductive barriers (‘reverse speciation’) at this reef. These results have dire implications for the conservation status of A. fuscus, and highlight the fragility of reproductive barriers in a recent marine radiation (Sanders et al. 2014).

Several names included within this taxon are sometimes considered full species or subspecies. Notechis s. scutatus (southeastern Australia) and N. s. occidentalis (southwestern Western Australia) are both recognized as subspecies by Uetz (2017). Several additional names included within the synonymy of N. scutatus are considered subspecies by Cogger (2014): N. ater (Flinders Ranges), N. niger (Kangaroo Island and other offshore islands of South Australia), N. a. serventyi (Chappel Island, Furneaux Group, Bass Strait, Tasmania) and N. a. humphreysi (King and nearby islands, Bass Strait, Tasmania). Clarification of subspecific boundaries in this taxon is required (N. Clemann pers. comm. 2017).
Kharin (1981) recognized two subgenera in the genus Aipysurus: Aipysurus and Smithohydrophis. He included A. apraefrontalis in Smithohydrophis (Kharin 1981).

The taxonomic history and range limits of Liasis mackloti are complex and still not fully resolved (Rawlings et al. 2004, D. Esquerre pers. comm. 2018). Confusion over range limits in Liasis fuscus, which was long considered a junior synonym of L. mackloti following Stuhl (1932), has resulted in a lack of clarity of the eastern and southern range limits of L. mackloti. Based on limited mtDNA sampling, Rawlings et al. (2004) found that Australian water pythons are divided into two clades, representing L. fuscus in Queensland and New Guinea and L. mackloti in the Northern Territory and the Indonesian islands Babar, Timor and Semau. Nevertheless, Australian workers have continued to recognize only a single water python species in this country pending resolution of taxonomic problems (Cogger 2014, Wilson and Swan 2017). New Guinean records have been attributed either to L. fuscus (McDowell 1975, Barker and Barker 1994, Barker et al. 2018) or to L. mackloti (O'Shea 2007, Cogger 2014). Carmichael et al. (2007) regard L. mackloti as an island endemic consisting of the subspecies L. m. mackloti, L. m. savuensis and L. m. dunni, excluding New Guinea from the distribution. These authors note that the three subspecies are allopatric and exhibit no evidence of hybridization. Rawlings et al. (2004) reported molecular evidence that the Sawu population, L. m. savuensis, may warrant specific recognition. Recently, both L. savuensis and L. dunni have been recognized as valid species (Barker et al. 2015, D. Esquerre pers. comm. 2018). Following these taxonomic changes L. mackloti is restricted to Timor, Roti, Semau and Alor (Barker et al. 2015), and further research may reveal that its range should be extended to the Northern Territory in northern Australia.

The taxonomy of Varanus timorensis and V. auffenbergi from Roti Island is unresolved, and the occurrence of V. timorensis on this island is in need of clarification (E. Arida and S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). Unpublished data suggest that V. auffenbergi represents a subspecies of V. timorensis (A. Koch pers. comm. 2019).
It is likely that this species as it is currently known represents a complex of two species, although the potential new species from Kakadu has not yet been named (Sweet 2004; E. Pianka pers. comm.).
This taxon could be considered a subspecies of Varanus melinus due to its morphological similarity and parapatric distribution (A. Koch pers. comm. 2019).

Prior to their scientific description, populations now assigned to this species were allocated to Varanus indicus. There is some evidence from genetic studies that the Buru subpopulation is not referable to V. rainerguentheri, and instead represents another member of the V. indicus complex (Weijola and Sweet 2015).

Prior to their elevation to species status (Koch et al. 2007), these monitors were treated as a subspecies of Varanus salvator (Mertens 1942, Böhme 2003). The various subpopulations on Sulawesi and its off-shore islands show considerable intraspecific variation in colour pattern (Auliya and Koch 2020). Further taxonomic investigations are needed (Koch and Arida, unpubl. data).

This taxon is now considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (1999), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

Lacerta anatolica was previously described as a subspecies of L. danfordi, but is now considered a full species. Following Arnold et al. (2007), Lacerta anatolica is now named Anatololacerta anatolica.

The gender of the genus Podarcis has been considered to be feminine by some authors (Arnold 2000, Lanza and Boscherini 2000, Montori and Llorente 2005) and masculine by others (Böhme 1997, 1998). We follow here the recent publication by Böhme and Köhler (2005) in considering the gender of Podarcis to be masculine. It is possible that this is a complex of several species (Oliverio et al. 1998, 2000), but the differences noted could represent intraspecific variation (Capula and Ceccarelli 2003).
Two subspecies are described. The nominative subspecies, E. p. punctatolineatus is found in north Eurasia, and E. p. kumerlavi Eiselt, 1970 is found in the area of Lake Van in eastern Turkey.

This species was formerly included in the genus Coluber, but is included here in Hierophis following Schätti and Utiger (2001) and Nagy et al. (2004). Nagy et al. (2002) showed that the subspecies H. viridiflavus carbonarius is probably a different evolutionary unit from H. v. viridiflavus. Mezzasalma et al. (2015) suggested on the basis of genetic evidence that these taxa should be considered distinct species, however there is a lack of correspondence between known morphological variation and genetic divergence (Rato et al. 2009) and between different genetic markers (Speybroeck et al. 2020). As such this assessment follows Speybroeck et al. (2020) in treating H. v. carbonarius as a subspecies.
The synonym Hierophis gyarosensis (known only from the island of Gyaros [Greece]) is actually an introduced population of H. v. carbonarius (Utiger and Schätti 2004).

This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Podarcis hispanicus, but it was raised to species rank by Oliverio et al. (2000). It was originally considered to be a North African species, but it has been shown also to be present in southern Spain (Harris et al. 2002). Populations in Tunisia might be another species.

This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Ablepharus kitaibellii, but was raised to species rank by Schmidtler (1997). A recent study has confirmed A. chernovi as a genetically distinct form (Poulakakis et al. 2005).
Anatololacerta anatolica was previously described as a subspecies of A. danfordi, but is now considered to be a full species.
This species is included in Montivipera following Nilson et al. (1999) and Lenk et al. (2001).
Populations in Iberia and France previously assigned to this species are now regarded as separate species jeanneae and manuelae (Busack et al. 2006).

Following Arnold et al. (2007), Lacerta laevis is now named Phoenicolacerta laevis.The subspecies Phoenicolacerta laevis troodica (Werner, 1936) from Cyprus was elevated to full species status as Phoenicolacerta troodica by Arnold et al. (2007).

This species was formerly included in the genus Lacerta, but is now included in Iberolacerta, following Carranza et al. (2004), and based on evidence from Arribas (1998, 1999), Carranza et al. (2004), Harris et al. (1998) and Mayer and Arribas (2003).

The extremely complex taxonomic history of the Gloydius halys complex is detailed by Wagner et al. (2016). These authors investigated the identity of populations in the Alai region, attributed variously to G. h. caraganus or a zone of sympatry between this taxon and the nominate G. h. halys. Comparing specimens with known G. halys subspecies on both molecular and morphological grounds, Wagner et al. (2016) found no close relationship with either G. h. halys or G. h. caraganus, finding that the Alai specimens most closely resembled geographically distant subspecies. Morphological differences from these latter (which were not sequenced) and geographic separation make the Alai population unlikely to be conspecific, and accordingly Wagner et al. (2016) described it as a new, full species G. rickmersi.

Recent DNA studies have elucidated the taxonomic status of this species. Previously, the name was applied to populations from four large islands (Isabela, Fernandina, Santa Cruz-Santa Fe and Santiago) and numerous associated satellite islets (Kizirian et al. 2004). Following DNA analysis, Benavides et al. (2007) restricted the range of the species to the Isabela-Fernandina islands, with the Santiago and Santa Cruz-Santa Fe populations now being recognized as Microlophus jacobi and M. indefatigabilis, respectively.

Recent DNA studies have elucidated the taxonomic status of this species. Previously, the name was applied to populations from four large islands (Isabela, Fernandina, Santa Cruz-Santa Fe and Santiago) and numerous associated satellite islets (Kizirian et al. 2004). Following DNA analysis, Benavides et al. (2007) restricted the range of the species to the Isabela-Fernandina islands, with the Santiago and Santa Cruz-Santa Fe populations now being recognized as Microlophus jacobi and M. indefatigabilis, respectively.

This species has historically had eleven recognized subspecies, and the taxonomic status of a number of these has varied, with specific status proposed and subsequently rejected for several (discussed in detail by Sullivan et al. 2014), with the resulting content of the "Little Striped Whiptail Complex" considered to contain four full species (Aspidoscelis inornata, A. arizonae, A. gypsi an A. pai) and seven subspecies within A. inornata in addition to the nominate form. In an effort to stabilize taxonomy within this complex, Sullivan et al. (2014) combined literature data on morphological variation with an mtDNA dataset on all four candidate species and four subspecies. These authors found a complex pattern of variation that in most cases did not follow recognized species and subspecies boundaries within this complex, and they recommended relegating A. arizonae, A. pai and A. gypsi to subspecific status and synonymizing A. l. junipera and A. l. llanuras within A. l. heptogramma.
This species was previously treated as a subspecies of Aspidoscelis burti, but is treated here as a full species following Crother et al. (2012).

Was under Iguanidae. In California, this species formerly was known as the coast horned lizard, Phrynosoma coronatum. Populations south of northern Baja California are now recognized as one or two distinct species, whereas the northern segment of the former P. coronatum is now P. blainvillii (see Leaché et al. 2009).

Mulcahy et al. (2006) examined phylogeography of Phrynosoma in the vicinity of the Salton Trough of southern California and northwestern Mexico and concluded that three species occur there: Phrynoma mcallii (endemic to the trough), P. goodei (which previously was recognized as a subspecies of P. platyrhinos; east of the Colorado River and south of the Gila River), and P. platyrhinos (elsewhere in the region).

Mulcahy et al. (2006) examined phylogeography of Phrynosoma in the vicinity of the Salton Trough of southern California and northwestern Mexico and concluded that three species occur there: Phrynoma mcallii (endemic to the trough), P. goodei (which previously was recognized as a subspecies of P. platyrhinos; east of the Colorado River and south of the Gila River), and P. platyrhinos (elsewhere in the region).

Phyllodactylus xanti nocticolus and P. x. xanti have been treated as distinct species by some authors, but Grismer (2002) identified a broad zone of intergradation between these nominal taxa and treated them as pattern classes of P. xanti. Stebbins (2003) also regarded them as conspecific (subspecies). de Queiroz and Reeder (in Crother 2012) cited Blair et al. (2009) and older studies in recognizing Phyllodactylus xanti and P. nocticolus as distinct species (the latter taxon is the one in the United States).

This species formerly was included in Contia tenuis; recognized as a distinct species by Feldman and Hoyer (2010). This species was originally named Contia longicaudae, however, because Feldman and Hoyer (2010) explicity treated the second part of the binomen as an adjective, it must agree with the name Contia in gender and number so that the correct spelling is Contia longicauda (Crother 2012).

Feldman and Hoyer (2010) formally split Contia tenuis into two species: Contia tenuis, which ranges from southern Vancouver Island (British Columbia) and central Washington to the northern portion of southern California, and C. longicaudae, with a smaller range extending from west-central Oregon to the Monterey Bay region of central California.

When the first assessment for this species was published it was under the generic name Eridiphas. Mulcahy (2008) transferred it to the genus Hypsiglena, hence the need for an updated assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When this species was assessed in 2007 it was treated as Stilosoma extenuatum, it was subsequently transferred to the genus Lampropeltis but the the specific name was left as extenuatum whereas it should have been corrected to extenuata. The assessment has been updated to reflect the correct name.

A combination of genetic analysis, divergence time estimates and ecological niche modelling identified five discrete clades within Lampropeltis getula, which did not correspond to recognized subspecific divisions (Pyron and Burbrink 2009a). Accordingly Pyron and Burbink (2009b) subsequently revised the systematics of L. getula, elevating L. splendida and L. californiae to specific status, redefining and elevating the former subspecies L. nigra and L. holbrooki, and synonymizing remaining subspecies (L. g. floridiana and L. g. meansi) within a monotypic L. getula. Pyron and Burbrink (2009b) also confirmed the previously recognized synonymy of L. g. goini and L. g. sticticeps within L. getula.

This species was originally assessed under the name Virginia striatula, but since the assessment was first published the species has been transferred to the genus Haldea (McVay and Carstens 2013), hence the need for this updated account.

Oldham and Smith (1991) demonstrated several significant categorical differences between Opheodrys aestivus and O. vernalis, indicative of a long history of divergent evolution, and assigned the latter species to a new genus (Liochlorophis), leaving aestivus as the only member of the genus Opheodrys. Crother et al. (2000) maintained vernalis in the genus Opheodrys whereas Walley (2003) concluded that available evidence supports recognition of the new genus. The latter classification was followed when this species was first assessed, however, subsequently most authorities (e.g. Crother 2012) have treated this species under the genus Opheodrys and hence this is the name used in this updated assessment.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Regina, but has since been transferred to the genus Liodytes (McVay and Carstens 2013), hence the need for this updated assessment.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Seminatrix, but has since been transferred to the genus Liodytes (McVay and Carstens 2013), hence the need for this updated assessment.
This species was first assessed under the generic name Regina, but has since been transferred to the genus Liodytes (McVay and Carstens 2013), hence the need for this updated assessment.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007,TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises. Chelonoidis donfaustoi is a recently described species (Poulakakis et al. 2015), previously included within C. porteri. The name C. porteri is now restricted only to the species of tortoise found on western Santa Cruz Island in the area known as La Reserva (the originally designated Tortoise Reserve). This Red List assessment treats this newly described taxon, C. donfaustoi, as a full species.

Anderson (1999) suggested that the population from Mazanderan in the valley of the Rud-e Atrak of the Kopet Dagh may prove to be a distinct taxon. This form has subsequently been described as the new species Darevskia kopetdaghica by Ahmadzadeh et al. (2013) and is assessed separately.

The validity of this species was questioned by Golubev in Ščerzbak (2003), who considered it an isolated population attributable to Phrynocephalus maculatus. According to Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007) P. golubewii is presently considered a valid species. It was treated within P. maculatus by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008), who however, noted that it appeared to be well-separated in the phylogeny provided by Arnold (1999).

This species has been listed as a possible synonym of Phrynocephalus versicolor Strauch, 1876 (Wermuth 1967). Both genetic and morphological evidence supports its recognition as a distinct species (Dunayev 1989, Solovyeva et al. 2014), a scheme that has been widely followed subsequently (Brushko 1995, Tuniyev and Ananjeva 2010, Solovyeva et al. 2014). Solovyeva et al. (2014) found that an undescribed, morphologically distinct taxon from the Dzhungarian Gate was genetically close to P. melanurus.

In a nomenclatural review of Phrynocephalus, Barabanov et al. (2007) referred P. grumgrzimailoi to the synonymy of P. melanurus based on the type locality and lectotype morphology. This work was however not a formal taxonomic review, and the name P. grumgrzimailoi has since been recognized in Chinese literature. This distinction is however "based on unreliable material and should be revised" (A. Barabanov pers. comm. 2018). Pending further taxonomic work, this account follows Barabanov et al. (2007) and the recommendation of A. Barabanov (pers. comm. 2018) in treating P. grumgrzimailoi as a junior synonym of P. melanurus.

The distribution and biogeographical distinctness of this taxon from Phrynocephalus guttatus was clarified by Dunayev (2009) who, however, retained it as a subspecies within "superspecies guttatus" despite recognizing a geographically intermediate form as the full species P. kuscakewitschi. Solovyeva et al. (2014) confirmed its distinctness on genetic grounds (with a genetic distance of 4–5%) and treated it as a full species, and this scheme is followed here.

This species was elevated from subspecific status within the eastern population of the Phrynocephalus guttatus complex by Dunayev (2009). Melville et al. (2009) reached the same conclusion based on molecular data, recommending that both P. g. kuschakewitschi and its sister taxon P. g. incerta (=P. incertus) be elevated to specific status. On genetic grounds Solovyeva et al. (2014) upheld the distinctiveness of the two taxa, while noting that P. kuschakewitschi and P. incertus are closely-related and difficult to distinguish morphologically. As such the precise distributional limits between the two species, which here follow the concepts applied by Solovyeva et al. (2014), may require further clarification.

The distribution and biogeographical distinctness of this taxon from Phrynocephalus guttatus was clarified by Dunayev (2009), who, however, retained it as a subspecies within "superspecies guttatus". Solovyeva et al. (2014) confirmed its distinctness on genetic grounds and treated it as a full species, and this scheme is followed here.

This species is included in Dolichophis following Nagy et al. (2004) rather than Hierophis, although workers within parts of its range - at least in Turkmenistan - cotinue to use Hierophis (A. Shestapol pers. comm. 2016). Until recently it was considered as a subspecies first of D. jugularis and, later, of D. caspius (Amr and Disi 2011).

The status of this species in El Salvador is unclear. Smith et al. (2001) stated that Sceloporus acanthinus ranges into El Salvador, while Köhler et al. (2006) and Köhler (2008), following advice from E. N. Smith, included El Salvador populations in S. malachiticus. These accounts follow the latter authors in attributing Salvadorian records to S. malachitus.

Apostolepis borellii has variously been considered either a valid species or a junior synonym of A. nigroterminata, with recent authors generally adopting the latter scheme (De Lema and Renner 2016). De Lema and Renner (2016) examined the holotypes of both taxa together with new material from Matto Grosso, and resurrected A. borellii as a validly distinct species.

authority: Passos, Texeira Jr, Recoder, de Sena, dal Vechio, de Arruda Pinto, Mendonça, Cassimiro & Rodrigues, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Atractus spinalis é uma espécie descrita recentemente para a Serra do Cipó por Passos et al. (2013), a espécie é morfologicamente similar a A. paraguayensis e A. potschi,  das quais se difere principalmente a partir de caracteres exclusivos de coloração (número e forma das bandas transversais), da morfologia hemipeniana (face mediana dos lobos sem ornamentação) além de diferenças merísticas (número de escamas ventrais e dentes maxilares) e morfométricas (comprimento rostro-cloacal dos adultos). Esta encontra-se alocada no grupo de espécies de A. paraguayensis (Passos et al. 2013).

authority: Pires, da Silva Jr, Feitosa, Costa-Prudente, Preira-Filho & Zaher, 2014

taxonomicNotes:
This species was previously synonymized with Amphiesma platyceps, a similar, sibling species (Khan 2006). It was removed from A. platyceps by Malnate (1966).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed back in the genus Herpetoreas (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

Hebius [Amphiesma] beddomei was described by Beddome in 1863 as Spilotes vittatus based on specimens collected from Nilgiri Hills, Western Ghats (Smith 1943). Günther (1864) moved it to the genus Tropidonotus and provided the replacement name Tropidonotus beddomei because vittatus was preoccupied in Tropidonotus by Tropidonotus vittatus Boie, 1827.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius (Guo et al. 2014). This species, which was resurrected from synonymy within Amphiesma parallelum by David et al. (2015), has been placed provisionally within Hebius.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

Although very similar to the Thai specimens of Hebius deschauenseei, the systematic allocation of Vietnamese specimens is currently under investigation. This identification should be considered provisional (Nguyen et al. 2009).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

The species is described based on a single specimen.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

authority: (David, Bain, Quang Truong, Orlov, Vogel, Ngoc Thanh & Ziegler, 2007)

This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. Smith's (1943) concept of this species ranged from northeastern India to Viet Nam, but this account follows David et al. (2007) in restricting the species to populations from northeastern India to Myanmar. Records of this species from outside this region are attributable to Hebius deschauenseei (Thailand), H. boulengeri (Viet Nam, and Guangdong and Guizhou in China), or an as-yet undescribed form from Viet Nam (P. David pers. comm. September 2011). Some records of this snake from Myanmar represent an additional, cryptic species. A revision of the H. modestum-H. venningi group is underway which will clarify the identify and distribution of true H. modestum (P. David pers. comm. September 2011).

Hebius monticola was first described by Jerdon in 1853 as Tropidonotus monticolus based on specimens collected from Wayanad Hills, Western Ghats (Smith 1943). The type of this species is lost.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

This species was elevated to specific status by Das (2010) (as Amphiesma taronense, an apparently incorrect emendation), having previously been treated as a subspecies or synonym of Amphiesma venningi. Das (2010) provides no explicit justification for this action, although the accompanying description highlights morphological differences between the two taxa (particularly in the number of subcaudals). Its appropriate taxonomic status remains unclear (e.g. Uetz and Hošek 2016).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species is not mentioned in Guo et al. (2014) although they do indicate that venningi is not monophyletic, hence as vennigi is treated under Hebius and following the Reptile Database (Uetz and Hošek 2016) we place this species under Hebius.

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
This species has previously been included in Clelia rustica (Cope, 1878) on some occasions.

A.L. Silveira (pers. comm. 2010) considers this species a junior synonym of Tantilla pallida based on work in preparation to revise this widespread species complex. This work has still not been published as of 2019, and consequently this taxon is considered valid pending a formal taxonomic revision (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyami, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyami and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

This species has three subspecies:
S. japonicus boettgeri (Fritze, 1894)
S. japonicus japonicus (Günther, 1868)
S. japonicus takarai (Ota, Ito & Lin, 1999).

Gekko hokouensis as currently defined is likely to refer to an assemblage of morphologically similar but evolutionarily divergent species (Shibaike et al. 2010) that may include one or more species of conservation concern (H. Ota pers. comm. 2007).

This taxon was previously considered as belonging to the otherwise central Ryukyu species Takydromus smaragdinus (Boulenger 1887), but is now recognized to be a distinct, phylogenetically rather distant species (see Lin et al. 2002, Ota et al. 2002).
Ouboter (1986) considered this species to be a synonym of Scincella modesta (Günther, 1864) based on some morphological similarity appearing in literature descriptions.

Trionyx triunguis has been considered a single widespread, relatively uniform species for decades, with no subspecies or other taxonomic units recognized or proposed in recent years. Phylogeographic studies of regional variation have demonstrated different, partly conflicting results, but were based on generally limited sets of specimens and genetic markers (Gidis et al., 2011; Guclu et al., 2011, 2015; Shanas et al., 2012). However, there is still uncertainty as to whether Mediterranean and African populations may in fact represent genetically definable separate Management Units (O. Türkozan unpubl. data).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anaur, Grismer, Quah, Murdoch, Muin, Davis, Aguilar, Klabacka, Cobos, Aowphol & Sites, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This population represents a new species of karst-adapted Bent-toed Gecko from the Cyrtodactylus pulchellus complex. All the morphological and genetic data concerning this population has been evaluated and confirms its new species designation (Grismer et al. 2014)

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Davis, Cobos & Murdoch, 2016
Grismer, Wood, Anaur, Grismer, Quah, Murdoch, Muin, Davis, Aguilar, Klabacka, Cobos, Aowphol & Sites, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Chelodina novaeguineae has been a taxonomic category to which a range of taxa of uncertain status have been assigned. It falls clearly within the thin-necked long-necked turtles of Australia, New Guinea, Timor and Rote. Only Chelodina pritchardi, Chelodina mccordi and Chelodina canni (Australia) have been definitively separated taxonomically from the Chelodina novaeguineae species complex. In one view, the remaining taxa, including Chelodina gunaleni and several yet to be described taxa conservatively remain under the taxon Chelodina novaeguineae. However, for the purposes of the Red Listing, Chelodina gunaleni is considered separately.

The name Chelodina oblonga now refers to northern populations of snake necked turtle referred to C. rugosa by Goode (1967) apparently in error. Chelodina colliei now applies to the snake necked form in south west Western Australia.

Allozyme data support the species designation (Georges et al., 2002), though hybridization with other species common. Two major mitochondrial haplotype clades distinguishing populations from the Northern Territory from those of southern New Guinea, Cape York and the rivers flowing into the Gulf of Carpentaria (Alacs, 2008), but these two clades are not regarded as warranting recognition at the level of species or subspecies. Chelodina siebenrocki is morphologically, genetically and ecologically indistinguishable from populations of Chelodina oblonga (formerly rugosa) from Cape York Peninsula, Australia, so the distinction between Chelodina oblonga (formerly rugosa) and C. siebenrocki is not maintained in this account.

Can be confused with Chelodina parkeri, with which it is broadly sympatric, distinguished by the lack of a distinct white patch immediately above and behind the tympanum and a ventral surface of the cervical scute wider than it is long.


1841 Chelodina oblonga Gray, 1841, holotype, BMNH 1947.3.5.89, from Western Australia. Synonymy follows that of (Thomson, 2000; 2006). 1890 Chelodina rugosa Ogilby, 1890, holotype, AMS R6256, from Cape York, Queensland. Precedence over Chelodina oblonga pending outcome of Case 3351, ICZN (Thomson, 2006). 1901 Chelodina siebenrocki Werner, 1901, holotype, ZMB 16491, from Papua New Guinea. Synonymy follows that of Georges et al. (2002), Georges and Thomson (2006). 1915 Chelodina intergularis Fry (1915), holotype, AMS R6255, from Australia. Synonymy follows that of Wermuth and Mertens (1961) and Cogger et al. (1983). 1969 Chelodina oblonga rugosa—Blackmore, 1969. 1969 Chelodina oblonga siebenrocki—Blackmore, 1969. 1985 Macrochelodina billabong Wells & Wellington, 1985, nomen nudum6 following Iverson et al. (2001). 1985 Macrochelodina rugosa—Wells & Wellington, 1985. 1997 Chelodina kuchlingi Cann, 1997c, holotype, WAM R29411, from Kalumburu, NW Australia, (14.18'S, 126.28'E). Synonymy follows that of Georges and Thomson (2006).

In addition to the morphological evidence provided in the original description, morphological data supporting its status as a separate species were provided by Rhodin (1994). Specimens used in allozyme comparisons were not distinct from C. novaeguineae, but they were from a captive collection, and may have been misidentified –further investigation is warranted. No substantive geographic variation has been reported and no subspecies are recognised.

Thomson and Georges (2009) placed the taxon bellii in the genus Myuchelys, which they separated from Elseya, a classification followed in the revision by Georges and Thomson (2010) and Fielder et al. (2015). Molecular and morphological assessments have found no substantive differences among populations from the Gwydir, Namoi, and Border Rivers catchments (Fielder et al. 2012; Fielder 2013), with little evidence to support any taxonomic subdivision of M. bellii at the species or subspecies level, as suggested by Cann (1998) and Wells (2007). The generic name Wollumbinia (Wells 2002) has been rejected as unavailable for this taxon (Georges and Thomson 2010; Fielder et al. 2015).

This taxon was listed as Elseya sp. 1 in the 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists. It was incorrectly spelled Elseya belli on the IUCN Red List from 2002, but corrected in 2009 to E. bellii following Rhodin et al. (2008).

Elseya branderhorsti (Ouwens, 1914)1914 Emydura branderhorsti Ouwens, 1914, described from a live specimen, type either non-existent or lost (Leo Brongersma pers. comm. to John Goode 1967, 28 June 1963), from southern New Guinea. 1994 Elseya branderhorsti—Bour et al., in David, 1994. First use of combination. 
Commonly confused with Elseya novaeguineae because of its superficial resemblance. Original description states lack of a cervical scute as the diagnostic character, by which it can typically be distinguished from Elseya novaeguineae (recently split to recognise Elseya shultzei and Elseya rhodini). A prominent alveolar ridge on the triturating surfaces of the mouth is also diagnostic. DNA sequence data suggest affinities with the species of Elseya from northern Australia. No subspecies are recognised.
Was listed as Elseya sp. 3 in the 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists.

EMBL (see http://www.embl-heidelberg.de/~uetz/LivingReptiles.html) reports that the status of this species is unclear "...recent authors don't mention this species any more. McDowell 1983 considered this a synonym of Elseya dentata. Fritz and Baur (1995) report vital hybrids between Emydura subglobosa and Elseya novaeguineae and between Emydura subglobosa and Chelodina longicollis".

Was listed as Elseya sp. 2 in the 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists.

Legler (1981) and others had long recognised the paraphyly of the genus Elseya. In 2007 the name Wollumbinia was proposed by Wells (2007) but was immediately declared as unavailable (Fritz & Havas, 2007). This was followed by Thomson and Georges (2009) in establishing the new genus Myuchelys for the group. An apparent paraphyly when using mtDNA was used to justify the splitting of Myuchelys and the genus Flaviemys (Le et al. 2013) was erected for this species. However Spinks et al. (2015) disagreed and synonymised Flaviemys with Myuchelys.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists prior to 2007 under the name Macroclemys temminckii. Was also treated by some authors under the generic name Macroclemmys.

Placed variously in Clemmys, Emys and Actinemys in recent years; the balance of opinion is split between Emys and Actinemys. Two subspecies were traditionally recognized, the typical A. m. marmorata (Baird & Girard, 1852), and A. m. pallida (Seeliger, 1945); some phylogenetic studies did not confirm this distinction and recommended abandoning the subspecies pallida (Spinks & Shaffer, 2005, 2009), but more recent work has now confirmed that these taxa are separate species (Spinks et al. 2014) and they are currently recognized as such (TTWG 2017). Additionally, an unnamed 'Baja California form' has been indicated based on morphological and molecular characteristics, but has not been formally described. Listed in the IUCN Red List from 1996 to 2006 under the name Clemmys marmorata.
Thirteen subspecies are recognised, plus additional unnamed taxonomically distinct lineages. These are summarised by Fritz (2001b: 419-426).
