Previously considered to encompass the Broad-headed Map Turtles inhabiting the Pascagoula and Pearl river systems, Graptemys gibbonsi was reduced in scope when the Pearl River form was described as a separate species, G. pearlensis Ennen, Lovich, Kreiser, Selman & Qualls, 2010.

Cuora flavomarginata is generally considered to include the form evelynae as a subspecies (Ota et al. 2009), though Ernst et al. (2008) retained evelynae as a full species. The name sinensis has been applied to mainland Chinese populations as a subspecies, with the typical flavomarginata restricted to Taiwan, but recent reviews (Fritz and Havas 2007; Ota et al. 2009; TTWG 2010) have not recognised Taiwanese and mainland populations as taxonomically distinct.

Cuora yunnanensis has been suggested to be an old example of an inter-specific hybrid, but a 1908 museum specimen was found to have unique mt-DNA indicating it to be a valid species status (Parham et al. 2004), and recent trade specimens of unreported origin agreed genetically with the 1908 specimen (He et al. 2007).
No subspecies proposed and no taxa synonymised.

Two subspecies are recognized: R. r. rubida (Cope, 1869), and R. r. perixantha (Mosimann & Rabb, 1953), defined on head pattern, marginal flare and geographic separation. These taxa may be elevated to species level in the future.
This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Kinosternon flavescens, but it was elevated to full species level by Serb et al. (2001).
This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Kinosternon flavescens, but it was elevated to full species level by Serb et al. (2001).

The former subspecies arizonense and durangoense were elevated to species by Serb et al. (2001). Subspecies spooneri is generally considered synonymous with flavescens (Berry and Berry 1984, Iverson 1992, Serb et al. 2001).

Includes the subspecies K. h. hirtipes (Wagler, 1833), K. h. chapalaense Iverson, 1981, K. h. magdalense Iverson, 1981, K. h. megacephalum Iverson, 1981, K. h. murrayi Glass & Hartweg, 1951, and K. h. tarascense Iverson, 1981. Taxon megacephalum may warrant species status, fide Joseph-Ouni 2003.
Taxonomic studies needed.
Two subspecies are universally recognised: Kinosternon sonoriense sonoriense LeConte, 1854, and K. sonoriense longifemorale Iverson, 1981.

Three recognised subspecies: Kinosternon subrubrum subrubrum (Bonnaterre, 1789), K. s. hippocrepis Gray, 1855, and K. s. steindachneri Siebenrock, 1906. Testudo Subrubra was first used by Lacepede, 1788, but this name was (probably) made unavailable by ICZN opinion 1463 (1987) suppressing part of Lacepede's work.

Two subspecies are generally recognized, Sternotherus minor minor and S. minor peltifer Smith and Glass, 1947. Occasionally Sternotherus depressus has been considered a third subspecies, but the balance of recent opinion is firmly to recognize depressus as a full separate species. The Sternotherus species have on occasion been placed in the genus Kinosternon.
Generally placed in Sternotherus, but on occasion in the past placed in the genus Kinosternon.
A recent molecular assessment of Pelusios confirmed that P. castanoides is a valid species but the validity of the Malagasy and Seychellois subspecies is not yet resolved (Fritz et al. 2011, 2013).

A recent molecular assessment of Pelusios confirmed that P. rhodesianus is a valid species, with deep divergences indicative of cryptic taxa (Fritz et al. 2011). Previously, Broadley (1981) and Broadley and Boycott (2008) distinguished between northern and southern morphs based on colour differences. Wider sampling is required to assess the taxonomic status of the northern and southern populations.

Recent molecular assessments of Pelusios confirmed that P. subniger is a valid species (Fritz et al. 2011) with evidence of cryptic taxa in continental Africa (Fritz et al. 2013). The latter study also indicated that the Malagasy and Seychellois populations were not differentiated from samples from South Africa and Mozambique, rendering the subspecies P. s. parietalis invalid.
Historically placed in Podocnemis. No subspecies are currently recognized.
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the incorrectly spelt specific name P. dumeriliana.
Two subspecies are recognized: Apalone mutica mutica (LeSueur, 1827) and Apalone mutica calvata (Webb, 1959)

Includes six widely recognised subspecies: Apalone spinifera spinifera (LeSueur, 1827), A.s. aspera (Agassiz, 1857), A.s. emoryi (Agassiz, 1857), A.s guadalupensis (Webb, 1962), and A.s. pallida (Webb, 1962); Apalone spinifera atra (Webb & Legler, 1960) has at times been treated as a full species, but is here treated as a subspecies of spinifera based on recent genetic and morphological studies (McGaugh 2008, McGaugh and Janzen 2008, McGaugh et al. 2008).

The previously recognized subspecies Apalone spinifera hartwegi (Conant & Goin, 1948) is now considered a synonym of A.s. spinifera, based on its limited morphological and molecular distinctiveness (McGaugh et al. 2008).
Placed by some as a subspecies under C. chitra.
Phillips et al. (1996) elevated rossignonii and acutirostris to species level (from geographically isolated subspecies of C. serpentina) based on genetic differentiation.

Two subspecies (Chelydra serpentina serpentina (Linnaeus, 1758) and C. s. osceola Stejneger, 1918) were recognized until osceola was synonymized with serpentina by Shaffer et al. (2008), based on lack of significant genetic differentiation. Phillips et al. (1996) removed the former subspecies rossignoni and acutirostris by elevating these to species level, based on genetic differentiation.

This is the single living species and genus in this family which dates back to the Eocene. A number of synonyms have been published for the species, all obsolete and not used for a long time. The corrected but invalid spelling mawei has been supported by some taxonomists.

Chrysemys picta is traditionally considered to include four subspecies: C. p. picta (Schneider, 1783), C. p. bellii (Gray, 1831), C. p. dorsalis Agassiz, 1857, and C. p. marginata Agassiz, 1857. Starkey et al. (2003) argued that dorsalis is genetically distinct enough to warrant elevation to full species status, a position tentatively supported by the Turtle Taxonomy Working Group (TTWG) (2010), while the remaining taxa (picta, belli and marginata) show limited genetic variability and great variability within populations, such that averages are statistically different, but individual animals from the core of a subspecies' range often cannot be reliably attributed to that subspecies morphologically. The status of belli and marginata (vs. picta) remains subject to further research. For the present assessment, however, we retain the traditional arrangement of picta, bellii, dorsalis and marginata as subspecies of picta.

authority: Fritz, Fattizzo, Guicking, Tripepi, Pennisi, Lenk, Joger & Wink, 2005
taxonomicNotes: Described by Fritz et al. (2005) as a full species in the Emys orbicularis complex, based on its molecular distinction; the species is morphologically indistinct.

Previously this species was known as Clemmys insculpta, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006; paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of insculpta and muhlenbergii into Glyptemys (Holman and Fritz 2001, Parham and Feldman 2002).

Previously this species was known as Clemmys muhlenbergii, under which name it appeared in IUCN Red Lists until 2008. Paraphyly of the traditional genus Clemmys (sensu McDowell, 1964) required placement of muhlenbergii and insculpta into Glyptemys.
Graptemys ernsti was described in 1992; before that, it was considered to represent the easternmost populations of G. pulchra.
This species is taxonomically uncontroversial and stable.
Two subspecies are generally recognized: the typical Graptemys nigrinoda nigrinoda Cagle, 1954, and G. n. delticola Folkerts and Mount, 1969.

As a swarm of superficially similar taxa with largely overlapping distributions, the taxonomy and distribution of the pseudogeographica and ouachitensis groups have a long and intertwined history, of which the extensive revision by Vogt (1993) is the most recent and is followed for the Red List assessments. For current purposes, Graptemys ouachitensis contains two subspecies: G. o. ouachitensis Cagle, 1953 and G. o. sabinensis Cagle, 1953.
Previously this species was considered the Pearl River population of Graptemys gibbonsi, until G. pearlensis was described by Ennen et al. (2010) as a full separate species.

As a swarm of superficially similar taxa with largely overlapping distributions, the taxonomy and distribution of the pseudogeographica and ouachitensis groups have a long and intertwined history, of which the extensive revision by Vogt (1993) is the most recent and is followed for the red list assessments.

For present assessment, Graptemys pseudogeographica includes two subspecies: G. p. pseudogeographica (Gray, 1831), and G. p. kohnii (Baur, 1890).

Recognition and attribution of subspecies varies by taxonomic author; the Red List accounts follow the taxonomy of the Turtle Taxonomy Working Group (TTWG) (2010). Pseudemys concinna is thus treated to have three subspecies: P. c. concinna (LeConte, 1829), P. c. floridana (LeConte, 1829), and P. c. suwanniensis Carr, 1937. (Note: the taxa concinna and floridana are in broad sympatry in the southeastern lowlands).

The former subspecies texana Baur, 1893, peninsularis Carr, 1938, and gorzugi Ward, 1984, are now recognised as full species and are assessed separately. Fritz and Havas (2007) consider floridana a full species (including subspecies peninsularis Carr, 1938), while Ernst and Lovich (2009) follow Seidel (1994) and consider floridana a subspecies of concinna but recognize both peninsularis and suwanniensis as full species. Former subspecies hieroglyphica Holbrook, 1836, mobilensis Holbrook, 1838, hoyi Agassiz, 1857, and metteri Ward, 1984, have not been recognised since Seidel’s 1994 revision.
Elevated to full species status by Ernst (1990) and Seidel (1994) from initial status of subspecies of Pseudemys concinna.

The status of the taxon Pseudemys peninsularis remains subject to different interpretations as a full separate species (TTWG 2010; following Seidel 1994, 1995) or a subspecies of P. floridana (Jackson 2006, Thomas and Jansen 2006, Fritz and Havas 2007), depending on the assignment of the taxon floridana as a full species or a subspecies of concinna; peninsularis is universally agreed to be a species distinct from concinna; the last word on determining the valid species name is yet to be spoken.

Isolated populations in Massachusetts were previously recognized as a separate subspecies, Pseudemys rubriventris bangsi Babcock, 1937, but recent evaluations of their taxonomic status concluded that these populations do not warrant taxonomic recognition (Iverson and Graham 1990, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2009).

Currently considered to comprise six subspecies: Terrapene carolina carolina (Linnaeus, 1758), T. carolina bauri Taylor, 1895, T. carolina triunguis (Agassiz, 1857), T. carolina major (Agassiz, 1857), T. c. mexicana (Gray, 1849) and T. c. yucatana (Boulenger, 1895). The taxonomic status of the taxa yucatana and mexicana remains dynamic; they were treated as full species by Smith et al. (1996) and Stephens and Wiens (2003), but were treated as subspecies of carolina by Fritz and Havas (2007) and TTWG (2010). Butler et al. (2011) argued that the subspecies T. c. major is based on a phenotype resulting from introgression of genes of the extinct subspecies Terrapene c. putnami in eastern subspecies (mainly T. c. carolina) and does not warrant formal recognition.
No subspecies and no synonymised taxa attributed.
Two subspecies are recognised: Terrapene ornata ornata (Agassiz, 1857), and Terrapene ornata luteola Smith & Ramsay, 1952

Traditionally considered a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, recognised as full species by several authors, including Seidel (2002). Seidel (2002) placed two taxa as subspecies of T. gaigeae: T. gaigeae gaigeae (Hartweg, 1939), and T. gaigeae hartwegi (Legler, 1990).

Previously extending to Argentina with about 15 subspecies in North, Central and South America, most former subspecies have been elevated to species rank in recent years, leaving only Trachemys scripta scripta, T.s. troostii and T.s. elegans as current subspecies (see Seidel 2002, TTWG 2007, Fritz and Havas 2007, for details).
This taxon has traditionally been considered to be a subspecies of Trachemys scripta (Legler 1990), but it was elevated to full species rank by Seidel (2002).
Traditionally considered a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, noted as sufficiently distinct to warrant species rank by Legler (1990), and formally elevated to full species by Seidel (2002).
This taxon was traditionally considered to be a subspecies of Trachemys scripta, but it was elevated to full species rank by Seidel (2002).

Traditionally placed in Chinemys, reevesii has in recent years been widely accepted as a species of Mauremys (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010). The species includes the forms Chinemys megalocephala Fang, 1934, Geoclemys grangeri Schmidt, 1925, and Damonia unicolor Gray, 1873, which have on occasion been considered as valid species or subspecies, but have in recent years been treated consistently as synonyms of reevesii (Guo et al. 1997; Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010).
This species is sometimes treated under the genus Chitulia.
This species was resurrected from within Hemidactylus frenatus by Mazuch et al. (2016).

Melnikov et al. (2015) described Pseudotrapelus chlodnickii based on new material from Sudan. In a phylogenetic analysis of Pseudotrapelus Tamar et al. (2016) subsequently applied this name to a widespread clade encompassing records formerly assigned to P. sinaitus from North Africa as a whole.

authority: Wood, Grismer, Grismer, Ahmad, Chan & Bauer, 2009
Wood, Grismer, Grismer, Neang, Chav & Holden, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This former species complex has been divided by recent work into three distinct species: Acanthosaura crucigera, A. phuketensis (Pauwels et al. 2015) and A. cardamomensis (Wood et al. 2010).

authority: Pauwels, Sumontha, Kunya, Nitikul, Samphanthamit, Wood & Grismer, 2015
Wood, Grismer, Grismer, Ahmad, Chan & Bauer, 2009
Grismer, Wood, Lee, Quah, Anuar, Ngadi & Sites, 2015
Grismer, Wood, Lee, Quah, Anuar, Ngadi & Sites, 2015

taxonomicNotes: It is unclear whether northeast Indian, Bangledeshi and Chinese populations of Calotes emma, which belong to the subspecies C. e. alticristata, are truly conspecific with C. e. emma, the form found in most of the species' Southeast Asian range. It is consequently possible that C. e. alticristata may be elevated to specific status in future (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).

This species belongs to the "taxonomically challenging" Draco fimbriatus group, three of whose four species are rarely encountered and poorly-represented in collections (McGuire et al. 2018). The 145-year-old holotype of D. cristatellus was until recently impossible to sequence for genetic analysis, and it was described based on characters in a preserved specimen that may not have preserved diagnostically relevant details of colouration in life (McGuire et al. 2018).

In his description of Draco punctatus from Bukit Larut Boulenger (1900) did not report any diagnostic differences between the two species, but nonetheless considered the two taxa to be distinct and both present in Sarawak. With no clear diagnostic characters available to distinguish the two taxa, the validity of one or both species has been unclear and the situation was complicated further by two competing taxonomic treatments published in the same year (Musters 1983, Inger 1983).

With the advent of new techniques for extracting molecular data from old museum specimens, McGuire et al. (2018) sequenced the D. cristatellus holotype in an effort to distinguish between multiple possible taxonomic arrangements within the D. fimbriatus group. The results of this work supported recognition of D. fimbriatus, D. punctatus and D. cristatellus as distinct species (McGuire et al. 2018).

A revision of the Draco fimbriatus species group is presently underway (J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017). This work indicates that this group contains five species-level taxa: D. cristatellus, the species presently known as D. fimbriatus and D. abbreviatus, D. maculatus and D. henningi Musters, 1983 (presently a junior synonym of D. fimbriatus) (McGuire et al.2018).

McGuire et al. (2018) report that this work will necessitate nomenclatural changes to the species traditionally known as Draco fimbriatus, with the result that this name should be considered a senior synonym of Draco abbreviatus, and the name Draco punctatus Boulenger 1900 (whose complex taxonomic history is discussed in detail by McGuire et al. 2018) is available for the taxon previously known as D. fimbriatus.

This assessment accepts the scheme proposed by McGuire et al. (2018) for consistency with this source's revision of D. cristatellus and to limit the possibility of confusion resulting from forthcoming nomenclatural changes.

The name Draco volans has a complex taxonomic history summarized by McGuire and Alcala (2000), with competing taxonomic arrangements presented by Inger (1983), Musters (1983) and Alcala (1986). Ross and Lazell (1991) reported that a number of Philippine taxa synonymized within D. volans by Hennig (1936), Inger (1983) and Musters (1983) occur in sympatry with no evidence of intergradation, and consequently recognized these as full species. This arrangement was followed by McGuire and Alcala (2000), who conducted the first comprehensive modern taxonomic assessment of Philippine Draco and recognized ten species from this archipelago, most of which had variously been considered synonyms or subspecies of D. volans or D. spilopterus.
As most taxonomic attention has focused on the complicated systematics of Philippine taxa (McGuire and Kiew 2001) the true identity of D. volans itself, which has a type locality on Java and which was removed from the Philippine fauna by McGuire and Alcala (2000), remained unclear until a subsequent revision of Southeast Asian Draco lizards by McGuire and Kiew (2001). These authors recognized D. sumatranus, D. boschmai and D. timoriensis - previously treated as either junior synonyms (Inger 1983) or subspecies (Musters 1983) of D. volans - as distinct species on the basis of allopatric distributions and morphological differences, restricting D. volans sensu stricto to Java and Bali. These authors noted that both D. boschmai and D. timoriensis as consequently defined represented species complexes in need of further taxomomic resolution.
Gonocephalus kuhlii was synonymized within G. chameleontinus by Barbour (1912), but this action has not been widely followed in recent literature (e.g. Das 2010, Manthey 2010).

Two records from Sarawak were originally described as Harpesaurus thescelorhinos (King 1978), although subsequent authors have followed Moody (1980) in considering this taxon conspecific with H. borneensis. A morphological examination including new material supports this synonymy, despite finding that the recent female specimens have longer rostral appendages than female museum specimens from either Sarawak or Kalimantan (Lardner et al. 2010). Both a long-horned (presumed to be males) and a short-horned (presumed to be juvenile or female) specimen have been reported from Kubah (I. Das pers. comm. 2018).
Records of this species from the central highlands of Viet Nam and Cambodia represent Liolaemus rubritaeniata, following Hartmann et al. (2012).

authority: Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016
Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016
Grismer, Quah, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Davis, Murdoch, Grismer & Cota, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Nguyen et al. (2011), in a review of Dopasia in Indochina, removed Dopasia ludovici from the synonymy of D. harti. These authors provisionally elected to retain D. hainanensis as a distinct species despite noting that the diagnostic characters of the latter taxon may change with age. Further research is needed to clarify the relationships between these taxa (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Nguyen et al. (2011), in a review of Dopasia in Indochina, removed Dopasia ludovici from the synonymy of D. harti. These authors provisionally elected to retain D. hainanensis as a distinct species despite noting that the diagnostic characters of the latter taxon may change with age. Further research is needed to clarify the relationships between these taxa (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Dopasia ludovici was long regarded as a synonym of D. harti (Pope 1935, Smith 1935, Bourret 2009, Nguyen et al. 2009), although Brygoo (1987) suggested that it should be considered a distinct species based on the number of vertebrae from the atlas to the remnants of the hind leg bones. In a review of Indochinese Dopasia Nguyen et al. (2011) further distinguished D. ludovici from D. harti based on differences in lateral color pattern and recommended treating it as a valid species.
Gonocephalus chamaeleotinus records from Java require confirmation and may represent confusion with G. kuhlii (D. Iskandar and J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017).

A revision of the Draco fimbriatus species group is presently underway (J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017). This work indicates that this group contains five species-level taxa: D. cristatellus, the species presently known as D. fimbriatus and D. abbreviatus, D. maculatus and D. henningi Musters, 1983 (presently a junior synonym of D. fimbriatus) (McGuire et al. 2018).

McGuire et al. (2018) report that this work will necessitate nomenclatural changes to the species traditionally known as Draco fimbriatus, with the result that this name should be considered a senior synonym of Draco abbreviatus, and the name Draco punctatus Boulenger 1900 (whose complex taxonomic history is discussed in detail by McGuire et al. 2018) is available for the taxon previously known as D. fimbriatus.

This assessment accepts the scheme proposed by McGuire et al. (2018) for consistency with this source's revision of D. cristatellus and to limit the possibility of confusion resulting from forthcoming nomenclatural changes.

McGuire and Heang (2001) recognized D. sumatranus, D. boschmai and D. timoriensis - previously treated as either junior synonyms (Inger 1983) or subspecies (Musters 1983) of D. volans - as distinct species on the basis of allopatric distributions and morphological differences, restricting D. volans sensu stricto to Java.

authority: Grismer, Wood, Ahmad, Sumarli, Vazquez, Ismail, Nance, Mohd-Amin, Othman, Rizzaijesika, Kuss, Murdoch & Cobos, 2014
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010

taxonomicNotes: The first record of this species from Gunung Mulu was originally assigned to Cnemaspis kendalli with the caveat that it may represent an undescribed species (Koch and Schulz 2014). Kurita et al. (2017) reported that this record is attributable to C. dringi. This assignment is accepted here, but as these authors did not sequence material from the C. dringi type locality for comparison it should be considered tentative (L. Grismer pers. comm. 2017)

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
Chan, Grismer, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Savage, Grismer, Ahmad, Remigio & Greer, 2010
Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar, Ngadi & Ahmad, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This assessment follows the taxonomy of Grismer et al. (2008), however the Thai records are 200 km north of the northernmost distribution at Gunung Inas. Firsthand examination of the Thai specimens and a molecular analysis of this population may indicate that the Thai and Malaysian records represent different species (Grismer et al. 2008, 2014).

authority: Grismer, Ahmad, Chan, Belabut, Muin, Wood & Grismer, 2009
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
Grismer, Ahmad, Chan, Belabut, Muin, Wood & Grismer, 2009
Grismer, Chan, Quah, Muin, Savage, Grismer, Ahmad, Greer & Remegio, 2010
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Cnemaspis temiah was described based on a population of Cnemaspis from the Cameron Highlands that was long recognized but previously considered to belong to C. flavolineata (Grismer et al. 2014).

Cnemaspis kendalli was long understood to be largely endemic to Peninsular Malaysia and Singapore, with records from Indonesia thought to be referrable to different species (Grismer 2011). Although the type locality is "Borneo", the species was known from this island only from the area of Kuching (Koch and Schulz 2014). Grismer et al. (2014), in a wide-ranging revision of Cnemaspis, found that C. kendalli was a polyphyletic complex of six species, and restricted the name to a taxon found in northwestern Borneo and several Indonesian archipelagos.

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Chan, Quah & Pauwels, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species is very similar to Liolaemus wiegmanni, and it has been suggested the two taxa may be conspecific (Etheridge 2000).

Examining surviving material of Draco ochropterus, the holotype of which was destroyed in WWII, McGuire et al. (2007) concluded that D. ochropetrus represents a junior synonym of D. lineatus. This synonymy was upheld by Karin et al. (2018), who further supported it with the finding that this species' type locality in the Kei Islands (where D. lineatus does not occur) is almost certain to be in error.

This species has several described subspecies:
D. maculatus maculatus (Gray, 1845), found in Thailand and Malaysia;
D. maculatus haasei Boettger, 1893, found in eastern Thailand, Cambodia and Viet Nam;
D. maculatus whiteheadi Boulenger, 1899, from northern Thailand, northern Viet Nam and Hainan 
D. maculatus divergens Taylor 1934, found in northwestern Thailand.
The validity of these subspecies is not clear (Manthey 2008).
The holotype of this species was formerly regarded as a syntype of Pseudocalotes floweri (Boulenger 1912).

Euprepes novemcarinatus Anderson, 1871 is the type species of the genus Toenayar (Karin et al. 2016). The generic name comes from the mythology of Myanmar, in which the Toenayar (Pronunciation: ‘‘Toh-Ay-Nah-Yar”), from the Burmese language, is a mythical Dragon or serpent with four legs. The Burmese language has no grammatical gender, but we treat the scientific name, Toenayar, as feminine.
Draco affinis Bartlett, 1895 is probably a junior synonym of D. cornutus (McGuire and Kiew 2001), and this treatment is followed here.

Greer (1970) noted "the two Bornean species of Lamprolepis ... are extremely closely related, perhaps even conspecific". As both species are very poorly-known it has been difficult to test this hypothesis, however a preliminary analysis of scutellation by M. Auliya in 2003 "revealed various similarities" (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). Subsequently, further specimens of L. vyneri have been obtained from three newly-reported localities (Das 2004, Auliya 2006, R. Bonke unpubl. data 2006). Research is underway to clarify the relationships between Bornean Lamprolepis, and it is likely that this will reveal that L. nieuwenhuissi is a junior synonym of L. vyneri (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2017).

Greer (1970) noted "the two Bornean species of Lamprolepis ... are extremely closely related, perhaps even conspecific". As both species are very poorly-known it has been difficult to test this hypothesis, however a preliminary analysis of scutellation by M. Auliya in 2003 "revealed various similarities" (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018). Subsequently, further specimens of L. vyneri have been obtained from three newly-reported localities (Das 2004, Auliya 2006, R. Bonke unpubl. data 2006). Research is underway to clarify the relationships between Bornean Lamprolepis, and it is likely that this will reveal that L. nieuwenhuissi is a junior synonym of L. vyneri (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Grismer, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Chan, Grismer & Ahmad, 2010
Grismer, Belabut, Quah, Chan, Wood & Hasim, 2014
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Mohamed, Chan, Sumarli, Loredo & Heinz, 2014

taxonomicNotes: The northern and southern populations exhibit some ecological differences, and further research is recommended to determine whether this reflects taxonomic differences (G. Shea, H. Cogger and M. Greenlees pers. comm. 2017).

There is unpublished morphological and genetic data suggesting that the Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Islands populations represent distinct species (R. Bray unpubl. data). Until this work is formally published, this account retains the traditional concept of Oligosoma lichenigerum.

The typical subspecies Aprasia rostrata rostrata was listed previously on the IUCN Red List, but as the other subspecies A. r. fusca Storr, 1979 is now recognized as a good species, the typical subspecies now becomes a full species.
This species is undergoing revision.

Zug et al. (1998) indicated that Nactus pelagicus is the name properly attributable to unisexual populations found primarily in the Oceanian region, and revalidated the names N. eboracensis and N. cheverti for bisexual populations. The taxonomy of asexual populations currently assigned to N. pelagicus has not subsequently been investigated to confirm that these are all referrable to a single species.

This species has a disjunct distribution and animals in eastern populations have much longer tails than those in western populations; this may imply that this species in fact comprises at least two different species (E. Pianka pers. comm.).

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.
Populations from east Arnhem land show differentiation and are poorly surveyed (C. Moritz pers. comm. 2017).

This is a complex of several species that is currently under revision. Rabosky et al. (2014) found that Ctenotus inornatus as presently understood is only poorly distinguishable from several other species on the basis of genetic data, and proposed wide-ranging taxonomic changes to resolve this issue, including subsuming five recognized species (helenae, brachyonyx, severus, saxatilis and fallens) within the synonymy of C. inornatus. These authors acknowledged that this complex requires consideration of further genetic and morphological material and, while noting that "there is no evidence that any supposedly diagnostic characters for the forms are grounded in phylogenetic reality", they do not support the proposed synonymies with morphological comparisons.  Additionally, their mitochondrial (but not cytochrome b) data cluster in accordance with the original species concepts proposed for the Western Australian taxa, with a distinct lineage comprising morphologically confusing central Australian populations (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017)

Given the complexity of the taxonomic issues involved and the need for further resolution, this assessment retains a traditional concept of C. inornatus following Cogger (2014), and recognizes C. helenae, C. brachyonyx, C. fallens, C. severus and C. saxatilis as valid pending further investigation of these proposed synonymies.
This species has two subspecies: Liopholis whitii whitii (Lacépède, 1804) and L. whitii moniligera (Duméril & Bibron, 1839).

Three genetic lineages are known: one isolated in Guyra in northern New South Wales; one in the Victorian High Country to the New England Tablelands; and one in the Victorian Volcanic Plains and Tasmania (G. Shea, Wapstra, E., Clemann, N., Hutchinson, M. and P. Robertson pers. comm. 2017).

Three subspecies erected by Copland (1946) are still sometimes recognized by non-systematists, but these are not thought to be valid and Hemiergis decresiensis is consequently considered to be monotypic (M. Hutchinson pers. comm. 2017).
Three subspecies are presently recognized: Varanus acanthurus acanthurus Boulenger, 1885, V. a. brachyurus Sternfeld, 1919 and V. a. insulanicus Mertens, 1958.

This species has two recognized subspecies: Varanus gouldii gouldii, found throughout continental Australia except the arid interior; and V. g. flavirufus found in the arid interior of Australia (Cogger 2014).
This species has recently been split, removing the new species Varanus hamersleyensis (Maryan et al. 2014)
Unpublished morphological and genetic analysis suggest that the three isolated populations of this species represent distinct taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The taxonomy of Varanus timorensis and V. auffenbergi from Roti Island is unresolved, and the occurrence of V. timorensis on this island is in need of clarification (E. Arida and S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). Unpublished data suggest that V. auffenbergi represents a subspecies of V. timorensis (A. Koch pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012

taxonomicNotes: The appropriate generic name for Sphenomorphus luteilateralis is subject to some dispute. Skinner et al. (2013) erected the monotypic genus Tumbunasincus for this species (at that time included within Eulamprus) as part of a wide-ranging effort to resolve paraphyly among Australian sphenomorphine skinks. It has subsequently been included within Concinnia on morphological grounds (Cogger 2014) or Magmellia (followed most recently by Wilson 2015). This latter name was coined by Wells (2009), and as such Tumbunasincus is a junior synonym (Cogger 2014), however there is controversy over the acceptance of Magmellia as a valid name (Kaiser et al. 2013, Cogger 2014). These accounts take the conservative approach of retaining both this species, and the related E. murrayi/E. tryoni clade (which has been given the name Silvascincus or Karma), within Eulamprus pending resolution of both nomenclatural issues and relationships between these taxa, as genetic and morphological data are "not yet fully in agreement" (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017)

Following examination of additional specimens of Cyrtodactylus leegrismeri, Grismer et al. (2015) concluded that characters considered diagnostic for C. thocuensis are more variable within C. leegrismeri than previously recognized, and as such cannot be considered reliable. These authors consequently synonymized C. thocuensis within C. leegrismeri.

authority: Johnson, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Wood, Grismer, Greer, Chan, Ahmad, Bauer & Grismer, 2012

taxonomicNotes: There are two recognized subspecies: C. p. peguensis and C. p. zebraicus.

The taxonomic history of Cyrtodactylus pulchellus is summarized by Grismer et al. (2016). This species was described from Pulau Penang based on a small number of characters by Cantor (1847), and the name was subsequently widely applied for populations on nearby islands and the Malay Peninsula (Grismer et al. 2016). Over the past decade, subpopulations outside Penang have been described as distinct species (summarized in Grismer et al. 2016), restricting C. pulchellus sensu stricto to this island.

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Mohamed, Chan, Sumarli, Loredo & Heinz, 2014

taxonomicNotes: The provenance of the Cyrtodactylus stresemanni holotype - which Grismer (2011) describes as "bizarre" - is doubted, and may not have been taken in Peninsular Malaysia, as it more closely resembles species found east of the Wallace Line than other Malaysian taxa and the identification of the type locality is based on the specimen label rather than the correspondence of the collector (Harvey et al. 2016). These authors recommend that future comparative diagnoses of newly-recognized Wallacean or Papuan Cyrtodactylus include C. stresemanni rather than "dismiss it as a Sunda Shelf species".

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Mohamed, Chan, Sumarli, Loredo & Heinz, 2014
Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Quah, Muin, Chan, Sumarli & Loredo, 2015
Ngo Van Tri, Grismer, Thai & Wood 2014
Cobos, Grismer, Wood, Quah, Anuar & Muin, 2016
Nguyen, Botov, Le Duc, Nophaseud, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species has historically been confused in the literature with, and variously considered a junior synonym of, Hemiphyllodactylus harterti, a situation further complicated by the fact that two morphologically distinct populations, one matching the holotype of H. harterti and the other the type of H. larutensis, occur in closely adjacent areas of Bukit Larut (Grismer et al. 2013). Molecular phylogenetics support recognition of H. larutensis as a distinct, valid species (Grismer et al. 2013)

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Muin, Quah, McGuire, Brown, van Tri & Thai, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Grismer et al. (2013) proposed elevating the subspecies Hemiphyllodactylus yunnanensis dushanensis, H. y. jingpingensis and H. j. longlingensis to full species on the basis of molecular evidence that these lineages were not one another's closest relatives. Although these authors conducted no morphological analysis and there is some overlap in the characters they provide (Uetz et al. 2019), this arrangement has since been accepted by other authors working on Hemiphyllodactylus (see synonym list in Uetz et al. 2019), none of which have, however, discussed these taxa in detail. Morphological diagnosis is often difficult within this genus but the existence of a lineage endemic to eastern Yunnan (i.e. the concept of H. yunnanensis applied by Grismer et al. 2013) is consistent with known patterns of diversity in this group (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019)  This account consequently provisionally accepts H. yunnanensis, H. dushanensis, H. jingpingensis and H. longlingensis as full species.

authority: Nguyen, Lehmann, Le Duc, Duong, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2013

taxonomicNotes:
Several historical specimens in European museums that Brown et al. (2011) assign to this species - which had previously been mistakenly considered to represent juveniles of Luperosaurus cumingii - are poorly-preserved or immature, and their assignment to this species must therefore be considered tentative (Brown et al. 2011).

One museum specimen with imprecise locality data is presumed to represent a record of this species from Camiguin Norte, from which recent collections have confirmed L. angliit occurs (Brown et al. 2011). It had previously been suggested that this specimen was taken on Camiguin Sur and surveys of this island are needed to determine whether a related species occurs here (Brown et al. 2011).

authority: (Sumontha, Pauwels, Kunya, Limlikhitaksorn, Ruksue, Taokratok, Ansermet & Chanhome, 2012)

taxonomicNotes: Gekko kuhli is the most widespread member of the subgenus Ptyvhozoon and molecular research by Brown et al. (2012) found that nine lineages, and five potentially species-level clades, could be identified throughout this species' range, corresponding to different island groups (Sumatra and Enggano; Borneo and Sulawesi; and a clade of unknown provenance possibly from Java) together with two distinct clades in Peninsular Malaysia. Genetic divergence was found to be greater than that between most recently-recognised species of cryptic geckos (Brown et al. 2012). At present no wide-ranging morphological analysis has been carried out on G. kuhli, most of the proposed lineages were supported by a small number of genetic samples, and available material from island populations may be insufficient to resolve the systematics of this widespread species (Brown et al. 2012). Consequently it is not clear whether island forms should be treated as specifically distinct (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2017).
This species was split from Lerista cinerea in 2016 (Couper et al. 2016).

Takydromus sexlineatus ocellatus is sometimes treated as a full species. Additional hidden diversity may exist within this widespread species, at least in Myanmar where at least one cryptic species is thought to exist within this complex (G. Wogan unpubl. data).

Takydromus quadrilineatus Daudin, 1802 [= T. sexlineatus Daudin, 1802] is the type species of the genus Takydromus Daudin, 1802.

Tachydromus sikkimensis Günther, 1888 has been removed from the synonymy of T. sexlineatus.

Reviewed by McDowell and Bogert (1954), McDowell (1967), Mertens (1961) and Underwood (1957). Based on a study of the structure of the ears, McDowell (1967) considered the family to be closely related to the extinct Mosasauridae from the Cretaceous and Rieppel (1983) showed that the only living species in the family, Lanthanotus borneensis (Steindachner, 1878), exhibits no special similarities with primitive snakes in his study of cranial structure. Rieppel (1980) showed that the genus Lanthanotus Steindachner, 1878, forms the sister-taxon of Varanus, the two lineages together forming the sister-taxon of the New World Heloderma.

authority: Harikrishnan, Vasudevan, De Silva, Deepak, Kar, Naniwadekar, Lalremruata, Prasoona & Aggarwal, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This is the type species of the monotypic genus Apterygodon, which is closely allied with Dasia and has frequently been treated as a junior synonym following Smith (1937). Greer (1970) opined that "the differences [between the genera] do serve to justify the generic separation of the two taxa". The name Apterygodon vittatum (or A. vittatus) is still used by several authors, although molecular results obtained by Honda et al. (2000) and Mausfeld and Schmitz (2003) suggest a low level of genetic differentiation between the two genera and the latter authors consequently synonymized Apterygodon within Dasia.

In a combined morphological and molecular analysis of the Eutropis multifasciata complex, Amarasinghe et al. (2018) concluded that Eutropis grandis represents a junior synonym of E. macrophthalma. This has implications for the distribution of this taxon; Amarasinghe et al. (2018) consider it likely that the E. macrophthalma type locality on Java is in error, and that the holotype - which falls genetically within samples of E. grandis from Sulawesi - was in fact collected on the latter island.

authority: Grismer, Huat, Siler, Chan, Wood, Grismer, Sah & Ahmad, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Scincella reevesii and S. rufocaudatus form a species complex whose systematics remain unresolved and are presently being investigated (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

Sphenomorphus malayanus has been considered to occur on the Malay Peninsula since Boulenger (1912) reported two specimens from the Titiwangsa Mountain Range, and this opinion was upheld in the first comparative analysis of Indonesian and Malaysian specimens despite some morphological differences (Lim 1998). Grismer (2011) subsequently suggested that these differences may be significant based on differences in the described characters and raised the possibility that these populations may not be conspecific, although without examining specimens.

Grismer and Quah (2015) reported an unknown skink from the Cameron Highlands - 56 km of Gunung Gerah, the sole confirmed Malaysian locality for S. malayanus - which resembled both Malay and Indonesian specimens of S. malayanus, but "differs even further ... from the description of the Sumatran holotype". These authors described this specimen as the new species S. senja, and referred the Gunung Gerah specimen to this species.

The sole Thai record of this species is from a site where Sphenomorphus tersus is also known to occur, and it is therefore possible that this represents a misidentification (N. Panitvong pers. comm. 2017).

Sphenomorphus malayanus has been considered to occur on the Malay Peninsula since Boulenger (1912) reported two specimens from the Titiwangsa Mountain Range, and this opinion was upheld in the first comparative analysis of Indonesian and Malaysian specimens despite some morphological differences (Lim 1998). Grismer (2011) subsequently suggested that these differences may be significant based on differences in the described characters and raised the possibility that these populations may not be conspecific, although without examining specimens. 
Grismer and Quah (2015) reported an unknown skink from the Cameron Highlands - 56 km of Gunung Gerah, the sole confirmed Malaysian locality for S. malayanus - which resembled both Malay and Indonesian specimens of S. malayanus, but "differs even further ... from the description of the Sumatran holotype". These authors described this specimen as the new species S. senja, and referred the Gunung Gerah specimen to this species.

Tropidophorus mocquardi has long been treated as a junior synonym of T. beccarii (Smith 1923, upheld by Manthey 1983 and Malkmus et al. 2002). It is retained as a valid entry by Uetz and Hallerman (2017), the basis for which is unclear.

Pui and Das (2017) reported a discrepancy in the number of midbody scale rows compared with the original description, but noted that this is a character that exhibits interpopulation variation within Tropidophorus.
Specimens from the Cameron Highlands previously included within Tytthoscincus bukitensis has recently been assigned to the new species T. jaripendek and to T. cf. kakikecil (Grismer et al. in press).

Molecular analysis by Grismer et al. (in press) found that Tytthoscincus butleri is paraphyletic with respect to the holotype of T. langkawiensis indicates that the population from Langkawi and an undescribed population from Pulau Pinang (=Penang). These authors consequently synonymized T. langkawiensis within T. butleri and referred the Penang population to this species.

This species was described as the type species of the monotypic genus Paralipinia. This genus was synonymized with Scincella by Greer and Shea (2003), but other authors have continued to regard it as valid following Nguyen et al. (2010), who propose awaiting additional data before accepting this synonymy.

Scincella reevesii and S. rufocaudata form a species complex whose systematics remain unresolved and are presently being investigated (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). The only recent published treatment of this issue (Neang et al. 2018) investigated the systematics of the rufocaudata complex in part of Cambodia and described a new species, S. nigrofasciata. The molecular phylogeny these authors provide, however, indicates that this new species belongs to the same monophyletic group as sequences assigned to S. rufocaudata, "S. cf. rupicola" and those identified by these authors as S. reevesii (which does not correspond to S. reevesii as presently understood - G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). Pending greater resolution of the systematics of this species complex, recognition of S. nigrofasciata - known from a single locality - is considered premature and this assessment retains it within S. rufocaudata.

Grismer et al. (2016), tentatively referred records from Singapore to Tytthoscincus sibuensis. Subsequently Grismer et al. (2017) demonstrated that the Singapore population represented a distinct species, which they described as T. temasekensis.
This species is species complex, further research needed to clarify its species boundary (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
This species was recently described based on populations previously included within Tympanocryptis cephalus.

This species was recently described from populations formerly included within Tympanocryptis cephalus (Doughty et al. 2015). Genetic divergence between this taxon and T. diabolicus is nevertheless low and it exhibits little morphological difference from this taxon, raising some doubt about its validity (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017). The Fortescue River is however a likely barrier to dispersal that justifies provisional recognition of this taxon as a full species (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
This species could be an aberrant Diplodactylus pulcher (B. Maryan pers. comm. to P. Doughty)

Three karyotypically and genetically distinct taxa have been identified within this name, but there are no known morphological differences (Oliver et al. 2009). These authors recommend further research to clarify the taxonomy of this species complex.
Genetic and morphological studies indicate the existence of multiple species under this name (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The name Oedura fracticolor De Vis 1884 has not been used to refer to a valid species since its original description, other than by Wells and Wellington (1985) without justification. The type is apparently lost and its identity is unclear. Hoskin et al. (2018) discuss the history of this name and agree with Oliver and Doughty (2016) that it is likely to be a senior synonym of O. castelnaui. As the name O. castelnaui has been in widespread use for over a century and fulfils the conditions set out by the Zoological Code of Nomenclature for a protected name (nomen protectum), Hoskin et al. (2018) propose giving this name precedence over Oedura fracticolor, rendering the latter a 'forgotten' name (nomen oblitum).
This is a species complex, which is likely to include range-restricted species (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).

In a revision of the Oedura monilis group Hoskin (2019) examined the related species Oedura coggeri and O. tryoni. He proposed no changes to the accepted species concepts, but noted that he retained northern coastal populations from the Gladstone-Mackay region within O. tryoni "until assessed in more detail".

Populations that may be referrable to this species have been found in the southeast and central Arnhem scarp (Oliver and Parkin 2014, P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). The known specimens from these localities exhibit a degree of morphological differentiation from Strophurus horneri, and molecular data is required to confirm their identity (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). Pending further taxonomic work these records are excluded from this assessment.
There are populations in the central ranges that may be geographically and genetically isolated (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
The relationship between this species and Strophurus robinsoni needs to be investigated.
The relationship between this species and Strophurus mcmillani needs to be investigated.
The taxonomic status of the New England Tableland subpopulation in relation to the southern subpopulation should be investigated (G. Shea, H. Cogger and M. Greenlees pers. comm. 2017).
This taxon is thought to be part of a species complex, and its relationships with Brachyurophis semifasciata and B. roperi are poorly-understood (S. Wilson and A. Amey pers. comm. 2017).
There is some taxonomic uncertainty between this species, Brachyurophis campbelli and B. semifasciatus.

Demansia reticulata reticulata and D. r. cupreiceps have long been considered subspecies of Demansia psammophis, in part following Storr et al. (1986). This treatment was followed by Wilson and Swan (2013) while Cogger (2014) recognized only D. r. reticulata as being distinct from D. psammophis. These arrangements neglect evidence presented by Hutchinson and Tyler (1996) that D. psammophis and D. reticulata (=D. r. cupreiceps of Storr 1978) co-occur in the Flinders Ranges with no evidence of intergradation. This suggests a species boundary exists between between D. psammophis and D. r. cupreiceps, and the most recent treatments follow Storr (1978) in treating D. reticulata, including D. r. cupreiceps, as a species distinct from D. psammophis (e.g. Wallach et al. 2014).
The isolated northern populations should be compared with southern populations, as there may be unrecognized taxonomic issues (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Unpublished genetic analyses suggest that the subspecies P. s. bushi and P. s. nullarbor are conspecific with Parasuta gouldii (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Storr (1984) analyzed variation in patterning in the widespread Denisonia (now Suta) suta and concluded that two sympatric forms occurred in the Ord river catchment in the eastern Kimberley. One of these, which he retained within S. suta, appeared to derive from central Australian S. suta; the other, which Storr described as Denisonia ordensis, was derived from populations in the Barkly Tableland.

Both the validity of S. ordensis and its distribution have subsequently been uncertain, and research is needed to confirm that Ord River Suta represent two distinct taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Storr (1984) did not distinguish S. ordensis from putative ancestral populations in the Barkly Tableland, and should S. ordensis prove to be valid it is consequently unclear whether it has a restricted distribution in the Ord River ranges or whether it is conspecific with the Barkly Tableland Suta. No genetic research has been conducted on this genus (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017), although it is likely that tissue exists in museum collections (R. Ellis pers. comm. 2017).
Taxonomic work to clarify the distinction between this species and Vermicella annulata is needed (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

There is significant taxonomic confusion regarding the status of this species in relation to Christinus marmoratus. Some sources apply the name alexanderi more widely to include other, presently undescribed populations in eastern Australia. There is also inconsistency between the original description of alexanderi based on morphology and the modern definition of the taxon based on genetics (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
This is thought to be a species complex, whose taxonomy is presently unresolved (C. Sanderson pers. comm. 2017).

Genetic data indicate that the subspecies Gehyra koira ipsa, which has a very restricted range on the southern edge of the Bungle Bungles in Purnululu National Park in Western Australia, and two cryptic lineages not presently recognized as distinct from the nominate form may warrant recognition as distinct species (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
There are eight or nine lineages within this species complex. It is currently under taxonomic revision (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
This is a species complex currently under taxonomic revision (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
Genetic data indicate that this is a complex of species, some of which might have very restricted ranges (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).

The type specimen of Myron resetari was described in 2011 from a preserved specimen at the Queensland Museum labelled as M. richardsoni (Holotype:  QM J52861. Type Locality: Broome, Western Australia) (Murphy 2011). The type locality was not specific and only alluded to the vicinity of Roebuck Bay adjacent to Broome, WA (From Murphy 2011: “Known only from the type locality, Broome, Western Australia; but it may be more widespread. Given Myron’s use of mangroves and mudﬂats it seems likely this snake is from the Roebuck Bay area of the Dampier Peninsula.”). There were no live specimens recorded until October 2013 when Scott van Barneveld and Steve Wilson recorded an additional five specimens alive during nocturnal searches. Subsequent to this first record of live individuals Scott van Barneveld made a thorough search of the Roebuck Bay region of Broome and recorded a further 22 individuals between 2013 and 2016. Multiple specimens have since been reported from Roebuck Bay in the vicinity of Broome.

Myron resetari is distinguished from M. richardsonii by the presence of one preocular scale as opposed to two preoculars in M. richardsonii, and by 19 mid-body scale rows as opposed to 21 in M. richardsonii and its largest upper labial is the 5th compared with the largest upper labial of 6 or 7 in M. richardsonii.

Genetic information indicates that this species is not part of the Enhydris clade. The oldest available generic name for this taxon is Pseudoferania (Alfaro et al. 2008) and has subsequently been treated under this generic by all subsequent authors (e.g. Murphy and Voris 2014).
The two recognized subspecies are likely to be sunk into a single monotypic species (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017)

The species status needs to be revisited (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017). It exhibits very low genetic divergence and few morphological differences from two species occurring in nearby areas (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2017).
Molecular and morphological work supports recognition of the subspecies Pletholalax gracilis edelensis as a full species (P. Doughty in prep.)
East coast and south coast populations are geographically and genetically distinct (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The taxonomic status of this species remains unclear as it is known only from a single 19th Century specimen (Cogger 2014). There is some doubt that the species was actually collected in Australia (Wilson and Swan 2013) and its assignment to the Australo-Papuan blindsnake genus Austrotyphlops (found to be a junior synonym of Anilios by Hedges et al. 2014) by Wallach (2006) appears to have been based on its described geographical range rather than examination of the specimen, and it is not clear that it correctly belongs to the same genus as other Australian blindsnakes (Shea 1999, then considering it within Ramphotyphlops).

This species was for many decades considered to be a very wide ranging species in Australia based on a number of widely scattered localities in the original description, most of which later proved to be misidentifications, and the difficulty in distinguishing this species from the more widespread Anilios wiedii on the basis of available keys (Shea 1999).
This species was originally assessed under the genus Ramphotyplops, but is now treated under Anilios (Hedges et al. 2014).
Ongoing genetic and morphological studies indicate that this is a species complex (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Morphological and genetic evidence suggests more than one species under this name. Some authorities recognize the species Anilios nigricauda (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
A manuscript in review will describe two new species in this complex; this will affect the distribution of this species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Genetic and morphological studies indicate that northwestern populations are taxonomically distinct from eastern Australian populations (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Hedges et al. (2014) found that Ramphotyphlops polygrammicus was polyphyletic, with the nominate form (which has a type locality on Timor) being appropriately assigned to their new genus Sundatyphlops, while Australian samples nested within the Australian radiation Anilios. These authors identify two potentially diagnostic morphological characters for the Australian taxon, for which the only available name is Typhlops torresianus (described from Murray Island). Hedges et al. (2014) define Anilios torresianus as including S. polygrammicus material from both Queensland and southern New Guinea, but caution that future taxonomic work is likely to reveal that this taxon is a species complex.
A new species is under description from the northwest Kimberly Islands which has a very small distribution range (C. Moritz pers. comm. 2017).
The validity of this species, which may be a junior synonym of Carlia fusca, is in question and needs additional research (A. Stubbs and G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

Zug (2010) recognized Carlia spinauris as distinct from Carlia peronii based on their type localities, one in a highland and one in a lowland area. Samples from the localities from which Carlia spinauris has been reported, at both high and low elevations, have been identified as C. peronii based on genetic research, and the validity of this species must consequently be considered uncertain (Stubbs et al. in prep.). This account consequently follows Greer (1976) in treating Carlia spinauris as a junior synonym of C. peronii.

O'Shea et al. (2015) suggested that a population from Timor-Leste may represent a distinct species; based on preliminary genetic data (Stubbs et al. in prep.) this population is included within C. peronii, but further taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between of Timorese subpopulations.
Donnellan et al. (2009) revalidated this species as a taxon distinct from Carlia longipes.
This is a complex of at least two species, a northern and southern species (C. Moritz pers. comm.).

Grismer (2011b) reports morphological differences between populations on Pulau Tioman and Pulau Tulai in Malaysia's Seribuat Archipelago, and suggests that future research is likely to reveal these represent two distinct species.
There is genetic variation between subpopulations from Chichijima and Hahajima Islands.

This taxon may be a species complex, and further taxonomic research is recommended. Recent genetic research across Thailand and Indochina supports this hypothesis and suggests that undescribed species occur in Thailand, Cambodia and Laos (Grismer et al. 2018). These authors refrain from proposing taxonomic changes at this stage due to potential sampling errors across this wide area.

This is probably a complex of species, however, taxonomic work is needed to resolve this. Populations from central Viet Nam and southern Lao PDR were assigned to the new species Acanthosaura nataliae by Orlov et al. (2006).

authority: Hartmann, Geissler, Poyarkov, Ihlow, Galoyan, Rödder & Böhme, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Records from eastern Viet Nam and Cambodia were described as a new species, Calotes bachae, by Hartmann et al. (2013).

Amarasinghe et al. (2014) recognized the Knuckles Range population of Calotes liocephalus as a new species C. pethiyagodai on morphological grounds. These authors cautioned that little material was available for either this species or C. liocephalus and that further research should be conducted to confirm this arrangement..

One of two Malaysian syntypes of Calotes floweri, taken from Gunung Tahan (Boulenger 1912), was assigned as the holotype of the new species Pseudocalotes dringi by Hallermann and Böhme (2000). The other appears to have been lost (Hallermann and Böhme 2000) but presumably also represents P. dringi. A record of P. floweri (Boulenger, 1912) from Kon Tum Province by Bain et al. (2007) was re-assigned to P. ziegleri by Hallermann et al. (2010).

Yang and Rao (2008) elevated the former subspecies Calotes kingdonwardi bapoensis to specific status and assigned it to the genus Japalura. Subsequently, Mahony (2010) redescribed C. kingdonwardi and reassigned it to Pseudocalotes. While Mahony (2010) noted that, having not examined specimens, he had "no comment on the validity of the recent elevation of Calotes kingdonwardi bapoensis", he noted that it is "clearly" not referable to Japalura and that neither the English text in the original description nor a characterization of the C. k. bapoensis holotype by Vindum et al. (2003) was sufficient to distinguish it from P. kingdonwardi. As such he adopted a traditional taxonomy retaining this taxon as a subspecies of P. kingdonwardi pending further research to confirm its taxonomic status, and this scheme is followed here.

Salea rosaceum, long considered a junior synonym of Dendragama boulengeri, was found by these authors to have been misattributed, and Harvey et al. (2017) referred this name to the synonymy of Pseudocalotes tympanistriga.
There is some taxonomic uncertainty around this species. Molecular research is needed to clarify differences between this species and Pseudocalotes microlepis.
The taxonomy of this species complex is in review (Reilly in prep.)

The taxonomy of this species is currently under revision by J. McGuire (in prep.). It is likely that the current subspecies Draco obscurus latepictus, found on Sumatra and the Mentawai Islands, will be elevated to specific status as a result of this work (J. McGuire pers. comm. 2018).
This is likely to be a species complex, the systematics of which are presently being investigated (Reilly).

Records of this species from northeast Vietnam (Ho et al. 2001, Ananjeva et al. 2007) are not supported by voucher specimens, and require confirmation following recognition of new Japalura species from China that had long been confused with J. flaviceps (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Leiolepis ocellata has variously been considered a subspecies of L. belliana or a full species in its own right, with a distribution understood to encompass southeastern Myanmar, northwestern and northeastern Thailand (Das 2010). Grismer et al. (2014) found that on genetic grounds L. ocellata nested within L. belliana, but proposed considering it a full species on the basis of morphological and karyotypic differences. 
The population Grismer et al. (2014) identify as L. ocellata is genetically exclusive and confined to the Chiang Mai valley, which these authors suggest may result in isolation from every other Leiolepis taxon. The name Leiolepis ocellata is however associated with a type locality in "Kokariet, Birma" (Peters, 1971), and consequently either the taxon is more widespread or this is not an available name for the taxon Grismer et al. (2014) call L. ocellata.

This species is difficult to distinguish from Dibamus novaeguineae and has been treated as a synonym by implication is some literature (Iskandar and Tjan 1996). Further morphological studies are needed to confirm the validity of this species (Koch 2012).

authority: Neang, Holden, Eastoe, Seng, Ith & Grismer, 2011
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Grismer, Sumontha, Cota, Grismer, Wood, Pauwels & Kunya, 2010
Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Phung, Nguyen, Hoang & Ziegler, 2012
Nguyen, Le, Van Pham, Ngo, Hoang, The Pham & Ziegler, 2015
Luu, Bonkowski, Nguyen, Le, Schneider, Ngo & Ziegler, 2016
Orlov, Nguyen, Nazarov, Ananjeva & Ngoc Sang, 2007
Geissler, Nazarov, Orlov, Böhme, Phung, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2009
taxonomicNotes: Nguyen et al. (2017) found that Cyrtodactylus cattiensis, which resembles C. thuongae morphologically, has a wider range than previously recognized in southern Vietnam. As presently understood both species co-occur in this area, and molecular research is required to clarify taxonomic boundaries within both species (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Quang, Orlov, Ananjeva, Johns, Ngoc Thao & Quang Vinh, 2007

taxonomicNotes: In a review of the systematics of the Cyrtodactylus intermedius group, Grismer et al. (2015) found low genetic divergence and no morphological differences between C. paradoxus, C. condorensis and several previously unassigned island and montane populations. These authors consequently synonymized C. paradoxus within C. condorensis.

In reporting the first records of this species from Laos, Luu et al. (2016) noted minor morphological differences between the Laotian and Vietnamese specimens. Although these authors reported low levels of genetic divergence and consider the two populations conspecific, they note that once a larger series becomes available for analysis the two populations may warrant treatment as separate subspecies.

The type locality of Cyrtodactylus soni (Van Long Nature Reserve) is only 30 km from the type locality of C. cucphuongensis (Cuc Phuong National Park) (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Morphological characters of these species are relatively similar, so the taxonomic separation of these species need to be confirmed by molecular data.(Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018).

authority: Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Nguyen, Milto, Martynov, Konstantinov & Chulisov, 2014
Kunya, Panmongkol, Pauwels, Sumontha, Meewasana, Bunkhwamdis & Dangsri, 2014
Bauer, Kunya, Sumontha, Niyomwan, Pauwels, Chanhome & Kunya, 2010
Bauer, Kunya, Sumontha, Niyomwan, Panitvong, Pauwels, Chanhome & Kunya, 2009
Luu, Bonkowski, Nguyen, Le, Schneider, Ngo & Ziegler, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Grismer et al. (2015) recognize a monophyletic lineage of Cyrtodactylus ranging from the Cardamom Mountains to Phu Quoc Island in Vietnam containing three recognized species: the wide-ranging C. intermedius, and the island endemics C. phuquocensis and C. hontreensis. These authors' analysis suggest that multiple undescribed species exist within C. intermedius. These authors report that a taxonomic revision of this species complex is in preparation (Murdoch et al. in prep.).

authority: Kunya, Sumontha, Panitvong, Dongkumfu, Sirisamphan & Pauwels, 2015

taxonomicNotes: There are numerous published and unpublished data suggest this is a species complex with other Cyrtodactylus species. Further research is needed to clarify its taxonomy (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Nguyen, Milto, Martynov, Konstantinov & Chulisov, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Genetic research indicates that this species as presently understood is a species complex, which includes Timorese records identified by O'Shea et al. (2015) as an undescribed species.

authority: Grismer, Wood Jr., Quah, Anuar, Muin, Sumontha, Ahmad, Bauer, Wangkulangkul, Grismer & Pauwels, 2012

taxonomicNotes: There is a need to review the taxonomic relationship between this species and Crytodactylus rufford, to determine whether they are synonymous (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Nguyen, Milto, Martynov, Konstantinov & Chulisov, 2014
Nguyen, Le, Van Pham, Ngo, Hoang, The Pham & Ziegler, 2015
Schneider, Nguyen, Schmitz, Kingsada, Auer & Ziegler, 2011
Sumontha, Pauwels, Kunya, Nittikul, Samphanthamit & Grismer, 2012
Nguyen, Le, Tran, Orlov, Lathrop, Macculloch, Le, Jin, Nguyen, Nguyen, Hoag, Che, Murphy & Zhang, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Molecular work (Nguyen et al. 2017) suggests that Cyrtodactylus pseudoquadrivirgatus sensu stricto is only known from the type locality in A Luoi district, and that records from the remainder of the distribution correspond to other species whose taxonomic status need to be confirmed. Pending resolution of the taxonomy of these cryptic forms, this account retains these records within C. pseudoquadrivirgatus.

authority: Nguyen, Yang, Thi Le, Nguyen, Orlov, Hoang, Nguyen, Jin, Rao, Hoang, Che, Murphy & Zhang, 2014
Ziegler, Nazarov, Orlov, Nguyen, Vu, Dang, Dinh & Schmitz, 2010
Luu, Calame, Nguyen, Le, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2016
taxonomicNotes: There is a need to review the taxonomic relationship between this species and Crytodactylus lomyenensis, to determine whether they are synonymous (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Luu, Bonkowski, Nguyen, Le, Schneider, Ngo & Ziegler, 2016

taxonomicNotes: The type locality of Cyrtodactylus soni (Van Long Nature Reserve) is only 30 km from the type locality of C. cucphuongensis (Cuc Phuong National Park) (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Morphological characters of these species are relatively similar, so the taxonomic separation of these species need to be confirmed by molecular data.(Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018).

authority: Luu, Calame, Nguyen, Le, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2015
Nazarov, Poyarkov, Orlov, Nguyen, Milto, Martynov, Konstantinov & Chulisov, 2014
Linkem, McGuire, Hayden, Setiadi, Bickford & Brown, 2008
Nguyen, Le, Tran, Orlov, Lathrop, Macculloch, Le, Jin, Nguyen, Nguyen, Hoag, Che, Murphy & Zhang, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Nguyen et al. (2017) found that Cyrtodactylus cattiensis, which resembles C. thuongae morphologically, has a wider range than previously recognized in southern Viet Nam. As presently understood both species co-occur in this area, and molecular research is required to clarify taxonomic boundaries within both species (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Schneider, Nguyen, Duc Le, Nophaseud, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2014
Hayden, Brown, Gillespie, Setiadi, Linkem, Iskandar, Umilaela, Bickford, Riyanto, Mumpuni & McGuire, 2008

taxonomicNotes: This species was described based on morphological characters, from a series of samples collected at around 900 m asl. (Nazarov et al. 2008). Records subsequently assigned to this species encompass much of Chu Yang Sin National Park across a wide elevational range (500 to 2,000 m asl.), but molecular research is required to confirm that these all refer to the same species (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). A gecko closely resembling Cyrtodactylus ziegleri from Dak Nong Province was found to be genetically distinct by Nguyen et al. (2017), raising the possibility of cryptic diversity within this morphologically similar group.

authority: Ziegler, Botov, Nguyen, Bauer, Brennan, Ngo & Nguyen, 2016
Botov, Phung, Nguyen, Bauer, Brennan & Ziegler, 2015
Nguyen, Wang, Yang, Lehmann, Le, Ziegler & Bonkowski, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between this species and Gekko thakhakhensis, which was described from the same area (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

This species is known from a number of isolated populations between the ranges of Gekko grossmanni (around 60 km to the north) and G. takouensis (about 120 km to the south), and it is possible that these - and potentially undiscovered populations within this general region -represent a cline of variation within the G. grossmanni species group (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the systematics of this and related species (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Rösler, Nguyen, van Doan, Ho, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This is a species complex which requires taxonomic review (T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Animals from northern Laos may warrant taxonomic investigation to confirm their identity. At present they are assigned to Gekko petricolus, the taxon which with they share the closest morphological and molecular affinities, but it is unclear whether they are truly conspecific (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

A suggestion that this species may be conspecific with Gekko taylori (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017) is supported by a recent examination of the G. taylori holotype by H. Ota (O. Pauwels to M. Sumontha, pers. comm. 2017). This account consequently follows the species concept adopted by Uetz and Hallerman (2017) in treating G. taylori as a junior synonym of G. siamensis.

authority: Luu, Calame, Nguyen, Le, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the relationship between this species and Gekko bonkowskii, which was described from the same area (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

This species is difficult to distinguish from related species, particularly the similarly parthenogenic, triploid Hemidactylus garnotii (Darevsky et al. 1984), and karyological data is necessary to distinguish it from the common and widespread H. frenatus (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

Hikida and Zhao (1989) note that one of the paratypes, the sole specimen from Hubei, differs from the other three specimens in lacking a postnasal. In the absence of any other known morphological differences these authors attribute this to intraspecific variation, but note that this character is diagnostically relevant for distinguishing species in other members of this genus.
This species was described based on two hatchlings and two embryos (Hikida 1989). As adult characters are unknown, it is possible that taxonomic issues exist with this species.
Proposed taxonomic revisions would place this species and other North American skinks in the genus Plestiodon (Brandley et al. 2005).

Additional studies to verify the taxonomic status of this species, especially concerning its relationship to Malayotyphlops ruficaudus, are needed (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007; McDiarmid et al. 1999).

McDowell (1974) suggested that this species may be conspecific with Typhlops luzonensis and/or T. ruber. Additional studies into the taxonomic status of this species are needed (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007). Only the holotype was available to Wynn et al. (2016), but these authors' examination suggested that it was distinct from Malayotyphlops luzonensis or M. ruber

Wynn et al. (2016) opine that this Typhlops manilae should not be included in the genus Malayotyphlops until its affinities can be "better evaluated", this nomenclature is retained here to preserve the definition of Typhlops sensu stricto as a New World genus (Hedges et al. 2014).

The name Typhlops luzonensis has been applied "somewhat indiscriminately" to blindsnake records from Luzon, Negros, Cebu and Marinduque, despite the recognition of a distinct species Malayotyphlops ruber on all of these islands (as well as Samar and Mindoro), and the apparently endemic M. hypogius on Cebu (Supsup et al. 2016). 
Since each nominal species has a type locality in a different, geologically distinct island group they are likely to be distinct, valid species (Ferner 2000), but although this arrangement has been followed in recent reviews of blindsnakes (Pyron and Wallach 2014, Hedges et al. 2014) the samples used in this work appear to be misidentifications (Wynn et al. 2016). Further study is therefore needed to clarify species boundaries between the apparently widespread M. luszonensis and M. ruber (Supsup et al. 2016).

The name Typhlops ruber has been applied to blindsnake records from Samar, Mindoro, Luzon, Negros, Cebu and Marinduque, but identification of specimens and clarification of this species' true distribution has been complicated by the "somewhat indiscriminate" use of the more recent name Typhlops luzonensis for specimens from most of these islands, as well as the recognition of a distinct species Malayotyphlops hypogius from Cebu (Supsup et al. 2016). 
Since each nominal species has a type locality in a different, geologically distinct island group they are likely to be distinct, valid species (Ferner 2000), but although this arrangement has been followed in recent reviews of blindsnakes (Pyron and Wallach 2014, Hedges et al. 2014) the samples used in this work are thought to be misidentifications (Wynn et al. 2016). Further study is therefore needed to clarify species boundaries between the apparently widespread M. luszonensis and M. ruber (Supsup et al. 2016).

This species was described from a nonspecific type locality and with limited detail, and examination of the three syntypes suggests that the types include representatives of two species (Wynn et al. 2016).
