These authors restrict their discussion of this name to a population from Luzon, but note that examination of the syntypes of Typhlops jagorii - presently a junior synonym of Malayotyphlops ruficaudus - is needed to confirm whether this assignment is correct and that the name Malayotyphlops ruficaudus can't presently be assigned with confidence to any specific island population. The concept applied by Wynn et al. (2016) is accepted here over the broader distribution suggested by Leviton et al. (2018) pending further research.
Horner (2007) treated Cryptoblepharus sumbawanus as a subspecies of C. balinensis, but the relationship between these taxa has not been studied in detail.
Blom et al. (2019) showed genetic divergence between populations of Cryptoblepharus burdeni that warrant further taxonomic study.
This genus needs an extensive revision in Indonesia, and the current name 'keiensis' may represent several different undescribed species (A. Stubbs, G. Shea and D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019).

There are unresolved taxonomic issues within Eremiascincus antoniorum and E. timorensis (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). 

It is unknown whether some or all of the undescribed Eremiascincus species reported by O'Shea et al. (2015) are conspecific to E. antoniorum. Greer (1990) assumed that records from lowland Timor represent this species based on morphological similarities, and suggested that this may also be the case for records of "E. emigrans" from other eastern islands in the Lesser Sundas, but neither he nor O'Shea et al. (2015) systematically investigated the taxonomy of this material.

Collections from Wetar, described as Eremiascincus wetarensis, have been referred to this species as the descriptions of these two taxa are not clearly distinct. Greer (1990) refrained from assigning Wetar specimens to any named species pending further research, but this population has subsequently been treated within E. emigrans by implication.
This species is known from widely-separated localities and it is unclear whether these are genetically homogeneous (K. Milto pers. comm. 2017).

Sphenomorphus nigrolabris is a species complex, within which species boundaries remain to be determined. S. amabilis is considered a junior synonym of S. nigrolabris in most literature, but as a distinct species by Koch (2012) following Malkmus (1993). Although likely to be distinct S. amiabilis has not yet been formally resurrected. As such diagnostic features which can reliably distinguish it from S. nigrolabris are unknown and its distribution cannot be determined with any certainty (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). It is consequently retained within S. nigrolabris here pending a formal taxonomic revision.

authority: Nguyen, Nguyen, van Devender, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2013

taxonomicNotes: The distinction between this species and the taxonomically complex Sphenomorphus melanopogon is not clear and is in need of further research (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Sumarli, Grismer, Wood Jr., Amiruddin, Rizal, Lukman, Nur & Linkem, 2016
Nguyen, Schmitz, Nguyen, Orlov, Böhme & Ziegler, 2011

taxonomicNotes: The subspecies Sphenomorphus vanheurnei balicus is likely to represent a different species to S. vanheurni (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
The records form central Sulawesi need examination to determine whether it is the same species (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
Vogel et al. (2016) removed this species from synonymy with Pseudorabion longiceps on the basis of morphological data.

authority: Murphy, Mumpuni, de Lang, Gower & Sanders, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
The Lesser Sundas Python was formerly recognized in the genus Python, and later included in the genus Broghammerus (Hoser 2004) that is considered invalid as it lacked accompanying data and analysis (Kaiser et al. 2011). Reynolds et al. (2014) therefore erected the new genus Malayopython, that has since been supported (Barker and Barker 2015, Murray-Dickson et al. 2017, Barker et al. 2018), and includes the two species M. reticulatus and M. timoriensis.

A subpopulation on Rinca Island has been recorded that likely reveals a new sister species of M. timoriensis (Barker et al. 2018).
The concept of this species previously included the subspecies E. submetallica klossii (Boulenger, 1914), but that is now considered to be a good species (Brown 1991) and is assessed separately.

The type of Euprepes microcephalus, an enigmatic species reportedly from Mexico and assigned by Boulenger to the anguid genus Diploglossus, is in poor condition but Smith and Taylor (1950) suggest that it may correspond to a species of the Asian skink genus Dasia and that the specimen was mislabelled. The validity and precise identity of this taxon remain unclear, but no similar species has been reported from Mexico, it has not been recognized as a valid species in recent Mexican checklists, and for convenience the Reptile Database includes a summary of its taxonomic status in their entry for Dasia olivacea (Uetz et al. 2019). Examination of photographs of the holotype suggests that this taxon is not a Dasia, but is probably a member of a different Asian or African genus (Shea and Iskandar 2020).

Shea and Iskandar (2020) examined photographs and the description of the holotype of Mabuia wirzi, a species neglected since its description in 1925, and concluded that it should be considered a junior synonym of Dasia olivacea.

Bauer et al. (2013) found Cyrtopodion to be non-monophyletic, and resurrected the name Tenuidactylus for the clade including T. longipes. These authors explicitly rejected the subspecific status for T. voraginosus suggested by Ščerbak and Golubev 1986 [1996] and followed by subsequent authors (e.g. Ananjeva et al. 2006, Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). This account follows Bauer et al. (2013) in treating T. voraginosus as a full species. T. microlepis, typically treated as a subspecies, has a similar genetic distance to T. voraginosusand is treated as a full species by Nazarov and Poyarkov (2013). This scheme is followed here.

authority: Ahmadzadeh, Flecks, Carretero, Mozaffari, Böhme, Harris, Freitas & Rödder, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Anderson (1999) suggested that the population from Mazanderan in the valley of the Rud-e Atrak of the Kopet Dagh may prove to be a distinct taxon. This form has subsequently been described as the new species Darevskia kopetdaghica by Ahmadzadeh et al. (2013).

Phrynocephalus kuschakewitschi was elevated from subspecific status within the eastern population of the P. guttatus complex by Dunayev (2009). Melville et al. (2009) reached the same conclusion based on molecular data, recommending that both P. g. kuschakewitschi and its sister taxon P. g. incerta (=P. incertus) be elevated to specific status. On genetic grounds Solovyeva et al. (2014) upheld the distinctiveness of the two taxa, while noting that P. kuschakewitschi and P. incertus are closely-related and difficult to distinguish morphologically. As such the precise distributional limits between the two species - which here follow the concepts applied by Solovyeva et al. (2014) - may require further clarification.
This taxon, long considered a subspecies of Ctenophorus caudicintus, was elevated by Melville et al. (2016).
Ctenophorus slateri was formerly a subspecies of C. caudicinctus, but was elevated to the species level by Melville et al. (2016).
Oliver et al. (2010) showed that there was deep mitochondrial diversity in this species as it is currently defined. Many of these lineages have very small ranges.
Cogger (2014) treats it under Gnypetoscincus, however, genetics place it in Concinnia; but genetics of this overall group are not well-resolved (G. Shea pers.comm.).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean populations of Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group of skinks nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Unfortunately this author, who did not conduct a molecular study of Indian Ocean taxa, neglected to address an earlier recommendation by Rocha et al. (2006) that "Molecular data on these taxa [C. b. aldabrae, C. b. gloriosus and C. b. bitaeniatus] are crucial for any further assessment of their taxonomic status".

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but these authors do not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Shea pers. comm. 2020).

In a wide-ranging genetic review of species boundaries in Ctenotus, Rabosky et al. (2014) proposed synonymizing C. borealis within their concept of C. robustus, as these authors could find no genetic differences between these taxa and they describe the morphological differences as "subtle" and "highly-overlapping". These authors acknowledge their very limited sampling of C. borealis (sequences from three specimens) and do not examine the primary morphological characters used to distinguish these taxa (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). On this basis, and given continuing taxonomic issues within C. robustus, this account retains C. borealis as a valid species.

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.

Two specimens from 17 km west of Windorah have been identified as Ctenotus capricorni, although this is some way outside the species' core range. A. Amey (pers. comm. reported in Venz 2011) reports that there are "indications (besides geographical) that this further-flung material is not conspecific with C. capricorni sensu stricto" and that the taxonomy of C. capricorni as presently understood is in need of revision. Re-examination of these southwestern specimens confirms that there are "some differences" between these are C. capricorni from the main part of the species' range (P. Couper and A. Amey pers. comm. 2017), and they are not considered in this account pending further research.

This species appears to exhibit no genetic differentiation from Ctenotus delli based on preliminary genetic work (S, Keogh unpubl. data); the latter species' distribution is entirely encompassed within the range of C. catenifer as presently understood, although the northern (Bajingarrah) population of C. catenifer is in need of research to clarify its status. The two taxa are ecologically distinct, but the differences could simply represent ecological adaptation to woodland habitats by C. delli.

This species appears to exhibit no genetic differentiation from Ctenotus delli based on preliminary genetic work (S, Keogh unpubl. data); the latter species' distribution is entirely encompassed within the range of C. catenifer as presently understood, although the northern (Bajingarrah) population of C. catenifer is in need of research to clarify its status. The two taxa are ecologically distinct, but the differences could simply represent ecological adaptation to woodland habitats by C. delli.

The validity of this species is uncertain, as purported diagnostic characters are inconsistent or subjective (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Animals referred to this species may represent large individuals of Ctenotus taeniolatus (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

A recent genetic study by Rabosky et al. (2014) found Ctenotus robustus, formerly understood to be a wide-ranging Australian and New Guinean species, to be a polyphyletic species consisting of at least two major clades in Australia (genetic studies of New Guinean and Cape York populations have not been undertaken - G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Accordingly, Rabosky et al. (2014) synonymized eastern populations within C. spaldingi and applied the name C. robustus to a clade containing Northern Territory and Western Australian populations.

While this treatment resolved paraphyly within C. robustus, both taxonomic and nomenclatural issues remain, as the resulting concepts of C. spaldingli and C. robustus cannot be distinguished morphologically (Rabosky et al. 2014 did not fully redescribe either species, and their comparative diagnosis provided no distinguishing characters other than a slight difference in size) . Additionally, in view of uncertainty over the provenance of the C. robustus holotype (Rabosky et al. 2014), it is uncertain to which clade the name C. robustus properly belongs (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

In order to retain taxonomic stability pending resolution of these issues, this account adopts a traditional concept of C. robustus as a widespread Australian species following Cogger (2014), while noting that at least two species are likely to be included under this name.
Taxonomic boundaries both between this species and related taxa, and between the two recognized subspecies, are not well-resolved (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Multiple clades have been identified within Ctenotus labillardieri.
This is a species complex of perhaps two species under current revision (P. Doughty pers. comm. 2017).
Taxonomic boundaries between this species and Ctenotus militaris are poorly-defined, and there are likely to be multiple species within C. pulchellus as presently understood (G. Shea pers. comm.).

The taxonomic status of central and southern Australian populations allocated to this species require additional review (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The two subspecies are poorly-defined and are difficult to consistently distinguish (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017)
Northeastern populations are morphologically distinctive and may represent a separate taxon (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
There are numerous morphological and genetic forms within the current concept, some of which may be recognizable as species in the future (G. Shea pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species is unresolved, and preliminary results suggest that it is comprised of more than one species (G. Shea and H. Cogger pers. comm. 2017).
Populations from Rockhampton north represent a distinct lineage (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
This species consists of two genetic lineages, northern and southern, which exhibit significant divergence between the two (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
This species appears to be indistinguishable from, and is likely to be conspecific with, Lampropholis delicata (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
Lampropholis colossus appears to be indistinguishable from, and is likely to be conspecific with, Lampropholis delicata (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
The validity of this species has been questioned; it may represent a pattern morph of Lerista macropistophus (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

The type locality of this species is Woodstock in Queensland, but the species has never been recorded from Queensland since this collection in the 1950s. It is unlikely that the Northern Territory populations currently understood to belong to Lerista karlschmidti are truly conspecific with the Queensland holotype, and therefore the name L. karlschmidti sensu stricto is likely to apply only to a taxon collected from Woodstock and not recorded since its original description (E. Vanderduys and A. Amey pers. comm. 2017). Pending formal action to resolve this issue, this assessment applies to L. karlschmidti as presently defined, including Northern Territory populations,.

Both the provenance and the identity of three records of this species, from Woodleigh Station, have been questioned. These were reported from "limestone uplands with Acacia grasbyi scrub" in 1997 by Aplin et al. (unpublished), who noted that the specimens did not differ in size, characters or patterning from southern populations. Subsequent visits to the area have reported no limestone upland habitats in this area and tissue samples appear to have gone missing (G. Gaikhorst pers. comm. 2017). Genetic analysis is recommended should the specimens be recovered or additional records obtained from the Woodleigh locality (Alpin et al. unpublished, G. Gaikhorst and M. Cowan pers. comm. 2017).

The status of Lerista talpina is unclear. Aplin and Smith (2001) consider it a junior synonym of L. petersoni on the basis of a submitted manuscript that was never published. Subsequently the species has been recognized as valid by some authors (Cogger 2014) but not others (Wilson and Swan 2013). This account tentatively follows the latter arrangement pending consensus on the taxonomy of L. talpina.
Uncertainty exists as to whether the holotype was an aberrant individual of Lerista griffini (Maryan and Robinson 1997).
This is probably more than one species.

The name with priority for this taxon is unclear, as the names Lerista chalybura and L. zietzi were independently coined within a month of one another to apply to this taxon and it is not entirely clear which was validly published first (Shea and Sadlier 1999).

Molecular, morphological and ecological work soon to be published has demonstrated that the Victorian and New South Wales populations of Liopholis guthega represent different species (Z. Atkins in prep.)

This species is currently divided in to two well-defined, allopatric subspecies: Liopholis margaretae margaretae in the central ranges of northern South Australia and the Northern Territory and L.m. personata from the Flinders Ranges of South Australia. Genetic evidence suggests that these are likely to warrant recognition as full species (Chapple et al. 2005), but no formal taxonomic action has yet been taken.

Aplin and Smith (2001) highlight extensive genetic diversity within the widespread "Menetia greyii complex", highlighting instances of sympatry, hybridization, polyploidy and "probable parthenogenesis" (parthenogenesis in M. greyii was later confirmed by Adams et al. 2003). Aplin and Smith (2001) suggested that a specimen from False Entrance Well, described by Storr as Menetia amaura, is very likely to represent an aberrant specimen of a locally abundant M. greyii complex species, and "quite possibly" represents M. greyii sensu stricto. M. amaura has never been recorded since its original description, although the name is still used to apply to the Shark Bay specimen (Cogger 2014), and is here included within the M. greyii complex on the advice of G. Gaikhorst (pers. comm. 2017) until its systematics are more fully resolved.
This is probably a complex of several cryptic species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Northern and southern subpopulations are genetically distinct from one another although levels of genetic divergence within this species are comparable to those within other Saproscincus species (Moussalli et al. 2005).

Recent molecular work has found that Saproscincus oriarus is nested within S. mustelinus as presently understood, rendering the latter species paraphyletic (Moussalli et al. 2005). There is "no compelling genetic evidence" to support the hypothesis that S. mustelinus comprises multiple species-level taxa and genetic differentiation between this taxon and S. oriarus falls well within the range of intraspecific divergence within Saproscincus (Moussalli et al. 2005). S. orarius nonetheless exhibits an allopatric distribution and consistent morphological and ecological differences from other populations of S. mustelinus, including its high-elevation sister clade (S. mustelinus "Central" of Moussalli et al. 2005). S. oriarus is consequently treated as a full species both by Moussalli et al. (2005) and in more recent literature, and this scheme is followed here.

The appropriate generic name for Lygosoma murrayi is subject to some dispute. Skinner et al. (2013) erected the genus Silvascincus for this species and L. tryoni (at that time both included within Eulamprus) as part of a wide-ranging effort to resolve paraphyly among Australian sphenomorphine skinks. They have alternatively been included within Concinnia (Cogger 2014) or Karma. This latter name was coined by Wells (2009), and as such Silvascincus is a junior synonym (Cogger 2014). There is, however, controversy over the acceptance of Karma as a valid name (Kaiser et al. 2013, Cogger et al. 2014). These accounts take the conservative approach of retaining both of these species, and the related E. luteilateralis, within Eulamprus pending resolution of both nomenclatural issues and relationships between these taxa, as genetic and morphological data are "not yet fully in agreement" (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017)

Three subspecies are recognized: T. j. jacksonii, T. j. xantholophus, T. j. merumontana (Tilbury 2010, Stipala 2014). An investigation of the status of these sub-species in a phylogenetic framework has not confirmed differentiation between them, as currently conceived, although the outlying Mt. Meru sub-species, T. j. merumontana, does appear to be distinct (Stipala 2014). It is clear that additional work is needed to resolve the status of these sub-species.
The taxonomic status of this Cordylus population is under review (Stanley et al. 2016).
This species is endemic to a restricted area of Angola's Great Escarpment (Stanley et al. 2016). The Namibian records are referred to Cordylus namakuiyus (J. De Boer pers. comm.).

authority: Greenbaum, Stanley, Kusamba, Moninga, Goldberg & Bursey, 2012
Stanley, Ceríaco, Bandeira, Valerio, Bates & Branch 2016

taxonomicNotes: This taxon was until recently considered a population of Platysaurus capensis (Whiting et al. 2015).

The taxonomic status of forms in the Smaug (Cordylus) warreni species complex (see Jacobsen 1989) was evaluated using molecular and morphological approaches (Stanley and Bates 2014). The study identified eight well supported distinct clades that are allopatric.

The taxonomic status of forms in the Smaug (Cordylus) warreni species complex (see Jacobsen 1989) was evaluated using molecular and morphological approaches (Stanley and Bates 2014). The study identified eight well supported distinct clades that are allopatric.
The status of this taxon needs to be investigated as more than one form may be involved (W. Conradie pers. comm. 2019).
No outstanding taxonomic issues. However, the name ‘Afroedura soutpansbergensis’ was mentioned in error in Jacobsen et al. (2014) on several occasions in reference to A. broadleyi.
No taxonomic issues.

The relationship between the three subspecies of Afroedura africana was investigated using molecular techniques by Jacobsen et al. (2014) and all the former subspecies are now recognized as full species.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No issues.

This species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis, but its weakly verticillate tail, smooth dorsal scales and single internasal scale, as well as its geographic location, suggest that it falls within the Afroedura marleyi-maripi-pongola group.

This species has not yet been included in a phylogenetic analysis. According to Jacobsen et al. (2014) it shares bluntly keeled to trihedral dorsal scales with A. haackei, A. multiporis and A. major and therefore may be part of the same clade.
No issues.
A molecular phylogeny by Heinicke et al. (2017) showed that Colopus wahlbergii and C. kochi are referable to the genus Pachydactylus.

Haacke (1976) revised Colopus wahlbergii and described a western subspecies, C. w. furcifer.

A molecular phylogeny by Heinicke et al. (2017) showed that Colopus wahlbergii and C. kochi are referable to the genus Pachydactylus. The status of P. w. furcifer should be assessed by means of a molecular analysis.
Lygodactylus bonsi is considered to be a distinct species (e.g. Branch 1998, Travers et al. 2014) and is assessed separately.
Current taxonomic studies are underway to confirm the taxonomic validity of this taxon (W. Conradie and A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019).

Conradie et al. (2016) report Lygodactylus specimens collected from Mt Mabu and Mt Ribáuè, and preliminary genetic analysis confirms that those are not the same taxon as L. regulus (K.A. Tolley unpub. data 2019). The species is therefore considered to occur only on Mt Namúli.
Unpublished genetic data suggest that this taxon consists of multiple species-level forms.
The taxonomic status is uncertain. More than one form may be involved.

Although a recent study (Conradie et al. 2016) suggested that the species may be synonymous with Causus rhombeatus, the sequenced specimens were collected from outside of the known range and subsequent examination of these specimens suggest that they may be referable to C. rhombeatus.

A recent phylogenetic analysis shows that this species consists of at least two separate clades that are distinct at the species level (Barlow et al. 2019). A southern clade (primarily found in South Africa) is closely related to Bitis schneideri, whereas a northern clade (primarily found in Namibia) is related to B. peringueyi. Populations from Botswana and Zimbabwe have not yet been assigned to either of these putative taxa.

The relationship between the three subspecies of Afroedura africana was investigated using molecular techniques by Jacobsen et al. (2014) and all the former subspecies are now recognized as full species.

Amblyodipsas microphthalma nigra was originally considered to be a melanistic form of Amblyodipsas microphthalma (e.g. FitzSimons 1962; Pienaar 1966; Pienaar et al. 1978; Broadley 1971, 1983), until Jacobsen (1986) described it as a subspecies. A phylogenetic assessment should be made of the relationship between A. m. micropthalma and A. m. nigra.
Records of this species from Cambodia represent confusion with Acanthosaura cardamomensis (T. Neang pers. comm. 2017).

Japalura szechwanensis was synonymized within Japalura fasciata by Ota (2000). Although the name J. szechwanensis has recently been used to refer to a recognized species (Rao et al. 2017), this work did not review its taxonomic status or justify this treatment. This account consequently includes J. szechwanensis as a junior synonym of Diploderma fasciata.

authority: Wood Jr., Grismer, Aowphol, Aguilar, Cota, Grismer, Murdoch and Sites Jr., 2017
Wood Jr., Grismer, Aowphol, Aguilar, Cota, Grismer, Murdoch and Sites Jr., 2017
Wood Jr., Grismer, Aowphol, Aguilar, Cota, Grismer, Murdoch and Sites Jr., 2017

taxonomicNotes: Further research is required to confirm that Gekko ulikovskii is a junior synonym of G. badenii, as proposed by Nguyen et al. (2010) and accepted here. Other members of this species group are separated from one another by around 1-200 km, while the type localities of G. badenii and G. ulikovskii are separated by about 400 km2 (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Further material from the G. badenii type locality, and molecular data for G. ulikovskii, will be necessary to resolve the systematics of this taxon (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
This species is part of the Gekko petricolus group (Kreuzer and Grossmann 2003).

Recent genetic and morphological studies on specimens referred to Bronchocela rayaensis from Tanintharyi Division found that these individuals were closer to Malaysian B. rayaensis than typical B. cristatella (Zug et al. 2017). These authors resurrected the neglected name B. burmana Blandford 1878, described from the same area of Myanmar, for this clade, although the holotype was not available for examination. While Zug et al. (2017) acknowledged that B. burmana may prove to be a senior synonym of B. rayaensis, they found a 5.5-6% molecular (ND2) divergence between the two taxa as well as preliminary evidence of morphological differences based on a small sample size, and elected to recognize B. rayaensis as a valid species.

Gopherus huecoensis † Strain 1966, described from the Pleistocene of Texas, is considered a synonym of G. flavomarginatus, reflecting the previous wider distribution of this species into the southwestern USA, including Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.

The record of this species from southern Vietnam, from Ma Da in Dong Nai Province (Bobrov 1992, Nguyen et al. 2009), is likely to represent a different species, and research is needed to confirm its assignment to D. melanostictus (V. S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
The taxonomic status of records attribute to this species from southern Vietnam needs to be confirmed (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017)
There is strong evidence, based on morphology and genetic analyses, that widespread hybridization is taking place with Crocodylus acutus in the Cuban Archipelago (Milian-Garcia et al. 2014).

The former subspecies Varanus salvator togianus (Peters, 1872), V. s. nuchalis, V. s. cumingi, and Varanus salvator marmoratus (WIiegmann, 1834) have been elevated to full species status (Koch et al. 2007), but Varanus salvator remains polytypic (Koch et al. 2013).

Ongoing molecular research suggests that Lygosoma anguinum is a large species complex exhibiting a high level of paraphyly (A. Miller pers. comm. 2018), and efforts are underway to clarify the systematics of this and related taxa (A. Miller, C. Siler and E. Freitas unpubl. data). Although as presently understood the species has a wide range in Myanmar and adjacent areas of Thailand, samples from the type locality are required to accurately define species limits in this group (A. Miller pers. comm. 2018).

Fuhn (1964) synonymized Ablepharus anselli within Panaspis tancredi; accepting this, Jacobsen and Broadley (2000) also formally synonymized A. moeruensis and A. seydeli within this species based on the types' possession of identical scale characters. Largen and Spawls (2006) dispute this on geographical grounds given the wide distances between the known localities and the lack of evidence for populations between these areas. This issue does not seem to have been investigated subsequently, however, Largen and Spawls (2010) report that P. tancredi is known only from the holotype. Medina et al. (2016) were unable to clarify the relationship between P. tancredi and P. seydeli in the absence of confirmed material of the former, but on the basis of their results consider A. anselli and A. moruensis to be junior synonyms of a distinct P. seydeli as previously proposed by Broadley and Cotterill (2004), but caution that better sampling may reveal that these taxa warrant recognition as distinct species.

The original description of Calotes chincollium indicated morphological differences between southern and northern records (Vindum et al. 2003). It is possible that the southern population may warrant recognition as a separate species, and research is recommended to investigate this (G. Wogan pers. comm. 2017).

authority: Sumontha, Chomngam, Phanamphon, Pawangkhanant, Viriyapanon, Thanaprayotsak & Pauwels, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is sometimes included in the synonymy of V. ursinii (see McDiarmid et al., 1999). This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).

This species is closely related to V. eriwanensis and V. renardi. McDiarmid et al. (1999), consider the species rank of V. lotievi to be debatable. This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).
This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomic status of Vipera transcaucasiana, which is considered by some authors (e.g.. Baran and Atatür 1998; McDiarmid et al. 1999; Tomovic 2006; Ursenbacher et al. 2008) to be a subspecies of Vipera ammodytes. We tentatively retain it here as separate from Vipera ammodytes.

Of the six described subspecies, five are distributed in the Caucasus. D. d. sylvatica (Bartenjev and Reznikova, 1931) inhabits the submontane part of the Krasnodar Territory, mainly in the Caucasian Biosphere State Reserve and the adjacent spurs of the Great Caucasus. D. d. boehmei (Bishoff, 1982) lives in the western spurs of the Great Caucasus in Krasnodar Territory and adjoining regions of Abkhazia up to Kodor River valley in the southeast. D. d. abchasica (Bishoff, 1982) inhabits the coast of the Black Sea of Abkhazia and the adjacent regions of western Georgia, D. d. barani (Bishoff, 1982) is known from coastal mountains regions of Ajaria and of neighbouring part of north-eastern Turkey. D. d. orlowae (Bishoff, 1984) inhabits southern slopes and foothills of the Great Caucasus in Georgia and northwestern Azerbaijan.

The nominative subspecies D. b. brauneri occurs in the south of the Krasnodar Territory, in Abkhazia and adjacent regions of Georgia. D. b. darevskii (Szczerbak, 1962) inhabits the foothills of the western part of the Great Caucasus range, mainly within the Krasnodar Territory. A comparatively small range of the subspecies D. b. szczebaki (Lukina, 1963) occupies a narrow strip of coastal rocky steeps, sporadically occurring along the coast of the Black Sea from the town Anapa in the north and for more than 100 km further to the south-east towards Novorossiisk.

The nominative subspecies D. p. porshchinskii occupies the most part of the distribution range. D. p. nigrita (Bakradze, 1976) is distributed in the ravines of the right side tributaries of the Kura River (the rivers Mashavera in Georgia and Debeta in Armenia).

The subspecies D. p. adjarica (Darevsky and Eiselt, 1980) is present in Georgia and in the ravine of the lower Chorokh River in Turkey. The remaining distribution is occupied by the nominative subspecies D. p. parvula.

The restricted range subspecies D. c. vedenica (Darevsky and Rotberg, 1999) is found on the northern slopes of the Andiysky Mountain range in the south-eastern Chechnya and possibly in the adjacent part of Ingushetia. The nominative subspecies, D. c. caucasica, occurs throughout the remainder of the range.

Three subspecies are described. The nominative subspecies D. r. raddei inhabits Armenia and Azerbaijan, and can be found in the western part of the Lake Sevan basin. D. r. nairensis is found in the ravine of the upper Kura River in Georgia (considered by some taxonomists to be a distinct species). D. r. vanensis occurs in the eastern part of the Lake Van basin in Turkey and adjacent Iran.
This species is part of the Vipera ursinii complex, and has often been included within Vipera eriwanensis.
The validity of this taxon has been questioned by some authors (e.g.. Baran et al. 2001; McDiarmid et al., 1999; Joger et al. 2003). This species is within the subgenus Pelias (Nilson et al. 1999).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The genus name is thus also used for species further to the south.

Taylor (1956) reviewed Middle American Mabuya found in Costa Rica and concluded that three species could be diagnosed: M. brachypoda, M. alliacea and M. unimarginata. Subsequent authors adopted this scheme inconsistently (Hedges and Conn 2012), and most recent publications have rejected this division and placed all Mabuya in Middle America in Mabuya unimarginata following Savage (2002), who contended that intergradation between these forms indicated the presence of only a single species in Costa Rica. Hedges and Conn (2012) reexamined representatives of these proposed species, and confirmed the original diagnosis of Taylor (1956). These authors noted that the position taken by Savage (2002) was not supported by evidence and was inconsistent with the observation presented by Taylor (1956) that M. unimarginata and M. brachypoda occur within 10 km of one another with no indication of hybridization, Hedges and Conn (2012) therefore revalidated M. brachypoda and M. alliacea, and assigned all former Mabuya in Central America to the new genus Marisora.

A record of this species from Mexico has been misidentified as Clelia clelia. It is unlikely that C. clelia occurs in Mexico. The distribution of this species in Costa Rica with respect to that of Clelia equatoriana is extremely confused, due to inconsistencies between species lists for this country and in descriptions of these species' colouration, morphological characters and ecology in the relevant literature, discussed in detail in Wilson et al. (2010). The expectation that C. equatoriana occurs in Costa Rica is based on the identification of a specimen from the northern highlands of the country's Cordillera Central (Zaher 1996), an unusual record for this predominantly lowland species which is not otherwise known north of Panama (Wilson et al. 2010). Due to difficulties presented by variation in and inconsistent descriptions of morphological characters for C. equatoriana, molecular work will be needed to establish whether this species in fact occurs in Costa Rica or whether highland populations are conspecific with C. scytalina (Wilson et al. 2010). Pending resolution of this issue, and following Wilson et al. (2010), Costa Rican records of C. equatoriana are considered to represent C. scytalina in these accounts.

There appears to be some confusion concerning the name Eremias novo. This was a temporary name for some populations subsequently identified as Eremias montana inhabiting the alpine meadows of Alvand Mountains in Hamedan Province (Nasrullah Rastegar-Pouyani pers. comm., September 2008). Eremias novo appears to have entered the literature, and has been recognised as a species by some authors (e.g.. Mozaffari and Parham, 2007).

Szczerbak (1974) suggested that Eremias quadrifrons may have been described based on an aberrant specimen of E. multiocellata. Sampling near the type locality reported by Orlova et al. (2017) obtained several specimens of E. multiocellata with patterning resembling E. quadrifrons. As the holotype remains the only confirmed record of E. quadrifrons these authors were unable to clarify its taxonomic status, and recommended further research including field surveys in order to clarify its taxonomic status and relationship to the E. multiocellata complex.

A single record from a gorge in the Mulu cave system (Forestry Department Sarawak 2006) represents a misidentification (I. Das pers. comm. 2018), and has since been described as the distinct species Cyrtodactylus muluensis (Davis et al. 2019).

The taxonomic placement of Alsophis ater into Hypsirhynchus was disputed by Grazziotin et al. (2012); who stated that the morphological characteristics used to place the species in Hypsirhynchus is based on morphological data provided by only a few specimens. This author places this species in Ocyophis, erected by Zaher et al. (2009).
Powell and Henderson (2003) synonymized C. carraui as a synonym with C. w. warreni and rejected its recognition as a subspecies.
Following Nilson and Rastegar-Pouyani 2007, Walterinnesia morgani is now recognised as being distinct from W. aegyptia.

Due to low levels of genetic differentiation between members of the Uromastyx aegyptia species group (considered to include U. aegyptia, U. leptieni, U. microlepis and U. occidentalis), Wilms et al. (2007) recognize U. aegyptia as a single species with three subspecies: U. a. aegyptia, U. a. leptieni and U. a. microlepis.

The relationship of U. occidentalis, which was not included in genetic analysis, to U. aegyptia remains in need of clarification, however Wilms et al. (2007) continue to recognize it as a full species due to its geographical separation from the remaining U. aegyptia-group taxa.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) does not agree with the placement of this species in Hypsirhynchus and places it instead in Schwartzophis, erected by Zaher et al. (2009) and subsequently treated as a junior synonym of Hypsirhynchus by other authors.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) does not agree with the placement of this species in Hypsirhynchusand places it instead in Schwartzophis, erected by Zaher et al. (2009) and subsequently treated as a junior synonym of Hypsirhynchus by other authors.
Preliminary research indicates that Hypsirhynchus parvifrons is a species complex containing 9 species, mostly corresponding with known subspecific boundaries (Hedges et al. in prep.)

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris recommended by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the generic assignment of the species.

.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris recommended by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the status of the species.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris recommended by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the status of the species.

Grazziotin et al. (2012) argued that the synonymization of the genus Darlingtonia with Ialtris done by Hedges et al. (2009) is not justified given distinct morphological characteristics between the genera. Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the status of the species.

It has been suggested that Sphaerodactylus kirbyi may be a junior synonym applied to several populations of S. vincenti (Daudin and de Silva 2007, citing F. Providence pers. comm.) More recent research has validated the recognition of S. kirbyi as a distinct species (e.g. Hite et al. 2008).
Was previously listed on The IUCN Red List under the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

The validity of the generic name Masticophis has been the subject of controversy "for many years" (Wilson et al. 2010), with some authors treating it as a synonym of Coluber. Limited taxon sampling has confounded efforts to resolve this question, with Nagy et al. (2004) finding no evidence for synonymy while a three-taxon study by Utiger et al. (2005) found M. flagellum to be nested within C. constrictor, although support for this conclusion was low (Wilson et al. 2010). More recent work involving broader taxon sampling within Masticophis and additional populations of C. constrictor found Masticophis to be monophyletic and sister to, rather than nested within, Coluber (Burbrink et al. 2008). Additional work to resolve the relationships between these and related genera is needed to resolve this issue, and is in preparation (R.A. Pyron pers. comm. October 2011). Research is also needed to resolve the position of the Central American M. mentovarius, which has not been included in these phylogenetic studies (Wilson et al. 2010). In the meantime this account follows Collins and Taggart (2008) and Wilson et al. (2010) in retaining Masticophis as a valid genus.

This species as presently understood consists of 11 subspecies, all occurring in the main island of Hispaniola or surrounding islands; it is considered to be a species complex (B. Hedges pers. comm. 2014).

Preliminary research suggests that Aristelliger expectatus is a complex of six species; the results of this work are in the final stages of preparation (Hedges et al. in prep). The identification of taxa within this species complex was not a primary focus of this research and no formal taxonomic action is imminent (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2016).

Populations in northern Hispaniola long attributed to Aristelliger lar have recently been found to represent either Aristelliger hechti or an undescribed taxon close to A. hechti (S.B. Hedges, in prep.).

Dendrophidion clarkii Dunn, 1933 is excluded from this taxon and treated separately as a good species. The population in the Serranía de Perijá likely also occurs in Colombia and may represent a distinct species.

Records from southern Colombia and Ecuador previously assigned to this species are now considered to represent Dendrophidion prolixum, and those from central Colombia an undescribed species, following the revision by Cadle (2012).

Specimens reported from the Cordillera Oriental of Colombia require further review, in order to establish their taxonomic identity (Myers 1974). These records are not considered in this assessment, which considers the species endemic to the Pacific versant of the northern Andes.

This snake has variously been considered a subspecies of either Leptotyphlops (=Epictia) goudoti or L. phenops (Wilson and Hahn 1973). These authors investigated its affinities and found no justification on morphlogical grounds for treating this form as a full species distinct from L. phenops, itself more recently treated as a subspecies of E. goudoti (see Uetz and Hallerman 2010 for attributions). Molecular data, however, indicate that this form is distinct from E. goudoti, and is indeed more closely-related to E. colombi (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009). On this basis, Adalsteinsson et al. (2009) resurrected E. magnamaculata as a full species.
Despite its restricted distribution, based on molecular evidence this species appears to be a species complex containing at least six species (Hedges in prep.).

Two museum records from the Madgalena Valley attributed to the Brazilian endemic Helicops carinicaudus are thought likely to be mislabelled H. danieli (Colombia checklist in prep.), and this assignment should be verified.
The validity of this species is in question (M. Calderon pers. comm. 2013)

Harvey et al. (2012) examined the type series of Ameiva bifrontata concolor, then understood to be a disjunct population of A. bifrontata confined to the Peruvian Andes. These authors recognize A. concolor as a separate species pending a full redescription. A. concolor was subsequently redescribed by Koch et al. (2013), who recognized the additional Peruvian species A. aggerecusans and A. nodam from within the former A. b. concolor.
manizalensis - no s
This species was described from within the Ameiva ameiva species complex (Ugueto and Harvey 2011).

authority: Goicoechea, Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher & de la Riva, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This taxon represents a species complex and research to clarify its systematics and identify cryptic species is presently underway; preliminary results suggest that three species are involved (S. B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015, 2016).

Based on molecular evidence (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data), two taxa previously considered subspecies of C. crusculus have been elevated to full species status (Henderson and Powell 2009). Celestus maculatus (Garman, 1888) occurs on Cayman Brac and Little Cayman and C. molesworthi (Grant, 1940) occurs along the northern coast of Jamaica, where it is allopatric with C. crusculus.

This taxon is treated as a full species on Caribherp; molecular evidence suggests that this is a distinct clade (S.B. Hedges unpubl. data) and morphological classifications have unhelpfully listed it as a subspecies of several related species.

This species was recently described based on morphological data, based on "relatively few" individuals from an island population of Thecadactylus rapicauda (Köhler and Vesely 2011). T. rapicauda is an extremely widespread species in mainland Central and South America and variation within this likely species complex has not been studied across its range. Further research is recommended to clarify the validity of this species,

Historical records of this species from Cuba and the United States have long been understood to be referrable to Sphaerodactylus elegans (Graham and Schwartz 1978); this name is however retained in error for numerous records within the GBIF database, and has been applied to specimens collected in the United States as recently as 1983. Unpublished sequence data suggests that S. cinereus is not closely related to S. elegans (S.B. Hedges, unpubl. data).

Sphaerodactylus darlingtoni as currently understood is a species complex (M. Landestoy, unpubl. data, D. Scantlebury pers. comm. 2016). A number of the component species are thought to correspond to recognized subspecies, with clearly allopatric distributions, however a number of candidate species remain undescribed at the subspecific level including at least two known from single sites outside Bani (D. Scantlebury pers. comm. 2016).
This represents a species complex that needs taxonomic revision (M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).
According to Pyron et al. (2016), a phylogeographic study may reveal cryptic species within this taxon, which is recognized as a species complex (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

Pyron et al. (2016) transferred Pseudotyphlops to the synonymy of Rhinophis, necessitating a new name for the species formerly known as Pseudotyphlops philippinus as R. philippinus was preoccupied. They determined that Uropeltis saffraganus was the oldest available name and coined the combination Rhinophis saffraganus.
The taxonomic history of this taxon was discussed by Mahopatra et al. (2017), who elevated it to specific status from within Ahaetulla nasuta and redescribed it, clarifying its distribution.

A record of Cnemaspis podihuna from Pallegama reported by Karunarathna et al. (2011) may be referable to C. kandambyi, a species with which C. kadambyi was previously confused (Batuwita and Udugampala 2017). Molecular research has not been conducted to clarify range limits between these taxa (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019), although a revision of C. podihuna is underway (S. Karunarathna and K. Ukuwela pers. comm. 2019).
“The specific epithet “chipkali” is the Hindi word for gecko” (Mirza and Raju 2017).

Afroedura langi originally contained several undescribed species (Jacobsen 1989, 1992a), but with a taxonomic revision and the description of six new species (Jacobsen et al. 2014), there are no other taxonomic issues.

A phylogenetic analysis indicated that A. pondolia comprises two well-supported phylogenetic clades (Makhubo et al. 2015), within which there are four cryptic species (Busschau et al. 2019). There is a possible zone of sympatry between A. pondolia and A. nivaria in the foothills of the Drakensberg Mountains that might be due to misidentified specimens. Furthermore, although A. pondolia and A. marleyi are clearly distinct species (Jacobsen et al. 2014), they are morphologically similar and this may result in misidentification of specimens from coastal KwaZulu-Natal Province.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues

A phylogenetic study indicates that B. inornata, B. albanica, B. armata and B. rubida form a closely related species complex (Barlow et al. 2019) and the relationships between these taxa is worthy of further investigation.

Originally described from Qudeni and Nkandla forests (Raw 1978), although the Nkandla subpopulation was later described as Bradypodion nkandlae (Raw and Brothers 2008). This was based on juvenile specimens which lacked clear diagnostic morphological differences with which to distinguish it from the Qudeni subpopulation. Phylogenetic studies showed a lack of divergence between chameleons from these two forests and as a result B. nkandlae was referred to the synonymy of B. nemorale (Tilbury and Tolley 2009). The species is now known from three forest patches, which has been confirmed by genetic studies (K.A. Tolley, unpubl. data 2019). There is also a morphologically distinct subpopulation near Greytown which is closely related genetically, but which has not been included in the current assessment.
No issues.

Recent genetic studies show that this species is part of the Bradypodion melanocephalum species complex. Based on mitochondrial DNA markers, there is low but diagnosable differentiation between these species (da Silva and Tolley, 2017).
The subpopulations are morphologically similar, but genetically, each is more similar to Bradypodion ventrale than they are to each other (Tolley et al. 2006).
Previously within the genus Cordylus (Stanley et al. 2011), but with the erection of the monotypic genus Ouroborus, there are no remaining taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No notable issues.

Recently transferred from Homopus to Chersobius. The subspecies, Homopus s. signatus and H. s. cafer, are partially sympatric in the western Karoo (Boycott 1986; 1989, Bour 1988, Iverson 1992, Boycott and Bourquin 2000). Colour patterns used to distinguish the subspecies appear to relate to crypsis on different substrates. The status of a subpopulation from the Pofadder area requires further investigation (Daniels et al. 2010). Records of this species from Namibia (Mertens 1955, 1971) are referable to C. solus (Branch 2007).
No notable issues.
No notable issues.
No notable issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No notable issues.

The generic placement of this species has long been in question, having been placed in Rhoptropus (Boulenger 1885, Branch 1998), Phelsuma (Roux 1907, Schmidt 1933), and a monotypic genus Rhoptropella (Hewitt 1937a). Evidence from phylogenetic studies have not yet adequately resolved the genus level status (Austin et al. 2004, Sound et al. 2006) although it is currently assigned to Rhoptropella (see Austin et al. 2004).
No taxonomic issues.
No notable issues.
There are no taxonomic issues.

A multi-locus phylogeny shows that the subspecies P. melanotus subviridis falls in the P. spinosus clade, not the P. melanotus melanotus clade (Stanley et al. 2011). Although morphologically quite distinct from Pseudocordylus melanotus subviridis, P. spinosus from Goodoo Pass in the Drakensberg Mountains also shared the same 16S mitochondrial haplotype as several P. m. subviridis individuals (Bates 2007b). Isolated subpopulations at Ixopo and Donnybrook in southern KwaZulu-Natal Province require taxonomic investigation.

Raw (1973) assigned specimens from the KwaZulu-Natal Midlands to S. guentheri, but these specimens were later described as S. bourquini (Broadley 1994). A photograph of an individual from Qudeni (KwaZulu-Natal Province) has been assigned to S. bourquini (Broadley 1994). Raw (2020) described this population as a separate species (S. farquharsoni), but this requires confirmation.

Although there appears to be genetic divergence between this species and the morphologically similar Scelotes montispectus (Bauer et al. 2003), further investigation of the species boundaries between these taxa and related forms is required. A molecular phylogeny (Heideman et al. 2011) suggested that the subpopulation of S. kasneri at Elands Bay may represent a distinct species, requiring a taxonomic revision.

A phylogenetic assessment (Heideman et al. 2011) suggested that the subpopulation of Scelotes gronovii at Elands Bay and the nearby Steenboksfontein Farm may represent a distinct species. The taxonomic status of this subpopulation needs further investigation.
This species is known from only two specimens, the holotype collected by E.A. Eastwood in November 1911, and another specimen collected by Vincent A. Wager in December 1928.

There is a potential taxonomic issue relating to the three Typhlosaurus species from the west coast of South Africa (T. caecus, T. lomiae, T. vermis) because they are morphologically similar, there is shallow genetic divergence between them (Lamb et al. 2010), and their ranges nearly continuous.

Phylogenetic analyses suggest that the genus Xenocalamus should be synonomised with Amblyodipsas (Figueroa et al. 2016, Portillo et al. 2018) but this needs to be confirmed with better taxon sampling.
No taxonomic issues.
No notable issues.
This taxon was separated from Phyllodactylus and placed in the monotypic genus Cryptactites by Bauer et al. (1997).
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues, although may be confused with K. spekii as they are morphologically similar.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues, although this species is morphologically similar to G. hewitti, leading to confusion between the two species.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
The southern populations of Goggia lineata were assigned to a new species, G. incognita (Heinicke et al. 2017), and the two species appear to be parapatric in the Knersvlakte area.
The southern subpopulation of Goggia rupicola has been assigned to a new species, G. matzikamaensis (Heinicke et al. 2017).

Although two isolated subspecies have been described, Afrogecko porphyreus cronwrighti (Hewitt 1937a) from Cape St Francis in the Eastern Cape Province and A. p. namaquensis (Hewitt 1935) from the western margin of South Africa (Bitterfontein, Little Namaqualand), neither is recognized currently (e.g., Branch 1998). Substantial genetic divergence across the Cape Fold Mountains has been noted (Heinicke et al. 2014), suggesting that a taxonomic revision is required.

The apparently disjunct population in the north-west Free State Province, South Africa (De Waal 1978) probably refers to A. aculeata distanti and records to the east of the distribution probably refer to A. aculeata aculeata

Although phylogenetic clades were found for the western and southern regions of South Africa (Daniels et al. 2007), these clades appear to relate to differences at the subspecies level rather than the species level (Spitzweg et al. 2020).
A recent phylogenetic study indicates fairly low divergence between two clades of this species (Hofmeyr et al. 2020), although there are habitat differences between the two groups.

The genus Homopus was found to be paraphyletic warranting resurrection of the genus Chersobius to accommodate the five-toed Homopus species (C. boulengeri, C. signatus and C. solus (Hofmeyr et al. 2017).
A recent phylogenetic study indicates that the western-most group along the escarpment forms a distinct lineage (Hofmeyr et al. 2017), which requires further investigation.

There has been confusion regarding the taxonomic status of the subspecies (P. t. tentorius, P. t. trimeni and P. t. verroxii) due to considerable colour and morphological variation and partially sympatric ranges. A recent phylogenetic study of southern African tortoise radiations indicates that P. tentorius consists of four to six deeply divergent lineages (Hofmeyr et al. 2017; Zhao et al. 2019a), suggesting a taxonomic revision is required.
Genetic studies show that populations from all three forests (Dlinza, Ntumeni and Ngoya) belong to this taxon (Tilbury and Tolley 2009).
No notable issues.
Northern and southern populations differ with regard to body proportions and scalation and are genetically divergent, indicating that two taxa may be present (Kelly et al. 2011).

The A. nivaria species complex requires revision, as at least two cryptic species within A. nivaria have been proposed (Makhubo et al. 2015). There is a possible zone of sympatry between A. nivaria and A. pondolia in the foothills of the Drakensberg Mountains that might be due to misidentified specimens. Records from the western Drakensberg Mountains (Free State Province) that were previously assigned to this taxon (Branch 1998) were shown to be more closely related to A. halli and might represent a cryptic species (Makhubo et al. 2015).

Records of P. capensis from the west coast of South Africa are generally referable to P. labialis. There is significant morphological variation within the species and further study is required to assess any possible taxonomically significant sub-structuring of subpopulations.
Pachydactylus maculatus has a wide distribution within which there is genetic variation (Skinner 2016), which could indicate that there are cryptic species.

Formerly a subspecies of Pachydactylus capensis, this species was raised to a full species (Jacobsen 1989). Pachydactylus vansoni as currently construed potentially contains cryptic species, in particular a “Highveld” and a “Lowveld” form (Jacobsen 1989).

A recent phylogeny suggests that this species should be elevated to a separate genus (Portillo et al. 2018), but additional work is needed to resolve the issue. Important synonyms: Choristocalamus concolor – de Witte & Laurent 1947.

The closely related population at Mkambati in the Eastern Cape Province appears to be a grassland ecomorph of this otherwise forest-dwelling species (K.A. Tolley unpubl. data 2019), but more research is needed to assess the taxonomic status of this population.

There has been some confusion between Bradypodion dracomontanum and an undescribed species ("Emerald Dwarf Chameleon"). Both occur in the Drakensberg Mountains, but B. dracomontanum occurs from Cathedral Peak northwards, whereas the Emerald Dwarf Chameleon occurs to the south of Cathedral Peak (Tolley and Burger 2007, da Silva and Tolley 2017).

Considerable morphological variation exists within this species (Tolley and Burger 2007) and it may contain multiple taxa (Jacobsen 1989). Although the subpopulations are monophyletic, genetic variation between these could be at the species level (see Tolley et al. 2004).
In the western part of the distribution there appears to be a contact zone with B. gutturale (Tolley et al. 2006), but it is not known if these species hybridize in the wild.
The taxonomic status of species in the Cordylus minor complex (Mouton and Van Wyk 1994), which includes C. aridus, is being re-evaluated using molecular techniques (Bates et al. in prep.).

This species displays regional variation in size and colouration, and there is an isolated subpopulation in the southern Great Escarpment and the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe (Alexander 1996). A phylogeographic analysis indicates limited genetic structuring across South Africa (Brand 2020). Although there is no phylogenetic data available for the relict subpopulation in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe, snakes from this area appear to be morphologically different with lower ventral and subcaudal counts than those in South Africa.

This species is often confused with Scelotes fitzsimonsi due to their morphological similarity, particularly where they are sympatric in KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa. The coastal and inland populations show differences in colouration and occur in different habitats.
No taxonomic issues.
No outstanding taxonomic issues.
There are no taxonomic issues.

There is a potential taxonomic issue relating to the three Typhlosaurus species from the west coast of South Africa (T. caecus, T. lomiae, T. vermis) because they are morphologically similar, there is shallow genetic divergence between them (Lamb et al. 2010), and their ranges nearly continuous.

A phylogenetic analysis shows that the sister taxon to the two northern subpopulations is Acontias gracilicauda, and not the nominal Eastern Cape Province form (Busschau et al. 2017). The nominal form is restricted to the Eastern Cape Province and the northern populations have been described as two species, viz. A. albigularis and A. wakkerstroomensis (Conradie et al. 2018).

Several discrete subpopulations occur along the southern African escarpment. Phylogenetic analysis correlates with morphological differences between these isolated populations, suggesting that between three and six cryptic taxa are subsumed under this name (C Kelly unpubl. data 2015).
No taxonomic issues.

The relationship of this species to other species remains uncertain. Its external morphology suggests a close relationship with Amplorhinus and it was provisionally included in the Pseudoxyrhophiinae (Vidal et al. 2008, Kelly et al. 2009). However, hemipenis morphology indicates close affinities to the lamprophiids (Zaher et al. 2019) and it is thus included in the Lamprophiidae in this treatment.
No issues.
Phylogenetic analyses suggest that there could be cryptic species within the A. amatolica complex (Makhubo et al. 2015).

The taxonomy of the A. nivaria species complex which includes A. halli requires revision, as a phylogenetic analysis suggests that there are cryptic species (Makhubo et al. 2015). A population in the south-eastern Free State Province referred to A. nivaria by de Waal (1978) was assigned to A. halli by Bates (1996a) and this population and two more in the area were confirmed to be A. halli by Makhubo et al. (2015). Another population from an inselberg in the eastern Free State previously assigned to A. nivaria (de Waal 1978, Branch 1998, Bates and Bauer 2018) was shown (together with additional nearby isolated populations) to be more closely related to A. halli (Makhubo et al. 2015).
The taxonomy of the Afroedura karroica complex requires revision, as a phylogenetic analysis suggests that there are undescribed, cryptic species (Makhubo et al. 2015).

Described by Onderstall (1984) as a subspecies of Afroedura pondolia. The taxon's specific status was first recognized by Branch (1998) and this has been followed by most subsequent authors (Monadjem et al. 2003, Boycott et al. 2007, Jacobsen et al. 2014).

Previously considered a subspecies of Afroedura pondolia (e.g., Onderstall 1984), Branch (1998) elevated it to a full species without comment. The specific status of A. marleyi has subsequently been confirmed in a phylogenetic framework (Jacobsen et al. 2014). Although A. pondolia and A. marleyi are clearly distinct species (Jacobsen et al. 2014), they are morphologically similar and this may result in misidentification of specimens from coastal KwaZulu-Natal Province.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.

The generic placement of this species has changed, initially being placed in Phyllodactylus (Haacke 1996) and thereafter transferred to Afrogecko (Bauer et al. 1997). Phylogenetic analysis has resolved this uncertainty, placing this species in a monotypic genus, Ramigekko (Heinicke et al. 2014). There are no further taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues, although this species is morphologically similar to G. essexi, leading to confusion between the two species.
No taxonomic issues.

The three subspecies of L. nigropunctatus are now considered separate species (Travers et al. 2014). However, the apparently isolated subpopulation in North West Province has not been investigated taxonomically.
No Issues.
No issues.
With the elevation of Lygodactylus ocellatus soutpansbergensis to a full species (Travers et al. 2014), there are no further taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.

Previously thought to occur as two isolated subpopulations (Bates and Branch 2018c), but this conclusion is likely the result of poor sampling in the intervening area rather than a true disjunction, given that the mountainous region is essentially continuous. Recent observations of this species in these intervening areas further supports the notion that the subpopulations may be connected.

Although P. affinis has been shown to be genetically distinct from P. capensis and P. vansoni (Bauer and Lamb 2002), these three species can be difficult to distinguish morphologically (e.g., Jacobsen 1989). There are potentially several cryptic species within this taxon that should be investigated using a phylogenetic framework.
No notable issues.
Although historically considered a subspecies of P. rugosus, with its elevation to full species (Lamb and Bauer 2000a), there are no further taxonomic issues.

Although historically considered a subspecies of P. capensis (Hewitt 1927) and P. rugosus (McLachlan 1979), P. formosus has since been elevated to a full species (Lamb and Bauer 2000b). There are no further taxonomic issues.

Pachydactylus monticolus FitzSimons, 1943 is considered a junior synonym of P. geitje and is in reference to high elevation subpopulations (McLachlan in Branch 1981, Branch et al. 1988, Branch and Bauer 1995). Recent phylogenetic analyses suggest that there are divergent clades that may represent cryptic species (Skinner 2016).
Historical literature records of P. namaquensis from the Western Cape and southern Northern Cape provinces are almost certainly referable to P. kladaroderma.
No taxonomic issues, although there has been some confusion with P. latirostris where their distributions overlap (da Silva et al. 2019).
There are no taxonomic issues at present. Where P. namaquensis and P. haackei are sympatric (in the Richtersveld area), there might be confusion in the assignment of records.
Pachydactylus oculatus is sometimes confused with its sister species, P. maculatus, and records from their area of sympatry on the Great Escarpment of South Africa require verification.

There is some geographic variation in body size, where individuals from inland areas are smaller than those from the western areas (Bauer et al. 2006b), and their status should be re-assessed using a phylogenetic approach.

The taxonomic status of the Chirindia langi species complex should be re-assessed, preferably by using a combination of morphological and phylogenetic analyses, to determine whether the subspecies C. l. occidentalis is a valid taxon.

The three “forms” of M. capensis capensis and the subspecies M. c. rhodesianus were elevated to full species based on morphology (Broadley 1997) but this has not yet been examined in a phylogenetic framework (see Measey and Tolley 2013).

Two subspecies were previously recognized, Meroles knoxii knoxii from south of the Orange River in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa and M. k. pequensis from north of the Orange River in Namibia based on slight differences in scalation, body size and egg clutch size (Branch 1998). However, these differences more likely reflect a morphological cline and geographic variation in life history within the species, as a contemporary study detected only population level structure across the range of this species (Strauss 2016).
A molecular phylogeny of the genus shows deep divergence within the species which could indicate cryptic diversity (see Branch et al. 2019b).
Records from the west coast of South Africa previously assigned to this taxon have been re-assigned to N. tessellata (Conradie et al. 2020), and thus there are no outstanding taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No notable issues.

There is substantial geographic variation within T. essexi with regards to the number of femoral pores, colour pattern and mitochondrial DNA sequences that could represent cryptic taxa (MJ Cunningham unpubl. data 2014).
No notable issues.

The currently recognised subspecies (Tropidosaura montana montana, T. m. rangeri and T. m. natalensis) do not show strong morphological or genetic differences (see Edwards et al. 2012, Engleder et al. 2013), suggesting they should be treated as a single taxon.
No notable issues.
No notable issues.

Although not formally elevated, A. atra knobeli from Namibia has been treated as a full species (Matthee and Flemming 2002, Swart et al. 2009). Subsequent phylogenetic studies show that A. knobeli is not valid (see Nielsen 2016), and it therefore must be treated as a junior synonym of A. atra. Agama atra can be confused with Agama anchietae, possibly resulting in incorrect distribution mapping in some areas of the Northern Cape Province where they presumably co-occur.

There is considerable variation in colour pattern (Branch 1998), habits and behaviour across the range of this species. This is accompanied by genetic divergence (Kelly et al. 2011) which suggests that there may be more than one taxon within this species.

Recent phylogenetic analyses suggest that B. albanica, B. armata, B. inornata and B. rubida are within a closely related species complex (Barlow et al. 2019) and the relationships between these taxa are worthy of further investigation.

A recent phylogenetic study suggests that B. albanica, B. armata, B. inornata and B. rubida form a closely related species complex (Barlow et al. 2019) and the relationships between these taxa is worthy of further investigation. In addition, the taxonomic status of an isolated subpopulation near Langebaan should be investigated.

A phylogenetic analysis of the genus shows that B. rubida is paraphyletic with regards to B. inornata and B. albanica (Barlow et al. 2019) and the relationships between these taxa is worthy of further investigation.
There is an isolated subpopulation in eastern Zimbabwe that could potentially represent a separate taxon.
Can be confused with Bradypodion gutturale (Tolley and Burger 2007).

There is an isolated population of a similar species at Grootvadersbosch forest, 150 km west of B. damaranum (Tolley and Burger 2007). Although morphologically similar in appearance, a phylogenetic analysis shows that they are separate taxa (Tolley et al. 2006). The Grootvadersbosch population requires formal description.
There are no taxonomic issues, but considerable morphological variation exists across the distribution of this species (Tolley and Burger 2007) and this can cause confusion for identifications.

Although there are no notable taxonomic issues (Tolley et al. 2004; 2006, Tolley and Burger 2007), this species is sometimes confused with Bradypodion caffer, which occurs further north along the coastline.

This species is part of a larger species complex (including Bradypodion melanocephalum and B. thamnobates) in which genetic differentiation is low but obvious morphological differences exist (da Silva and Tolley 2013, 2017).
No notable issues.
There are no major taxonomic issues, although a contact zone may exist between Bradypodion occidentale and B. pumilum and this could potentially result in hybridisation.

Genetic studies show that there are at least two ecomorphs of B. pumilum, a colourful ornate form that inhabits the western side of the range across Cape Town and environs, and an inornate form that is found in the eastern portion of the range and inhabits fynbos vegetation of the Cape Fold Mountains (Tolley et al. 2006, Tolley et al. 2019b).

Tetradactylus laevicauda (Hewitt 1915) was described from the KwaZulu-Natal Drakensberg region of South Africa but has been treated as a subspecies (FitzSimons 1943) and a junior synonym (Branch 1990b) of T. seps. Current distribution records show a large geographic gap in the Eastern Cape Province, which was thought to indicate subpopulations in the Cape area and KwaZulu-Natal Province. Preliminary phylogenetic analyses suggest that there are no notable genetic differences between the Western Cape, Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal subpopulations. However, there appears to be some genetic structure within the southern subpopulation (KA Tolley and W Conradie unpubl. data 2020).

Tetradactylus bilineatus has been treated as a subspecies (Loveridge 1942, FitzSimons 1943) and as a junior synonym (Branch 1990b) of T. tetradactylus. A preliminary phylogeny suggests that T. bilineatus from along the Great Escarpment and eastern Karoo is genetically differentiated at the species level (W Conradie unpubl. data 2020).
No taxonomic issues.

Phylogenetic analyses show shallow divergence between A. tristis, A. grayi, A. lineatus and A. litoralis (Daniels et al. 2006, Lamb et al. 2010) as well as paraphyly between these taxa (Janse van Vuuren 2009). Furthermore, there are no clear, diagnostic morphological differences among taxa (but see Broadley and Greer 1969), and there are some limited areas of sympatry. This has cast some doubt as to the current taxonomic arrangement.

Acontias meleagris, A. orientalis and A. lineicauda have complex taxonomic histories (Broadley and Greer 1969, Daniels et al. 2002, 2005, 2006, 2009), having been treated as subspecies of A. meleagris and subsequently as full species (Lamb et al. 2010). The taxonomy is still problematic due to confusion around colour morphs that do not correspond to the species level phylogenetic results, paraphyly of A. meleagris (Engelbrecht et al. 2013) and a lack of topotypic material for A. lineicauda (from Dunbrody, Hewitt 1937b). In this assessment, the taxonomy recommended by Engelbrecht et al. (2013) has been followed. There is a potential contact zone between A. meleagris and A. orientalis in the Breede River Valley (Engelbrecht et al. 2013). Records from the eastern parts of the Western Cape and the Eastern Cape provinces are now referred to Acontias orientalis (Fig. 5 in Engelbrecht et al. 2013).

Phylogenetic analyses show shallow divergence between A. tristis, A. grayi, A. lineatus and A. litoralis (Daniels et al. 2006, Lamb et al. 2010) as well as paraphyly between these taxa (Janse van Vuuren 2009). Furthermore, there are no clear, diagnostic morphological differences among taxa (but see Broadley and Greer 1969), and there are some limited areas of sympatry. This has cast some doubt as to the current taxonomic arrangement.
