Acontias meleagris, A. orientalis and A. lineicauda have complex taxonomic histories (Broadley and Greer 1969, Daniels et al. 2002, 2005, 2006, 2009), having been treated as subspecies of A. meleagris and subsequently as full species (Lamb et al. 2010). The taxonomy is still problematic due to confusion around colour morphs that do not correspond to the species level phylogenetic results, paraphyly of A. meleagris (Engelbrecht et al. 2013) and a lack of topotypic material for A. lineicauda (from Dunbrody, Hewitt 1937b). Acontias percivali tasmani is not distinct from A. orientalis, showing low genetic divergence and near complete overlap in morphological characters (Broadley and Greer 1969, Lamb et al. 2010) although they differ in colour. In this assessment, the taxonomy recommended by Engelbrecht et al. (2013) has been followed.
No taxonomic issues.

The historical records of this species in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa (Bauer 2014a) are referable to A. occidentalis (Busschau et al. 2017). A potential record from the Swartberg Pass in the Western Cape Province (Bauer 2014a) is referable to the Acontias meleagris group (W Conradie pers. obs. June 2017).

Acontias lineicauda, A. orientalis and A. meleagris have complex taxonomic histories (Broadley and Greer 1969, Daniels et al. 2002, 2005, 2006, 2009), having been treated as subspecies of A. meleagris and subsequently as full species (Lamb et al. 2010). The taxonomy is still problematic due to confusion around colour morphs that do not correspond to the species level phylogenetic results, paraphyly of A. meleagris (Engelbrecht et al. 2013) and a lack of topotypic material for A. lineicauda (from Dunbrody, Hewitt 1937b).

Phylogenetic analyses show shallow divergence between A. tristis, A. grayi, A. lineatus and A. litoralis (Daniels et al. 2006, Lamb et al. 2010) as well as paraphyly between these taxa (Janse van Vuuren 2009). Furthermore, there are no clear, diagnostic morphological differences among taxa (but see Broadley and Greer 1969), and there are some limited areas of sympatry. This has cast some doubt as to the current taxonomic arrangement.
No taxonomic issues.
No notable issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No issues.
No notable issues.
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomic issues.

There has been confusion regarding the identity of this species in the past. Raw (1973) assigned specimens from the KwaZulu-Natal Midlands to S. guentheri, but these specimens were later described as S. bourquini (Broadley 1994). Because S. guentheri is known from only a single specimen, its taxonomic status remains uncertain, although most authors consider it valid (e.g., FitzSimons 1943, Broadley 1994, Branch 1998). However, the differences between this species and S. bourquini are minor (the presence of a slightly higher ventral scale count, a postnasal scale and the absence of preanal pores) but this is difficult to assess based on a single specimen.
Morphological variation within this species suggests that there could be cryptic species (Marais and Bauer 2014a).
No notable issues. Records from Vernon Crookes Nature Reserve and Durban are probably incorrectly identified or represent undescribed species (Broadley 1994).
This species was last reviewed by Broadley (1994) and there are no outstanding issues.

Although relatively high genetic divergence between Scelotes montispectus and the related S. kasneri has been recorded (Bauer et al. 2003), there is not strong phylogenetic support for species level differences (Heideman et al. 2011). Regardless, S. montispectus is currently considered distinct from S. kasneri based on small morphological differences and geographical separation (Heideman et al. 2011).

This species forms part of the Leptotyphlops scutifrons species complex (Broadley and Wallach 2007). The taxonomy of several species in the genus is in question (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009) as there is species level diversity within described taxa as well as paraphyly of some currently recognised species.

Leptotyphlops nigricans was restricted to the two southern Cape provinces (Broadley and Broadley 1999), but subsequent phylogenetic analyses showed deep genetic divergence between the Western Cape Province and Eastern Cape Province subpopulations that may indicate separate species (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009). The area of separation between the putative species is unknown as the distribution of L. nigricans is currently thought to be continuous (Broadley and Broadley 1999).

Broadley and Broadley (1999) recorded Leptotyphlops sylvicolus from three isolated subpopulations in forest habitats on the east coast of South Africa. Recent records from grassland habitat in the former Transkei, South Africa, are of specimens that do not fully conform to the morphology of this species, and the deep genetic divergence within this species complex (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009, Busschau et al. 2021) indicates the presence of a number of undescribed species that may have more restricted ranges and may be of significant conservation concern.
The taxonomic validity of this species and its relationship to other populations in the Leptotyphlops scutifrons/conjunctus complex requires further study.
Although there is colour polymorphism across the range, this does not appear to reflect species level differentiation (see Kelly et al. 2008).
No issues.
No notable issues.

The Zimbabwean subpopulation is geographically isolated from the nearest South African subpopulation and there is substantial genetic divergence between these subpopulations (Kelly et al. 2009). Subpopulations may also exist within South Africa (south-western and eastern) but this has not been investigated in a phylogenetic context.
No taxonomic issues.
Zaher et al. (2019) placed P. sundevallii in the newly erected family Prosymnidae. No taxonomic issues.
The relationship between the isolated subpopulations should be investigated in a phylogenetic framework.
A phylogenetic analysis would be helpful to assess the taxonomic status of the isolated subpopulation of C. macrolepis in the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe.
The taxonomic status of  forms in the Cordylus minor species complex (Mouton and Van Wyk 1994), to which C. cloetei belongs, are being re-evaluated using molecular techniques (Bates et al. in prep.).

A phylogenetic analysis revealed that Cordylus tasmani is paraphyletic with C. cordylus and it is therefore treated as a junior synonym of C. cordylus (Stanley et al. 2011). Although a phylogeographic study showed there are two clades (south-western Cape and another covering the rest of the distribution), the divergence between these clades is not at the species level (Diedericks et al. 2013). There are no other outstanding taxonomic issues.

The taxonomic status of forms in the Cordylus minor species complex (Mouton and van Wyk 1994), to which C. imkeae belongs, have not yet been evaluated within a phylogenetic framework, but this species appears to be valid (Tolley et al. In review). However, there have not been any taxonomic issues with C. imkeae noted to date.

There is a large geographic gap between each of the three subpopulations, particularly for the northernmost subpopulation. A phylogenetic study would reveal the relationship between these populations.
Cordylus aridus and C. cloetei have been synonymised with C. minor (Tolley et al. 2021).
A phylogenetic analysis (Daniels et al. 2004) suggests that there is cryptic diversity, possibly at the species level, within Cordylus niger.
The populations occurring at Dasklip Pass, Landdroskop and Piketberg appear to be genetically distinct at the species level (Daniels et al. 2004, Stanley et al. 2011) and merit further investigation.
There is genetic and morphological structure within C. vittifer that could represent at least three species (de Waal 1978, Stanley et al. 2011).

Loveridge (1944) recognised two species, Pseudocordylus [Hemicordylus] capensis and P. [H.] robertsi (van Dam 1921) based on morphological differences, while Branch (1981) treated these as subspecies of P. [H.] capensis. The subspecies are no longer considered valid (Herselman et al. 1992). A subsequent phylogenetic analysis suggested that there are multiple divergent clades within Hemicordylus capensis that may represent cryptic species (Mabe 2009).

There are no taxonomic issues. However, because the distribution overlaps with the congener H. capensis which is morphologically similar, there could be a number of misidentifications in the existing records.

The melanistic subpopulation in the Saldanha-Langebaan area was suspected to be a separate species (Mouton et al. 2002), but phylogenetic analyses do not support that assumption (Engelbrecht et al. 2011, Stanley et al. 2011).
Previously included in the genus Cordylus (Stanley et al. 2011), but with the erection of the genus Namazonurus, there are no remaining taxonomic issues.
Previously within the genus Cordylus (Stanley et al. 2011), but with the erection of the genus Namazonurus, there are no remaining taxonomic issues.

Previously within the genus Cordylus but with the erection of the genus Ninurta (Stanley et al. 2011), the remaining taxonomic issue concerns the subpopulation in the Langeberg Mountains. There are distinct morphological differences between lizards from this subpopulation and the main subpopulation to the east.
No notable issues.
This species is sympatric with P. minor, but they are morphologically and genetically distinguishable (M. Whiting unpubl. data 2020). While sympatric, they are usually not syntopic (Jacobsen 1989).
No notable issues.

This species is sympatric with P. guttatus, but they are morphologically and genetically distinguishable (M. Whiting unpubl. data 2020). While sympatric, they are usually not syntopic (Jacobsen 1989).
No notable issues.
The genus Platysaurus requires taxonomic revision and a phylogenetic analysis should help resolve the status of the two subspecies, P. orientalis orientalis and P. o. fitzsimonsi.

Genetic and morphological data suggest that there are species-level differences between P. m. melanotus and P. m. subviridis and possibly within Pseudocordylus melanotus melanotus (Bates 2007b). A multi-locus phylogeny also shows that the subspecies of P. melanotus are paraphyletic, with P. m. subviridis falling in the P. spinosus clade, rather than the P. melanotus melanotus clade (Stanley et al. 2011).

Although there are some morphological features unique to each subspecies (FitzSimons 1943, Bates 2005b), their taxonomic status is uncertain. In the east of the distribution, P. microlepidotus may be parapatric with P. melanotus subviridis (Bates 2014c) and this could cause confusion with identifications.

Based on morphological and phylogenetic analyses, Pseudocordylus transvaalensis was found to be a valid species rather than a subspecies of P. melanotus (Jacobsen 1989, Bates 2005b, 2007b, Stanley et al. 2011). The three allopatric populations differ morphologically (Bates 2007b), but it is not possible to assess if they are differentiated genetically due to incomplete sampling (see Bates 2007b, Stanley et al. 2011).
All former subspecies of Smaug warreni have been raised to full species (Bates and Stanley 2020).
Previously a subspecies of S. warreni, but with its elevation to a full species (Stanley and Bates 2014), there are no further taxonomic issues.
Previously a subspecies of S. warreni, but elevated and split into two species – S. barbertonensis and S. swazicus (Bates and Stanley 2020).
The isolated western records attributed to both this species and S. vandami by Jacobsen (1989) and Mouton (2014b) are in fact referable only to Smaug breyeri (Stanley and Bates 2014).
The isolated western records attributed to this species by Jacobsen (1989) and Mouton (2014b) are in fact referable only to Smaug breyeri (Stanley and Bates 2014).

Some authors have treated P. amoenus as a subspecies of P. mariquensis (e.g., Kluge 2001), but the species status has been confirmed based on molecular phylogenetics and morphology (Bauer et al. 2011).

Although the taxonomic history of this species has been unstable, it was confirmed as a valid species (Bauer et al. 2011). There appears to be some confusion with P. mariquensis in the south of the range, and the diagnostic morphological features used to identify these species are unclear (da Silva et al. 2019).

The subspecies Tetradactylus a. fitzsimonsi and T. a. africanus (FitzSimons 1943, Branch 1998) were informally treated as full species due to morphological differences (Bates et al. 2014). New records from Hluleka Nature Reserve, Haga-Haga, Lubanzi and Mazeppa Bay in the Eastern Cape Province are referable to T. fitzsimonsi (Venter and Conradie 2015, http://vmus.adu.org.za; https://www.inaturalist.org/).
There is an isolated subpopulation in south-central Namibia, separated from the main distribution by about 500 km.

There are several previously recognised subspecies (T. h. depressa, T. h. peringueyi, T. h. smithi), and of those, T. depressa Peters 1854 has been reinstated as a full species (Branch 1998, Broadley 2000). A phylogenetic analysis revealed some genetic differences within T. homalocephala for subpopulations along the west coast of South Africa (Weinell et al. 2019) and these are possibly referable to the subspecies T. h. homalocephala (southwest coast) and T. homalocephala peringueyi (central-west coast).

The subspecies Tetradactylus a. africanus and T. africanus fitzsimonsi (FitzSimons 1943, Branch 1998) were informally treated as full species due to morphological differences (Bates et al. 2014). The identity of a T. africanus specimen collected in 1919 from Witsieshoek (or Witzies Hoek) in the Drakensberg Mountains at 1,800 m a.s.l. was confirmed by Bates (1992), but no additional specimens have been collected within 200 km of this site, or in similar high elevation habitat (e.g., de Waal 1978, Bourquin 2004), so this record is viewed with scepticism.
No taxonomic issues.

Schmidtler (1997) raised the subspecies budaki, chernovi, and rueppellii to full species status, thus restricting Ablepharus kitaibelii to southeastern Europe and west and central Turkey. However, the taxonomy of this species is currently under review (P. Lymberakis pers. comm.). Ljubisvljevic et al. (2002) examined geographic variation in parts of the Balkan peninsula. Poulakakis et al. (2005) showed that A. kitaibelii is not monophyletic, and that the population on the Kastelorizo Island group (Greece, off the Lycian coast of southwestern Turkey) is particularly distinct and deserves specific status. The remaining populations of A. kitaibelii consist of two clades, one comprising the populations inhabiting continental Greece and the west Aegean (Cyclades and Kithira) and Ionian (Leukada) islands, and the other comprising populations that inhabit the East Aegean islands (including ?Crete?) and Turkey.

A recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors (e.g., Leviton et al. 2014, Lillywhite et al. 2014, Rasmussen et al. 2014, Ukuwela et al. 2014, D'Anastasi et al. 2016, Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2016, Udyawer et al. 2015, Mirtschin et al. 2017).

A distinctive new subspecies of sea snake from inner-basin waters of Golfo Dulce, Costa Rica has been described (Bessesen and Galbreath 2017). The Yellow sea snake, Hydrophis platurus ssp. xanthos Bessesen & Galbreath, 2017 is diagnosed by a notably smaller body size and nearly uniform yellow colouration, which contrasts with the black and yellow striae and tail spots or bands typical of the species (Bessesen and Galbreath 2017).
A taxonomic review and molecular phylogeny found that Homopholis wahlbergii arnoldi is a valid species (Broadley et al. 2014). There are no other outstanding taxonomic issues.

A recent phylogenetic analysis demonstrated that P. goodi is a junior synonym of P. atorquatus (Šmíd et al. 2018). These two taxa were described as separate species based on colouration pattern, but it now appears that it is a single species that contains multiple colour morphs.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy was largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises, while synonymizing the four central and southern Isabela Island populations (vicina, guntheri, microphyes, and vandenburghi) under C. vicina. However, TTWG (2017) and this Red List assessment now treat these four Isabela Island taxa, previously treated as subspecies of vicina, as separate and valid species, rather than retaining their previous rankings.

The taxonomy of the C. vicina species complex remains less resolved than for other Galápagos taxa, with four taxa on central (microphyes, vandenburghi) and southern (guntheri, vicina) Isabela treated here as a series of four recognized species. These most recently diverged lineages may not have been completely sorted into reciprocally monophyletic clades in terms of mitochondrial DNA data, although their nuclear gene pools are distinct (Ciofi et al. 2006, Poulakakis et al. 2008, Edwards et al. 2014). They may possibly represent subspecies or Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) rather than full species (Edwards et al. 2014). TTWG (2009, 2014), following Pritchard (1996), synonymized these four taxa under C. vicina, but in consideration of the majority of the assessors’ view that they may be full species, TTWG (2017) and the Red List now treats them as separate species.

Tortoises from southern Isabela Island have also been referred to as C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) vicina for the southwestern Cerro Azul population and C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) guentheri or C. (n.) guntheri for the southeastern Sierra Negra subpopulation. The guentheri and guntheri names have previously either been considered nomina dubia and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology. Tortoises from Darwin Volcano on north central Isabela have historically been recognized as C. (n.) microphyes, a name that has previously been considered either a nomen dubium and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology (review by Pritchard 1996). Tortoises from Alcedo Volcano on central Isabela have traditionally been recognized as C. (n.) vandenburghi, but were previously synonymized under C. (n.) vicina based on morphology (Pritchard 1996; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2009, 2014).

All these taxa have in the past variously been argued to be valid at species or subspecies level (under either elephantopus and/or nigra), and placed in the genera Testudo, Geochelone, or Chelonoidis, and these permutations, plus a variety of typographic errors, have yielded over 50 nomenclatural combinations and chresonyms.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy was largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises, while synonymizing the four central and southern Isabela Island populations (vicina, guntheri, microphyes, and vandenburghi) under C. vicina. However, TTWG (2017) and this Red List assessment now treat these four Isabela Island taxa, previously treated as subspecies of vicina, as separate and valid species, rather than retaining their previous rankings.

The taxonomy of the C. vicina species complex remains less resolved than for other Galápagos taxa, with four taxa on central (microphyes, vandenburghi) and southern (guntheri, vicina) Isabela treated here as a series of four recognized species. These most recently diverged lineages may not have been completely sorted into reciprocally monophyletic clades in terms of mitochondrial DNA data, although their nuclear gene pools are distinct (Ciofi et al. 2006, Poulakakis et al. 2008, Edwards et al. 2014). They may possibly represent subspecies or Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) rather than full species (Edwards et al. 2014). TTWG (2009, 2014), following Pritchard (1996), synonymized these four taxa under C. vicina, but in consideration of the majority of the assessors’ view that they may be full species, TTWG (2017) and the Red List now treats them as separate species.

Tortoises from southern Isabela Island have also been referred to as C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) vicina for the southwestern Cerro Azul population and C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) guentheri or C. (n.) guntheri for the southeastern Sierra Negra subpopulation. The guentheri and guntheri names have previously either been considered nomina dubia and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology. Tortoises from Darwin Volcano on north central Isabela have historically been recognized as C. (n.) microphyes, a name that has previously been considered either a nomen dubium and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology (review by Pritchard 1996). Tortoises from Alcedo Volcano on central Isabela have traditionally been recognized as C. (n.) vandenburghi, but were previously synonymized under C. (n.) vicina based on morphology (Pritchard 1996; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2009, 2014).

All these taxa have in the past variously been argued to be valid at species or subspecies level (under either elephantopus and/or nigra), and placed in the genera Testudo, Geochelone, or Chelonoidis, and these permutations, plus a variety of typographic errors, have yielded over 50 nomenclatural combinations and chresonyms.
With the description of the northern population of Platysaurus capensis as a new species, P. attenboroughi (Whiting et al. 2015), there are no further outstanding taxonomic issues.

This species' taxonomic status is unclear: it was synonymized within Typhlops platycephalus without comment by Boulenger (1893) but this scheme appears to have been followed inconsistently and this species has been considered "a valid species in the ruficaudus" group by Uetz et al. (2019). Although no formal revision has been published, it is referred to as a valid name without further comment in recent taxonomic literature on blindsnakes without discussion (Hedges et al. 2014, Pyron and Wallach 2014).

The validity of this species is unclear, and it is not recognized by Pyron and Wallach (2014)\, but is treated as valid here following Uetz et al. (2019). The complete absence of any information on this species' distribution makes the appropriate generic identity uncertain; the assignment to Indotyphlops is based on morphological similarity but no evidence of an Asian origin exists.

The former subspecies Glaphyromorphus crassicaudus arnhemicus (Storr, 1967) is now regarded as a full species by some authors (Greer 1989, Reeder 2003), but retained as a subspecies by Wilson and Swan (2013), although Greer (1989) found that arnhemicus was not the sister taxon to crassicaudus. It is not recognized by Cogger et al. (2014), who does not comment on this omission. G. Shea (pers. comm. 2017) considers it a valid species based on discrete morphology and distribution. Additionally, taxonomic issues may exist with Queensland populations as multiple species may be present under the name G. crassicaudus (P. Couper pers. comm. 2017). This account treats G. arnhemicus as a distinct taxon following Greer (1989), as future taxonomic changes within G. crassicaudatus will not impact the strongly allopatric G. arnhemicus (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).

Chilabothrus argentum is a recently discovered species (Reynolds et al. 2016), unknown until July 2015. Species description was based on genetic and morphological analysis of six specimens, in the context of other Bahamian and West Indian boas. This species is divergent from other West Indian boas at an mtDNA locus and is readily distinguishable based on morphometric and morphological characteristics.

This species is known from the Cook Strait and the Coromandel Peninsula; genetic divergence and minor morphological differences suggest that more than one taxon my be included under the name Toropuku stephensi (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019).

Chapple et al. (2008) revised Oligosoma olivieri, describing the new species O. townsi. Jewell (2019) subsequently resurrected the name Leiolopisma pachysomaticum (as Oligosoma pachysomaticum) for a morphologically distinct group of populations, restricting O. olivieri to Poor Knights. Although this split has been "widely welcomed" within the New Zealand herpetological community (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019) it is not supported by genetic evidence previously presented by Chapple et al. (2008), which suggests that the new concept of O. polysomaticum is not monophyletic, and this assessment regards O. pachysomaticum as a junior synonym of O. olivieri following Chapple et al. (2008). Further research is, however, likely to be warranted to resolve the relationships between the island populations (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019).

Recent genetic evidence suggests that the east and west populations of this species diverged in the Miocene (Chapple et al. 2012). While this is not thought to have taxonomic implications, this finding indicates that the two populations should continue to be treated as separate management units and needs to be accounted for in captive breeding programs (Chapple et al. 2012).
Named after Sir Robert Falla (1901–1979), a prominent New Zealand naturalist (Gill and Whitaker 2001).

The taxonomy of Oligosoma infrapunctatum has until recently not been studied in detail, although multiple undescribed species have been informally recognized from within the complex (discussed in Melzer et al. 2019). Uncertainty surrounds the identity of 'true' O. infrapunctatum, whose type locality is unknown: an assumption that this was Stephens Island (Takapourewa) (McCann 1955) is now considered to be in error, as the species known from this island is not conspecific with the O. infrapunctatum holotype (Melzer et al. 2019). These authors combined morphological evidence with a previous molecular phylogeny of the species complex to revise the taxonomy of this group.
This is a recognized species complex; as presently defined a northern and southern clade are recognized as distinct (Whitaker et al. 2018).

Three genetic groups were identified within Sphenodon by Daugherty et al. (1990) based on allozyme data. These authors proposed a two-species scheme, revalidating S. guntheri for the clade from the North Brother Island population, that was subsequently adopted in New Zealand's conservation policy. More recent research (Hay et al. 2010 and references therein) incorporating mitochondrial and nuclear DNA does not support this arrangement. Hay et al. (2010) consequently favoured treating all extant tuatara populations as a single species, S. punctatus.

The name Woodworthia brunnea (sometimes, incorrectly, W. brunneus) has been used informally to refer to a species recognized as distinct from Dactylocnemis pacificus and from Woodworthia maculata, for which the name Pentadactylus brunneus is thought to be available (Jewell 2008). This action was taken without providing the taxonomic justification for associating the new taxon with the P. brunneus holotype. Nielsen et al. (2011) describe the content of Woodworthia as including W. brunnea, but do not comment on this assignment and elsewhere refer to samples of this species as Hoplodactylus cf. brunneus. Subsequently Hitchmough et al. (2016) used the form Woodworthia cf. brunnea to refer to this taxon, and this usage is preferred pending a formal examination of the appropriate nomenclature (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019).

The formally recognized species concept for Woodworthia maculata represents a known species complex, containing between 9 and 12 identified lineages recognized as distinct at the species level but not yet formally described (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019). These taxa are now generally excluded from W. maculata by workers within New Zealand and this assessment adopts a reduced concept, considered to represent W. maculata sensu stricto, following this usage and van Winkel et al. (2018).

authority: Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson 2011

taxonomicNotes: Work is underway to clarify the systematics of this species complex (R. Hitchmough and D. van Winkel pers. comm. 2019).

Five major geographic clades have been identified within Oligosoma polychroma (Liggins et al. 2008), and these are likely to be elevated to specific status in future (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019). Hitchmough et al. (2016) treated these taxa separately in their conservation assessment, but all are included within O. polychroma for the purposes of this assessment pending a formal taxonomic revision.

authority: Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Western and northern populations of this species are likely to be recognized as belonging to a separate species in future (R. Hitchmough pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson, 2011
Chapple, Bell, Chapple, Miller, Daugherty & Patterson, 2011

taxonomicNotes: The newly discoverd subpopulations at Mount Sanga and Chitagal (Jones et al. 2017) need phylogenetic validation.

Molecular analyses consistently placed Angolosaurus within Gerrhosaurus, rendering the latter genus paraphyletic (Lamb et al. 2003). As a consequence, Angolosaurus should be considered a synonym of Gerrhosaurus.

This species was initially described as the type species (by monotypy) of the genus Palmatogecko Andersson, 1908. Immunological comparisons with other African geckos suggested, however, that the species was a highly derived Pachydactylus (Joger 1985). The close relationship of this species to Pachydactylus austeni was confirmed by DNA-based phylogenetic analysis (Bauer and Lamb 2005, Lamb and Bauer 2006). The genus Palmatogecko was formally synonymised with Pachydactylus by Bauer and Lamb (2005).
Accepted as Nadzikambia baylissi in Branch & Tolley (2010). No notable taxonomic issues.

The taxonomy of the genus Cryptoblepharus is controversial and cannot be considered stable despite recent reviews by Rocha et al. (2006) and Horner (2007). Based on the results of their mitochondrial sequence analysis, Rocha et al. (2006) concluded that the subspecific assignments of the Western Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus are the most appropriate. By contrast, Horner (2007) used morphological characteristics from a small sample to elevate C. boutonii africanus to species status, and recognized it as distinct from its former synonym C. ahli. The taxonomy of Horner (2007) is followed in this assessment, in keeping with the adoption of a general evolutionary species paradigm in South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. It is however the case that the species divisions in allopatric, highly mobile populations, such as those of the C. boutonii species complex, is controversial.

Molecular studies (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009) indicate deep genetic divergence between many leptotyphlopid species. Members of the Leptotyphlops rostratus group (sensu Broadley and Broadley 1999, i.e. L. rostratus, L. occidentalis, L. gracilior, L. labialis, L. latifrons) have been placed in the new genus Namibiana.

Vences et al. (2004) confirmed the validity of Hemidactylus mercatorius as a species distinct from H. mabouia, with which it had previously been confused, considering that it represented mainland African and Madagascan members of this species complex. Uncertainty over the exact definitions of these two species, and potential confusion with additional species of Hemidactylus, remain, making it difficult to establish the global distribution of either H. mercatorius or H. mabouia. Vences et al. (2004) found that Madagascan H. mercatorius were genetically distinct from a sample from Mozambique. Within Madagascan H. mercatorius, at least three distinct lineages appear to exist (Vences et al. 2004, Boumans et al. 2007). Rocha et al. (2005) found that Gulf of Guinea "H. mabouia" identified by Jesus et al. (2005) belonged to the northern Madagascar lineage of H. mercatorius identified by Vences et al. (2004). This concept of H. mercatorius as a widespread island species appears to correspond to Clade A of "H. mabouia" identified by Rocha et al. (2010), which is also found in Tanzania, South Africa (where three separate lineages have been identified), Uganda and the Seychelles, including a lineage endemic to the Aldabra archipelago. However, given the apparent basal relationships of mainland African members of this clade and continuing uncertainty over their taxonomic assignment, this assessment follows Rocha et al. (2010) in restricting the name H. mercatorius to island populations within this clade, with continental populations remaining under the name H. mabouia until the taxonomy of this species complex is resolved. As of 2020 work to understand the systematics of this complex are ongoing; current evidence from the Seychelles suggests that an ancient native lineage occurs in Aldabra but that the population from Mahé represents the widespread African island species and - as suggested by Rocha et al. (2010) - is an introduction on this island.
The status of the Angolan population in relation to conspecifics elsewhere requires further investigation (Marques et al. 2018)

Spawls et al. (2002) followed FitzSimons (1963) in considering Lycodonomorphus obscuriventris a subspecies of L. whytii. Rasmussen (2004) subsequently examined the taxonomy of this species in detail, redescribing L. whytii and accepting the opinion of Broadley (1995) that the poorly-diagnosed L. obscuriventris should be treated as a distinct species.  This latter scheme is followed here.
Broadley (1996) synonymized Cryptolycus with Lycophidion.
This is a nomen novum for Prosymna frontalis (Bocage, 1895; pre-occupied).
Two subspecies are recognised, namely Thelotornis capensis capensis and T. c. oatesii.

Previous (Scott et al. 2004) and current (S. Keogh et al. unpubl. data) phylogenetic work suggests that the Platysaurus intermedius complex will undergo significant taxonomic change and potentially some of the subspecies may warrant being raised to full species. For example, a phylogeny (Scott et al. 2004) placed Platysaurus intermedius wilhelmi in a clade with P. lebomboensis, separate from P. i. intermedius. Furthermore, P. i. rhodesianus is in a clade with P. imperator and P. torquatus, rather than with P. i. intermedius and other P. intermedius subspecies, and P. lebomboensis, P. minor, P. monotropis and P. orientalis. In addition, P. i. rhodesianus is widespread, with some populations separated by significant physical barriers (e.g. the Limpopo River) that are expected to constrain gene flow. Also, a number of populations show significant morphological variation, suggesting that P. i. rhodesianus may represent a species complex.

This species has two subspecies: Platysaurus pungweensis pungweensis Broadley, 1959 occurs in the eastern Highlands of Zimbabwe and Mozambique. P. p. blakeii Broadley, 1964 is found on South Manica Platform in central Mozambique.

Earlier molecular phylogenetic results placed Acontias plumbeus with other robust species in a restricted Acontias phylogeny (Daniels et al. 2006). More recent research (Lamb et al. 2010) demonstrates that it is also closely related to skinks formerly placed in Acontophiops and  Typhlosaurus sensu lato. The taxonomic status of isolated subpopulations in the Eastern Cape Province and on the eastern escarpment of Zimbabwe require investigation. Acontias poecilus has been synonymized with A. plumbeus (Zhao et al. 2019).

Specimens from Kibwezi in Kenya were referred to this species by McDiarmid et al.(1999), but in a subsequent detailed taxonomic revision by Broadley and Wallach (2007) the same specimens were identified as Leptotyphlops scutifrons merkeri.

Given the difference in habitat and distance between the two disjunct subpopulations between Luanda and southern subpopulation  more detailed taxonomic revision is needed to confirm their con specificity.

There appears to be confusion between Trachylepis bocagei and other Eastern African striped skinks, particularly T. quinquetaeniata. This may have lead some authors to treat this species as being widespread from Angola to Zambia, Zimbabwe and Malawi.

Branch and Bauer (1995) noted considerable variation in most characters used by FitzSimons (1943) to separate the subspecies C. trivittatus trivittatus and C. t. australis and supported Loveridge's (1942) contention that these taxa are referable to one variable species, namely C. subtessellatus.  Most authors subsequent to FitzSimons (1943) have followed Loveridge's (1942) taxonomy (e.g. Branch 1988, 1998).
Possible sympatry between the Chondrodactylus angulifer namibensis and C. a. angulifer has been noted in the Sperrgebeit (Branch 1994) suggesting that these two subspecies may be valid species.

Monopeltis mauricei was previously considered to be a subspecies of M. sphenorhynchus (Broadley et al. 1976) but was raised to specific status by Broadley (2001). A specimen from Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park in the Northern Cape was tentatively referred to M. spenorhynchus by Bates et al. (2010) but its identification is uncertain.
There is uncertainty about the taxonomic validity of this species. (Bates 2018)

Previously known as Typhlops fornasinii, but placed in the endemic African genus Afrotyphlops by Broadley and Wallach (2009). The taxonomic status of the insular populations off the coast of Mozambique should be investigated using molecular phylogenetics, as should the population in southeastern Zimbabwe.

This species has a complicated taxonomic history. It was initially described as a subspecies of Leptotyphlops conjunctus (Broadley and Watson 1976), which itself has been treated as either a full species or a subspecies of the widespread L. scutifrons. It was raised to species status within the L. scutifrons species complex by Broadley and Broadley (1999). Recent molecular studies (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009) revealed numerous cryptic species within the L. scutifrons/conjunctus complex, including L. incognitus. Further studies, including those using DNA sequences from topotypic material (Mutare, Zimbabwe), are required to assess whether L. incognitus is composite. The current assessment is based on the latest concept of the species (Broadley and Broadley 1999).

Previously considered a subspecies of Naja haje but elevated to species status (as N. annulifera annulifera) by Broadley (1995). Broadley and Wüster (2004) later showed that N. annulifera anchietae was a valid species, rendering N. annulifera monotypic.
There is a need to closely review the existing specimens allocated to this taxon, to better determine the distribution of the species.

Crochet et al. (2008) proposed treating Telescopus obtusus and T. somalicus as subspecies of T. dhara, pending research into the systematics of this poorly-sampled genus although, noting "distinct and constant morphological differences", Geniez (2015) recognized T. obtusus as distinct from T. dhara, and T. somalicus as a subspecies of T. obtusus. Recently, Šmíd et al. (2019) conducted the first full-genus genetic analysis of Telescopus and found "a considerable degree" of variation that justified recognizing T. obtusus as a distinct species, and this arrangement is followed here. High levels of genetic variation in the resulting concepts of both T. obtusus and T. dhara suggests that diversity within this group in both the Arabian Peninsula and the Horn of Africa is likely to be underestimated (Šmíd et al. 2019). The status of T. somalicus remains unresolved as this taxon was not sampled; Šmíd et al. (2019) provisionally retain it as a subspecies of T. dhara, a species not otherwise known from Africa, however, it is unlikely to be referable to or closely-related to T. dhara (J. Šmíd pers. comm. 2019) and so this account follows Geniez (2015) in treating it as a subspecies of T. obtusus.

This taxon was previously included within Trachylepis aurata, as the subspecies T. a. septemtaeniata and T. a. transcaucasica. Following the validation of T. septemtaeniata as a full species (Mausfeld and Schmitz 2003, Moravec et al. 2006) the western range limit of this species in Anatolia (where T. aurata also occurs) is in need of clarification. This account provisionally follows the distribution provided in Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008).

Karin et al. (2016) now place this species in the genus Heremites.
Previously included in the genus Mabuya.  Karin et al. (2016) now place this species in a separate genus Heremites.
This recently described species was previously referable to Goggia rupicola (Branch et al. 1995, Bauer et al. 1997, Heinicke et al. 2017).
There is potentially a contact zone between G. lineata and G. incognita in the north of the distribution around the Knersvlakte that could cause taxonomic confusion and misidentifications.
Genetic data (Nielsen unpubl. data) suggest that Agama knobeli may need to be synonymized with A. atra.
No notable taxonomic issues.

authority: Branch, Guyton, Schmitz, Barej, Naskrecki, Farooq, Verburgt & Rödel, 2017
taxonomicNotes: Broadley (1966) was the first to refer to the Afroedura on Mount Gorongosa under the name Afroedura transvaalica, but did not evaluate the taxonomy of this population. It was subsequently described as a new species by Branch et al. (2017).
The taxonomy of this species is unstable and cryptic diversity occurs and the taxon is under revision (L. Ceríaco pers. comm. 2019).
The biporosus-barnardi complex of the genus Rhoptropus is in need of taxonomic revision.
The biporosus-barnardi complex of the genus Rhoptropus is in need of taxonomic revision.
With the recognition of Rhoptropus diporus, R. bradfieldi is a paraphyletic taxon. Further taxonomic work may justify the recognition of coastal and inland populations as distinct species.

This species was until recently known as Trachylepis angolensis (Monard, 1937). This name is, however, preoccupied by Euprepis angolensis Bocage, 1872 (a neglected name of uncertain identity which, following Boulenger 1887, Marques et al. (2018) provisionally treat as a junior synonym of T. varia). Marques et al. (2018) consequently coined the replacement name Trachylepis monardi. Ongoing taxonomic revisions suggest that T. monardi is likely a junior synonym of T. wahlbergi.

Ongoing taxonomic revision of this species (as of 2019) will likely result in a split into more than one form. Extralimital records ascribed to this species refer to misidentifications or undescribed species.

This species is considered to be a junior synonym of Atheris squamigera by Lawson and Ustach (2000). They argued that one of the diagnostic traits between A. anisolepis and A. squamigera (number of rows of subocular scales) was in fact a sexually dimorphic trait within A. squamigera. However, Chippaux and Jackson (2019) note that other diagnostic morphological characteristics were not addressed by Lawson and Ustach (2000) and continued to recognize A. anisolepis as a valid species.

Sixteen subspecies are currently recognized, but some may warrant elevation to full-species status (Gifford et al. 2004).

P. c.  woodi Cochran, 1934.

P. lineolatus lineolatus Duméril & Bibron, 1839

P. l.  semotus Schwartz, 1966.

P. maynardii maynardii Garman, 1888
P.  maynardii parvinaguae Barbour & Shreve, 1936
P.  maynardii uniformis Noble & Klingel, 1932.
Because this species was recently described, it is sometimes referenced in the literature as Ctenosaura bakeri or Enyaliosaura bakeri, the sister species it was split from.

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus greeri and L. nigrofasciolatus are now placed in the genus Epibator.

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus greeri and L. nigrofasciolatus are now placed in the genus Epibator.
Further studies are necessary to clarify the status of a population from Chapada Diamantina, Minas Gerais, which exhibits different colouration from those elsewhere (A.S. Argôlo pers. comm. 2012).
Populations in the north at Rivière Nehoué and the Kaala massif are genetically divergent and may represent distinct taxa.
This species was regarded as conspecific with Tropidoscincus variabilis when reviewed by Sadlier in 1986 (Bauer and Sadlier 2000).

Low levels of genetic divergence occur between the isolated populations on the northwestern ultramafic massifs and the more continuous population in the south, but these do not warrant taxonomic distinction.

Bauer et al. (2012) in a molecular phylogenetic analysis of the giant geckos found that the few subpopulations of Rhacodactylus trachyrhynchus sampled were strongly divergent from one another and a specimen from Îlot Môrô near the Île des Pins is especially distinctive. This specimen and others examined from Îlot Môrô are morphologically assignable to the species described by Boulenger in 1878 as Chameleonurus trachycephalus (and later treated as a subspecies of R. trachyrhynchus) and is now recognized as a full species (Bauer et al. 2012).
Marked regional variation in colour and pattern indicates historical fragmentation and possible genetic substructuring.

The genetic study (Sadlier 2014) revealed the presence of two clearly differentiated lineages within what has previously been regarded as a single species, Nannoscincus mariei. Although the geographic range of samples available for the genetics study is not as extensive as that represented by museum specimens it is, in combination with morphological data, sufficient to indicate that the samples represent two parapatric taxa: N. mariei Bavay (Mt. Koghis south to the Goro Plateau, including Rivière Bleue), and N. fuscus (the Chaîne Centrale at Mt. Mou, Mt. Dzumac and Mt. Vulcain).

Recent genetic data indicates that populations at Île des Pins and on the islets near there and the east coast of Grande Terre that were earlier assigned to Bavayia crassicollis are not this taxon and that all geckos in the Îles Loyauté that were previously assigned to Bavayia cyclura are in fact Bavayia crassicollis.

There is a moderate level of genetic and morphometric differentiation between the widely disjunct groups of populations in the north and south of the species' range, and there is also a consistent difference in colouration between the population on the Panié massif and Koniambo. In the absence of data on the occurrence of the species between these groups of populations these differences are insufficient for taxonomic distinction.

The population of Kanakysaurus on Dôme de Tiébaghi is genetically very close to Kanakysaurus zebratus yet is morphologically indistinguishable and genetically highly divergent from the K. viviparus with which it is sympatric. Whether this represents a distinct taxon or is the result of mitochondrial introgression awaits further research (Sadlier et al. 2009).
Caledoniscincus cryptos is highly differentiated by genetic characters but is weakly distinguished morphometrically from its congeners.

Three subspecies of Rhacodactylus leachianus have been described: R. l. leachianus (Cuvier, 1829) (Grande Terre); R. l. aubrianus Bocage, 1873; R. l. henkeli Seipp & Obst, 1994 (Ile des Pins and satellite islands); but these are unsupported by genetic data and no longer recognized as valid (Good et al. 1997).

Bavayia robusta is one of the few taxa within the Bavayia cyclura complex that has been formally described. Even so, the distinction between Bavayia robusta s.s. and populations putatively assigned to it from Île des Pins and its satellite islands still requires clarification. The specific status of some individual populations in the extreme southeast of Grande Terre and on Île des Pins is also equivocal.

Recent morphometric and genetic data suggest that, as presently defined, Marmorosphax tricolor sensu (Bavay, 1879) may include several cryptic species some of which have relatively confined distributions. The neotype of Marmorosphax tricolor is from Mount Aoupinié (Sadlier 1986).

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is polyphyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. ciliatus and R. sarasinorum are sister taxa but are not part of the same clade as the other giant geckos hence the generic name Correlophus has been resurrected for them (Bauer et al. 2012).

Populations of Oedodera on the Poum and Kaala massifs are genetically and morphometrically divergent from O. marmorata from Dôme de Tiébaghi. They are treated as potentially distinct taxa under description and hence are not included in this assessment for Oedodera marmorata.

The genetic relationships of a redefined Caledoniscincus atropunctatus (Sadlier 2013) identifies two major subgroups, one located mainly in the northern and central-east regions of Grand Terre and the other in the southern and central-west regions and also including the population on the Loyalty Islands.
The low-elevation specimens (Vavouto) are likely to be another species (on-going studies by A. Bauer and R. Sadlier pers. comm.).

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is not monophyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. chahoua forms a distinct clade separate from Rhacodactylus sensu stricto and hence a new genus, Mniarogekko has been created to accommodate R. chahoua. Genetic data  also shows that the subpopulations in northern Grande Terre and on the Iles Belep are highly distinct and are hence described as a new species M. jalu (Bauer et al. 2012) which is assessed separately.

The population of Kanakysaurus on Dôme de Tiébaghi is genetically very close to Kanakysaurus zebratus yet is morphologically indistinguishable and genetically highly divergent from the K. viviparus with which it is sympatric. Whether this represents a distinct taxon or is the result of mitochondrial  introgression awaits further research (Sadlier et al. 2009).

Recent genetic data show that, as presently defined, Bavayia sauvagii sensu (Boulenger, 1883) comprises a complex of at least nine cryptic species that appear to mostly have relatively confined, allopatric ranges.

Recent genetic data show that, as presently defined, Bavayia cyclura sensu Günther 1872 comprises at least ten cryptic species all of which have relatively confined, largely allopatric ranges. The data also show that material from the Îles Loyauté that was previously assigned to Bavayia cyclura is in fact Bavayia crassicollis.

Genetic research shows that, as presently defined, Caledoniscincus austrocaledonicus sensu (Bavay, 1869) comprises several allopatric cryptic taxa, one of which is confined to the far north of Grande Terre (north of  Koumac) and the islands to the north, including the Iles Belep.

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is polyphyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. ciliatus and R. sarasinorum are sister taxa but are not part of the same clade as the other giant geckos hence the generic name Correlophus has been resurrected for them (Bauer et al. 2012). Genetic substructuring has been detected between the population at Mt Koghis and those in the Prony district but this does not warrant specific distinction.
There is significant genetic divergence between the known populations on Mt Panié and Tchingou.

Recent genetic data shows that, as presently defined, Bavayia montana sensu Roux, 1913 comprises a complex of at least six cryptic species all of which have relatively confined, largely allopatric ranges.

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus maruia and L. tillieri are now placed in the genus Phasmasuarus.

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus maruia and L. tillieri are now placed in the genus Phasmasuarus.

Recent genetic studies have shown the New Caledonian scincid genus Lioscincus to be polyphyletic and that it comprises four distinct evolutionary lineages which should be recognized at generic level (Sadlier et al. 2015). As a result, Lioscincus novaecaledoniae is now placed in its own genus Caesoris.

Amarasinghe et al. (2014) recognized the Knuckles Range population of Calotes liocephalus as the new species Calotes pethiyagodai on morphological grounds. These authors cautioned that little material was available for either this species or C. liocephalus and that further research should be conducted to confirm this arrangement.

authority: Samarawickrama, Ranawana, Rajapaksha, Ananjeva, Orlov, Ranasinghe & Samarawickrama, 2006
taxonomicNotes: There has been considerable controversy over the priority of the names Cophotis dumbara Samarawickrama, Ranawana, Rajapaksha, Ananjeva, Orlov, Ranasinghe & Samarawickrama, 2006 and Cophotis dumbarae Manamendra-Arachchi, de Silva & Amarasinghe, 2006, with both names being published at very close dates. Hallermann and Böhme (2007) reviewed this issue, and determined that Cophotis dumbara (published on November 25, 2006) should take priority over Cophotis dumbarae (published on December 6, 2006). Following an application to the ICZN by the authors of C. dumbarae (considered to have been based on the absence of a reply) this issue now appears to be settled, with C. dumbara accepted as the correct name (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
Melanophidium khairei was described from populations previously understood to represent a northern isolate of Melanophidium punctatum (Gower et al. 2016).
This is believed to be a species complex in need of revision. Populations in Sri Lanka may represent a distinct species endemic to this island (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

Mirza et al. (2010) suggested that the multiple colour morphs then recognized within Cyrtodactytlus collegalensis may indicate that the taxon is a species complex. These authors cautioned that their data was preliminary and subsequent work has been hampered by the scarcity of collections and molecular data (Agarwal et al. 2016). Agarwal et al. (2016) redescribed C. collegalensis, resurrected C. speciosus from its synonymy, and described a third member of this complex, C. varadgirii.
This species was previously synonymized with Cyrtodactylus rubidus (Blyth, 1861) (which is now restricted to the Andaman Islands).
Eublepharis satpuraensis was described from populations previously included within E. hardwickii by Mirza et al. (2014).

Using morphological evidence and recently-obtained sequence data (including material from the type locality), Agarwal et al. (2018) revised Ophisops microlepis, a name that had previously been applied to widespread Indian populations but never systematically reviewed. These authors redescribed this species and described two new species, O. kutchensis and O. pushkarensis, from within this complex.

Lygosoma ashwamedhi was originally described as Riopa ashwamedhi by Sharma in 1969. A molecular phylogentic analysis has confirmed the validity of this species but concluded that it should be transferred to Eutropis (Srinivasulu et al. 2016).
This species was formerly the only member of the genus Balanophis but is now treated under Rhabdophis.

Boiga beddomei was described as Dipsadomorphus beddomei by Wall in 1909 based on specimens from Ceylon (Sri Lanka) (Smith 1943). It has been considered a synonym of Boiga ceylonensis Günther 1858 by Smith (1943) and De Silva (1990). While presently considered valid, with a well-defined species concept, the identity of past locality records is in need of clarification due to confusion within the Boiga ceylonensis/B. beddomei/B. nuchalis/B. andamanensis species group.
This is a complex of more than one species, with taxonomic studies needed to resolve this problem (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
Ganesh and Vogel (2018) synonymized Lycodon osmanhilli within L. anamallensis.
This represents a species complex that needs taxonomic revision (M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).
Batuwita (2019) re-described this species, referring the majority of records to other species.

Hemidactylus pieresii, which had not been recorded since its original description, was synonymized with Hemidactylus depressus by Smith (1935). Following the collection of additional material, Batuwita and Pethiyagoda (2012) determined that H. pieresii represents a validly distinct taxon and redescribed both species. These authors confirmed that Nubilia argentii represents a junior synonym of H. depressus.
It is possible that this species is a misidentified specimen of Hemidactylus brookii (M.S. Khan pers. comm. 2010).
Previously incorrectly thought to be a separate species, Hypnale walli is now treated as junior subjective synonym of Hypnale nepa (Maduwage et al. 2009).

Amarasinghe and Campbell (2016) resolved longstanding confusion surrounding the identity of the holotype of Cnemaspis podihuna and fixed the type locality. These authors' redescription of the holotype it did not discuss the broader distribution of this taxon, which has also been controversial. The most recent characterization of this species' distribution (Batuwita and Udagampala 2017) is followed here, but beyond describing a new species (Cnemaspis kandambyi) previously confused with it and providing a distribution map, these authors did not discuss taxonomic problems with C. podihuna in detail. Ongoing molecular and morphological research indicates that C. podihuna is likely to be a species complex, and that C. podihuna sensu stricto is likely to have a much more restricted range than presently recognized (S. Karunarathna and S. Kannishka pers. comm. 2019).

Two morphological variants of this species were found at Knuckles and molecular and alpha taxonomy is in progress (A. de Silva pers. comm). Molecular phylogenetic data reveal that Geckoella is embedded within Cyrtodactylus, and this placement is now widely accepted and hence followed here.

In a morphological review of Lankascincus, Batuwita (2019) found that characters described as being diagnostic for L. munindradasai could not reliably distinguish it from the similar L. taprobanensis. This author consequently synonymized L. munindradasai with L. taprobanensis on both morphological and biogeographic grounds.
This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. Two subspecies are recognized: Rhabdophis subminiatus subminiatus and R. s. helleri.

Cyrtodactylus jeyporensis was described by Beddome in 1877 based on specimens collected from Pathinge Hill, Jeypore, Orissa (Smith 1935). Molecular phylogenetic data reveal that Geckoella is embedded within Cyrtodactylus, and this placement is now widely accepted and hence followed here.

Two distinct populations of this species are diagnosable on morphological and ecological grounds, with distinct differences between the hemipenes of populations from the wet zone and those from the dry zone (although there is some penetration of the wet zone taxon, Trimeresurus trigonocephalus sensu stricto, into the dry zone - M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). A description of the dry zone form as a distinct species is presently underway, including the collection of molecular data (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).  The species is placed in the genus Craspedocephalus under the revisions of Malhotra and Thorpe (2004) and David et al. (2011).

Taxononomic uncertainty persists with regard to the relationship between this species and R. punctatus (Pyron et al. 2016 and references therein; M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).

Taxononomic uncertainty persists with regard to the relationship between this species and R. punctatus (Pyron et al. 2016 and references therein; M. Wickramasinghe and N. Wickramasinghe pers comm. 2019).

Pyron et al. (2016) suggest a comprehensive phylogeographic study of this species, which has the imprecise type locality "Sri Lanka", and to clarify whether this apparently widespread species represents a species complex once its type locality has been restricted.
Records of Rhinophis blythii, a species otherwise known only from the Central Hills, from southwestern Sri Lanka are likely to represent this species (Wickramasinghe et al. 2009).
This name may be comprised of more than one species (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
Records from Kandy and at higher elevations are not included in the range description provided by Somaweera and Somaweera (2009), who note that these may represent a related but distinct species.

In a morphological review of Lankascincus, Batuwita (2019) concluded that Lankascincus deraniyagalae is likely to represent local variation within L. fallax, as a series of this species from the Central Hills agreed in nearly all characters with the type of L. deraniyagalae. This author concludes that the L. deraniyagalae holotype corresponds to L. fallax and formally synonymized the two species.
Agarwal et al. (2017) synonymized Cnemaspis clivicola and within C. upendrai. The holotypes of these two species differ genetically from one another by only 0.1% using ND2.
Historical records of this species outside the known range were found to represent different species by Maramendra-Arachchi et al. (2007), who also referred Cnemaspis ranwellai to its synonymy.
Cnemaspis ingerorum was previously confused with Cnemaspis kumarasinghei. It was found to be genetically distinct by Agarwal et al. (2017) and formally described by Batuwita et al. (2019)
Records of this species from Borangamuwa represent the newly-described species Cnemaspis anslemi.
Records of Cnemaspis aliwisi from the south of the species' currently known range represent a separate, recently-described species, C. hitihami.

Calotes manamendrai was described from a population formerly referred to C. liolepis at high elevations within the Knuckles Range. No distinct morphological characters were provided in the original description of C. desilvai that can reliably distinguish this species from the C. liolepis species complex, which which it is sympatric (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Based on molecular analysis C. desilvai is a valid species (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019), but further taxonomic resolution within the C. liolepis complex is needed to clarify range limits within this group as C. liolepis as presently defined is thought to contain multiple species.

No distinct morphological characters were provided in the original description that can reliably distinguish this species from the Calotes liolepis species complex, which which it is sympatric (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Based on molecular analysis C. desilvai is a valid species (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019), but further taxonomic resolution within the C. liolepis complex is needed to clarify range limits within this group and identify diagnostic characters for C. desilvai (Karunararathna et al. 2012).
This species is likely to represent a species complex (Das 1999, Harikrishnan et al. 2012).

The new species of diplodactylid gecko, Bavayia nubilaa, was described in 2012 from forests at two sites in the drainage of the Tontouta Valley in the ultramafic ranges of southeastern New Caledonia. The new gecko is the sister species of the much smaller Bavayia goroensis; both species are basal within the B. cyclura clade.

Caledoniscincus constellatus (described in 2012) has a bold, white midlateral stripe, a feature which distinguishes it from most other species of Caledoniscincus except the regionally sympatric C. haplorhinus (Günther) and C. austrocaledonicus (Bavay), from which it can be distinguished by a unique pattern of contact between the pale midlateral stripe and the ear. DNA sequence data for the ND2 mitochondrial gene identifies a high level of genetic differentiation between the new species and all other Caledoniscincus, further supporting its distinctiveness as an independent evolutionary lineage.

The new species of skink, Caledoniscincus notialis was described in 2013 from the ultramafic ranges in southern New Caledonia. It is most similar to, and has previously been referred to Caledoniscincus atropunctatus (Roux), a species with a widespread distribution throughout the Grande Terre and Loyalty Islands. The new species is distinct genetically from all other Caledoniscincus and can be distinguished by a unique pattern of dorsal coloration in males.

Caledoniscincus pelletieri was described in 2014 from the far north-west region of New Caledonia. It has a bold, white mid-lateral stripe on the body, a feature which distinguishes it from most other species of Caledoniscincus except the regionally sympatric Caledoniscincus haplorhinus (Günther) and Caledoniscincus austrocaledonicus (Bavay), and the recently described Caledoniscincus constellatus Sadlier, Whitaker, Wood & Bauer just to the south. The new species can be distinguished from these taxa in features of scalation and colouration, most notably in lacking an extension of the pale midlateral stripe between the ear and forelimbs and in having more lamellae on the underside of the fourth toe. The differences in morphology between C. pelletieri and the other members of the genus are complemented by a high level of genetic differentiation, further supporting its distinctiveness as an independent evolutionary lineage warranting recognition as a distinct species. The DNA sequence data for the ND2 mitochondrial gene identifies the new species as the sister to C. constellatus and these two taxa as the sister to all Caledoniscincus.

Correlophus belepensis (described in 2012) is a large diplodactylid. It differs from C. sarasinorum in possessing a prominent crest of spinose scales extending from behind the orbit to the shoulder region. It is most similar to its sister taxon C. ciliatus, but may be distinguished from it by its homogeneous dorsolateral trunk scalation and (in three of the four types) its possession of a series of small whitish tubercles on the lower back and/or tail base.

The Diplodactylid gecko genus Dierogekko is endemic to the northern Grande Terre of New Caledonia and the adjacent ultramafic offshore islands. All species are allopatric except D. poumensis and D. inexpectatus. Dierogekko baaba was described (in 2014) on the basis of a single female which is distinguished from its congeners by its small size (<38 mm SVL) and narrow, divided subdigital scansors. It is separated from all other Dierogekko by an uncorrected ND2 divergence of 6–15% (Tajima-Nei distance 6-17%).

A molecular phylogenetic analysis of the New Caledonia giant geckos has revealed that Rhacodactylus is not monophyletic (Bauer et al. 2012). The results show that R. chahoua forms a distinct clade separate from Rhacodactylus sensu stricto and hence a new genus, Mniarogekko has been created to accommodate R. chahoua. Genetic data showed that the subpopulations in northern Grande Terre and on the Iles Belep are highly distinct and are hence described as M. jalu (Bauer et al. 2012).

Mniarogekko jalu is a large (to 140 mm SVL) diplodactylid. It may be distinguished from its sister taxon M. chahoua by its much lower number of precloacal pores in males typically arranged in three, rather than four rows. Colour comparisons between the two species of Mniarogekko are difficult to make. There are relatively few wild caught M. chahoua in museum collections and captive animals have been bred for particular colour patterns (de Vosjoli et al. 2003) so ‘wild type’ coloration, which is itself already quite variable is difficult to characterize. Ventral body coloration in the new species seems to be uniformly a pale yellowish green, whereas M. chahoua is often white or cream, with a greenish tinge localized to some parts of the venter.

The genetic study (Sadlier 2014) revealed the presence of two clearly differentiated lineages within what has previously been regarded as a single species, Nannoscincus mariei. Although the geographic range of samples available for the genetics study is not as extensive as that represented by museum specimens it is, in combination with morphological data, sufficient to indicate that the samples represent two parapatric taxa: Nannoscincus mariei Bavay (Mt. Koghis south to the Goro Plateau, including Rivière Bleue), and Nannoscincus fuscus (the Chaîne Centrale at Mt. Mou, Mt. Dzumac and Mt. Vulcain).

Nannoscincus koniambo was described in 2014 (Sadlier, 2014). It is part of the N. mariei group, is restricted to the Koniambo massif and can be distinguished from all other members of the genus a combination of characters: frontoparietals fused; loreal single; left oviduct lost in females; lower labials five; lower eyelid with a semi-translucent window; ear opening minute; body scales smooth; adult dorsal color two toned; ear opening positioned two scales posterior to lower secondary temporal; presacral vertebrae 32; phalangeal formula for manus 2.3.4.4.3.; phalangeal formula for pes 2.3.4.5.3.
The genus Phaeoscincus and two new species P. ouinensis and P. taomensis were described in 2014.

Bauer et al. (2012) in a molecular phylogenetic analysis of the giant geckos found that the few subpopulations of Rhacodactylus trachyrhynchus sampled were strongly divergent from one another and a specimen from Îlot Môrô near the Île des Pins is especially distinctive. This specimen and others examined from Îlot Môrô are morphologically assignable to the species described by Boulenger in 1878 as Chameleonurus trachycephalus (and later treated as a subspecies of R. trachyrhynchus) and is now recognized as a full species (Bauer et al. 2012).

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a Sigaloseps lineage of three taxa from the interior ranges of the southern ultramafic New Caledonia region: one representing populations on the adjacent peaks of Mt Ouin and Mt Humboldt formerly included under S. ruficauda and described as S. ferrugicauda; one representing the type population of S. ruficauda sensu stricto from Mt Mou; and one representing a taxon from Mt Humboldt that is morphologically very distinct but shows a low level of genetic differentiation from S. ruficauda and is described as S. balios.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a taxon formerly included within Sigaloseps deplanchei sensu lato and represented by populations from the southeast of the southern ultramafic region at Rivière Bleue and Pourina River and here described as S. conditus.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a Sigaloseps lineage of three taxa from the interior ranges of the southern ultramafic New Caledonia region: one representing populations on the adjacent peaks of Mt Ouin and Mt Humboldt formerly included under S. ruficauda and described as S. ferrugicauda; one representing the type population of S. ruficauda sensu stricto from Mt Mou; and one representing a taxon from Mt Humboldt that is morphologically very distinct but shows a low level of genetic differentiation from S. ruficauda and is described as S. balios.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies (Sadlier et al. 2014) reveals a taxon formerly included within Sigaloseps deplanchei sensu lato and represented by populations in the central (Tontouta valley) and northern (Pic Ningua) areas of the southern ultramafic region, and coastal ultramafic ranges in the east-central region (Nakéty) and here described as Sigaloseps pisinnus.
Specimens collected from the more central region of Sulawesi around Wotu and north of Tenteno will require examination to determine to solve taxonomy (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
A population from Pulau Buton has previously been treated within this species, but its taxonomy remains unsolved and it is suspected to be different species (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019).
This species and Oligodon unicolor may represent the same species, for which the name O. forbesi has priority (D.T. Iskandar and A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
This species and Oligodon forbesi may represent the same species, for which the name O. forbesi has priority (D.T. Iskandar and A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).

Kaiser et al. (2018) removed Stegonotus sutteri from synonymy with this species. These authors noted that as the resulting concept of S. florensis was represented by only two specimens, their characterization of its diagnostic features should be considered "tenuous".
It is thought that Lipinia infralineolata may consist of more than one species (Das and Greer 2002).
There are unresolved taxonomic issues within Eremiascincus antoniorum and E. timorensis (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
The phylogeny of Blom et al. (2019) shows that Cryptoblepharus renschi is nested within C. leschenault, indicating that C. leschenault as presently understood is a species complex.

Sigaloseps deplanchei displays considerable morphometric variation and a low level of genetic variation across its range. Sadlier et al. (2014) investigated the variation further through a broad-scale genetic study and identified two new species that were previously included within S. deplanchei, those are now assessed separately as S. conditus and S. pisinnus.

The results from field, morphological and genetic studies revealed that Sigaloseps ruficauda was a species complex containing two distinct taxa and it was therefore split it into a more restricted concept of S. ruficauda and a new species S. ferrugicauda (Sadlier et al. 2014).
This species is known only from the holotype and its taxonomic status is consequently uncertain (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2012).

authority: Curcio, Sales Nunes, Suzart Argolo, Skuk & Rodrigues, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species is known from only two specimens. One of them is considered lost and the other preserved in poor condition, making comparisons with more recent material difficult. Any new collections need to be compared with the surviving specimen to confirm their identity.
A record of this species from the Serra de Baturité, state of Ceará was reidentified as Epictia albifrons by Borges-Nojosa in 2006, following a survey of diversity in this area.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Entiauspe-Neto et al. (2021) examined the only known specimen of Phalotris cerradensis, originally described as a range extension for P. concolor to Bahia State, and confirmed that P. cerradensis represents a junior synonym of P. concolor.

authority: Da Silva, Rodrigues Silva, Ribeiro, Souza & Do Amaral Souza, 2005
taxonomicNotes: The validity of the taxon uncertain, as it is known from a single specimen that may be an anomalous individual of Atractus pantostictus (P. Passos pers. comm. 2012).

Apostolepis striata was described based on its type specimen alone (Lema 2004). More data is necessary for a more complete description, including comparisons with other Apostolepis such as Apostolepis serrana Lema, 2004, A. nigroterminata Boulenger, 1896, and A. phillipsae Harvey, 1999.

authority: Curcio, Sales Nunes, Suzart Argolo, Skuk & Rodrigues, 2012

taxonomicNotes: The identity of two records from Santa Cruz in Bolivia, assigned to this species by Harvey (1999), based on two specimens that these authors acknowledged differ from the holotype, remains uncertain. Entiauspe and Lema (2015) concluded that these represented Apostolepis christineae based on photographs of the museum specimens, but did not examine the specimens to confirm this identification and A. christineae is so far known with certainty only from the Brazilian type locality. Pending direct examination of the specimens it is considered speculative to assign these records to either species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), and they are consequently excluded from this assessment.

H. Zaher (pers. comm. 2012) reported that this species was being reviewed and will possibly be synonymized with Erythrolamprus almadensis. This synonymy has never been published and ecologically distinct form "may well" represent a validly distinct species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

This species is only weakly distinguishable from Bothrops atrox, and a preliminary investigations of the relationships between these taxa concluded that further research is required to fully resolve its status (Wüster et al. 1996, Alencar et al. 2016).

The taxonomic status of Apostolepis sanctaeritae is unresolved. This species was long considered a junior synonym of A. flavotorquata following Amaral (1930), but more recently has variously been treated as either a full species (Lema and Fernandes 1997, Lema 2002) or a junior synonym of A. cearensis (Ferrazzi et al. 1993). Ferrarezzi et al. (2005) adopt the latter arrangement, but despite summarizing the taxonomic confusion surrounding this species they do not comment on this assignment.
