Most recently, molecular samples referred to A. sanctaeritae were recovered as distinct from A. caerensis by Grazziotin et al. (2012), but these authors do not comment on this finding and the "A. sanctaeritae" samples used are now recognized to have been mislabelled sequences referabble to A. ammodytes (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2018). This account follows the advice of C. Nogueira (pers. comm. 2018) in retaining A. sanctaeritae as a junior synonym of A. caerensis pending further research.

This species was described from a specimen which may have erroneous locality data (H. Zaher pers. comm. 2019), as it does not resemble any other known South Anerican snake (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). It is consequently possible it is from another continent.

The name Micrurus ibiboboca is applied to a complex of at least three species endemic to Brazil. M. ibiboboca sensu stricto has a range evidently restricted to the Caatinga and to the Atlantic Forest of Northeast Brazil.

Traditionally considered to be a single species with some variation in colouration, morphological and molecular phylogenetic analyses have produced conflicting results and conclusions in recent years (Blanck et al. 2006, Spinks et al. 2009). The Vietnamese and possible Laotian populations are recognized as a separate species, Cuora cyclornata Blanck, McCord & Le 2006, with two subspecies, C. c. cyclornata Blanck, McCord & Le, 2006 and C. c. meieri Blanck, McCord & Le, 2006.

authority: Ihlow, Vamberger, Flecks, Hartmann, Cota, Makchai, Meewattana, Dawson, Kheng, Rödder & Fritz, 2016

taxonomicNotes: This species is known from a single historical specimen that appears to have been overlooked until formally described by Hedges and Conn (2012).

Praschag et al. (2011), in a detailed study of the species in the range, have shown that the evolutionary distances of the two allopatrically distributed clades (Lissemys scutata, Myanmar) and (Sri Lanka) to their closest relatives are distinctly higher than among Indian ones. This suggested that the two clades from Myanmar and Sri Lanka represent old lineages that diverged between the Early Miocene and the Lower Pliocene (mean estimates: approx. 11 and 8 myr), whereas the other clades between the uppermost Miocene and the Early Pleistocene, mean ages of 4.5 and 4.2 myr).

This is a new concept for this species which now includes C. timorensis McCord, Joseph-Ouni, and Hagen 2007a. Three subspecies of Chelodina mccordi are currently recognized (TTWG 2017): C. m. mccordi (Rhodin 1994) from western Roti (Rote) Island in the Lesser Sunda Islands of Indonesia, C. m. roteensis (McCord et al. 2007b) from eastern Roti (Rote) Island, and C. m. timorensis (McCord et al. 2007a) from Timor Leste. However, preliminary genetic work in progress suggests that there may be only one taxon on Roti (C. mccordi) and one taxon in Timor Leste (C. timorensis), possibly distinct at the species level. The common name on Roti in Bahasa Indonesian is Kura-kura Rote, and in Timor Leste the name in Tetum is Lenuk Kakorok Naruk.

Subpopulations of this species display morphological variation, with northwestern Indian subpopulations being phenotypically distinct from southeastern Indian subpopulations (Gaur et al. 2006). Range wide phylogeographic studies are clearly needed.

Common names for this species in various regional languages are as follows: Tamil: Nakshatra Amai, Moonam (Irula); Telugu: Nakshatra Tabelu; Oriya: Pathuria Kaincha, Tara Kaincha; Gujarati: Suraj Kachbo, Paththar Kachabo, Kabacha, Jamin no Kachabo; Sri Lanka:  In Sri Lanka Geochelone elegans is known by several Sinhala (language of the main ethnic race, Sinhalese) names. These names differ according to the province. For example, in Southern Province the star tortoise is popularly known as the Vehera Ibbā (Vehera = stupa or dageba as the dome-shaped carapace resembles a stupa, Ibbā = tortoise), Väṭakeyiyā Ibbā (Väṭakeyiyā = Pandanus), and in the North Central Province it is know as the Mēvara Ibbā (Mēvara= marked) or Thāraka Ibbā (Thāraka = Star). Some additional Sinhala names used in different parts of the country for Geochelone elegans are: Hūniam Ibbā (Hūniam= magic or witchcraft), Vayiran Ibbā (Vayiran = striped), Mūkalan Ibbā (Mūkalan = forest), Mékaral Ibbā (Mǟkaral = long bean), Mal Ibbā (Mal = flower), and Monara Ibbā (Monara = peacock). However, the widely used Sinhalese names are Thāraka Ibbā, Vehera Ibbā and Mevara Ibbā.Tamil names used in Sri Lanka: Kāṭṭu āmai (Kāṭṭu = forest, āmai = tortoise), Kātupeṭṭi āmai (Kāṭṭu = forest, peṭṭi = basket), Moon āmai, Pudukotta. Tamil names used in the Eastern province: Kātupeṭṭi āmai, Kal āmai (stone tortoise), Manchal āmai (Manchal = yellow) and Malai āmai (Malai = mountain tortoise); the first name is the commonly used name in the Eastern Province (Ahamed, Dharmaratnam and de Silva, 2004). It is of interest to note that the Urdu name of the star tortoise is “Tariwala kachua”.

Elevated from subspecies of Cuora galbinifrons by Stuart and Parham (2004), this elevation was rejected by Fritz et al. (2006), but supported by Spinks et al. (2012) and TTWG (2014). The common name in Vietnamese is  Rua hop bua-re.

Elevated from a subspecies of Cuora galbinifrons by Stuart and Parham (2004); species status was contested by Fritz et al. (2006), and reaffirmed by Spinks et al. (2012) and accepted by TTWG (2014). The common name in Vietnamese is Rua hop vietnam.

Cuora galbinifrons previously included the taxa bourreti and picturata as subspecies; the latter two were elevated to full species rank by Stuart and Parham (2004) (though see Fritz et al. 2006 for dissenting perspective) and reconfirmed as full species by Spinks et al. (2012) and accepted by TTWG (2014). Cuora serrata is generally accepted to be a hybrid between C. galbinifrons and C. mouhotii (Parham et al. 2001, Shi et al. 2005). Cuora hainanensis (Li 1958), once considered a full species, later a galbinifrons subspecies, is now viewed as so similar to C. galbinifrons as to not require a separate designation (Stuart and Parham 2004). The common name in Vietnamese is Rua hop tran vang.

Manthey and Denzer (2016) examined genetic material and voucher specimens for Melanesian Hypsilurus (sensu lato) and Australian outgroups including the two representatives of this genus. The results supported an earlier suggestion (Manthey and Denzer 2006) that the Australian taxa and Melanesian H. dilophus, the type species of the genus Lophosaurus, formed a separate species group from the remaining Oceanian taxa. While Manthey and Denzer (2016) deferred nomenclatural changes to Melanesian Hypsilurus sensu lato pending further work, these authors resurrected Lophosaurus for the clade containing H. dilophis, H. spinipes and H. boydii.

A recent systematic revision by Carranza et al. (2016), using an integrative approach including molecular (mitochondrial and nuclear markers) and morphological data, indicated that the species originally classified as Asaccus caudivolvulus (Arnold and Gardner 1994, Gardner 2013) was an assemblage of three different species that started diversifying during the Mid-Miocene. The analyses uncovered a very old diversification event that resulted in a case of microendemicity, where three morphologically and ecologically similar medium-sized species previously classified within A. caudivolvulus coexist in a very short and narrow mountain stretch.

As a result of this study, two new species – A. gardneri and A. margaritae – were described, both of them widely distributed across the northern tip of the Hajar Mountains. Conversely the third species - Asaccus caudivolvulus sensu stricto - appears to be restricted to a small coastal area of the United Arab Emirates under heavy development, where the only two localities in which the species has ever been recorded occur. The molecular analyses indicate that A. caudivolvulus has been evolving independently from its sister taxon, A. gardneri, for approximately four million years.
Synonym = Enyaliosaurus bakeri (Stejneger, 1901). Not a basionym.

A range-wide molecular study (mitochondrial and nuclear DNA) of southern African tortoises indicated that Homopus is paraphyletic and that the genus Chersobius warrants resurrection to accommodate the five-toed Homopus species, including H. signatus (Hofmeyr et al. 2017), a name change adopted by TTWG (2017). A paper detailing the taxonomic revision has been published (Hofmeyr and Branch 2018).

Wang and Rao (2008) removed Gekko scabridus from synonymy with G. chinensis, within which it had been placed by Zhao and Adler (1993). Molecular research supports this arrangement (K. Zhou unpubl. data 2010).

There has been considerable taxonomic debate over the angular-toed or thin-toed geckos, and they have been variously assigned to Cyrtodactylus, Cyrtopodion and Tenuidactylus (Auffenberg et al. 2004). This species was referred to the genus Cyrtopodion by Auffenberg et al. (2004), following the simplified arrangement presented by Anderson (1999), and despite the assignment of this species to Altigekko by Khan (2003) Following Bauer et al. (2013) it is now treated under Altiphylax.

Gymnodactylus walli was, for a long time, considered a synonym of C. stoliczkai, until Khan (1992) provided a case to recognize G. walli as a separate species, an action subsequently supported by Auffenberg et al. (2004).

Auffenberg et al. (2004) consider Alsophylax (Altiphylax) boehmi to be a junior synonym of this species.
This species was assigned from Leptotyphlops to Myriopholis by Adalsteinsson et al. (2009).
The relationship between this species and Urocotyledon palmeri requires additional research.
The conspecific nature of the populations from each island needs review, as these may represent distinct species.

authority: Harvey, Scrivani, Shaney, Hamidy, Kurniawan & Smith, 2018
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Onn, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
taxonomicNotes: Lowland populations close to villages may belong to a different, undescribed species (A. Riyanto pers. comm. 2019).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Onn, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
Grismer, Wood, Anuar, Riyanto, Ahmad, Muin, Sumontha, Grismer, Onn, Quah & Pauwels, 2014
Harvey, O'Connell, Barraza, Riyanto, Kurniawan & Smith, 2015
Harvey, O'Connell, Barraza, Riyanto, Kurniawan & Smith, 2015
Riyanto, Mulyadi, McGuire, Kusrini, Febylasmia, Basyir & Kaiser, 2017
Stubbs, Karin, Arifin, Iskandar, Arida, Reilly, Bloch, Kusnadi & McGuire, 2017
taxonomicNotes: Stubbs et al. (2017) cautioned that further research is required to confirm that the Kei Kecil and Kur populations are conspecific; records from both islands were subsequently assigned to this species without comment by Karin et al. (2018).

Siler et al. (2014) found that a deep genetic divergence existed within Pseudogekko brevipes as then understood, corresponding to the two recognized faunal regions where the species occurred. Subsequently, Davis et al. (2015) described the Visayan lineage as the new species P. atiorum, restricting P. brtevipes to the Mindanao faunal region. These authors redescribed P. brevipes, whose original description lacked detail.

Siler et al. (2014a) conducted a taxonomic reappraisal of Pseudogekko compressicorpus based on a morphological study of the the available material (the holotype having been destroyed during WWII) combined with recent genetic research (Siler et al. 2014a,b). These authors identified four candidate species within the P. compressicorpus complex, with P. compressicorpus sensu stricto potentially being restricted to Luzon, and recommend further research to clarify species and geographical boundaries.

authority: Siler, Welton, Davis, Watters, Davey, Diesmos, Diesmos & Brown, 2014
Siler, Davis, Watters, Freitas, Griffith, Binaday, Lobos Amarga & Brown, 2017
Amarasinghe, Vogel, McGuire, Sidik, Supriatna & Ineich, 2015
Bauer, Giri, Greenbaum, Jackman, Dharne & Schouche, 2008
taxonomicNotes:
Bauer et al. (2008) synonymized Teratolepis with Hemidactylus which rendered Hemidactylus fasciatus (Blyth, 1853) a junior secondary homonym of Hemidactylus fasciatus Gray, 1842. Bauer et al. (2008) therefore proposed the new name Hemidactylus imbricatus for the species previously known as H. fasciatus. Bauer et al. (2008) also state that Blyth’s paper most likely had been published in 1853, not 1854 as often cited, although the volume itself is dated "1854".

There is a need for comparison of Pakistani material with the Indian holotype to clarify whether the records from both countries represent the same species (V. Giri pers. comm. 2019).

This species was considered a synonym of Gymnodactylus stoliczkai until its reclassification by Khan (1992). Its correct generic placement has been under dispute, with different authors treating it under Gymnodactylus, Cyrtodactylus, Tenuidactylus, Cyrtopodion and now Mediodactylus.

Sitana attenboroughi was described from three specimens from a single locality at the northern range limit of Sitana marudhamneydhal. This description was based on a qualitative morphological character that appears to exhibit overlap with S. marudhamneydhal, and the describing authors' genetic phylogeny suggests that it differs by 2.2% (based on ND2 alone) from a sample of marudhamneydhal and less than 2% from a second specimen which they identified as "Sitana sp." and which, based on low genetic divergence from S. marudhamneydhal, is considered also to represent this species (V. Deepak and N.S. Naruyanan pers. comm. 2019). As other members of this group have been delimited based on greater morphological evidence, larger sample sizes, and sequence data - including multiple genes - that exhibit 3% divergence using ND2, this is considered insufficient evidence to recognize Sitana attenboroughi as a valid species, and this account follows the recommendation of V. Deepak (pers. comm. 2019) in retaining it within S. marudhamneydhal pending further research.
There is a need for a taxonomic revision of this widespread and seemingly generalist species, and it is widely expected that it will prove to be a species complex.

Amarasinghe et al. (2015) revised Sitana ponticeriana, removing S. deccanensis from synonymy and describing two new species - S. bahiri and S. devakai - from Sri Lanka. Subsequently, Deepak et al. (2018) suggested that S. bahiri should be considered a junior synonym of S. ponticeriana, citing morphological and molecular evidence reported in previous papers that suggested "extensive overlap between S. ponticeriana and S. bahiri". Confusingly, Deepak et al. (2016b), the paper they cite in support of the morphological similarity, makes no reference to the two taxa being difficult to diagnose morphologically, describes distinct differences in dewlap size, and provides distribution records for S. bahiri that appear not to correspond to the known range of the species recognized under this name by Amarasinghe et al. (2015) (but may represent records of "Sitana cf. bahiri", a genetically similar form that Deepak et al. 2016a explicitly refrained from referring to S. bahiri). Due to this confusion, it is unclear whether the molecular evidence referred to by Deepak et al. (2018) correspond to the original concept of S. bahiri. As these authors provided no novel data to resolve this confusion, S. bahiri is here treated as a valid species pending further taxonomic research.

This species was described from Sri Lankan material previously considered to represent Sitana ponticeriana (Amarasinghe et al. 2015). Molecular studies are needed to clarify species limits between this species, bahiri and ponticeriana. The status of an undescribed population from northeastern Sri Lanka, removed from S. ponticeriana by Amarasinghe et al. (2015), is presently being investigated and may affect range limits in S. devakai.

This taxon was considered a valid species of the Oligodon cyclurus group (David et al. 2011). Previously, it had also been regarded as a synonym of Oligodon cyclurus by Smith (1943) but has been recognized as a valid species by Schleich and Kästle (2002) and Whitaker and Captain (2004), and has been regarded as a different species by David et al. (2011).
Bungarus sindanus walli Wall, 1907, has recently been treated as a full species (Wallach et al. 2014, Ahsan and Rahman 2017) and this scheme is tentatively followed here.
Not in red list.

authority: Simó-Riudalbas, Metallinou, Pous, Els, Jayasinghe, Péntek-Zakar, Wilms, Al-Saadi & Carranza, 2017
Harikrishnan, Vasudevan, Chandramouli, Choudhury, Dutta & Das, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Sitana deccanensis was removed from synonymy with S. ponticeriana by Amarasinghe et al. (2015), and subsequently transferred to the new genus Sarada by Deepak et al. (2016).

The species name calamarius was replaced by templetoni because Coluber calamarius was considered to be the legitimate type species of Calamaria (see Brongersma et al. 1966, Bull. Zool. Nomencl. 22). However, Calamaria linnaei was later declared the type species of Calamaria by ICZN Opinion 2196. This species was therefore renamed from templetoni to calamarius and Oligodon calamarius is thus the correct name for this taxon (Uetz et al. 2018).

Agarwal et al. (2018) redescribed Cyrtodactylus khasiensis and elevated the subspecies C. k. cayuensis to species level, as C. cayuensis based on diagnostic characters reported in the English abstract and the generally narrow distributions of Cyrtodactylus in this area. This scheme is followed here, but a more detailed comparison of these taxa is required to confirm this assignment.
Further taxonomic studies are recommended on similar looking populations from parts of the Eastern Ghats (Ganesh and Arumugam 2016).

authority: Agarwal, Mirza, Pal, Maddock, Mishra & Bauer, 2016

taxonomicNotes: This species, which had not been recorded since its original description, was synonymized with Hemidactylus depressus by Smith (1935). Following the collection of additional material, Batuwita and Pethiyagoda (2012) determined that H. pieresii represents a validly distinct taxon and redescribed both species.
This species was described from populations previously understood to represent a northern isolate of Melanophidium punctatum (Gower et al. 2016).
This species was recently resurrected from synonymy within Uropeltis arcticeps by Ganesh et al. (2014).
This species was removed from synonymy within Uropeltis ceylanica by Ganesh et al. (2014).

This species has been considered as a synonym of Trimeresurus labialis (e.g. by Wallach et al. 2014) but was revalidated by Vogel et al. 2014. It has the type locality of Nicobar Islands; restricted to “Camorta Island, in the central Nicobars”.
Phrynocephalus nasatus was synonymized within P. axillaris by Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007).

It is unclear what constitutes a species within Himalayan Japalura. Given current information it may be that every drainage basin has an endemic species, implying that J. tricarinata is likely to be a species complex and highlighting the need for genetic surveys of this group (J. Macey pers. comm.).
As currently conceived this species complex encompasses a few recognised synonyms, each referring to a distinct morphotype (Smith 1943).

Pseudoplectrurus canaricus was described as Silybura canarica by Beddome in 1870 based on specimens collected from Kudremukh, Karnataka (Beddome 1870, Smith 1943). Boulenger (1893) transferred it to the genus Pseudoplectrurus and Smith (1843) transferred it to Plectrurus. Pyron et al. (2016) have transferred it back to Pseudoplecturus as it is a distinct monophyletic taxon.

Uropeltis ceylanica was described as U. ceylanicus by Cuvier in 1829 based on specimens supposedly from Sri Lanka (Smith 1943) but as it thought to be endemic to India, the original locality must be incorrect (Gower et al. 2008, Ganesh et al. 2014). The many synonyms originating from different hill ranges suggests the need for further taxonomic investigation (Gower et al. 2008). Gower et al. (2008) removed Uropeltis bicatenata from synonymy, but as neither these authors nor Ganesh et al. (2014) (who elevated Uropeltis shortii from synonymy with this species for populations from the Eastern Ghats) re-diagnosed this species the identity of much historical material assigned to U. ceylanica and the species' range of morphological variation remain unclear (Pyron et al. 2016).

Uropeltis macrorhyncha  was described by Beddome in 1877 as Silybura macrorhyncha based on a specimen collected from near Ponachi (=Pollachi), Anaimalai Hills, Coimbatore district, Tamil Nadu, India  (Smith 1943).

Uropeltis maculata was described by Beddome in 1878 as Silybura maculata based on type series collected from the Anaimalai Hills, Coimbatore district, Tamil Nadu, India  (Beddome 1878, Smith 1943). Although, Beddome (1878) has not assigned the type locality, Boulenger (1893) included Anaimalai Hills as the type locality of this species.

Uropeltis nitida was described as Silybura nitida by Beddome in 1886 based on type series collected from the Western side of the Anaimalai Hills near Nelliyampathy, Palakkad district, Kerala, India  (Beddome 1886, Smith 1943).

Uropeltis rubrolineata was described as Silybura rubrolineata by Günther in 1875 based on type series collected from the Western side of the Anaimalai Hills near Nelliyampathy, Palakkad district, Kerala, India and Tirunelvelli Hills (probably the present day Agasthyamalai Hills), Tirunelvelli district, Tamil Nadu (Günther 1875, Boulenger 1893, Smith 1943). By lectotype designation the type locality has been restricted to Tirunelvelli Hills, Tamil Nadu by McDiarmid et al. (1999). Gans (1966) treated Uropeltis phipsonii (Mason, 1888) as a synonym of this species, Rajendran (1985) revalidated its specific status.

A possible issue of homonymy was created when Rhinophis grandis Beddome, 1867 was transferred to Uropeltis by Smith (1943), since Uropeltis grandis Kelaart, 1853 was a pre-existing name. Gans (1966) thus erected U. smithi as a nomen novum for R. grandis, with the same type series and locality. However, Tennent (1861) had long since relegated U. grandis Kelaart, 1853 to the synonymy of Pseudotyphlops philippinus (Müller, 1832), which Pyron et al. (2016) have since renamed as R. saffragamus (Kelaart, 1853). Hence the name U. grandis (Beddome, 1867) can be used again.

Mabuya "nagarjuni" was originally described by Sharma in 1969 based on specimens from Nagarjunakonda, Andhra Pradesh (Srinivasulu et al. 2006). Following revision of the genus Mabuya by Mausfeld et al. (2002) this taxon is presently included within Eutropis Fitzinger, 1843. The species epithet was mistakenly named as a patronym but it is evident that it should have been named as a toponym after the area where it was found, hence the epithet has been emended to "nagarjunensis" (Amarasinghe et al. 2016).

The taxonomic history and range limits of Liasis mackloti are complex and still not fully resolved (Rawlings et al. 2004, D. Esquerre pers. comm. 2018). Confusion over range limits in Liasis fuscus, which was long considered a junior synonym of L. mackloti following Stuhl (1932), has resulted in a lack of clarity of the eastern and southern range limits of L. mackloti. Based on limited mtDNA sampling, Rawlings et al. (2004) found that Australian water pythons are divided into two clades, representing L. fuscus in Queensland and New Guinea and L. mackloti in the Northern Territory and the Indonesian islands Babar, Timor and Semau. Nevertheless, Australian workers have continued to recognize only a single water python species in this country pending resolution of taxonomic problems (Cogger 2014, Wilson and Swan 2017). New Guinean records have been attributed either to L. fuscus (McDowell 1975, Barker and Barker 1994, Barker et al. 2018) or to L. mackloti (O'Shea 2007, Cogger 2014). Carmichael et al. (2007) regard L. mackloti as an island endemic consisting of the subspecies L. m. mackloti, L. m. savuensis and L. m. dunni, excluding New Guinea from the distribution. These authors note that the three subspecies are allopatric and exhibit no evidence of hybridization. Rawlings et al. (2004) reported molecular evidence that the Sawu population, L. m. savuensis, may warrant specific recognition. Recently, both L. savuensis and L. dunni have been recognized as valid species (Barker et al. 2015, D. Esquerre pers. comm. 2018). Following these taxonomic changes L. mackloti is restricted to Timor, Roti, Semau and Alor (Barker et al. 2015), and further research may reveal that its range should be extended to the Northern Territory in northern Australia.

The taxonomic history and range limits of Liasis mackloti are complex and still not fully resolved (Rawlings et al. 2004, D. Esquerre pers. comm. 2018). Confusion over range limits in Liasis fuscus, which was long considered a junior synonym of L. mackloti following Stuhl (1932), has resulted in a lack of clarity of the eastern and southern range limits of L. mackloti. Based on limited mtDNA sampling, Rawlings et al. (2004) found that Australian water pythons are divided into two clades, representing L. fuscus in Queensland and New Guinea and L. mackloti in the Northern Territory and the Indonesian islands Babar, Timor and Semau. Nevertheless, Australian workers have continued to recognize only a single water python species in this country pending resolution of taxonomic problems (Cogger 2014, Wilson and Swan 2017). New Guinean records have been attributed either to L. fuscus (McDowell 1975, Barker and Barker 1994, Barker et al. 2018) or to L. mackloti (O'Shea 2007, Cogger 2014). Carmichael et al. (2007) regard L. mackloti as an island endemic consisting of the subspecies L. m. mackloti, L. m. savuensis and L. m. dunni, excluding New Guinea from the distribution. These authors note that the three subspecies are allopatric and exhibit no evidence of hybridization. Rawlings et al. (2004) reported molecular evidence that the Sawu population, L. m. savuensis, may warrant specific recognition. Recently, both L. savuensis and L. dunni have been recognized as valid species (Barker et al. 2015, D. Esquerre pers. comm. 2018). Following these taxonomic changes L. mackloti is restricted to Timor, Roti, Semau and Alor (Barker et al. 2015).
This species has recently been elevated from a subspecies of Plestiodon chinensis (Kurita et al. 2017).
The two populations of this species may correspond to distinct species.

Peters (1869) described Euprepes laevigatus (= Trachylepis laevigata) from Gerlachshoop in Limpopo Province, South Africa. The species was later synonymised with T. varia. Based on genetics, lepidosis and colouration, Weinell and Bauer (2018) reinstated T. laevigata as a full species.

This species, formerly in Mehelya, was included in the resurrected genus Gonionotophis by Kelly et al. (2011). Broadley et al. (2018) provisionally referred it to the resurrected Mehelya, but noted that it did not fit their diagnostic key, and it was not included in these authors' genetic analysis.

This species was transferred to Gonionotophis from Mehelya by Kelly et al. (2011). Broadley et al. (2018) provisionally referred it to the resurrected Mehelya, but noted that it did not fit their diagnostic key, and it was not included in these authors' genetic analysis.
Records of Eremias beuchneri from Kyrgyzstan are now assigned to E. kokshaaliensis (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).

Although Eremias multiocellata is a recognized species complex (Dujsebayeva et al. 2009 and refs therein), the validity of proposed subspecies has been questioned and the taxon is presently regarded as monotypic by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008). Other authors recognize two valid subspecies other than the nominate form: E. m. bannikowi (Szczerbak 1973); and the recent description E. m. tsaganbogdensis (Munkhbayar and Borkin 2010). A review of this species complex is in press, including the description of a new taxon from within this complex from the Dzhungarian Gobi (Orlova et al. 2017). Karyotype variation in a population from Bei Shan in China's Nei Mongol province may reflect the occurrence of a cryptic species at this locality; it is presently unclear whether this represents an undescribed form or the previously proposed subspecies E. m. kozlowi (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). Dujsebayeva et al. (2009) tentatively assign records from central Tien-Shan to E. multiocellata based on comparisons with E. stummeri and E. kokshaaliensis (although the definition of this latter species is itself under review - Orlova et al. 2017), but note that the taxonomy of these subpopulations requires further investigation.
This species was recently split from Acontias breviceps (Essex 1925) (Conradie et al. 2018).
Recently split from Acontias breviceps Essex, 1925, although it is closely related to Acontias gracilicauda Essex, 1925 (Conradie et al. 2018).

Golubev (1991) identified Phrynocephalus reticulatus as a junior subjective synonym of Agama ocellata and consequently resurrected the combination Phrynocephalus ocellatus. This nomenclature was accepted by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008) and by Solovyeva et al. (2011). Babaranov and Ananjeva (2007), however, pointed out that the name P. reticulatus has been in usage by many authors for over a century, and consequently proposed that this name should be protected under the provisions of the Zoological Code of Nomenclature. Most workers in the region reject the nomenclature proposed by Golubev (1991) (N. Ananjeva pers. comm. 2016) and Phrynocephalus reticulatus is the name retained here.

Wiens and Penkrot (2002) examined variation in Sceloporus jarrovii using morphological and DNA data and found that three approaches each supported division of S. jarrovii into five species, but only two species were the same among the three approaches. They found the greatest support for the five species that were delimited by mtDNA data. Following Wiens and Penkrot (2002) and Wiens et al. (1999), S. jarrovii occurs in Arizona, New Mexico, and Mexico and the other four species (S. cyanostictus, S. minor, S. oberon, and S. sugillatus) occur in Mexico. These species do not strictly conform with traditional subspecies circumscriptions. We currently follow Wiens and Penkrot (2002) in retaining S. lineolateralis within S. jarrovii.

The previous Red List assessments for Galapagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (name now Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and more recently several researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) have treated most of them as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy has been largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most phylogenetic lineages of Galapagos tortoises. This Red List assessment treats C. phantasticus as a full species, rather than retaining its previous subspecies ranking from earlier taxonomies. The species has never before been assessed for the IUCN Red List.

Preliminary genetic analysis of the single old adult male saddlebacked holotype of C. phantasticus from Fernandina has indicated its apparently closer relationship with dome-shaped C. porteri from distant Santa Cruz rather than the more proximate populations of C. vicina on Isabela or any other saddlebacked taxa (Poulakakis et al. 2012). This apparent biogeographic anomaly, in addition to the lack of any discovery to date of skeletal tortoise remains or other living tortoises on Fernandina, has created some uncertainty as to its relationships. However, tortoise scats and bite marks on cacti found in 1964 have confirmed that other tortoises have occurred and more recent sightings and signs suggest that a few tortoises might yet persist on Fernandina.

This species has historically been placed in the genus Typhlops, but has recently been moved to Indotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014, Pyron and Wallach 2014).

Two of five known specimens from Hong Kong have since been redescribed as a different species, Typhlops lazelli (Wallach and Pauwels 2004), although the remaining three specimens assigned to Ramphotyphlops albiceps from Hong Kong are considered to represent this species.

authority: Sanders, Rasmussen, Elmberg, Mumpuni, Guinea, Blias, Lee & Fry, 2012
taxonomicNotes: Aipysurus mosaicus was previously considered to be an allopatric population of A. eydouxii, which occurs throughout the Sunda Shelf and in New Guinea. Molecular analyses reveal these two species to be sister lineages with fixed nucleotide substitutions at three independent mitochondrial and nuclear loci, and a deep phylogenetic divergence exceeding that of all other sampled species pairs in Aipysurus. Aaipysurus mosaicus is also distinguished from A. eydouxii by morphological characters relating to scalation (for example, number of ventral scales), colour pattern (for example, number and shape of transverse body bands), internal soft anatomy (for example, position of heart in relation to ventral scales), and skeletal morphology (for example, shape of nasal and caudal neural spines; Sanders et al. 2012).

This species was first described in 2012 using a combination of molecular (mitochondrial and nuclear) and morphological (scalation, colour pattern and skull osteology) characters (Ukuwela et al. 2012).
This species was resurrected from synonymy with Ramphotyphlops (Austrotyphlops) australis in 2004 (Rabosky et al. 2004).

The species has been taxonomically supported since its description (Hollingsworth 1998). Morphological data places Sauromalus hispidus as sister to the clade containing S. ater, S. klauberi, and S. slevini (Hollingsworth 1998), while molecular data place S. hispidus as a sister to S. varius (Petren and Case 1997).

Agarwal et al. (2018) redescribed this species and elevated the subspecies Cyrtodactylus khasiensis cayuensis to species level, as C. cayuensis. These authors also removed Gymnodactylus himalayicus from synonymy with C. khasiensis.
This species is genetically highly variable and may represent a species complex (De Pous et al. 2015).
There are questions on whether Aipysurus pooleorum is a distinct species as many of the morphological characters mentioned are overlapping with A. laevis (Mirtschin et al. 2017).

This species was formerly known as Lapemis curtus, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.

Hydrophis curtus is sometimes regarded as two species, H. curtus occurring in the Indian Ocean and H. hardwickii occurring in southeast Asia and Australasia (Smith 1926, Cogger 2000). This division is not supported by morphological analyses based on large numbers of individuals from populations throughout the species’ geographic range (Gritis and Voris 1990). However, molecular data show a deep divergence between clades of H. curtus in the Indian Ocean versus the West Pacific (Ukuwela et al. 2014). Further work is required to confirm the identity of this species across its range, and at present, a single species, H. curtus, is maintained.

This is a newly described species split from the former Naja (Boulengerina) melanoleuca complex based on an an analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear gene sequences and morphological data (Wüster et al. 2018).

.An analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear gene sequences plus morphological data (Wüster et al. 2018) has solved the long-standing uncertainty surrounding the Naja melanoleuca ‘species complex’. This is now shown  to contain five distinct species: a more restricted N. melanoleuca; N. guineensis (western Africa); N. savannula (savanna parts of western and central Africa); N. peroescobari (endemic to the island of São Tomé); and N. subfulva (central to northeast and Africa and southwards to Angola in the west and South Africa in the east). Wüster et al. (2018) note that this work did not encompass the full range of morphological variation known in N. subfulva, the most wide-ranging member of the complex, and that additional cryptic diversity may exist within this taxon.

This is a newly described species split from the former Naja (Boulengerina) melanoleuca complex based on an an analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear gene sequences and morphological data (Wüster et al. 2018).

McDowell (1972) first mentioned a specimen from Sepik River, East Sepik District, New Guinea (AMNH 104340) that was very similar to the ‘beaked sea snake’, Hydrophis schistosus, but showed some morphological characters which were not in accordance with H. schistosus. Later, Kharin (1985) described a new species, Enhydrina zweifeli, based on McDowell´s (1972) data. The morphological similarity between E. zweifeli and H. schistosus is striking. However, a recently published paper (Ukuwela et al. 2012) presented molecular evidence showing the two species represent distinct lineages and are not each other’s closest relatives, indicating convergent phenotypic evolution probably related to a specialist diet of large, spiny prey (Ukuwela et al. 2012). See also Rasmussen et al. (2014).

A phylogenetic study of 39 Sea Snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013).

authority: Rodrigues, Cassimiro, De Freitas & Santos Silva, 2009

taxonomicNotes:
Two subspecies are recognized:
P. cordylinum cordylinum Tschudi, 1847
P. cordylinum champsonotus (Werner, 1910).
No taxonomic issues. Pietersen et al. (2018) elevated A. fitzsimonsi to specific status.

authority: Rodrigues, Camacho, Sales Nunes, Sousa Recoder, Teixeira Jr., Valdujo, Ghellere, Mott & Nogueira, 2008
Rodrigues, Xavier Freire, Machado Pellegrino & Sites, 2005
Rodrigues, Cassimiro, Pavan, Curcio, Kruth Verdade & Machado Pellegrino, 2009
(Colli, Caldwell, Costa, Gainsbury, Garda, Mesquita, Filho, Soares, Silva, Valdujo, Vieira, Vitt, Werneck & Widerhecker, 2003)

taxonomicNotes:
Melnikov et al. (2014) recognized four species within what was previously considered Phrynocephalus arabicus, elevating the two recognized subspecies (P. a. macropeltis and P. a. nedjensis) to species level, and describing a new species from Iran: P. ahvazicus. The Reptile Database (Uetz et al. 2018) describes the description of the new species as "rather confusing" due to a lack of clarity about the tissue samples used and inconsistencies between the number of specimens studied and those reported in their results. Melnikov et al. (2014) do not formally redescribe P. arabicus or fully diagnose or characterize the distributions of P. macropeltis or P. nedjensis. Additionally, the authors report that morphological differentiation between P. arabicus and P. macropeltis requires further investigation.

The Reptile Database (Uetz et al. 2018) consequently currently recommends rejecting the action of Melnikov et al. (2014) pending further research, and this scheme is followed here. Although Uetz et al. (2018) treat P. ahvazicus as a valid species, recognizing it as distinct would render P. arabicus sensu lato paraphyletic based on the molecular results presented by Melnikov et al. (2014). P. ahvazicus is consequently retained within P. arabicus here.
Originally treated under the genus Typhlops (Broadley and Wallach 2009) and later transferred to Afrotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

This species has been placed in several different genera in the past, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.

A recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.

There are three forms of this species (Smith 1926).

This species has often been confused with G. deccanensis and has only recently been resurrected from its synonymy by Bauer and Giri (2004).  Species of Geckoella are sometimes allocated to the genus Cyrtodactylus.  Molecular phylogenetic data reveal that Geckoella is embedded within Cyrtodactylus, and this placement is now widely accepted and hence followed here.

Cyrtodactylus deccanensis was described by Günther in 1864 based on specimens collected from Deccan (Smith 1935, Bauer and Giri 2004).  This species has often been confused with C. albofasciatus and the latter has only recently been resurrected from its synonymy by Bauer and Giri (2004).  Molecular phylogenetic data reveal that Geckoella is embedded within Cyrtodactylus, and this placement is now widely accepted and hence followed here.

Falk (1925) proposed the name Acanthosaura cyanocephala for an agamid species he observed in Angola, should this prove to be an unknown taxon. He did not, however, fully describe this taxon nor did he preserve the holotype. Wagner et al. (2018) determined that this name was validly published, and is consequently the oldest available name for the western-most member of the Acanthosaura atricollis complex. Wagner et al. (2018) consequently designated a Neotype for and redescribed A. cyanocephalus, which is now recognized as a full species.

Wagner et al. (2018) resurrected Acanthosaurus gregorii from synonymy within A. atricollis, and found that A. loveridgei - formerly a junior synonym of A. atricollis - represents a morphotype of A. gregorii.
In their revision of the Acanthocercus atricollis species complex, Wagner et al. (2018) elevated this former subspecies to specific status, and clarified its range limits.
In their revision of the Acanthocercus atricollis species complex, Wagner et al. (2018) elevated this former subspecies to specific status, and clarified its range limits.
In their revision of the Acanthocercus atricollis species complex, Wagner et al. (2018) elevated this former subspecies to specific status, and clarified its range limits.

authority: Siler, Heitz, Davis, Freitas, Aowphol, Termprayoon & Grismer, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Genetic and morphological research identified three geographically distinct evolutionary lineages within the widespread Lygosoma quadrupes, corresponding to the recently-recognized Philippine form L. tabonorum (Heitz et al. 2016), a taxon restricted to Java to which the name L. quadrupes is applicable, and a lineage found throughout the Southeast Asian mainland (Siler et al. 2018). This latter taxon, representing the major part of the former range of L. quadrupes, was described as the new species L. siamensis by Siler et al. (2018). This description was based on material from Thailand, and these authors recommend further studies to resolve species and distributional limits within L. siamensis as presently understood across Thailand and Indochina. Pending this further work, this account provisionally treats all Asian mainland records of L. quadrupes as being referrable to L. siamensis.

authority: Heitz, Diesmos, Freitas, Ellsworth, Grismer, Aowphol, Brown and Siler, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Heitz et al. (2016) coined the name Lygosoma tabonorum for Philippine populations then contained within Lygosoma quadrupes, on the basis of both genetic and morphological evidence. A subsequent revision of the L. quadrupes complex supported recognition of L. tabonorum as a distinct species (Siler et al. 2018).

The single known specimen of Lygosoma schneideri was synonymized with Lygosoma bampfyldei by Boulenger (1912). Grismer et al. (2018) re-examined this specimen during a revision of the taxonomy of L. bampfyldei and identified differences between the holotypes of the two species. These authors consequently resurrected L. schneideri from synonymy.

The name Erythrolamprus epinephelus as presently understood encompasses a widespread complex of snakes that probably contains "at least three or four", possibly unrelated, clades (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2018).
A record of Pseudogonatodes manessi from the Peninsula de Paria has been found to represent a distinct, undescribed species in a recent genetic analysis (M. Jowers unpubl. data).

authority: Rodrigues, Pellegrino, Dixo, Verdade, Pavan, Argolo & Sites, 2007

taxonomicNotes: Was under Iguanidae.

Monopeltis mauricei was described from near Ghanzi, Botswana by Parker (1935) but later treated as a subspecies of M. sphenorhynchus by Broadley et al. (1976). Subsequently, when he recorded the first specimen of the typical form Botswana, Broadley (2001) elevated M. s. mauricei to specific status. This arrangement was followed by Gans (2005), but genetic support is needed.

Numerous recent, comprehensive molecular phylogenetic studies have firmly established that Agama anchietae is a distinct species within the southern African Agamids clade, and is most closely related to A. atra (Matthee and Flemming 2002, Swart et al. 2008, Leache et al. 2009, 2014). Unpublished data recovered three distinct, structured populations across their distribution but further analysis is required before any taxonomic adjustments are made (Nielsen 2016). Although readily diagnosable to the practiced eye, this taxon is occasionally confused with related species with overlapping distributions (e.g. A. atra, A. hispida and A. a. aculeata).

Broadley et al. (1976) considered Monopeltis decosteri to be a synonym of M. capensis, referable to Group C (Broadley et al. 1976) . However, a subsequent revision by Broadley (1997) revived M. decosteri as a full species. The entire M. capensis group requires a taxonomic investigation within a phylogenetic framework because morphological traits appear to be very variable.
Broadley (1997) elevated Monopeltis capensis capensis Group B to species status as M. infuscata. The taxonomy of the entire group will be improved by a systematic revision using molecular methods.

Broadley and Broadley (1997) recognized two subspecies, Zygaspis vandami vandami and Z. v. arenicola, differing only with regard to the number of postoculars and the fusion of temporal head shields. Gans (2005) recognized these as separate species, although with no justification. Bates et al. (2018) subsequently evaluated the taxonomic status of the two subspecies, and on the basis of differences in geographic range and ecology, as well as the recognized morphological differences, formally proposed recognizing Zygaspis arenicola as a distinct species applying an evolutionary species concept.
There are no known taxonomic issues.

Stanley et al. (2011) recognised the subspecies Chamaesaura anguina tenuior from Rwanda, Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania and eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo as a full species. The relationship between the other two subspecies, C. anguina and C. anguina oligopholis remains problematic and requires investigation in a phylogenetic framework.

Jacobsen (1989) was of the opinion that this taxon is conspecific with Cordylus tropidosternum. However, a recent molecular phylogeny (Stanley et al. 2011) indicated that the two species are not closely related.

Broadley and Baldwin (2006) referred Aspidelaps lubricus infuscatus to the synonymy of A. lubricus cowlesi (Namibia and southwestern Angola). However, relationships between the subspecies should be investigated in a molecular phylogenetic framework.

Three subspecies are recognised, namely Aspidelaps scutatus scutatus, A. s. intermedius and A. s. fulafula. According to Broadley and Baldwin (2006), the latter two subspecies may together represent a single species (A. s. fulafula is the older name) separate from A. s. scutatus. It is unclear if distributions of the subspecies are allopatric and a phylogenetic analysis is needed to verify if there is any subspecies or species level structure.

The various subspecies of Elapsoidea sundevallii have overlapping morphological characters making them difficult to distinguish morphologically. There is therefore a need to investigate their status by means of a molecular phylogenetic analysis.

Naja nigricollis and N. nigricincta are considered as separate species (Uetz et al. 2021), with the latter also consisting of subspecies (N. nigricincta nigricincta and N. n. woodi). Wüster et al. (2007) considered all three taxa as subspecies of Naja nigricollis (N. nigricollis nigricollis, N. n. nigricincta, N. n. woodi), although they cautioned that the taxonomy of the N. nigricollis-nigricincta complex still requires further study. This assessment follows the taxonomy of Uetz et al. (2021) in recognising Naja nigricollis and N. nigricincta as full species, and N. nigricincta woodi as a subspecies. Only the subspecies Naja nigricincta woodi occurs in South Africa.

The taxonomic status of the various disjunct populations of this species should be investigated. Afroedura loveridgei was formerly considered as a subspecies of A. transvaalica (Onderstall 1984) but has since been elevated to specific status (Branch 1998).

Jacobsen et al. (2014) found relatively deep sequence divergences among localities, with samples from Limpopo clustered with those from southern Zimbabwe, while northern Zimbabwe populations were more distinct. They also noted: "Previous interpretations of distributional data for this taxon reflected three disjunct populations (e.g. Onderstall 1984, Branch 1998), however, more complete sampling across Zimbabwe suggests that there may be no significant gaps between these (D.G. Broadley pers. comm.).

Previously treated as Pachydactylus bibronii (FitzSimons 1943, Branch 1998), but transferred to the genus Chondrodactylus by Bauer and Lamb (2005). Confusion with C. turneri (previously Pachydactylus laevigatus) was resolved by Benyr (1995).

Broadley et al. (2014) showed that Homopholis wahlbergii arnoldi is a full species and resurrected it from the synonomy of H. wahlbergii. Homopholis arnoldi is usually distinguishable by a distinct dark dorsolateral stripe on either side of the body.

This taxon was treated as a subspecies of Lygodactylus capensis by FitzSimons (1943), as a synonym of the same species by Loveridge (1947), and revived as a full species by Pasteur (1965). The molecular phylogeny of Röll et al. (2010) showed that L. bradfieldi and L. capensis are separate species. Due to this long confusion the identity of many records in Angola (and presumably elsewhere), including recent reports from Huíla Province, remains in need of clarification as they may refer to either L. bradfieldi or L. capensis (Butler et al. 2019).
The identity and taxonomic status of the "relict" subpopulation at Lillie Nature Reserve in Limpopo Province, South Africa needs to be clarified (Jacobsen 1989).

FitzSimons (1943) and Loveridge (1947) regarded Pachydactylus capensis as a polytypic species with many subspecies. Subsequently Broadley (1971, 1977), Branch (1988, 1998), and Jacobsen (1989) elevated these subspecies, resulting in a monotypic P. capensis. Earlier records of this species from both the west coast and northeast of South Africa require individual confirmation, because specimens referable to P. labialis, P. affinis and P. vansoni were often identified as P. capensis. There is still confusion with respect to specific identity within the P. capensis group due to gross morphological similarities. This applies particularly to P. capensis and P. affinis, which occur in sympatry throughout much of the range of the latter (Jacobsen 1989). Some juvenile P. capensis have distinctive head markings that are similar to those of P. vansoni and this may also lead to misidentifications.

This species is part of the Pachydactylus serval group (Bauer et al. 2006). Older references to P. serval and P. onscepensis from the lower Orange River valley west of Goodhouse (e.g. McLachlan and Spence 1966) may be referable to P. carinatus. The identity of a population of geckos at Koboop near Onseepkans, tentatively referred to P. carinatus by Bauer et al. (2006), requires verification.

This species was previously confused with Pachydactylus namaquensis (Branch et al. 1996, Bauer and Branch 2003 [2001]). Most old records of P. namaquensis from Namibia and the Orange River valley are almost certainly referable to P. haackei.

This species has often been considered as a subspecies of Pachydactylus mariquensis (e.g. Loveridge 1947, Branch 1998), but consistent morphological differences in cephalic scalation, as well as molecular differences, support its specific distinctness (Bauer et al. 2011). The identification of older specimens from areas of sympatry and near sympatry with P. mariquensis should be confirmed.

This species is part of the Pachydactylus weberi group (Bauer et al. 2006). Some old records of P. weberi from the Richtersveld and adjacent southern Namibia may be referable to P. monicae (e.g. Bauer and Branch 2003 [2001]).

Until a recent revision (Bauer et al. 2006), this species was generally cited as Pachydactylus serval onscepensis following the work of McLachlan and Spence (1966). Many records of P. serval from the Northern Cape and southern Namibia are thus referable to P. montanus. Although there are no known diagnostic features that separate populations of P. montanus from the Onseepkans area from other populations, there is a large divergence in mitochondrial DNA (Bauer et al. 2006) and further taxonomic studies are warranted. Adult P. montanus are very similar in appearance to P. serval and also P. purcelli. Because P. montanus co-occurs with one or both of these congeners across most of its range, identifications of all specimens should be carefully checked. Further study of isolated populations in southern Namibia (30 km east of Aus; Farm Houmoed, Tirasberg Mountains) is warranted.

Bauer and Branch (1995) elevated the northwestern Namibian subspecies Pachydactylus punctatus scherzi to specific status, and considered all other subspecies and synonyms of P. punctatus as being referable to P. p. punctatus. However, they indicated that there was extensive geographically correlated colour pattern variation in the species and further study is required. Pachydactylus amoenoides has occasionally been considered as a valid species (Wermuth 1965) or subspecies of P. punctatus (Jacobsen 1989) from southwestern Namibia, but it was tentatively included in the synonymy of P. punctatus by Bauer and Branch (1995). A phylogeographic study of P. punctatus should be  undertaken.

Based on provisional results of the latter study, the name P. punctatus would apply to eastern populations, but P. amoenoides will need to be resurrected for Northern Cape populations.

Until recently, this taxon was treated as a subspecies of Pachydactylus serval based on the work of McLachlan and Spence (1966). The P. serval species complex was recently revised and elevated to species status (Bauer et al. 2006). Several literature references to P. serval in South Africa are actually based on P. purcelli. Adults are very similar to those of the closely related P. serval and P. montanus, and the identity of specimens from areas of sympatry or near-sympatry (both sides of the Orange River between Goodhouse and Kakamas, and the Karasberg Mountains in Namibia) must be carefully checked.

Prior to the elevation of Pachydactylus barnardi and P. formosus from subspecific status within P. rugosus (Lamb and Bauer 2000), some references to P. rugosus from the western portions of the Western and Northern Cape actually refer to these other species.
Broadley (1977) elevated Pachydactylus tigrinus to full specific status within the P. capensis group, and also established its synonymy with P. rhodesianus.

This species is part of the Pachydactylus weberi group (Bauer et al. 2006). Some earlier references to, and photographs of, P. weberi from the lower Orange River and the Fish River Canyon are, at least in part, referable to this species (Branch 1988, 1994, 1998; Bauer and Branch 2003 [2001]; Bauer and Lamb 2005).

Trinomials have been used since FitzSimons (1935) treated Ptenopus maculatus Gray, 1865 as a subspecies of P. garrulus (Brain 1962, Haacke 1975). A phylogeographic survey of this wide-ranging species may reveal intraspecific diversity.

authority: Kieckbusch, Mecke, Hartmann, Ehrmantraut, O’Shea & Kaiser, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This species was identified as distinct during an ongoing revision of the widespread Cylindrophis ruffus species complex (Kieckbusch et al. 2016).
This species was described from specimens that had been confused with Cylindrophis melanotus (Kieckbusch et al. 2018).

A revision of the Draco fimbriatus species group is presently underway (J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017). This work indicates that this group contains five species-level taxa: D. cristatellus, the species presently known as D. fimbriatus and D. abbreviatus, D. maculatus and D. henningi Musters, 1983 (presently a junior synonym of D. fimbriatus) (McGuire et al.2018).

McGuire et al. (2018) report that this work will necessitate nomenclatural changes to the species traditionally known as Draco fimbriatus, with the result that this name should be considered a senior synonym of Draco abbreviatus, and the name Draco punctatus Boulenger 1900 (whose complex taxonomic history is discussed in detail by McGuire et al. 2018) is available for the taxon previously known as D. fimbriatus.

This assessment accepts the scheme proposed by McGuire et al. (2018) for consistency with this source's revision of D. cristatellus and to limit the possibility of confusion resulting from forthcoming nomenclatural changes.
In a revision of Stegonotus, Kaiser et al. (2018) removed Lycodon aruensis from synonymy with S. modestus on morphological and biogeographic grounds.

In a revision of Stegonotus, Kaiser et al. (2018) removed Lycodon lividum from synonymy with S. modestus on biogeographic grounds. These authors note that this species can however not be adequately characterized morphologically as only two specimens were available for study, although they report that it is morphologically distinct from the similarly poorly-known S. florensis.
In a revision of Stegonotus, Kaiser et al. (2018) removed Lycodon keyensis from synonymy with S. cucullatus on morphological and biogeographic grounds.
This species was removed from synonymy with Stegonotus florensis on morphological and biogeographic grounds by Kaiser et al. (2018).

authority: Ruane, Richards, McVay, Tjaturadi, Krey & Austin 2017
Ruane, Richards, McVay, Tjaturadi, Krey & Austin 2017

taxonomicNotes: Alexander (1987) suggested that the subspecies Philothamnus natalensis occidentalis be elevated to full species status based on morphological and behavioural differences between it and Philothamnus natalensis natalensis. This has been confirmed by a phylogenetic analysis (Engelbrecht et al. 2019). It is easily confused with Philothamnus natalensis and P. hoplogaster because of superficial similarities in general appearance and behaviour.

The identity of Calumma linotum, a nasutum-group member described from the imprecise locality "Madagascar", was particularly unclear until its taxonomy was recently revised by Prötzel et al. (2015). Until recently, there was confusion over the status of Calumma linotum and C. boettgeri. A molecular phylogenetic approach and a taxonomic revision have provided the resolution needed to understand the complex systematics of this group (Gehring et al. 2012, Prötzel et al. 2015), and the northern populations (from Montagne d’Ambre  and Andampy in the Tsaratanana massif ) are now understood to be C. linotum, with C. boettgeri restricted to the Sambirano region of Madagascar (Prötzel et al. 2015).

Until recently, there was confusion over the status of Calumma boettgeri and C. linotum. A molecular phylogenetic approach and a taxonomic revision have provided the resolution needed to understand the complex systematics of this group (Gehring et al. 2012, Prötzel et al. 2015), and the northern populations (from Montagne d’Ambre  and Andampy in the Tsaratanana massif ) are now understood to be C. linotum, with C. boettgeri distributed in the Sambirano region of Madagascar (Prötzel et al. 2015).

Bachia alleni has variously been treated as a subspecies of B. heteropa (Dixon 1973) or a full species (Donoso-Barros 1968) in historical literature. It was re-elevated to specific status by Kohlsdorf and Wagner (2006) and this was accepted by Henderson and Powell (2018), but its relationship with a form found in Trinidad and Tobago (treated as the subspecies B. h. triniatis or B. a. trinitatis) remained unresolved. Murphy et al. (in press) revised the B. heteropa complex using both morphological and molecular data, confirming that B. alleni from Grenada and the Grenadines is distinct from both B. heteropa and B. trinitatis. These authors note that the taxonomic status of two specimens from Bequia Island requires further investigation, but these are provisionally retained within B. alleni here following Murphy et al. (2019). These authors also examined the status of the neglected name Scolecosaurus alleni parviceps, and concluded that pending further research it should be considered a junior synonym of B. alleni. Murphy et al. (2019) also discuss the nomenclatural history of Brachypus cuvieri Fitzinger 1826, an enigmatic name that may represent a senior synonym of either B. alleni or B. trinitatis, and propose that B. cuvieri should be considered a nomen dubium due to uncertainty over the true identity of this specimen.

authority: Murphy, Salvi, Santos, Braswell, Charles, Borrzee & Jowers, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species was described by Murphy et al. (2019) based on specimens previously identified as hybrids between Bachia heteropa heteropa and B. h. trinitatis.
Murphy et al. (2019) elevated Bachia marcelae, previously a subspecies of B. heteropa, to a full species based on morphological differences.

authority: Murphy, Salvi, Santos, Braswell, Charles, Borrzee & Jowers, 2019
taxonomicNotes: Murphy et al. (2019) described Bachia whitei based on specimens from Tobago previously assigned to B. flavescens.

Murphy et al. (2019) elevated Bachia lineata, previously a subspecies of B. heteropa, to a full species based on morphological differences. These authors uphold the action by Burt and Burt (1933) in regarding B. anomala as a junior synonym of B. lineata in the absence of sufficient morphological data to reevaluate its taxonomic status, but suspect that it may warrant recognition as a separate species as first proposed by Shreve (1947).

This species has two subspecies:
Leiocephalus melanochlorus melanochlorus Cope, 1863
Leiocephalus m. hysistus Schwartz, 1965.

The taxonomic status of Draco norvilii was considered doubtful by Musters (1983), who elected to treat it as a subspecies of Draco blanfordii. McGuire et al. (2001), in an evaluation of Draco systematics based on mitochondrial DNA, explicitly refrained from making a judgment on this issue. This taxon has more recently been accepted as a full species (e.g. Manthey 2010, Islam and Saikia 2013), but it is not clear that any formal action has been taken to justify this treatment. J. McGuire (pers. comm. 2019) notes that this species cannot reliably be distinguished from D. blanfordii and suspects that it is unlikely to be valid either as a species or subspecies, however cautions that further material is needed to resolve this issue.

This species, together with other helmeted terrapins throughout sub-Saharan Africa, Madagascar and the southwestern Arabian Peninsula, were previously combined under the name Pelomedusa subrufa. Phylogenetic evidence indicates that P. galeata in western South Africa represents a separate lineage and a possible candidate new species (Petzold et al. 2014, Fritz et al. 2015).

authority: Edwards, Karl, Vaughn, Rosen, Meléndez Torres & Murphy, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Gopherus evgoodei was previously considered to be part of Gopherus morafkai, but was demonstrated to be morphologically and genetically distinct by Edwards et al. (2016). Both these species were previously considered to be part of Gopherus agassizii sensu lato, the Desert Tortoise. This taxonomy has been accepted by TTWG (2017).

The species Acanthochelys chacoensis (Fritz and Pauler 1992) was included in the 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists, was been determined by Fritz and Pauler (1999) to be a junior synonym of A. macrocephala.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy was largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises, while synonymizing the four central and southern Isabela Island populations (vicina, guntheri, microphyes, and vandenburghi) under C. vicina. However, TTWG (2017) and this Red List assessment now treat these four Isabela Island taxa, previously treated as subspecies of vicina, as separate and valid species, rather than retaining their previous rankings.

The taxonomy of the C. vicina species complex remains less resolved than for other Galápagos taxa, with four taxa on central (microphyes, vandenburghi) and southern (guntheri, vicina) Isabela treated here as a series of four recognized species. These most recently diverged lineages may not have been completely sorted into reciprocally monophyletic clades in terms of mitochondrial DNA data, although their nuclear gene pools are distinct (Ciofi et al. 2006, Poulakakis et al. 2008, Edwards et al. 2014). They may possibly represent subspecies or Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) rather than full species (Edwards et al. 2014). TTWG (2009, 2014), following Pritchard (1996), synonymized these four taxa under C. vicina, but in consideration of the majority of the assessors’ view that they may be full species, TTWG (2017) and the Red List now treats them as separate species.

Tortoises from southern Isabela Island have also been referred to as C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) vicina for the southwestern Cerro Azul population and C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) guentheri or C. (n.) guntheri for the southeastern Sierra Negra subpopulation. The guentheri and guntheri names have previously either been considered nomina dubia and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology. Tortoises from Darwin Volcano on north central Isabela have historically been recognized as C. (n.) microphyes, a name that has previously been considered either a nomen dubium and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology (review by Pritchard 1996). Tortoises from Alcedo Volcano on central Isabela have traditionally been recognized as C. (n.) vandenburghi, but were previously synonymized under C. (n.) vicina based on morphology (Pritchard 1996; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2009, 2014).

All these taxa have in the past variously been argued to be valid at species or subspecies level (under either elephantopus and/or nigra), and placed in the genera Testudo, Geochelone, or Chelonoidis, and these permutations, plus a variety of typographic errors, have yielded over 50 nomenclatural combinations and chresonyms.

The previous Red List assessments for Galápagos tortoises treated the various allopatric island populations as subspecies of Chelonoidis nigra (now named Chelonoidis niger), as did several authors (Pritchard 1996, Caccone et al. 1999, Beheregaray et al. 2003, Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2007, Rhodin et al. 2008). However, other authors have considered them as full species based on morphology (Bour 1980, Fritts 1983, Ernst and Barbour 1989) and the more recent consensus among researchers (Caccone et al. 2002; Russello et al. 2005, 2007; Poulakakis et al. 2008, 2012, 2015; Chiari et al. 2009) is to treat most as full species based on congruent patterns of mitochondrial and nuclear variation. This elevated species-level taxonomy was largely accepted by TTWG (2009, 2014) and TEWG (2015) for most, but not all, phylogenetic lineages of Galápagos tortoises, while synonymizing the four central and southern Isabela Island populations (vicina, guntheri, microphyes, and vandenburghi) under C. vicina. However, TTWG (2017) and this Red List assessment now treat these four Isabela Island taxa, previously treated as subspecies of vicina, as separate and valid species, rather than retaining their previous rankings.

The taxonomy of the C. vicina species complex remains less resolved than for other Galápagos taxa, with four taxa on central (microphyes, vandenburghi) and southern (guntheri, vicina) Isabela treated here as a series of four recognized species. These most recently diverged lineages may not have been completely sorted into reciprocally monophyletic clades in terms of mitochondrial DNA data, although their nuclear gene pools are distinct (Ciofi et al. 2006, Poulakakis et al. 2008, Edwards et al. 2014). They may possibly represent subspecies or Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) rather than full species (Edwards et al. 2014). TTWG (2009, 2014), following Pritchard (1996), synonymized these four taxa under C. vicina, but in consideration of the majority of the assessors’ view that they may be full species, TTWG (2017) and the Red List now treats them as separate species.

Tortoises from southern Isabela Island have also been referred to as C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) vicina for the southwestern Cerro Azul population and C. (n.) elephantopus or C. (n.) guentheri or C. (n.) guntheri for the southeastern Sierra Negra subpopulation. The guentheri and guntheri names have previously either been considered nomina dubia and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology. Tortoises from Darwin Volcano on north central Isabela have historically been recognized as C. (n.) microphyes, a name that has previously been considered either a nomen dubium and referred to vicina based on type locality, or synonymized under C. (n.) vicina by morphology (review by Pritchard 1996). Tortoises from Alcedo Volcano on central Isabela have traditionally been recognized as C. (n.) vandenburghi, but were previously synonymized under C. (n.) vicina based on morphology (Pritchard 1996; Fritz and Havas 2007; TTWG 2009, 2014).

All these taxa have in the past variously been argued to be valid at species or subspecies level (under either elephantopus and/or nigra), and placed in the genera Testudo, Geochelone, or Chelonoidis, and these permutations, plus a variety of typographic errors, have yielded over 50 nomenclatural combinations and chresonyms.

This widespread species has the following subspecies:
Leiocephalus carinatus carinatus Gray, 1827,
Leiocephalus carinatus aquarius Schwartz & Ogren, 1956,
Leiocephalus carinatus armouri Barbour & Shreve, 1935,
Leiocephalus carinatus cayensis Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus coryi Schmidt, 1936,
Leiocephalus carinatus granti Rabb, 1957,
Leiocephalus carinatus hodsdoni Schmidt, 1936,
Leiocephalus carinatus labrossytus Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus microcyon Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus mogotensis Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus virescens Stejneger, 1901, and
Leiocephalus carinatus zayasi Schwartz, 1959.

L. varius, previously considered a subspecies, is treated as a full species following McCranie (2015).

The assignment of specimens to this species has been complicated by the brevity of the original description and only three verifiable specimens have been reported in the last 124 years, one of which has since been lost (see discussion in Grismer et al. 2018). Following the collection of new material allied to Lygosoma bampfyldei from Peninsular Malaysia, Grismer et al. (2018) evaluated the taxonomic status of every known specimen and determined (on morphological grounds, as insufficient specimens are known to conduct a meaningful genetic analysis) that they corresponded to four discrete populations. These authors considered that, given the observed morphological differences, "it would require more ad hoc justification to consider the variation ... as simply conspecific geographic variation within Lygosoma bampfyldei than it would to consider them all different species", and consequently presented a revised taxonomy for the L. bampfyldei group.

The appropriate generic name for Lygosoma tryoni is subject to some dispute. Skinner et al. (2013) erected the genus Silvascincus for this species and L. tryoni (at that time both included within Eulamprus) as part of a wide-ranging effort to resolve paraphyly among Australian sphenomorphine skinks. They have alternatively been included within Concinnia (Cogger 2014) or Karma. This latter name was coined by Wells (2009), and as such Silvascincus is a junior synonym (Cogger 2014). There is, however, controversy over the acceptance of Karma as a valid name (Kaiser et al. 2013, Cogger et al. 2014). These accounts take the conservative approach of retaining both of these species, and the related E. luteilateralis, within Eulamprus pending resolution of both nomenclatural issues and relationships between these taxa, as genetic and morphological data are "not yet fully in agreement" (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
There are no taxonomic issues.

Wickramasinghe et al. (2019) described a new species, Aspidura desilvai sp. nov., closely resembling A. trachyprocta and the last addition to the genus, from Knuckles massif, Matale District, of Sri Lanka.

This species was elevated from a subspecies of Chironius fuscus by Hollis (2006) based on diagnostic morphological features, but this author did not formally redescribe the species. Torres-Carvajal et al. (2019) fully redescribed this species, identifying further morphological differences.
The status of the isolated subpopulation of this species in Maputaland and adjacent southern Mozambique should be assessed.

The species is widespread and shows some morphological variability across its range. The possibility of significant population structuring and the presence of cryptic species should be investigated, particularly in the vicinity of the lower Orange River (Bauer and Branch 2003 [2001], Branch et al. 2006).
A disjunct population in eastern Namibia (de Waal 1978, Branch 1998) was incorrectly attributed to this taxon (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019).

Previous assessments of the Nucras tesellata complex, which includes N. intertexta, presented various morphological characters to distinguish between the taxa (Broadley 1972, Jacobsen 1989, Bates 1996). A molecular phylogeny of Nucras confirmed the species status of N. intertexta, which is the sister species of N. ornata (Edwards et al. 2013).

The Nucras tesselata complex was last revised by Broadley (1972), who recognized three subspecies (N. t. tessellata, N. t. livida and an unnamed subspecies of N. tessellata). Apart from typical N. t. tessellata, Broadley (1972) also recognized two varieties (N. t. tessellata var. elegans and N. t. tessellata var. 'T'). Although N. t. livida was subsequently elevated to species level (Branch and Bauer 1995), the taxonomic status of the two varieties and the unnamed subspecies remain unresolved. A molecular phylogeny of Nucras confirmed the species status of N. tessellata, which is the sister species of N. taeniolata (Edwards et al. 2013), but a detailed molecular investigation of N. tessellata is still needed.  At present, Nucras tessellata includes the two varieties but excludes the supposed Angolan subspecies which, considering its vast geographical separation from other conspecifics represents a separate species. This has been confirmed by a recent study of the group (Branch et al. 2019).

Pedioplanis inornata is paraphyletic with respect to P. gaerdesi, with a clade from northern Namibia and another from southern Namibia and the Northern Cape. These two clades represent two different species (Makokha et al. 2007).

There has been confusion regarding the subspecies (Pedioplanis lineoocellata lineoocellata, P. lineoocellata pulchella, P. lineoocellata inocellata). The ranges are overlapping (see Bates et al. 2014) and although Branch (1998) suggested there are morphological differences between the subspecies, a detailed study of the two South African subspecies P. lineoocellata lineoocellata, P. lineoocellata pulchella) could find no morphological differences to support the subspecies status (Edwards 2013). Although Makokha et al. (2007) suggested there were notable genetic differences between these subspecies, only a few localities were included in that study and the genetic structure was not deep. Sampling from multiple localities across the range of both subspecies suggest that while there is some geographic structuring, this does not match the subspecies and the subspecies as currently described should not be considered valid (Edwards 2013).

A molecular analysis indicated that Pedioplanis namaquensis consists of two distinct taxa, one in Namibia and the other in South Africa (Makokha et al. 2007), but their distributions are still unclear. Until further work can be done to resolve this issue, the taxon must be considered as a single species.
