This species was previously considered a subspecies of Lycodonomorphus whytii but raised to species status by Broadley (1995). The relationship between these two taxa should be investigated by means of a molecular phylogenetic analysis.

Broadley (1967) treated Lycodonomorphus rufulus mlanjensis as a subspecies of L. leleupi, rendering L. rufulus a monotypic species. Lycodonomorphus leleupi mlanjensis was later raised to species status by Broadley and Cotterill (2004). The status of the isolated population of L. rufulus on the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe, and phylogenetic relationships within the genus, require investigation (Bates et al. 2014).
Previously a subspecies of Prosymna sundevallii, but elevated to species status by Broadley (1999).

The taxonomic status of this species—which is part of the Psammophis ‘phillipsii’ species complex—has been investigated by Kelly et al. (2008). Psammophis brevirostris leopardinus from southern Angola and Namibia is now considered a valid species (Broadley 2002, validated by Kelly et al. 2008). The taxonomic status of several apparently relict populations in South Africa requires further assessment (Bates et al. 2014).
Last reviewed by Broadley (1968). Transferred from Typhlosaurus to Acontias by Lamb et al. (2010) on the basis of molecular phylogenetics.
A molecular study indicates that Acontias kgalagadi subtaeniatus is a valid species and this will necessitate the reevaluation of the taxonomic status for both taxa.

The genus Microacontias, to which this species had previously been assigned (Daniels et al. 2006), was synonymised with Acontias by Lamb et al. (2010) based on molecular phylogenetic results. Daniels et al. (2006) suggested that A. litoralis was derived from within a polytypic A. lineatus, making the latter paraphyletic. In a subsequent mitochondrial DNA phylogeny of the ‘Microacontias’ group (Janse van Vuuren 2009), the four currently recognized taxa in this clade were found to interdigitate in the phylogram. However, although all taxa were found to be identifiable morphologically, it was suggested that all subspecies of A. lineatus retain their status, with A. litoralis treated as a fourth subspecies of A. lineatus. The findings of Lamb et al. (2010) were similar to those of Daniels et al. (2006) and, on this basis and with regards to the diagnostic differences described by Broadley and Greer (1969), they elevated A. l. grayi and A. l. tristis to full species status, rendering A. lineatus monotypic.

Previously considered a subspecies of Acontias percivali, an East African species. Recent molecular phylogenetic studies (Daniels et al. 2006, Lamb et al. 2010) have revealed that Acontias occidentalis is closely related to A. percivali percivali, but not to A. percivali tasmani, which Lamb et al. (2010) synonymised with A. orientalis. Lamb et al. (2010) also formally elevated A. occidentalis to full species status based on morphological diagnosability (Broadley and Greer 1969) and the 1,700 km disjunction between this form and its East African sister taxon, rendering A. percivali a monotypic species.

Originally described as Typhlosaurus aurantiacus parietalis, subsequently transferred to Acontias by Lamb et al. (2010). All five subspecies of Acontias aurantiacus recognized by Broadley (1968, 1990) may represent valid species (Pietersen et al. 2018). Pietersen et al. (2018) elevated A. parietalis and A. fitzsimonsi to specific status. Although KwaZulu-Natal populations of this species have been referred to A. a. aurantiacus (e.g. Branch 1998), Broadley (1990) clarified that these, along with specimens from Inhaca Island, Mozambique, were referable to A. parietalis, with the former taxon restricted to southern coastal Mozambique.

Panaspis maculicollis was first recognized by Jacobsen (1989) as a cryptic species related to P. wahlbergii, and was described by Jacobsen and Broadley (2000) based on differences in the average number of scale rows at mid-body, body patterning (particularly on the neck) and male colouration during the breeding season. Older specimen records and pre-2000 references to P. wahlbergii should be carefully checked using the key provided by Jacobsen and Broadley (2000). In a recent phylogentic study of the Panaspis group, previous unknown cryptic diversity was documented (Medina et al. 2016). According to Medina et al. (2016), 'P. maculicollis' group is comprised of at least two cryptic species. Further taxonomic work is needed to describe the above cryptic diversity.

The species was last reviewed by Broadley (1994). Bauer (2016) provided evidence that Scelotes bicolor is a synonym of S. arenicola and clarified that the specific epithet is indeed “arenicola”, despite the fact that Scelotes is masculine.

Two subspecies of Scelotes limpopoensis are currently recognized, namely S. l. limpopoensis and S. l. albiventris, with sympatric distributions. Phylogenetic investigations are needed to determine taxon boundaries and the taxonomic status of these two forms.
Currently no notable issues with this species, but due to its large distribution there are potentially cryptic species.

There are several cryptic species within the taxon formerly recognized as Trachylepis varia (Weinell and Bauer 2018). Petters (1870) described Euprepes damarana from Damaraland, which was subsequently synonymised with Trachylepis varia. Based on genetics, lepidosis and colouration Weinell and Bauer (2018) reinstated this species to full status.
Trachylepis sparsa differs from T. punctatissima in both morphology and coloration, but is not genetically distinct. It may therefore not be a valid species.

Three poorly defined subspecies of Trachylepis sulcata have been recognized, namely T. s. sulcata, T. s. ansorgii and T. s. nigra (Bauer et al. 1993, Branch 1998). In a molecular study, T. s. nigra-from Lüderitz, Namibia was found to be merely a melanistic form which is not genetically distinct from the nominate subspecies (Portik et al. 2010, 2011). Trachylepis s. ansorgii occurs in Angola (Bauer et al. 1993, Portik 2009).

Bitis schneideri was revived from synonymy with Bitis caudalis by Haacke (1975). Recent phylogenetic analysis shows that B. caudalis is polyphyletic, with a southern clade related to B. schneideri and a northern clade related to B. peringueyi (Barlow et al. 2019). The relationship between subpopulations of B. schneideri on either side of the Orange River has not been investigated, but they are assumed to be a single taxon.

There is extensive confusion surrounding the identity of the species Lygosoma megalops, Sphenomorphus dorsicatenatus and Eutropis tammana. The collection localities of the original two syntypes of S. megalops were described as Kitulgala in the wet zone and Puttalam in the dry zone, but while the syntypes have been lost these specimens have long been suspected to correspond to two different species. Subsequently, Deraniyagala (1944) described Lankascincus dorsicatenatus (the holotype of which has also been lost) from the southern wet zone and Das et al. (2008) described a new species from Puttulam, Eutropis tammana. Based on presently understood concepts, all three species are difficult to distinguish from one another and it is likely that either the wet zone S. dorsicatenatus or the dry zone E. tammana represents a junior synonym of L. megalops. Due to the lack of clarity over the true identity of S. megalops and the presumption that the two syntypes are not conspecific, it is presently impossible to determine to which of these two species the name should refer, or indeed whether S. megalops represents a genuinely distinct taxon (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

In an effort to resolve confusion surrounding this species, Batuwita (2019) assigned a neotype to S. megalops based on material from Kitulgala, but this has served to generate further confusion and controversy. The selection of this type locality was justified only by the claim that "the only known Lankascincus from Puttulam is L. fallax", but this author did not discuss the status of Eutropis tammana (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Furthermore, he assigned a neotype for Lankascincus dorsicatenatus and redescribed it as a validly distinct species from his Lankascincus megalops, although recent molecular evidence suggests that material from the type locality of L. dorsicatenatus - which is close to Kitulgala - is conspecific with the Kitulgala form (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). On this basis, M. Wickramasiinghe (pers. comm. 2019) argues that recognizing L. megalops as a valid species from Kitulgala necessitates relegating L. dorsicatenatus to its synonymy.

It’s not clear if this species was properly published, as the paper lacks a Zoobank registration number and is poorly-presented (Uetz et al. 2019). V. Deepak (pers. comm. to P. Uetz 2018) suggests that it is likely to be a junior synonym of Sitana sivalensis.
Giri et al. (2017) described Rhabdops aquaticus to encompass northern populations of R. olivaceus found to be distinct on both genetic and morphological grounds
This species was previously confused with Cnemaspis kumarasinghei. It was found to be genetically distinct by Agarwal et al. (2017) and formally described by Batuwita et al. (2019).

authority: Karunarathna, Bauer, de Silva, Surasinghe, Somaratna, Madawala, Gabadage, Botejue, Henkanaththegedara & Ukuwela, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Similar populations in Bangladesh, about 100 km from the northernmost record of C. tripuraensis in the same area of continuous natural habitat, may represent this species but genetic research is required to confirm this assignment (Agarwal et al. 2018). Al-Razi et al. (2018) reported records from Kamalganj Upazila, Lawachara National Park in Bangladesh under the name C. tripuraensis and these are presently accepted here, but this identification was based on morphological characters and requires validation with molecular data (V. Giri pers. comm. 2019).

Smith (1935) examined available specimens of Cyrtodactylus “khasiensis” and Gymnodactylus himalayicus, concluding that the latter fell within the morphological range of his redefined C. khasiensis. As a result, Smith (1935) referred G. himalayicus to the synonymy of C. khasiensis. Agarwal et al. (2018) subsequently re-examined these specimens and concluded that G. himalayicus warrants recognition as a distinct species (as Cyrtodactylus himalayicus), with the caveat that the two known specimens are poorly-preserved and not all relevant taxonomic characters could be identified.
This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix.
This species has been also recently placed in the genera Elaphe and Rhadinophis.
The apparently isolated record of this species from Khammam, Telengana needs taxonomic validation (C. Srinivasulu and P. Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019).
This species was described from within Hemiphyllodactylus aurantiacus.
No notable taxonomic issues.
No notable taxonomic issues.
Accepted as Rhampholeon maspictus (Branch et al. 2014). No notable taxonomic issues.
Accepted as Rhampholeon nebulauctor (Branch et al. 2014). No notable taxonomic issues.

Rhampholeon tilburyi is found in the lower elevation forests on Mt Namuli. Phylogenetic analysis confirms that R. tilburyi is a separate taxon to an undescribed species (R. sp. nov. 'namuli2') that is found in the high elevation forests (K.A. Tolley unpub. data 2019). The holotype of R. tilburyi was collected from Ukalini Forest on Mt Namuli, but it was not included in the phyologenetic analysis that lead to the species description (Branch et al. 2014). The only material included was from the Cha Madal tea estate and these samples form a monophyletic clade with those from Ukalini Forest. Samples of Rhampholeon collected from Manho Forest, which is higher in elevation, are in a different clade (K.A. Tolley unpub. data 2019). Recent records from Mt Ribáuè, Mt Mepalué and Mt Socone were confirmed as Rhampholeon tilburyi using a phylogenetic analysis (K.A. Tolley unpub. data).
The phylogenetic relationship within Scolecoseps requires investigation.

The presence of an undescribed species of Dipsadoboa was first reported from Mount Mabu in 2008 (Bayliss et al. 2014). Newly collected material in subsequent surveys allowed phylogenetic analysis that confirmed it representeda new species, which was subsequently described as D. montisilva (Conradie et al. 2016, Branch et al. 2019). No further notable taxonomic issues.

The recent collection of new material of this taxon, previously treated as a subspecies of Psammophylax rhombeatus, enabled Branch et al. (2019) to evaluate its taxonomic status on both morphological and molecular grounds. These authors confirmed that this species should be recognized as a distinct species, while noting that the new material exhibits some character differences and was collected at different elevations from historical material.

There has been extensive taxonomic confusion within Chondrodactylus, which is the subject of ongoing research (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2020). Four taxa presently accepted as species - C. turneri, C. laevigatus, C. pulitzerae and C. fitzsimonsi (Uetz et al. 2019) - have all previously been treated as subspecies of a single widespread species under the name C. turneri or C. laevigatus. Genetic evidence suggests that taxonomic issues remain within C. laevigatus (Bauer et al. 2019). Due to a lack of clarity about range limits of these various taxa, which have been recognized as distinct based on phylogenetic work (Lamb and Bauer 2002, Bauer and Lamb 2005, Heinz et al. 2011), these assessments follow preliminary work presented by A. Bauer, T. Jackman and I. Brennan at conferences (pers. comm. 2020, Bauer et al. 2019), and for species other than C. turneri summarized by Marques et al. (2018).
This species represents Central African populations formerly assigned to Echis ocellatus (Trape 2018).

authority: Ceríaco, Soares, Marques, Bastos-Silveira, Scheinberg, Harris, Brehm & Jesus, 2018
Portillo, Branch, Tilbury, Nagy, Hughes, Kusamba, Muninga, Aristote, Behangana & Greenbaum, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been considered a subspecies of Rhoptropus boultoni, but molecular research indicates that this represents a distinct species (Kuhn 2016, Heinicke et al. 2017).

Trachylepis quiquetaeniata langheldi has widely been treated as a full species in recent literature and this scheme is followed here, although comparative research is needed to clarify that it is distinct from T. quinquetaeniata (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020). L. Chirio (pers. comm. 2020) reports that the two commonly co-occur in northern Cameroon, apparently within the same population, supporting the idea that T. langheldi is just a colour morph of T. quinquetaeniata.

This species has long been treated as a junior synonym of Cyrtodactylus marmoratus. Following a comparative examination of the holotypes of both taxa Rösler et al. (2007) revalidated C. agamensis, but Harvey et al. (2015) note that this action - in a German-language publication - was subsequently neglected. D.T. Iskandar (pers. comm. 2019) has confirmed that, while poorly-described, this is a validly distinct taxon.

This species was described from highland populations previously included within Trimeresurus sumatranus. Molecular studies are underway on this species, which was described based on morphological data (Awal pers. comm. 2019).  This species would be classified in the genus Parias under the revisions of Malhotra and Thorpe (2004).
There are no taxonomic issues.

Bertola et al. (2018) reported a population related to Phyllurus gulbaru from The Pinnacles, while recognising that this represented an evolutionarily significant unit whose taxonomic status was in need of further investigation. Subsequent morphological and molecular research confirmed that this population should be regarded as a distinct species despite moderately low mtDNA differentiation Hoskin et al. (2019), and these authors accordingly described it as the new species Phyllurus pinnaclensis.

Passos et al. (2018) synonymized Atractus limitaneus within Atractus collaris based on comparison of the type material of A. limitaneus and the description of A. collaris (for which the type has apparently been lost). These authors report that the state of one character distinguishing the two species is impossible to determine from the damaged A. limitaneus holotype, but note that this character is unlikely to be a reliable diagnostic feature. Atractus collaris as defined by Passos et al. (2018) is likely to exhibit some degree of divergence across its broad range, and a number of related species exhibit very restricted ranges. Passos et al. (2018) recommend further taxonomic studies at a higher resolution may be required to fully clarify the systematics of this species and to identify cryptic diversity.

Python bivittatus was recently recognized as a full species (Jacobs et al. 2009), having previously been considered a subspecies of P. molurus. The subspecies P. b. progschai has been erected to describe populations from Sulawesi (Jacobs et al. 2009).

Eiselt (1963) renamed Procteria viridis to Xenodon werneri, because X. viridis is preoccupied by Xenodon viridis Duméril & Bibron, 1854 (= Macropisthodon plumbicolor Cantor, 1839). Yuki (1993) erected a new genus, Thalesius, for Procteria, however, this is pre-occupied. The correct name for this taxon, which some authors have continued to call Thalesius viridis following Yuki (1993), is therefore Xenodon werneri.

The holotype was supposedly from Tsumeb, Namibia, but Eiselt  (1963) questioned this and indicated it was possibly from South America.

While the holotype was reportedly collected from northern Australia, examination of all available Eugongylus material from Australia and the Torres Strait by G. Shea confirms that the only species known from this area is E. rufescens (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). The type locality is consequently considered to be in error.
This species was described from material originally attributed to Calamophis jobiensis by Murphy (2012).
This species was described from material originally attributed to Calamophis jobiensis by Murphy (2012).
This species was described from material originally attributed to Calamophis jobiensis by Murphy (2012).

Broadley and Broadley (1997) recognized two subspecies, Zygaspis vandami vandami and Z. v. arenicola, differing only with regard to the number of postoculars and the fusion of temporal head shields. Gans (2005) recognized these as separate species, although with no justification. Bates (2018) subsequently evaluated the taxonomic status of the two subspecies, and on the basis of differences in geographic range and ecology, as well as the recognized morphological differences, formally proposed recognizing Zygaspis arenicola as a distinct species applying an evolutionary species concept.

Praschag et al. (2007, 2008) demonstrated that the widespread species Batagur baska comprised at least two genetically distinct species, and separated out B. affinis for the southern species occupying southern Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, and Sumatra in Indonesia, retaining the name B. baska for the more northern species from India, Bangladesh, and Myanmar. Praschag et al. (2009) further assessed the genetics and taxonomic status of a Cambodian relict subpopulation and eastern Peninsular Malaysian subpopulations and described them as the new subspecies B. affinis edwardmolli, with B. a. affinis occurring in western Peninsular Malaysia and Sumatra. Moll et al. (2015) reviewed the range-wide conservation biology and conservation status of the species.

Two subspecies are recognized, Chitra chitra chitra Nutphand, 1986 occurring in western Thailand and presumably Peninsular Malaysia, and Chitra chitra javanensis McCord & Pritchard, 2003 recorded from eastern Java and possibly extending to Sumatra.
Taxonomic research is needed, particularly regarding subspecies and northeast Indian status.

authority: Giri, Gower, Das, Lalremsanga, Lalronunga, Captain & Deepak, 2019
taxonomicNotes: Smithsophis atemporalis was described from a sample of Northeast Indian Rhabdophis previously confused with Rhabdophis (now Smithsophis atemporalis) (Giri et al. 2019).

Prior to analysis by Keogh et al. (2008), all Fijian banded iguanas were lumped together as a single species (Brachylophus fasciatus). The Gau Banded Iguana, Brachylophus gau, was newly described in 2017 (Fisher et al. 2017) as being morphologically distinct from the Lau Banded Iguana (Brachylophus fasciatus) and from the Central Fijian Banded Iguana (Brachylophus bulabula).
The two known populations of this species, one from the eastern Bukit Barisan and the other from the western part of the range, may represent different species (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019).

The closest related species to Trimeresurus arunachalensis is T. tibetanus (Captain et al. 2019). Therefore, under the general proposed by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004) both species would be in the genus Himalayophis.

Recent studies have placed Cnemidophorus abaetensis in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended it should remain in Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review of Brazilian species is concluded. Nonetheless the Sociedade Brasileira de Herpetologia and this evaluation follow Harvey et al. (2012).

Recent studies listed Cnemidophorus nativo within the genus Ameivula (Harvey et al. 2012). Pyron et al. (2013) suggested that it should remain within Cnemidophorus until a more extensive revision is completed. Following common usage among workers in the area where this species occurs, this evaluation follows Harvey et al. (2012) and Arias et al. (2014) in treating this species within Ameivula.

Leposternon octostegum was described in 1851 from a specimen now archived in the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, in Paris, with uncertain locality (Brèsil). Other specimens were lost due to uncertain taxonomic status; destroyed during World War II (Deutsches Museum Bonn, Germany), or deposited in unknown collections (Barros-Filho et al. 2013). It was rediscovered in 2003 from five subpopulations (Barros-Filho et al. 2013), and was subsequently re-described in detail by Barros-Filhos et al. (2019).

authority: Rodrigues, Texeira, Recoder, Dal Vechio, Damasceno & Machado-Pellegrino, 2013
(Rocha, Bamberg Araújo, Vrcibradic & Mamede Da Costa, 2000)
taxonomicNotes: A recent study listed Cnemidophorus littoralis under the genus Ameivula (Harvey et al. 2012). Pyron et al. (2013) suggested it remain under Cnemidophorus before a more extensive revision is completed.

Recent studies have placed Cnemidophorus nigrigula in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended it should remain as Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review of Brazilian species is concluded. However, the Sociedade Brasileira de Herpetologia and this evaluation follow Harvey et al. (2012).

authority: (Colli, Costa, Garda, Kopp, Mesquita, Péres, Valdujo, Vieira & Wiederhecker, 2003)
taxonomicNotes: Morphological and molecular studies have shown that Ameiva parecis belongs within Ameiva, and not Cnemidophorus as in its original description (Arias et al. 2011, Harvey et al. 2012, Giugliano et al. 2013).

authority: Teixeira, Sousa-Recoder, Camacho, de Sena, Navas & Rodrigues, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Formerly considered to be Bachia bresslaui.

A recent study (Hedges and Conn 2012) separated the species previously, included in Mabuya, in a different genus. Vrcibradic et al. (2006) analysed the complex M. agilis, M. caissara, and M. heathi, and found that the genetic distances between them were small. They suggested that the three may represent a single species, but indicated the need for further data.

authority: Teixeira, dal Vechio, Sales-Nunes, Mollo-Neto, Moreira-Lobo, Storti, Junqueira-Gaiga, Freire-Dias & Rodrigues, 2013
de Freitas, Strüssmann, de Carvalho, Kawashita-Ribeiro & Mott, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Gainsbury and Colli (2003) included this population within Bachia cacerencis. De Freitas et al. (2011) confirmed it represented a new species, which they named Bachia didactyla.
On the basis of morphology and distribution, Costa et al. (2019) synonymized Amphisbaena mensae within A. talisiae.

The species was described from its holotype found in the state of Bahia (no specific locality; Peters 1878), and later Gans (1965) redescribed it based on an individual found in the municipality of Itabuna, also in Bahia.

authority: Teixeira Jr, dal Vechio, Neto & Rodrigues, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Péres (2003) indicated that Tupinambis palustris is a junior synonym of Tupinambis teguixin. While this - from an unpublished review - has not been widely accepted, and the species was treated as valid by Harvey et al. (2012) without comment, it is possible that confusion between the two taxa has contributed to the scarcity of data on this species.

Recent studies have listed Cnemidophorus cyanurus in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended that it remain in the genus Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review is carried out. For this evaluation, the specialists followed Harvey et al. (2012).

authority: Rodrigues, De Freitas, Santos Silva & Viña Bertolotto, 2006

taxonomicNotes: The species of Anolis have been divided into eight genera (Nicholson et al. 2012, Castañeda and de Queiroz 2013) but the classification has not been widely accepted. In this assessment A. pseudotigrinus Amaral, 1933, is placed in the genus Anolis Daudin, 1802.

The species of Anolis have been divided into eight genera (Nicholson et al. 2012, Castañeda and de Queiroz 2013) but the classification has not been widely accepted. In this assessment A. nasofrontalis Amaral, 1933, is placed in the genus Anolis Daudin, 1802.

The taxonomic status of an outlier specimen from the Free State Province was originally in doubt (de Waal 1978) but is currently considered to be T. breyeri (Bates 1996c). Given this record is isolated by 120 km, confirmation of its occurrence and possibly evaluation in a molecular phylogenetic framework is needed.
The specific name was incorrectly spelt on earlier Red Lists as kempi.
The species blandingii has generally been placed in Emydoidea in recent years, but has also been argued to belong in the genus Emys, based on molecular phylogeny results.

authority: Giri, Chaitanya, Mahony, Lalrounga, Lalrichhana, Das, Sarkar, Karanth & Deepak, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species was described based on a lineage within the complex Hemidactylus brookii group, originally identified as being divergent by Agarwal et al. (2019).

This species was previously included in the Oligosoma infrapunctatum species complex but had been recognized as a candidate species by multiple authors, under the informal names Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "Chesterfield" (a name properly applied to the sister species Oligosoma salmo) or Oligosomaa aff. infrapunctatum "Alborn".

This taxon, previously included within Oligosoma infrapunctatum, has been informally treated as a part of distinct species by several authors under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "southern North Island" (and further split by van Winkel et al. 2018, who restricted its distribution to Hawke's Bay under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "Hawke's Bay"). Melzer et al. (2019) formally described this species, coining the name Oligosoma auroraensis later emended to O. aurorarense.

This taxon has previously been included within the O. infrapunctatum species complex, although since its discovery in 1993 it has been recognized as a candidate species under the common name 'Chesterfield skink' and, scientifically, by several authors under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "Chesterfield". Melzer et al. (2019) formally described this species, and coined the name Oligosoma salmo for this taxon.

Uncertainty surrounds the identity of 'true' Oligosoma infrapunctatum, whose type locality is unknown: an assumption that this was Stephens Island (Takapourewa) (McCann 1955) is now considered to be in error, as the species known from this island is not conspecific with the O. infrapunctatum holotype (Melzer et al. 2019). Melzer et al. (2019) resurrected the name Oligosoma newmani for the Takapourewa population. The concept applied by these authors encompassed the majority of South Island populations previously included within O. infrapunctatum, but they cautioned that significant morphological differences between island and mainland populations suggest that taxonomic issues are likely to remain within this clade despite relatively low genetic divergence.

This taxon, previously included within Oligosoma infrapunctatum, has been informally treated as a distinct species by several authors under the name Oligosoma aff. infrapunctatum "crenulate". Melzer et al. (2019) formally described this species, and resurrected the name Oligosoma robinsoni for this taxon (excluding a genetically and morphologically distinct population from Granity and Hokitika in the South Island). These authors note morphological differences between mainland and island populations.

authority: Mallik, Achyuthan, Ganesh, Pal, Vijayakumar & Shanker, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019
Karunaratha, Poyarkov, de Silva, Madawala, Botejue, Gorin, Surasinghe, Gabadage, Ukuwela & Bauer, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species was treated for a time as a subspecies of Hemiphyllodactylus typus until Bauer and Das (1999) showed it to be a distinct species. These authors' concept for H. aurantiacus it as a single, widespread species, which was subsequently shown to be a species complex and revised by Agarwal et al. (2019).

Calliophis beddomei was described by Smith in 1943 based on specimens collected from two locations, one each from Shevaroy Hills, Salem District, Tamil Nadu and Koppa, Chikamagaluru district, Karnataka (Smith 1943).
Hemidactylus satarensis was described based on specimens collected from Chalakewadi, Satara District, Maharashtra (Giri and Bauer 2008) .

This species was described based on two specimens from Yercaud. Recent surveys have revealed the presence of two additional species within the Shevaroys, partitioned along an elevational gradient, which had previously been understood to represent this species, and also additional populations atop nearby peaks (Kolli Hills, Pachamalai Hills) (Ganesh and Arumagam 2016, Agarwal et al. 2019).
Ahaetulla dispar was described by Günther in 1864 as Tragops dispar based on specimens collected from Anaimalai Hills, Western Ghats (Smith 1943).

Cnemaspis nilagirica was described by Manamendra-Arachchi, Batuvita and Pethiyagoda in 2007 based on type specimen from Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007). The holotype was formerly a syntype of C. tropidogaster, presently understood to be endemic to Sri Lanka. Following recent clarification of the species concept for C. tropidogaster, research is needed to establish its relationship to Indian taxa and to verify the validity of C. nilagrica.

Calotes aurantolabium was described by Krishnan in 2008 based on two female specimens collected from Kalakkad-Mundunthurai Tiger Reserve, Agasthyamalai Hills, Western Ghats, Tamil Nadu, India. Calotes andamanensis reported from mainland India by Ishwar and Das (1998) based on specimens collected from Kalakkad-Mundanthurai Tiger Reserve are misidentified Calotes aurantolabium (Krishnan 2008). It was subsequently recognized as a distinct genus based on a distinct phylogenetic position by Pal et al. (2018).
Coronella brachyura was described by Günther in 1866 as Zamenis brachyurus (Smith 1943) based on specimens collected from Western Ghats in Poona, Poona District, Maharashtra (Smith 1943).

authority: Marques, Ceríaco, Stanley, Bandeira, Agarwal & Bauer, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Avila-Pires et al. (2010) state that a large sample of small amphisbaenians from the area around the Amphisbaena tragorrhectes type locality confirm that this species is a junior synonym of A. vanzolini. It appears that a "forthcoming paper" providing the evidence for this synonymy has never been published, and at present A. tragorrhectes is recognized as a valid species.

Recent molecular studies (Geurgas et al., 2008) indicate that the taxonomic diversity within Coleodactylus is largely underestimated, resulting from ancient vicariant events started back in the late Cretaceous (64.2 - 75.2 mya). The genus includes a large number of cryptic species, and Coleodactylus natalensis is nested within a clade including undescribed species currently assigned to C. meridionalis. Further taxonomic studies are necessary for describing the real diversity within this genus. Despite the overall ancient nature of divergence within the genus, molecular data indicate a relatively recent (1.9 ± 1.3 mya) divergence between C. natalensis and undescribed species allocated to C. meridionalis.

authority: Verrastro, Veronese, Bujes & Martins Dias Filho, 2003

taxonomicNotes: The genus Platynotus has been revalidated by Schmidt and Inger (1951) and by Vanzolini et al. (1980).

Although Broadley (2002) elevated Psammophis leightoni namibensis and P. l. trinasalis to full species, a recent phylogenetic analysis shows that these three species are a single species (Taft 2018, Taft et al. in press).
This species was recently split from the larger Nucras tesellata group (Broadley 1972, Branch et al. 2019).

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Weinell and Bauer (2018) examined morphological and genetic variation within the Trachylepis varia complex and identified eight major clades across the species' range. These authors' focus was on resolving the taxonomy of southern African members of this group, from which they revalidated Trachylepis laevigata and T. damarana. A clade recognized from most of Angola, Zambia and the southern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is likely to correspond to one of two recognized species, either T. albopunctata or T. angolensis (Weinell and Bauer 2018). Weinell et al. (2019) follow Marques et al. (2018) in using the name T. albopunctata for most of the Angolan and Zambian populations of what were usually called T. varia.
Exemplares deste táxon vinham sendo identificados como outras espécies (Apostolepis pymi, Apostolepis gr. nigrolineata ou Apostolepis sp.) (Costa e Bérnils 2018).

Chilabothrus schwartzi is a recently elevated boa species (Reynolds et al. 2018). The species was originally described as Epicrates chryogaster schwartzi by Donald W. Buden in 1975 based on four type specimens collected by locals on Crooked and Acklins islands. Individuals were not recorded again in the literature (and no additional specimens were secured) until Reynolds et al. (2018) recorded four individuals on Crooked Island in 2017. Subsequent analyses of DNA, morphology, and comparison to the types by Reynolds et al. (2018) provided support for the elevation of the lineage to the specific level within the West Indian endemic genus Chilabothrus on the basis of diagnostic and divergent morphological and genetic characters.

The relationship between P. interscapularis and P. sogdianus is unclear. The latter taxon has been listed both as a subspecies of P. interscapularis (Milto and Barabanov 2012) and as a full species (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008, Melville et al. 2009) in recent literature. Solovyeva et al. (2014) found "only insignificant" genetic differentiation between the two taxa and suggested that the status of P. sogdianus, which they retained as a full species, warrants further investigation.

This species' validity has been uncertain for more than a century, with various authors suggesting the sole known specimen is synonymous with different South American, Caribbean or African species (summarized in Miralles et al. 2009).  The most recent treatment, by Miralles et al. (2009), confirmed that it is distinct from known Neotropical mabuyine skinks, but it remains possible that - if it is not from the Americas - it represents a known African species.

Roux-Estève (1974) proposed synonymizing Cathetorhinus within Rhinotyphlops, but did not justify this assignment although V. Wallach (pers. comm. in Uetz 2019) suggests it may be correct. If, as proposed by Cheke (2010), the type locality of Cathetorhinus melaanocephalus is on Mauritius, this name is likely to be a senior synonym of the only native blindsnake known from Mauritius, Madatyphlops cairei. This author cautions, however, that it is "not likely to be easy" to demonstrate a connection between the two, as M. cairei is known only from subfossil remains from a site with poor DNA preservation and the C. melanorhinus holotype has been preserved in alcohol for more than 200 years.

Brown (1991) treated Papuascincus buergersi as a junior synonym of Emoia atrocostata on a "preliminary" basis, but without examining the types. This assignment is "clearly" not correct (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017 quoted in Uetz et al. 2021), and is not discussed by Slavenko et al. (2021) who treat this species as valid without comment.
Cyrtodactylus nebulosus was described by Beddome in 1870 as Gymnodactylus nebulosus based on type specimen collected from Golkonda Hill, Visakhapatnam District, Andhra Pradesh (Smith 1935).

If, as proposed by Cheke (2010), the type locality of Cathetorhinus melanocephalus is on Mauritius, this name is likely to be a senior synonym of the only native blindsnake known from Mauritius, Madatyphlops cairei. This author cautions, however, that it is "not likely to be easy" to demonstrate a connection between the two, as M. cairei is known only from subfossil remains from a site with poor DNA preservation and the C. melanorhinus holotype has been preserved in alcohol for more than 200 years.

Low levels of genetic divergence between Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus (Rocha et al. 2006) and difficulties in morphologically differentiating several forms (including the Comoran C. b. ater and C. b. mohelicus – F. Glaw pers. comm. June 2011) suggest the validity of many forms identified by Horner (2007) - who revised the genus and identified 54 species within it - requires further investigation, and the species recognized by Horner (2007) are not widely accepted by workers in the Indian Ocean region (e.g. Blom et al. 2019, Augros and Hawlitschek 2019).

The assessments for this group nonetheless follow the taxonomy proposed by Horner (2007) pending a more detailed revision of Indian Ocean Crypotoblepharus. Prior to the Horner revision, specific status was previously proposed for the Madagascan C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi and supported by significant morphological differences (Andreone and Greer 2002), but this has not been widely adopted within the region and the taxonomy of these forms remains among the most controversial in the genus.

Recent genetic evidence from a biogeographic paper (Blom et al. 2019) confirms that genetic divergence within Indian Ocean Cryptoblepharus is low, but does not sample all nominal taxa and their results suggest that divergence - including that between C. cognatus and C. voeltzkowi - is comparable to that among Pacific Cryptoblepharus lineages recognized as full species (G. Shea pers. comm. 2020).

Apostolepis tertullianobuei was synonymized within Apostolepis assimilis within a year of its description (Ferrarezi et al. 2005) on the basis that the described characters fell within the latter species' range of variation. These authors did not, however, examine the holotype of A. tertullianobuei, and following a subsequent comparison of the holotypes of the two species Lema and Renner (2007) revalidated it. This was not followed in the checklist by Wallach et al. (2014) but was accepted by Costa and Bérnils (2015), who determined that A. parassimilis represents a junior synonym of A. tertullianobeui. The validity of this species remains in question (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020); and is considered doubtful, but it is accepted as valid in a recent atlas for Brazilian snakes (Nogueira et al. 2019).

Phrynocephalus roborowskii was elevated to specific status (from a variant or subspecies of P. vlangalli) by Peters (1984), and has since been mentioned only in a small number of publications by German and Russian authors, mainly checklists. While this arrangement is presently considered valid (Milto and Barabanov 2012), it is not recognized by workers in China, the only known range state (Y.Z. Wang pers. comm. 2018). As both taxa are endemic to China, this assessment follows the accepted Chinese arrangement in retaining P. roborowskii within P. vlangalli.

A proposed change in the specific name from pulchra to nigra (Hunt 1983) was rejected by most herpetologists (see Murphy and Smith 1985, 1991; Ballinger et al. 1992; Jennings et al. 1992); 1993 rulings by the ICZN conserved the name Anniella pulchra for this species and placed the name argentea (as published in the trinomen Anniella nigra argentea, on the list of rejected and invalid names.

It has been recognized since the 1970s that Anniella pulchra as presently understood is a species complex (Bezy and Wright 1971, Bezy et al. 1977). Papenfuss and Parham (2013) recognized several new species from within Anniella pulchra: A. campi, A. alexanderae, A. stebbinsi and A. grinelli. This scheme was subsequently adopted in US national checklists but recent investigation suggests that recognizing these taxa as distinct is premature as Anniella has been insufficiently sampled throughout its distribution (G. Pauly pers. comm. 2019). Consequently the currently accepted state taxonomy in California does not recognize the species described by Papenfuss and Parham (2013) (G. Pauly pers. comm. 2019).
No taxonomic issues.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Dryophis. Records of this mangrove species from far inland in northeastern India, presumably from upland forest, are very likely to be misidentifications.
Barkudia insularis was described by Annandale in 1917 based on a single specimen collected from Barkuda Island, Chilka Lake, Orissa (Smith 1935, Das 1999).

This species was previously included within Blaesodactylus antongilensis. Recent phylogenies of the genus (Greenbaum et al. 2007, Bauer et al. 2011) confirm that the Ankarafantsika form represents a distinct species. This is consistent with long-recognized morphological differences from typical B. antongilensis (e.g. Henkel & Schmidt 1991, Glaw & Vences 1992), and Bauer et al. (2011) formally described this species. Further research is needed to clarify the distribution of this gecko outside Ankarafantsika, and to establish the specific identity of locality records presently assigned to B. boivini to the north and/or B. sakalava to the south.
Brookesia antoetrae is treated as a synonym of B. thieli but additional study is needed on the taxonomy of these taxa (Glaw and Vences 2007)
No taxonomic issues.
No taxonomy issues.
No taxonomic issues.
The taxonomy of Calumma marojezense is in need of revision.
This species is part of the C. nasutum/fallax complex, and there are other populations which have not yet been assigned, and might yet be referable to vohibola (Gehring et  al. 2011)

This species has a highly unusual distribution, with no known subpopulations between Montagne d'Ambre and Bemaraha despite intensive surveys (Raselimanana 2008, F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011). It is consequently unclear whether the two taxa represent the same species, or whether the Bemaraha form is a distinct species that resembles C. albiventris in patterning and scale counts (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011). Genetic studies are needed to clarify relationships between these populations (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2011).
The validity of this species has been questioned, but it is currently considered a good species (R. Jenkins pers. comm. June 2011, C. Raxworthy pers. comm. Jan 2011).

Records of this species from Ambohijanahary are attributable to Furcifer willsii (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011). Records from Parc National Tsingy de Bemaraha may represent this taxon,. F. willsii, or an undescribed form; due to uncertainty about the correct assignment of these records the Bemaraha records are not included in the assessments for either F. petteri or F. wilsii.

G. mukutense has been recently described and differs from all other species of the Gongylosoma genus in having a single, enlarged, posterior temporal; chinshields of equal size, and a thin nuchal band that contacts a vestigial vertebral stripe (Grismer et al. 2003).

This species has also been placed in the genera Opisthotropis and Amphiesma. Research is underway to clarify the validity and content of Parahelicops, and pending resolution of this issue P. annamensis should be retained within this genus (P. David pers. comm. February 2011).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

Hebius taronensis was elevated to specific status by Das (2010) (as Amphiesma taronense, an apparently incorrect emendation), having previously been treated as a subspecies or synonym of Amphiesma venningi. Das (2010) provides no explicit justification for this action, although the accompanying description highlights morphological differences between the two taxa (particularly in the number of subcaudals). Its appropriate taxonomic status remains unclear (e.g. Uetz and Hošek 2016). This account tentatively follows Das (2010) in recognizing H. taronensis as a valid species separate from H. venningi.

authority: Necas, Sindaco, Korený, Kopecná, Malonza & Modrý, 2009
taxonomicNotes: Accepted as Kinyongia asheorum in Necas et al. (2009).
Two subspecies are currently recognized, T. h. hermanni and T. h. boettgeri (includes hercegovinensis).

Stenophis gaimardi was reassigned to Lycodryas by Nagy et al. (2010). The relationship of this species with L. carleti (the validity of which is uncertain - Glaw and Vences 2007) needs further investigation. Nagy et al. (2010) report a form they describe as S. sp. aff. gaimardi, found to be related to S. citrinus. This form is not included in the present account.

There are no distinct morphological or meristic differences between Andasibe and Ambohitantely populations, but further genetic study is needed to establish whether Lygodactylus guibei represents a single species (Puente et al. 2009).

Additional genetic comparisons are needed between specimens from Nosy Be and the mainland to determine the status of Lygodactylus madagascariensis petteri at Montagne d'Ambre, and some morphological differences between this subpopulation and that from Manongarivo have been reported (Glaw and Vences 2007, Puente et al. 2009).

The habitat at the type locality, Morondava, is very different from that occupied by skinks attributed to this species elsewhere in its range. Recent taxonomic study of the holotype has established that it is conspecific with Madascincus moroundavae from elsewhere in Madagascar, but it is unclear whether this specimen was in fact collected at Morondava or whether the type locality is in error (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011), and it may be that this species does not actually occur at Morondava.
Parastenophis, previously a subgenus of Stenophis containing only S. betsileana, was elevated to a full genus by Nagy et al. (2010) in their revision of Stenophis and Lycodryas.

Three subspecies are recognized:

Pyxis arachnoides arachnoides Bell, 1827
Pyxis arachnoides brygooi (Vuillemin & Domergue, 1972)
Pyxis arachnoides oblonga Gray, 1869

Along with other members of the Liopholidophis stumpffi group, this species was briefly included within the new genus Bibilava (Glaw et al. 2007, Glaw and Vences 2007). Cadle and Ineich (2008) later resurrected Thamnosophis for this species group.
Accepted as Trioceros fuelleborni in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).
This species has been placed in the genus Sibon in the past, but was returned to Tropidodipsas by Wallach (1995).
Genetic data reveal that U. phantasticus is a complex of several species and a full taxonomic revision is required (Glaw and Vences 2007).

A recent study treated U. sameiti as a full species that occurs in the same sites as U. sikorae but at lower elevations (Raxworthy et al. 2008); it had previously been regarded as a subspecies of U. sikorae.

There is no observed genetic distinction between Z. laticaudatus and Z. anelanelany in the south-east and further studies are needed using a larger sample size (only two individuals of Z. anelanelany have been included in comparisons), and from a wider area, than has been previously undertaken to clarify whether this is a real effect (Raselimanana et al. 2009). The two species are morphologically distinct, and therefore introgression or hybridization may account for the lack of genetic differences (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011).

There is strong evidence for three distinct population lineages based on molecular studies and the putative existence of a new species (Raselimanana et al. 2009). Subpopulations in the Reserve Speciale de Marotandrano, Tampolo and Antalaha, and Daraina represent three distinct clades. Specimens from the latter location resembling Z. bemaraha, a species only known from a single site in western Madagascar (Raselimanana et al. 2009). Z. brygooi has a type locality of Nosy Be, an island off the northwest coast of Madagascar, but this is probably incorrect (A. Raselimanana and M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011), and this assessment considers the lizard absent from this locality.
The Marine Iguana (genus Amblyrhynchus) is a single species, with 11 subspecies after taxonomic revision by Miralles et al. (2017).

Rocha et al. (2017) identified cryptic diversity within Ailuronyx seychellensis based on both morphological and molecular evidence which suggested the existence of at least distinct northern and southern species-level clades. Although these authors took no taxonomic action and did not sample every island where the species is reported to occur, they recommended further investigation into the taxonomy of this species.

Rocha et al. (2017) identified "considerable levels of genetic diversity and extensive geographical structure" within Ailuronyx tachyscopaeus based on both morphological and molecular evidence, and identified two candidate species Although these authors took no taxonomic action, they recommended further investigation into the taxonomy of this species.

Species and subspecific boundaries within Seychelles Phelsuma are unclear, and Phelsuma sundbergi longinsulae has variously been treated as a subspecies or a full species. Rocha et al. (2013) examined molecular variation in this group and recommended that, pending further research, this was best reflected by retaining the three recognized subspecies: P. s. sundbergi, P. s. longinsulae and P. s. ladinguensis.
This species exhibits little evidence of gene flow, and deep divergence between some lineages suggests that cryptic diversity exists (Rocha et al. 2011).
This species is "not particularly distinct" from African members of the genus (Rocha et al. 2009), and its validity as a full species is uncertain (Kopeczky and Gemel 2016).

We follow Smith and Wallach (1994) in including this species in the monotypic genus Lycognathophis, rather than in Scopelophis, as proposed by Dowling (1990). This is supported by more recent molecular studies, which confirm its placement within Natricidae (e.g. Pyron et al. 2013, Zaher et al. 2019). Genetic evidence indicates that this species belongs to an ancient lineage, having diverged from African relatives around 35 million years ago (Deepak et al. 2021).

The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. The two nominal species in this genus are frequently treated as a single species, J. braueri, following Cheke (1984) and a series of subsequent resurrections and re-synonymizations (Bowler et al. 2006). The first genetic study on this genus suggests greater divergence than is represented by a two-species model, with at least three lineages on Silhouette alone (Harris et al. 2015). These authors recommend recognizing considering Janetaescincus as a single species complex under the name J. braueri, pending further taxonomic research.

For the sake of taxonomic stability, these assessments retain the two-species approach adopted in prior Red List assessments pending clarification of species boundaries, with the caveat that neither a one- nor a two-species model accurately reflects our current understanding of diversity in this group (S. Rocha and J. Harris pers. comms. 2020).

The genus Janetaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. The two nominal species in this genus are frequently treated as a single species, J. braueri, following Cheke (1984) and a series of subsequent resurrections and re-synonymizations (Bowler et al. 2006). The first genetic study on this genus suggests greater divergence than is represented by a two-species model, with at least three lineages on Silhouette alone (Harris et al. 2015). These authors recommend recognizing considering Janetaescincus as a single species complex under the name J. braueri, pending further taxonomic research.

For the sake of taxonomic stability, these assessments retain the two-species approach adopted in prior Red List assessments pending clarification of species boundaries, with the caveat that neither a one- nor a two-species model accurately reflects our current understanding of diversity in this group (S. Rocha and J. Harris pers. comms. 2020).

The monotypic genus Pamelaescincus was established by Greer (1970), and is endemic to the Seychelles. Molecular evidence suggests that two highly divergent clades exist within this species as presently understood, and morphological research is needed to determine whether taxonomic changes are necessary (Valente et al. 2014).

In a range-wide review of the two Seychelles species of Trachylepis, Gerlach (2005) referred the doubtful subspecies Trachylepis wrightii ilotensis to the synonymy of T. sechellensis on morphological grounds. Subsequent surveys and molecular research have confirmed that both species are present on the island, but do not support the existence of a distinct subspecies T. w. itolensis (Rocha et al. 2013)  These authors' data indicate that the species has undergone widespread hybridization with T. wrightii and mtDNA replacement in the south of its range (Mahé, Fregaté and north Silhouette). This is expected to have resulted in the extinction of some genetic lineages within the latter species, but there appears to be no ongoing hybridization (Rocha et al. 2016).

In a range-wide review of the two Seychelles species of Trachylepis, Gerlach (2005) referred the doubtful subspecies Trachylepis wrightii ilotensis to the synonymy of T. sechellensis on morphological grounds.

Reiserer et al. (2013) proposed recognizing the four established subspecies of Heloderma horridum as full species, as these are morphologically diagnosable and have been found to exhibit relatively high levels of genetic divergence. This latter observation was based on the results of Douglas et al. (2010), although those authors did not propose elevating these taxa to specific status. While Reiserer et al. (2013) caution that the morphological diagnoses of the former subspecies are "somewhat incomplete" and that further research is needed to confirm their species-level arrangement, the four-species approach is now widely accepted and is followed here.

Reiserer et al. (2013) proposed recognizing the four established subspecies of Heloderma horridum as full species, as these are morphologically diagnosable and have been found to exhibit relatively high levels of genetic divergence. This latter observation was based on the results of Douglas et al. (2010), although those authors did not propose elevating these taxa to specific status. While Reiserer et al. (2013) caution that the morphological diagnoses of the former subspecies are "somewhat incomplete" and that further research is needed to confirm their species-level arrangement, the four-species approach is now widely accepted and is followed here.

Reiserer et al. (2013) proposed recognizing the four established subspecies of Heloderma horridum as full species, as these are morphologically diagnosable and have been found to exhibit relatively high levels of genetic divergence. This latter observation was based on the results of Douglas et al. (2010), although those authors did not propose elevating these taxa to specific status. While Reiserer et al. (2013) caution that the morphological diagnoses of the former subspecies are "somewhat incomplete" and that further research is needed to confirm their species-level arrangement, the four-species approach is now widely accepted and is followed here. There has been an assumption that intergradation occurs between H. horridum and H. exasperatum along a north-south gradient, but no definitive evidence of this exists (Reiserer et al. 2013),

Reiserer et al. (2013) proposed recognizing the four established subspecies of Heloderma horridum as full species, as these are morphologically diagnosable and have been found to exhibit relatively high levels of genetic divergence. This latter observation was based on the results of Douglas et al. (2010), although those authors did not propose elevating these taxa to specific status. While Reiserer et al. (2013) caution that the morphological diagnoses of the former subspecies are "somewhat incomplete" and that further research is needed to confirm their species-level arrangement, the four-species approach is now widely accepted and is followed here. There has been an assumption that intergradation occurs between H. horridum and H. exasperatum along a north-south gradient, but no definitive evidence of this exists (Reiserer et al. 2013). Recent confirmation that H. alvarezi occurs as far north as Oaxaca (García-Grajales et al. 2020) suggests that a possible intergradation area may exist here.

Hoskin (2019) revised the taxonomy of the Oedura monilis species complex and found that it consisted of four morphologically distinct species. He did not provide genetic data, but indicated that then-unpublished work demonstrated "substantial divergence" in both mitochondrial and nuclear DNA between the identified clades. He consequently described three new species: O. elegans, O. lineata and O. picta.

Hoskin (2019) revised the taxonomy of the Oedura monilis species complex and found that it consisted of four morphologically distinct species. He did not provide genetic data, but indicated that then-unpublished work demonstrated "substantial divergence" in both mitochondrial and nuclear DNA between the identified clades. He consequently described three new species: O. elegans, O. lineata and O. picta.

Hoskin (2019) revised the taxonomy of the Oedura monilis species complex and found that it consisted of four morphologically distinct species. He did not provide genetic data, but indicated that then-unpublished work demonstrated "substantial divergence" in both mitochondrial and nuclear DNA between the identified clades. He consequently described three new species: O. elegans, O. lineata and O. picta.

Hoskin (2019) revised the taxonomy of the Oedura monilis species complex and found that it consisted of four morphologically distinct species. He did not provide genetic data, but indicated that then-unpublished work demonstrated "substantial divergence" in both mitochondrial and nuclear DNA between the identified clades. He consequently described three new species: O. elegans, O. lineata and O. picta. He restricted the name O. monilis to the northernmost clade within the former complex, and concluded that Oedura attenboroughi represents a junior synonym.
The common name for this species in Vietnamese is Rùa Trung Bộ.

Trape et al. (2012) indicate that Panaspis tristaoi (Monard, 1940) is the correct name for the species previously referred to as P. nimbensis (the common spelling nimbaensis - e.g. Uetz and Hallerman 2012 - being incorrect - Schmitz et al. 2005). The Monard description appears to have been forgotten; Angel described P. nimbensis without reference to Monard's earlier work, and the name tristaoi is not a recognized synonym (Uetz and Hallerman 2012). As the two names are considered to refer to the same species, L. Chirio (pers. comm. 2013) argues P. tristaoi has priority over the previously-accepted name P. nimbensis. However, as this name has not been used since the species' original description over 70 years ago, the name P. tristaoi may be a nomen oblitum (P.P. van Dyck pers. comm. 2013). Subsequent to the assessment being published on the Red List it appears that the earlier name for this species has been accepted for use (e.g. Uetz et al. 2020), hence the assessment is updated to reflect this change.
Cebu records appear to represent this species but are "biogeographically anomalous" (R. Brown pers. comm. 2020)

Some individuals of this species are genetically similar to Lepidodactylus yami from Lanyu Island, which also exhibits morphological overlap. Further research is needed to determine whether one or two species are represented (S. Eliades pers. comm. 2020).

This species is poorly differentiated from Lepidodactylus planicaudus in the original description, and additional genetic data is needed to resolve of the relationships between these species as well as to identify possible cryptic species within L. christiani as presently understood (S. Eliades and C. Siler pers. comm. 2020).

Preliminary genetic data suggest that L. christiani may be more widespread than currently recognized, as it belongs to a lineage that may reach southern Luzon (S. Eliades pers. comm. 2020).

This species consists of two subspecies: Lepidodactylus herrei herrei from Negros and nearby islands, and L. h. medianus from Mindanao and the Central Visayas islands (Supsup et al. 2016). Although no taxonomic changes appear to have been formally proposed, by restricting its described distribution to Negros, Cebu and Camiguin Sur, Venturina et al. (2020) implicitly exclude L. h. medianus from their concept of L. herrei. These two clades are genetically divergent and each is mostly restricted to a single faunal region; as such they may represent distinct species (R. Brown pers. comm. 2020).

Brown et al. (2013) suggest that Lepidodactylus planicaudus may be a species complex, and that as presently understood it may be the name applicable to a number of geckos from Luzon which these authors refer to as L. cf. lugubris.

This species is poorly differentiated from Lepidodactylus christiani in the original description, and additional genetic data is needed to resolve of the relationships between these species as well as to identify possible cryptic species within L. christiani as presently understood (S. Eliades and C. Siler pers. comm. 2020).

Gaulke et al. (2007) discussed taxonomic problems with Luperosaurus cumingii as then understood and restricted its distribution to Luzon and Polillo, describing records from the Visayan Islands as the new species Luperosaurus corfeldi noting that further research was needed to clarify the identity of records from other islands. Subsequently Brown et al. (2011) referred the specimens from Polillo and most records from Luzon to the new species Luperosaurus angliit and concluded that the imprecise type locality should be restricted to the Bicol Peninsula.

Hatchlings from Polillo have variously been assigned to Luperosaurus cumingii (Gaulke et al. 2007) or L. macgregori; Oliveros et al. (2011) suggested that the Polilllo specimens likely represent an undescribed species, and Brown et al. (2011) tentatively assigned them to their new species Luperosaurus angliit.

This taxon might be a complex of three species; one from each of the islands from which it has been recorded. Oliveros et al. (2011) noted that a revision of this species was then ongoing, but no further work on this species appears to have been published.

authority: Brown, Meneses, Wood, Fernandez, Cuesta, Clores, Tracy, Buehler & Siler, 2020
taxonomicNotes: A single immature specimen from Caramoan is tentatively included in this species by Brown et al. (2020), who nevertheless note that it is genetically divergent from Sorsogon sequences and suspect that it is likely to represent an undescribed species.

Elseya rhodini is part of a complex of three allopatric species in New Guinea, formerly considered to be a single species, Elseya novaeguineae. Elseya rhodini was split from Elseya novaeguineae, and Elseya schultzei resurrected, on the basis of exceptionally high genetic divergences arising from the drainage divides and ranges separating northern New Guinea from the south, and the Vogelkop/Bomberai (Birds Head) Peninsula in the west from the rest of New Guinea in the east. Elseya novaeguineae is now restricted to the Birds Head area, E. schultzei to northern New Guinea, and E. rhodini to southern New Guinea. Adult specimens of these species are commonly confused with Elseya branderhorsti, owing to superficial similarity, and museum identifications are often unreliable. Fritz and Baur (1995) reported captive hybridization between Emydura subglobosa and Elseya novaeguineae (which then included Elseya rhodini); Emydura subglobosa is sympatric with Elseya rhodini.

De Pous et al. (2015) resurrected the genus Trachydactylus Haas & Battersby, 1959, and moved Bunopus spatalurus to it; in addition, they raised the former subspecies hajarensis to specific level, as Trachydactylus hajarensis (Arnold, 1980).

Liolaemus pantherinus was originally described based on two juvenile specimens, using two characters that are not sufficient either alone or in combination to validly distinguish a species of Liolaemus (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016). The name was not subsequently used in the literature to describe either a valid species or a synonym, even in comparative studies of related species, until Donoso-Barros (1966) who considered it an established species within the Chilean fauna.

Its taxonomic status has subsequently been uncertain; Laurent (1982) suggested that it represented a juvenile L. ornatus, and subsequently (Laurent 1992) that it was indistinguishable from L. signifer. An examination of the cotypes (Etheridge in litt.) broadly supports the latter interpretation, although the scale counts this author reports are not identical to those in L. signifer.

Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2002) revalidated L. pantherinus as a valid species, a decision subsequently upheld by Etheridge and by Langstroth (2005). Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2002), however, further complicated the taxonomy of this group by proposing that L. islugensis should be considered a junior synonym of L. pantherinus. This opinion is still held by H. Núñez (pers. comm. 2016) who, however, cautions that he has not examined the specimens. The synonymy was justified in part by the identification of the type locality as Lake Titicaca by Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2002), however, the cotypes do not have an associated type locality (R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).

Ruiz de Gamboa and Ortiz (2010) recognize L. isuglensis as distinct from both L. pantherinus and L. signifer.

R. Langstroth (in litt.) has carried out a detailed examination of specimens originally collected by P.O. Simons, which include Bolivian material determined to be Liolaemus annectens by Boulenger and subsequently recognized as L. orientalis by Laurent (1990), as well as a series identified by Boulenger as L. signifer used by Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez (2005) in their characterization of this species. This study concluded both that the latter authors were misled by the "L. signifer" specimens, which represent the population from Uyuni considered to be L. islugensis by Ruiz de Gamboa and Ortiz (2010), and that the L. pantherinus cotypes are conspecific with Boulenger's Bolivian L. annectens from Uyuni and Potosi (=L. orientalis).

While the taxonomy involved is extremely complex, in summary this account considers that L. pantherinus is a senior synonym of L. orientalis and is not closely-related to either L. signifer or L. islugensis, with which it has been confused historically largely due to confusion regarding the correct delimitation of L. signifer.

The taxonomic relationship between A. fuliginosus and A. univittatus needs resolution, as Atractus univittatus may be a junior synonym for Atractus fuliginosus (Rivas et al. 2012). At present the name Atractus univittatus is still used for Colombian populations pending resolution of this issue, and this concept is followed here.
The genus Ebenavia was revised by Hawlitschek et al. (2018). These authors described a lineage endemic to the Comoros previously included within E. inunguis as the new species E. tuelinae.

Paroedura sanctijohannis was previously considered to occur on all four islands in the Comoros Archipelago, and this scheme was adopted in a previous Red List assessment (Hawlitschek and Glaw 2011) The population from Mayotte has since been described as the new species P. stellata (Hawlitschek and Glaw 2012).

Paroedura sanctijohannis was previously considered to occur on all four islands in the Comoros Archipelago, and this scheme was adopted in a previous Red List assessment (Hawlitschek and Glaw 2011) The population from Mayotte has since been described as the new species P. stellata (Hawlitschek and Glaw 2012).

Hawlitschek et al. (2012) concluded that Dipsadoboa maculata, described with the uncertain provenance "Central America", is conspecific with Comoran Lycodryas sanctijohannis from Anjouan and Mayotte, and that this species is distinct from the form found on Grand Comoro and Mohéli. These authors therefore synonymized L. sanctijohannis within L. maculatus, and referred populations of "L. sanctijohannis" from Grand Comoro and Mohéli to the new species L. cococola.

Hawlitschek et al. (2012) concluded that Dipsadoboa maculata, described with the uncertain provenance "Central America", is conspecific with Comoran Lycodryas sanctijohannis from Anjouan and Mayotte, and that this species is distinct from the form found on Grand Comoro and Mohéli. These authors therefore synonymized L. sanctijohannis within L. maculatus, and referred populations of "L. sanctijohannis" from Grand Comoro and Mohéli to the new species L. cococola.
This species represents one of three separate colonization events of the Comoros archipelago by the genus Phelsuma, as inferred by Rocha et al. (2009).

This species, together with Phelsuma robertmertensi and P. v-nigra, represents one of three separate colonization events of the Comoros Archipelago by the genus Phelsuma, as inferred by Rocha et al. (2007, 2009). Originally, it was described as a subspecies of P. v-nigra (Meier 1984).

This species, together with Phelsuma pasteuri and P. v-nigra, represents one of three separate colonization events of the Comoros Archipelago by the genus Phelsuma, as inferred by Rocha et al. (2007, 2009).

Each island of the Union of the Comoros is inhabited by a separate subspecies, as described by Meier (1986): Phelsuma v-nigra v-nigra (Mohéli); P. v-nigra comoraegrandensis (Grand Comoro); and P. v-nigra anjouanensis (Anjouan). Phelsuma pasteuri (Mayotte) was also considered a subspecies of P. v-nigra by Meier (1986) and this concept was followed in an earlier Red List assessment of P. v-nigra (Ineich 2009). A molecular study by Rocha et al. (2007) found that P. pasteuri is more closely related to P. robertmertensi than to P. v-nigra, warranting its recognition as a distinct species.

A multivariate analysis of morphometric data by Berry (1978) demonstrated the distinctiveness of the endemic, allopatric taxon Kinosternon scorpioides abaxillare from the parapatric K. s. cruentatum. In addition, preliminary molecular sampling of the K. scorpioides complex by Iverson et al. (2013) suggested that K. s. abaxillare was more closely related to K. oaxacae than to K. s. cruentatum (or any other K. scorpioides). Given both the morphometric and molecular evidence, the latter authors followed Alvarez del Toro (1973, among many others) and suggested that K. abaxillare be recognized as a full species. Until more thorough geographic and molecular sampling is completed, following TTWG (2017) we treat the taxon here as a species.

A blindsnake resembling this species was collected on Mayotte in 2014, and referred to as Madatyphlops cf. comorensis by Augros and Hawlitschek (2019). It was subsequently described as the new species M. eudeleni by Hawlitschek et al. (2021).

This taxon is "almost certainly a species complex" (M. McCoy pers. comm. August 2012). A historical record from New Britain is likely to represent a different species, and records from New Guinea (Bauer and Henle 1994) are thought to represent misidentification. Genetic divergence is low between Lepidodactyus guppyi and the morphologically similar L. vanuatuensis, and range limits between these two taxa are unclear.
Specimens from the Huon Peninsula in the type series were found to represent the distinct species Lepidodactylus sacrolineatus by Kraus and Oliver (2020).

Kraus (2019) noted that this species' type locality has historically been misreported in the literature as the Vogelkop Peninsula, and that the correct locality given in the original description is Lake Sentani. This author also reports that an additional paratype from Mt. Nibo was intended based on correspondence prior to publication, but omitted apparently in error from the formal description.

As presently understood, and mapped here, Lepidodactylus novaeguineae probably represents three species - with populations from the Huon Peninsula almost certainly different - but there are no genetic data from close to type locality, and there is very little morphological variation in this group (F. Kraus and P. Oliver pers. comm. 2020). It is unclear to which of the lineages identified by Oliver et al. (2018) the name L novaeguineae refers.

An additional lineage from Waigeo is part of this species complex, but as the name L. novaeguineae is certainly not referable to this form this is not treated as part of this species in this assessment.

The taxonomic status of Lepidodactylus browni and its relationship to L. orientalis is being investigated (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2020). A population from Kamiali, which is genetically and ecologically divergent is no longer considered to belong to this species (P. Oliver pers. comm. 2020).

The validity of this species - which may have been introduced to Guadalcanal from elsewhere in the Pacific, although this is considered doubtful - is uncertain, and additional specimens are required in order to clarify its taxonomic status (M. McCoy pers. comm. August 2012). It closely resembles Lepidodactylus guppyi, from which it appears to differ only in the number of interorbital scales (a character which may be unreliable based on only a single specimen) (M. McCoy pers. comm. August 2012). This latter species is itself thought to be a species complex (M. McCoy pers. comm. August 2012).

authority: Ota, Fisher, Ineich, Case, Radtkey & Zug, 1998

taxonomicNotes: This taxon was referred to as a candidate species in a molecular phylogeny by Oliver et al. (2018).

authority: Karkkainen, Richards, Kraus, Tjaturadi, Krey & Oliver, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species is a member of the Lepidodactylus novaeguineae group and was originally reported as the candidate species Lepidodactylus sp. Salawati by Oliver et al. (2018).

This species was included within Lepidodactylus novaeguineae by Stubbs et al. (2017), and listed as the candidate species Lepidodactylus Boiaboiawaga in a subsequent molecular phylogeny (Oliver et al. 2018).

This species was originally referred to in the literature as a candidate species by Oliver et al. (2018). Specimens from the Huon Peninsula now assigned to this species were previously included in the type series of Lepidodactylus magnus (Kraus and Oliver 2020).

Honda et al. (2014) revised Japanese members of Goniurosaurus, previously considered either the full species G. kuroiwae, G. toyamai, G. yamashinae, G. orientalis and G. splendens, or a single taxon G. kuroiwae with five subspecies. These authors' results supported the recognition of two full species, G. splendens and G. kuroiwae, and they proposed treating G. orientalis, G. toyamai and G. yamashinae as subspecies of G. kuroiwae.

Further molecular research into this species complex is ongoing, and has confirmed that there are at least five species-level clades in the Ryukyus, corresponding to subspecies of G. kuroiwae recognized by Honda et al. (2014) plus G. splendens (H. Ota pers. comm. 2016). As a revision of this group is due to be submitted for publication shortly, this account adopts a traditional five-species treatment of this complex, while recognizing that both G. kuroiwae and G. orientalis as presently recognized may be further subdivided in the near future.

There are several localities in Mozambique (Mt. Namuli, Mt. Mabu) which were originally suspected to contain populations of Rhampholeon chapmanorum (Tilbury 2010). However, molecular phylogenetic analysis confirms that R. chapmanorum is endemic to remaining forest fragments on Malawi Hill, and the Mozambican localities are home to separate species of Rhampholeon (Branch et al. 2014).
Prior to its formal description this species was listed as Madatyphlops cf. comorensis in Augros and Hawlitschek (2019).

Günther (1888) described Boaedon mentalis based on a single specimen from “Damara Land”, but the type locality appears to be in error (see Hallermann et al. 2020). Most authors regarded it as a subspecies of B. fuliginosus and subsequently B. capensis (Bogert 1940; Rose 1950; Loveridge 1957; FitzSimons 1962, 1966; Buys and Buys 1983; Chippaux 2006). However, Vidal et al. (2008) showed that B. mentalis is a sister clade to a larger clade comprising B. fuliginosus, B. lineatus, B. olivaceus and B. capensis, supporting the revalidation of the taxon as a full species. Based on a recent molecular phylogeny supported by morphological differences, B. mentalis was reinstated as a full species and two distinct genetic clades were identified, one from southern Angola and northern Namibia, and the other from southern Namibia and north-western South Africa (Hallermann et al. 2020). Individuals in the south of the range have two different colour patterns, plain and striped morphs, and these appear to co-occur.

The recognised subspecies are marginata, sarda, and weissingeri. The subspecies weissingeri was elevated to species rank by Bour (1996), but it is frequently considered a to be subspecies of Testudo marginata. It is not even accorded subspecies status by some authors, but it was validated as a full species by Perala (2002a). In this account we include weissingeri within T. marginata, pending resolution of its taxonomic status.

There may be cryptic taxa within Boaedon capensis (Kelly et al. 2011, Hallermann et al. 2020), and the well-known ‘mentalis’ morphotype of the western arid region of the subcontinent (Branch 1998) was recently recognised as a full species (Hallermann et al. 2020). There is long-standing confusion between the ranges of B. capensis and B. fuliginosus. Boaedon fuliginosus was considered to be restricted to West Africa by Trape and Mediannikov (2016), although Hallerman et al. (2020) assign specimens from northeastern Angola to B. fuliginosus, and dark-coloured individuals from northern Zambia have also been referred to B. fuliginosus (Broadley et al. 2003, Pietersen et al. 2021). Hughes (1997) considered B. fuliginosus to occur sympatrically with B. capensis in East Africa and the Horn of Africa, a concept that has not been followed by Spawls et al. (2018), which refer all East African material to B. fuliginosus group. Until a full examination of existing material relating to the taxonomic status of this species, this assessment follows Hughes (1997) in the separation of B. capensis and B. fuliginosus.

Macroprotodon cucullatus is a recognized species complex (Carranza et al. 2004, Geniez 2018), whose members are difficult to distinguish morphologically (Geniez 2018). This author describes the systematics of this group as "controversial and still under discussion".

Populations of northern Algeria and Tunisia (and the introduced populations of Mallorca and Menorca) are recognized by some authors as the distinct species Macroprotodon mauritanicus (V. Pérez Mellado pers. comm.; Geniez 2018). Recent genetic data suggests that, if it is specifically distinct from M. cucullatus, M. mauritanicus is at least very close to it genetically, however Geniez (2018) cautions that this is based on research that only included one sequence referred to M. cucullatus.

Pending resolution of the systematics of this group, M. mauritanicus and M. cucullatus are treated here as conspecific, though the two species are currently maintained as valid by The Reptile Database (Uetz et al. 2021).
Was under Iguanidae.
